title: Velocity Guided Chirplet Transform: Utilizing Rotation Speed Information in Time-Frequency Analysis
authors: Jianshu Yin, Zhenyi Chen, Jin Chen, Qi Gao, Yanyang Zi
publish: IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
abstract: Time-frequency analysis (TFA) methods are significant in vibration signal analysis and fault diagnosis of mechanical equipment. However, large-scale mechanical equipment such as aerospace engine works under fast-varying rotation speed, leading to blurred time-frequency representation (TFR) from vibration signals for health monitoring. Meanwhile, it should be noticed that with the development of measuring techniques, the difficulty in acquiring rotation speed signals is decreasing, which should be considered to be utilized in TFA. In this study, a novel time-frequency analysis method referred to as velocity guided chirplet transform (VGCT) is proposed. This method directly uses rotation speed signal to describe the instantaneous frequency of the basis functions, and the basis functions are constructed by numerical integration instead of analytic expression to match the harmonic components in vibration signals, which can achieve the best performance in violent non-stationary signal analysis. After that, a numeric simulation was given to test its performance and computational efficiency. Finally, this paper gave two experiment cases, which showed its applicability and advantage in the field of health management for the aerospace equipment.

title: Wheelchair–Exoskeleton Hybrid Robot with Retractable Parallelogram Lift for Sit-to-Stand Support: Motion Analysis and Muscle Activity Assessment
authors: Ronnapee Chaichaowarat
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: This paper introduces a novel wheelchair–exoskeleton hybrid robot featuring a retractable parallelogram lift, developed to assist individuals with mobility impairments in transitioning between ambulation over uneven terrain and seated navigation on smooth surfaces. The system enables stable sit-to-stand and stand-to-sit transitions by maintaining ground contact through a wheelchair equipped with a front differential drive and rear omni wheels. In the upright position, the foldable lift retracts and repositions the driving platform vertically behind the user, removing obstructions during walking. The exoskeleton structure supports the lift’s weight, allowing full ground contact through the user’s feet for improved mobility. The parallelogram lift produces a curvilinear seat trajectory, with design parameters derived from kinematic analysis to closely emulate natural sit-to-stand motion. A dynamic model was formulated to estimate the seat reaction force and actuation requirements across various postures, incorporating hip and knee moments provided by the exoskeleton to enhance physical human–robot interaction. Preliminary experiments were conducted with four healthy participants performing sit-to-stand and stand-to-sit motions under three distinct support conditions: no support, lift support, and combined hip support. Consistent with the theoretical simulation, the seat reaction forces recorded from multiple participants confirmed that the lift mechanism supports up to approximately fifty percent of their body weight. Surface electromyography recorded from the quadriceps and hamstring muscles provides insight into the underlying muscle activation patterns and inter-muscular coordination during assisted movement. These results contribute to the understanding and optimization of human–robot interaction in hybrid assistive systems.

title: AFast-Transient Digital LDO with Asynchronous Coarse and Dual-Mode Fine Regulation Loops
authors: Ibrar Ali Wahla, Jongwoon Lee, Young-Ryul Yun, Muhammad Abrar Akram, In-Chul Hwang
publish: IEEE Open Journal of Power Electronics
abstract: This paper presents a fully-integrated all-digital low-dropout regulator (DLDO) for efficient fine-grained power delivery and management in system-on-chip (SoC) devices. The proposed DLDO is designed to drive both digital and analog load circuits, addressing their distinct requirements. An asynchronous coarse control ensures a fast load transient response to meet the dynamic demands of digital loads. In parallel, a fine-loop voltage stabilizer, equipped with dual-mode operation, enables ripple-free and precise voltage regulation essential for noise-sensitive analog loads. The dual-mode operation employs binary-shifting to quickly reach the target output voltage (VOUT), followed by unary-shifting for fine-tuned VOUT adjustment, thereby minimizing the output voltage ripples (VRIPP). Fabricated in a 65-nm CMOS process with an active area of 0.098 mm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>, the proposed DLDO operates with an input voltage (VDD) range of 0.6 V to 1.2 V and delivers a VOUT of 0.55 V to 1.15 V. Worst-case measurement results demonstrate the recovery time of ≤ 30 ns for a 109 mV voltage droop when a (0mA → 25mA) load current (ILOAD) is changed with an edge timing of 10 ns, achieving an overall figure-of-merit of 1.106 ns<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>. The proposed DLDO achieves the worst-case VRIPP of ≤ 2mV while driving a minimum ILOAD of 0.5 mA.

title: Solution Approaches for the Dynamic Naval Air Defense Planning Problem_supp4-3648686.mp4
authors: Caner Arslan
publish: N/A
abstract: The naval air defense planning (NADP) problem entails the defense of a naval fleet against aerial threats. This complex and dynamic problem requires real-time decision-making and adaptation to evolving warfare environment. While our previous work addressed the static NADP problem by proposing a mathematical model and heuristic solutions for sensor allocation, engagement scheduling, and ship routing, this study extends to the dynamic NADP problem. Unlike the static version, which assumes complete knowledge of future threats, the dynamic NADP problem requires continuous updates and real-time adjustments to decisions as new threats emerge and situational parameters change. We present modifications in the mathematical formulation, which is based on a mixed-integer nonlinear programming (MINLP) model, alongside a comprehensive simulation structure. We employ heuristic solution approaches that utilize a combination of a genetic algorithm, construction of an engagement graph to solve the shortest path problem, and dynamic programming (DP) techniques. Computational experiments are conducted to evaluate the effectiveness of these methods in addressing the dynamic NADP problem. The study also explores machine learning models for threat prioritization, offering innovative solutions to the challenges posed by dynamic naval air defense scenarios.

title: Thickness-Dependent Enhancement of Ferroelectric Properties in ${\text{HfZrO}_{x}}$ Devices by Bottom ${\text{TiO}_{2}}$ Interlayer
authors: Zhe Qu, Jiajie Yu, Zhenhai Li, Kangli Xu, Yongkai Liu, Hao Zhu, Jialin Meng, Qingqing Sun, David Wei Zhang, Tianyu Wang, Lin Chen
publish: IEEE Transactions on Electron Devices
abstract: Hafnium-based ferroelectric materials have broad application prospects. In this work, we successfully enhanced the ferroelectric properties of HfZrO x films by inserting TiO2 layer and expounded the effect of layer thickness on the film’s performance. By modulating the interface layer thickness, the best overall performance was achieved at a thickness of 0.5 nm. Compared to the pure HfZrO x films without interface layer, the remanent polarization increased by $17.46\mu $ C/cm2, and the fatigue characteristics improved by at least one order of magnitude. Storage tests were further performed on TiO2/HfZrO x sample with interlayer thickness of 0.5 nm. This work provides valuable insights for optimizing the performance of Hafnium oxide-based ferroelectric films for future applications.

title: An Automated, Scalable Machine Learning Model Inversion Assessment Pipeline
authors: Tyler Shumaker, Jessica Carpenter, David Saranchak, Nathaniel D. Bastian
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: Machine learning (ML) models have the potential to transform military battlefields, presenting a large external pressure to rapidly incorporate them into operational settings. However, it is well-established that these ML models are vulnerable to a number of adversarial attacks throughout the model deployment pipeline that threaten to negate battlefield advantage. One broad category is privacy attacks (such as model inversion) where an adversary can reverse engineer information from the model, such as the sensitive data used in its training. The ability to quantify the risk of model inversion attacks (MIAs) is not well studied, and there is a lack of automated developmental test and evaluation (DT&E) tools and metrics to quantify the effectiveness of privacy loss of the MIA. The current DT&E process is difficult because ML model inversions can be hard for a human to interpret, subjective when they are interpretable, and difficult to quantify in terms of inversion quality. Additionally, scaling the DT&E process is challenging due to many ML model architectures and data modalities that need to be assessed. In this work, we present a novel DT&E tool that quantifies the risk of data privacy loss from MIAs and introduces four adversarial risk dimensions to quantify privacy loss. Our DT&E pipeline combines inversion with vision language models (VLMs) to improve effectiveness while enabling scalable analysis. We demonstrate effectiveness using multiple MIA techniques and VLMs configured for zero-shot classification and image captioning. We benchmark the pipeline using several state-of-the-art MIAs in the computer vision domain with an image classification task that is typical in military applications. In general, our innovative pipeline extends the current model inversion DT&E capabilities by improving the effectiveness and scalability of the privacy loss analysis in an automated fashion. With it, a clearer understanding of the risk to military ML-enabled capabilities can be obtained.

title: A Survey on Finger Vein Authentication System: A Secure Biometric Identification Method
authors: J. Aarthy Suganthi Kani, Varshini P, Supriya B, Prajwal H R, Nandan Gowda N
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: Uniqueness, liveness, and counterfeiting resistance by finger vein authentication have rendered it a secure and reliable biometric modality. Finger vein patterns, unlike external features such as fingerprints or face, are subcutaneous, i.e., not visible to the naked eye and extremely difficult to replicate. Image capture, preprocessing, vein enhancement, feature extraction, template creation, and matching are all typical elements of an average system. In different imaging conditions, preprocessing methods like adaptive Wiener filtering, homomorphic unshading, and enhancement of vesselness increase visibility a lot. From deep models such as Siamese networks to graph anatomical analysis and texture features such as Local Binary Patterns (LBP) and Gray-Level Co-occurrence Matrix (GLCM), feature extraction methods address many issues of noise, illumination, and orientation. Hybrid methods that blend handcrafted with deep features for increased robustness are the focus of recent literature. These developments show finger vein verification's promise in safe usages such as financial, medicine, and immigration control.

title: HD2FBCN: Hybrid Distributed Dual Deep Learning Model for Multiclass Object Classification
authors: M Kiran Kumar Goud, Balusu Nandini
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: Object classification refers to the identification, localization, and categorization of several objects present within a single image. The challenges faced using the traditional object classification approaches include lower classification accuracy, increased computational complexity, poor scalability, and additional resource requirements. To overcome such drawbacks, the research proposes the Hybrid Distributed attention-enabled Dual learning assisted Fight-Or-Free optimized deep network (HD2FBCN) model. Specifically, the Hybrid Distributed Attention (HyDA) mechanism boosts the object classification performance by simultaneously capturing the cross-dimensional complex and informative features. The dual learning strategy simulates faster classification and improves the scalability by diminishing the data scarcity and catastrophic forgetting issues. Moreover, the Structural Transformer Shape (STS) descriptor emphasizes the extraction of distinct features and ensures accurate object classification. Nevertheless, finetuning the model parameters with the Fight-Or-Free Optimization algorithm improves the robustness of the model against premature convergence and results in efficient object classification. Experimental validation shows that the HD2FBCN attains superior object classification performance with a reduced False Omission Rate of 0.013, and Mean Squared Error of 3.53, and a higher Negative Predictive Value of 0.98, for the 9 K-Folds using the COCO dataset.

title: Geo-Potential based Smart Land Analyzer
authors: Ragavarthini. V, Kirthick Balaji SS, Shreyaas S, Kiransuryakumar K, Tirumala Naidu.G
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: Evaluating land for agricultural purposes and forecasting energy output potential for renewable energy sources are important goals of land use planning and decision making for more efficient utilization of resources for greater economic returns. This article describes the design and development of a web-based Smart Land Potential Analyzer, that employs a plug and play model within the Django framework, that integrates weather forecasting, soil properties and analysis, the energy generation potential and energy generation estimates, and crop recommendations based on local properties, weather conditions and potential energy estimates. Our system implements the Open-Meteo API in which an estimate for a year long hourly weather forecast, is capable that can be retrieved from. Additionally, the SoilGrids API, assesses soil properties, and has access to several existing agricultural crop databases for agricultural intelligence usage. In terms of energy potential, we have determined the energy potential for both solar and wind, whilst making the discourse about crop selection properties locally. The application also incorporates satellite imagery, interactive dashboards for visualization of data, and report generating options to export reports of analysis. The results of the assessment highlight that the system proposed is feasible, and useful for farmers, investors, and decision makers when exploring land use opportunities.

title: Chrono-Analytics in Healthcare: Inferring Recovery Archetypes from Temporal Data
authors: S. Gomathi, K. Anita Davamani, Meena Kumari Bugatha N, M. Amanullah, V. Janakiraman, Chandrasekaran B
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: Healthcare recovery is a dynamic process, which demands the ongoing monitoring and analysis of the temporal patient data to optimize interventions and rehabilitation procedures. This paper suggests a hybrid chrono-analytics model that combines K-Means clustering and time-series forecasting (ARIMA/LSTM) to discover recovery patterns and forecast further patient development. The temporal sequences of all significant clinical indicators were created using the Stroke Prediction Dataset that is publicly available, and thus, it is possible to model the characteristics of both the static and dynamic recovery. K-Means clustering was used to find three unique recovery archetypes, namely: the rapid, gradual, and delayed/relapsing recovery which was validated using the Adjusted Rand Index (ARI). LMST predictions of future conditions of recovery showed the accurate prediction of future conditions with a higher degree of performance compared to ARIMA, which was mainly unsuccessful in crossing linear lines. The personal patient predictions were used to show that the framework can provide individual predictions on recovery, and the common recovery patterns were identified at the cluster level. The combination approach will fill the gap between descriptive analytics and predictive modelling to provide a new tool of personalized and population-based healthcare decision-making. Strengthen health systems and emergency preparedness.In general, the paper demonstrates how the analysis of temporal data and machine learning may be used to improve patient recovery monitoring and clinical intervention optimization.

title: Performance Evaluation of Handcrafted Feature Extraction Techniques using Bayes Net Classifier for Skin Disease Image Classification
authors: Ayyappan G, Senthil K
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: The medical field requires increased reliance on automated skin disease diagnosis through image classification because both dermatological disorders are more prevalent and patients require accessible clinical help. This research examines how Bayes Net performs as a classification system by using six different handcraft descriptor techniques when analyzing high-resolution dermatological images. The analysis incorporates six particular feature descriptors which are PHOGF (Pyramid Histogram of Oriented Gradients), SCHF (Simple Color Histogram Filter), Gabor Filter, JPEG Coefficient Filter (JPEGCF), FCTH (Fuzzy Color and Texture Histogram Filter), and FOHF (Fuzzy Opponent Histogram Filter). The research utilized publicly available images from a ten-disordered skin diseases collection for the experiments. The evaluation of classifiers used Accuracy, Precision, Recall together with ROC (Receiver Operating Characteristic) and PRC (Precision-Recall Curve) and computational time measurement metrics. A combination of Gabor Filter with Bayes Net produced the most effective result with an accuracy rate of 97.59% alongside 0.98 precision and recall and 0.99 ROC and PRC scores at a computation time of 0.02 seconds. PHOGF+Bayes Net generated 95.71% accuracy while SCHF+Bayes Net produced 95.49% accuracy but the extended computational time reached 33.63 seconds. The combination of JPEGCF with Bayes Net allowed an efficient execution time to produce 92.83% accuracy results. This research confirms that the combination between custom-designed features and the probabilistic Bayes Net classifier leads to highly precise solutions that maintain rapid computational effectiveness for skin disease diagnosis systems.

title: Decentralized Model-Distributed Inference
authors: Alp Berke Ardic, Matthew Dwyer, Erdem Koyuncu
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: We introduce and study the problem of decentralized model distribution, where a deep neural network is partitioned into fixed blocks of layers, and the assignment of these blocks to networking nodes must be carried out without centralized coordination. This problem naturally arises in edge and fog networks, where nodes can only communicate and compute locally. We show that the decentralized layer assignment task is equivalent to a constrained decentralized graph coloring problem, where each node begins with an arbitrary color representing its initial layer assignment and updates its color through interactions with neighbors. We introduce a distributed color-switching algorithm that guarantees convergence to a valid assignment, where each layer block is uniquely assigned to a node. Once this initialization phase is complete, inference can be initiated from any node in the network. To evaluate the effectiveness of an assignment, we define a hop-based inference cost that captures the number of communication steps required to complete a forward pass. Our algorithm supports a decentralized dynamic programming routing algorithm using lightweight tables and enables efficient inference even in complex network topologies. Extensive simulations confirm that the proposed approach yields low-cost, low-conflict decentralized inference across a range of realistic network conditions.

title: Demo: Energy Neutral Backscatter Device Utilizing High Performance Commercial Components
authors: Kalle Koskinen, Jingyi Liao, Kalle Ruttik, Riku Jäntti
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on 6G Networking (6GNet)
abstract: This demonstration presents an energy-autonomous ambient backscatter device that achieves full operational selfsufficiency by harvesting energy from ambient light. Unlike the 3GPP-defined Ambient Internet of Things (A-IoT) concept, which relies on RF-based energy harvesting and continuouswave illumination, our setup exploits existing LTE downlink signals as the communication carrier and leverages the user equipment (UE) channel estimator as the backscatter receiver. The prototype integrates a high-performance microcontroller unit (MCU) capable of executing complex signal processing tasks while maintaining energy neutrality through photovoltaic energy harvesting. Real-time power measurements demonstrate less than <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$30 \mu \mathrm{W}$</tex> consumption for communication, and the energy harvested suffices for continuous operation. This proof-of-concept validates the feasibility of light-powered, infrastructure-compatible ambient backscatter communication, representing a complementary and sustainable direction for 6 G A-IoT systems.

title: Kolmogorov–Arnold Networks for Multimodal Feature Fusion and mmWave Beam Prediction
authors: Saba M. Hosseini, Amirhossein Safari, Nazanin Rahnavard
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: Optimal beam alignment in dynamic mmWave environments remains a key challenge. Integrated sensing and communication attempts to address this challenge leveraging heterogeneous sensor data. We propose a deep learning framework for the mmWave beam prediction (BP) based on Kolmogorov–Arnold Networks (KANs), a recently proposed alternative to Multi-Layer Perceptrons (MLPs) that replaces fixed node-wise activations with learnable spline-based functions on network edges. Our architecture fuses GPS, LiDAR, and vision modalities in a real-world vehicle-to-infrastructure scenario through KAN-based late fusion. We use convolutional neural networks and Gated Recurrent Units for spatial and temporal feature extraction before passing the features to KAN-based heads. We evaluate the models in regression and classification settings for BP. Extensive experiments demonstrate that KAN-based models outperform MLP-based models cross single-and multi-modal setups, yielding significant improvements in beam index prediction accuracy. These results highlight the effectiveness of KANs for robust BP in dynamic wireless environments.

title: Enhancing Criminal Investigations through an AI-based Photographic Memory for CGI Detection
authors: Rohit Kumar Roy, Nitin Pandey, Samarpita Ghatak, Raman Sharma
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: The emergence of advanced computer-generated imagery (CGI) tools and generative AI technologies is posing new problems in digital forensics, particularly in separating synthetic imagery from authentic materials in legal cases. This study describes a system called AI-PMF (AI-Based Photographic Memory Framework) which attempts to replicate the cognitive technology of human memory for detecting and retrieving digitally generated materials. The system proposed integrates CNN-focused memory retrieval, contextual retrieval with transformers, and memory retrieval augmentation to identify and cross-reference images automatically. This integrates all three types of memory retrieval proposed in the system. To further the system's generalization ability, training and testing used the system's various components and the four public datasets, DFDC, StyleGAN, FFHQ, and CUISD, which encompass a broad range of real and synthetic imagery. The system's performance is empirically validated with a score of 94% on classification accuracy, 0.92 on F1 score, 0.97 on the area under the receiver operating characteristic curve (AUC-ROC), and 0.86 on retrieval precision (mAP@10), all of which demonstrate considerable improvement on classification and retrieval compared to baseline deep learning models, EfficientNet and Vision Transformer. Performance results indicate the AI-PMF can be utilized in forensic analysis as it reliably identifies CGI manipulations and retrieves appropriate evidence instances in a visually similar manner. This research establishes a foundation for law enforcement agencies integrated AI systems in criminal investigations where AI can be used reliably and cross-validated with visual evidence for integrated cross-digital evidence analysis and trust-augmented AI in crime.

title: Application of Post-Quantum Cryptography in IoT Networks
authors: Tomasz Styn, Michał Pitera, Mateusz Okoń, Patryk Harasik, Marcin Niemiec
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: The advent of powerful quantum computing poses significant risks to the security of cryptographic systems, as we know them today. At the same time, the continuous expansion of the already widespread IoT ecosystem highlights the need to secure both the devices it comprises and the communication between them. This paper describes the process of implementing ML-KEM-512 (Kyber) – a post-quantum key encapsulation mechanism – in the ZigBee protocol. Furthermore, an encryption layer utilizing AES with a 256-bit key is introduced in a way that is compatible with existing infrastructure, as that is the key to rapid and widespread adoption among consumers and businesses. Through the use of a demonstrative IoT network based on ZigBee, efficiency measurements were taken before and after implementing the proposed solution, and were analyzed in order to judge its viability. Transmission time fluctuations were found likely to be connected with hardware functionality, rather than network retransmissions, as was initially theorized. The security level of the paper’s proposed solution was evaluated in the context of the existing standard.

title: Federated Learning for MCS Selection in 5G Sidelink MANETs
authors: Jamie Sloop, Evan Allen, Evar Jones, Charles E. Thornton, Lingjia Liu, Fred Templin, Daniel J. Jakubisin
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: 5G Sidelink protocols pose unique challenges in mobile ad hoc networks (MANETs) due to dynamic topology, decentralization, bandwidth and energy constraints, and scalability. Moreover, 5G Sidelink operated in a fully ‘out-of-coverage’ scenario does not have the benefit of a base station for centralized resource control. We explore the use of federated learning to address some of these challenges in 5G-based MANET communication. We apply federated learning to modulation and coding scheme (MCS) selection, which involves balancing throughput and reliability. In highly-dynamic MANETs, the ability to intelligently select an appropriate MCS becomes critical. Federated learning offers a solution by enabling network devices to share learned information instead of learning in isolation. This collaborative approach allows for faster and more informed decision-making. We implement two federated learning-based MCS selection models, which are evaluated using the CORE and EMANE emulation tools. The first uses signal-to-interference-plus-noise ratio (SINR) data to predict the optimal MCS across the network, while the second adjusts algorithm parameters over time using success rate data from all nodes. Our results show that federated learning is able to outperform a baseline of local SINR lookup tables. Based on these results, we propose future steps to practically investigate the effectiveness of federated learning in MANETs.

title: NeTIF: Network Traffic to Image Features for Robust Intrusion Detection
authors: Stephen Villanueva, Abu Saleh Md Tayeen, Qixu Gong, Satyajayant Misra, Aden Dogar, Huiping Cao, Jiefei Liu, Pratyay Kumar, Jayashree Harikumar
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: With the rapid increase in cyber attacks, Machine Learning (ML)-based Network Intrusion Detection Systems (NIDS) are essential for safeguarding computer network security. Most ML-based NIDS rely on either flow-based or packet-based network traffic feature representations. However, flow-based methods may overlook characteristics in individual packets and fail to detect certain attacks. Meanwhile, packet-based methods primarily capture the malicious payload of individual packets, often missing the abnormal correlations between multiple packets, rendering them ineffective against certain types of attacks. To overcome these limitations, we propose a Network Traffic to Image Features (NeTIF)-based Intrusion Detection System (IDS). NeTIF consists of two steps. The first step is a novel data transformation method that derives image representations of network flows from raw network packets. The second step is a Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) that automatically learns feature representations and patterns for detecting anomalous network flows. Our extensive experimental results on two public datasets demonstrate that our NeTIF-based IDS achieves a higher detection rate compared to traditional IDS approaches. Furthermore, our method’s superior performance can be easily explained through plotting intermediate features. This contributes to the model usability and interpretability, which is an increasingly critical aspect in cybersecurity applications.

title: A Review on Smart Traffic Light Management and Energy Optimization with Artificial Intelligence(AI) enabled Programmable Logic Controller(PLC) using Internet of Things(IoT)
authors: A. Manonmani, Ranjith Kumar K, Sugantha Kumar M, Sham Kumar G
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: Urbanization has aggravated issues surrounding traffic congestion, energy distribution, and emergency management in present-day urban cities. Conventional traffic systems rely on static timers for functioning and hence present inefficacies, while present energy distribution systems often fail to handle dynamic demand variations and renewable energy integration. In this project, an advanced PLC-based intelligent smart city system is proposed that integrates adaptive traffic management with IoT-based energy load management and AI-based emergency response systems. Traffic lights are controlled variably using infrared sensors, ESP32-CAM vehicle detection systems with ATmega328 processing units integrated with a real-time clock module to facilitate accurate scheduling. At the same time, energy management employs ESP8266 with voltage and current sensors to ensure optimized power allocation among solar panels, storage batteries, and the electrical supply grid with DC-DC converters. An artificial intelligence module predicts congestion and emergency occurrences to enable priority-based allocation of traffic resources as well as energy resources. Aiming to reduce congestion levels, waste energy reduction, and emergency responsiveness improvement to offer a scalable, sustainable, and adaptable infrastructure for future urban city smart cities development.

title: Survey on Development of UDS Diagnostic Tester for ECU Communication with Data Logging Support
authors: Subashini J, Sandhya Devi R S, Ashrita A, Kiruba S, Sugirtha S M
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: Electric vehicles are more rapidly growing in order to replace Internal Combustion Engines. For a vehicle to work efficiently, proper diagnostic tools are required. Normal 2-wheeler ICE’s have both OEM and General OBD scanners to diagnose fault in vehicles. However, the 2- wheelers of EV have only company specified OEM scanner; there is no generic OBD scanner. This paper represents a study on diagnostic frameworks of EVs On-Board Diagnostics (OBD-II), Unified Diagnostic Services (UDS), and Data logging functionality. This literature highlights the integration of OBD-II and UDS for developing EV diagnostic and monitoring systems.

title: A 12-b 1-GS/s Pipelined-SAR ADC With a Hybrid Parallel Timing Scheme and PVT-Robust Ring-Amp
authors: Junhui Guo, Yunchu Li
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Integrated Circuits and Microsystems (ICICM)
abstract: This paper presents a 12-b 1GS/s single-channel pipelined successive approximation register (SAR) analog-to-digital converter (ADC), designed in a $\mathbf{2 8}-\mathbf{n m}$ CMOS process. In this paper, a hybrid parallel timing scheme is introduced. Firstly, the passive residue transfer technique is employed to enable parallel operation of the RA and first stage SAR conversions, thereby lessening the timing burden of the $1^{\text {st }}$-satge. In addition, the $2^{\text {nd }}$-stage SAR ADC employs partially parallel conversion to alleviate the timing constraints due to the additional CDAC reset clock and charge-sharing clock introduced by the passive residue transfer. A fully differential ring amplifier is adopted. To improve the process, voltage, and temperature (PVT) robustness of the ring amplifier, a Class-AB biasing scheme is used. The results reveal that the 12-b 1-GS/s ADC achieves 64.8 dB SNDR and 78.1 dB SFDR with the Nyquist input and consumes 26.6 mW at 0.9 V supply. This simulated performance is equivalent to Walden and Schreier figure-of-merit (FoM) of $\mathbf{1 8. 7 5 ~ f J}$ /conversion-step and 168.8 dB, respectively.

title: Experimental Demonstration of Robust Distributed Wireless Clock Synchronization
authors: Kumar Sai Bondada, Hiten Kothari, Yibin Liang, Daniel J. Jakubisin, R. Michael Buehrer
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: Distributed wireless clock synchronization aligns the clocks of distributed transceivers wirelessly to support joint transmission and reception techniques. It allows for transceiver mobility and operates independently of GPS. A recently explored method involves synchronizing distributed transceivers using a two-tone waveform, in which the tones are separated in frequency by a clock (frequency) reference signal. Prior research has demonstrated frequency accuracy better than 1 Hz. However, this approach remains vulnerable to both intentional and unintentional interference. In this demonstration, we present a robust frequency-hopped two-tone waveform that enables transceivers to extract the reference signal for clock synchronization.

title: Design of a Two-Stage Fully Differential Operational Amplifier for High-Resolution Sigma Delta ADCs
authors: Zhan Shi, Zenghao Zhu, Yan Zhao, Franco Maloberti
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Integrated Circuits and Microsystems (ICICM)
abstract: High-resolution sigma-delta analog-to-digital converters (ADCs) demand an operational amplifier in the first integrator to have stringent performances, such as a high gain $(\gt100 \mathrm{~dB})$, a large gain-bandwidth product, a fast slew rate, and a wide output swing. To meet these demands, a two-stage fully differential operational amplifier was designed in a SMIC $0.13 \mu \mathrm{~m}$ CMOS process. The first stage employed an improved folded-cascode amplifier to generate common-mode feedback and extend the output range of the second stage. The second stage utilized a dynamic-biasing cascode amplifier to enhance both gain and slew rate further. Additionally, a switched capacitor common-mode feedback circuit was implemented to synchronize with the integrator timing. Simulation results show that the amplifier achieves a DC gain of $\mathbf{1 2 2 ~ d B}$, a gain-bandwidth product of $\mathbf{8 3}$ MHz, and a maximum negative slew rate of $53 \mathrm{~V} / \mu \mathrm{s}$ with a capacitive load of 15 pF. Besides, the output common-mode voltage is stable at half the supply voltage.

title: FLASH: Federated Learning Across Simultaneous Heterogeneities
authors: Xiangyu Chang, Sk Miraj Ahmed, Srikanth V. Krishnamurthy, Basak Guler, Ananthram Swami, Samet Oymak, Amit K. Roy-Chowdhury
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: The key premise of federated learning (FL) is to train ML models across a diverse set of data-owners (clients), without exchanging local data. An overarching challenge to this date is client heterogeneity, which may arise not only from variations in data distribution, but also in data quality, as well as compute/communication latency. An integrated view of these diverse and concurrent sources of heterogeneity is critical; for instance, low-latency clients may have poor data quality, and vice versa. In this work, we propose FLASH (Federated Learning Across Simultaneous Heterogeneities), a lightweight and flexible client selection algorithm that outperforms state-of-the-art FL frameworks under extensive sources of heterogeneity, by trading-off the statistical information associated with the client’s data quality, data distribution, and latency. FLASH is the first method, to our knowledge, for handling all these heterogeneities in a unified manner. To do so, FLASH models the learning dynamics through contextual multi-armed bandits (CMAB) and dynamically selects the most promising clients. Through extensive experiments, we demonstrate that FLASH achieves substantial and consistent improvements over state-of-the-art baselines—as much as 10% in absolute accuracy—thanks to its unified approach. Importantly, FLASH also outperforms federated aggregation methods that are designed to handle highly heterogeneous settings and even enjoys a performance boost when integrated with them.

title: Determination of the Number of Zeros of Quasi-Polynomials via Function Curves
authors: Honghai Wang
publish: IEEE/CAA Journal of Automatica Sinica
abstract: Dear Editor, The distribution of eigenvalues, i.e., the zeros of the characteristic functions of linear time-invariant (LTI) systems, is of great significance for analyzing and synthesizing the performance of these systems. The research on the distribution of eigenvalues mainly focuses on the determination of the number of zeros of polynomials or quasi-polynomials in a fixed region of the entire complex plane, where the determination of the distribution of zeros of quasi-polynomials has always been a challenging issue [1], [2]. Recently, several results on the determination of the number of zeros of a class of quasi-polynomials in the open right-half complex plane were derived in [3], where the quasi-polynomials can be neutral type with complex (real) coefficients.

title: Spatio-temporal Analysis of Vegetation Stress using Serverless Approach in Precision agriculture
authors: Pritish Patil, Shraddha Thorbole, Vinay Basargekar, Saurabh Rai
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: Modern agriculture faces increasing challenges in sustaining productivity due to environmental pressures and limited resources. Traditional crop monitoring, relying on manual observations, often detects stress factors, such as drought, nutrient deficiency, or pest damage, only after significant yield losses have occurred, leading to inefficient resource utilization. To transition from reactive to proactive management, farmers need stress detection systems that can identify early warning signals before they worsen. However, interpreting satellite imagery and Normalized Difference Vegetation Index (NDVI) data is technically advanced and often inaccessible to farmers. This paper proposes AgriStream platform suggesting a serverless, cloud-based solution that leverages Sentinel-2 imagery, NDVI computation, and AWS automation for near-real-time vegetation stress detection. The system translates complex geospatial datasets into understandable, implementable insights without requiring specialized infrastructure or expertise. This enables early detection of stress conditions, allowing targeted interventions such as optimized irrigation and fertilization. By empowering farmers with timely, accurate stress monitoring, AgriStream aims to minimize losses, improve resource efficiency, and enhance crop resilience, establishing a scalable solution that supports sustainable agricultural practices.

title: WeatherViT: A Vision Transformer-based End-to-End Framework for Multi-Class Weather Phenomenon Classification
authors: S. Kalpana, K.V. Kanimozhi
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: Accurate weather image classification plays a critical role in intelligent environmental monitoring and climate informatics. Traditional convolutional models often rely heavily on handcrafted features or limited receptive fields, which constrain their ability to generalize across diverse atmospheric patterns. This work introduces WeatherViT, a Vision Transformer (ViT-B/16)–based architecture designed to perform end-to-end classification of weather images. The proposed system leverages transformer-based attention mechanisms to capture both global and local visual dependencies, enabling more robust feature extraction. Two publicly available weather datasets were combined to form a comprehensive corpus of 14,561 labeled images across 11 weather conditions, including fog, frost, rain, and lightning. Data imbalance was addressed using an inverse-frequency weighted sampling strategy, while data augmentation was applied to enhance diversity. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed model achieved a validation accuracy of 95.88%, outperforming single-dataset and augmentation-only baselines. The findings confirm that dataset merging, weighted sampling, and transformer-based architectures significantly improve classification robustness in complex atmospheric scenes. The proposed framework offers a scalable foundation for automated meteorological perception systems.

title: Environment Aware Secure Key Derivation via RF Sensing and ISAC in 5G/6G Systems
authors: Robert Zakrzewski, Mark A. Beach
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: As wireless networks evolve toward 5G and 6G, securing communications in dense, dynamic, and potentially adversarial environments becomes increasingly critical. Traditional cryptographic security, relying on symmetric or asymmetric key exchanges at higher layers or pre-provisioning, imposes significant operational complexity—especially in decentralized private networks and tactical deployments where infrastructure is limited and exposure to interception or cryptanalysis is high.This work introduces an environment-aware cryptographic key derivation method that utilizes 5G NR waveforms and Integrated Sensing and Communication (ISAC) principles, accompanied by updates to the security frameworks in 5G and next-generation 6G networks. It exploits radio channel reciprocity to extract highly correlated features observable only by legitimate transceivers, while inherently excluding spatially separated eavesdroppers.Our system derives shared secret keys directly from Channel State Information (CSI), achieving high-entropy keys with a 100% agreement rate and a high key generation rate between legitimate nodes. We demonstrate its robustness using software-defined radios operating in the 5G FR1 band, across diverse environments, while constraining the amount of publicly accessible information available to potential eavesdroppers.By embedding geographical awareness, this approach provides a physically secure key generation method, making it well-suited for 5G/6G systems, private networks, and ultra-massive Machine-Type Communication (umMTC) scenarios. The results highlight the potential of physical layer security for future wireless encryption frameworks with design considerations to maximize security and limit eavesdropping feasibility.

title: MAPPO for Edge Server Monitoring
authors: Samuel Chamoun, Christian McDowell, Robin Buchanan, Kevin Chan, Eric Graves, Yin Sun
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: In this paper, we consider a goal-oriented communication problem for edge server monitoring, where jobs arrive intermittently at multiple dispatchers and must be assigned to shared edge servers with finite queues and time-varying availability. Accurate knowledge of server status is critical for sustaining high throughput, yet remains challenging under dynamic workloads and partial observability. To address this challenge, each dispatcher maintains server knowledge through two complementary mechanisms: (i) active status queries that provide instantaneous updates at a communication cost, and (ii) job execution feedback that reveals server conditions upon successful or failed job completion. We formulate a cooperative multi-agent distributed decision-making problem in which dispatchers jointly optimize query scheduling to balance throughput against communication overhead. To solve this problem, we propose a Multi-Agent Proximal Policy Optimization (MAPPO)-based algorithm that leverages centralized training with de-centralized execution (CTDE) to learn distributed query-and-dispatch policies under partial and stale observations. Experiments show that MAPPO achieves superior throughput-cost tradeoffs and significantly outperforms baseline strategies across varying query costs, job arrival rates, and dispatchers.
