title: Autonomous Agentic AI for Clinical Workflow Orchestration: Self-Managing Healthcare Operations
authors: Arjun Warrier, Abhilash K S
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: Healthcare operations are inherently complex, involving dynamic coordination across emergency triage, diagnostics, surgery, and discharge processes. Traditional orchestration methods such as manual scheduling, static bed boards, and siloed communication struggle to manage this complexity, often resulting in delayed interventions, inefficiencies, and suboptimal resource utilization, especially during high-acuity surges or emergencies. Agentic Artificial Intelligence (AI) introduces a transformative paradigm by embedding autonomy, reasoning, and negotiation capabilities into intelligent digital agents that perceive, learn, and act within clinical workflows. Unlike conventional AI systems that rely on predefined rules or static predictions, agentic AI employs multi-agent reinforcement learning (MARL) to enable decentralized decision-making, adaptive resource allocation, and cooperative policy optimization across interconnected hospital systems. This study presents an autonomous agentic AI framework for clinical workflow orchestration, integrating agents for triage, bed management, laboratory, imaging, transport, and discharge operations. Using HL7 Fast Healthcare Interoperability Resources (FHIR) and DICOM standards, agents exchange real-time information while adhering to governance and safety protocols aligned with the NIST AI Risk Management Framework and the EU AI Act. The architecture further incorporates three core design elements: (i) inter-hospital communication for mutual-aid and load sharing, (ii) decentralized ambulance routing that rebalances transport in real time based on dynamic capacity and patient acuity, and (iii) distributed crisis-management protocols for maintaining operational equilibrium during mass-casualty events. Evaluation through digital-twin simulations and shadow-mode deployments demonstrated substantial operational gains, including 60% faster ambulance response, 38% shorter door-to-clinician intervals, and 22% higher operating room throughput. These results confirm that agentic AI transforms reactive, human-initiated workflows into proactive, self-governing systems, enhancing responsiveness, equity, and resilience across healthcare networks.

title: A Comparative Analysis of Deep Learning Methods for Alzheimer's Disease Diagnosis
authors: P. Muthukumar, Valantina Stephen, T Baldwin Immanuel
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: Alzheimer’s Disease is the primary cause of dementia, characterised by memorial loss and impaired cognitive abilities. Early detection of this disease is required for accurate treatment. Although manually detecting this disease is challenging and time-consuming. Hence, an automated classification system is needed to perform this task, and scientists have analysed the proficiency of utilising Artificial Intelligence (AI), especially machine learning (ML) and deep learning (DL) models to deal with these difficulties. This system offers a detailed study on the detection and classification of this disease using a hybrid Vision Transformer (ViT) and Gate Recurrent Unit (GRU) deep learning model. This model is developed to enhance the classification rate and reduce computational cost by minimizing the parameter count. This study aims to analyse how this model improves the accuracy of classification. The model is trained with an Alzheimer’s MRI dataset from Kaggle and classifies four classes of this disease with a highest accuracy of 93.3%.

title: Formal Verification of Autonomous Cyber Defense for Abstraction of Critical Network Scenarios
authors: Samy Meziane, Laurin Holz, Tobias Hürten, Johannes Loevenich, Thies Möhlenhof, Roberto Rigolin F Lopes
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: Autonomous Cyber Defense (ACD) systems require formal guarantees to ensure their reliability and effectiveness in protecting critical network infrastructures. This paper presents a formal verification approach for an abstraction of the Cyber Autonomy Gym for Experimentation (CAGE) Challenge 4 cybersecurity scenario using probabilistic model checking with Probabilistic Symbolic Model Checker (PRISM). We develop a comprehensive multi-zone enterprise network model that captures red-team attack strategies, cross-zone infiltration, and defensive mechanisms. Due to computational complexity and state explosion challenges, we implement a curriculum learning approach, starting with red-only agent models to understand attack behaviors before progressing to adversarial blue-red scenarios. Our methodology aims to prove the feasibility of formal verification for autonomous cyber defense validation, providing probabilistic guarantees for network security properties and establishing a foundation for future multi-agent formal verification frameworks. Our results demonstrate over eight selected scenarios that near-optimal blue policies achieve perfect service degradation prevention while revealing fundamental scalability limits with state spaces growing exponentially from a single-zone model to complete multi-zone scenarios.

title: Home Energy Management System using Adaptive Giant Trevally Optimizer for Enhancing User Comfort
authors: Jarin T, Priya Jose, Shyjith M B, Jilsy A J, Joyel P R, Jyotsna E
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: Hydrogen is important in the transformation toward clean and sustainable energy systems. Efficient energy management in smart homes (SH) is important for achieving minimized electricity cost, better user comfort, and sustainable energy utilization. As SH technologies are evolving, optimizing energy usage has become an essential in reducing costs, improving efficiency, and maintaining user comfort. This work presents an Adaptive Giant Trevally Optimizer (AGTO) based home energy management system (HEMS) that optimizes appliance scheduling on the basis of real time pricing (RTP) models. The AGTO algorithm balances exploration and exploitation by fine-tuned control parameters. Compared to traditional metaheuristic methods, AGTO shows better convergence speed and robustness in avoiding local optima. The proposed AGTO minimizes peak-to-average ratio (PAR), reduces overall cost of electricity, and enhances user comfort by transferring loads from peak to off-peak hours. Simulation outcomes on several residential cases show that AGTO attained approximately 75% cost reduction and 25-61% PAR improvement over other approaches. These outcomes validate AGTO as a robust optimization approach for real-time HEMS and contribute to supportable and cost-efficient energy systems.

title: A Review on Multimodal Emotion Recognition Security: Evasion Attacks on Teacher-Leading Architectures
authors: Chilato Chilato, Yu Gu, Zheng Yan, Rui Zhang, Atif Hussain
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conferences on Internet of Things (iThings) IEEE Green Computing &amp; Communications (GreenCom) IEEE Cyber, Physical &amp; Social Computing (CPSCom) and IEEE Smart Data (SmartData) and IEEE Congress on Cybermatics (Cybermatics)
abstract: Multimodal Emotion Recognition (MER) systems have gained significant attention for their ability to integrate text, audio, and visual modalities to improve emotion classification accuracy. However, the security vulnerabilities of these systems, particularly evasion attacks that manipulate inputs to degrade performance, remain underexplored. This paper investigates the security risks associated with Teacher-Leading multimodal Architectures, where a dominant modality (e.g., text) guides weaker modalities (e.g., audio, visual) through techniques such as knowledge distillation and attention-based fusion. We systematically review evasion attack methodologies, assess their impact on system performance, and evaluate existing defense mechanisms.By highlighting the limitations of current approaches and identifying critical research gaps, this work aims to inspire future research on building robust and secure MER systems capable of withstanding adversarial threats.

title: Deep Learning-Driven Image Classification of Jellyfish: A CNN Model Approach
authors: Sripelli Jagadish, Bhoomika, Manisha Aeri, Aanchal Rawat
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: Rising in importance as an environmental problem, jellyfish blooms impair aquaculture infrastructure, upset marine ecosystems, and reveal human health risks. Good early reaction and monitoring depend on accurate and fast identification of several kinds of jellyfish. This article presents an image-based Convolutional Neural Network (CNN)-based automated jellyfish species categorization system. Drawn from the Kaggle open-source platform, 900 images totalling six species—Moon jellyfish, Barrel jellyfish, Blue jellyfish, Compass jellyfish, Lion's mane jellyfish, and Mauve stinger—were gathered. Training, validation, and assessment of the proposed CNN model were directed by standard performance criteria including accuracy, precision, recall, and F1-score. High classification accuracy of the model revealed its capacity to learn unique visual features and span over numerous species. Confusion matrix and classification report were generated to further investigate the performance of the model. The results validate the possibility of CNN-based models in marine species identification with a scalable and automated real-time jellyfish monitoring system. Future work could include more varied datasets, better model design, and system deployment in pragmatic coastal surveillance uses.

title: Integrating Artificial Intelligence and Data Analytics into Sustainable City Planning for Urban Heat Island Mitigation
authors: Moorthi K, Nagendra Prabhu S, Kiruthika M
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: Urban Heat Islands (UHIs) are one of the environmental issues that are most important in the 21st century and they have a huge negative impact on the quality of life, human health, and nature in cities. The rapid expansion of cities leads to natural land areas being turned into urban ones. The areas that are being turned into urban ones are mainly made of impervious materials such as concrete, asphalt, and glass through which heat is trapped. This is the reason why smaller cities are hotter than the countryside around them. UHIs affect the urban environment in ways such as increased energy demand, poor air quality, thermal discomfort, and climate change becoming more severe. In tropical countries like India, where the base temperature is already high, UHI leads to heat-related illnesses and even more deaths in summer. Although there are many studies that make use of satellite imagery and climatic datasets to analyze the UHIs, traditional methods are still very slow, scattered, and cost-consuming. In this study we integrated artificial intelligence and data analytics and designed a framework for urban heat island mitigation which provides prediction, visualization and recommends various strategies can be adopted for heat management. The different data coming from various sources is merged into a PostGIS spatial database, which not only aligns them geographically but also synchronizes them in time. The data that has been processed first goes through a combined machine learning pipeline that includes Random Forest Regressor, Gradient Boosting, and Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs). Random Forest and Gradient Boosting are used for prediction at the feature level and trend analysis, whereas CNNs are utilized to find the spatial characteristics in the thermal images that lead to the forecasting of temperatures at the pixel level. The model reaches a very strong accuracy of R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> = 0.94, which is better than that of traditional regression models.

title: Aerial Jamming Against Aerial Eavesdropping for UAV-Assisted Secure, Ultra-Reliable and Low-Latency Communications
authors: Emmanouel T. Michailidis, Nikolaos I. Miridakis
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: This paper investigates an unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV)-assisted network, where an aerial jammer is strategically deployed to mitigate interception attempts by an aerial eavesdropper. To ensure secure and ultra-reliable low-latency communications (URLLC), an optimization framework is proposed that maximizes the secrecy rate by dynamically adjusting the transmit power, jamming power, and trajectories of legitimate UAVs. To accurately characterize the system’s temporal behavior, a hierarchical time structure is employed, wherein long-term path loss variations and short-term URLLC transmissions are treated independently. The resulting non-convex problem is decomposed into tractable subproblems using the block coordinate descent (BCD) method and solved iteratively via successive convex approximation (SCA). Simulation results confirm the effectiveness of this approach in improving the secrecy rate and meeting URLLC constraints under adversarial conditions.

title: Model-agnostic clean-label backdoor mitigation in cybersecurity environments
authors: Giorgio Severi, Simona Boboila, John Holodnak, Kendra Kratkiewicz, Rauf Izmailov, Michael J. De Lucia, Alina Oprea
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: The training phase of machine learning models is a delicate step, especially in cybersecurity contexts. Recent research has surfaced a series of insidious training-time attacks that inject backdoors in models designed for security classification tasks without altering the training labels. With this work, we propose new techniques that leverage insights in cybersecurity threat models to effectively mitigate these clean-label poisoning attacks, while preserving the model utility. By performing density-based clustering on a carefully chosen feature subspace, and progressively isolating the suspicious clusters through a novel iterative scoring procedure, our defensive mechanism can mitigate the attacks without requiring many of the common assumptions in the existing backdoor defense literature.

title: The Trajectory of Deep Learning in Time Series Forecasting: A Survey
authors: WeiShen Zhang, BangLie Yang, Cheng Dai
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conferences on Internet of Things (iThings) IEEE Green Computing &amp; Communications (GreenCom) IEEE Cyber, Physical &amp; Social Computing (CPSCom) and IEEE Smart Data (SmartData) and IEEE Congress on Cybermatics (Cybermatics)
abstract: Time series forecasting (TSF) is a fundamental task supporting critical applications in finance, energy systems, and meteorology. However, the inherent complexity of real-world time series poses significant challenges to traditional statistical models and early-stage machine learning methods. In response, deep learning has emerged as a powerful paradigm, reshaping the field. This survey systematically reviews the evolution of deep learning models for TSF, demonstrating their progression from foundational recurrent architectures to the current state-of-the-art. We further analyze the ongoing paradigm shift towards large foundation models. By consolidating key advancements and architectural innovations, this paper provides a comprehensive analysis of the current landscape, concluding with a discussion of open challenges and promising directions for future research.

title: Extending Kubernetes to Provide Federated and Adaptive Tactical Edge Clouds
authors: Alessandro Amato, Harrie Bastiaansen, Masoud Bozorgi, Willem Datema, Mattia Fogli, Johan van der Geest, Thomas Kudla, Pablo Sanchez, Niranjan Suri, Susan Watson
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: This demonstration shows a Kubernetes-based architecture and proof of concept that extends cloud computing capabilities into the tactical edge, creating federated and adaptive tactical edge clouds for efficient data processing at the edge. This demonstration has been developed by the NATO IST-193 RTG on "Edge Computing at the Tactical Edge".

title: Predicting Solar Irradiation: A Machine Learning Comparison With Correlation Feature Selection
authors: Oussama Khouili, Mohamed Louzazni, Mohamed Hanine
publish: IEEE Power Electronics Magazine
abstract: Accurate solar yield prediction is paramount for optimizing electricity generation and sizing photovoltaic (PV) power systems. With the growing prevalence of utility-scale PV installations, the inherently variable nature of solar yield necessitates robust prediction models. Precise forecasting enhances energy market trading, optimizes solar power system performance, supports grid stability, and facilitates efficient energy management, financial planning, investment decisions, and maintenance operations. This study introduces an approach for predicting solar yield using artificial neural networks (ANNs), exploring various ANN architectures to determine the most suitable structure and comparing its performance against several machine learning models. Through the use of Spearman and Pearson correlation feature selection techniques, we identified all input features as being essential for accurate prediction of global horizontal irradiance (GHI). The findings indicate that the highest performing ANN attains a RMSE of 25.92 W/<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\text{m}^{2}$ </tex-math></inline-formula>, a MBE of −1.55 W/<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\text{m}^{2}$ </tex-math></inline-formula>, a MAPE of 0.11%, and a R-squared of 0.9926. This result demonstrates that our ANN model significantly outperforms other models, including a highly-tuned Random Forest (RMSE: 32.83 W/<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\text{m}^{2}$ </tex-math></inline-formula>, <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\text{R}^{2}$ </tex-math></inline-formula>: 0.988), establishing its superior performance for solar yield prediction.

title: Hybrid CNN–RNN Model for Real-Time Flood Forecasting using Multi-Sensor Data
authors: S. Banupriya, Manju Priya K, Nandeeni P, Kishore R V, Naveen P
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: To improve readiness and decrease hazards associated with floods, real-time flood forecasting with data from several sensors is essential. Due to uncertainties in flood quantity, timing, location, and geophysical interactions, complete control of floods remains unattainable. Although conventional flood control methods have been effective in reducing peak elevations and geographic extents, this process have not been able to eradicate floods totally. The suggested research proposes a method for real-time flood prediction that uses deep learning to overcome these shortcomings. Feature extraction through VMD follows the processing of multi-sensor data utilizing power transformations like the Box-Cox transformation and the Gamma Test to choose important input variables. In order to capture the spatial and temporal connections within the data, a CNN-RNN architecture with an attention mechanism is designed. In order to enhance the accuracy of predictions, the RNN models sequential patterns and the CNN extracts spatial characteristics from sensor inputs. The suggested CNN-RNN model is robust and reliable, as shown by the experimental findings, which show a success rate of 99.21 percent. Based on these results, it seems that deep learning integrated with multi-sensor data can greatly improve real-time flood forecasting, which in turn can help with proactive decision-making and better flood risk management.

title: Artificial Intelligence-Driven Diagnostic Systems for Early Detection of Esophageal Cancer: Trends and Perspectives
authors: Sreejith k, Sumitha. J
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: Esophageal cancer (EC) remains one of the most lethal malignancies globally due to its silent progression and late-stage diagnosis, resulting in poor survival rates. Conventional diagnostic methods, including endoscopy, biopsy, and imaging, although widely used, are invasive, time-consuming, and heavily relied on the expertise of clinicians, which often leads to diagnostic variability and delays in treatment. To overcome these challenges, this review synthesizes findings from recent studies on intelligent diagnostic systems employing machine learning (ML), deep learning (DL), hybrid, and ensemble techniques to facilitate early and accurate detection of EC. These techniques utilise endoscopic images, radiologic scans, and histopathological data to identify early-stage abnormalities, improve diagnostic accuracy, and reduce clinical workload. Also, it examines advancements in intelligent systems, their methodologies, and associated challenges. While the studies have demonstrated notable improvements in lesion detection, staging, and risk stratification, significant gaps persist, including limited dataset diversity, insufficient multicenter validation, lack of interpretability, and difficulty in integrating such systems into real-world clinical workflows. Future directions emphasize the development of explainable AI, incorporation of multimodal data, and real-time adaptive learning frameworks to enhance reliability and clinical trust. Advancing these technologies will enable early, non-invasive, and precise detection of EC, ultimately improving patient outcomes and supporting personalized treatment strategies.

title: Performance Evaluation of an Andvanced-Node CMOS Sensor for Partical Detection
authors: Yue Su, Mingjie Feng, Zhiyu Xiang, Cheng Zeng, Congcong Wang, Hui Zhang
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Integrated Circuits and Microsystems (ICICM)
abstract: The Monolithic Active Pixel Sensors (MAPS) implemented in high-voltage CMOS (HVCMOS) technology are suitable for tracking of high-energy particles in particle physics experiments. To explore performance improvements in smaller technology nodes, a prototype of the next-generation HVCMOS sensor has been done using 55 nm high-voltage technology. This technology offers the benefits of smaller feature size and reduced power consumption.

title: A Game-Theoretic Framework for Dynamic Decoy Placement in Cyber Networks
authors: Mi Zhou, Zherui Zhou, Qirui Zhang, Andrew Clark
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: Decoy nodes such as honeypots defend military cyber systems from malicious attacks by detecting adversaries, gaining information on novel exploits, and introducing misinformation to adversaries. Virtual honeypots and honeynets enable cyber systems to rapidly create, reconfigure, and take down decoy nodes in order to maximize the effectiveness of the deception. This paper presents a game-theoretic framework for dynamic decoy placement. In contrast to existing game-theoretic methodologies that focus on static decoy placement, our framework formulates dynamic strategies that modify the decoy locations in response to suspicious network activity. In order to solve the game, we propose a reinforcement learning approach for computing an optimal decoy placement policy. We mitigate the computational complexity by exploiting submodular structure of the value function of the game, which enables provable optimality bounds using a sequential greedy approximation at each time step. We conduct a numerical study that demonstrates our approach is tractable for a 100-node grid network and significantly improves win probability while reducing resource cost compared to a static decoy placement algorithm.

title: Adaptive Transformer Mechanisms for Identifying Mental Health Indicators in Conversations
authors: Mukesh Kumar Tripathi, Jyoti Agarwal, Shelly Gupta
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: Mental health illnesses affect millions of individuals globally and impede the availability of timely and efficient care. In this era of artificial intelligence (AI), there are novel avenues to detecting mental health conditions by leveraging AI, which can be used to create scalable and convenient supportive communities. The AI-based mental health detection system introduced in this work employs Mental RoBERTa to monitor user interactions and detect early signs of mental unease such as stress, anxiety and depression. The system is based on concept of a customizable modular application that consists of a report in the reporting engine, a time psychological screening module and the March Bot Controller, which is used to interact with the patient during a session. It is the feature selection that optimizes the data dimensionality within this model to achieve, for effective mental health prediction, high precision and relevancy of detected relations. Experiments show that our approach is promising, yielding stable information and achieving above 85% in classification accuracy. Some users liked the chat flow on the app as it had been described to be supportive, encourage openness and reduce stigma. That the disjuncture between people and professional mental health care can be bridged by reported feeling, applied feel, can serve as a low-cost Judgment of risk tool offering the model and first phase in early detection. For wider use in monitoring and support for mental health, research will focus on further tweaking the model, broadening the range of data it can be trained on, and addressing ethical issues. This study also demonstrates how AI is a game-changer in fulfilling unmet needs in global mental health care.

title: Design and Implementation of a Two-Stage P&O MPPT with CC/CV Controlled Boost Converter for Efficient Electric Vehicle Battery Charging
authors: R. Tamilamuthan, R. Aiswarya, R. Anitha, S. Dinakar Raj, B. T. Geetha, M. Lakshmanan
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: The present paper describes a two-step Perturb and Observe (P&O) Maximum Power Point Tracking (MPPT) and Constant-Current/Constant-Voltage (CC/CV) Controlled Boost Converter that can enhance the efficiency of the process of charging electric vehicle (EV) batteries, and the stability of charging of the vehicle battery under photovoltaic (PV) sources. The architecture proposed is based on a two-step coordinated control process, with the first step using an adaptive P&O MPPT control algorithm to optimize power extraction using the solar array and the second step using a dual mode CC/CV control loop to maintain charging current and voltage as a function of battery state of charge (SOC). The converter is defined and designed in MATLAB/ Simulink 2021a and the performance of the system is evaluated with variable irradiance and load conditions. As the simulation results prove, the given system has 96.1% of conversion efficiency, settling time of 0.13 s, steady-state error of 0.9, and reduction of the voltage ripple of 41.9% in relation to the traditional PI-controlled converters. The adaptive P&O algorithm removes steady-state oscillations and enhances the tracking accuracy by about 4 percent and CC/CV control enables the smooth transition between charging modes without overshoot or current spikes. The combination of both control phases has better dynamic control, energy efficiency and voltage stability. These findings show that the proposed two-stage system is effective in the application of renewable-integrated EV charging and can be flexible in respect to smart grid environments.

title: AI based EV Charging Station Scheduling for Smart Energy Systems
authors: Sunil SK, Mohan Das, Prajwal M R, T Purushotham, Praveen Kumar, V Bhargav
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: A sustainable energy management system for campus environments has been developed which will use artificial intelligence technology in order to optimise electric vehicle charging time schedules and to balance the energy loads. The aims of the system are to reduce the cost of electricity, to prevent the danger of power overloads and to carry out the use of renewable sources of energy, while providing essential departments with an uninterrupted supply of electric power. It thus collects and forecasts data of energy demand and then uses a genetic algorithm to calculate the EV charging time schedule. The system has wind turbines and photovoltaic panels incorporated and a battery energy storage system in order to reduce reliance on the grid to be provided by the local authorities. The system will be supplied with a dashboard of MATLAB based software which will give instant data together with reports on energy consumption, cost savings and CO₂ emissions reduced. The hardware of the systems would comprise smart EV chargers, digital energy meters, solar panels and battery.

title: Deep Reinforcement Learning Based Routing for Heterogeneous Multi-Hop Wireless Networks
authors: Brian Kim, Justin H. Kong, Terrence J. Moore, Fikadu T. Dagefu
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: Routing in multi-hop wireless networks is a complex problem, especially in heterogeneous networks where multiple wireless communication technologies coexist. Reinforcement learning (RL) methods, such as Q-learning, have been introduced for decentralized routing by allowing nodes to make decisions based on local observations. However, Q-learning suffers from scalability issues and poor generalization due to the difficulty in managing the Q-table in large or dynamic network topologies, especially in heterogeneous networks (HetNets) with diverse channel characteristics. Thus, in this paper, we propose a novel deep Q-network (DQN)-based routing framework for heterogeneous multi-hop wireless networks to maximize the end-to-end rate of the route by improving scalability and adaptability, where each node uses a deep neural network (DNN) to estimate the Q-values and jointly select the next-hop relay and a communication technology for transmission. To achieve better performance with the DNN, selecting which nodes to exchange information is critical, as it not only defines the state and action spaces but also determines the input to the DNN. To this end, we propose neighbor node selection strategies based on channel gain and rate between nodes rather than a simple distance-based approach for an improved set of states and actions for DQN-based routing. During training, the model experiences diverse network topologies to ensure generalization and robustness, and simulation results show that the proposed neighbor node selection outperforms simple distance-based selection. Further, we observe that the DQN-based approach outperforms various benchmark schemes and performs comparably to the optimal approach.

title: A Fast Auto-Frequency Calibration Technique with High Reference Frequency for PLL
authors: Yan Feng, Yongjie Ye, Guoxiao Cheng, Liu Wang, Wei Kang
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Integrated Circuits and Microsystems (ICICM)
abstract: This article proposes a fast auto-frequency calibration (AFC) technique with high reference frequency for wideband phase-locked loop (PLL). The AFC circuit block obtains frequency information based on time-to-voltage converter (TVC), which eliminates the dependence on high-frequency counters. Meanwhile, new settable divider-by-3 (S-Div3) and voltage comparator circuit have been proposed to ensure that the AFC circuit can operate adaptively and rapidly at high reference frequency and different operating states. And a high reference frequency can fundamentally improve the AFC locking time. A $\mathbf{7. 6} \sim \mathbf{8. 5 ~ G H z}$ voltage-controlled oscillator (VCO) incorporating AFC technology is implemented in 55 nm CMOS process. The simulation results demonstrate that under $\mathbf{1 3 2 ~ M H z}$ reference frequency and 8.45 GHz output frequency, the total AFC setting time achieves an outstanding $\mathbf{1 1 0. 5}$ ns.

title: An Analytical Compact Model for Multi-time Programmable Memory Cells
authors: Tiantian Gan, Xiaojin Li, Tengyang Liu, Yabin Sun, Yanling Shi, Jianpeng Chu
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Integrated Circuits and Microsystems (ICICM)
abstract: Single-poly multi-time programmable (MTP) memory cell demonstrates promising prospects in embedded nonvolatile memory technologies. In this paper, a novel analytic compact model is proposed for erasing/programming operations in MTP memory cells. The model incorporates the effects of ramp voltage slew rate on memory cells and, based on the capacitive coupling coefficient model, constructs a computational framework to derive closed-form analytical solutions. Compared to the prior approaches, this methodology achieves computational simplicity without iterative calculation. Furthermore, model predictions demonstrate good agreement with experimental data (error $\lt 2.16 \%$). The proposed framework enables rapid performance evaluation of memory cells, delivering a guiding framework for cooptimizing memory cell architecture and peripheral circuit design.

title: Demo: Toward Multi-Connectivity 6G IoT - Practical IoT Device-to-Core Integration
authors: Quang Quoc Ngo, Ruttik Kalle, Dang Yongchao, Jäntti Riku, Jose Costa-Requena
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on 6G Networking (6GNet)
abstract: The emerging 6G vision aims to enable massive IoT deployments, multi-connectivity, and heterogeneous networks while ensuring ultra-reliable low-latency communications, robust security, and intelligent network orchestration. Current approaches to IoT connectivity remain fragmented and isolated, lacking seamless interoperability and exposing gaps in end-to-end security. To address these gaps, we present a lightweight implementation for direct authentication and registration of IoT UEs with a commercial 5G Core (5GC) using Raspberry Pi 5 devices over Wi-Fi, enabling 5G-AKA authentication and secured NAS channel. Our implementation aims to provide a ready-to-use solution that can expand to other wireless standards, aligning with the 6G vision and emerging IoT standards such as DECT NR+. By offloading authentication, session management, and traffic control to the 5GC, resource-constrained IoT devices gain access to carrier-grade security and efficient traffic handling. Furthermore, we demonstrate a secured data-plane setup in which WireGuard configuration is exchanged between two UEs through the gNB, establishing an encrypted VPN tunnel. Validation through Wireshark captures and the 5GC GUI confirms compliance with 3 GPP specifications. This work provides a practical step toward 6G IoT integration, offering a scalable, secure, and multi-connectivity-ready solution for industrial and enterprise deployments.

title: Battery Evolution Forecasting in Electric Vehicles using Deep Learning Models
authors: P. Maniraj. M.E, Abinaya Devi N, Ayyappan A, Hariharan S, Janarathinababu A
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: Accurate prediction of battery health will become increasingly important for monitoring performance, safety, and longevity as electric vehicles become popular. Currently, battery health monitoring methods, including manual inspections and some simple analytical models, provide results that are usually inaccurate owing to the complexity of battery behavior. This paper proposes a deep learning model for predicting battery health and remaining useful life that can be developed from EV battery data sets. It also evaluates the important aspects of the salient performance of the battery using the deep learning method. The project also provides a web-based platform that issues alerts on battery health status and predictive maintenance, and other important information to make decisions on operation. In this way, it promotes efficient and sustainable use of EVs and extends and broadens the green transportation technology due to fewer service costs, breakdowns, and battery life.

title: Resilience-Driven Topology Reconfiguration via Hierarchical Deep Reinforcement Learning in Low-Altitude UAV Networks
authors: Jingbin Zhang, Dezhi Zheng, Zhengzhi Yang, Yumeng Li, Wenbo Du, Tony Q. S. Quek, Shuai Wang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Network Science and Engineering
abstract: In low-altitude wireless networks, Unmanned Aerial Vehicles (UAVs) are vulnerable to environmental disturbances, which can cause failures, disrupting network topology and weakening coverage and backhaul. Consequently, network reconfiguration has become an urgent problem. Such reconfiguration must jointly consider coverage and backhaul, while obstacles in low-altitude environments further increase its complexity and challenges. To address this problem, we propose UR-HDRL (UAV network Reconfiguration based on Hierarchical Deep Reinforcement Learning), a novel framework that adopts a hierarchical architecture to decouple safety constraints from communication performance optimization. The algorithm integrates Control Barrier Functions (CBFs) and Graph Neural Networks (GNNs) to ensure safety and enhance collaborative decision-making in environments with obstacles. Experimental results indicate that UR-HDRL achieves significant improvements in data transmission efficiency, network coverage, and collision avoidance compared with baseline methods. The results also reveal distinct differences between communication coverage and sensing coverage, highlighting the inherent trade-offs between them.

title: Learning Degradation-Aware Diffusion Prior for Hyperspectral Reconstruction from RGB Image
authors: Jingxiang Yang, Haifeng Xu, Heyuan Yin, Hongyi Liu, Liang Xiao
publish: IEEE Transactions on Computational Imaging
abstract: Hyperspectral image (HSI) is applicable in many fields due to the ability in discriminating different materials. Collecting HSI usually requires expensive hardware and long period. Reconstructing HSI from RGB image, also called spectral super-resolution (SSR), is an affordable and feasible way for HSI acquisition. Despite the SSR results achieved by existing deep unfolding networks (DUNs), they still face challenges in: 1) recovering the fine-grained and realistic details; 2) suppressing the spectral distortion. Diffusion model has advantages in generating diverse and realistic contents, while its fidelity is limited due to the inherent randomness. In this study, to reconstruct a faithful and realistic HSI, we integrate the diffusion model in DUN, and propose a degradation-aware unrolling diffusion model for SSR (deDiff-SSR). The generative diffusion prior is jointly leveraged with the spectral degradation and deep prior learning. Specifically, we first pre-train a channel attention enhanced denoising diffusion probabilistic model (DDPM), the spectral correlation is exploited for learning the diffusion prior of HSI. To aware the degradation, by optimizing a diffusion and deep priors regularized HSI SSR model, we propose a degradation-aware diffusion sampling method, the spectral degradation is learned to refine each diffusion sampling step. Via unrolling the degradation-aware diffusion sampling steps, we build the deDiff-SSR network. It contains diffusion and deep proximal operators to represent the diffusion and deep priors, respectively. We implement the diffusion proximal operator with one sampling step of the pre-trained DDPM. Moreover, we design a state-space Transformer as the deep proximal operator, the spectral-spatial long-range relationship of HSI can be efficiently captured. The experiments on several indoor and remote sensing datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of deDiff-SSR.

title: DUVET: Dual-View Enhanced Transformer for Anomaly Detection in Aviation Safety Monitoring
authors: Chengxiang Li, Xu Li, Haodong Chen, Linjiang Zheng, Fan Li, Xinbin Zhao, Huabo Sun, Riquan Zhang, Jiaxing Shang
publish: IEEE Sensors Journal
abstract: In recent years, the prevalence of modern flight data sensing systems, represented by Quick Access Recorder (QAR), has made it viable to improve flight safety by analyzing massive flight parameters. However, existing studies predominantly concentrate on predefined safety events where the expert-annotated data are highly scarce and imbalanced. In this paper, we address this issue by uncovering abnormal flight patterns from tremendous unlabeled data to discover potential and unexpected safety risks. To this end, we propose DUVET, a reconstruction-based DUal View Enhanced Transformer model for flight data anomaly detection, which plays a vital role in aviation safety monitoring. Specifically, DUVET adopts patching and channel independence techniques to reduce model parameters and improve Transformer’s computational efficiency while preserving its semantic representation capacity. Based on the observation that flight safety risks usually relate to both long-term trend and short-term patterns, we creatively propose Flight Trend-Aware Attention and Bell attention mechanisms to capture both global and local dependencies, enhancing the model reconstruction ability. We evaluate DUVET on six public real-world datasets and one QAR dataset, demonstrating that DUVET achieves state-of-the-art performance in general time series anomaly detection task. Further experiments on the QAR dataset show that DUVET meets key criteria of anomaly detection for flight safety in terms of stability, training efficiency and detection accuracy. Case study shows that DUVET can effectively uncover hidden flight safety risks.

title: MorphoCopter: Design, Modeling, and Control of a New Transformable Quad–Bi Copter
authors: Harsh Modi, Hao Su, Xiao Liang, Minghui Zheng
publish: IEEE/ASME Transactions on Mechatronics
abstract: This article presents a novel morphing quadrotor, named MorphoCopter, covering its design, modeling, control, and experimental tests. It features a unique single rotary joint that enables rapid transformation into an ultranarrow profile. Although quadrotors have seen widespread adoption in applications, such as cinematography, agriculture, and disaster management, with increasingly sophisticated control systems, their hardware configurations have remained largely unchanged, limiting their capabilities in certain environments. Our design addresses this by enabling the hardware configuration to change on the fly when required. In standard flight mode, the MorphoCopter adopts an X configuration, functioning as a traditional quadcopter, but can quickly fold into a stacked bicopters arrangement or any configuration in between. Existing morphing designs often sacrifice controllability in compact configurations or rely on complex multijoint systems. Moreover, our design achieves a greater width reduction than any existing solution. We develop a new inertia and control-action aware adaptive control system that maintains robust performance across all rotary-joint configurations. The prototype can reduce its width from 447 to 138 mm (nearly 70% reduction) in just a few seconds. We validated the MorphoCopter through rigorous simulations and a comprehensive series of flight experiments, including robustness tests, trajectory tracking, and narrow-gap passing tests.

title: Cross-Scene Open-Set Hyperspectral Image Classification via Joint Distribution Matching and Unknown Class Uncertainty Suppression_supp1-3650003.pdf
authors: Kai Deng
publish: N/A
abstract: Cross-scene hyperspectral image (HSI) classification plays a vital role in a variety of applications, including agricultural monitoring, military reconnaissance, and urban planning. Due to the nonlinear nature of land-cover characteristics, the diversity of scenes, and the distribution shifts caused by variations in acquisition conditions or sensors, deep HSI open-set domain adaptation (OSDA) has emerged as a key approach to tackling cross-scene HSI classification. Existing methods assume identical joint distributions between training and test data. However, this rigorous assumption renders them ineffective in real-world scenes when encountering varied sensors, changed imaging conditions, different spatial resolution in HSI imaging, e.g., water vapor bands at 1.36-1.39 μm. To address this, we propose a more generalizable deep HSI OSDA method JDMUS based on Joint Distribution Matching and unknown class Uncertainty Suppression, for cross-scene HSI classification. Specifically, we employ χ<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>-divergence to characterize the joint distribution discrepancy and propose a least-squares χ<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>-divergence estimator without explicitly modeling the two joint distributions, yielding a quadratic problem with an analytical solution. Furthermore, we prove the methodology that the upper bound of the target error for neural network classification model is determined by the average source error, χ<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>-divergence, and open-set risk difference. Based on this methodology, we design joint distribution matching and unknown class uncertainty suppression mechanisms, and thus construct the JDMUS algorithm with theoretical guarantees, in which weighted generative adversarial network with dynamic thresholding is used for feature extraction. Experiments on cross-scene HSI datasets demonstrate that our JDMUS outperforms existing state-of-the-art approaches.

title: Clustering Guided Residual Neural Networks for Multi-Tx Localization in Molecular Communications
authors: Ali Sonmez, Erencem Ozbey, Efe Feyzi Mantaroglu, H. Birkan Yilmaz
publish: IEEE Communications Letters
abstract: Transmitter (Tx) localization in Molecular Communication via Diffusion is a critical topic with many applications. However, accurate localization of multiple transmitters is a challenging problem due to the stochastic nature of diffusion and overlapping molecule distributions at the receiver surface. To address these issues, we introduce clustering-based centroid correction methods that enhance robustness against density variations, and outliers. In addition, we propose two clusteringguided Residual Neural Networks, namely AngleNN and SizeNN. Experimental results show that both approaches provide significant improvements by reducing localization error between 69% (2-Tx) and 43% (4-Tx) compared to the K-means.

title: Chaos Masking via Invertible Optical Transform within the Security Strategy Framework
authors: Shi Wang, Yang Liu, Mengfan Cheng, Yin Li
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Industrial Technology Applications (AIITA)
abstract: We propose a chaos masking scheme whereby an invertible transformation performed by the time domain fractional Fourier transform (FrFT) is utilized. The chaotic phase noise is transformed onto the intensity axis by the FrFT., thus masks the intensity modulated messages. The proposed architecture achieves physical-layer security enhancement through asynchronous chaos modulation, bypassing the explicit synchronization constraints inherent in conventional chaotic encryption paradigms. By varying the control parameters of the FrFT with an external pseudo random binary sequence (PRBS), certain attacks against the FrFT can be immuned. The FrFT parameters and the PRBS are covered by the chaotic phase noise signal which make the eavesdropper difficult to crack the system. Decoupling chaotic entropy generation from optical transmission layers allows independent optimization of broadband photonic noise sources, while enabling plug-and-play security module integration through standardized FrFT operator interfaces.

title: A General Framework for Scalable UE-AP Association in User-Centric Cell-Free Massive MIMO based on Recurrent Neural Networks
authors: Giovanni Di Gennaro, Amedeo Buonanno, Gianmarco Romano, Stefano Buzzi, Francesco A.N. Palmieri
publish: IEEE Transactions on Communications
abstract: This study addresses the challenge of access point (AP) and user equipment (UE) association in cell-free massive MIMO networks. It introduces a deep learning algorithm based on Bidirectional Long Short-Term Memory cells (a specific type of Recurrent Neural Network) and a hybrid probabilistic methodology for weight updating. This approach enhances scalability by adapting to variations in the number of UEs without requiring retraining. In addition, the study proposes a novel master-centric methodology for managing the AP-UE association process, which helps improve scalability not only with respect to the number of UEs, but also to that of APs. Furthermore, a variant of the proposed AP-UE algorithm ensures robustness against pilot contamination effects, a critical issue arising from pilot reuse in channel estimation. Extensive numerical results validate the effectiveness and adaptability of the proposed methods, demonstrating clear advantages over widely used heuristic alternatives.

title: Resilience Enhancement of Smart Power Systems Against False Data Injection Attacks Using Adaptive Intrusion Detection Mechanisms
authors: Mohammad Ghiasi, Mahmud Fotuhi-Firuzabad
publish: IEEE Transactions on Reliability
abstract: The integration of Cyber-Physical Systems (CPS) within smart power grids has brought significant improvements in monitoring and controlling these systems. However, it has also increased the cyber-security and privacy risks for the grids. This article introduces a new way to improve the security and privacy of smart power systems through an adaptive intrusion detection mechanism. This mechanism is designed to tackle the specific challenges that CPS environments present, using real-time data processing and adaptive intrusion detection mechanisms. It can effectively identify both known and new cyber threats with high accuracy. A strong method is outlined to enhance the detection and reduction of false data injection attacks (FDIAs) that target smart power grids. This approach helps identify targeted attacks, even when anomalies are minimal, thereby ensuring better system resilience, operational stability, and data privacy protection. This adaptive framework offers a promising solution to boost the resilience of CPS in power systems. The effectiveness of the proposed technique is assessed using IEEE 14-bus, IEEE 39-bus, and 118-bus systems in the MATLAB (R2023b) environment. It measures resilience and privacy leakage caused by FDIA in two scenarios: delayed detection with high residual values and timely detection with low residual values. The simulation results showcase the effectiveness of this strategy for secure grid operation.

title: A novel transfer learning strategy based on Inception-ResNet+1D-CNN for DC-DC converter degradation fault diagnosis
authors: Guoqing Zhang, Yang Liu, Zhiliang Chen, Yichun Wang
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: Reliable fault diagnosis of DC-DC converters is critical for ensuring the safety and operational continuity of electric vehicles (EVs) and industrial power systems. In practical applications, early detection of progressive degradation can prevent catastrophic failures and significantly reduce maintenance costs. However, developing robust diagnostic models is hindered by sensor noise, environmental disturbances, and the scarcity of labeled fault data—particularly for subtle degradation scenarios where real-world collection is expensive. To address these issues, this paper proposes a transfer learning framework based on Inception-Residual Neural Network (ResNet) + One-Dimensional Convolutional Neural Network (1D-CNN), aiming to enhance diagnostic performance under small-sample conditions. The proposed network extracts discriminative features from simulated voltage signals (source domain) and transfers this knowledge to real-world experimental data (target domain). To reduce domain discrepancies, a Whitening and Coloring Covariance Alignment (WCA) is employed for global feature alignment, while a novel Classwise WCA strategy further refines the alignment at the category level to preserve fault-specific structures. Additionally, the classifier is fine-tuned using L2 Starting Point (L2-SP) regularization, which constrains parameter shift to prevent overfitting under limited supervision. The method is non-intrusive and practical, operating efficiently using only the output voltage ripple. Experimental results validate the effectiveness of the proposed approach, demonstrating a diagnostic accuracy of 91.6% even with limited samples, significantly outperforming conventional transfer learning methods in cross-domain fault identification tasks.

title: WECI-YOLO: Multi-Module Enhanced Steel Surface Quality Defect Detection
authors: Huixiang Zhou, Jian Wang, Tianxing Jiang
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: Steel surface quality is crucial for industrial product performance, yet defect detection remains challenging due to type diversity, scale variations, and complex backgrounds. Existing deep learning methods often lack accuracy and robustness. This paper proposes WECI-YOLO, an enhanced algorithm based on YOLO11n. The backbone network integrates a C3k2-WTConv module to widen the receptive field. A lightweight EUCB module is embedded in the upsampling path to improve multi-level feature fusion. For elongated defects, a C2PSA-CAA attention module is designed to optimize extraction. Additionally, the Inner-SIoU loss function combines SIoU’s angle perception with Inner-IoU’s internal scaling strategy. Experiments on the GC10-DET and Aug-GC10-DET datasets demonstrate that WECI-YOLO achieves recall rates of 65.8% and 66.5%, respectively, along with mean average precision (mAP) values of 66.6% and 67.9%. Compared to YOLO11n, recall improved by 2.4% and 2.5%, while precision increased by 4.0% and 3.6%, achieving optimal performance on Aug-GC10-DET. The impacts of augmentation and the proposed modules are evaluated separately in the experiments.Notably, these accuracy gains are achieved with only a small and acceptable increase in computational cost. The proposed algorithm demonstrates clear advantages over existing methods in steel surface defect detection.

title: Design of 6-to-8-bit High-Speed Time-Interleaved SAR ADC
authors: Zhenyang Zhang, Fangxu Lv, Zhengbin Pang, Jiaqing Xu, Qiang Wang, Meng Li
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Integrated Circuits and Microsystems (ICICM)
abstract: This paper presents a high-speed time-interleaved (TI) SAR ADC with digitally programmable resolution from 6 to 8 bits. Utilizing a dual-channel architecture, the single-channel sampling rate achieves $500 \mathrm{MS} / \mathrm{s}$, enabling an overall sampling rate of $1 \mathrm{GS} / \mathrm{s}$ after interleaving. The single-channel SAR ADC employs a Vcm-based switching scheme and split-capacitor technique to simplify the input signal. A novel SAR logic architecture optimized for high-speed operation is proposed. The circuit is implemented in a 28 nm CMOS process. Operating at a 0.9 V supply voltage and $1 \mathrm{GS} / \mathrm{s}$ sampling rate, the ADC achieves an SNDR of 49.3 dB with a power consumption of 4.7 mW, resulting in a figure of merit (FOM) of $\mathbf{1 9}$ fJ/conversion-step.

title: Topology-Preserving Power Adaptation for Mobile Ad Hoc Networks
authors: Dmitrii Dugaev, Charlie Greenbacker, Ram Ramanathan
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: Conventional techniques for the adaptation of transmit power in mobile ad hoc networks (MANET) result in considerable disruption to the MAC and routing protocols due to frequent topology changes, playing havoc with network control. We present CAPE (Conserving Energy through Power Adaptation), a fully distributed and dynamic protocol for conserving energy and visibility via power adaptation that preserves the topology that would have resulted without adaptation, typically the max-power topology. CAPE uses the Received Signal Strength Indication (RSSI) to create an excess-power map of the neighborhood that is shared with neighbors to reduce the transmit power to accommodate the highest-path-loss neighbor. We present extensive simulation results on CAPE’s performance on a model of the goTenna mesh network. Our results show that CAPE reduces energy by 29% - 70%, and visibility by 28% - 64%, depending on the density of the network and the CAPE variant used. CAPE delivers its gains with zero impact on other parts of a MANET, making it attractive for real-world systems.

title: A Package-on-Package Module with Integrated FPGA Minimum System for 48-Channel Synchronous Sampling 16-bit ADC
authors: Han Li, Jiangbo Wei, Yuan Miao, Weize An, Xudong Wu, Huan Yu, Chao Wang
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Integrated Circuits and Microsystems (ICICM)
abstract: This study investigates microsystem technology for multi-channel analog signal measurement in Civil Space Industry to address the challenges of miniaturization, high reliability, high performance, and low cost in Spaceborne equipment. First, the architecture of a data processing and control system based on a multi- channel analog signal measurement system is introduced. Then, through low-cost microsystem integration technologies centered on simplified electrical principle design, microassembly, and Package-on-Package (PoP) packaging, the core hardware of the system is reduced to 20% of its original size, significantly decreasing volume, dimensions, and weight. Additionally, the long-term reliability of interfacial adhesion between metal materials and potting materials is evaluated to resolve signal integrity control issues in the measurement microsystem. A universal solution for the design and implementation of a multi-channel analog signal measurement microsystem is proposed, and its reliability is validated through physical testing, confirming the feasibility of this miniaturized, high-reliability, high-performance, and low-cost microsystem integration approach.

title: High-Performance Hydrogenated Oxide-Semiconductor Schottky Barrier Diodes with ALD HfO2 Interface
authors: Yucheng Cao, Chenyang Huang, Yuyang Cai, Kuan-Chang Chang, Lei Li, Congwei Liao, Yufeng Jin, Lei Lu
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Integrated Circuits and Microsystems (ICICM)
abstract: The bulk resistance dominates the on-resistance ($\boldsymbol{R}_{\text {on }}$) of oxide semiconductor (OS) Schottky barrier diodes (SBDs). While highly conductive OSs enable superior current capability, their abundant interface defects at metal contacts lower the effective barrier and cause excessive leakage. In this work, high-indium InZnO (In: $\mathbf{Z n}=\mathbf{5: 1}$, IZO5:1) was employed as the active layer, and an ultrathin HfO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf> interlayer was introduced to suppress metal-induced states and enhance the barrier height. However, the interlayer alone could not fully mitigate interface defects in In-rich IZO. To address this, hydrogenation technology was further developed, effectively reducing leakage while maintaining strong forward conduction. Optimized devices with a $2 \mathrm{~nm} \mathrm{HfO}_{2}$ interlayer and $\mathbf{1 0 0 s}$ hydrogenation treatment achieved a barrier height of 0.73 eV, an ideality factor of 1.16, and a breakdown voltage of 136 V. This approach provides a promising pathway for interface engineering and performance improvement of high-current OS SBDs.

title: kNN-MOA: An Accurate and Scalable Detection of Malicious Content in Social Media Platforms
authors: A Prashanthi, M Anusha Sri, Mounica Velpula, Bairi Pravalika, Veesam Uday Prakash, Budarapu Ganesh
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: Content-based cybercrime detection in Online Social Networks (OSNs) such as YouTube, Twitter, Facebook, and WhatsApp has become increasingly essential due to the rapid surge of harmful, misleading, and malicious digital content. However, existing machine learning methods often struggle with high false-positive rates and reduced accuracy when dealing with noisy, high-dimensional social media data. To address this challenge, this study proposes an integrated detection framework combining k-Nearest Neighbors (kNN) with the Masterpiece Optimization Algorithm (MOA) to enhance feature selection, parameter tuning, and classification reliability. The system is evaluated using the OSN-CyberCrimeText-2024 dataset and experiments are carried out in the Python-based Anaconda environment. The proposed MOA–kNN model demonstrates significant performance improvements compared to two widely used existing models—Support Vector Machine (SVM) and Random Forest (RF). Experimental results show that the integrated model achieves higher Accuracy, increased True Positive Rate (TPR), reduced False Positive Rate (FPR), and improved F1-Score. Specifically, the model yields measurable improvements such as a notable rise in accuracy, substantial reduction in FPR, and enhanced TPR and F1-Score compared to the benchmark models. These results confirm the model’s capability to effectively identify cybercrime-related content across multiple social platforms.

title: Radio Frequency Machine Learning Mixture of Experts
authors: Matthew Judah, Scott Kuzdeba
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: Traditional machine learning techniques struggle to generalize in modeling and interpreting complex domains like radio frequency (RF) signals. One reason is that RF signals exhibit a high number of degrees of freedom due to variability in modulation schemes, channel conditions, noise characteristics, sampling rate, and temporal dynamics. Mixture of Expert (MoE) models offer a powerful framework to deal with this level complexity in data. By dynamically routing inputs to specialized sub-models, MoE architectures efficiently capture diverse signal behaviors while maintaining computational scalability. This pa-per investigates the suitability of MoE models to implicitly learn underlying characteristics of RF signals and determines if expert routing techniques are sufficient for a complex and temporally dynamic domain like RF signals. We show that MoE routing networks are able direct specific inputs to specialized experts given input signal characteristics and generalizes expert-routing across multiple datasets with different channel characteristics.

title: A Multi-Task, Multi-Model Deep Learning Analysis for Lung Cancer Detection on CT Scans
authors: Sumit Kumar, Manikandan J, Sricharan Andra, Rishita Arora, Mannan Ali Shaikh, Kushagra Vardhan
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: Lung cancer remains a leading cause of cancer-related mortality worldwide, making early and accurate detection critical for improving patient outcomes. Deep learning models, particularly Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs), have shown immense promise in analyzing medical images like Computed Tomography (CT) scans. However, performance can vary significantly based on model architecture and the specific diagnostic task. This paper presents a comprehensive, multi-task comparative study of five distinct CNN architectural families for lung cancer analysis. We evaluate these models on three separate, well-defined tasks: (1) multi-class nodule classification, (2) semantic nodule segmentation, and (3) binary malignancy classification. The architectures benchmarked include legacy models (VGG-16), residual networks (ResNet-50), densely connected networks (DenseNet-121), mobile-optimized networks (MobileNet-V2), and modern efficient networks (EfficientNet-B0). Our findings demonstrate that model suitability is highly task-dependent. EfficientNet-B0 overwhelmingly outperforms all other models in the primary multi-class classification task, achieving an Accuracy of 98.8% while utilizing significantly fewer computational resources. In contrast, a U-Net architecture utilizing a ResNet-50 encoder provides the most robust results for nodule segmentation, suggesting that architectural depth is critical for spatial feature preservation. Furthermore, we conduct a computational complexity analysis, revealing that modern architectures reduce parameter counts by up to 96% compared to legacy models without compromising accuracy. This study underscores the importance of architectural selection for specific clinical applications and provides a rigorous baseline for future work in automated lung cancer diagnostics.

title: AI-Integrated Smart Vertical Axis Wind Turbine for Efficient Urban Power Generation
authors: Gowri S, Dhinesh Kumar M, Indraleka A, S Dilip Kumar
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: Vertical Axis Wind Turbines (VAWTs) are best suited for city center energy harvesting due to their ability to respond to multidirectional and turbulent winds within a limited area. However, the low self-start, reduced efficiency, and vulnerability to high-speed winds limit their use. The Smart Helical Shape VAWT with AI-Controlled Structure project overcomes these constraints through the use of protective covers, helical blade alignment, and AI-controlled control. This design uses CFD simulation, experimentation, and field testing to optimize for performance. Wind damage is avoided through windbreak structures, helical blades maximize power efficiency, and AI delivers adaptive pitch control, predictive maintenance, and real-time optimization. Together, protection, aerodynamics, and AI create a robust, effective, and sustainable future small-scale wind power solution for intelligent cities.

title: AI Powered Predictive Maintenance in Supply Chain Logistics Networks
authors: Kiruthikaa Natarajan Srinivasan
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: As more supply chain and logistics industry sectors evolve, the need for continued operational efficiency and real time streamlining will continue to drive adoption of predictive maintenance strategies (PdM). The current work looks at the use of varying degrees of Artificial Intelligence (AI) to optimize predictive maintenance for various logistics assets, including vehicles, conveyors, storage units, and other fleet management systems. The work outlines the various components of a system that deploys predictive maintenance. It describes system architecture, various types of data that need to be collected, and a combination of high end neural networks and deep reinforcement learning. The work also describes the lack of deployed AI systems, or operational black boxes, within the operational domain of predictive maintenance, and how to overcome these to create truly operational predictive maintenance systems. Numerous case studies within the work illustrate the operational benefits of PdM, including the reduction of unplanned downtimes, the better deployment of assets, the reduction of operational costs, enhanced resiliency within the entire supply chain; all interlaced with the positive environmental impacts of AI systems within logistics. The work concludes with a description of the remaining research gaps and added components of geographically located networked information systems within intra-logistics systems.

title: Multi-Branch Autoencoder Networks for Efficient Inverse Design of Wideband Frequency-Selective Surfaces
authors: Wei Jiang, Haoran Huang, Guangxin Liao, Shenli Zheng, Jiacheng Guo, Yuan Du
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Integrated Circuits and Microsystems (ICICM)
abstract: Traditional electromagnetic design automation (EDA) methods for frequency-selective surfaces (FSS) are computationally expensive and inefficient for complex designs. Neural network-based surrogate models have been introduced to accelerate the process, but conventional architectures struggle to accurately predict electromagnetic responses due to limited frequency-dependent feature extraction. To address this, we propose a Multi-Branch Autoencoder (MBAE) framework that separately encodes structural and frequency-domain features, significantly improving predictive accuracy. The integration of Fourier Neural Operators (FNO) enhances the model’s ability to learn complex electromagnetic behaviors, while an adaptive Differential Evolution (DE) algorithm improves global optimization. Experimental results show that our method achieves the target frequency response ($19.5-25 \mathrm{GHz}$) in just seven iterations, delivering a $58 \times-117 \times$ speedup over full-wave simulations and a $152.8 \times$ acceleration per iteration compared to manual optimization. Notably, it outperforms conventional neural networks in predictive accuracy, providing a more efficient and scalable solution for advanced electromagnetic design.

title: Predictive Flocking of an Omnidirectional Multi-Agent System for Lattice Formation: Sigma-Norm Design and Comparative Performance Assessment
authors: Eusebio E. Hernández, Hengameh Mirhajianmoghadam, Eduardo S. Espinoza, Luis Rodolfo Garcia Carrillo
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: This paper presents a decentralized Model Predictive Control (MPC) flocking algorithm based on the sigma norm, designed to achieve coordinated motion among agents while ensuring collision avoidance and lattice formation. The proposed method is rigorously compared against a seminal classic flocking model and two advanced MPC-based strategies that incorporate lattice-structured cost functions. Through a series of statistical hypothesis tests, we demonstrate that the proposed approach reliably achieves the target lattice configuration, ensures convergence to a common velocity, and prevents collisions with both obstacles and neighboring agents. The results show that our method consistently outperforms existing approaches, offering superior performance and reliability for multi-agent systems modeled as omnidirectional four-wheeled robots.

title: Exact DoA Estimation in OTFS Radar Systems with Beam Squint Effect and Off-Grid Problem
authors: Jeong-Hoon Park, Seong-Cheol Kim, Seongwook Lee
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: In this paper, we propose an enhanced target parameter estimation method in orthogonal time-frequency space (OTFS) radar systems considering the beam squint effect, where the beam direction estimation depends on the signal frequency. First, the range-velocity (r-v) response of the received signal is obtained by the conventional matched filter to detect multiple targets and estimate r-v value of each target. Then, the estimated range value with error due to the beam squint effect and the offgrid problem causes serious performance degradation in direction of arrival (DoA) estimation. To solve issues, we propose the DoA estimation method considering the beam squint effect, which compensates for the range error and estimates the exact DoA by the gradient descent method. As a result, the proposed method improves the DoA estimation performance by overcoming the beam-squint effect and the off-grid problem.

title:
A 2.9mV
