                    Ripple 60mA Digital Low-Dropout Regulator in 28nm CMOS
authors: Wenxin Zhang, Yuhang Zhang, Yang Shen, Xiaojin Li, Bingyi Ye, Yabin Sun
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Integrated Circuits and Microsystems (ICICM)
abstract: This paper introduces a digital low-dropout regulator (DLDO) that improves low steady-state voltage ripples ($V_{\text {Ripp }}$) throughout a broad range of load currents ($I_{\text {load }}$) utilizing a high-resolution VCO-based ADC and a small unity PMOS current. The ADC is implemented with a pair of VCOs, an 8-bit binary counter, a Gray code counter, and a Gray-to-binary converter, enabling precise detection of small voltage deviations and allowing finer control of the PMOS array to reduce steady-state limit cycle oscillation (LCO) amplitude. Implemented in a 28nm CMOS process, this DLDO occupies a core size of $0.029 \mathrm{~mm}^{2}$. The simulation results indicate that the DLDO attains a $V_{\text {Ripp }}$ of 2.9 mV with $V_{\text {out }}$ at $1.4 \mathrm{~V}, V_{\text {in }}$ at 1.8 V, and $I_{\text {load }}$ at 60 mA. Additionally, with a 7- to- $55 \mathrm{~mA} 2-\mu \mathrm{s}$ load current step and a 100- pF on-chip capacitor, the output waveform indicates a $220-\mathrm{mV}$ voltage droop and a $\mathbf{3. 4} \boldsymbol{-} \boldsymbol{\mu}$ s settling time.

title: SCADA with Remote Monitoring System using GSM Technology
authors: Naresh Jella, D. Prasanth Sai, Vamshi Dhandugudum, G. Sandeep Rao, G Srikanth, Kalagotla Chenchireddy
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: The latest technological trend in industrial monitoring and control is the Supervisory Control and Data Acquisition (SCADA) system. The SCADA systems are the backbone of process automation. To take it a notch further, we integrated a feature that sends data about the power system under SCADA's control to the relevant mobile phone via GSM. Any digital information pertaining to any process automation developed with digital electronics may be automatically sent to any chosen mobile phone anywhere in the globe, thanks to the flexible and modern technology of GSM-based project activities. The primary goal of a supervisory control and data acquisition (SCADA) system is to digitize the analogue data from any power system's many channels, maintain constant watch over all information channels, automatically display the digital data from each channel by selecting the appropriate channel, and safeguard the power system through the implementation of control actions. [4]-[7] Complex devices that need constant vigilance and immediate response from operators greatly benefit from SCADA systems like this. There has been a lot of interest in SCADA systems, and almost every industry is trying to find ways to improve their operations with more sophisticated systems. As a result, we settled on this project's tasks and, to demonstrate our theory in practice, we built a single SCADA system for the power grid. Here, a single power transformer serves as a stand-in for an entire power system. A number of parameters pertaining to this transformer are continuously monitored, converted, and shown digitally. Additionally, control actions are put in place to prevent the transformer from overheating for a variety of reasons. Lastly, all of this data is automatically sent to a chosen mobile phone.

title: Leveraging Computer Vision and IoT for Optimized Last-Mile Delivery in Smart Logistics Systems
authors: Ravi Teja Jagarlamudi
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: Smart logistics systems also provide more efficient, accurate, and scalable last-mile delivery operations. Using real-time data provided by IoT-enabled sensors and advanced Computer Vision algorithms, the work introduces a system capable of dynamic route optimization, package detection, automatic parcel recognition, and delivery verification. We also propose a scalable architecture with edge computing support for low-latency decisions and cloud connectivity for centralized data management. Experimental results show significant improvements in delivery accuracy, operational efficiency, and resource utilization. By accelerating and optimizing the delivery processes, reducing delivery lead time and carbon footprints as well as increasing customer satisfaction, the proposed framework offers a contribution to sustainable urban logistics.

title: Interface Quality Improvement in Planar SiC MOSFETs Using Supercritical Fluid Nitriding
authors: Xiaoqing Bao, Lei Li, Lei Lu, Kuan-Chang Chang
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Integrated Circuits and Microsystems (ICICM)
abstract: This study investigates the application of supercritical fluid nitriding treatment to enhance the interface quality and electrical performance of planar silicon carbide (SiC) metal-oxide-semiconductor field-effect transistor (MOSFET) devices. Comprehensive electrical characterization was conducted through systematic comparison of output characteristics, transfer characteristics, and capacitance-voltage measurements before and after treatment to evaluate the effectiveness of this novel approach. The experimental results demonstrate substantial improvements in key device parameters following supercritical fluid nitriding treatment. The saturation drain current increased by approximately 100% at the highest gate voltage level, while transconductance characteristics showed enhanced gate control efficiency and carrier transport properties. The on-resistance decreased from $1270 \mathrm{~m} \Omega$ to $1090 \mathrm{~m} \Omega$, representing a 14% reduction in conduction losses. Capacitance-voltage measurements revealed reduced hysteresis and improved curve symmetry, confirming lower interface trap density and enhanced interface quality. The treatment process demonstrated excellent compatibility with existing fabrication technologies while maintaining gate oxide integrity. These findings establish supercritical fluid nitriding as a promising low-temperature approach for addressing the fundamental interface quality challenges in SiC MOSFET technology, offering significant potential for advancing wide-bandgap semiconductor applications in power electronics.

title: Nail Disorder Detection and Classification Using Deep Learning with EfficientNet-B3
authors: Bura Vijay Kumar, Ruchika Bhuria, Sonali Gupta, Vartika Aarwal
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: Nail disorders are critical clinical signs of the localized and systemic disease and timely diagnosis of the nail disorder is of great significance in the effective planning of the treatment. Abnormalities in the nails are subject to variability as they can be examined by hand and hence the necessity of automated and reliable diagnostic instruments. This paper introduces a computer-assisted nail disease classification system on the basis of deep learning with a fine-tuned EfficientNetB3 architecture, achieved with the help of the strength of transfer learning and compound scaling to improve feature extraction. The data includes 3,835 photos that belong to six categories, i. e. Acral Lentiginous Melanoma, Healthy Nail, Onychogryphosis, Blue Finger, Clubbing, and Pitting. Such preprocessing as resizing, normalization, and massive data augmentation were used to ensure sound training. To preserve generic visual features and fine-tune the upper layers to learn task-specific patterns, the EfficientNetB3 model was modified by freezing the lower convolutional layers, and a new classification head which included Global Average Pooling layer, dense ReLU activation, dropout, and softmax output had been implemented. The model was trained and verified with adoption of AdamW as an optimizer and categorical cross-entropy losses and early termination in preventing overfitting. The results of the experiments provided evidence that the suggested framework reached a total accuracy of 96% and equal precision, recall, and F1-scores of all the classes. These results illustrate why the fine-tuned EfficientNetB3 model is a successful predictor of nail disease to be used as a dependable automated nail disease detection tool and provide the opportunities to implement it into clinical diagnostics and telemedicine systems.

title: Smart Cultural Mapping: An Integrated Google Maps API and AI Chatbot Solution for Personalized Heritage Recommendation and Real-Time Preservation Reporting
authors: K. Karthikeyan, Sangamithra J T, Saranya T
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: Despite the cultural diversity of Tamil Nadu, awareness and preservation of the state's heritage sites have been steadily declining due to factors like rapid urbanization, a lack of digital documentation, and disjointed data management. The majority of the online resources currently available are static and do not offer interactive engagement, tailored recommendations, or real-time preservation feedback. These restrictions hinder the promotion and monitoring of lesser-known heritage sites and lower cultural engagement. The Smart Cultural Mapping project suggests an interactive heritage platform that combines a multilingual AI-powered chatbot with the Google Maps API to offer personalized recommendations and real-time preservation reporting. To increase user engagement, the platform makes use of 360° virtual tours, gamified cultural quizzes, and data-driven recommendations. The suggested system enables travel planning, visitor participation, and sustainable cultural preservation through community collaboration by combining geospatial mapping with intelligent automation.

title: A 28 – 32 Gb/s Wireline Receiver with A Genetic- Algorithm-Based Adaptive CTLE in 28 nm CMOS
authors: Yingjie Zhang, Fangxu Lv, Liangyong Yuan, Xiaoyue Hu, Ruixiao Kuai, Xianchao Zeng
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Integrated Circuits and Microsystems (ICICM)
abstract: A $28-32 \mathrm{~Gb} / \mathrm{s}$ wireline receiver with a genetic-algorithm-based adaptive continuous-time linear equalizer (CTLE) is presented in this paper. The proposed CTLE adopts adaptive genetic algorithm (AGA) to update coefficients, which has a stronger global search ability and lower power consumption, and it is less prone to local optima. Experimental results show that the receiver offers a wide gain tuning range and can equalize $\mathbf{8 - 1 4 ~ d B}$ channel insertion loss at $\mathbf{2 8 - 3 2 ~ G b} \boldsymbol{/} \mathbf{s}$. The receiver is fabricated in $\mathbf{2 8}-\mathbf{n m}$ technology and achieves a bit error rate (BER) below $10^{-9}$.

title: Waves of Imagination: Unconditional Spectrogram Generation using Diffusion Architectures
authors: Rahul Vanukuri, Shafi Ullah Khan, Talip Tolga Sarı, Gokhan Secinti, Diego Patiño, Debashri Roy
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: The growing demand for effective spectrum management and interference mitigation in shared bands, such as the Citizens Broadband Radio Service (CBRS), requires robust radar detection algorithms to protect the military transmission from interference due to commercial wireless transmission. These algorithms, in turn, depend on large, diverse, and carefully labeled spectrogram datasets. However, collecting and annotating real-world radio frequency (RF) spectrogram data remains a significant challenge, as radar signals are rare, and their occurrences are infrequent. This challenge makes the creation of balanced datasets difficult, limiting the performance and generalizability of AI models in this domain. To address this critical issue, we propose a diffusion-based generative model for synthesizing realistic and diverse spectrograms of five distinct categories that integrate LTE, 5G, and radar signals within the CBRS band. We conduct a structural and statistical fidelity analysis of the generated spectrograms using widely accepted evaluation metrics Structural Similarity Index Measure (SSIM) and Peak Signal-to-Noise Ratio (PSNR), to quantify their divergence from the training data. Furthermore, we demonstrate that pre-training on the generated spectrograms significantly improves training efficiency on a real-world radar detection task by enabling 51.5% faster convergence.

title: Attention-Enhanced Deep CNN Framework for Efficient Brain Tumor Classification
authors: G.R.L.M Tayaru, Kallepalli Rohit Kumar, Ninitha Mary Antonina N M, G. Prasanthi, J. David Sukeerthi Kumar, A. Lakshmanarao
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: Brain tumor classification plays a vital role in medical image analysis, where accurate detection is essential for early diagnosis and effective treatment planning. This paper introduces AttentionBrainNet, an attention-enhanced deeplearning framework that improves tumor recognition from MRI scans using channel and spatial attention mechanisms. A baseline Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) is first implemented to learn fundamental spatial features. To enhance focus on significant tumor regions, a Squeeze-and-Excitation (SE)–based CNN model is developed as an intermediate improvement. Finally, a Convolutional Block Attention Module (CBAM) is integrated with the CNN to form the proposed model, which adaptively refines feature maps by emphasizing relevant areas while suppressing background noise. The models were trained and validated on a brain MRI dataset collected from Kaggle. Comparative results showed that the proposed CBAM-based architecture achieved superior accuracy, stability, and robustness compared to the baseline and SE-based models. The framework demonstrates promising potential for computer-aided diagnosis and real-time clinical applications.

title: Near-Pilotless Single Carrier Communications Using Matrix Decomposition
authors: K. Sai Praneeth, P. Aswathylakshmi, Radha Krishna Ganti
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: Single Input-Multiple Output (SIMO) systems are key enablers of high data rates in the next generation wireless communications. However in SIMO systems, channel estimation and equalization are challenging particularly in the presence of rapidly changing channels. The high pilot overhead required for channel estimation can reduce the system throughput for large antenna configuration. In this paper, we provide an iterative matrix decomposition algorithm for near-pilotless or blind decoding of SIMO signals, in a single carrier system with frequency domain equalization. This novel approach replaces the standard equalization and estimates both the transmitted data and the channel without the knowledge of any prior distributions, by making use of only one pilot. Our simulations demonstrate improved performance, in terms of error rates, compared to the more widely used pilot-based Maximal Ratio Combining (MRC) method.

title: High-Accuracy Beat-By-Beat Arrhythmia Detection from MIT-BIH ECG Data using Deep 1D CNN Learning
authors: Kalaiamudhan S, V Purushothaman, Lakshmi D
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: Cardiovascular disorders are the major causes of death in the world, and the cardiac arrhythmias are one of the critical categories, which necessitates their early identification. Analyses of the electrocardiograms (ECGs) are time consuming and prone to errors, which especially commonly occur with rare or subtle arrhythmias, taking place manually. This work provides a complete automated design that utilizes a OneDimensional Convolutional Neural Network (1D CNN) to detect ECG heartbeats of 5 clinically meaningful categories (Normal, N, Right Bundle Branch Block, R, Left Bundle Branch Block, L, Premature Ventricular Contraction, V and Atrial Premature Contraction, A) according to AAMI standard. The model is directly applied to unprocessed signals and uses segmented data on the MIT-BIH Arrhythmia Database to get the temporal features without any preprocessing or manual feature engineering. Trained on 10 optimal epochs, it recorded 96.72% test accuracy and high F1-scores on each of the classes, and as such, it could have strong clinical applications in early disease detection, resource balancing, and remote cardiac monitoring. Only detailed performance measures, confusion matrices and ROC confirm performance reliability in classifying common and uncommon arrhythmias.

title: Hybrid Genetic Algorithm–Neural Network Model for Fertilizer Recommendation and Crop Yield Prediction
authors: Narmada B, Saravanakumar R., Gnanasekar V, Gulzar Begam J, Soundharya G, Geetha G
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: The backbone of economic growth is agriculture, and the future depends on increasing crop output through efficient fertiliser usage. Crop requirements, climate variability, and soil nutrient uncertainty are difficult for traditional models to account for. A hybrid genetic algorithm–neural network (GA–NN) model for predicting crop production and recommending fertiliser is presented in this research. While neural networks effectively record irregular interactions among soil, climate, and crop characteristics, genetic algorithms are used for optimal feature selection. According to experimental evaluation, the suggested model outperforms traditional techniques with 92% precision, 0.38 t/ha RMSE for yield prediction, and 96% accuracy for fertiliser recommendation. By combining GA and NN, a viable, precise, and effective precision agriculture framework is demonstrated, improving farmer productivity and sustainable farming methods.

title: Optimizing Canteen Operations : A Digital Approach to Queue Management
authors: P.Poovizhi, Brindhasri S, Harthika S, Karishma Subramanian, Kavipriya N, Dharani K
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: Optimizing Canteen Operations is an application based on mobile used to streamline canteen operations and minimize waiting times for students during college breaks. The system facilitates students to pre-order meals, choose pickup times, and make payments online through a friendly login interface, while an admin login provides canteen staff with facilities to manage orders, update the menu, and monitor sales in an efficient manner. In order to further improve operational effectiveness and customer experience, the app incorporates machine learning methods to forecast peak order hours, suggest foods according to individual taste and order history, predict sales patterns, and customize menu offerings. Such smart capabilities assist canteen personnel in managing inventory proactively, saving food, and providing customized services. Overall, the system provides advantages of shortened waiting times for the students, optimized canteen functioning, higher student satisfaction, enhanced sales for vendors, and real-time data-based management of orders. Implementation technical requirements include Android mobile app development, backend development for database management and API integration, deployment of machine learning models, integration of payment gateway, and integration of SMS notification system, for college students, canteen workers and vendors, and college administrators.

title: Real-Time IoT Framework for Efficient Water and Nutrient Management in Horticulture
authors: S. Bindhu, Kujani T
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: Effectively managing crop water and nutrient use has been shown to increase crop yields and support sustainable Horticulture practices. This work presents a IoT framework to optimize irrigation and fertigation using soil sensors, smart control algorithms and cloud monitoring. The framework enables continuous measurement of soil moisture, pH, and electrical conductivity (EC) to a cloud server in real-time. The smart decision-making algorithm autonomously controls and operates pumps and solenoid valve to optimize soil growing conditions. After being field deployed for a 45-day growing season, the IoT-based framework produced a 20% increase in plant growth index, and a 28% reduction in water to the irrigation system. The results provide evidence that using IoT to intercept, monitor, decisions maker and autonomous operate can improve Water Use Efficiency (WUE) and Nutrient Use Efficiency (NUE) for edible crops. The framework is proposed in this research paper is a scalable data driven solution for precision Horticulture in sustainable Horticulture practices.

title: Design and Nonlinear Analysis of a Multi-Stepped MEMS Resonator with 1:3 Internal Resonance
authors: Peilong Li, Yu Jin
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Integrated Circuits and Microsystems (ICICM)
abstract: This study develops a nonlinear dynamic framework for capacitive MEMS resonators exhibiting 1:3 internal resonance. The Adomian Decomposition Method (ADM) is used to analytically model the mode shapes and frequency ratios of multi-stepped beams, enabling precise control of modal coupling. Nonlinear stiffness parameters are extracted using a static load method, based on which a Duffing-type vibration model is established incorporating both linear and cubic stiffness, as well as DC bias and AC excitation. Multi-scale analysis is applied to derive internal resonance conditions. The analytical model further reveals how excitation parameters influence the nonlinear behavior of the resonator. Additionally, frequencydomain analysis confirms the presence of mechanically generated frequency combs. COMSOL simulations show close agreement with theoretical predictions. This approach provides a compact and effective methodology for analyzing MEMS resonators with controllable nonlinear dynamics, offering new insights into microscale nonlinear phenomena.

title: Machine Learning-based Receiver Scheduling for Electronic Support
authors: Vaibhav Sekhar, Gottfried Lechner, Khoa Nguyen, Simon Faulkner
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: Electronic Support (ES) relies on intercept receivers to gain situational awareness of emitters operating in the electromagnetic environment. Due to sensitivity and Size, Weight and Power (SWaP) constraints, the receive bandwidth of intercept receivers is typically smaller than the total bandwidth of the Radio Frequency (RF) spectrum to be monitored. Consequently, ES intercept receivers rely on scheduling algorithms that dictate which frequency band to monitor and when. Traditional schedulers rely on knowledge of emitters expected in the electromagnetic environment and their operating characteristics. However, reliable intelligence on emitters is not always available. In this paper, we present a machine-learning (ML) based approach with a focus on intercepting periodic-scan emitters. We use Double Deep-Q-Networks (Double DQN), a form of Deep Reinforcement Learning (DRL), to develop a model-free neural-network-based receiver scheduler. We train and test the scheduler on simulated electromagnetic environments based on realistic emitters. We analyse the interception performance of our scheduler over various scenarios, using test parameters within and out-of-range of our model’s training parameters. The results show that our ML-based scheduler is capable of developing a robust schedule across emitters with different transmission characteristics. Unlike traditional schedulers, our ML-based scheduling technique does not require prior knowledge of emitter characteristics.

title: Intelligent Multi-Objective Optimization Framework for Electric Vehicle Charging Energy Management using Hybrid Machine Learning and Deep Learning Approaches
authors: D. Sungeetha
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: The rapid adoption of electric vehicles (EVs) necessitates intelligent energy management systems to optimize charging efficiency, reduce costs, and extend battery lifespan. This paper presents a novel hybrid ensemble framework that combines gradient boosting algorithms (XGBoost, LightGBM, CatBoost) with Deep Neural Networks (DNNs) for multi-objective optimization of EV charging energy management. We developed an advanced feature engineering pipeline incorporating 24 temporal-spatial features and conducted comprehensive comparative analysis across 11 machine learning algorithms using a dataset of 1,320 real-world charging sessions. The proposed Hybrid Ensemble model achieved exceptional performance with an R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> score of 0.9897 for energy consumption prediction and 0.8478 for charging cost prediction, representing a 0.65% improvement over traditional Random Forest baselines. The framework incorporates multi-target prediction capabilities for simultaneous optimization of energy consumption, charging cost, duration, and efficiency. Feature importance analysis revealed that temperature efficiency, battery capacity, and charging rate are the most critical factors influencing energy consumption. The system also includes an intelligent recommendation module for personalized charging strategies. The results demonstrate that hybrid ensemble approaches combining tree-based gradient boosting with deep learning significantly outperform individual algorithms, achieving RMSE of 2.17 kWh and MAE of 1.45 kWh for energy prediction. This research contributes to sustainable transportation by enabling more efficient EV charging infrastructure management and provides a scalable framework for real-time energy optimization in smart grid applications.

title: Multi-Hop Relay-Aided Task Offloading for Tactical Edge Computing
authors: Zhaofeng Zhang, Xuanli Lin, Guoliang Xue, Yanchao Zhang, Kevin S. Chan
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: Recent years have witnessed explosive growth in the deployment of IoT devices over tactical edge networks, which demand flexible task offloading strategies to accommodate limited connectivity and computing resources. While many existing works assume direct access to edge servers, such assumptions often break down in adversarial and dynamic environments. This work introduces a novel edge task offloading framework that enables multi-hop communication and enables task execution not only at edge servers but also at relay nodes and local devices. We formulate the problem of joint task offloading, resource allocation, and time frame/slot assignment, under a timedivision multiple access (TDMA) uplink scheme, as a nonlinear integer program to maximize total rewards, subject to various communication and resource constraints. To solve it optimally, we first construct a feasibility-aware directed graph that captures valid communication links based on signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) constraints, and then design a dynamic programming (DP) algorithm that integrates slot-minimizing offloading path selection with the assignment of the largest feasible number of time frames for each user to reduce total time slots consumption without violating task completion deadlines. To improve scalability, efficient heuristics are developed using scaling and rounding techniques. Extensive experiments demonstrate that our proposed DP algorithm achieves optimal task offloading and resource allocation, while our heuristic algorithms offer a computationally efficient alternative with competitive performance.

title: Jamming Smarter, Not Harder: Exploiting O-RAN Y1 RAN Analytics for Efficient Interference
authors: Abiodun Ganiyu, Dara Ron, Syed Rafiul Hussain, Vijay K Shah
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: The Y1 interface in O-RAN enables the sharing of RAN Analytics Information (RAI) between the near-RT RIC and authorized Y1 consumers, which may be internal applications within the operator’s trusted domain or external systems accessing data through a secure exposure function. While this visibility enhances network optimization and enables advanced services, it also introduces a potential security risk – a malicious or compromised Y1 consumer could misuse analytics to facilitate targeted interference. In this work, we demonstrate how an adversary can exploit the Y1 interface to launch selective jamming attacks by passively monitoring downlink metrics. We propose and evaluate two Y1-aided jamming strategies: a clustering-based jammer leveraging DBSCAN for traffic profiling and a threshold-based jammer. These are compared against two baselines strategies – always-on jammer and random jammer – on an over-the-air LTE/5G O-RAN testbed. Experimental results show that in unconstrained jamming budget scenarios, the threshold-based jammer can closely replicate the disruption caused by always-on jamming while reducing transmission time by 27%. Under constrained jamming budgets, the clustering-based jammer proves most effective, causing up to an 18.1% bitrate drop while remaining active only 25% of the time. These findings reveal a critical trade-off between jamming stealthiness and efficiency, and illustrate how exposure of RAN analytics via the Y1 interface can enable highly targeted, low-overhead attacks, raising important security considerations for both civilian and mission-critical O-RAN deployments.

title: Residual Network-Driven Diagnostic Framework for Multi-Class Nail Pathology Classification
authors: Gotte Ranjith Kumar, Vishnu Kant, Manika Manwal, Gagan Bansal
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: Nail disorders are crucial indicators of local and systemic health status, hence warranting early and correct diagnosis for timely intervention. In this research, we introduce a deep learning-based method with a fine-tuned ResNet18 model for automatic classification of six nail disorders: Acral Lentiginous Melanoma, Healthy Nail, Onychogryphosis, Blue Finger, Clubbing, and Pitting. The data set, obtained from Kaggle, consisted of 3,835 labeled images, which were split between the training and validation subsets in an 80:20 ratio. The images were preprocessed and normalized and subjected to augmentation in order to enhance generalization. The fine-tuned ResNet18 model resulted in overall accuracy of 94%, clearly showing robust performance across all the classes. Classification report metrics showed high recall and precision and F1-scores between 0.90 and 0.98. The confusion matrix also supported accurate classification with small misclassifications between visually close classes like Blue Finger and Clubbing. Training and validation curves showed stable convergence with low overfitting, further supporting the strength of the proposed approach. This study adds to advancing artificial intelligence in medical diagnosis by providing an effective, scalable, and inexpensive diagnostic system. The results directly contribute to worldwide action for good health and well-being, innovation in the medical technology, decreased inequality in accessing healthcare, and facilitating sustainable development through early disease prevention and enhanced healthcare provision.

title: Research on SoC Chip System Modeling for Noise Suppression and Self-organizing Communication Integration for Distributed Photovoltaics
authors: Quan Sun, Gang Chen, Changyou Men, Shuang Wu
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Integrated Circuits and Microsystems (ICICM)
abstract: With the large-scale deployment of distributed photovoltaic power generation systems, inter-system communication noise interference and network self-organizing capabilities have become key factors affecting power generation efficiency and system stability. This paper proposes a SoC chip system architecture that integrates noise suppression and selforganizing communication. By establishing a mathematical model and designing a dedicated algorithm, efficient communication and intelligent coordination of distributed photovoltaic systems are achieved. First, a noise model of the distributed photovoltaic communication network is established, and the impact of electromagnetic interference on communication quality is analyzed. Second, a noise suppression algorithm based on adaptive filtering and a layered self-organizing communication protocol are designed. Finally, a SoC chip architecture design scheme integrating these functions is proposed. Simulation results show that the proposed system can maintain a communication success rate of over 95% in strong noise environments, shorten the network self-organizing time by 40%, and improve overall system efficiency by 15%. This research provides important technical support for the intelligent upgrade of distributed photovoltaic systems.

title: Quality-Related Fault Detection Based on Reversible Instance Normalization Temporal Auto-Encoder Canonical Correlation Analysis
authors: Bing Song, Xuanyu Gu, Hongbo Shi, Jiahao Zhou, Yang Tao, Li Wang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Industrial Informatics
abstract: In contemporary industrial processes, factors such as raw material fluctuations and noise interference lead to significant changes in the statistical characteristics of data over time, resulting in nonstationary behavior. This nonstationary tends to obscure fault-related information in industrial systems, posing severe challenges for quality-related fault detection. This article proposes a method named reversible instance normalization temporal autoencoder (TAE) canonical correlation analysis (CCA) for quality related fault detection. First, this method quantifies the interdependencies among variables to select process variables that are highly correlated with quality indicators. Subsequently, a reversible normalization module dynamically adjusts normalization parameters to achieve local stationarization of process data. Furthermore, a TAE is utilized to extract temporal features from processed data. Then, a CCA model is established by integrating quality indicators, enabling efficient monitoring of quality indicator under nonstationary conditions. Finally, the proposed method was tested and validated in two real industrial cases.

title: A Comprehensive Review of Fault-Tolerant Non-Isolated DC–DC Converters for Critical Applications: Active and Passive Redundancy Approaches
authors: J Divya Navamani, K Boopathi, A Lavanya, Pradeep Vishnuram, Mohit Bajaj, Vojtech Blazek
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: Reliability in most of the power converters used in critical applications is achieved by incorporating fault-tolerance features. In this paper, various fault-tolerant dc-dc converters proposed with active and inactive redundancy are reviewed and compared to gain an understanding of the prominent solutions. Guidelines for the selection of a fuse are presented with computation for various input switching current waveforms. Various fault-tolerant configuration with active redundancy is derived and discussed. Multiport DC–DC converters inherently exhibit fault-tolerant characteristics owing to the availability and flexible utilization of multiple input sources. This paper presents an overview of selected converter topologies in which component-level redundancy is strategically employed to enhance reliability and fault tolerance. In addition, relevant IEEE and IEC codes and standards for diverse applications are examined, with a particular focus on protection and safety requirements. This study also emphasizes the need of proactive adherence to standards and codes to address the protection mechanisms and avoid fault occurrences, thereby ensuring reliable operation. Moreover, the study identifies the fault-prone elements within critical power-conditioning converter components. Experimental results of a fault-tolerant quadratic boost converter with 2-level redundancy are presented. This article will offer valuable design guidelines for researchers working in this area to enhance the reliability of high-gain dc-dc converters. In conclusion, key open research challenges and several recommendations for future research analysis are emphasized.

title: Toward State Estimation Algorithms in Cooperative Positioning: A Comprehensive Framework Design and Its Realization
authors: Guangteng Fan, Ruichen Zhang, Lu Cao, Xi Chen
publish: IEEE Transactions on Intelligent Transportation Systems
abstract: Cooperative positioning enhances localization accuracy in intelligent artifact swarms through shared measurements, especially in environments such as urban canyons or disaster zones. Dynamic topologies, heterogeneous measurements, and scalability demands create complex challenges for state estimation. This paper introduces MRCA, the first comprehensive framework unifying heterogeneous measurements, reasoning processes, environment cognition, and scenario-based applications for cooperative positioning. The four-layer architecture comprises: i) the Measurement block converts signals into measurement parameters in a standard format independent of sensor types and measurement methods; ii) the Reasoning block uncovers the underlying principles of state transition using a four reasoning elements; iii) the Cognition block underscores the importance of node-environment interactions by identifying new valid radiation sources and verifying the ongoing validity of existing ones; iv) the Application block offers users task-driven cooperative positioning services, like execute potential navigation actions. Our proposed framework demonstrates performance improvements in various key metrics compared to legacy swarm positioning algorithms. Focusing on the framework itself, we employ the most basic algorithms within each block, and the experimental results are as follows: In scenarios featuring static unknown anchors, sparse perception, and collision interference, MRCA reduces cumulative positioning error by over 51% for dead-reckoning and 39% for traditional distributed cooperative positioning, while reducing average orientation error by over 31% and 27%, respectively. Running on <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">${\$}5$</tex-math> </inline-formula> consumer-grade IMUs, MRCA achieves a final RMSE of 10.27 m, outperforming even a <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">${\$}1~500$</tex-math> </inline-formula> industrial-grade IMU in dead-reckoning mode (11.99 m). Through the validation of real - scene datasets, the paper illustrates how this framework integrates into system-level solutions for real-world implementation, further advancing the theoretical understanding of state estimation in cooperative positioning systems.

title: Spatial–Temporal Transformers With Stochastic Time-Warping and Joint-Wise Encoding for Rehabilitation Exercise Assessment
authors: Tanawat Matangkasombut, Wuttipong Kumwilaisak, Chatchawarn Hansakunbuntheung, Nattanun Thatphithakkul
publish: IEEE Open Journal of the Computer Society
abstract: Accurate and objective assessment of rehabilitation exercises is critical for ensuring correct execution and maximizing patient recovery, particularly in unsupervised or home-based settings. Existing deep learning approaches frequently rely on graph-based skeletal representations with predefined topologies, which constrain the discovery of long-range or task-specific joint dependencies and limit adaptability across datasets with varying skeletal definitions. To address these limitations, we propose a Spatial–Temporal Transformer framework that directly models 3D joint position data without requiring an explicit adjacency matrix. The framework incorporates a joint-wise feature encoding and structure embedding mechanism to provide unique representations for each joint, thereby mitigating ambiguities arising from symmetry or overlapping movements. Furthermore, a stochastic time-warping augmentation strategy is introduced to simulate execution speed variations, enhancing robustness to diverse patient movement patterns. By applying small, randomized temporal scaling to local segments while consistently interpolating spatial coordinates within temporal boundaries, this stochastic variation enriches the dataset significantly while preserving the biomechanical patterns. Experimental results on the KIMORE dataset demonstrate that the proposed method reduces mean absolute deviation (MAD) by 67.4 % relative to the current state of the art, while also maintaining strong generalization on the UI-PRMD dataset. The approach is compatible with multiple pose estimation algorithms and acquisition modalities, making it suitable for deployment in real-world telerehabilitation and clinical monitoring applications.

title: Adaptability of Vision Foundation Models for 3D Medical Image Segmentation
authors: Suhyun Ahn, Donggyu Lee, Jinah Park
publish: IEEE Open Journal of Signal Processing
abstract: Vision Foundation Models (VFMs), such as DINOv2 and SAM, have demonstrated unprecedented generalizability in natural imaging and show strong promise in medical imaging due to their semantically rich representations. However, their effective application to 3D volumetric segmentation remains largely underexplored, especially concerning optimal adaptation strategies for transferring 2D pretrained knowledge to the structurally disparate 3D domain. To address this, we present a comprehensive investigation into the transferability and task-specific adaptability of six diverse 2D VFMs (including Self- Supervised, Vision-Language, and Segmentation Generalists) for 3D medical image segmentation. We systematically evaluate four distinct transfer learning paradigms, including advanced Fine-Tuning methods, across four heterogeneous 3D medical datasets. Our results establish VFMs as a powerful and cost-effective generalist baseline, consistently outperforming non-pretrained and standard 3D ViT architectures despite the substantial domain shift. Crucially, our systematic exploration reveals that parameter-efficient finetuning achieves the highest segmentation accuracy across all datasets. Feature-level analyses using PCA and CKA provide key insights, confirming that optimal performance stems from successfully balancing the preservation of generalizable low-level visual features with the adaptation of high-level, task-specific semantics.

title: A High-Efficiency Reconfigurable Charge Pump With Full Capacitance Utilization and Two-Dimensional Multiphase Interleaving
authors: Ziliang Zhou, Zhenhao Li, Xi Deng, Mingyang Gong, Min Tan
publish: IEEE Transactions on Circuits and Systems II: Express Briefs
abstract: This paper presents a reconfigurable high-voltage charge pump with regulated output, designed to deliver high efficiency across a wide operating range. Different from previous designs, the charge pump is reconfigured by connecting unit cells in series or parallel, achieving full capacitance utilization and hence improved power efficiency. The stage reconfiguration circuit is implemented without using high-voltage tolerant devices and allows modularity and scalability. Two-dimensional multiphase interleaving is proposed to enhance power efficiency while reducing the input current ripple and output voltage ripple. The system was fabricated in a 55 nm standard CMOS process occupying a core area of 470 μm by 225 μm. Experimental results indicate the maximum increase in efficiency for different load currents is 10%. The peak efficiency increases from 46.2% to 51.4% at a 150-μA load and 8-V output while achieving >42% overall efficiency.
