title: ScaleRSNet: Advancing Remote Sensing Image Segmentation with Multi-Scale Contextual Attention Mechanisms
authors: Zhanran Liang, Minyi Li
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: Remote sensing image semantic segmentation faces critical challenges including extreme object scale variations, severe class imbalance, spectral similarity, and background noise. These challenges often lead to inaccurate boundary delineation and misclassification of small objects. To address these limitations, ScaleRSNet is proposed, a novel deep learning architecture designed to handle multi-scale objects through a hierarchical multi-scale feature learning framework. ScaleRSNet integrates a hierarchical encoder, multi-scale contextual aggregation, spatial feature transformation, and a cross-layer fusion decoder. The hierarchical encoder employs dilated convolutions with progressively increasing dilation rates to capture fine-grained details and broader context across multiple scales. Spatial attention mechanisms selectively enhance discriminative features and refine segmentation boundaries for small or fragmented objects. Experimental results demonstrate that ScaleRSNet achieves 69.62% mPA and 82.16% accuracy on the WHDLD dataset, representing improvements of 19.09% in mPA and 10.88% in accuracy compared to the baseline UNet. On the EarthVQA dataset, ScaleRSNet achieves 45.65% mPA and 60.02% accuracy, representing improvements of 20.15% in mPA and 22.24% in accuracy compared to UNet. Grad-CAM visualizations demonstrate the model’s ability to focus on relevant areas during inference, providing insights into its decision-making process. These results confirm that ScaleRSNet offers a robust solution for remote sensing image segmentation, delivering superior performance in diverse environments.

title: SIA-KalmanNet: A Structurally-Integrated Attention Kalman Filter for Multi-UAV Localization in Partially GNSS-Denied Environments
authors: Xiuli Xin, Hongyu Zhou, Xiaoxue Feng, Feng Pan, Jiacheng Wang, Zhenxu Li
publish: IEEE Internet of Things Journal
abstract: Cooperative localization is an essential task in multi-unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) networks, especially in environments with partial Global Navigation Satellite System (GNSS) denial. By effectively integrating low-precision Inertial Navigation System (INS)-derived priors, inter-UAV relative distances, and sparse anchor-based measurements, the Extended Kalman Filter (EKF) can be employed for UAV localization. However, localization accuracy suffers under nonlinear dynamics and inaccurate knowledge of process and measurement noise statistics. To address these challenges, this paper proposes a Structurally-Integrated Attention Kalman Filter called SIA-KalmanNet for accurate and robust state estimation. By combining state-space models with attention-based neural networks in the Kalman flow, the estimator preserves the data efficiency and interpretability of traditional model-driven methods while implicitly learning second-order covariance matrices from data. Specifically, two networks are devised to learn the Kalman gain: the Self-Attention Residual Masked Network (SA-RMN) and the Self-Cross Attention Residual Masked Network (SCA-RMN). Among them, SA-RMN is a lightweight network for end-to-end state estimation. SCA-RMN introduces masked cross-attention to adaptively fuse forward state features and backward historical correction information to obtain a more precise state estimate. Furthermore, a practical training strategy based on sliding window and causal masking is developed to ensure efficient training and real-time inference. Experimental results show that the proposed algorithm achieves superior localization performance compared to the traditional EKF and KalmanNets. Moreover, it exhibits strong robustness against INS drift and non-line-of-sight (NLOS)-induced distance errors, even in harsh environments where only a limited number of UAVs can access GNSS signals.

title: A Deep Reinforcement Learning-Based Hyper-Heuristic for Time-Dependent Green Logistics With Crowdsourcing_supp1-3641646.pdf
authors: Kang Li
publish: N/A
abstract: The rapid growth of e-commerce has increased the complexity of supply chain management, particularly in urban logistics where efficiency and sustainability are critical concerns. In response, this study proposes a selection hyper-heuristic framework for time-dependent green logistics, incorporating key factors such as economic costs, carbon emissions, rider types, real-time traffic conditions, and time-window constraints. To address the complexities introduced by these real-world factors, we design a two-layer distribution model with crowdsourced delivery that covers the flow from city distribution centers to regional hubs and ultimately to end customers. The first layer involves location selection and the delivery process, while the second layer focuses on order allocation and last-mile delivery. For the location selection and order allocation problems, exact optimization models are developed to obtain high-quality solutions. In the delivery process, we integrate Deep Reinforcement Learning to replace the traditional adaptive layer of the Adaptive Large Neighborhood Search algorithm, enabling dynamic and intelligent adjustments during the search. Comparative analyses against existing and traditional methods across various benchmark instances demonstrate the superior efficiency and solution quality of the proposed framework. Simulation experiments based on a real-world road network in China validate the effectiveness of the proposed framework. In addition, the well-trained model can be directly applied to various scenarios, highlighting its strong generalization capability.

title: Dual-Population Evolution-Based Collaborative Optimization for Coordinated UAVs Mission Patrol Under Mountainous Environments
authors: Yunhe Wang, Wenyuan Xiao, Dong Wang, Yajuan Zhang, Qingda Chen, Shengxiang Yang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Emerging Topics in Computational Intelligence
abstract: Uncrewed aerial vehicles (UAVs) play a crucial role in visiting task points to support sector surveillance and maintain environmental and operational stability in mountainous mission patrols. Completing UAV patrol missions requires determining an optimal sequence for visiting task points and planning feasible paths to ensure the UAV safety in the presence of diverse peaks, valleys, and infeasible regions in mountainous environments. To address these issues, we propose a dual-population evolution-based collaborative optimization algorithm (DECOA) for coordinated UAV mission patrol, encompassing both UAV task assignment and path planning, in mountainous environments. First, we design a comprehensive model to represent mountainous environments accurately. Then, DECOA is proposed to address the UAV mission patrol optimization problem using a population-evolution framework applied to the constructed model. In DECOA, two distinct particle encoding schemes are introduced to efficiently convert task assignment and path planning solutions in UAV mission patrol models into representations suitable for optimization processing. Additionally, a dynamic dual-population search strategy is devised to balance exploration and exploitation capabilities. To enhance the global search capability of DECOA in promising regions, an adaptive collaboration mechanism is proposed. Furthermore, to evaluate the performance of DECOA, various scenarios are designed to conduct extensive experiments, focusing on UAV task assignment, path planning, and coordinated mission patrol. The experimental results demonstrate the superiority of the proposed algorithm and validate the effectiveness of the designed test scenarios.

title: Design for Hardware Acceleration of Signature Verification in PQC Stateless Hash-Based Digital Signature Algorithm
authors: Haoran Liu, Liji Wu, Lei Li, Yifan Yang, Xiangmin Zhang
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Integrated Circuits and Microsystems (ICICM)
abstract: A hardware design of SLH-DSA signature verification is proposed for efficient deployment in post-quantum cryptographic systems. Based on the SPHINCS<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">+</sup> framework selected by NIST, the architecture utilizes FORS and WOTS<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">+</sup> schemes with SHA-256 to achieve stateless operation and quantum resistance. The verification pipeline integrates message hashing, signature decoding, public key reconstruction, and Merkle root validation, implemented through a pipelined and FSM-controlled data-path. Synthesized on an Intel Cyclone IV EP4CE115 FPGA, the design achieves a latency of 1.854 ms and supports a throughput of $\mathbf{8 3 9}$ verifications per second at $\mathbf{1 0 0 ~ M H z}$. Postsynthesis power analysis reports 32.4 mW dynamic core power and an energy cost of $60.08 \mu \mathrm{~J}$ per verification. The fully self-contained architecture eliminates the need for external processors and offers a scalable, low-power solution for embedded postquantum applications. The results confirm both functional correctness and practical efficiency, making it suitable for real-world deployment.

title: A Novel Hybrid Switching Scheme for SAR ADC with High Efficiency and High Linearity
authors: Yushi Chen, Ying Li, Fang Liang, Zewen Wang, Zuoru Dong, Xiaodong Wang
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Integrated Circuits and Microsystems (ICICM)
abstract: This paper gives a hybrid switching scheme specifically designed for successive approximation register (SAR) analog-to-digital converter (ADC). The presented scheme does not require energy consumption during the first three cycles by utilizing zero energy consumption switching technique (ZECST). Moreover, a multi-level switching technique (MLST) is applied during remaining cycles to further improve efficiency. Based on above two techniques, a reduction of 99.48% in switching energy and 75% in the number of capacitors has been achieved. The presented method exhibits a DNL of 0.162 LSB and an INL of 0.167LSB.

title: SmartTarget-Algo: Cross-Domain User Interest Modeling System via Graph Neural Networks
authors: Yang Lanyan
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: In cross-domain recommendation tasks, user behavior exhibits complex characteristics of the dynamism, nonlinearity, and heterogeneity across different platforms. Therefore, addressing the difficulty of accurately modeling user interest migration and evolution under the single-domain assumption of traditional recommendation algorithms, this paper proposes a cross-domain user interest modeling system based on Graph Neural Networks (GNNs), named SmartTarget-Algo. This system employs a dual-channel hybrid structure, collaboratively capturing short-term behavioral changes and long-term interest preferences in both sequential and unordered dependency layers. Furthermore, as an innovation, a Multi-View Hypergraph Convolution (MV-HGC) mechanism is introduced to model higher-order coupling relationships across domains. This innovation enables the diffusion and migration of interest features across different domains. Simultaneously, the model designs a location-aware dynamic attention mechanism, adaptively adjusting user interest weights in both temporal and semantic dimensions. This operation enhances the model's ability to express multi-level semantic associations. During the inference phase, SmartTarget-Algo generates cross-domain interest score vectors through multi-hop neighborhood diffusion and hyperedge aggregation. This fusion modeling achieves globally consistent interest structure modeling. This paper conducts large-scale comparative experiments on three composite datasets: Edu-Shop, Video-News, and Music-Travel. Performance comparisons with six benchmark algorithms are also performed to verify the overall performance. Experimental results show that SmartTarget-Algo achieves significant improvements across all evaluation metrics. Specifically, compared to sequence recommendation models GRU4Rec and SASRec, it improves HR@10 and NDCG@10 by approximately 9.3% and 6.8%, respectively. Compared to graph structure models GC-SR, HGNN-Cross, and SeHGNN, it improves MRR and AUC by 3.5% and 3.2%, respectively. Furthermore, in sparse user scenarios, SmartTarget-Algo achieves a 31.6% improvement in HR@10. Performance tests show that model has approximately 10.4M parameters and a forward inference latency of 18.5 ms in a single-card V100 environment.

title: A Comparative Analysis of Enhanced MIMO-FSO Communication with PSK Modulation for Long-Range Optical Links
authors: Geerthana S, Shankar Sharma K J, Reni Gideon J, Thanush Saran S
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: The efficient wireless communication solution for high speed, secure, over long distances is offered by Free Space Optical (FSO) communication. To design a MIMO FSO system capable of long-range communication with stable operation over a distance of 10 km under 5dB attenuation using PSK Modulation in comparison to various atmospheric conditions like Haze, Rain, Mist, Snow, and Mid-fog is the objective which is simulated using OPTISYSTEM 7.0 software. This work evaluates the ability of different modulation techniques, under varying atmospheric conditions and comparative analysis of the best system for effective communication with a particular focus on Phase Shift Keying (PSK). The attenuation, line of sight, bit rate, quality factor, received power, bit error rate and signal quality, are the FSO parameters analyzed to optimize the system performance. The simulation results provided insights about the PSK modulation in maintaining reliable communication for long-distance MIMO FSO links.

title: GPU-GLMB: Assessing the Scalability of GPU-Accelerated Multi-Hypothesis Tracking
authors: Pranav Balakrishnan, Sidisha Barik, Sean M. O’Rourke, Benjamin M. Marlin
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: Much recent research on multi-target tracking has focused on multi-hypothesis approaches leveraging random finite sets. Of particular interest are labeled random finite set methods that maintain temporally coherent labels for each object. While these methods enjoy important theoretical properties as closed-form solutions to the multi-target Bayes filter, the maintenance of multiple hypotheses under the standard measurement model is highly computationally expensive, even when hypothesis pruning approximations are applied. In this work, we focus on the Generalized Labeled Multi-Bernoulli (GLMB) filter as an example of this class of methods. We investigate a variant of the filter that allows multiple detections per object from the same sensor, a critical capability when deploying tracking in the context of distributed networks of machine learning-based virtual sensors. We show that this breaks the inter-detection dependencies in the filter updates of the standard GLMB filter, allowing updates with significantly improved parallel scalability and enabling efficient deployment on GPU hardware. We report the results of a preliminary analysis of a GPU-accelerated implementation of our proposed GLMB tracker, with a focus on run time scalability with respect to the number of objects and the maximum number of retained hypotheses.

title: Hardware Design and Side-Channel Security Analysis on the Key Computational Block for YOLOv11
authors: Runquan Shao, Liji Wu, Jing Hu, Le Wu, Xiangmin Zhang
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Integrated Circuits and Microsystems (ICICM)
abstract: YOLO (You Only Look Once) algorithm plays a crucial role in autonomous vehicles and medical imaging, which require a large number of object detection and image classification tasks because of its advantages of speed and accuracy on edge device. However, due to the intrinsic high computational workload of YOLO model, it is still challenging when implementing large models on the embedded device, especially the latest version YOLOv11. In this paper, we propose the hardware design based on time-division multiplexing of the key computational block C3k2 which is most used in YOLOv11 on FPGA. Firstly, we extend a fast convolution (Conv) algorithm to our Conv layer. Secondly, the batch normalization (BN) layer has been significantly optimized, especially in the stage of calculating the mean and variance. Finally, a Sigmoid Linear Unit (SiLU) activation function in the form of a piecewise function will appear completely in the form of time-division multiplexing, which will greatly reduce the consumption of resources. Experimental results show that our design can achieve a 0.19 ms delay on an AMD artix-7 xc7a35tftg256 FPGA under the working frequency of 50 MHz, while the average relative error is 1.67%. Furthermore, we use the cw305 board, which can extract power information, to implement a simple power analysis (SPA) on C3k2 block and the SiLU. The information within the hardware design was successfully analyzed, such as the number of runs and input data information.

title: Secret Share Network Coding with User Equipment Hopping
authors: Walter Roensch, Shikhar Bhattarai, Hyuck M. Kwon
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: A secret share or secret split network coding (SSNC) communication system transmits split-secret message via multipath links, assuming that each link is perfect. However, a wireless physical layer (PHY) channel is never perfect, but under interference, noise, jamming, and fading. Hence, the probability of SSNC failure increases and the link throughput decreases as the channel quality degrades and the number of links increases. In this paper, we propose a method to leverage the available PHY channel signal-to-interference-noise ratio (SINR) information, improve performance of the existing SSNC significantly, and apply for the NextG SSNC.

title: A Model of a C-band Mixer Circuit
authors: Xuezhen Zhao, Jun Liu, Jing Wang, Guodong Su
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Integrated Circuits and Microsystems (ICICM)
abstract: This paper presents a C-band up-conversion mixer model, which consists of a core mixing unit and a Marchand Balun structure. The mixing unit employs a passive double-balanced ring topology to achieve the mixing function, while the Marchand Balun performs the conversion from single-ended to differential signals. The model operates with a local oscillator (LO) / radio frequency (RF) range of $4-9 \mathrm{GHz}$ and an intermediate frequency (IF) signal covering DC-3.5 GHz. Within the $\mathbf{4 - 9 ~ G H z}$ frequency range, the model achieves a conversion loss of 9 dB, with typical RF return loss and IF return loss values of $\mathbf{- 1 1} \mathbf{~ d B}$ and $\mathbf{- 9 ~ d B}$, respectively. Furthermore, by comparing the model with chip test data, the data error is minimized, verifying the reliability of the model.

title: Intelligent Energy Efficient Routing Framework for Wireless Sensor Networks using Whale Optimization Algorithm and Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning
authors: Monali Darshan Joshi, Manivel Kandasamy
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: The limitation in the resources of the nodes opens the Wireless Sensor Networks (WSNs) to energy efficiency challenges, scalability problems and data reliability. In order to overcome such problems, Intelligent Energy Efficient Routing Framework has been introduced which involves multi-agent reinforcement learning (MARL) and Whale Optimization Algorithms (WOA). The WOA is also used in this algorithm to select the optimal cluster head based on the residual energy, distance, and load balancing agents dynamically adjust routing decisions based on the dynamic changing network conditions. According to the experiment results, the optimal route choice determined based on packets with ratio of 94.8 percent and energy consumption of 92.1 and weight of determination of optimal route choice of 95.6 are relevant to the network performance compared to the traditional route plan. These findings bring to the fore the framework of life cycle networking, energy saving and even data security. Lastly, metaheuristic optimization that is coupled with the reinforcement learning is a powerful intellectual approach to sustainable WSN routing.

title: A Smart Path: AI based Career Guidance for Rural Researcher
authors: Swati Sehgal, Sunil Kumar Vengalil, Mani Kumar P, Thanvika S, Sai Vishnu Vardhan Reddy, Ram Shreyas M
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: The design and development of a Smart Path: AI Based Personalized Career Guidance system for undergraduates that respond to API requests with appropriate data and through advice. Our system overcomes the limitation of traditional career guidance resources by introducing, hands on style of personalized experience to the users, such as students of rural areas, professionals and people with disabilities. In our approach, the front end is designed in a simple and responsive manner as web browser (integrated with Teachable Machine) to make initial interaction users friendly based on recommendation. Upon recommendation completion, the prediction based on users input category is passed on through API to the script.js which manages the back end logic. Real time information is assured by requesting external API services that provides industry trends, educational needs and market analysis. Post yielding the precise recommendation, JSON file is shared with web browser to represent the user an engaging dashboard with personalized career guidance and course suggestion. This is user friendly and scalable chat bot, A Smart Path: AI Based Personalized Career Guidance for Scholars, provides a cost, effective way to democratize career counseling, particularly for students in underprivileged communities. The novelty of our work is expressed by filling the gap by using a web browser, based CNN model (google Teachable Machine) and along with a generative language model (Gemini) to provide quick, image driven personalized career suggestions.

title: RL-Driven Adaptive Numerology for NR-V2X Sidelink: Toward 6G AI-Native Orchestration
authors: Oussema Abdelmoula, Naila Bouchemal, Sondes Kallel, Merouane Debbah
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on 6G Networking (6GNet)
abstract: The transition to 6 G networks demands ultrareliable low-latency communications (URLLC) and flexible numerologies for dynamic vehicular services. This paper proposes an offline reinforcement learning framework for adaptive numerology selection in NR-V2X sidelink, training agents on pre-collected network traces across diverse scenarios. Evaluation across four reward configurations demonstrates 93-95% policy divergence from baseline, with latency-focused agents exhibiting ultra-concentrated action selection and throughputfocused agents adopting adaptive bi-modal strategies. This work establishes an AI-native framework for adaptive numerology orchestration in 6G V2X networks.

title: A 24-28GHz GaN SPDT MMIC with High Isolation and Low Insertion Loss
authors: Peiyao Liu, Pengfei Jiang, Kui Dang, Rujun Sun, Yue Hao, Jincheng Zhang
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Integrated Circuits and Microsystems (ICICM)
abstract: As an important part of the communication system, RF front-end transceiver components have higher frequency, higher power, lower loss and smaller performance requirements, among which the performance of RF switches directly affects the transmitting power and efficiency of the transmitting system and the noise of the receiving system. In this work, we propose a GaN single-pole double-throw RF switch, which adopts a topology of quarter-wavelength transmission lines combined with parallel transistors to achieve high isolation design while taking into account low insertion loss. The measurement results show that in the frequency range of $24-28 \mathrm{GHz}$, the insertion loss is $1.2-1.45 \mathrm{~dB}$, the isolation is $\mathbf{4 2. 4}-\mathbf{6 0. 8} \mathrm{dB}$, and the return loss is greater than 12.7 dB.

title: CNN with Efficient Channel Attention for Multi-Class Respiratory Sound Prediction
authors: Shannan Dhirshath T, Deva Priya Isravel, Julia Punitha Malar Dhas
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: Computerized listening relies on machine learning tools for the analysis of breathing sounds and can be reliably used for the detection of lung diseases. This paper presents the design of a novel advanced deep learning system based on a Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) architecture with an Efficient Channel Attention (ECA) section (CNN-ECA model) for classifying multiple groups of different types of breathing sounds. The performance of the proposed system was evaluated against three existing methods, including a simple Random Forest (RF) classifier, a mixed Gated Recurrent Unit-Convolutional Neural Network (GRU-CNN), and a VGG-16 model with transfer learning. The study utilized the public ICBHI 2017 Respiratory Sound Database. Once the audio signals were converted to Mel spectrogram images, the training and testing processes followed. The new CNN-ECA model outperformed all baseline models with an excellent performance rate for this multi-group classification, reaching 95.0% accuracy and 94.5% F1-score. These results demonstrate that the incorporation of a simple attention mechanism can substantially improve the ability of the CNN to identify and utilize critical information in the sounds. The CNN-ECA model thus stands to become an efficient system for automatic identification of respiratory diseases.

title: Constrained Edge AI Deployment: Fine-Tuning vs. Distillation for LLM Compression
authors: Jacob Sander, David Moe, Achraf Cohen, Brian Jalaian, Brent Venable, Venkat R. Dasari
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: Modern foundational models are often compressed via a combination of structured pruning and re-training to meet the strict compute, memory, and connectivity constraints of edge deployments. While state-of-the-art (SoTA) pruning schemes target the entire Transformer, we adopt a simple, layer-wise L<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf>-norm pruning on only the multi-layer perceptron (MLP) blocks as a fixed baseline. Our focus is not on achieving maximal compression, but on isolating the impact of the re-training loss function: (i) L2-norm Pruning with Cross-Entropy Fine-Tuning (L2PFT), which relies on labeled data, versus (ii) L2-norm Pruning with KL-Divergence Self-Distillation (L2PSD), which utilizes only teacher logits without requiring labeled data. We evaluate both pipelines on the OLMo2-7B-SFT model for CommonsenseQA, suitable for intermittent or denied connectivity scenarios typical of edge networks. Under identical pruning schedules, L2PSD achieves comparable or superior test accuracy to L2PFT, indicating that the choice of loss function has a significant impact on compressed model recovery in resource-constrained environments.

title: Collateral Damage Assessment Model for AI System Target Engagement in Military Operations
authors: Clara Maathuis, Kasper Cools
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: In an era where AI (Artificial Intelligence) systems play an increasing role in the battlefield, ensuring responsible targeting demands rigorous assessment of potential collateral effects. In this context, a novel collateral damage assessment model for target engagement of AI systems in military operations is introduced. The model integrates temporal, spatial, and force dimensions within a unified Knowledge Representation and Reasoning (KRR) architecture following a design science methodological approach. Its layered structure captures the categories and architectural components of the AI systems to be engaged together with corresponding engaging vectors and contextual aspects. At the same time, spreading, severity, likelihood, and evaluation metrics are considered in order to provide a clear representation enhanced by transparent reasoning mechanisms. Further, the model is demonstrated and evaluated through instantiation which serves as a basis for further dedicated efforts that aim at building responsible and trustworthy intelligent systems for assessing the effects produced by engaging AI systems in military operations.

title: Enhancing Sentiment Analysis and Topic Modeling with a Hybrid Data Verification and Refinement Framework
authors: B. Karthick, T. Meyyappan
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: This paper introduces the Hybrid Data Verification and Refinement (HDVR) Framework, a novel approach to enhancing data quality in social media analytics by integrating probabilistic modeling with rule-based data refinement. The HDVR framework employs Bayesian inference for anomaly detection and weighted rule-based heuristics for refining data, ensuring improved accuracy, consistency, and completeness in large-scale social media datasets. A comprehensive evaluation was conducted using a publicly available Twitter dataset, demonstrating the framework’s effectiveness in mitigating noise, bias, and missing values. The results indicate that HDVR improves data completeness by 25%, reduces bias by 30%, and enhances classification accuracy by 15% compared to traditional machine learning models such as Naïve Bayes and Decision Trees. Additionally, a comparative analysis with existing sentiment analysis techniques highlights HDVR’s superior data reliability and error reduction capabilities. The framework’s scalability was evident in its ability to process 100,000 social media records in just 35.8 seconds, making it highly suitable for real-time social media monitoring and business intelligence applications. This research provides a structured, adaptable, and efficient data refinement strategy, enabling more reliable social media analytics for improved decision-making in digital marketing, public opinion analysis, and business intelligence. Future work will explore the integration of deep learning techniques for further refinement and extend HDVR’s applicability to various social media platforms for broader validation.

title: Electric Vehicles Battery Monitoring via Can Gateway
authors: Bhargav Deshpande, Parshuram Deshpande, Harsh Bide, Tanvi Gudekar, Rupali Gavaraskar
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: This paper presents the design and implementation of a real-time battery monitoring system using ESP32, CAN Bus, and the Blynk IoT platform. EV batteries face issues such as deterioration from charge cycles, damage from over/under charging, limited monitoring accuracy, safety risks like overheating, and unreliable Wi-Fi communication in noisy settings. The project addresses these by enabling real-time surveillance using ESP32 and sensors, robust CAN Bus communication, ML-based predictions for State of Charge (SoC) and State of Health (SoH), and notifications with cost estimation via Blynk. The system tracks voltage, current, power, and energy usage in real time, transmitting data over CAN Bus and displaying it on an LCD module and the Blynk app. A machine learning model trained with Edge Impulse enables on-device inference, detecting anomalies like over-discharge, heating, or rapid wear while providing insights without cloud reliance. The prototype used a BAK NMC 18650 2000mAh 3.6V Lithium-Ion cell, a format widely adopted in EVs, e-bikes, hybrid cars, and energy storage modules, where large packs are assembled from thousands of such cells.

title: Dynamic Flow Routing and Scheduling for Time-Critical Network Services
authors: Xuanli Lin, Zhaofeng Zhang, Zunzheng Zhang, Guoliang Xue
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: A key challenge in next-generation networks is providing intelligent network services to support time-sensitive applications such as AR/VR and the Internet of Military Things (IoMT). This work aims to answer the question: "How can we design a network service scheduling and flow routing scheme to satisfy the stringent demand and deadline requirements of tactical network applications?" We take a time-expanded graph-based approach to this study. Specifically, given a time-expanded graph constructed from an original network graph, we propose an optimization problem to find a subset of network services to maximize their total completion rewards such that the data of all services in this subset can be transmitted to their destination nodes by their deadlines. Unfortunately, solving this problem directly is challenging since it is a mixed-integer program. We propose a heuristic algorithm based on a sequential rounding approach where a linear programming (LP) feasibility problem is iteratively solved to update the network service subset, guided by a relaxed reward maximization problem that prioritizes high-reward requests. To further improve efficiency, we fine-tune the above LP feasibility problem from a static flow perspective, enabling fast feasibility checks on the original graph, and design the corresponding efficient heuristic algorithm. The simulation results demonstrate the trade-off among different approaches and validate the effectiveness of the proposed algorithms.

title: Demo: At-Scale Deployment of Network Digital Twin on the Cloud for Network Configuration Validation
authors: Allen Abishek, Lluis Gifre Renom, Raul Muñoz, Abdul Rehman Qureshi, Adrian Asensio, Xavier Masip-Bruin, Ricard Vilalta
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on 6G Networking (6GNet)
abstract: This paper introduces a scalable Network Digital Twin (NDT) framework designed to mitigate the extensive compute demands typically associated with large-scale twinning of network topologies. The proposed approach enables efficient deployment of NDT instances without relying on High Performance Computing (HPC) infrastructure, thereby facilitating the modeling and analysis of complex network topologies using standard, cost-effective cloud resources.

title: Automated Brain Tumor Detection from MRI Scans using Transfer Learning with VGG16
authors: V Sumalatha, Soumyasis Das, Saurabh Fulara, Chandra Kishore
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: The problem MRI scans are highlighted in the current study due to the delicate issue of supporting brain tumors identification that is often mixed up with complicated images and scarcity of labelled examinations. Diagnosis Diagnosis Manual Diagnosis Manual diagnosis may be tedious and subject to interradiologist popularity. The solution to all these problems is to adopt a deep learning framework consisting of transfer learning with VGG16 architecture, to categorize brains MRI image into tumor and non-tumor types. The variables will be two classes YES (tumor) and NO (no tumor). Normalization, resizing, and cropping were used as preprocessing and data augmentation introduced to increase the robustness of a model. The hyper-optimized VGG16 classifier obtained 86% and 80% validation and test accuracy, respectively. The majority of errors were those cases when the tumor boundaries were felate and not very apparent.

title: Ambiguity-aware Broad 2D Beamforming
authors: Nathaniel Rowe, Nicolas Law, Dola Saha
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: Wireless communications and remote sensing require accurate knowledge of target location to perform directional beamforming. This is especially true for mobile applications, when platform dynamics, long range and evolving mission demands necessitate beam tracking to maintain system performance. In practice, these dynamics create target location ambiguity, stressing application performance when directional beams are not accurately steered. To overcome these challenges, this paper introduces a novel ambiguity beamforming optimization program to uniformly distribute energy across a two-dimensional uncertainty region. The methodology operates on array weights without signal pre-coding, a departure from alternative approaches, while maximizing physical-layer availability for user applications such as sensing and communications. The uncertainty region has been quantized via Fibonacci spherical sampling for uniform optimization solving, and the resulting density has been related to worst-case gain error to fine-tune performance. Our results show an approximately 25 dB improvement in worst-case beamforming gain across uncertainty regions with a maximized uniform gain, while simultaneously minimizing off-angle energy, and the practical design makes it viable for adoption into emerging systems.

title: A Deep Learning Framework for Energy Consumption Forecasting with n-Gram, Attention, and ARMA
authors: A. Akilandeswari, R. Jeena, A. Gnanasoundari, R. Dhanalakshmi, S. Vasantha, S. Pushpa Latha
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: Accurate forecasting of hourly energy consumption is critical for efficient power grid management, particularly with complex, non-linear patterns. This paper proposes a novel deep learning model integrating n-Gram Embedding, Count-Aware Self-Attention, and Recency-Weighted ARMA for forecasting on the PJME hourly dataset. The model captures local motifs and temporal dependencies, achieving a Mean Absolute Error (MAE) of 661.65 and Root Mean Square Error (RMSE) of 779.25, significantly outperforming classical models: ARIMA (MAE: 7603.09, RMSE: 9094.82), Holt-Winters (MAE: 1080.37, RMSE: 1217.77), and Linear Regression (MAE: 1446.69, RMSE: 1699.96). By leveraging symbolic patterns and statistical modeling, the model offers robust performance for real-time applications in resource-constrained settings. This work advances energy forecasting by addressing limitations in traditional and deep learning approaches, providing a scalable solution for modern energy systems.

title: Augmented Reality in E-Commerce: Enhancing User Engagement and Reducing Return Rates
authors: Nikhilesh Sharma, Nadhema Ahmed Jaff, G. Vikram, A. Vini Infanta, Naama Hussein Al-Muraad, B. Anitha Vijayalakshmi
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: Augmented reality in e-commerce seeks to enhance customer experience in regard to return rates while bringing satisfaction. The basic application of e-commerce seems to be facing high returns as well as the impossibility to visualize products. Return rate levels due to dissatisfaction with traditional product representation stand at a very unacceptable high level. Methods involving a standard product image plus text description fail to yield immersive experiences. The proposed work is to incorporate AR into e-commerce portals so that customers can envision products in their real-world environment before buying them. The purpose of this work is to evaluate the influence of AR on customer conversion rates, return rates, and satisfaction. In this research, the novelty will be applied by using AR to fill the gap between online and in-store purchasing experiences to provide a more interactive and informed purchasing decision process. Findings have been generated indicating that features of AR bring about significant return rates decline and conversion rate enhancement with higher customer confidence levels towards purchase decisions. Results depict how AR can influence the potentiality of customer satisfaction, enabling them to experience a more immersive, transparent, and interactive shopping environment. This research contributes to the rapidly expanding knowledge base on AR in e-commerce, providing valuable information for businesses looking to leverage new technologies to increase customer engagement and retention.

title: CNN-based Medical Waste Classification for Sustainable and Efficient Healthcare Disposal Systems
authors: Kanimozhi S, D. Yobu, Madhukumar S, Manikandan B, M. Madheswaran, Monisha R
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: Accurate medical waste classification is essential for promoting environmental sustainability and mitigating health hazards. Conventional hand-sorting techniques are ineffective and susceptible to inaccuracies, requiring automated alternatives. This research presents a Convolutional Neural Network (CNN)-driven medical waste categorization system to improve precision and efficacy in healthcare waste segregation. The system was trained on a dataset of 50,000 labeled medical waste images, classified as sharp, infectious waste, plastics, and recyclables. Experimental findings indicate that the CNN model achieved an accuracy of 97.3%, markedly enhancing the dependability of waste categorization. The system achieved a precision of 96.8% and a recall of 97.5%, guaranteeing great accuracy in identifying various waste types. Incorporating a CNN-based methodology into a hospital waste management system yielded a 35% decrease in misclassification errors and a 28% enhancement in waste segregation efficiency relative to traditional techniques. The findings underscore the efficacy of deep learning in improving medical waste disposal, hence advancing sustainable and automated healthcare waste management methods. It highlights the capability of CNN-based classification systems to enhance waste disposal, foster environmental accountability, and minimize operational inefficiencies in healthcare institutions.

title: SmartHerd AI: Integrating Bio-Inspired Swarm Intelligence with XAI for Cattle Health Monitoring
authors: Sangeetha V, A Nandini, Amruta M, Gaargi N
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: SmartHerd AI is an AI-based cattle health monitoring system developed to overcome the challenges of traditional livestock management. It uses deep learning for early disease detection and Swarm Intelligence to look over herd-level behavior and identify anomalies. The system processes key data such as temperature and activity level, aiming to provide real-time, preventive health updates. Explainable AI (XAI) is used to help farmers understand the system easily. While IoT integration is planned, the current implementation shows the potential in improving animal care, reducing veterinary costs, and supporting smarter farm decisions through AI-driven solutions.

title: Real-Time Energy Consumption and Carbon Footprint Estimation of AI Agents in 6G
authors: Lucas Otávio Nascimento De Araújo, Abdelkader Outtagarts
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on 6G Networking (6GNet)
abstract: Assessing the environmental impact of AI algorithms is becoming crucial with the increasing use of AI in industry. To ensure environmentally sustainable growth of AI, we need to consider the AI ecosystem, particularly energy consumption. The goal of this demo is analyzing the energy and carbon footprint of Deep Reinforcement Learning (DRL) in a use case of access control of data transmitted by Internet of Things (IoT). In real-time, we estimate energy and carbon footprint during the training and inference of DRL TinyQMix model for an mMTC (massive Machine-Type Communication) admission control over different scenarios and evaluated the energy-delay efficiency landscape of training and testing these models.

title: Crimeview – An Interactive Dashboard for Crime Data Visualization
authors: Shri Ram P A, Muthu Kumar S, Pulan Naresh Kumar R S, P. Rampriya
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: The annual Crime Review Report of the Tamil Nadu Police has more than 700 pages of statistical information on Indian Penal Code (IPC) and Special & Local Laws (SLL) crimes. While immensely informative, its magnitude and intricacy render it unintelligible to the common populace and busy officials. This study presents CrimeView, an interactive online dashboard aimed at breaking down such reports into graphical insights. Employing crime data from 2013 to 2022, the system provides district-wise, type-wise, and year-wise analysis using charts, maps, and ranking tables. Preprocessing is done with Python libraries (Pandas, NumPy), plots are constructed using Plotly and Seaborn, and the frontend is created using React.js. The system provides functionalities like hotspot detection, district filtering, and comparative analysis. Findings indicate that crime data visualized is easier to interpret much more quickly than text-based reports, enhancing law enforcement decision-making and public awareness.

title: A double layer placement algorithm for IC-based modules of printed circuit board
authors: Hangyuan Li, Yu Chen, Zhaoyang Yang, Haotian Pang, Ning Xu
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Integrated Circuits and Microsystems (ICICM)
abstract: For large-scale printed circuit board (PCB) placement scenarios, this paper proposes an innovative clustering algorithm based on the traditional density-based spatial clustering of applications with noise (DBSCAN) algorithm, which is divided into integrated circuit (IC)-pin points clustering and components clustering. Meanwhile, since the distribution evolutionary algorithm based on a population of probability model (DEA-PPM) has achieved satisfactory performance in solving component orientation variables, this algorithm is introduced into the component orientation optimization of PCB, and the component coordinates are solved by conjugate sub-gradient algorithm (CSA). Based on the global placement results, a set of systematic legalization algorithms are proposed to eliminate overlap and satisfy the basic design specifications in industry.

title: Power Electronic Society’s Plans for the Next Five Years! [President’s Message]
authors: Johan H. R. Enslin
publish: IEEE Power Electronics Magazine
abstract: As we reach the end of another exciting year at the Power Electronics Society with around 14,000 members, it reminds me of how far our community has come and how much opportunity still lies ahead. Over the past months, our Society has seen remarkable engagement across all fronts. Through our conferences, e.g., ECCE North America, eGRID, WiPDA, and INTELEC, as well as the many regional, Technical Committee, and Chapter events, continue to grow in both participation and technical quality. The energy and enthusiasm at these gatherings affirm the strength of our community. I am particularly encouraged by the increasing involvement of industry members, students, and young professionals, whose fresh ideas and dedication are shaping the future of PELS.

title: A 16-b 8-MS/s Pipelined SAR ADC With Robust Ring Amplifier and On-Chip Bit-Weight Calibration
authors: Shaojuan Chen, Xiaoyi Li, Xuanhao Zhang, Xingshuai Zou, Zhenbing Li, Jiaxin Liu
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Integrated Circuits and Microsystems (ICICM)
abstract: This paper presents a pipelined successive approximation register (SAR) analog-to-digital converter (ADC). A robust ring amplifier with high power efficiency is implemented in the ADC. The standard deviation ($\sigma$) of its output common-mode voltage is less than $4 \mathbf{m V}$ across temperature from $-40^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ to $105^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$. The on-chip bit-weight calibration is embedded in the ADC to mitigate CDAC mismatch effects. The overall system is designed in a 55 nm standard CMOS technology with 1.8 V analog supply, 1.2 V digital supply and 1.2 V reference voltage. The ADC works at $8 \mathrm{MS} / \mathrm{s}$ consuming 1.38 mW and achieves 80.8 dB signal-to-noise-and-distortion-ratio (SNDR) and 89.3 dB spurious-free dynamic range (SFDR) resulting in $\mathbf{1 7 5. 4 d B}$ Schreier Figure-Of-Merit (FoMs).

title: Real-Time Medical Insurance Claim Fraud Detection using Hybrid Machine Learning Models
authors: Varimadugu Bharath Kumar Reddy, J. A. M. Rexie
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: The increasing amount of false claims in the medical insurance space presents a challenge to both the healthcare and insurance sectors, resulting in considerable costs, inefficiency, and financial loss. This project describes the design and development of a real-time fraud detection system for medical insurance claims using advanced machine learning technology. A hybrid model leveraging supervised (XGBoost) and unsupervised (Isolation Forest) algorithms are applied to increase detection rates and minimize false positives. Feature engineering and data preprocessing gives significant insights into claim data and informs accurate anomaly detection. Real-time scoring of claims along with automating alerts reduces manual intervention and supports timeliness in decision making. The project also consists of a dashboard for interactive data visualization, allowing investigators to work efficiently when monitoring claims for possible fraudulent activity. The established proposal is designed to be scalable, adaptable, and reliable for real-world use cases in insurance environments. Overall, the system provides insurers with the capabilities to reduce financial expense and gain integrity into the management of claims through intelligent, data-driven automation. The novelty of this system lies in combining supervised and unsupervised learning in a single hybrid framework capable of detecting both known and previously unseen fraud patterns. The proposed model achieves an accuracy of 96.4% and significantly reduces false positives through real-time automated scoring, advanced feature engineering, and threshold-based alerting. This establishes a transparent, scalable, and real-world–ready architecture for medical insurance claim fraud detection.

title: Machine Learning in Cardiovascular Health: Heart Disease Prediction using Support Vector Classifier
authors: Nagendar Yamsani, Arpanpreet Kaur, Manika Manwal, Gagan Bansal
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: One of the most common causes is still heart disease of global death, which underlines the necessity of more specific diagnosis instruments to put more emphasis on early diagnosis and treatment. The paper uses a clinical and demographic data to examine the applicability of the Support Vector Classifier (SVC) in classifying heart disease. The data set consists of 14 attributes such as age, sex, type of chest pain, resting blood pressure, serum cholesterol, fasting blood sugar, resting ECG, maximum heart rate, exercise angina, old peak (ST depression), and ST slope, and the binary target attribute that indicates whether the individual has a heart disease or not. This dataset was used to train and test the SVC model on the existence of heart disease. Normalization and encoding of data preprocessing and stringent measures of preprocessing data were adopted to give optimal results in the model. The result indicates good classification figures: 88 accuracy, 0.88 precision of both classes, 0.85 recall of non-diseased patients and 0.89 recall of diseased patients, and F1 of 0.87. This is evidenced by the fact that the SVC model can categorize patients with and without heart disease. The findings demonstrate that clinical and demographic variables should be considered in machine learning algorithms to provide powerful predictive analytics. The precision, recall and F1-score of the SVC model are close to accuracy and thus balanced leading to its suitability in diagnosis of heart disease classification. The study contributes to the growing body of knowledge about the use of machine learning in healthcare, demonstrating how SVC can be used to enhance the early detection process and make informed clinical judgments.

title: Optimizing Mango Crop Health Through CNN-based Leaf Analysis
authors: Nagendar Yamsani, Arpanpreet Kaur, Manika Manwal, Gagan Bansal
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: Although mango is a crucial fruit crop with considerable financial and nutritional value, leaf diseases including powdery mildew, bacterial canker, and anthracnose can seriously compromise plant condition and output. Early diagnosis and classification of these diseases is fundamental for good therapy. An automated mango leaf disease detection convolutional neural network (CNN)-based system is presented in this paper. A publicly available dataset including images of both healthy and sick leaves was used encompassing several illness categories in order to imitate real-world circumstances. Excellent results in all disease areas came from CNN model training and evaluation. Precision, recall, and average accuracy measurements demonstrated how well different diseases could be distinguished with minimal mistakes. Analysis of Precision-Recall curves and confusion matrices validated consistent generalizing across training and validation datasets. Stable convergence free of overfitting assured reliable forecasts from the model. The results validate the CNN-based method as a practical tool for early disease identification, therefore reducing the demand for human inspection and enabling rapid response. This approach can help to support sustainable development by way of improved disease control. More study could expand the system to real-time applications and larger datasets therefore enhancing its scalability and usability.

title: Federated Intelligence-Enabled Adaptive Intrusion Detection System for Privacy-Preserving Threat Mitigation in IoT Ecosystems
authors: Betshrine Rachel Jibinsingh, Anisha Isaac, Malik Bader Alazzam, Aaied Eqab Muraay Majed, Sajiv G, Alamelu Alias Rajasree. S
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: The high reliance on Internet of Things (IoT) devices has increased demand in robust and privacy-preserving IDS. The long-standing methods of IDS are usually centralized data gathering, vulnerating information and unable to address the changing cyber threats in heterogeneous IoT environments. In addressing these shortcomings, this study introduces FedAdaptShield, adaptive IDS based on federated intelligence which facilitates decentralized training of models on edge devices without exchange of raw data, hence, privacy protection. FedAdaptShield adds an adaptive learning dynamic, which uses models and adapts them according to new patterns of attacks that occur, making the system more accurate and robust in detecting attacks. Employed in federated learning architectures and deep neural networks models, FedAdaptShield proves to have an accuracy level greater than 98% on a variety of attacks and demonstrates better performance in comparison to baseline and centralized IDS implementations. FedAdaptShield eliminates network bandwidth and computational requirements in collaborative learning settings because learning is performed locally, yet using high security services. The scalable, efficient and privacy-aware solution can be effectively used to counter highly-efficient cyber threats in IoT applications across smart homes, healthcare, and industrial automation.

title: A Fast Transient and High PSRR LDO with 62 ns Settling Time
authors: Ruijie Wang, Zhiguo Yu, Xiaofeng Gu
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Integrated Circuits and Microsystems (ICICM)
abstract: This paper presents a low-dropout regulator (LDO) with fast transient response and high power supply rejection ratio (PSRR). The proposed LDO employs a error amplifier (EA) with high gain class-AB amplifier and incorporates a transient enhancement module with undershoot/overshoot suppression circuit. This transient enhancement module accelerates the charging/discharging process of the power transistor gate, effectively suppressing the undershoot /overshoot voltage amplitudes of the LDO output, and significantly reducing transient response time. Additionally, a feedforward circuit is introduced to suppress the noise ripple from the power supply. This work is designed in 55 nm CMOS process with an input voltage of 1.5 V and an output voltage of 1 V. Simulation results indicate that the proposed LDO exhibits good loop stability for load current ranging from 0 to 100 mA. When the load steps between 0 and 10 mA, the proposed LDO output settling times are 61 ns and 62 ns, with undershoot and overshoot voltages of 38 mV and 41 mV, respectively. The load regulation is $0.023 \mathrm{mV} / \mathrm{mA}$, and the PSRR reaches $\mathbf{- 5 0 ~ d B}$ at $\mathbf{1 0 0 ~ k H z}$.

title: A Stochastic Computing-Based Computing-in-Memory Macro with Bit-Split Stochastic Number Generation
authors: Zhiting Lin, Dandan Chen, Siyan Li, Shuang Liu, Yu Liu, Xiulong Wu
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Integrated Circuits and Microsystems (ICICM)
abstract: This paper proposes a novel digital-domain computing-in-memory (CIM) macro architecture based on stochastic computing (SC), which integrates a Bit-Split Stochastic Number Generator (BSSNG) to enhance energy efficiency and computational parallelism. The proposed BSSNG divides each binary number into high and low bit segments, enabling the parallel generation of stochastic bitstreams. By embedding this mechanism within local computation units and peripheral input circuits, the architecture reduces stochastic number generation time by 16x. The system utilizes a 6T SRAM array with shared linear feedback shift registers (LFSR) to store 8-bit weights and generate uncorrelated bitstreams. These streams are processed through correlation-aware stochastic logic circuits, followed by binary restoration via counters and shift-accumulate units. The proposed macro is fabricated in TSMC 28nm CMOS process, supporting 8-bit input/weight multiply-accumulate (MAC) operations and delivers a 19-bit output with a clock frequency of $\mathbf{4 1. 7 ~ M H z}$. It achieves a 64. 7 % power reduction compared to full binary-to-stochastic conversion methods and reaches an energy efficiency of $17.81 \mathrm{TOPS} / \mathrm{W}$ under a 0.9 V supply. The compact and reconfigurable local logic unit design further contributes to area savings, making this architecture well-suited for energyconstrained machine learning and edge computing applications.

title: Greedy-ECHO: Score-Based Forwarding for Efficient Broadcast in MANETs
authors: Sheikh Tareq Ahmed, Annamalai Annamalai
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: Network-wide broadcast (NWB) is a core yet challenging task in Mobile Ad Hoc Networks (MANETs), particularly in low-power, long-range systems like LoRaWAN. While the ECHO protocol enables control-free broadcasting, it lacks prioritization and directionality in its Pruned Flood (PF) phase. This paper presents Greedy-ECHO, a backward-compatible enhancement that introduces a lightweight, score-based suppression mechanism. Each forwarding node computes a Greedy Score using hop distance, RSSI, Spreading Factor (SF), and battery level, and transmits only if no better candidate is overheard. Greedy-ECHO preserves ECHO’s stateless design while reducing redundancy and latency. The protocol requires no control messaging or neighbor discovery, making it suitable for embedded and energy-constrained deployments. NS-3 simulations under realistic LoRaWAN conditions show that Greedy-ECHO improves delivery ratio by up to 11.4%, reduces total communication load by 21.7%, and produces a more compact connected dominating set compared to baseline ECHO.

title: Design and Implementation of a Secure Boot RISC-V Processor for IoT Devices
authors: Zeyu Li, Liji Wu, Jing Hu, Han Sun, Xiangmin Zhang, Haijie Wang
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Integrated Circuits and Microsystems (ICICM)
abstract: The open-source RISC-V instruction set provides a new direction for China to establish an autonomous and controllable IoT ecosystem. At the same time, the IoT devices face the security threat of firmware tampering. Aiming at these problems, this paper provides a low-power pipelined processor based on RISC-V architecture that supports secure boot, which supports RV32IM instruction set, fast interrupt response and dynamic pipeline control. In the meantime, the secure boot mechanism of the processor is designed based on the Chinese commercial cryptographic algorithm SM3, when the boot file BootCode is tampered with, the processor is prevented from booting by a hardware-level blocking mechanism. The design passes the instruction set and secure boot functionality tests and it is verified on an FPGA board, the results show that the total utilization of logic lookup tables(LUT) is 22827, accounting for 19.5% of the total resources, while the average startup time of the system is 49.35 ms, without causing large resource and time overhead, it is suitable for resource-constrained IoT devices and providing a guarantee of autonomy and security for China’s RISC-V ecosystem at the same time.

title: Research on Analysis and Compensation of Telescope Pitch Pointing Error Based on Inclination Sensor and Beidou Differential Positioning System
authors: Shaowei He, Shaohui Feng, Lisi Geng, Ning Li, Deming Kong
publish: IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
abstract: The pitch pointing error of the telescope is a key factor affecting high-precision observation, characterized by non-linearity and multi-source. Existing correction methods mainly rely on long-term observation data to analyze the influence of different error sources, which limits their application in the early stage of telescope installation and calibration. To solve this problem, in this paper, a pitch pointing error analysis and compensation method based on the inclination sensor and the Beidou differential positioning system is proposed. In the analysis, the pitch pointing error of the telescope at various azimuth and pitch angles is calculated according to the actual pitch angle measured by the inclination sensor and the theoretical pitch angle provided by the encoder firstly. Then, the primary error sources are systematically analyzed and corrected. For the azimuth axis tilt, the Beidou differential positioning system is used to collect the positioning data of the telescope, and the motion trajectory is fitted using the positioning data to determine the tilt attitude. Regarding azimuth bearing defects, the spatial-domain filtering algorithm combining standard deviation thresholding with weighted average correction is employed to detect and correct the abrupt errors in the inclination sensor measurement value. Aiming for the pitch encoder zero offset, the finite element model is used to analyze the mechanical stress on the inclination sensor at different pitch angles, and the difference between sensor and encoder readings at the angle of minimum stress is used to quantify the offset value. To solve the structural gravity deformation, the inclination sensor is used to measure the pointing deviations caused by gravity under different pitch angles, and the polynomial model is used to characterize the error trend. Finally, a sinusoidal error model is designed to correct the residual error that varies with pitch angle. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed method can effectively analyze and correct the above error sources during the installation and calibration stage, which is of great significance for improving the pitch pointing accuracy of the telescope.

title: Multiphysics Design Methodology for High-Speed Synchronous Reluctance Machines
authors: Arash Allahyari, Ilya Petrov, Juha Pyrhönen, Juho Montonen, Lassi Aarniovuori
publish: IEEE Transactions on Industry Applications
abstract: This study introduces a multi-physics design methodology to enhance the performance of high-speed synchronous reluctance machines (SynRMs). The primary innovation is to optimize the design of the rotor flux guides (FGs), instead of the commonly optimized flux barriers. This may sound like a minor change and just a dual model, but the difference in results is significant and allows different mechanical solutions. In case of transversally laminated rotor targeting high speeds requires thick radial and tangential ribs to support the flux guides, but the ribs diminish torque and power factor and negatively impact efficiency. Reducing the rotor mass can decrease the thickness of these ribs, improving performance. This research combines the optimization of rotor FGs with effective mechanical support strategies based on the machine's maximum speed, comparing two constructional methods: conventional radial and tangential ribs, and non-magnetic backplates between flux guides. Optimizing the rotor geometry with FGs provides deeper insight into the design process and ensures the rotor is electromagnetically and mechanically optimized for maximum performance. To demonstrate the effectiveness of this methodology, a 6-pole-36-slot motor with 300 kW peak power featuring 2, 3, or 4 FGs, identical stator dimensions, and a maximum speed of 12,000 r/min is designed, optimized, and compared. A prototype of a 6-pole-36-slot motor with 3 FGs manufactured with backplates is presented, along with initial measurement results.

title: Fully Coherent Fusion of BeiDou-based Passive Multistatic Radar for Weak Target Detection
authors: Zuhan Cheng, Jun Wang, Jinxin Sui, Ziqian Huang, Te Zhao, Zhiyuan Yan
publish: IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
abstract: Multiple spatial diversity channels and multiple coherent processing intervals cause differences in the target’s scattering nature, bistatic range, and bistatic Doppler frequency. The paper proposes a fully coherent fusion method for moving target detection on BeiDou-based passive multistatic radar. It first implements a signal synchronization algorithm, followed by a joint signal parameter estimation method based on the sparse algorithm and the least squares method. Lastly, a coherent matching strategy is applied to align target positions and phases in all integrated maps. This enables the multi-source coherent fusion of echoes, maximizing the target energy in practice. Both simulated and real-measured data prove the remarkable performance in weak target detection compared to the existing methods.

title: Towards Continuous and Contactless Cardiac Monitoring: A State-Space Approach with FMCW Radar
authors: Xuelin Kong, Wenren Zhou, Bo Wang, Yong-Xin Guo
publish: IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
abstract: Cardiac disease remains a leading global cause of morbidity and mortality, necessitating continuous and unobtrusive monitoring of cardiac activities. Traditional contact-based ECG monitoring is limited by patient discomfort, skin irritation, and restricted long-term usability, driving the need for non-contact alternatives. This study introduces a system for reconstructing electrocardiogram (ECG) signals from radar-based chest displacement data, treating the human body as a signal generator and radar as a state observer. Each heartbeat is modeled as an independent event, and system parameters are iteratively optimized using reinforcement learning to refine state-space matrices. This integration enables accurate reconstruction of stable physiological signals. Experimental results from an overnight sleep dataset demonstrate high fidelity in cardiac motion reconstruction, achieving a Pearson correlation coefficient approximately 0.9 of the ECG waveform and a mean absolute error of 16.45 ms in heart rate variability (HRV) compared to polysomnography (PSG) reference, approaching clinical-grade accuracy. The proposed system effectively addresses common generalization challenges in data-driven methods, achieving high accuracy with minimal training data and maintaining consistent performance across subjects, ensuring robust and scalable non-contact cardiac monitoring.

title: HyPyraMamba: A Pyramid Spectral Attention and Mamba-Based Architecture for Robust Hyperspectral Image Classification
authors: Dekai Li, Uzair Aslam Bhatti, Mengxing Huang, Lorenzo Bruzzone, Jiaxin Li
publish: IEEE Transactions on Geoscience and Remote Sensing
abstract: In hyperspectral image (HSI) classification, the high-dimensionality and the complex coupling of spatial-spectral features present severe challenges to existing deep learning methods in terms of accuracy, generalization, and computational efficiency. Researchers have recently explored CNN and Transformer-based methods to overcome these limitations, but CNN's limited receptive field prevents effective modeling of long-range dependencies, while Transformers suffer from high computational cost and inefficiency in high-dimensional data. Motivated by these limitations, the state-space model (SSM) Mamba shows great potential as an efficient alternative for sequence and dependency modeling. Building on this foundation, we propose HyPyraMamba, a novel architecture designed to effectively overcome the above challenges. It integrates the Pyramid Spectral Attention (PSA) module to capture multi-scale key spectral features, thereby reducing interference caused by spectral redundancy. We developed an Adaptive Expert Depthwise Convolution (AEDC) module that enhances the model's ability to express multi-scale spatial-spectral features, and a sequence modeling module, Mamba. In the Mamba module, we utilize the spatial Mamba and spectral Mamba branches to enhance spatial structure and spectral correlation modeling. Extensive experiments on four benchmark HSI datasets demonstrate that HyPyraMamba significantly outperforms several recent state-of-the-art methods and provides a favorable accuracy–efficiency trade-off. In particular, class-wise analyses on spectrally similar land-cover categories (e.g., different soybean and bareland types) show that HyPyraMamba markedly reduces mutual confusion compared with CNN-, Transformer-, and Mamba-based baselines. The code will be available at https://github.com/dekai-li/HyPyraMamba.

title: Coupled Diffusion Posterior Sampling for Unsupervised Hyperspectral and Multispectral Images Fusion
authors: Yang Xu, Jian Zhu, Danfeng Hong, Zhihui Wei, Zebin Wu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Image Processing
abstract: Hyperspectral images (HSIs) and multispectral images (MSIs) fusion is a hot topic in the remote sensing society. A high-resolution HSI (HR-HSI) can be obtained by fusing a low-resolution HSI (LR-HSI) and a high-resolution MSI (HR-MSI) or RGB image. However, most deep learning-based methods require a large amount of HR-HSIs for supervised training, which is very rare in practice. In this paper, we propose a coupled diffusion posterior sampling (CDPS) method for HSI and MSI fusion in which the HR-HSIs are no longer required in the training process. Because the LR-HSI contains the spectral information and HR-MSI contains the spatial information of the captured scene, we design an unsupervised strategy that learns the required diffusion priors directly and solely from the input test image pair (the LR-HSI and HR-MSI themselves). Then, a coupled diffusion posterior sampling method is proposed to introduce the two priors in the diffusion posterior sampling which leverages the observed LR-HSI and HR-MSI as fidelity terms. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed method outperforms other state-of-the-art unsupervised HSI and MSI fusion methods. Additionally, this method utilizes smaller networks that are simpler and easier to train without other data.

title: Unleashing AI Tools for Power Electronics— From Machine-Readable Data Sheets to Digital Twins
authors: Kevin Hermanns
publish: IEEE Power Electronics Magazine
abstract: The accelerating adoption of wide-bandgap semiconductors and the push toward electrification across industries are driving unprecedented complexity in power electronics design. This article presents a comprehensive approach to addressing these challenges through the integration of artificial intelligence (AI) tools, automated characterization, and standardized data exchange. It introduces the concept of machine-readable data sheets as a critical enabler for AI-driven design workflows, facilitating seamless data access and model generation. This article also explores the role of digital twins in enhancing traceability, predictive maintenance, and yield optimization by leveraging entity-specific data. By outlining a decentralized, API-based framework for data sharing and emphasizing the importance of uncertainty quantification, this work proposes a scalable, future-proof methodology for power electronics development. The presented strategies aim to reduce time-to-market, mitigate the expert shortage, and unlock the full potential of AI in the design and operation of power electronic systems.
