title: Flexible Testbed for Cyber Electromagnetic Activities with 5G Networks
authors: Octavio Galindo, Kevin J. Valdez, Martha Torres Lozano, Andres Vicario Cisneros, Virgilio Gonzalez
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: Modern C5I—encompassing Command, Control, Communication, Computer, Cyber, and Intelligence—serves as a foundational pillar in field operations. The rapid growth of the Internet of Things (IoT) has interconnected a myriad of devices, all reliant on Position, Navigation, and Timing signals as well as pervasive wireless networks that span both public and private links. Recent global conflicts have highlighted how Electronic Warfare and Signal Intelligence can significantly disrupt both military and civilian systems. To effectively support research and education in emerging technologies and associated services, enhanced instrumentation and emulation capabilities are essential. These systems must facilitate studies in cybersecurity; this paper focuses on the concept of Cyber Electromagnetic Activities (CEMA) and the proposed testbed for its evaluation. Cyber Electromagnetic Activities represent the synchronized integration of cyberspace operations, electronic warfare, and spectrum management operations to seize, retain, and exploit advantages in cyberspace and the electromagnetic domain, while denying adversary access and safeguarding friendly system electromagnetic phenomena, protocol efficiency, and advanced Future Generation Network functionalities.

title: Accelerating Quantum Key Distribution Over Imperfect Quantum Channels by Reliable Quantum State Tomography
authors: Phillip Cornett, Albert B. Dinkins, Kwang-Cheng Chen
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: Traditional deployments of Quantum Key Distribution (QKD) promise unconditionally secure communication in which single measurements over individual key qubits are guaranteed to be correlated when no eavesdropper is present. When presented with a noisy quantum channel, this correlation is no longer a promise, and redundancy is required to ensure the key is properly exchanged in both noisy and compromised conditions. In this work, we present two new QKD methods called "BB84 with Quantum Error Mitigation" and "FAST QKD", each leveraging fast quantum state tomography (FQST) over quantum reference states - preamble qubits - to compute a channel model at a much faster rate than conventional tomography methods. Fast QKD further expands by leveraging fast tomography itself, permitting lower fidelity thresholds in noisy conditions while maintaining secure key generation. An evaluation of new potential attacks for both processes is also presented.

title: Applicability of Björck Sequences to NTN-Based Localization
authors: Harish K. Dureppagari, Chiranjib Saha, R. Michael Buehrer, Harpreet S. Dhillon
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: In this paper, we explore the use of Björck sequences, a class of constant amplitude zero autocorrelation (CAZAC) sequences, as a promising candidate for designing positioning reference signals (PRS) in Low Earth Orbit (LEO)based positioning, navigation, and timing (PNT) systems. Unlike legacy systems such as Global Navigation Satellite Systems (GNSS) and terrestrial networks (TNs), LEO-based systems experience large Doppler shifts and delay spreads, where traditional orthogonalization methods become ineffective. Compared to widely used sequences like Gold and Zadoff-Chu (ZC), Björck sequences offer improved ambiguity function behavior, nearly ideal autocorrelation, greater resilience to interference, and accurate delay estimation in high Doppler environments. To broaden their applicability, we also introduce a novel construction method that extends Björck sequences to non-prime lengths while minimizing cyclic autocorrelation. Focusing on LEO-based non-terrestrial network (NTN) localization, we compare the positioning performance of Björck and Gold sequences under diverse interference scenarios. The results demonstrate Björck sequences as a viable alternative for PRS design in Doppler-challenged NTN positioning systems.

title: Comparative Analysis of GNFETs and CNTFETs for Quaternary Logic - A review
authors: Saleem Syed, Korrapadu Mahammad Haneef, Puttu Chandra Sekhar, Sujitha Kasturi, L. Swathi, Pravallika Surabhi
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: As binary computing faces limitations from the "interconnection bottleneck," Multiple-Valued Logic (MVL) offers a path to greater computational density. A comparative analysis on two of the most trending research insight technologies CNTFET and GNFET based quaternary logics proved that Graphene Nanoribbon Field-Effect Transistors (GNFETs) whose threshold voltages can be controlled by simply adjusting the nanoribbon width are profoundly more efficient and provide a manufacturable platform for next generation computing. In the direct performance benchmark of a quaternary half-adder, the GNFET- based design demonstrates its superiority by achieving a 55% reduction in power dissipation and a 71% improvement in power delay product compared to an equivalent CNTFET circuit. Moreover, the flat structure of the architecture is compatible than the existing chip manufacturing which sidesteps the major fabrication and integration problems that hinder CNTFETs. This blend in the superior energy and a practical path to commercialization makes GNFETs the more promising platform for future high-density computing

title: Modeling Risk Assessment in IC Supply Chains under Hardware Trojan Attacks Using Prospect Theory
authors: Satyaki Nan
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: Hardware Trojans (HTs) pose significant threats to Integrated Circuits (ICs), particularly when test procedures are outsourced to potentially malicious third parties. Traditional detection approaches often fail under stealthy, dynamic adversaries, such as malicious testers who behave honestly during most sessions and deviate intermittently, executing so-called On-Off attacks. This paper proposes a trust evaluation framework that moves beyond individual test outcomes and instead assesses the trustworthiness of aggregate test data over time. Our model uses Bayesian inference with ternary anomaly feedback (detected, not detected, and uncertain) to estimate belief states. A prospect-theoretic utility function captures varying system risk tolerances, enabling application-aware trust assessment. To counter on-off attacks, we introduce an asymmetric weighted moving average (AWMA) scheme that penalizes abrupt deviations more than rewards cooperative behavior. Simulation results demonstrate that our framework reliably detects transient threats, adapts to imperfect anomaly detection, and reflects critical system-level trust requirements.

title: A Review on Utilization of Thermoelectric Generator (TEG)-based Power Harvesting Systems for IoT Applications
authors: A. Kalaiazhagi, S. Abarna, S. Sneha, P. Yuvaraj
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: In recent years, the adoption of Internet of Things (IoT) technology has expanded rapidly across various sectors. However, most of these devices still rely on conventional batteries, which have limited lifespans and are difficult to replace, particularly in remote or inaccessible locations. To address this challenge, researchers have explored thermoelectric generators (TEGs) as a promising alternative energy source. TEGs can directly convert waste heat into usable electrical energy, providing a sustainable solution for powering IoT systems. This paper presents a comprehensive review of different approaches for utilising TEGs in IoT applications. It highlights advancements in thermoelectric materials, circuit design, and energy storage techniques that enhance system efficiency. Furthermore, it discusses the role of technologies such as Maximum Power Point Tracking (MPPT) techniques and low-power communication in improving overall performance. The review also identifies key challenges, innovative trends, and future opportunities for implementing TEG-based energy harvesting in industrial automation, transportation, and smart home environments.

title: ProLoC: An Efficient Probability-Based Forwarding Mechanism Considering Load Factor for Congestion Control in Named Data Networking
authors: Wenzhuo Lyu, Pushpendu Kar, Sherif Welsen, Alejandro Guerra-Manzanares
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conferences on Internet of Things (iThings) IEEE Green Computing &amp; Communications (GreenCom) IEEE Cyber, Physical &amp; Social Computing (CPSCom) and IEEE Smart Data (SmartData) and IEEE Congress on Cybermatics (Cybermatics)
abstract: Named Data Networking (NDN) has become a highly promising architecture for the future of the Internet of Things (IoT). However, congestion remains a significant challenge in NDN, as it hinders real-time communication between network devices and lowers the Quality of Service (QoS). Developing effective congestion control mechanisms for NDN remains a persistent challenge, particularly in fully utilizing its multipath routing and router capabilities. Previous work has overlooked the essential role of NDN routers in congestion control. To address this gap, we propose an efficient Probability-based Forwarding Mechanism considering Load Factor for Congestion Control (ProLoC) in NDN. Our innovative approach incorporates the load factor into the probability-based forwarding decision process and dynamically updates congestion information. The mechanism actively manages traffic, distributes load across multiple paths to prevent congestion, and optimizes resource allocation. Simulation results demonstrate that ProLoC outperforms three state-of-the-art congestion control protocols for NDN (PCON, QSCCP, and AQM). Specifically, ProLoC demonstrates zero packet loss over 10,000 time steps, in contrast to AQM's 14,080 lost packets and PCON's 24. Throughput comparisons show that ProLoC achieves 53.8 % higher throughput than QSCCP and a 156.2 % improvement over PCON, while consistently maintaining a stable round-trip time (RTT) of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$11 \pm 1 ~\text{ms}$</tex> and a near perfect fairness index of 0.9995. This highlights ProLoC's ability to prevent and respond to sudden network congestion while maintaining high performance across key metrics.

title: Zerobite: A Real-Time Food Donation and Waste Management System
authors: Cinthuja K, Kavitha Subramani, Jeya Mohan H, Vyshnavi K, Alin Jebitha B, Amrin Joshiga A
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: This Food waste is a significant societal challenge, characterized by a paradox: an abundance of surplus food coexists with community need. Zerobite is a web application designed to bridge this gap by creating an efficient connection between food donors—such as restaurants and individuals—and recipients, including NGOs and volunteers. The platform is built on a modern, scalable stack, utilizing the Django REST Framework for a robust backend API and React with SCSS for a dynamic and intuitive frontend interface. Data is managed and structured efficiently using MySQL. The application incorporates a comprehensive suite of features to streamline the food redistribution process. This includes secure user registration and authentication, modules for posting food donations and requests, and critical tracking of food expiry times to ensure safety. An integrated mapping system allows for precise location verification, facilitating efficient pickup and delivery logistics. Furthermore, a structured donation confirmation process provides accountability and transparency for all parties involved. By digitizing this ecosystem, Zerobite establishes an efficient operational workflow that not only reduces food waste but also fosters community solidarity. It stands as a practical, technology-driven solution to a pressing environmental and social problem, promoting sustainability through effective resource sharing.

title: Molecular Resistance Pathway Prediction System using SMILES-based Structural Features for Drug Response and Bioactivity Analysis
authors: Syed Athika Sultana, Pasuluri Binduswetha, Charan Sai Raja Vennakandla, Nimmagadda Padmaja, Sowmya Gali, Udayabhaskar Pattapu
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: This paper introduces a compact deployable Streamlit-based system molecular property prediction with resistance pathway classification that shows the ability to use the minimal, well-defined features for the rapid prototyping in the drug discovery workflow. The application has two interactive streams, one is the estimator of the molecular weight with two explicit inputs i.e. number of hydrogen bond donors and number of hydrogen bond acceptors, and it performs the inference using a pre-trained model loaded from molecularmodel.pkl The second stream predicts resistance pathways based on accepting SMILES string (or csv file with a SMILES column) and obtaining a simple feature (SMILES length) and using a binary classifier loaded from resistance model. pkl to assign Resistant or Non-Resistant labels for the entries, with batch predictions being supported and make predictions in a tabular view. The codebase uses pandas for handling the data and joblib to serialize the model, as needed to process HDF5 files, and according to the project environment, scikit-learn and rdkit are among the project's dependencies, suggesting that the project supports traditional chemoinformatics tools. We describe the input engineering, outflows of inference, user interaction design and evaluate ready outputs implied by the code and emphasize the desire for reproducibility, for transparency of feature choices and light weight versatility for deployment path that can be aggressive for exemplary analyses and integration into larger pipelines.

title: Low Power ΣΔ Modulator Applied to CIS Column Parallel Readout Circuit
authors: Dengju Sun, Zhongjie Guo, Ruiming Xu, Jinquan Zhou
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Integrated Circuits and Microsystems (ICICM)
abstract: This paper is based on the second-order incremental $\boldsymbol{\Sigma} \boldsymbol{\Delta}$ analog-to-digital converter (ADC) of CMOS image sensor (CIS). A low-power column parallel $\boldsymbol{\Sigma} \boldsymbol{\Delta}$ modulator based on the shared structure of inter-column operational amplifier(OTA) is proposed. Through the time division multiplexing of the OTA between the two adjacent columns of readout circuits, compared with the traditional modulator structure, the power consumption can be reduced by nearly half. It is made by 55 nm CIS process and powered by a 3.3 V power supply. The power consumption of a single column is $344 \mu \mathrm{~W}$. The operating rate of the modulator is $5 \mathrm{MS} / \mathrm{s}$, and the OTA is 256. At the input signal bandwidth of 8.27 kHz, the simulation results show that the SNDR is $\mathbf{9 3. 9 d B}$ and the ENOB is $\mathbf{1 5. 3}$ bits.

title: Using Machine Learning to Detect and Locate Rogue Devices from Time-Domain Reflectometry
authors: Michael Eydenberg, Jason J. Haas
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: Cyber-Physical Systems (CPSs), such as automobiles, aircraft, or operational technology (OT), often lack security mechanisms present in more traditional information technology (IT) networks, including physical security mechanisms or barriers. To defend CPSs, we need to consider cyber attacks enabled by physical access. Specifically, attackers may place a rogue device, which is under their control, into a CPS to be used at a time and place (consider mobile systems) of their choosing. To sufficiently defend a system, one may need to detect such a device before operating a system, such as driving an automobile. We propose and present results from a novel approach that couples time-domain reflectometry (TDR) with physics-informed machine learning to detect and localize rogue devices. We demonstrate and validate our approach using both simulated and testbed Controller Area Network (CAN) TDR data. We will evaluate our methods on real-world networks in future work.

title: A 9.37-Tb/s/mm 5-bit-6-bit Crosstalk Cancellation Transceiver with ICBS Codes for High-Density Die-to-Die Interfaces
authors: Ruotian Yin, Jinwen Li, Fangxu Lv, Geng Zhang, Ruixiao Kuai, Bohui Bai
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Integrated Circuits and Microsystems (ICICM)
abstract: A $9.37-\mathrm{Tb} / \mathrm{s} / \mathrm{mm}$ 5-bit-6-bit crosstalk cancellation (XTC) transceiver is proposed for high-density Die-to-Die Interfaces. An XTC scheme based on Inter-Channel Bit Smoothing Coding (ICBS) is proposed to improve the signal integrity. Through controlled inter-channel bit transitions, the ICBS reduces far-end crosstalk (FEXT) by 40.07%. Simulation results in 28 nm CMOS demonstrate 69.3% jitter reduction at $12.5-\mathrm{Gb} / \mathrm{s} / \mathrm{pin}$ on a high-density on-chip channel with FEXT of 4.14 dB, enabling reliable high-speed multi-die integration.

title: Hybrid Autoencoder and Ensemble Deep Learning Model for Stroke Prediction
authors: Soujanya Thirunagari, A.V. Lalitha Devi, Pinninti Siva Deepthi, Vunnava Dinesh Babu, Vangapandu Venkata Kalyani, A. Lakshmanarao
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: Brain stroke is a serious and life-threatening medical emergency caused by interrupted blood flow to the brain, leading to permanent neurological damage or death if not diagnosed early. Predicting stroke risk from patient health data remains challenging due to complex feature interactions, data imbalance, and heterogeneous clinical attributes. This work proposes a Hybrid Autoencoder and Ensemble Deep Learning Model for reliable stroke prediction using the publicly available Kaggle dataset. The proposed system integrates a denoising autoencoder to extract compact latent features from demographic, lifestyle, and medical variables, effectively reducing noise and redundancy in the input space. These latent representations are concatenated with key original attributes and used to train multiple advanced models, including TabNet, FT-Transformer, Deep Neural Networks, XGBoost, and CatBoost. Class imbalance is addressed through the Borderline-SMOTE technique and class-balanced focal loss during model optimization. A stacking ensemble with logistic regression as a meta-learner combines the outputs of the top-performing base models to generate the final prediction. Experimental evaluation demonstrates improved accuracy, F1-score, and ROC-AUC compared to traditional machine learning and standalone neural network approaches, confirming the effectiveness of the proposed hybrid deep ensemble for early stroke risk assessment.

title: Attention-Enhanced Deep Learning Framework for Driver Drowsiness Detection in Intelligent Transportation Systems
authors: Kuruma Purnima, Chandragiri Guruprasad, Kotte Chaitanya, Kanikanti Naga Sai Rama Krishna, A Naresh, Dasamandam Harsha Vardhan
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: Driver drowsiness is a major cause of road accidents, endangering lives and reducing transportation efficiency. To address this issue, this paper proposes an attention-enhanced deep learning framework for real-time driver drowsiness detection within intelligent transportation systems (ITS). The system integrates convolutional neural networks (CNNs) for spatial feature extraction, Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) units for modeling temporal behavior, and an attention mechanism to prioritize fatigue-related cues such as eyelid closure, yawning, and gaze deviation. Attention maps highlight critical regions, improving interpretability and reducing false detections. The framework is optimized for low latency and can operate on embedded platforms for in-vehicle deployment. Experimental evaluations on benchmark and custom-acquired datasets demonstrate an accuracy exceeding 95%, with superior robustness under varying illumination and head pose conditions. The proposed approach provides a scalable, interpretable, and efficient solution for enhancing road safety and advancing real-time driver monitoring in modern ITS environments.

title: Classification of Automated Driving Systems
authors: Bidhya Shrestha, Bhargab Acharya, Jonathan Petit, Christos Papadopoulos
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: Automated driving vehicles are transforming the consumer and military landscapes. Although most of them currently rely on a single, proprietary, embedded system, Software-Defined Vehicles (SDVs) are poised to accommodate multiple such systems, each best suited for different operating environments. Detecting which system is currently active is important for identifying system malfunction or compromise.We developed a machine learning-based classifier to distinguish between various automated systems, as well as when a human is driving, using only telematics data. We employed a Gated Recurrent Unit (GRU)-based classification model trained on time-series telematics datasets from three automated driving systems: Comma’s Openpilot, Tesla’s Autopilot, and Cadillac’s Super-Cruise, to analyze key driving behavior indicators such as acceleration profiles, braking, and steering patterns. Our experiments show that we can differentiate between the three automated systems or when a human is driving (F1-score of 90+%). Our tests are on passenger cars, but we expect our system to be applicable to any automated vehicle type (land, air, or marine) with telematics.

title: A Jamming-Resilient 5G PUCCH Receiver for Small Block Coding Region
authors: Mustafa Celik, Cagri Goken, Okan Erturk
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: As the 5G New Radio (NR) standard is primarily designed to meet the needs of commercial cellular communications, it is not inherently robust against malicious interference sources such as jammers. To support military-grade deployments in diverse tactical environments, there is a need for a jamming-resilient physical uplink control channel (PUCCH) receiver. PUCCH plays a vital role in transmitting various control messages, collectively referred to as uplink control information (UCI), from user equipment (UE) to the base station (BS). For UCI payloads between 3 and 11 bits, small block coding (SBC) is employed. Due to their short lengths, these codes do not include a cyclic redundancy check (CRC), complicating error detection and the assurance of message reliability, especially in the presence of interference. To address this challenge, we propose a jamming-resilient PUCCH receiver that leverages a robust reliability assessment mechanism based on a threshold criterion, which bounds the probability of decoding errors. Additionally, we introduce a channel estimation error-aware equalizer tailored for DFT-s-OFDM waveforms, enabling more accurate computation of log-likelihood ratios (LLRs). Simulation results demonstrate that the proposed receiver can effectively evaluate decoding reliability without relying on CRC, even under jamming conditions, thereby enhancing the robustness of 5G control signaling in contested environments.

title: Low-Power MCU Architecture Optimization and Energy Efficiency Enhancement in Intelligent Pressure Sensor SoCs
authors: Yaoming Lv, Hong Yang, Feng Zou, Yuhua Cheng
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Integrated Circuits and Microsystems (ICICM)
abstract: In intelligent pressure sensor System-on-Chip (SoC) applications, the micro-controller unit (MCU) serves as a critical control and computational core, with its power consumption directly impacting system energy efficiency and battery life. These MCUs typically operate in a periodic wake-up and short-term operation mode within such systems. Reducing MCU active time by maximizing operating frequency is essential for power savings. This study proposes a dynamic adaptive calibration technique for maximum frequency, which adjusts system frequency in real time by monitoring MCU instruction fetch correctness. Unlike conventional voltage-tracking-based maximum frequency calibration, this approach eliminates voltage detection circuits and voltage-frequency mapping tables while mitigating aging effects. In low-power designs, clock control strategy plays an important role in optimizing power consumption. This paper proposes an instruction-decoding-driven fine-grained dynamic clock control technique. Compared to conventional approaches, this method enables instruction-level clock gating to achieve micro-operation-level power optimization. Experimental validation in intelligent sensor systems demonstrates that the proposed low-power technique enhances system energy efficiency by 16% under typical operating conditions.

title: Channel-Shuffle UNet: An Efficient Boundary-Preserving Framework for Nucleus Segmentation
authors: Gunjan Shandilya, Sheifali Gupta, G Sunil, Sonal Malhotra, Kamlesh Kukreti
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: Precise nucleus segmentation is a very important condition of computational pathology and analysis of whole-slide images, which allows the accurate quantification of cellular morphology and spatial arrangement. Nevertheless, conventional deep learning systems tend to lose fine nuclear borders and feature variety in the decoding process. This research proposed a Boundary Aware EfficientNet-UNet and Channel Shuffle Decoder to overcome these constraints to segment nuclei in H&E-stained histopathological images automatically. To extract the multi-scale contextual features, the proposed framework uses an EfficientNet-B0 encoder which is computationally efficient. There is the introduction of a channel shuffle-based decoder to increase the inter channel feature interaction and decrease redundancy to be able to get better feature fusion during upsampling. Also, the skip connections provide structural consistency of the encoder and decoder paths. The model is trained and tested on NuInsSeg dataset. The experimental findings reveal that the given approach performs better in terms of Dice coefficient of 0.82 and Intersection-over-Union (IoU) of 0.71 and accuracy of 95 percent especially at the boundaries of nuclei, and the computational overhead is low.

title: Heuristic-Enhanced Mathematical Optimization Algorithms for Channel Assignment and Interference Mitigation
authors: Ryan Li, Vicky H. Mak-Hau, Trudy Lam, Angus Gaudry
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: This paper addresses the frequency assignment problem in high-throughput geostationary satellite communication (SATCOM) systems, where co-channel interference imposes serious constraints on spectrum efficiency. We propose two computational frameworks, ALG-MUSIC and ALG-BEAT, developed within our SatDreamOpt system to optimize frequency allocation under interference limitations. ALG-MUSIC seeks to maximize the number of users assigned their full bandwidth, while ALG-BEAT prioritizes activating a larger total of weighted user sub-channels by allowing partial allocations. Both approaches employ a Two-Pass hybrid strategy. The first pass applies a greedy heuristic to assign sub-channels while strictly enforcing interference thresholds. The second pass expands the candidate set by temporarily relaxing these constraints, followed by an integer programming model that selects a final set of active users satisfying the interference limits. Experiments on both synthetic and SatDreamOpt data show that ALG-MUSIC achieves solution quality comparable to commercial solvers such as Gurobi, but with significantly reduced computation time. ALG-BEAT achieves higher spectrum utilization, especially in bandwidth-constrained settings. Both algorithms scale effectively to problem sizes beyond the reach of exact methods. The results demonstrate the practicality and efficiency of hybrid optimization for interference-aware frequency planning in satellite networks.

title: MCF-UPCN: Modified Conditional Random Field-based Deep Learning Model for Liver Tumor Detection using Computed Tomography Images
authors: Baswanthrao Patil, Sachinkumar S Veerashetty
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: In recent decades, liver tumor detection has remained a significant problem due to the vague boundary nature of the liver. The traditional models face certain obstacles related to misinterpretation, poor accuracy, overfitting issues, and high computational complexity. Hence, to address such intricacies, the research proposes the Basawanthrao Patil P3-based UNet ensembled Pyramidal Deep Convolution Neural Network (MCF-UPCN), a liver tumor detection model using computed tomography scans. The MCF-UPCN model offers effective planning and monitoring, which would lead to accurate volume measurement. In addition, the research incorporates a Modified Conditional Random Field-based UNet segmentation technique, which offers a precise segmentation outcome with minimal training samples. Moreover, the proposed models extract efficient spatial and texture-based information through the incorporation of 3DGH features, which showcase powerful features for exact segmentation and detection of liver tumors. Further, the superiority of the MCF-UPCN model is evaluated using the training percentage analysis, which reveals 95.92% accuracy, 97.05% sensitivity, and 93.66% specificity in terms of training percentage 90.

title: A Node Merging Algorithm Using Fault-Detection for XOR-Majority Network
authors: Shijia Fan, Feifei Deng
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Integrated Circuits and Microsystems (ICICM)
abstract: Recent advancements in emerging technology have spurred the development of novel electronic devices, such as Quantum-dot Cellular Automata (QCA) as a transistoralternative computing architecture, and Magnetic RandomAccess Memory (MRAM) as a next-generation storage medium. These technologies enable efficient implementations of XOR and majority logic, which offer superior expressiveness compared to traditional AND/OR logic. As a result, researchers have introduced new logical structures MIGs and XMGs, which pose more demands for digital logic synthesis. In this paper, we propose a node merging algorithm using fault detect model for XMGs logic synthesis, including building an optimal majority node and XOR node model using the path sensitivity method from single stuck-at fault model testing, activating and propagating faults among majority node and XOR nodes in the XMGs, and using ROBDD tree to compute and store the mandatory assignment sets for efficient storage. The algorithm is implemented in the C++ language under the framework of the EPFL logic synthesis tool. The experiment results show that the proposed algorithm can effectively reduce the depth and number of nodes of XMGs circuits when applied to the standard test circuit in EPFL, with an average optimization depth of 2.07% and an average optimization number of 0.91% in the 2-level verification, and can gain better optimization effect when the window sizes increase.

title: CMOS PWM Controller Design for GaN-Based 48V1 V DC-DC Buck Converter
authors: Guanyu Wu, Miao Cui
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Integrated Circuits and Microsystems (ICICM)
abstract: Gallium Nitride (GaN) devices have seen increasing adoption in applications such as space systems and data center power management, owing to their superior efficiency, highfrequency capabilities, and excellent thermal stability. The direct $\mathbf{4 8 V}$-to-1V GaN converters are emerging as promising alternatives to conventional two-stage voltage regulation. This direct approach offers significant advantages in offering high power density and enhancing transient response. However, implementing direct 48 V -to-1V conversion necessitates an extremely low duty cycle (approximately 2%) which poses challenges for control precision and power stage design. This work proposes a CMOS-based PWM generator capable of achieving a wide duty cycle range ($1 \%-99 \%$) at $\mathbf{1 0 M H z}$. The circuit successfully drives the EPC2065 GaN device at $\mathbf{1 M H z}$, enabling stable $\mathbf{4 8 V}$-to- $\mathbf{1 V}$ power conversion and offering a compact, high-performance solution for next-generation power management systems.

title: Two-Dimensional XOR-Based Secret Sharing for Layered Multipath Communication
authors: Wai Ming Chan, Rémi Chou, Taejoon Kim
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: This paper introduces the first two-dimensional XOR-based secret sharing scheme for layered multipath communication networks. We present a construction that guarantees successful message recovery and perfect privacy when an adversary observes and disrupts any single path at each transmission layer. The scheme achieves information-theoretic security using only bitwise XOR operations with linear O(|S|) complexity, where |S| is the message length. We provide mathematical proofs demonstrating that the scheme maintains unconditional security regardless of computational resources available to adversaries. Unlike encryption-based approaches vulnerable to quantum computing advances, our construction offers provable security suitable for resource-constrained military environments where computational assumptions may fail.

title: Blockchain Consortium Model for Gig Economy Contract Agreements
authors: Inayatulloh Inayatulloh, Adhi Surya, Tulus Martua Sihombing, Denok Sunarsi, Wiza Teguh, Ernawaty Ernawaty
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: The gig economy is an economic system where work is task-based, project-based, or short-term contract-based rather than full-time employment. In this system, workers are referred to as gig workers or freelancers, and they typically work flexibly through digital platforms or applications. The gig economy has raised concerns about the lack of transparency in employment transactions, which affects worker protection and wages. Therefore, this study proposes developing a blockchain-based model to manage gig economy activities, with a focus on ensuring information transparency to safeguard workers' rights. The research focuses on online transportation involving drivers, the government, and digital platform companies. The blockchain model used is a consortium blockchain, where system management is shared among involved organizations. This study employs a Research and Development (R&D) approach, encompassing stages such as problem identification, system design, prototype development utilizing smart contracts and Hyperledger Fabric, and prototype testing. Simulation results with Hyperledger indicate that all transactions related to the gig economy must undergo peer-to-peer validation to ensure the transparency of the information.

title: Computation- and Communication-Efficient Online FL for Resource-Constrained Aerial Vehicles
authors: Ferdous Pervej, Richeng Jin, Md Moin Uddin Chowdhury, Simran Singh, İsmail Güvenç, Huaiyu Dai
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: Privacy-preserving distributed machine learning (ML) and aerial connected vehicle (ACV)-assisted<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">1</sup> edge computing have drawn significant attention lately. Since the on-board sensors of ACVs can capture new data as they move along their trajectories, the continual arrival of such ‘newly’ sensed data leads to online learning and demands carefully crafting the trajectories. Besides, as typical ACVs are inherently resource-constrained, computation- and communication-efficient ML solutions are needed. Therefore, we propose a computation- and communication-efficient online aerial federated learning (2CEOAFL) algorithm to take the benefits of continual sensed data and limited onboard resources of the ACVs. In particular, considering independently owned ACVs act as selfish data collectors, we first model their trajectories according to their respective time-varying data distributions. We then propose a 2CEOAFL algorithm that allows the flying ACVs to (a) prune the received dense ML model to make it shallow, (b) train the pruned model, and (c) probabilistically quantize and offload their trained accumulated gradients to the central server (CS). Our extensive simulation results show that the proposed 2CEOAFL algorithm delivers comparable performances to its non-pruned and non-quantized, hence, computation- and communication-inefficient counterparts.

title: Advanced AI Driven Solution for Precise Water Management in Irrigation Systems
authors: S.S.Thamilselvi, Kalpana Devi S, Kamatchi Kannan V, B.V. Sai Thrinath, K. Thenmalar, Ponmurugan P
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: The research provides an artificial intelligence (AI) approach that uses data from temperature and soil moisture sensors stored in the cloud to provide precise water management in agricultural irrigation systems. To assess irrigation demands, the proposed method compares real-time sensor readings with specified threshold levels. This automated procedure increases crop productivity, conserves water, and supports environmentally friendly farming methods. Proactive intervention, accurate decision-making, and the combination of AI algorithms and IoT sensors enables real-time adjustments to irrigation processes. In order to accommodate different farm sizes and geographic locations, the suggested system offers scalability, adaptability, and user-friendly interfaces. This helps to promote sustainable agriculture and resource conservation.

title: Fast Online Digital Twinning on FPGA for Mission Critical Applications
authors: Bin Xu, Ayan Banerjee, Sandeep K.S. Gupta
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: Digital twinning enables real-time simulation and predictive modeling by maintaining a continuously updated virtual representation of a physical system. In mission-critical applications—such as mid-air collision avoidance—these models must operate online with extremely low latency to ensure safety. However, executing complex Model Recovery (MR) pipelines on edge devices is limited by computational and memory bandwidth constraints. This paper introduces a fast, FPGA-accelerated digital twinning framework that offloads key neural components—including gated recurrent units (GRU) and dense layers—to reconfigurable hardware for efficient parallel execution. Our system achieves real-time responsiveness, operating five times faster than typical human reaction time, and demonstrates the practical viability of deploying digital twins on edge platforms for time-sensitive, safety-critical environments.

title: TerraLearn: Scalable AI Tutoring for Remote and Resource-Constrained Regions
authors: Subhashree Rath, Kasamsetty Varshitha, Kattamreddy Bhavyuktha, Modaboina Rithika, Mukkamalla Sasritha Reddy
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: TerraLearn is a site that implements AI to support students through tutoring and assessment. It has been able to impress with the same accuracy on both offline and online modes during the machine learning process with a single user involved in real time. The process of quizzing features a testing engine that produces quizzes customized to a person's changing performance. The usage of federated learning boosts the algorithms while maintaining the utmost privacy, even more so. The platform supports a multilingual voice interface and smart scheduling in order to make the learning experience smoother across various language barriers and provide more effective study times according to the learner's pace. Also, TerraLearn enables students to share their resources with each other. They can swap lessons and keep the records of their achievements even when there is no internet connection. TerraLearn is not only really personalized but also offline quick and low-cost smartphones with dependable multilingual voice recognition after a series of tests. It was more versatile and efficient than traditional learning apps. The commitment to privacy and scalability makes TerraLearn a blessing for equal, data-rich education in the areas with limited or no internet connectivity.

title: Exploring Emerging Materials and Architectures for Energy-Efficient and High-Performance Computing
authors: Eswararao Boddepalli, Ban Safar Khalaf, Faris Hassan Taha Hussain, Abdul Hussein Mohsen, S.Suma Christal Mary, Prabhu M
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: Alternatives to traditional CMOS scaling are explored in terms of advanced computing technology, materials and device architecture in this study. High speed and low power electronic devices can be fabricated using carbon nanotubes and graphene owing to their excellent transfer mobility and thermal conductivity. Such materials including MoS<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf> and black phosphorus have good switching capabilities and are suitable bandgaps for electronic applications. Among the innovated devices Tunnel FETs have demonstrated extremely low power consumption and high ON/OFF ratios which are good factors for energy efficient computing. High density memory solution is also presented using spintronic devices and memristors. Nonvolatility is provided by spintronics, while ultrafast switching can be performed with minimal energy use utilizing memristors. However, despite that potential for exponential speedups, quantum computing is an extremely challenging thing to implement. In both case of memristors and spintronic devices, the power efficiency is much higher than conventional CMOS technologies. The comparison shows that they are capable of achieving 50–100 TOPS/W, which is beyond CMOS. Advances in these technologies have the potential to provide the technology revolution needed for high performance and energy efficient computing systems. For the development of ultra-low power and neuromorphic architectures, they are particularly important since they can provide a significant enhancement in scalability, energy usage and speed over present CMOS based systems.

title: Link Budgets of Engineered Wavefronts in Near-Field THz Communications
authors: Hichem Guerboukha
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: The millimeter-wave and terahertz (THz) bands are key enabler for sixth-generation (6G) wireless networks. Traditional link budgets based on the Friis equation fail in the near-field, where wavefronts are neither spherical nor planar, especially for large-aperture antennas at THz frequencies. In this work, we develop a formulation for near-field link budgets, derived from the Huygens-Fresnel diffraction principle, and we drastically reduce computational complexity via a space-separable approximation. We evaluate engineered wavefronts, including Gaussian, focused, Bessel and Airy beams, and demonstrate unique power distribution behaviors and potential advantages such as obstacle evasion and localized energy focusing. Finally, using this framework, we propose an alternative definition of the far-field distance based on the practical applicability of the Friis equations. The proposed formalism enables more accurate performance evaluation and design of near-field THz wireless links.

title: Demo: V2X Enabled Delivery - Towards an Integration with Robot, Aerial and Ground Vehicle
authors: Lukang Ning, Manuel Bied, Alexey Vinel
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on 6G Networking (6GNet)
abstract: The future 6G communication systems are expected to enable and support new robotic applications that rely on a higher density of communication links. At the same time the adoption of robotics is becoming more and more widely. One of the new emerging research areas is the integration of robotics into delivery processes to alleviate human labor. In this work we examine a scenario in bike delivery which combines Unmanned Aerial Vehicles (UAVs) and robots with Vehicle-to-Everything (V2X). We present a demonstration that showcases preliminary steps toward realizing the full scenario. The demonstration features a robot that autonomously loads cargo into a delivery bag. In the envisioned system, a UAV delivers packages near the bicycle, and a robot loads the items into a bag mounted on the rear of the bike. With the application of V2X technology in this scenario, these components could form a network and communicate with each other. This approach aims to enhance the efficiency and regularity of deliveries, thereby ease the burden of the human in delivery. This preliminary work presents a demonstration in which a robot autonomously picks up a small cargo item from the ground and loads it into a bag, simulating the envisioned loading procedure.

title: Replicated Partitioning for Hypergraphs with Multiple Constraints
authors: Kexin Zhang, Shunyang Bi, Jing Tang, Hailong You, Qiwang Chen
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Integrated Circuits and Microsystems (ICICM)
abstract: Nowadays, with the explosive growth of circuit design complexity and the limited capacity of a single FPGA, the Multi-FPGA System (MFS) has become the primary solution to tackle the challenges brought by large-scale designs. Therefore, designing a suitable partition for MFS to reduce the total_hop has become a key research question affecting the overall system performance. This paper first combines replication and movement operations to optimizes the total hop by replicating appropriate gates. The experimental results show that our method can reduce the total hop by an average of 43%, effectively improving the partitioning performance.

title: Isoflux Beamforming Method for Phased Arrays in LEO Satellites Based on Enhanced MMPTE
authors: Huadong Guo, Wen Wang, Meng Zhang, Xiaoke Feng, Jinglong Guo
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: This paper proposes an isoflux beamforming method for phased array antennas in low Earth orbit (LEO) satellite systems, incorporating two key enhancements to the classical method of maximum power transmission efficiency (MMPTE). A constraint-based optimization strategy is introduced to enable wide-angle isoflux coverage, while a precision weighting mechanism is developed to support consistent power distribution and directional flexibility in multi-beam scenarios. These techniques respectively address the challenges of significant link loss variation across wide angular spans and gain degradation at large off-axis angles. By embedding constraints into the optimization process and dynamically adjusting the weight matrix, the proposed method achieves consistent isoflux radiation under varying orbital altitudes. Simulation results based on a 6×6 uniform rectangular array (URA) show that the proposed method effectively forms wide-angle beams covering up to ±40° with deviations of less than 1dB from the theoretical profile. In addition, flexible direction and gain control in dual- and triple-beam scenarios is demonstrated. The results further confirm the broad applicability of the proposed method to isoflux beam shaping across varying orbital altitudes, validating its effectiveness in enabling wide-angle and multi-beam isoflux communication with consistent signal quality in LEO environments.

title: Mutated Leader Algorithm based DenseNet for COVID-19 Classification using CT Images
authors: S. Karthi, L. R Sudha, M. Navaneetha Krishnan
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: Coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) is a global pandemic in December 2019, continues to spread worldwide. Thus, real-time reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (rRT-PCR) and chest computed tomography (CT) imaging are vital for diagnosing COVID-19. Particularly, chest CT is more advantageous because it provides rapid results, cost-effective, and offers high sensitivity for detecting lung infections. Recently, Deep Learning (DL)-based techniques have shown significant potential for clinical imaging. However, training traditional DL models requires large datasets, and medical professionals face increased risks when gathering CT images from COVID-19 individuals due to the complicated growth of the virus. Thus, this work presents an effective Mutated leader Algorithm_DenseNet (MLA_DenseNet) for classifying various levels of COVID-19. At first, the input CT image is pre-processed by an adaptive bilateral filter. Thereafter, lung lobe segmentation was conducted through U-Net ++. After that, segmentation of lung lesions is conducted based on U-Net ++. In addition, significant features are extracted from the lung lesion segmentation results. Lastly, COVID-19 classification is carried out using a Densely Connected Convolutional Network (DenseNet), and the Mutated Leader Algorithm (MLA) is utilized to train the hyperparameters of DenseNet. Furthermore, the developed module achieved precision, sensitivity, and specificity of 90.00%, 90.288%, and 90.858%.

title: Low-SWaP Spectrum Sensing across 32 GHz Bandwidth at D-Band using Maximally-Decimated Uniform Approximate DFT Polyphase FIR Filterbanks on Altera Stratix-10 AX Chiplets
authors: Michael Nilan, Buddhipriya Gayanath, Kasun Karunanayake, Arjuna Madanayake, Renato J. Cintra
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: The increasing use of mm-waves and sub-THz bands, especially the 100–300 GHz range for a variety of wireless applications in the battlefield, opens up new challenges for sensors and systems. In this work, we demonstrate spectral channelization in the D-band across a 32 GHz bandwidth at a spectral resolution of 1 GHz with a sample rate 64 GS/s. A low-complexity polyphase filterbank that replaces fast Fourier transform (FFT) blocks that require ${\mathcal{O}}$(N logN) multiplications with an approximate discrete Fourier transform (DFT) requiring zero multiplication operations is used for channelization. An analysis filterbank of order 32 is used for box-car responses across each subband, with a total interference suppression better than 44 dB. Spectrum occupancy is sensed using a multiplierless energy detection algorithm; an error correction technique is proposed and demonstrated experimentally to show how the approximate discrete Fourier transform (ADFT) errors can be largely removed for sensing applications. A testbed consisting of a D-band receiver from Virginia Diodes and a digital mixed-signal field programmable gate array (FPGA) platform from Altera with integrated analog-to-digital converters (ADCs) operating at 64 GS/s over 128 parallel digital phases are used for verification of the algorithms.

title: Zak-OTFS with Spread Pilot in Sub-6 GHz: Implementation and Over-the-Air Experimentation
authors: Junyao Zheng, Venkatesh Khammammetti, Beyza Dabak, Sandesh Rao Mattu, Tingjun Chen, Robert Calderbank
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: In 6G mobile communication systems, it is anticipated that joint channel estimation and data decoding (JCED) will play a key role in resource sharing, spectrum utilization and reducing the hardware costs. The shortcomings of Orthogonal Frequency Division Multiplexing (OFDM) as a JCED waveform have led to interest in new waveforms, among them Zak-Orthogonal Time Frequency Space (Zak-OTFS), which has good spectral efficiency and error rate performance even in doubly spread channels. In theory, it has all the features required for a next-generation waveform, but over-the-air (OTA) experiments are lacking. In this paper, we describe the first OTA implementation of Zak-OTFS with a spread pilot for JCED at sub-6GHz frequencies. We perform turbo iteration to improve channel predictability. Our bit error rate (BER) and error vector magnitude (EVM) results against pilot to data power ratio (PDR) show that the selection of PDR plays an important role in improving the performance of JCED using Zak-OTFS with spread pilot.

title: A Deep Learning based Generative Channel Emulator for Neural Wireless System Design
authors: Adhitya Bantwal Bhandarkar, Debashri Roy, Tathagata Mukherjee, Sudharaman K. Jayaweera
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: Accurate wireless channel modeling is essential for the development and testing of modern communication systems, but traditional channel emulators often struggle to adapt to dynamic environments that vary in time. In order to address substantial demand for bandwidth in contemporary communication systems, the Terahertz spectrum (THz) could be utilized to build "beyond 5G and 6G" communication systems, particularly those with Integrated Sensing and Communications (ISAC). To address the challenges of channel emulation in dynamic high bandwidth environments like the THz band, we propose a Conditional Generative Adversarial Network (CGAN)-based wireless channel emulator capable of learning statistical channel characteristics directly from raw signal data. Unlike conventional approaches, the proposed framework is designed to generalize across diverse channel conditions, including additive noise and both large- and small-scale fading effects, while also adapting to potential temporal variations. Through extensive experiments, we demonstrate that our CGAN-based generator effectively replicates real-world wireless channels, including Additive White Gaussian Noise (AWGN) and various fading distributions such as Rayleigh, and Nakagami. We further validate our model on different modulation schemes that were previously unseen by the model during training, showcasing its versatility in practical communication scenarios. The performance of the proposed emulator is evaluated by comparing the statistical similarity between the true and emulated channel distributions using multiple distance metrics and analyzing first-, second- and higher-order moments. The results confirm that the proposed architecture provides an accurate and adaptive channel emulation framework, offering a robust tool for the design and evaluation of wireless communication systems.

title: Addressing Signal Integrity Challenges in DDR5 SDRAM: A High-Precision ZQ Calibration Circuit with Fast Calibration Time
authors: Kexin Feng, ZhiQiang Zhang
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Integrated Circuits and Microsystems (ICICM)
abstract: With the increasing data transfer rate, the DDR5 DRAM interface requires more and more stringent impedance matching accuracy. In this paper, a high-precision ZQ calibration circuit is proposed to achieve less than 3% impedance tolerance and 335 ns calibration time through three innovations. First, a $\mathbf{1 0 0 ~ M H z}$ chopper-modulated ZQ comparator is used to reduce the input offset voltage by 80%; second, a stopping mechanism is designed to force a larger voltage deviation and eliminate comparator substability; and third, a programmable Vref is designed to expand the reference voltage range and suppress process/voltage errors. Test results show that the scheme effectively improves impedance matching accuracy and addresses the signal integrity challenges of high-speed SDRAM.

title: TS-iCutpaste: Time Series Anomaly Detection for Cloud Performance Monitoring via Pre-Trained Models
authors: Anyi Zhang, Peng Xu, Yazhou Cao
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conferences on Internet of Things (iThings) IEEE Green Computing &amp; Communications (GreenCom) IEEE Cyber, Physical &amp; Social Computing (CPSCom) and IEEE Smart Data (SmartData) and IEEE Congress on Cybermatics (Cybermatics)
abstract: Anomaly detection of the time series data for cloud performance monitoring is to judge whether the current data deviates from the normal value from the general rule of historical data. Existing anomaly detection algorithms cannot effectively solve the anomaly detection problem of multi-dimensional time series operation status data. Because the statistical characterization of data is dynamically changing caused by frequent server increase or decrease and/or application online or offline. Inspired by pre-trained models, we study the problem of anomaly detection for multi-dimensional time series data from the aspect of pre-trained model. To address this problem, we propose a pretrained model called TS-iCutpaste. Specifically, first, we propose a Shift-Image-Transform approach to transforming time series data to a series of images. Then, we propose an improved Cutpaste approach to perform anomaly detection on images based on multi-dimensional time series data. Finally, we conduct experiments on the dataset and compare TS-iCutpaste with Cutpaste and TS-Bert. The results show that TS-iCutpaste can improve the accuracy by an average of 10 % compared with these methods.

title: Wide Area SATCOM Interference Mitigation for Radio Telescope Arrays Using Distributed RISs
authors: Jafar Norolahi, Tiep M. Hoang, Alireza Vahid, Rashmi Shah
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: This paper proposes a method to reduce satellite communication (SATCOM) interference around large radio telescope arrays (RTAs) using distributed active Reconfigurable Intelligent Surfaces (RISs). Unlike single RIS solutions, distributed RISs cover a broader area and field of view, improving interference management and signal reception at the RTA. RTAs receive interference directly from satellites and indirectly, in opposite phase, via the RISs. Our approach optimizes the Signal-to-Interference-plus-Noise Ratio by jointly optimizing RISs’ reflecting coefficients for interference self-mitigation and receive beamforming weights at RTA. This alignment reduces the interference. Our method employs active RISs capable of amplification to ensure sufficient reflected signal strength and effective cancellation of direct interference at the RTA. Simulations confirm the method’s effectiveness in reducing interference at RTA, improving the detection of astronomical signals, and validating this approach as a practical solution for protecting astronomical observations from growing SATCOM interference.

title: Design and Optimization of a Multi-Directional Anti-Misalignment Magnetic Coupler for Oil Drilling Rotary Steerable Systems
authors: Xincheng Xu, Chen Qi, Sichao Wang, Ning Liu, Peng Wang
publish: IEEE Journal of Emerging and Selected Topics in Power Electronics
abstract: To address power fluctuations caused by polar angle misalignment in rotary wireless power transfer (RWPT) for oil drilling rotary steerable systems (RSS), a novel three layers orthogonal magnetic coupler has been proposed. The proposed magnetic coupler uses a three-layer DD coil structure, with mutually orthogonal magnetic fields, which was utilized to generate mutual inductance to remain stable during rotation, with minimal variations under axial, radial, and polar angle misalignments. A design optimization method integrating Finite element analysis (FEA) and sequential mixed-integer nonlinear programming (SMINLP) is proposed, determining optimal mutual inductance and finding matching structural parameters, which save time of simulation and experiment. Compared to existing magnetic couplers, the proposed magnetic coupler exhibits tolerance against 360° full-space misalignment. At last, the prototype validates the multi-directional anti-misalignment capability of the proposed magnetic coupler.

title: Repeater Swarm-Assisted Cellular Systems: Interaction Stability and Performance Analysis
authors: Jianan Bai, Anubhab Chowdhury, Anders Hansson, Erik G. Larsson
publish: IEEE Transactions on Wireless Communications
abstract: We consider a cellular massive MIMO system where swarms of wireless repeaters are deployed to improve coverage. These repeaters are full-duplex relays with small form factors that receive and instantaneously retransmit signals. They can be deployed in a plug-and-play manner at low cost, while being transparent to the network—conceptually they are active channel scatterers with amplification capabilities. Two fundamental questions need to be addressed in repeater deployments: (i) How can we prevent destructive effects of positive feedback caused by inter-repeater interaction (i.e., each repeater receives and amplifies signals from others)? (ii) How much performance improvement can be achieved given that repeaters also inject noise and may introduce more interference? To answer these questions, we first derive a generalized Nyquist stability criterion for the repeater swarm system, and provide an easy-to-check stability condition. Then, we study the uplink performance and develop an efficient iterative algorithm that jointly optimizes the repeater gains, user transmit powers, and receive combining weights to maximize the weighted sum rate while ensuring system stability. Numerical results corroborate our theoretical findings and show that the repeaters can significantly improve the system performance, both in sub-6 GHz and millimeter-wave bands. The results also warrant careful deployment to fully realize the benefits of repeaters, for example, by ensuring a high probability of line-of-sight links between repeaters and the base station.

title: Low-Barrier Dataset Collection With Real Human Body for Interactive Per-Garment Virtual Try-On_supp1-3649499.mp4
authors: Zaiqiang Wu
publish: N/A
abstract: Existing image-based virtual try-on methods are limited to frontal views and lack real-time performance. While per-garment virtual try-on methods have tackled these issues by adopting per-garment training, they still encounter practical limitations: (1) the robotic mannequin used for per-garment datasets collection is prohibitively expensive; (2) the synthesized garments often misalign with the human body. To address these challenges, we propose a low-barrier approach to collect per-garment datasets using real human bodies, eliminating the need for an expensive robotic mannequin and reducing data collection time from 2 hours to 2 minutes. Additionally, we introduce a hybrid person representation that ensures precise human-garment alignment. We conducted qualitative and quantitative comparisons with state-of-the-art image-based virtual try-on methods to demonstrate the superiority of our method regarding image quality and temporal consistency. Furthermore, most participants in our user study found the system effective in supporting garment purchasing decisions.

title: Design and Fabrication of Wide-Angle Dual-Band Temperature-Controlled Absorption Metamaterial with Rotating-4F micro-nano Structures
authors: Hongyong Huang
publish: IEEE Sensors Journal
abstract: These Absorbing metamaterials show potential in both civilian and military applications. The in-depth research on the sixth-generation mobile communication (6G) has also increased the attention on terahertz absorbing metamaterials. This article studies and fabricates a terahertz-range dual-band absorption metamaterial, which is composed of a copper substrate, silicon dioxide, vanadium dioxide, graphene, and a rotating-4F silver metal patterned structure. Based on the Finite Difference Time Domain (FDTD) method, it was found that there are two peaks at 4.984 THz and 6.629 THz, with peak values of 86.18% and 94.43% under direct incidence conditions. The experimentally prepared samples exhibited peak frequencies of 4.977 THz and 6.648 THz, with peak values of 86.62% and 94.33% under direct incidence conditions, respectively. The paper analyzes the reasons for the absorption resonance at these two absorption peak frequencies from the perspectives of excitation electric field distribution and impedance. This metamaterial also demonstrates two remarkable characteristics: a large absorption half-value angle and a significant sensitivity to temperature regulation. Owing to its absorption peak, peak frequency, absorption angle, and other attributes, this metamaterial promises to be a highly promising receiver for 6G communication.

title: IEEE Guide for Corrosion Inspection and Evaluation of High-Voltage Direct Current (HVDC) Grounding Electrodes (±400 kV to ±1100 kV)
authors: N/A
publish: N/A
abstract: Methods of corrosion inspection and evaluation of high-voltage direct current (HVDC) grounding electrodes, including general requirements, selection of excavation point, excavation, sampling, corrosion inspection, and evaluation, are described by this guide. This guide is applicable to corrosion inspection and evaluation of HVDC grounding electrodes after excavation with voltage ratings from ±400 kV to ±1100 kV.
