title: Automatic Irrigation System with Fiber-Optic Pressure Sensor for Real-Time Intrarenal Pressure Control During Instrument Insertion and Laser Irradiation
authors: Noriko Tsuruoka, Takashi Yoshida, Yoichi Haga, Hidefumi Kinoshita, Sanq-Seok Lee, Tadao Matsunaga
publish: IEEE Sensors Journal
abstract: Precise control of intrarenal pressure (IPP) during flexible ureteroscopy is critical for preventing postoperative complications linked to pyelovenous or pyelosinus reflux. We developed an automatic irrigation system incorporating an ultraminiature fiber-optic pressure sensor for real-time IPP monitoring and control. The sensor, with an outer diameter of 0.125 mm, positioned 2 mm inside the ureteroscope tip, provides high-resolution pressure measurements (±~0.75 mmHg) with temperature compensation. A proportional-integral-derivative controller automatically adjusts the speed of a roller pump to maintain target IPP levels based on real-time sensor feedback. The system was evaluated using a porcine kidney model during insertion/removal of surgical instruments (272-μm laser fiber and 1.3-Fr basket forceps) and Ho:YAG laser lithotripsy procedures. Manual control showed delayed responses to pressure changes during both insertion and removal, whereas the automated control demonstrated a rapid return to a stable pressure. During 10-W Ho:YAG laser irradiation, constant pump speed operation led to progressive IPP baseline elevation with repeated firing, while the automated control prevented cumulative pressure buildup and maintained a stable baseline pressure. The fiber-optic sensor demonstrated superior spatial and temporal resolution compared to sheath-based pressure monitoring systems. The automated irrigation system effectively reduced IPP fluctuations during critical surgical operations. This approach represents a significant advancement in endourological safety and precision, and offers the potential for widespread clinical implementation in flexible ureteroscopy procedures.

title: An 8 TX–16 RX W-Band 2-D Distributed Active Array TD-MIMO FMCW Radar in 28-nm CMOS
authors: Dong-Yeol Yang, Seuk-Won Kang, Jeongbae Yoon, Jae-Hyun Park, Hyun-Hwan Choi, Seung-Yeon Kim, Si-Jun Lee, Kwan-Woo Moon, Seo-Ryeong Choi, Reem Song, Sangwook Nam, Byung-Sung Kim
publish: IEEE Transactions on Microwave Theory and Techniques
abstract: This article presents a 94-GHz time-domain multiple-input–multiple-output (TD-MIMO) frequency- modulated continuous-wave (FMCW) radar system with 8 transmitters (TXs) and 16 receivers (RXs). The system incorporates a single-channel TX chip and a four-channel RX chip, which are separately designed to enable flexible antenna array optimization. Both chips are implemented in 28-nm bulk CMOS technology and feature a <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\times 24$</tex-math> </inline-formula> frequency multiplication scheme, along with a direct backside antenna-feeding architecture through the silicon substrate. This approach effectively reduces the complexity and cost of large-scale W-band array implementation by eliminating the need for low-yield, expensive millimeter-wave (mm-wave) packaging. A compact, center-fed antenna is directly integrated into the package, removing the external antenna feedlines and enabling efficient arrangement of a 2-D thinned active array, which is optimized using a genetic algorithm (GA) for enhanced angular resolution. Furthermore, a time-interleaved intermediate-frequency (IF) sampling architecture is adopted to realize 128 virtual channels with reduced back-end hardware and processing burden. The fabricated antenna-integrated TX and RX module achieve an equivalent isotropic radiated power (EIRP) of 27 dBm and a conversion gain of 34 dB, respectively. The radar system demonstrates high angular resolutions of 0.81° in azimuth and 1.5° in elevation direction.

title: Unsupervised Disbond Detection in CFRP Joints via Guided Waves and Autoencoders
authors: Mohsen Barzegar, Sahar Moradi Cherati, Muchao Zhang, Dario J. Pasadas, Artur L. Ribeiro, Helena G. Ramos
publish: IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
abstract: Ultrasonic guided waves (UGWs) are well-suited for the nondestructive inspection (NDT) of adhesive joints as they can enable the transmission and reception of signals across the joint without requiring direct access to the damaged area. Conventional damage indices (DIs), such as the peak of the signal envelope, are limited for Carbon Fiber Reinforced Polymer (CFRP) adhesive joints due to the material's anisotropy and the complexity of UGW propagation. This is especially challenging for disbond detection and sizing. This study proposes an unsupervised approach using autoencoders for automatic disbond characterization in CFRP joints. Angle beam transducers (ABTs) were used in a pitch-catch setup to collect UGW signals under pristine conditions at two excitation frequencies (320 kHz and 650 kHz). The proposed DI is based on the reconstruction error between the original and autoencoder-reconstructed signals. Three architectures, including fully connected, Transformer-based, and CNN-LSTM autoencoders, were evaluated using 5-fold cross-validation and tested on independent scans. Performance was assessed using different metrics. Results show that the CNN-LSTM model consistently achieved the highest detection accuracy, while the Transformer model exhibited the most stable performance across folds. In a controlled temperature and humidity environment, the proposed DI provides superior localization and sizing of disbonds compared to conventional manually extracted signal features.

title: Regression is all you need for medical image translation
authors: Sebastian Rassmann, David Kügler, Christian Ewert, Martin Reuter
publish: IEEE Transactions on Medical Imaging
abstract: While Generative Adversarial Nets (GANs) and Diffusion Models (DMs) have achieved impressive results in natural image synthesis, their core strengths – creativity and realism – can be detrimental in medical applications, where accuracy and fidelity are paramount. These models instead risk introducing hallucinations and replication of unwanted acquisition noise. Here, we propose YODA (You Only Denoise once – or Average), a 2.5D diffusion-based framework for medical image translation (MIT). Consistent with DM theory, we find that conventional diffusion sampling stochastically replicates noise. To mitigate this, we draw and average multiple samples, akin to physical signal averaging. As this effectively approximates the DM’s expected value, we term this Expectation-Approximation (ExpA) sampling. We additionally propose regression sampling YODA, which retains the initial DM prediction and omits iterative refinement to produce noise-free images in a single step. Across five diverse multi-modal datasets – including multi-contrast brain MRI and pelvic MRI-CT – we demonstrate that regression sampling is not only substantially more efficient but also matches or exceeds image quality of full diffusion sampling even with ExpA. Our results reveal that iterative refinement solely enhances perceptual realism without benefiting information translation, which we confirm in relevant downstream tasks. YODA outperforms eight state-of-the-art DMs and GANs and challenges the presumed superiority of DMs and GANs over computationally cheap regression models for high-quality MIT. Furthermore, we show that YODA-translated images are interchangeable with, or even superior to, physical acquisitions for several medical applications.

title: Ultrasonic Characterization of Fat Content in Commercially Available Bovine Milk
authors: Pooja Dubey, Nico F. Declercq
publish: IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
abstract: Ultrasound is widely applied in the dairy industry for milk decontamination, homogenization, and sterilization. This study presents an ultrasonic method for rapid, non-destructive characterization of fat content in bovine milk. It can provide information about fat content, droplet size, and the temporal evolution of milk product characteristics. This paper examines conventional linear ultrasonic techniques, such as speed of sound and attenuation, alongside nonlinear acoustical methods for precise bovine milk characterization. This study assesses the reliability of ultrasound-based fat quantification and compares the effectiveness of linear and nonlinear acoustic measurements. By analyzing the intrinsic nonlinearity of milk samples, this study advances milk characterization with a highly sensitive technique capable of detecting fat variations as low as 1 g/100ml—unachievable by conventional methods. Detailed analysis of the relative nonlinearity parameter sets a new standard for precision in nonlinear acoustic characterization of complex liquids. This research enables a rapid, non-destructive, and scalable ultrasonic method for milk fat characterization, with implications for quality control and dairy processing optimization. Unlike prior ultrasound studies that require controlled laboratory conditions, chemical reagents, or specialized sample preparation, our approach combines linear (speed/attenuation) and nonlinear (harmonic content) acoustic features at sub-cavitation drive levels to separate composition from temperature effects. The protocol is simple to execute, non-destructive, and suitable for in-line or atline monitoring, offering a practical path to rapid quality control in dairy processing.

title: MHFS: Multimodal Haptic Feedback System for Enhanced Immersive Experience
authors: Zihe Zhao, Hongbei Meng, Cong Li, Wenyu Yang, Shengbo Wang, Xuhang Chen, Chenyu Tang, Yu Pan, Arokia Nathan, Shuo Gao
publish: IEEE Transactions on Computational Social Systems
abstract: Haptic feedback devices provide a sense of immersion that makes them play a key role in the domain of human-environment interactivities, such as in telemedicine, teleoperation, and online education. However, widely used unimodal or limited-modal approaches, such as vibrotactile, electrotactile, force-feedback, thermal, and emerging mid-air ultrasound/magnetorheological systems, are merely capable of simulating few virtual materials, exhibit a deficiency in fidelity, and necessitate substantial training expenditures. To address these limitations, we propose a multivirtual object recognition system based on multimodal haptic feedback and develop an evaluation and training scheme. The system is based on electrohaptic, vibrohaptic, and thermohaptic, acquires four haptic perception modalities, roughness, sharpness, hardness, and temperature, and simulates the haptic sensation of eight different materials. In experiments, the fidelity alignment of haptic feelings of real and virtual objects is 85.8%, and after averaged 2.8 trainings, the recognition accuracy reaches 100%. Our research not only improves the realism of haptic feedback but also significantly reduces the training cost, providing a more cost-effective and practical solution for user experience enhancement in virtual reality (VR) and meta-universe applications.

title: Diversified Prompting Strategy for Improving Slot Filling with Large Language Models
authors: Mirr Shin, Youhyun Shin
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: We propose a diversified prompting strategy to address the challenges of slot filling with Large Language Models (LLMs), where recall often suffers from prediction omissions and precision declines due to duplicate or excessive slot assignments. Our strategy combines sub-prompt, which partitions candidate slots into smaller groups to improve recall, and multi-view prompt, which applies diverse structural prompt variations to the same utterance. Final slot predictions are selected through threshold-based majority voting, effectively balancing recall and precision. Experiments on three benchmark datasets (SNIPS, MASSIVE, and MultiWoz) with six LLMs (bloomz, falcon, llama2, llama3, qwen2, and gemma) show consistent improvements when compared with the baseline and all single-prompt methods. For example, on SNIPS, llama3-8B improves recall from 78.4 to 90.5 and F1 from 72.6 to 82.0. Additionally, we conducted experiments across various model sizes to confirm the general applicability of our methodology. These results demonstrate that the proposed diversified prompting strategy effectively restores balance among recall, precision, and F1, offering a scalable methodology for enhancing LLM-based slot filling.

title: Privacy-Preserving, Verifiable, and Transformable Access Control for Cloud-Assisted IoV
authors: Liang Zhu, Xuetao Zhang, Xiangxue Li
publish: IEEE Internet of Things Journal
abstract: The Internet of Vehicles (IoV) cloud platform enables multi-dimensional sharing of vehicle data, enhancing both its value and the quality of vehicle services. To ensure dynamic authorized access control and safeguard user privacy in the IoV cloud platform, an attribute-based encryption (ABE) scheme is employed. However, existing state-of-the-art schemes still struggle to simultaneously address the following challenges: 1) the limitation of single-application scenarios due to the difficulty of achieving cross-primitive ciphertext transformation; 2) the risk of user privacy leakage caused by the inability to fully hide access policies; 3) the potential for malicious accusations against the delegator due to a lack of verifiability. To tackle these issues, we propose PPVTAC, a Privacy-Preserving, Verifiable, and Transformable Access Control scheme for cloud-assisted IoV. Specifically, we leverage a hybrid proxy re-encryption technique to transform ABE ciphertext into identity-based encryption (IBE) ciphertext, making it more suitable for collaborative scenarios. A cuckoo filter is introduced to achieve fully hidden policies, thereby protecting user privacy. Additionally, we incorporate non-interactive zero-knowledge proofs (NIZKPs) to ensure verifiability, guaranteeing the correctness of transformed ciphertexts while preventing malicious accusations against the delegator. A further advantage of our scheme is its support for unbounded attribute spaces, eliminating the need for system reboot when adding new attributes. In addition, our scheme requires only a constant number of pairing operations during the decryption and re-encryption phases, regardless of the number of attributes. We formalize a security model and rigorously prove that our scheme achieves adaptive security. Our scheme achieves simultaneously for the first time cross-primitive ciphertext transformation, fully hidden policy, and verifiability while ensuring adaptive security. We implement our scheme in real-world environments and compare it with existing state-of-the-art schemes. Our approach offers a more comprehensive feature set without significant performance trade-offs, making it highly suitable for cloud-assisted IoV scenarios.

title: Blockchain-Assisted MANET Security using Addax Optimizer and Discrete Hopfield Neural Networks
authors: Natrayan L, M.Sivaramkrishnan, Kiruthika Balakrishnan, Anand Rajendran, Ramya M
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: The fast growth of Internet of Things (IoT)-based Mobile Ad-hoc Networks (MANETs) has brought severe security issues such as unauthorized access, identity theft, and data tampering. MANETs' dynamic environment makes it more susceptible to attacks, hence the necessity for secure communication and anomaly detection. Enhancing Secure IoT Architecture in MANET Using Addax Optimizer and Discrete Hopfield Neural Network with Blockchain-Based BATMAN (DHNN-AOA) is presented in this research to enhance network security and routing effectiveness. First, behavioral and network traffic characteristics are gathered from IoT nodes and then feature selection through Quokka Swarm Optimization (QSO) to remove redundant information. Discrete Hopfield Neural Network (DHNN) is utilized for anomaly detection and node classification into normal or malicious, while Addax Optimization Algorithm (AOA) optimizes the hyperparameters of DHNN for learning rates, activation functions, and regularization weights to enhance the detection rate and minimize false alarms. Secure routing and authentication are ensured through integration of the Better Approach to Mobile Ad-hoc Networking (BATMAN) protocol with blockchain technology to ensure tamper-proof authentication and trust-based communication. Fair Consensus in Blockchain with Heterogeneous Miners Technology proposed allows high-reputation nodes to authenticate transactions and ensure efficient and reliable security protocol for MANET-based communication. Experimental comparison confirms the effectiveness of the proposed model in comparison to other approaches, with a 14.82% improvement in detection accuracy and 16.91% in precision with a decrease in computational overhead. The model provides a scalable, adaptive, and privacy-preserving solution for MANET security in IoT-based systems, providing robust intrusion detection, secure routing, and efficient validation of consensus in decentralized networks.

title: Resource Block Hopping for NextG Smart Factory/Manufacturing
authors: Shikhar Bhattarai, Walter Roensch, Hyuck M. Kwon, Dn Pokhrel
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: This paper demonstrates the significant performance gains of signal-to-interference-plus-noise ratio (SINR)-aware resource block (RB) hopping assignment in mitigating channel fading for NextG communication systems. The proposed technique leverages the mandatory SINR reports in 5G New Radio (NR) standards to intelligently allocate a subset of RBs with higher channel quality to higher priority source and vice versa for lower priority source. Using a simulation framework built on the finite blocklength channel coding model, we evaluate block error rate (BLER) and throughput under log-normal and Rayleigh fading channel models. Experiments were also done for 256 Quadrature Amplitude Modulation (QAM). Our results prove that intelligently hopping provides a substantial performance advantage over a static, non-hopping baseline, maintaining low BLER even under low SINR conditions. These findings validate SINR-aware RB hopping as a powerful, low-complexity, and practical method for enhancing the resilience and reliability of NextG networks, specially, NextG smart factory/manufacturing.

title: A Measurement Study of Dynamics and Liquid Data Transport in OneWeb LEO Satellite Networks
authors: Owen Perrin, Evan Gossling, Daji Qiao, Hongwei Zhang
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: Operators such as SpaceX and Eutelsat have launched mega-constellations of Low Earth Orbit (LEO) satellites to support their LEO satellite networks (LSNs), Starlink and OneWeb, respectively. These networks offer broadband Internet access to previously un-serviceable regions that lack sufficient terrestrial infrastructure. However, these LSNs are not without idiosyncrasies; relatively high latency and jitter accompany throughput variations. Most notably, though, are frequent packet losses that hinder link usage and consistent traffic flows. While consumer-focused LSNs such as Starlink have been extensively studied, other LSNs with distinct properties remain underexplored. In this work, a measurement study of the OneWeb LSN is presented, documenting and detailing an under-studied network which focuses on reliability and enterprise use-cases. Furthermore, we examine the potential benefits of liquid data transport, which allows TCP flows to maintain a large congestion window size and reduce retransmissions, thereby minimizing the impact of packet loss over LSNs. We find that OneWeb generally fulfills its service-level agreements, and liquid data transport may be used to further increase the reliability of TCP flows over LSNs.

title: Real-World Integration and Evaluation of Open-Source 5G Core with Commercial RAN
authors: Guoying Zu, Joshua Ofori Boateng, Varun S. Advani, Taimoor Ul Islam, Vincent Lee, Sarath Babu, Md Nadim, Daji Qiao, Mohamed Y. Selim, Hongwei Zhang
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: Open-source platforms are reshaping cellular networks by decoupling proprietary stacks and enabling rapid innovation across radio access networks (RANs) and cellular cores. Production-quality open-source 5G cores have become available for years, yet there lacks rigorous, publicly-available studies on the feasibility and results of integrating open-source cores with commercial RANs. In this work, we present the first field-validated integration of Open5GS, a fully open-source 5G core, with a commercial Ericsson RAN in the ARA wireless living lab, spanning a diameter of 30 km in central Iowa. We detail the integration workflow, practical challenges, and lessons learned. We perform extensive real-world field measurements and show that Open5GS offers reliable performance by achieving more than 200 Mbps per UE in 90% of our field measurements, comfortably exceeding the enhanced mobile broadband (eMBB) requirements. Our results demonstrate that open-source cores can achieve carrier-grade performance and robustness with commercial RANs, thereby accelerating vendor-neutral, rapid innovation while offering affordable platforms for 5G adoption in private networks, rural communities, and so on.

title: Varuna: Maximizing 5G Coverage with Out-of-Band Interference Protection for Radio Astronomy
authors: Naru Jai, Yi Shi, Wenjing Lou, Luiz DaSilva, Y. Thomas Hou
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: Radio astronomy (RA) studies the universe by detecting extremely weak radio signals using highly sensitive antennas. The increasing deployment of 5G base stations (BSs) in neighboring frequency bands creates a risk of out-of-band (OOB) interference, threatening to disrupt RA. To address this risk, one would have to impose a limit on 5G deployment, which could in turn adversely affect its area coverage. In this paper, we present Varuna—an algorithm designed to maximize 5G network coverage while ensuring the OOB interference threshold at passive RA site is satisfied. Varuna operates by selectively adjusting the transmit power of 5G BSs based on a penalty-driven metric that balances coverage loss against interference reduction. Through simulation experiments on a real-world Very Large Baseline Antenna (VLBA) site and using the Irregular Terrain Model (ITM) propagation model, we demonstrate that Varuna achieves nearly maximum spatial coverage while offering OOB interference protection for RA.

title: AI-Enabled Optimization Algorithms for Energy-Efficient HVAC System Control
authors: Sanjay Kumar, Sapna Bawankar
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: Heating, Ventilation, and Air Conditioning (HVAC) systems are among the most energy-intensive systems in residential, commercial, and industrial buildings. With increased energy efficiency, economic benefits, and ecological consciousness, the application of Artificial Intelligence (AI)-based optimization methods for HVAC system control has become a groundbreaking trend. This paper discusses the design and implementation of AI-based optimization technologies for innovative, adaptive, and energy-efficient control of HVAC systems. Conventional HVAC systems typically operate on preprogrammed schedules or rule-based control, which are not responsive to fluctuating environmental conditions, usage patterns, and heat loads. In contrast, AI optimization algorithms such as Genetic Algorithms (GA), Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO), Ant Colony Optimization (ACO), and Reinforcement Learning (RL) offer real-time, dynamic control. The algorithms utilize past data, sensor data, and predictive models to adjust system parameters, thereby improving energy efficiency without compromising indoor thermal comfort. This research presents a detailed review and comparative assessment of various AI optimization techniques implemented in HVAC systems. The article highlights model predictive control (MPC) integrated with AI to forecast future environmental variations and optimize the actuator response accordingly. Machine learning algorithms are also investigated to learn and predict usage patterns, weather fluctuations, and thermal performance of buildings. Case studies of intelligent buildings demonstrate that this methodology is effective in reducing energy consumption by up to 30% while ensuring compliance with indoor air quality and comfort standards. Additionally, the paper addresses implementation issues, including computational complexity, data requirements, real-time processing capabilities, and integration with existing Building Management Systems (BMS). A hybrid approach that integrates data-driven models and physics-based simulations is proposed to achieve optimal performance and robust control. Overall, AI-activated optimization schemes offer a viable path to sustainable and intelligent management of HVAC systems. Their management of nonlinearities, adaptation to uncertainties, and learning capabilities make next-generation energy-efficient control strategies possible. Some of the future research frontiers include lightweight AI model design for edge deployment, integrating renewable energy sources, and privacy-preserving data analysis for occupant-centric optimization. This research advances the emerging field of innovative building technology, enabling global urban transitions to low-carbon and energy-resilient infrastructures.

title: An Ensemble of Diverse Deep Learning Approaches for Efficient and Robust Classification of Gastrointestinal Diseases
authors: Sourav Das Polok, Salil Batra, Gouri Shankar Chakraborty, Makul Mahajan
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: Gastrointestinal (GI) diseases are the general group of disorders that have severe impact on the digestive tract and they are commonly classified as cancers or sometimes inflammatory diseases. Over the years, endoscopic imaging in diagnostic processes has played a significant role. Nevertheless, the conventional ways to identify these diseases do not usually work well in terms of high accuracy and consistency when identifying various classes of GI disorders. This work introduces a new ensemble method that can assist in classifying multiple gastrointestinal diseases using endoscopic images. The suggested approach is a hybrid of various deep learning models, namely, EfficientNetV2L, InceptionResNet, MobileNetV3Large, Vit-L16, and DenseNet-121, to improve diagnostic results. Through this ensemble method, a decent test accuracy of 92.37% is obtained, which is better than individual models and the current solutions. The idea behind this work is to overcome the drawbacks of the conventional diagnostic methods and offer a more credible, accurate, and reliable solution to the diagnostic challenges of GI diseases.

title: Resilient and Reliable Cloud Network Control for Mission-Critical Latency-Sensitive Applications
authors: Chin-Wei Huang, Jaime Llorca, Antonia M. Tulino, Andreas F. Molisch
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: The growing demand for mission-critical latency-sensitive services will require next-generation cloud-integrated networks to guarantee both reliable and resilient service delivery. While reliability imposes timely-throughput (on-time delivery rate) requirements under strict latency constraints, resilience relates to the network’s ability to swiftly recover timely-throughput performance following an outage event caused by non-stationary conditions, such as node failures or shifting network topologies. While recent studies have increasingly focused on designing reliable network control policies, a comprehensive solution that combines reliable and resilient network control has yet to be fully explored. This paper formulates the least-cost resilient and reliable network control problem as a stochastic control problem with long and short-term timely throughput constraints. We then present a solution through the Resilient and Reliable Cloud Network Control (ResRCNC) algorithm and show through numerical experiments that it jointly ensures reliability under normal conditions and resilience upon complete network node failures.

title: Studying the Effect of Schedule Preemption on Dynamic Task Graph Scheduling
authors: Mohammadali Khodabandehlou, Jared Coleman, Niranjan Suri, Bhaskar Krishnamachari
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: Dynamic scheduling of task graphs is often addressed without revisiting prior task allocations, with a primary focus on minimizing makespan. We study controlled schedule preemption, introducing the Last-K Preemption model, which selectively reschedules recent task graphs while preserving earlier allocations. Using synthetic, RIoTBench, WFCommons, and adversarial workloads, we compare preemptive, non-preemptive, and partial-preemptive strategies across makespan, fairness, utilization, and runtime. Results show moderate preemption can match most makespan/utilization gains of full preemption while maintaining fairness and low overhead.

title: Threat-aware Aerial Network Control
authors: Travis Cuvelier, Ryan M. Dreifuerst, Nicholas Pang, Christian Minor, Clare Jenney, Sriram Vishwanath, Hammad Iqbal
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: The need to achieve reliable command and control in contested environments motivates threat-aware approaches to cross-layer network control. Our proposed approach incorporates non-traditional out-of-band data sources to inform the control and adaptation of military communication networks in contested operations. In this work, we propose to view network adaptation as a problem of sequential decision making under uncertainty; namely as a Markov decision problem (MDP). In particular, the proposed model can capture how actions influence the manifestation of external threats. This leads to a radio power control optimization problem of maximizing network throughput while minimizing probability of detection, which we solve using a model predictive control heuristic. We apply our model to an example scenario of an aerial network susceptible to electromagnetic warfare (EW) threats. Numerical results demonstrate the advantage of threat-aware adaptation.

title: MAC Layer Shortcuts for Low-Latency Intra-RAN UE Communication
authors: Joel John, Marius Corici, Thomas Magedanz
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on 6G Networking (6GNet)
abstract: Low latency communication is critical for supporting latency-sensitive applications in beyond 5G and 6G networks. While there have been various advancements in optimizing the latency, current network architectures still route data traffic between User Equipments (UEs) connected to the same gNodeB (gNB) through the core network. This causes unnecessary delays and resource consumption that could otherwise be avoided. This paper proposes a novel approach to optimize intra-RAN UE communication by introducing “shortcuts” at the Medium Access Control (MAC) layer of the gNB. By enabling direct data forwarding between UEs connected to the same RAN, the proposed approach reduces end-to-end latency. This is achieved by bypassing higher layers in the gNB and the core network for eligible traffic. A proof-of-concept implementation by modifying the MAC layer of the srsRAN project, an open-source 5G RAN, demonstrates the viability of such an approach. The implementation and further analysis demonstrate measurable end-to-end latency reduction and improved consistency. Such an approach holds significant potential for optimizing intra-RAN UE communication.

title: MobiLLM: An Agentic AI Framework for Closed-Loop Threat Mitigation in 6G Open RANs
authors: Haohuang Wen, Prakhar Sharma, Vinod Yegneswaran, Ashish Gehani, Phillip Porras, Zhiqiang Lin
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: The evolution toward 6G networks is being accelerated by the Open Radio Access Network (O-RAN) paradigm—an open, interoperable architecture that enables intelligent, modular applications across public telecom and private enterprise domains. While this openness creates unprecedented opportunities for innovation, it also expands the attack surface, demanding resilient, low-cost, and autonomous security solutions. Legacy defenses remain largely reactive, labor-intensive, and inadequate for the scale and complexity of next-generation systems. Current O-RAN applications focus mainly on network optimization or passive threat detection, with limited capability for closed-loop, automated response.To address this critical gap, we present an agentic AI framework for fully automated, end-to-end threat mitigation in 6G O-RAN environments. MobiLLM orchestrates security work-flows through a modular multi-agent system powered by Large Language Models (LLMs). The framework features a Threat Analysis Agent for real-time data triage, a Threat Classification Agent that uses Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) to map anomalies to specific countermeasures, and a Threat Response Agent that safely operationalizes mitigation actions via O-RAN control interfaces. Grounded in trusted knowledge bases such as the MITRE FiGHT framework and 3GPP specifications, and equipped with robust safety guardrails, MobiLLM provides a blueprint for trustworthy AI-driven network security. Initial evaluations demonstrate that MobiLLM can effectively identify and orchestrate complex mitigation strategies, significantly reducing response latency and showcasing the feasibility of autonomous security operations in 6G.

title: An Efficient Deep Learning Approach for Identifying Multiple Tea Leaf Diseases
authors: Sripelli Jagadish, Seerat Singla, Manisha Aeri, Aanchal Rawat
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: Tea is the most widely consumed beverage globally. The quality and production of tea are highly dependent on various diseases of leaves. It becomes highly important to detect and classify diseases at an early stage and in an accurate way. For this purpose, this research uses a dataset that is specifically related to the disease of tea leaves and can be downloaded from kaggle. The dataset consists of eight classes. The proposed model uses an approach of transfer learning along with ResNet50 models and an additional fully connected layer consisting of dense, normalization, activation, and drop-out functions. The dataset is preprocessed through resizing and splitting (80:10:10). Other augmentation processes are performed to introduce diversity. The experimentation on the proposed approach justified robust convergence through the training and valid accuracy at an overall value of 0.92 accuracy on the confusion matrix.

title: Mitigating Interleaved ADC Mismatches in Automatic Modulation Classification via Sampling Schemes and Layer Fusion
authors: Alexander Gros, Véronique Moeyaert, Patrice Mégret
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: Time Interleaved Analog to Digital Converters (TI-ADCs) are widely used in wideband spectrum monitoring systems to achieve high sampling rates and large instantaneous bandwidths. However, as highlighted in the literature, accurately compensating for inter-channel mismatches such as gain, offset, and timing skew, is critical, as these impairments can distort the digitized signal. While traditional studies focus on spectral analysis under ideal sinusoidal inputs, this work examines the direct impact of TI-ADC mismatches on Automatic Modulation Classification (AMC) accuracy. Using a publicly available dataset of IQ-modulated signals, we introduce controlled mismatch impairments and evaluate classification performance across varying distortion levels, from relaxed to extreme. We propose a lightweight dyadic down-sampling scheme combined with a CNN-based fusion architecture that improves robustness of AMC to interleaving mismatches and calibration drift. Results show up to 6.7 percent improvement in classification accuracy under severe mismatch conditions, underscoring the method’s consistent gains and robustness to hardware distortions. These findings are particularly relevant for field-deployed or long-duration monitoring applications where hardware degradation and limited recalibration are expected.

title: An Autonomic Framework for Optimized Data Confidentiality in the Internet of Things
authors: Rebecca Belval, Christopher Rouff, Ali Tekeoglu
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: Data confidentiality for the Internet of Things (IoT) devices must balance data security with other resource constraints common to these devices, such as limits on power consumption and desired performance. This paper describes research in developing an autonomic framework that balances these competing concerns and choosing the most appropriate encryption algorithm for a given IoT device given a range of variables, including minimum security level, residual power, available stack space, available memory, and desired throughput. This research also compares three classification algorithms to determine the one that provides the best self-management of the encryption algorithm choice for the system.

title: Neuro6G: A Brain-Inspired Architecture for Adaptive Resource Allocation in Next-Generation Wireless Environments
authors: R. Krishnamoorthy, Kazuaki Tanaka, Jayendra Gopal Thatipudi, Nellore Manoj Kumar, M. Amina Begum, V. Jayalakshmi
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: The new applications and scenarios in 6G era, likely to trigger the unprecedented growth of Internet of Things (IoT) components and connections, which is driving the need for a 6G-enabled IoT to accommodate millions of connections per square kilometer. But conventional orthogonal multiple access strategies limit the effectual use of the available spectrum. Here, we proposed the innovative Non-Orthogonal Multiple Access (NOMA)-based hybrid spectrum access system to be integrated with 6G-enabled cognitive IoT (C-IoT) Even during the active transmission of the Primary User (P-U), the use of NOMA allows the C-IoT to access free and busy bands. Two types of methodologies for uplink resource allocation for the C-IoT are proposed in this paper. This method tries to make best use of the average aggregate rate of transmission of the C-IoT, and thus guarantee the smallest rate of transmission for the P- U and each C-IoT node and each cluster to send arc on circle nobility hybrid spectrum access depends on the NOMA protocol having more benefits and rate guarantees for clustering NOMA-based C-IoT are demonstrated and compared by the simulation results.

title: GeNetE - Generative Network Environments: A Specialized Small Language Model
authors: Sebastian Burfeid, Paulo H. L. Rettore, Philipp Zißner, Peter Sevenich, Clayson Celes, Bruno P. Santos
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: Network emulation is crucial for testing and validating network systems, especially in the military domain involving devices from multiple network vendors, interfaces, and components in a federated mission. However, constructing the network infrastructure generally requires specialized expertise and a time-consuming setup process. Although Large Language Models (LLMs) can assist in code generation, general-purpose models often lack the domain-specific precision required for network emulators. This article introduces GeNetE, a Generative Network Environments framework, for creating a Specialized Small Language Model (SSLM) by fine-tuning open-weight LLMs using synthetic, domain-specific datasets. GeNetE enables streamlined emulator use, runs efficiently on low-resource devices, and reduces user workload. GeNetE was extensively evaluated using the Mininet emulator, employing various model sizes and quantization techniques, achieving approximately 60% valid Software-Defined Network environment generation with a compact 2.4 GB model, underscoring its potential for accessible and efficient network testing.

title: A Guide to Improving Thermal Simulations With Refined Foster and Cauer Models
authors: Alexander Weyman
publish: IEEE Power Electronics Magazine
abstract: Proper thermal modeling is essential for managing heat flow in power electronic devices ensuring optimal efficiency and reliability. Chain-like networks of the Cauer and Foster types provide a simple yet effective approach for accurate and optimized simulations of complex systems. Although modeling semiconductor junction temperatures and heat transfer with thermal chains may seem trivial, hidden assumptions can cause delays in heat flow and inaccurate temperature predictions. Fortunately, many of these pitfalls can be avoided with straightforward solutions. This article covers the principles of Cauer and Foster thermal chains and provides readers with a practical guide to developing more accurate and reliable thermal models.

title: Deep Learning-Driven Multiclass Bone Fracture Detection and Localization: A Comparative Study of CNN Architectures with YOLOv8-based Segmentation in Medical Imaging
authors: Pravallika Kondapalli, Md Zillur Rahman Saimon, Sourav Das Polok, Gouri Shankar Chakraborty, Md Idris Ali Miah, Salil Batra
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: Bone fracture is a common health complication and usually needs accurate diagnosis and early intervention. X-ray imaging is a common technique in diagnosing and categorizing such fractures, whereas manual analysis may be time consuming and may not be accurate. This paper actually describes a multiclass classification system based on the Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs) and YOLOv8 that can be used to segment the image with the goal of fractured bone detection; that is, to automate the bone fracture diagnosis. We tested CNN models of EfficientNetV2, Xception, and MobileNetV3 on an image dataset of X-rays and obtained results of 93.49, 88.14, and 89.42 with EfficientNetV2 which is the best among the models. Also, it used YOLOv8 to perform the segmentation task and effectively localized and identified the bone fractures in the images of X-Rays. The integration of these methods yielded great enhancements in the classification as well as the localization and offered an efficient and accurate means of detecting and segmenting bone fractures. This study has shown the possibility of using a combination of deep learning models to analyze bone fracture and thus help improve the process of diagnosis in clinical and medical settings.

title: Ensemble Regression Techniques for Enhanced Stock Price Forecasting
authors: Muskan Sureka, Aadi Poddar, Saurabh Bilgaiyan, Sonal Jain, Mahendra Kumar Gourisaria, Parthasarathi Pattnayak
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: Stock Price Prediction has been a concern for many financial analytics and business owners. This paper focuses on a machine learning framework for predicting stock prices accurately and comprehensively. The dataset used in this paper contains 365 daily records of five stocks. The data provides 218 characteristics, such as technical indicators, lag factors, and statistical measurements. Feature reduction technique like Principal Component Analysis (PCA) is used in this paper for predicting accuracy by utilizing both variance-based and fixed-component approaches. A variety of regression models and boosting techniques have been used in this paper such as Random Forest, XGBoost, Linear Regression, and Support Vector Machines. This paper uses a time-aware data partitioning and cross-validation techniques to guarantee accurate performance predictions. The results clearly show that SVR Linear outperforms other algorithms in terms of predicting stock prices accurately with R2 scores of 99.97% and RMSE values as low as 0.0585.

title: Using AI-Powered Deep Learning Models to Revolutionize Medicinal Plant Identification
authors: G. Govinda Rajulu, P. SaiKumar Reddy, U. Ram Manikanta, S. P. Santhoshkumar, R. M. Dilip Charaan, J. Kavitha
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: The process of identifying and classifying medicinal plants is crucial to the field of traditional medicine, pharmacology, and biodiversity conservation. Traditional identification of plants can be time-consuming, error-prone, requires expertise, and involves assessing multiple distinguishing factors about each plant. Thus, the purpose of this study was to present a Medical Plant Detection System using Deep Learning methods. Specifically, using convolutional neural networks (CNNs), plants were detected and classified as medicinal plants based on images of the plant and therefore very accurately. A novel dataset of medicinal plants was created with labeled images of the plants. The dataset of medicinal plants was used to train and test the model. The Medical Plant Detection System can identify individuals of a particular plant species under varying conditions, exhibiting reliability in each scenario. Therefore, the plant detection system is a beneficial tool for researchers, health care practitioners, and conservationists studying medicinal plants. The plant detection system provides a more valuable tool for identifying medicinal plants and will also benefit conservation by enabling proper identification and use of medicinal plants.

title: Joint Channel Sensing and Dynamic Resource Allocation for Multi-RIS Assisted Wireless Networks: A Bi-Level Optimization Approach
authors: Shawon Dey, Lijun Qian, Hao Xu
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: This paper develops a novel bi-level optimization framework for addressing multi-user channel estimation and dynamic resource allocation problems jointly in integrated sensing and communication (ISAC). As RIS is emerging as a key technology for 6G communication, its deployment in dynamic, obstructed environments alongside base stations aims to enhance spectral efficiency while minimizing power consumption. However, traditional resource allocation becomes challenging when user equipment (UE) positions are uncertain and the wireless environment is non-stationary. To address this, the developed bi-level optimization can effectively integrate dynamic resource allocation and multi-user channel estimation in RIS-assisted wireless networks into a unified framework and solve them simultaneously. Specifically, multi-UE dynamic channel estimation is formulated at the lower level, whereas transmit power and RIS phase shift optimization are formulated at the upper level. Due to the hierarchical nature of bi-level framework, the lower level estimates uncertain wireless channels, which are then utilized in the upper level for joint optimization of resource parameters. To ensure robustness against worst-case estimation errors, a zero-sum game formulation is introduced at the upper level, enabling reliable transmission power allocation and RIS phase shifts. Next, a hierarchical reinforcement learning (RL) scheme is developed, where the upper level employs an online actor-critic RL algorithm for dynamic resource allocation, while the lower level uses a neural network-based estimator for channel estimation and multi-user localization.

title: An Optimized ROM based Direct Digital Synthesizer Based on 65nm CMOS Technology
authors: Yuan Yuan, Qingsheng Hu, Xu Wu, Li Anming Li
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Integrated Circuits and Microsystems (ICICM)
abstract: This paper presents a design of a ROM based direct digital synthesizer using 65 nm CMOS process. The design aims to generate a high-speed direct digital synthesizer (DDS) with high precision and high performance for signal sources. By employing a pipelined phase accumulator, working speed is increased effectively. A ROM compression structure is also used in order to reduce hardware resource consumption, and some optimization techniques such as dithering injection and spur cancellation are utilized to improve spectral purity. To boost the output frequency further, a dual-channel DDS structure combining with a doubled frequency control word and a $2: 1$ multiplexer is employed. Simulation results show that the operating frequency can be up to 500 MHz and a 12-bit output signal with a frequency resolution of 0.1397 Hz and phase resolution of $8.382 \times 10^{-80}$ can be achieved. The power consumption is about 17.58 mW under 1.2 V power supply voltage at 500 MHz working frequency. This DDS is expected to provide a high - precision, high - frequency and low power frequency source.

title: Attack Behavior Observations and Profiling Through Varying Cyber Deception Mechanisms
authors: Eric Savage, Nathaniel D. Bastian, Ruolin Zhou
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: As attackers continue to target exposed services with automated and persistent techniques, defenders need better ways to profile and understand malicious behavior. This work presents a comparative analysis of attacker activity collected from three secure shell honeypot deployments: Cowrie, Heralding, and a Raspberry Pi-based low-interaction system. IP-based profiles have been extracted using features such as total login sessions and days active, and then K-means clustering has been applied to uncover common behavioral patterns. The resulting clusters reveal clear distinctions between short-lived probes, opportunistic attackers, and long-term brute-force campaigns. Additionally, we highlight representative attacker profiles to illustrate the differences across systems and show how behavioral profiling can support broader defensive strategies. Finally, we discuss how this clustering approach can complement deception-based defenses and how it could be integrated into a Zero Trust Architecture to inform trust decisions. This work paves a way to explore honeypot deployments across geographically distributed networks and the use of multi-node honeynets to track attacker movement and behaviors through a system.

title: Tracking Deforestation using High-Resolution Satellite Images with Deep-learning Techniques Combining UNet and ResNet
authors: K S Shashikala, Sandyarani Vadlamudi, Shishyantha B M, Gajanand L Immannavar, Rekha
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: This paper describes a deep learning approach for monitoring and tracking deforestation automatically using high-resolution satellite images and computer vision techniques. The UNet model applies semantic segmentation with a ResNet-50 encoder to separate the forested areas from RGB images. Deforestation maps showing the regions of forest loss were created by comparing the cover predictions of different time zones. The model trained with various training processes. This study proved to be feasible for identifying forest changes, land usage purpose and proposed a scalable method supporting environmental monitoring and land use.

title: When the Base Station Flies: Rethinking Security for UAV-Based 6G Networks
authors: Ammar El Falou
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on 6G Networking (6GNet)
abstract: The integration of non-terrestrial networks (NTNs) into 6G systems is crucial for achieving seamless global coverage, particularly in underserved and disaster-prone regions. Among NTN platforms, unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) are especially promising due to their rapid deployability. However, this shift from fixed, wired base stations (BSs) to mobile, wireless, energy-constrained UAV-BSs introduces unique security challenges. Their central role in emergency communications makes them attractive candidates for emergency alert spoofing. Their limited computing and energy resources make them more vulnerable to denial-of-service (DoS) attacks, and their dependence on wireless backhaul links and GNSS navigation exposes them to jamming, interception, and spoofing. Furthermore, UAV mobility opens new attack vectors such as malicious handover manipulation. This paper identifies several attack surfaces of UAV-BS systems and outlines principles for mitigating their threats.

title: A Deep Multi-Modal Framework for Cyberbullying Detection using Textual and Behavioural Features on Social Media
authors: Chintha Venkata Ramana, Sumathy V, Nagagopiraju Vullam, G. Prasanthi, A. Lakshmanarao, P. Varaprasada Rao
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: Cyberbullying on social media continues to escalate due to the rapid growth of user-generated content and the ease of anonymous communication. Accurately identifying harmful behaviour remains challenging because of informal writing styles, overlapping aggression types, and highly imbalanced data distributions. This paper proposes a Deep Multi-Modal Framework for cyberbullying detection that fuses textual features with behavioural indicators to enhance classification performance. The textual branch employs a hybrid CNN– BiLSTM encoder, while behavioural cues such as sentiment polarity, punctuation intensity, and lexical aggression scores are processed through a dense projection network. Extensive experiments were conducted on a large-scale Kaggle cyberbullying dataset and evaluated against traditional machine-learning models, deep neural networks, and transformer-based architectures. Baseline machine-learning models achieved moderate results, with SVM reaching an accuracy of 0.84. Deep learning architectures improved performance substantially, with the CNN–BiLSTM model attaining 0.93 accuracy. Transformer-based models such as BERT and RoBERTa further enhanced performance, achieving accuracies of 0.94 and 0.95, respectively. The proposed multi-modal fusion model outperformed all baseline approaches, achieving an accuracy of 0.96, precision of 0.96, recall of 0.95, and an F1-score of 0.96. These findings demonstrate that integrating behavioural and semantic information yields a more robust and reliable strategy for cyberbullying detection on social media platforms.

title: Targeted Attacks and Defenses for Distributed Federated Learning in Vehicular Networks
authors: Utku Demir, Tugba Erpek, Yalin E. Sagduyu, Sastry Kompella, Mengran Xue
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: In emerging networked systems, mobile edge devices such as ground vehicles and unmanned aerial system (UAS) swarms collectively aggregate vast amounts of data to make machine learning decisions such as threat detection in remote, dynamic, and infrastructure-constrained environments where power and bandwidth are scarce. Federated learning (FL) addresses these constraints and privacy concerns by enabling nodes to share local model weights for deep neural networks instead of raw data, facilitating more reliable decision-making than individual learning. However, conventional FL relies on a central server to coordinate model updates in each learning round, which imposes significant computational burdens on the central node and may not be feasible due to the connectivity constraints. By eliminating dependence on a central server, distributed federated learning (DFL) offers scalability, resilience to node failures, learning robustness, and more effective defense strategies. Despite these advantages, DFL remains vulnerable to increasingly advanced and stealthy cyberattacks. In this paper, we design sophisticated targeted training data poisoning and backdoor (Trojan) attacks, and characterize the emerging vulnerabilities in a vehicular network. We analyze how DFL provides resilience against such attacks compared to individual learning and present effective defense mechanisms to further strengthen DFL against the emerging cyber threats.

title: GA-ML Powered Intelligent Crop Prediction with Real-Time Environmental Data
authors: Akshya R, Farhana N, Gunavathie M A
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: This paper proposes a hybrid AI design for crop prediction that leverages genetic algorithms (GA) and machine learning (ML) models in order to improve agricultural decision- making. The proposed design improves the performance of the random forest model through GA-based hyper-parameter tuning and also incorporates real-time environmental data using Ag-Data APIs. These environmental data include key soil and climate characteristics such as nitrogen (N), phosphorus (P), potassium (K), pH, temperature, humidity, and rainfall to better inform predictions of the optimal crop. The design incorporates a soil nutrient analysis feature to flag deficiencies in certain soil nutrients outside of N, P, K and provide recommendations for additional soil nutrients without N, P, K. A web-based interactive dashboard was also developed to display real-time predictions and recommendations. Experimental results suggest that the accuracy and usability of the recommendations is superior to standard university crop recommendations.

title: Channel Estimation Using DVB-S2/S2X Pilots for Adaptive MODCOD Selection
authors: Wahab Khawaja, Ozgur Ozdemir, Rune H. Jacobsen
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: Digital video broadcasting satellite second generation (DVB-S2) and extension DVB-S2X are popular standards for satellite communications. However, there is no inherent mechanism in DVB-S2 and DVB-S2X for channel estimation. This work presents a robust custom channel estimation setup that extracts the peak channel impulse response (CIR) amplitude using DVB-S2 and DVB-S2X pilot symbols. The peak power from the channel scan can be used to precisely estimate the link condition and adaptively select the modulation and coding (MODCOD) during a satellite pass. The channel estimation setup uses GPS disciplined oscillators (GPSDOs) and USRPs.

title: NextG Positioning at User Equipment against Amplify-and-Forward Relay Jamming
authors: Walter Roensch, Hyuck M. Kwon, Shikhar Bhattarai, Manjula Naik Banavath
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: In the existing 5G system, a gNodeB base station computes the location of a user equipment (UE) with collaboration among three or more gNodeBs and the uplink (UL) sounding reference signals (SRS) received from the UE. For the NextG, it is proposed in this paper that the UE find its location itself instead of the gNodeB by using only down link (DL) positioning reference signals (PRSs), PRS is always available at a UE because multiple gNodeBs broadcast their PRSs periodically. Thus, the proposed method does not require the UE to transmit its UL SRS and other feedback signals. Therefore, the proposed method can be beneficial and useful in the battle field because it is dangerous to expose the location of a UE to an adversary gNodeB or a fake base station. We evaluate the performance of the proposed method under amplify-and-forward (AF) relay jamming by analyzing the probability of detection (PD) before and after the AF relay jamming removal for a given signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) and bandwidth W, finally we present an example of location estimation accuracy.

title: Satellite Fingerprinting Using Attention-Integrated Autoencoders for Robust Spoofing Detection
authors: Hans Siegfried Amelang, Mohd Hasan Ali, Dipankar Dasgupta, Myounggyu Won
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: Satellites serve as a foundational element of modern society, supporting a wide range of critical functions across communication, navigation, environmental monitoring, and national security. The growing accessibility of low-cost software-defined radio (SDR) systems has heightened the vulnerability of legacy satellite systems, which often lack robust cryptographic protections, to spoofing and replay attacks. In this paper, we propose a radio fingerprinting system centered on an autoencoder-based deep learning model enhanced with an attention mechanism to capture structured and/or temporal patterns in satellite data and improve attack detection accuracy. The model was trained and evaluated on a dataset of 1.7 million satellite downlink messages, and its performance was benchmarked against a state-of-the-art satellite radio fingerprinting system. Experimental results show that our approach outperforms the state-of-the-art fingerprinting system by 13% in ROC Area Under Curve (AUC) and 13% in Equal Error Rate (EER).

title: Zero Trust 6G: Survivability Optimization with Stochastic Attack Modeling
authors: Qasem Abu Al-Haija, Abdullah AlShuaibi
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: Future sixth-generation (6G) wireless networks are envisioned as a backbone for mission-critical applications, including autonomous transportation, smart grids, space communications, and tactical defense systems. Ensuring continuous service delivery under adversarial conditions is a fundamental goal of Zero Trust Architectures (ZTA) for Future G. This paper presents an integrated framework that combines stochastic cyberattack modeling with cost-constrained survivability optimization to enhance resilience in 6G mission-critical networks. We extend the methodology to 6G radio access networks (RAN) and core infrastructures by building upon validated survivability models for cyber-physical systems (CPSs) and stochastic attack rate prediction. We also incorporate redundancy allocation strategies and series-parallel reliability modeling. Cyber-attacks are characterized by using stochastic processes such as Poisson and negative binomial distributions to predict attack rates and dynamically update trust scores within ZTA policy engines. The proposed approach is supported by comparative analysis, including numerical insights from prior validated studies and literature benchmarks. The framework aligns with 3GPP security enhancements for 6G and offers a pathway toward unbreakable resilience in Zero Trust-enabled mission-critical networks.

title: Adaptive VREF variation Compensation Scheme for High-Speed DRAM interface & Its Offset Calibration Scheme
authors: Chris Eom, Kenji Wen, Mia Xu, Taco Zhang, Derek Yang, Bosco Lai
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Integrated Circuits and Microsystems (ICICM)
abstract: This paper presents an adaptive VREF variation compensation scheme designed to enhance the RX margin in highspeed DRAM interfaces. The proposed approach addresses the challenge of reduced RX gain under lower reference voltages by increasing the bias current via an additional current path. This adjustment leads to improved RX gain performance at lower reference voltages. Furthermore, an offset calibration scheme is applied to the RX. Unlike the conventional major voting method, this approach enables the removal of offset in all signal paths, specifically for each internal DQ path, which is captured and divided by the DQS path. As a result, a reduction in offset by over 80% was achieved, as demonstrated through Monte Carlo simulations. Implementing this scheme results in an 11% improvement in RX timing margin and a 23% enhancement in voltage margin.

title: A Next-Generation Cyber-Physical Architecture with Multi-Agent AI, IoT Sensing, and Autonomous Robotic Swarms
authors: Shaek Arif A, Vijay S, Tamizhselvi A
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: The growing complexity and interconnectivity of cyber-physical systems pose challenges to real-time decision making, resource optimization, and security. Existing systems usually fail to incorporate autonomous robotics, IoT networks, and intelligent energy management with secure, adaptable operation. This project envisions a next-generation AI-enabled cyber-physical ecosystem that overcomes such challenges through the integration of autonomous robot and drone swarms, distributed IoT sensors, cloud computing, smart energy modules, sophisticated cybersecurity, and brain-computer interfacing. Multi-modal AI architectures analyze real-time data for predictive analysis and adaptable system behavior, while multi-agent reinforcement learning coordinates autonomous agents to perform tasks such as environmental monitoring, disaster management, logistics, and smart city operations. Firebase facilitates secure, real-time data storage with cross-platform accessibility, and a brain-computer interface facilitates the direct neural control of devices. The innovation in this system is the fully autonomous, cloud-united platform that offers intelligent, predictive, and secure management to future smart ecosystems.

title: Multiparty, Multilingual Voice Communications in Constrained Tactical Networks with Voice Clones
authors: Andrew Tabarez, Ryan Quinn, John Ostwald, Sinclair Gurney, Nathaniel Soule, Ralph Kohler, Mahmoud Ashour, Madeline Fuentes
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: Sharing data at the edge with situational awareness systems like the Tactical Assault Kit (TAK) can enable powerful real-time common operating pictures on mobile phones and tablets, but there is often no substitute for voice communications to clearly and unambiguously relay certain types of critical information. Unfortunately, verbal communication quickly becomes inefficient or infeasible when in multinational operations where there is no common spoken language or where accents prevent effective communication. Further, many tactical networks are too limited or too overloaded to be able to provide consistent team-wide voice comms, even in a single language. It is in this context that we present the TAK Transcription and Automated Language Kit (TAK TALK) as a mechanism to achieve voice communications over constrained tactical networks, even in the presence of multiparty, multilingual deployment settings. TAK TALK capitalizes on recent advancements in Machine Learning (ML) for automated speech to text, machine translation, text to speech and voice cloning, to achieve a capability that emulates true voice conversations using only a very small fraction of the bandwidth of traditional mechanisms. Here we present TAK TALK, explore its key systems and the ML models that underpin them, evaluate its efficiency and efficacy, compare those results to the state of the art in today’s voice communications, and examine the new possibilities that text-based audio transmission enables.

title: WCV-Facilitated Efficient Directional Wireless Charging for IoTDs Sleep Time Minimization
authors: Ziqing Lin, Xilong Liu, Yuzhuo Zhang, Xihua Ma
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conferences on Internet of Things (iThings) IEEE Green Computing &amp; Communications (GreenCom) IEEE Cyber, Physical &amp; Social Computing (CPSCom) and IEEE Smart Data (SmartData) and IEEE Congress on Cybermatics (Cybermatics)
abstract: As Internet of Things (IoT) has been widely applied in modern society, IoT devices (IoTDs) and their various applications are dramatically improving people's daily lives. IoTDs usually require considerable sufficient energy amounts to maintain normal functions. Based on far-field wireless charging technique, tremendous existing studies have proposed to employ conventional cellular base stations (BSs) to wirelessly charge their surrounding IoTDs. However, when the charging distance between a BS and an IoTD is relatively long, the BS's charging efficiency decreases accordingly. Therefore, from both academia and industry, it is still crucial to improve the farfield wireless efficiency to achieve the practical and convenient wireless charging. In this work, we adopt a green energy powered wireless charging vehicle (WCV) to effectively power the IoTDs in wireless charging IoT network. We propose a nonlinear energy conversion model to accurately calculate the received wireless power of the IoTDs. In order to extend the lifespan of IoT network, we aim to minimize the sleep time of IoTDs by reducing the WCV's traveling distance. Since this sleep time minimization problem is proved to be NP-hard, we further propose the One-to-Multiple charGing (OMG) algorithm to efficiently solve it. Extensive simulations have validated that our proposed algorithm exhibits obvious advantages in terms of shortening the total sleep time of the IoTDs.

title: Automated Breast Cancer Classification using a Custom CNN Architecture on the BUSI Dataset
authors: Rahul Singh, Sheifali Gupta, Nagendar Yamsani, Manika Manwal, Gagan Bansal
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: Breast cancer is one of the most prevalent and life-threatening diseases among women, where early detection plays a crucial role in reducing mortality rates. Ultrasound imaging has emerged as a widely used, cost-effective, and non-invasive diagnostic tool, though its interpretation is often challenging due to noise and operator dependency. To address these challenges, this study proposes a custom convolutional neural network (CNN) architecture for automated breast cancer classification using the BUSI dataset. The dataset comprises 780 ultrasound images categorized into normal, benign, and malignant cases, supplemented with ground truth annotations. The proposed CNN incorporates multiple convolutional layers, max-pooling operations, dropout regularization, and dense layers to achieve robust feature extraction and classification. Experimental evaluation demonstrates strong performance, achieving 95.45% overall accuracy with precision, recall, and F1-scores above 92% across all classes. Training and validation performance trends confirm the model’s generalization ability, while the confusion matrix highlights its effectiveness in distinguishing between visually similar lesion types. These findings establish the proposed CNN as a lightweight, efficient, and clinically applicable model for breast cancer diagnosis, offering potential as a decision-support system in healthcare environments.

title: IQ Imbalance-Aware Pilot Assignment for Channel Estimation in Delay-Doppler Domain
authors: Armed Tusha, Seda Dogan-Tusha, Monisha Ghosh
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: A simple transceiver design is essential for achieving low computational complexity, low power consumption, and cost-effectiveness in beyond 5G (B5G) wireless systems. However, these architectures introduce hardware impairments that can significantly compromise the performance reliability of transmissions. This paper delves into the problem of in-phase and quadrature (IQ) imbalance hardware impairment at transmitter (Tx) for orthogonal time frequency space (OTFS), which is a recent promising waveform for potential use in B5G communications systems. A novel pilot allocation strategy is proposed to mitigate the impact of Tx IQ imbalance in delay-Doppler (DD) domain. Specifically, this scheme aims to circumvent the physical impact of mirror-Doppler interference (MDI) caused by IQ imbalance at TX so that wireless channel estimation in DD domain is successfully performed despite the presence of IQ imbalance. Different from classical IQ imbalance estimators based on iterative methodologies, the proposed pilot location in DD domain eliminates the need for additional signal processing stages, and avoids substantial losses in spectral efficiency. The obtained results validate the robustness of the proposed pilot location strategy in various practical scenarios, showcasing its superiority over conventional pilot allocation strategies in DD bin.

title: Indoor/Outdoor Spectrum Sharing Enabled by GNSS-based Classifiers
authors: Hossein Nasiri, Muhammad Iqbal Rochman, Monisha Ghosh
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: The desirability of the mid-band frequency range (1 - 10 GHz) for federal and commercial applications, combined with the growing applications for commercial indoor use-cases, such as factory automation, opens up a new approach to spectrum sharing: the same frequency bands used outdoors by federal incumbents can be reused by commercial indoor users. A recent example of such sharing, between commercial systems, is the 6 GHz band (5.925 - 7.125 GHz) where unlicensed, low-power-indoor (LPI) users share the band with outdoor incumbents, primarily fixed microwave links. However, to date, there exist no reliable, automatic means of determining whether a device is indoors or outdoors, necessitating the use of other mechanisms such as mandating indoor access points (APs) to have integrated antennas and not be battery powered, and reducing transmit power of client devices which may be outdoors. An accurate indoor/outdoor (I/O) classification addresses these challenges, enabling automatic transmit power adjustments without interfering with incumbents. To this end, we leverage the Global Navigation Satellite System (GNSS) signals for I/O classification. GNSS signals, designed inherently for outdoor reception and highly susceptible to indoor attenuation and blocking, provide a robust and distinguishing feature for environmental sensing. We develop various methodologies, including threshold-based techniques and machine learning approaches and evaluate them using an expanded dataset gathered from diverse geographical locations. Our results demonstrate that GNSS-based methods alone can achieve greater accuracy than approaches relying solely on wireless (Wi-Fi) data, particularly in unfamiliar locations. Furthermore, the integration of GNSS data with Wi-Fi information leads to improved classification accuracy, showcasing the significant benefits of multi-modal data fusion.

title: Leveraging Formal Methods to Strengthen Cyber-Resilience in Authorization to Operate
authors: Alice Lee, Jack Cheng, Tim Braje, Noah Luther, Ian McQuoid, Gruia-Catalin Roman, Joseph Dan Trujillo, Richard Skowyra, Samuel Mergendahl
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: Authorization to Operate (ATO) is a challenging but necessary process for systems to obtain approval for deployment within the Department of Defense (DoD). ATO includes requirement creation, selection, implementation, and satisfaction. Because each step of ATO involves multiple stakeholders, any disconnect between stakeholders can lead to approval difficulties and delay. When these miscommunications compound, they undermine the main goal of the ATO process: to ensure that only secure systems are deployed. In order to addresses these difficulties, this paper proposes to augment the ATO process with formal methods to strengthen the cybersecurity posture of deployed systems. In particular, we first introduce the traditional ATO process and its main stakeholders. We then introduce formal methods and their role to improve ATO. Finally, we apply our enhanced ATO architecture on the Cyber-Hardened Satellite Software (CHSS), satellite flight control software developed by AFRL/RV and MIT LL, to demonstrate how our work illuminates gaps in the traditional ATO process, aids in better communication between stakeholders, and provides formalized security guarantees.

title:
