                    Mixed-Dimensional Bulk Heterostructure-Based Memristor for Artificial Synapses
authors: Libin Liang, Ziyao Lu, Zhenhua Guo, Chunyi Qiu, Zhuoling Zhou, Changjiu Teng
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Integrated Circuits and Microsystems (ICICM)
abstract: To overcome the von Neumann bottleneck, it is imperative to develop advanced neuromorphic computing architectures that emulate the integrated memory and processing capabilities of biological neural systems, for which artificial synaptic memristors offer a promising solution. Therefore, it is urgent to develop advanced neuromorphic computing architectures to simulate the data storage and computing integration of biological neural systems. This study proposes a $\mathrm{Mo}_{2} \mathrm{C}-\mathrm{MoS}_{2}$ mixed dimensional bulk heterostructure (MDBHs) artificial synaptic memristor. MoS<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf> microspheres are synthesized on titanium foil by a hydrothermal method, and Mo<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf>C nanodots are in situ generated on the edge of MoS<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf> using a CVD carbonization process to prepare $\mathbf{A u} / \mathbf{M o}_{\mathbf{2}} \mathbf{C}-\mathbf{M o S}_{\mathbf{2}} \mathbf{M D B H} / \mathbf{T i}$ devices. Unlike traditional RRAMs that rely on sharp resistance switches caused by conductive channels (CF), this device exhibits gradual synaptic enhancement and inhibition behaviors under high bias. Its conductive mechanism is direct tunneling (DT) at low bias and Fowler-Nordheim tunneling (FNT) at high bias. Mo<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf>C nanodots reduce the barrier height and form a tunneling conductive path, significantly improving synaptic performance. The device’s operating current is as low as $0.1 \mu \mathrm{~A}$, which is much lower than existing two-terminal artificial synapses, and exhibits good uniformity and reliability. This study provides a new approach to low-power, high-state artificial synapses through innovative heterostructure design, which has broad application prospects in neuromorphic computing.

title: Stirring the Data Pot: Shuffling Data in Networks for Fast Decentralized Learning
authors: Zonghong Liu, Harris Ransom, Kevin S Chan, Salim El Rouayheb
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: In decentralized learning, especially in tactical network environments where centralized coordination may be infeasible, data correlation across network nodes can degrade the performance of random walk-based learning algorithms. The graph structure induces Markovian dependencies in data sampling, leading to biased updates and slow convergence. We propose a decentralized and asynchronous data shuffling framework to address this issue. Inspired by the Ising model, our method uses Glauber dynamics to guide local data swaps among connected nodes based on an energy function defined via the total variation distance between nodes’ neighborhood label distribution and the uniform distribution. The algorithm shuffles the data with the goal of approximating a uniform label distribution in each node’s neighborhood. Experiments on synthetic and real datasets show that our method can significantly improve convergence and accuracy, approaching centralized performance.

title: Deep Transfer Learning Framework for Cotton Plant Pathology Classification using EfficientNetB3
authors: Kanegonda Ravi Chythanya, Vishnu Kant, Pallavi Semwal, Anzar Ahmed
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: The cash crop cotton is bringing much needed economic benefits besides sustaining more population of people and particularly in the agricultural farming regions. Diseases in the leaves that are diagnosed late normally had a greater impact on the yield of cotton plants. This paper reports a classification system of cotton focusing on leaf disease that employs EfficientNetB3 deep learning model after fine-tuning. The system works under six classes such as Aphids, Army Worm and Bacterial Blight, Healthy, Powdery Mildew and Target Spot wherein the system gets training and evaluation. The results of the confusion matrix reported that the model was accurate in the test stage with 100% accuracy. The study was carried out on the entire development procedure of traditional machine learning along with the integration of IoT and customized CNN models that preoccupy crop diseases detection. Studies promote sustainable agricultural growth that integrates climate migration with good health interests and zero hunger initiatives and represents reasonable consumption and economic development and industrialization with smart farming research application. This suggested system will be able to recognize diseases at an earlier stage and aid the process of decision making as well as provide security to farms and food resources. One of the AI-based solutions is implemented in the concept of sustainable development to change the traditional farming into an efficient and resilient system.

title: Enhancing Abnormal Network Traffic Detection via Efficient Data Generation Leveraging LLM
authors: Changming Li, Zejun Xu, Qiufan Ji, Fan Yang, Cong Shi, Michael DeLucia, Yingying Chen
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: Network attacks (e.g., distributed denial of service (DDoS), worms, and botnets) have become serious threats to the Internet. To mitigate these threats, network systems increasingly utilize machine learning (ML) models to analyze network traffic (e.g., packet rates and traffic volumes), detecting anomalies related to attacks. However, these ML-based methods normally fail to detect multi-vector attacks, where a single malicious network traffic simultaneously exhibits multiple attack characteristics. The key bottleneck is that the network traffic datasets are predominantly single-vector (i.e., one attack type per traffic). In this paper, we design a novel framework that can generate diverse multi-label datasets to facilitate attack detection by only leveraging existing single-vector datasets. The key idea is to leverage large language models (LLMs) to interpret the single-vector network traffic, learning the underlying statistical characteristics of each individual attack. Through advanced prompt engineering, our framework can generate network traffic exhibiting the statistical characteristics of real-world multi-vector attacks. Extensive experiments on both public and self-collected datasets show that the generated network traffic can build ML models for effective multi-vector attack detection.

title: Cognitive Radio for Asymmetric Cellular Downlink with Multi-User MIMO
authors: Omer Gokalp Serbetci, Lei Chu, Andreas F. Molisch
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: Cognitive radio (CR) is an important technique for improving spectral efficiency, letting a secondary system operate in a wireless spectrum when the primary system does not make use of it. While it has been widely explored over the past 25 years, many common assumptions are not aligned with the realities of 5G networks. In this paper, we consider the CR problem for the following setup: (i) infrastructure-based systems, where downlink transmissions might occur to Receivers (Rxs) whose positions are not, or not exactly, known; (ii) multi-beam antennas at both primary and secondary base stations. We formulate a detailed protocol to determine when secondary transmissions into different beam directions can interfere with primary users at potential locations and create probability-based interference rules. We then analyze the "catastrophic interference" probability and the "missed transmission opportunity" probability, as well as the achievable throughput, as a function of the transmit powers of the primary and secondary base stations and the sensing window of the secondary base station. Results can serve to more realistically assess the spectral efficiency gains in 5G infrastructure-based cognitive systems.

title: Pushing the Boundaries in CBRS Band: Robust Radar Detection within High 5G Interference
authors: Shafi Ullah Khan, Michel Kulhandjian, Debashri Roy
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: Spectrum sharing is a critical strategy for meeting escalating user demands via commercial wireless services, yet its effective regulation and technological enablement, particularly concerning coexistence with incumbent systems, remain significant challenges. Federal organizations have established regulatory frameworks to manage shared commercial use alongside mission-critical operations, such as military communications. This paper investigates the potential of machine learning (ML)-based approaches to enhance spectrum sharing capabilities within the Citizens Broadband Radio Service (CBRS) band, specifically focusing on the coexistence of commercial signals (e.g., 5G) and military radar systems. We demonstrate that ML techniques can potentially extend the Federal Communications Commission (FCC)-recommended signal-to-interference-plus-noise ratio (SINR) boundaries by improving radar detection and waveform identification in high-interference environments. Through rigorous evaluation using both synthetic and real-world signals, our findings indicate that proposed ML models, utilizing In-phase/Quadrature (IQ) data and spectrograms, can achieve the FCC-recommended 99% radar detection accuracy even when subjected to high interference from 5G signals upto -5dB SINR, exceeding the required limits of 20 SINR. Our experimental studies distinguish this work from the state-of-the-art by significantly extending the SINR limit for 99% radar detection accuracy from approximately 12 dB down to −5 dB. Subsequent to detection, we further apply ML to analyze and identify radar waveforms. The proposed models also demonstrate the capability to classify six distinct radar waveform types with 93% accuracy.

title: Model-based Stability Analysis and Adaptive Power Coordination for Small-Scale DC V2G Systems
authors: Jiang Hai, Yuan Haibing, Liang Yuhang, Li Tianwen, Ma Jiawei, Jiang Libiao
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: This paper addresses the nonlinear and coupling characteristics of small-scale DC V2G systems under conditions of limited number of electric vehicles, frequent load disturbances, and battery parameter drift. A model-based stability analysis and adaptive power coordination control method is proposed. First, a system state-space model is established, incorporating the bus, electric vehicle energy storage units, DC/DC converters, and load dynamics. Theoretically, bounded disturbance assumptions and parameter uncertainties are taken into account. This is used to build a framework for Lyapunov stability analysis and to establish an adaptive gain convergence rule that uses fixed-point theory to dynamically modify the control gain. This function guarantees the system's overall stability in the face of time-varying disruptions. Second, a weighted optimization goal function is provided, taking into account inter-vehicle power imbalance and global voltage variation, based on a model-driven power coordination mechanism. An adaptive law is used to optimize power allocation in real time. On the MATLAB/Simulink platform, a small-scale V2G simulation model involving five electric vehicles is created. The rated bus voltage is 400 V, the load power fluctuates between 2 and 6 kW, the battery has a 12 kWh capacity, and the state of charge (SOC) ranges from 60% to 90%. According to experimental results, the algorithm described in this study is more robust and stable under situations of parameter drift and load rapid changes than the conventional MPC, PSO-MPC, and IWOA-MPC approaches. Specifically, when the load increases from 3 kW to 5 kW, the steady-state deviation of the bus is reduced by approximately 85%, the voltage fluctuation amplitude is reduced by 40%, and the system peak current decreases by 12.7%. The system can sustain a convergence error of less than 10⁻<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</sup> even with parameter uncertainties of ±12%. The uniqueness and convergence of the adaptive law under fixed-point theory are confirmed by the gain's simultaneous convergence to the steady-state value K* = 0.832I.

title: Deep Learning-Driven Framework for Diabetic Retinopathy Diagnosis and Virtual Ophthalmic Support
authors: Gullapalli Sathar, N. Sunanda, Gollapudi Mounika, K. Shailaja, K. Vamsi Krishna, Anil Kumar Sikkakoli
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: Diabetic retinopathy (DR) is a significant cause of visual impairment, especially if it is undetected on the early stages, for people with diabetes. This work describes the development of a new integrated system of both natural language processing (NLP) and machine learning for detecting and managing DR. To classify retinal fundus images collected from the clinically annotated dataset APTOS 2019 it utilizes a Convolutional Neural Network (CNN). This achieved a test accuracy 96.5%, recall 96.7% and F1-score 96.5% for categorizing the DR severity stages. An LLM, or large language model of NLP was integrated to feed real-time lifestyle adjustments and other post-diagnostic support. The dual modules of classification and advisory recommendation were made available to users via a Flask hosted web application, both offering high diagnostic accuracy as well as patient engagement. The integrated approach lends support to ophthalmologists in early detection of DR and potentially helps fill the gap in advisory recommendations through human-readable AI.

title: Spectrum Sharing and Spatial Isolation for 5G Cellular Networks and Military Radars in the FR1 Frequency Bands
authors: C. Nicolas Barati, Aditya Dhananjay, Michael Zappe, Paulo Marques, Luis Pereira, Roberto Magueta, Sundeep Rangan, Kimberly Gold, Scot A. Hawkins, Sachin Shetty
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: One of the most persistent challenges wireless systems, especially cellular licensed bands, face is the scarcity of bandwidth as demand grows. Spectrum sharing, i.e., mix use of frequency resources shared between an incumbent and secondary users has emerged as a remedy to this problem. In this work, we present a modular, open-source and versatile approach to spectrum sharing between a 5G cellular network, as a secondary user, and incumbent military radar systems. We present the architecture of the overall configuration and demonstrate the parallel coexistence of these fundamentally different systems by spatially suppressing interference emanating from the 5G network to the radar transmitter. Leveraging multi-element beamformers and through a step-by-step approach, we first detect the presence of a radar transmission, then estimate the angle of arrival and finally project nulls towards the radar transmitter while serving 5G users on the remaining spatial degrees of freedom (beams). This entire system will be part of a spectrum sharing testbed at Old Dominion University and all components, software and hardware, will be open-sourced and available to the research community for verification and extension.

title: UCAT-Net: Semantic Segmentation of Ultrasound Placenta and Amniotic Fluid Images in IoT Environment
authors: Junming Wei, Jun Liu, Cong Chen, Haixiao Gong, Zhenwei Di, Bocheng Liang, Ying Tan, HongYan Lu
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conferences on Internet of Things (iThings) IEEE Green Computing &amp; Communications (GreenCom) IEEE Cyber, Physical &amp; Social Computing (CPSCom) and IEEE Smart Data (SmartData) and IEEE Congress on Cybermatics (Cybermatics)
abstract: Medical ultrasound imaging is essential for assessing fetal anatomical structures but is often affected by noise, blurring, and operator variability, which obscure boundaries and reduce segmentation accuracy. To address these issues, we propose UCAT-Net, a lightweight and enhanced segmentation network based on U-Net. It employs a ResNet50 encoder to improve deep feature extraction and incorporates an ELA attention mechanism in the residual branches to enhance channel-wise representation. A multi-scale fusion module further aggregates decoder features for refined semantic segmentation. Experiments on a multi-class ultrasound dataset (placenta and amniotic fluid) show that UCAT-Net surpasses the original U-Net, with <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1. 8 \%}$</tex> and 3.05 % improvements in mIoU and mDice, respectively. With an inference time of just 0.0265 seconds per image under limited computational resources, UCAT-Net shows strong potential for real-time use in IoT-based clinical settings.

title: Smart Solar-Driven E-Uniform with Climate Control for Soldiers
authors: Konda Govardhan, K. Vinod Kumar, Moilla Mani Kumar Reddy, Soma Mahesh Kumar, Balapanur Venkatesu, Paradesi Swetha
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: Soldiers operating in harsh battlefield environments face extreme temperature variations, which can lead to discomfort, fatigue, and reduced operational effectiveness. To address this challenge, this work presents a Smart Solar-Driven E-Uniform equipped with an autonomous climate control system that maintains thermal comfort while minimizing external power dependence. The proposed uniform integrates flexible solar panels for on-body energy harvesting, a rechargeable battery storage module, and a NodeMCU-based microcontroller system that monitors ambient temperature using a digital sensor. Depending on real-time environmental conditions, the controller activates either micro cooling fans for ventilation in hot climates or resistive heating pads for warmth in cold conditions. The system architecture ensures energy-efficient operation by prioritizing renewable power use and switching dynamically between heating and cooling modes. Experimental evaluation demonstrated stable temperature regulation, reliable mode switching, and extended runtime supported by solar energy, reducing the need for external charging sources. The results indicate that the system enhances soldier comfort and endurance while contributing to sustainable and mobile power solutions. This research highlights the potential for integrating wearable renewable energy systems with intelligent climate management to improve operational readiness in defense applications.

title: Transfer Learning in Adversarial Attacks Across Graph Neural Networks
authors: Pooja Chigurupati, Ashokkumar R Patel, Gokhan Kul
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: Graph Neural Networks (GNNs) are widely applied in many applications such as social networks, recommendation systems and cybersecurity. However, the impact of adversarial attacks on GNNs is a prevalent problem. Previous research shows that GNNs have adversarial vulnerabilities due to a minor perturbation of graph data can lead to poor performance outcomes for these models. Our research investigates the transferability of GNN’s robustness against adversarial vulnerabilities to different GNN architectures through transfer learning. This method examines how adversarial information can propagate across different GNN models, while investigating methods to develop robustness of the model. Our approach begins with a graph convolutional network (GCN) trained on an adversarial dataset which showcases its specific vulnerabilities. We then create a robust graph-attention network (GAT) model that are expected to be more resistant to adversarial perturbations. In training the model on an adversarial dataset, we assess its robustness while working towards improving its adversarial defenses. We also apply meta-learning at the target-side model to improve its adaptability and further develop the model’s defenses. Our research aims to improve the adversarial robustness of GAT, contributing to developing more effective defenses for applications involving graph-based data protection.

title: A Responsive Deep Q-Learning Framework for Sustainable Integrated Energy Systems
authors: Jarin T, Tony C J, Jyotsna E, Siddarth Rajesh
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: The fast integration of storage models, renewable energy sources, and demand-side management has increased the complexity of modern Integrated Energy Systems (IES). Existing optimization and control methods generally fails with scalability, uncertainty, and nonlinear dynamics. Recent advances in deep learning (DL) provide efficient tools to manage high-dimensional data and extract hidden patterns, yet their black-box nature and dependency on large datasets limit their use in safety critical domains. To overcome these challenges, Constraint aware DL (CADL) and Constraint Aware Deep Q Learning (CADQL) model is presented that have embedding physical laws, conservation principles, and engineering constraints directly into DL model. This hybrid model enhances robustness, adaptability, provides better forecasting, control, and decision-making. Empirical studies report substantial improvements: forecasting error reduced by 65%, operational costs decreased by 11%, enhances renewable utilization by 10%, and carbon emissions reduced by 26%. With respect to learning with domain knowledge, the CADQL provided a scalable pathway toward sustainable, resilient, and cost effective IES management. This supports global efforts in renewable integration and carbon reduction.

title: Advances in Quantum Technologies for Defense: Opportunities and Security Challenges
authors: Joanna Sliwa, Konrad Wrona, Marco Piani, Marta I. Garcia-Cid, Michal Krelina, Federico Grasselli, Armando N. Pinto, Nuno A. Silva, Joan Bas, Kadir Durak
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: Quantum technologies harness the fundamental principles and features of quantum mechanics, such as superposition, no-cloning, entanglement, and quantum tunneling, to deliver transformative advancements in areas including secure communications, PNT (Positioning, Navigation, and Timing), sensing, and computing. Potential defense applications of quantum technologies include secure command and control channels resistant to interception, GPS-independent navigation systems, and quantum-enhanced radar capable of detecting stealth objects. However, quantum systems also bring new challenges and potential vulnerabilities, which are particularly relevant in the defense domain, where operational reliability and security are of paramount importance. We discuss insights into the opportunities and limitations of quantum technologies in the defense sector, as identified by the NATO STO IST-219 Research Task Group on Quantum Technology Vulnerabilities. We also present initial findings regarding identified security challenges and validation methodology.

title: GraphRL-Core: Intelligent Logic Synthesis Optimization via Graph Transformer and Deep Reinforcement Learning
authors: Sujie Zhu, Guande Dong, Haoyang He, Chong Xia, Jianwang Zhai
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Integrated Circuits and Microsystems (ICICM)
abstract: With the rapid expansion of circuit design scales, traditional logic synthesis methods are encountering severe bottlenecks in optimizing complex circuit structures. This paper proposes an intelligent optimization approach, GraphRL-Core, which combines a graph transformer with deep reinforcement learning (DRL) and innovatively integrates the global modeling capability of the Gradformer model with the decision adaptability of reinforcement learning (RL). The system automatically generates optimization instructions for logic circuits by extracting graph structural features, utilizing graph transformer encoding, and employing a multi-objective reward-driven policy learning approach. Experiments conducted on several representative circuits demonstrate that the proposed method outperforms both traditional optimization flows and existing RL frameworks in terms of LUT minimization, optimization efficiency, and generalization capability, highlighting its significant practical value.

title: Federated-Learning Optimized AirComp Over UAV-Based CF Massive-MIMO Mobile Networks
authors: Guohao Pang, Xi Zhang
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: UAV-based Cell-free massive-MIMO (CF massiveMIMO) networks can support diverse quality of service and high spectral efficiency, making them a natural substrate for next-generation mobile networks used for both civil and military applications. This paper proposes UAV-based federated learning (FL) optimized over-the-air computation (AirComp) schemes for CF massive-MIMO mobile networks. To tackle the model aggregation errors that undermine FL accuracy, our schemes jointly optimize mobile users’ (MUs) transmit power, access points’ (APs) receiving vectors, central processing unit’s (CPU) large-scale fading decoding (LSFD) weight, and UAV locations under power and receiver constraints. Using the fully connected signal path inherent in CF massive-MIMO, we cast the entire mobile networks as a trainable neural network whose parameters correspond to the physical transceiver coefficients. Using preconfigured pilot symbols, a forward–backward training procedure directly learns power allocation and combines coefficients without channel estimation, thus simplifying design and reducing signaling overhead. The extensive simulations obtained confirm that our proposed schemes can accelerate FL convergence, enhance mobile networks robustness under high levels of noise, and outperform conventional two-stage optimization baselines, validating our developed FL optimized AirComp over UAV-based CF massive-MIMO mobile networks.

title: Frequency-reconfigurable adhoc networks with dynamic metasurface antennas
authors: Nitish Vikas Deshpande, Ibrahim Kilinc, Joseph Carlson, Robert W. Heath
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: The dynamic metasurface antenna (DMA) is a low-cost and low-powered frequency-reconfigurable antenna architecture. Prior work has focused on exploiting the frequency-reconfigurability property of a DMA in a cellular network setting. We propose DMAs to enable frequency-reconfigurable mobile adhoc networks (MANETs). We envision devices in an adhoc network equipped with DMAs that have the ability to dynamically change the operating frequency within a feasible range depending on the DMA design. We propose a dynamic operating frequency selection approach that reduces interference in an adhoc network compared to the case when all devices operate in the same band. To maximize the signal-to-interference- and-noise ratio (SINR), we optimize the per-element resonant frequencies of the DMA using a gradient-ascent based technique. We use ray-traced channels to perform Monte-Carlo simulations for the adhoc network. We show that the normalized transmission capacity, i.e., the number of successful transmissions per unit area per unit frequency, increases with the DMA tuning range using our proposed optimization. The DMA with wider tuning range is more energy-efficient compared to a fully-digital receiver.

title: Smartphone-Based Indoor/Outdoor Inference: A SigCap Approach
authors: Hossein Nasiri, Muhammad Iqbal Rochman, Monisha Ghosh
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: Indoor/outdoor (I/O) classification holds significant importance in various applications, particularly in the domain of dynamic spectrum sharing, where environmental context profoundly influences propagation models and resource allocation. Furthermore, an accurate I/O classification is crucial for intelligent power management and interference reduction in wireless systems. Wi-Fi and Global Navigation Satellite System (GNSS) signals, ubiquitously available on a multitude of wireless devices, offer rich and accessible data sources highly correlated with the ambient environment, making them ideal for I/O classification. Despite this potential, to date, there has been a notable absence of live, on-device I/O classification. In this work, we address this critical gap by implementing real-time I/O classification on a mobile device within the SigCap Android application. We leverage two distinct methodologies: a robust machine learning approach utilizing multiple Random Forest models (trained on Wi-Fi, GNSS, and combined features) and a computationally efficient threshold-based method (relying on per-satellite GNSS RSSI thresholds). This work details the implementation of both methods, alongside a comparative analysis in terms of computational complexity, memory footprint, scalability, and configurability, highlighting the practical challenges and solutions for deploying advanced classification capabilities in a mobile environment.

title: An Efficient Certificateless Key Agreement Scheme with Revocation Checking in Smart Grids
authors: Boyu Liu, Jing Zhang, Pengfei Yu, Junyi Wang, Hengrui Yang
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conferences on Internet of Things (iThings) IEEE Green Computing &amp; Communications (GreenCom) IEEE Cyber, Physical &amp; Social Computing (CPSCom) and IEEE Smart Data (SmartData) and IEEE Congress on Cybermatics (Cybermatics)
abstract: Smart grids integrate traditional power infrastructure with intelligent digital management to enhance service quality and efficiency. However, existing smart grids are confronted with critical security challenges. Deploying secure authentication and key agreement (AKA) is the basic requirement to ensure security. In this paper, we propose CAKARC, an efficient Certificateless Authentication and Key Agreement scheme with Revocation Checking in smart grids. CAKARC mitigates the key escrow problems and eliminates the need for computationally intensive operations, such as signing or bilinear pairings, while enabling efficient public key revocation and verification. We formally define the security model for CAKARC and prove its security in the random oracle model. Additionally, we implement and evaluate CAKARC to demonstrate its practical efficiency.

title: Process Integration Optimization for RF SOI Process with Arcing Issue
authors: Zhangli Liu, Fei Meng, Ruofan Dai
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Integrated Circuits and Microsystems (ICICM)
abstract: The process optimization for RF SOI process with arcing issue is comprehensively investigated in the work. By failure mechanism and analysis, the optimized integration process solution is proposed: (1) Passivation and top via photo wafer edge exposure (WEE) setting, (b) Top via W Chemical-Machine-Polishing (CMP) with wafer edge over polish, and (c) Passivation etch process optimized, by reducing the passivation thickness on the thick top metal. Arcing free is obtained by the optimized integration process solution. The method is verified by mass production.

title: Railway Safety Assessment Using Dual-Frequency Insar Data in Central Shandong of Eastern China
authors: Shaoyang Guan, Chao Wang, Yixian Tang, Fan Wu, Lichuan Zou, Peichen Yu, Jing Ning
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: With rapid development of high-speed railway in China, land subsidence poses significant risks to railway operational safety and facilities reliability, requiring precise and efficient monitoring solutions. This study utilizes dual-frequency Differential InSAR (DInSAR) to monitor surface deformation along railway corridors in central Shandong, China, using COSMO-SkyMed (CSK, X-band) and LuTan-1 (LT-1, L-band) satellite data. The results reveal that most segments remain stable, but severe subsidence affected <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{0. 6 1 \%}$</tex> (CSK) and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{0. 4 9 \%}$</tex> (LT-1) of the region, with high-risk subsidence zones associated with construction activities and slope instability. Notably, the longer wavelength of LT-1 demonstrates superior coherence and deformation monitoring capability in vegetation-dense regions. This study provides valuable insights into multi-band InSAR applications for deformation monitoring and risk assessment along railway corridors.

title: Dynamics of Q -Learning in Networked Stochastic Games
authors: Zheng Yuan, Guangchen Jiang, Shuyue Hu, Matjaž Perc, Chen Chu, Jinzhuo Liu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Neural Networks and Learning Systems
abstract: Stochastic games form the foundational mathematical framework for describing multiagent interactions and underpin the theoretical foundations of multiagent reinforcement learning (MARL) and optimal decision making. However, previous research has typically focused on either two-agent settings or large-scale well-mixed agent populations, where the considered interaction scenarios were far from realistic. In this article, we consider structured populations where agents can interact with immediate neighbors. By using the pair-approximation method, we develop a new dynamical model to describe the <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$Q$</tex-math> </inline-formula>-learning dynamics in stochastic games on regular graphs. Through comparisons with agent-based simulation results, we validate the accuracy of our dynamical model across various stochastic games, population structures, and algorithm parameters. Our research thus provides both qualitative and quantitative insights into the effects of state transition rules and graph topologies in population dynamics. In particular, we show that, under certain conditions, state transitions can significantly promote the evolution of cooperation in social dilemmas. We also explored the effects of agent degree on cooperation, and unlike previous findings, we show that this can have either positive or negative implications for cooperation depending on the transition rules.

title: Solution Approaches for the Dynamic Naval Air Defense Planning Problem_supp5-3648686.pdf
authors: Caner Arslan
publish: N/A
abstract: The naval air defense planning (NADP) problem entails the defense of a naval fleet against aerial threats. This complex and dynamic problem requires real-time decision-making and adaptation to evolving warfare environment. While our previous work addressed the static NADP problem by proposing a mathematical model and heuristic solutions for sensor allocation, engagement scheduling, and ship routing, this study extends to the dynamic NADP problem. Unlike the static version, which assumes complete knowledge of future threats, the dynamic NADP problem requires continuous updates and real-time adjustments to decisions as new threats emerge and situational parameters change. We present modifications in the mathematical formulation, which is based on a mixed-integer nonlinear programming (MINLP) model, alongside a comprehensive simulation structure. We employ heuristic solution approaches that utilize a combination of a genetic algorithm, construction of an engagement graph to solve the shortest path problem, and dynamic programming (DP) techniques. Computational experiments are conducted to evaluate the effectiveness of these methods in addressing the dynamic NADP problem. The study also explores machine learning models for threat prioritization, offering innovative solutions to the challenges posed by dynamic naval air defense scenarios.

title: Learning Multilayer Feature Projection for Homogeneous and Heterogeneous Palmprint Recognition
authors: Lunke Fei, Kaiting Huang, Shuping Zhao, Qi Zhu, Bob Zhang, Wei Jia
publish: IEEE Transactions on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics: Systems
abstract: Owing to its remarkable convenience, weak invasiveness, and strong private security, palmprint recognition has become one of the most promising biometric methods and has attracted increasing attention in both academia and industry. Although considerable recognition performance has been achieved by existing palmprint learning methods, they generally require the use of substantial labeled datasets and involve substantial computational overhead for feature learning. In this article, we propose a novel multilayer projection learning (MLPL) method to achieve efficient palmprint feature learning and recognition. First, we transform the palmprint images into their direction-specific representations by computing the difference in the multiple directional responses. Then, we learn three layers of feature projections for robust feature learning, including low-rank projection for image noise decoupling, feature projection for discriminative feature exploration, and quantization projection for information preservation during feature encoding. With multilayer feature projections, palmprint images can be transformed into discriminative feature representations through a single-step process for efficient palmprint recognition. Moreover, we extend the proposed MLPL, referred to as E-MLPL, by minimizing the representation discrepancy between heterogeneous palmprint images to make it applicable for heterogeneous palmprint recognition. The results obtained from five widely adopted databases confirm the superior performance of the proposed method in terms of both accuracy and efficiency.

title: A Tongue-computer Interface for Silent Speech Recognition_supp1-3638364.docx
authors: Xiaoyang Kang
publish: N/A
abstract: Speech recognition and interaction have been always based on the modalities of acoustic signals and mechanical motions, which build on the premise that humans must make a sound or make a movement of throat or face. Here we introduced a tongue-computer interface capable of speech recognition that do not relay on vocal cords, throat or face, which only based on the surface electromyography (sEMG) of tongue by using a soft electrode array. A Multiscale Attention Fusion - Temporal Convolutional Networks (MSAF-TCNet), was designed for silent speech recognition of tongue sEMG, integrating input features, channel attention, and spatial attention to adaptively handle attention features at different scales, achieving more comprehensive and balanced feature representations. Quantitative results show that the model achieved average recognition accuracies of 88.4% and 78.6% on the daily sentence dataset and phoneme dataset from seven participants, respectively; qualitative observations indicate that the tongue-computer interface can work stably in noisy environments due to its independence from acoustic signals, and can realize silent speech recognition only through tongue movements. The combination of the tongue-computer interface and neural network optimization provides a highly promising solution for silent speech recognition that requires no sound production and relies only on tongue movements.

title: Resonance-based Sensing on Large Surfaces Using RF Excitation for Human Machine Interaction
authors: Vikas Kumar, Shivansh Awasthi, Vikash Sharma, Santosh Parajuli, Thomas George Thundat, Ankur Gupta
publish: IEEE Sensors Letters
abstract: This letter proposes resonance-based sensing on large surfaces using 13.56 MHz RF excitation to enhance human safety in human machine interaction (HMI). In this approach, whole large conducting surface itself functions as a sensor by varying its resonance characteristics in response to object interactions. The sensing system is compact in design and optimized for operation in the industrial, scientific, and medical (ISM) band. The surface is excited using a single conductor powered resonant coil, which provides good passive voltage gain at -16 dBm input power. A secondary resonant coil is employed to amplify voltage variations caused by human touch on the surface. The system delivers a high voltage output signal that can be directly interfaced with a computing platform through an analog to digital converter (ADC), thereby eliminating the need for external amplifiers or analog filters. This technique offers a cost effective, low power, and large area sensing solution for human robot collaboration (HRC). The proposed system can be seamlessly integrated into machines or robotic platforms for sensing applications in HMI.

title: Quantum Internet Architecture: unlocking Quantum-Native Routing via Quantum Addressing
authors: Marcello Caleffi, Angela Sara Cacciapuoti
publish: IEEE Transactions on Communications
abstract: The key objective of the Quantum Internet is the distribution and manipulation of entanglement to enable unprecedented applications. This requires a radical departure from classical Internet design principles, such as the end-to-end argument, due to the inherently stateful and non-local nature of entanglement, which demands coordinated in-network operations and persistent state awareness. To this end, we propose a novel hierarchical Quantum Internet architecture centered on the concept of Entanglement-Defined Controller (EDC). This architectural design constitutes the foundational layer, by enabling a clear separation between control and data planes. While necessary, this separation is insufficient to manage entanglement resources, requiring a quantum-native control plane. Consequently, we propose a quantum addressing scheme that embeds quantumness directly into node identifiers, allowing the network to natively track and manipulate entanglement as a dynamic resource. Built upon these two interdependent pillars – EDC-based architecture and quantum addressing – we design a quantum-native routing protocol that achieves scalability through compact routing tables, by efficiently operating over entanglement-defined topologies. Finally, we design a quantum address splitting functionality based on Schrödinger’s oracles that generalizes classical match-and-forward logic to the quantum domain. Collectively, these contributions demonstrate, for the first time, the fundamental advantages of quantum-by-design network control for enabling scalable quantum networking.

title: An Active Shaping Reflector Method for Space-borne Membrane Reflector Antennas
authors: Gu Yongzhen, Wang Mengtian, Wang Haoxin
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: Conventional space-borne antenna shaping designs predominantly rely on a pre-defined reflector geometry, which lacks the capability to adapt to varying multi-stage service requirements once in orbit. To overcome this limitation, this paper proposes an active shaping method for space-borne membrane reflector antennas (MRA) through coordinated control of electrostatic forces and boundary cable tensions. A coupled structural-electromagnetic model is established that integrates the nonlinear finite element method for structural mechanics and the physical optics approach for radiation analysis, capturing the interactions between actuation forces, reflector morphology, and far-field performance. With electrostatic voltages and cable tensions as design variables, an optimization model is formulated to minimize the root mean square error of the directivity at sample points within the target coverage region. Numerical simulations conducted on a 30-meter aperture MRA demonstrate the effectiveness of the method, achieving an average directivity improvement of approximately 2.67 times after active shaping. The approach provides a feasible strategy for in-orbit reconfiguration of membrane reflector antennas to accommodate dynamic mission profiles and was verified through experiments with 5-meter electrostatically formed MRA.

title: Using the Reinforcement Learning agent to test the correctness of rule configuration in Web Application Firewalls
authors: Mariusz Sepczuk, Krzysztof Sosnowski
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: Data protection is one of the most essential elements of cyber security strategies and processes. One of the components that support this process are firewalls, particularly web application firewalls (WAFs). These tools are responsible for detecting and blocking potential attacks coming from user traffic. Their proper security configuration (usage of appropriate blocking rules) is behind this crucial task, which is often marginal. One method of verifying such a configuration is using fuzz tests, but they have some drawbacks. In this work, we investigated the effectiveness of WAF configurations in the context of cross site scripting attacks (XSS) with an agent using a reinforcement learning (RL) approach.For this purpose, we created a suitable test environment with six different types of WAFs (e.g., ModSecurity, Naxsi, and SafeLine) and we conducted several experiments using the RL agent to check whether it is possible to bypass attack detection by the application firewall. Moreover, we compared the effectiveness of the RL agent with five web application fuzzers to verify whether it is capable of finding more effective payloads that can bypass WAF detection. The results allow us to conclude that using the RL concept and fuzzing can be an appropriate method for verifying the efficacy of WAF configurations.

title: Control Barrier Functions for Safe Stabilization via Zubov’s Theorem
authors: Jiaxing Wang, Wei Ren, Weiguo Xia, Xi-Ming Sun
publish: IEEE Transactions on Automation Science and Engineering
abstract: Safety guarantee is a fundamental requirement for numerous dynamical systems. In this work, the safe stabilization problem in complex scenarios is considered. First, we introduce the notion of the local safe set, a convex and compact set disjoint from unsafe regions, to construct a finite sequence of such sets. Next, we leverage Zubov’s theorem to propose the Zubov barrier function (Zubov BF), which provides safety guarantees on local safe sets. Compared with the existing ones, the Zubov BF reduces the conservatism and complexity in safety analysis. The relations between the Zubov BF and existing ones are discussed to show the generality of Zubov BF. The Zubov control barrier function (Zubov CBF) is further extended for control synthesis. Sufficient and necessary conditions are provided to verify the existence of the derived controller. To achieve the safe stabilization objective, we provide a modified quadratic programming (QP) framework with feasibility guarantee and demonstrate the continuity of the derived controller in closed form. Finally, a numerical example from the overtaking problem of two autonomous vehicles and a practical experiment on the safe navigation for a quadrotor are provided to illustrate the derived results.

title: Research on Defect Localization of Power Cables Using Compressed Sensing-Based FDR Method
authors: Haotian He, Feihu Zheng, Xingzhe Zhao
publish: IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
abstract: Frequency Domain Reflectometry (FDR) is widely used for detecting and locating local defects in power cables. However, noise, multiple reflections, and spectral leakage can generate spurious peaks and sidelobes in the FDR spectrum, which may mislead defect localization. Moreover, FDR testing requires the collection of a large volume of data, placing high demands on on-site storage and real-time processing. This study proposes a compressed sensing (CS)-based method for defect localization in power cables. The method first preprocesses the raw signal using Variational Mode Decomposition (VMD) and windowing and performs compressed sampling with a sparse random measurement matrix, after which the signal is reconstructed and preliminarily denoised under the Discrete Fourier Transform (DFT) basis, followed by sparse reconstruction under the Chirp Z-Transform (CZT) basis to obtain a sparse representation. Simulations and field tests verify that the proposed method maintains high localization accuracy even under high compression ratios, while effectively suppressing spurious peaks and sidelobe interference.

title: A Resilience-enhancing Service Pricing Framework for Modern Distribution Networks with the Integration of Hydrogen Energy Storage Systems and Vehicle-to-Grid
authors: Ding Jin, Xiangyu Li, Zhenyu Huang, Xin Cui
publish: IEEE Transactions on Industry Applications
abstract: Flexible resources (FRs) including battery energy storage systems, hydrogen energy storage systems, and electric vehicles can effectively enhance the resilience of power distribution networks (PDNs) during extreme weather events. However, the high-impact, low-probability (HILP) nature of extreme weather events creates challenges in accurately assessing spatial temporal risk. Moreover, the complex interplay among PDN and multiple FRs introduces challenges in effectively incentivizing FRs to enhance PDN resilience. To address these issues, we apply the tail-focused risk measure known as Entropic Value at-Risk (EVaR) to assess the spatial-temporal risk of energy not supplied. In addition to the wholesale price, we develop a dynamic EVaR-based price adder designed to encourage multiple FRs to deliver resilience-enhancing services when risks are identified. This approach can mitigate supply shortfall risks by facilitating spatial-temporal FR power injection into the PDN, incentivized by the price adder. Case studies show that the EVaR risk measure is sensitive to HILP events, and the proposed pricing framework effectively incentivizes FRs to provide resilience-enhancing services at high-risk nodes and during critical intervals.

title: Diffusion-Driven Self-Supervised Learning for Shape Reconstruction and Pose Estimation_supp1-3647855.pdf
authors: Jingtao Sun
publish: N/A
abstract: Fully-supervised category-level pose estimation aims to determine the 6-DoF poses of unseen instances from known categories, requiring expensive manual labeling costs. Recently, various self-supervised category-level pose estimation methods have been proposed to reduce the requirement of the annotated datasets. However, most methods rely on synthetic data or 3D CAD model, and they are typically limited to addressing single-object pose problems without considering multi-objective tasks or shape reconstruction. To overcome these challenges and limitations, we introduce a diffusion-driven self-supervised network for multi-object shape reconstruction and categorical pose estimation, only leveraging the shape priors. Specifically, to capture the SE(3)-equivariant pose features and 3D scale-invariant shape information, we present a Prior-Aware Pyramid 3D Point Transformer. This module adopts a point convolutional layer with radial-kernels for pose-aware learning and a 3D scale-invariant graph convolution layer for object-level shape representation. Furthermore, we introduce a Pretrain-to-Refine Self-Supervised Training Paradigm to train our network. It enables proposed network to capture the associations between shape priors and observations, addressing the challenge of intra-class shape variations by utilising the diffusion mechanism. Extensive experiments conducted on four public datasets and a self-built dataset demonstrate that our method significantly outperforms state-of-the-art self-supervised category-level baselines and even surpasses some fully-supervised instance-level and category-level methods.

title: F-VIS: Efficient Robotic Tactile Sensing via Fiber Bragg Grating-Based Force and Vision Fusion
authors: Qiaokang Liang, Xiaoyu Yuan, Jianyong Long, Dan Zhang
publish: IEEE/ASME Transactions on Mechatronics
abstract: This article introduces F-VIS, a novel visual–tactile sensor that integrates direct force measurement based on fiber Bragg grating (FBG) with vision-based tactile sensing. F-VIS achieves multimodal tactile perception in real time by combining high-precision force and visual data, without relying on marker layers or data-driven force estimation. The sensor uses three spiral structures for 3-D force measurement (Fx, Fy, and Fz) and a designed contact body for tactile image acquisition and depth reconstruction. Static calibration experiments show that F-VIS has root-mean-square error (RMSE) values of 0.01, 0.018, and 0.022 N for <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$F_{x}$</tex-math></inline-formula>, <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$F_{y}$</tex-math></inline-formula>, and <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$F_{z}$</tex-math></inline-formula> within the <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\pm$</tex-math></inline-formula>5 and [0, 10] N ranges. It also achieves an average RMSE of 0.12 mm in depth reconstruction. Fusion experiments show the sensor achieves RMSE of 2.5 pixels and 0.12 N for contact location and force, respectively. With high sensitivity (up to 24.95 pm/N) and a 100-Hz operating frequency, F-VIS enables rapid, precise force detection. Temperature compensation keeps FBG drift under 7 pm (25<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$^\circ$</tex-math></inline-formula>–50<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$^\circ$</tex-math></inline-formula>); after 500 cycles, transmittance rises 0.36%. F-VIS excels in hardness detection, object classification, and delicate manipulation, detecting 0.16 N forces and capturing slip forces. It outperforms existing sensors with superior precision, responsiveness, and versatility.

title: Analytical Prediction of Partial Demagnetization in Interior Permanent Magnet Synchronous Motor Using Magnetic Equivalent Circuit Modelling
authors: WonJun Jeong, Sarbajit Paul, Pil-Wan Han, Junghwan Chang
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: In Interior Permanent Magnet Synchronous Motor (IPMSM) for railway traction applications, irreversible demagnetization of permanent magnets can lead to severe degradation in motor performance and even system failure. The irreversible demagnetization can be induced by high temperature, opposing magnetic fields, or mechanical stress. While Finite Element Analysis (FEA) is highly accurate in predicting the irreversible demagnetization, it is computationally expensive and inefficient for the early design stage, where repeated geometric changes and parametric studies are often required. In this study, a Magnetic Equivalent Circuit (MEC)-based approach is proposed to efficiently assess the risk of partial demagnetization in the Permanent Magnets (PMs). The method enables localized analysis by dividing the magnet into structurally weak subregions, such as ribs and bridges, and evaluating whether demagnetization is likely to occur in each area. The proposed technique offers a fast and practical solution to identify demagnetization-prone regions in the initial design phase of railway IPMSM.

title: a Multimodal Hindi Dataset for Misinformation Detection With Emotional Cues and Sentiments_supp1-3649246.pdf
authors: raghvendra kumar
publish: N/A
abstract: Misinformation poses a growing threat across media ecosystems, yet research on Hindi, one of the world's most widely spoken languages, remains limited. We introduce a novel multimodal Hindi dataset of 6,544 article–image pairs to advance misinformation detection. Unlike existing English-centric and predominantly unimodal datasets, ours integrates text, images, and affective signals while being carefully cleaned of veracity cues to avoid artefact-driven inflation. Each sample is annotated with sentiment and emotions, making this the first Hindi resource with multimodal and affective dimensions. Through extensive experiments using IndicBART, IndicBERT, mBERT, and Vision Transformer models, we demonstrate the effectiveness of text–image fusion and affective features across multiple configurations. We also analyze the readability characteristics of genuine and misleading articles, providing insights into the linguistic patterns of Hindi misinformation. This dataset establishes a robust benchmark for multimodal misinformation detection and lays essential groundwork for research in Hindi and other low-resource languages.

title: A Low-Complexity Codebook-Based Physical Layer Security Framework for Ambient IoT Systems
authors: Riadh Ouzane, Salah Eddine Zegrar, Hüseyin Arslan
publish: IEEE Wireless Communications Letters
abstract: This letter introduces a novel physical-layer security (PLS) mechanism for ultra-low-power ambient IoT (A-IoT) devices. The proposed system leverages on-off keying (OOK) signaling in combination with randomly modulated transmitter-side phases to generate a secure, channel-dependent detection pattern. This modulation technique causes the energy detector output of the A-IoT receiver to be highly sensitive to the unique properties of the wireless channel. Through a training stage, the transmitter learns a one-to-one mapping between transmitted sequences and observed binary outcomes, forming a secure codebook without requiring channel state information (CSI). To handle sparse multipath, random pre-filtering further enlarges the security gap. Analytical derivations and simulations show strong agreement, demonstrating a clear key disagreement rate (KDR) gap between legitimate devices and eavesdroppers under both rich and sparse multipath channels.

title: A New Neural Network PI-Funnel Distributed Control for Cooperative Manipulator With Global Prescribed Performance
authors: Cui-Hua Zhang, Ze-Yun Hu, Yu-Jia Li, Ying Zhang, Chang-Chun Hua
publish: IEEE Transactions on Neural Networks and Learning Systems
abstract: This article addresses the distributed global prescribed-performance control problem for uncertain Lagrangian dynamics, with a particular emphasis on minimizing steady-state error oscillations. A novel global distributed prescribed-performance control framework is proposed based on a dynamic funnel function and neural network design. Specifically, by integrating funnel barrier properties and derivative information, a new neural network learning law is developed. Furthermore, a projection operator is incorporated into the learning law to guarantee the boundedness of the weight estimates in the stability proof, ultimately avoiding potential constraint incompatibility problems caused by neural network integration. The established control framework ensures that the trajectory consensus error of robotic manipulators under distributed control satisfies global arbitrary convergence rates and steady-state error bounds while leveraging neural network approximation to mitigate the inherent uncertainties of controllers that do not require precise mathematical model, thereby effectively suppressing steady-state error oscillations. Unlike existing literature, this work pioneers the incorporation of neural networks into distributed funnel control, achieving global prescribed performance while significantly reducing steady-state error oscillations. Finally, simulation results validate the effectiveness of the proposed method.

title: CFSCNet: A Coarse-Fine Stream Conformer Neural Network for Swallow Segmentation
authors: Yanxia Liu, Chujian Lin, Lian Wang, Xiaozhen Li, Nannan Cui, Zulin Dou
publish: IEEE Journal of Biomedical and Health Informatics
abstract: This study develops an efficient and accurate method for segmenting complex swallowing events in patients with dysphagia. We propose CFSCNet, a novel model that integrates multimodal signals—audio, nasal airflow, and tri-axial accelerometry—to enhance swallowing event segmentation. The model employs a dual-stream architecture to capture swallowing information across varying durations and utilizes an exponential moving average-based cost-sensitive weighting method to address data imbalance. To further improve the stability of predictions for clinical applications, a Swallowing State Machine-Driven Post-Processing Method is introduced to smooth the segmentation sequences. CFSCNet achieves state-of-the-art performance on two benchmark datasets, reaching an AUC of 89.83 on the HRCA dataset and 94.10 on the SMSD dataset, significantly outperforming existing methods. Built on a series of tailored methodological innovations, the proposed framework offers a comprehensive and novel solution for swallowing event segmentation. It demonstrates strong accuracy and reliability, as well as great potential for future extension and clinical translation. This work is expected to advance high-precision detection and diagnosis of dysphagia, thereby supporting more effective swallowing rehabilitation and medical interventions.

title: Securing Swarms: Cross-Domain Adaptation for ROS2-based CPS Anomaly Detection
authors: Julia Boone, Fatemeh Afghah
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: Cyber-physical systems (CPS) are being increasingly utilized for critical applications. CPS combines sensing and computing elements, often having multi-layer designs with networking, computational, and physical interfaces, which provide them with enhanced capabilities for a variety of application scenarios. However, the combination of physical and computational elements also makes CPS more vulnerable to attacks compared to network-only systems, and the resulting impacts of CPS attacks can be substantial. Intelligent intrusion detection systems (IDS) are an effective mechanism by which CPS can be secured, but the majority of current solutions often train and validate on network traffic-only datasets, ignoring the distinct attacks that may occur on other system layers. In order to address this, we develop an adaptable CPS anomaly detection model that can detect attacks within CPS without the need for previously labeled data. To achieve this, we utilize domain adaptation techniques that allow us to transfer known attack knowledge from a network traffic-only environment to a CPS environment. We validate our approach using a state-of-the-art CPS intrusion dataset that combines network, operating system (OS), and Robot Operating System (ROS) data. Through this dataset, we are able to demonstrate the effectiveness of our model across network traffic-only and CPS environments with distinct attack types and its ability to outperform other anomaly detection methods.

title: Design and Implementation of an AI Agent for Natural Language-Driven Database Operations
authors: Aparup Roychowdhury, Anu Shit, Aritra Mukherjee, Subhabrata Banerjee
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: Natural Language Interfaces to Database (NLIDB) plays a significant role in simplifying data access for users by providing access through natural language instead of complex SQL commands. This work presents an intelligent, agent-driven NLIDB system powered by a Large Language Model (LLM) and a ReAct agent architecture. This system generates accurate SQL queries by interpreting user inputs and performs the task by selecting appropriate tools. The defining feature of this work is the incorporation of specialized tools – Read, Write and Commit. The memory module stores previous interactions, which allows the agent to use it as a reference to improve subsequent responses. Multi-step database tasks can be executed easily by the agent by using the available tools iteratively. This ReAct agent separates write and commit actions, which supports iterative SQL execution, dynamic error correction, and safe transactional behaviour. This agent provides reliability by allowing users to review intermediate database changes before committing. Overall, the proposed system is capable of performing complex multi-query operations while maintaining accuracy, safety and transparency.

title: High-Performance Data Prefetching Accelerator for Real-Time Object Detection
authors: Yanzhou Tang, Xiangyu Zhou, Zeyi Lin, Ming Cheng, Naifeng Jing, Jianfei Jiang, Weiguang Sheng, Qin Wang
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Integrated Circuits and Microsystems (ICICM)
abstract: A prefetch-centric accelerator is proposed to efficiently address memory bottlenecks in real-time object detection on edge devices. The architecture integrates a scalable 2-D Matrix Processing Unit (MPU) with configurable Vector Processing Units (VPUs), a pipelined sliding-window prefetch engine, and unified dataflow for multiple operators including convolution, pooling, matrix multiplication, and upsampling. The sliding-window mechanism reduces on-chip register demands and streams kernel-sized vectors each cycle, maintaining high throughput and hiding DRAM latency. Evaluation results demonstrate sustained computational efficiency, achieving a peak throughput of 409.6 GOPS and an energy efficiency of 44.2 GOPS/W when running YOLOv3-tiny, showing competitive performance and energy efficiency compared to existing solutions.

title: Predicting Drug Efficacy with Molecular Embeddings and Graph Context
authors: Kaushik T, Janesh Kumar A, M. Shalini
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: Drug repurposing has emerged as a promising approach to accelerate the discovery of new therapeutic uses for existing drugs, thereby reducing both cost and time compared to traditional drug development. In this work, we present a three-stage framework that integrates feature engineering, baseline machine learning, and heterogeneous graph neural networks (H-GNNs) for drug repurposing. The system constructs a heterogeneous graph consisting of drugs, proteins, and diseases, where edges represent pharmacological and biological interactions. Drug features are derived from SMILES strings using cheminformatics tools, while protein and disease features are extracted from network-based properties. A baseline XGBoost model is trained on these features to establish reference performance. Building on this, a heterogeneous GAT-based encoder and MLP predictor are employed to capture high-order structural relationships within the graph. The framework also incorporates a prediction module that dynamically adds unseen disease nodes and identifies potential candidate drugs. Experimental results on benchmark biomedical datasets demonstrate that our method achieves higher accuracy and interpretability compared to traditional feature-based and shallow models, while also ensuring scalability to large biomedical networks. This highlights the potential of graph-based deep learning in advancing computational drug repurposing.
