title: Enhancing Automated Strawberry Harvesting via MobileNetV2 Binary Classification
authors: Nagendar Yamsani, Shanvi Chauhan, Ritika Badhani, Ashwani Kharola
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: Agricultural supply chain crucially depends on strawberry quality evaluation to achieve maximum production of the yield and also experiences low losses on harvest following the agriculture. The study investigates strawberry sorting as either pickable or unpickable optimization of harvest harvesting because of Sustainable Agriculture production efficiency improvement. The study works with the collection of 521 image collections of strawberry where 418 were used in training, and 103 images were allocated to which a study employed them in validation. The pictures are labeled by performing visual look to investigate whether the strawberry is ready to be harvested or not. Our classification protocol adopted the strategy of MobileNetV2 deep learning framework as its principal task since it is a weightless convolutional neural source of exemplary real-time performance in small equipment untroubled by resource. The optimized network acquired skills in the strawberry maturity recognition characteristics that were able to achieve successful validation output at 86%. Deep learning technologies have promising results on Responsible Consumption and Production and resource optimization along with the resource innovation in Agricultural technology. The improved work can be used with the targets of Zero Hunger without violating the agricultural operators and approach the course of verifying the identifications on fruits with enhanced and efficient fruit recognizing technologies alongside the regulations that balance sustainability aspects with economical ones.

title: Privacy Preserving Semantic Communications Using Vision Language Models: A Segmentation and Generation Approach
authors: Haoran Chang, Mingzhe Chen, Huaxia Wang, Qianqian Zhang
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: Semantic communication has emerged as a promising paradigm for next-generation wireless systems, improving the communication efficiency by transmitting high-level semantic features. However, reliance on unimodal representations can degrade reconstruction under poor channel conditions, and privacy concerns of the semantic information attack also gain increasing attention. In this work, a privacy-preserving semantic communication framework is proposed to protect sensitive content of the image data. Leveraging a vision-language model (VLM), the proposed framework identifies and removes private-content regions from input images prior to transmission. A shared privacy database enables semantic alignment between the transmitter and receiver to ensure consistent identification of sensitive entities. At the receiver, a generative module reconstructs the masked regions using learned semantic priors and conditioned on the received text embedding. Simulation results show that generalizes well to unseen image processing tasks, improves reconstruction quality at the authorized receiver by over 10% using text embedding, and reduces identity leakage to the eavesdropper by more than 50%.

title: A Wideband Blocker-Tolerant Receiver with High Linearity and Low 0 dBm-BNF in 65-nm CMOS
authors: Kaiyun Deng, Yingqi Liu, Qingrui Jiang, Kailin Liu, Shaohui Pan, Haigang Feng
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Integrated Circuits and Microsystems (ICICM)
abstract: This paper presents a blocker-tolerant receiver implemented in a 65 nm CMOS process. The receiver adopts a LNTA-first architecture and leverages an N-path filter with rapid roll-off characteristic to suppress out-of-band (OB) interferer. Additionally, a second-order transimpedance amplifier (TIA) is employed to enhance selectivity on the baseband side. The receiver operates over a frequency range of $0.4-4.5 \mathrm{GHz}$, with a RF bandwidth (RFBW) of $\mathbf{6 0 ~ M H z}$. It achieves a maximum gain of 38.57 dB and a minimum double-sideband (DSB) noise figure (NF) of 3.34 dB. The in-band (IB) third-order input intercept point (IIP3) is $\mathbf{- 8. 2 ~ d B m}$, while the OB IIP3 reaches $\mathbf{1 7. 5 ~ d B m}$ with a frequency offset of $\boldsymbol{\Delta} \boldsymbol{f} \boldsymbol{/} \boldsymbol{B} \boldsymbol{W} \boldsymbol{=} \mathbf{5}$ and the blocker NF (BNF) reaches 8.02 dB under a 0 dBm interferer of at 2 GHz. The total power consumption of the receiver is $\mathbf{4 4. 1 ~ m W}+\mathbf{1. 8 ~ m W} / \mathbf{G H z}$.

title: GNN-Based Predictive Model for Adversarial Cyber Behavior Using the MITRE ATT&CK
authors: Wooyoung Son, Soonhong Kwon, Jong-Hyouk Lee
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: Recently, the significance of Cyber Situational Awareness (CSA) has grown beyond mere defense in cyber military operations. The U.S. Field Manual defines CSA as the timely and accurate understanding of friendly and enemy forces, as well as ongoing activities across the battlefield. In line with this, there is a growing demand for capabilities that can analyze and predict attacker behavior in real time. Reflecting this trend, the focus is shifting from traditional Cyber Threat Intelligence to Predictive Threat Intelligence. However, most existing research has concentrated on analyzing and visualizing past attacks, with limited success in forecasting future threats. To address this gap, we propose a Tactics, Techniques, and Procedures (TTP) prediction mechanism based on Graph Neural Networks (GNNs). Through experimentation with various GNN models, we found that the GraphConv model delivered the best performance. Specifically, GraphConv outperformed the GCN model by 9.51% in Recall and 8.73% in Macro F1-score. These results highlight the potential for preemptively detecting future cyber attacks and lay the groundwork for minimizing security threats.

title: Tampering Attacks on CSI Feedback Reports in 5G New Radio
authors: Santosh Timilsina, Marwan Krunz
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: Despite the security enhancements that 3GPP has added to 5G New Radio (NR), several Physical-layer functions remain vulnerable, including channel state information (CSI) reports. CSI estimation plays a crucial role in scheduling downlink (DL) and uplink (UL) resources. In 5G NR, the base station (gNB) relies on UL CSI reports to optimally allocate resources for DL data transmissions. In this paper, we identify vulnerabilities in CSI reporting that affect communication integrity and confidentiality. We then introduce an attack model where an adversary exploits these vulnerabilities by transmitting a deceptive signal that tampers with the rank indicator (RI) field in the CSI reports. This sophisticated attack bypasses integrity validation and deceives the gNB. We determine the set of subcarriers that the attacker should target to manipulate the 2-bit or 3-bit RI field of a UL CSI report over the air. Using the MATLAB 5G Toolbox, we model the attack and analyze its impact on system performance. Our analysis demonstrates that the attack is effective at signal-to-tampering ratios (STR) of up to 3.69 dB and 5.6 dB for the 2-bit and 3-bit RI fields, respectively. The attack reduces average DL throughput by approximately 50% to 100% for the 2-bit RI case and 35% to 55% for the 3-bit RI case. The impact is most severe when the RI value is maliciously increased, often causing a complete collapse of DL throughput.

title: YOLO based Adaptive Traffic Signals Control System and Real Time Violation Monitoring
authors: Sai Kumar Bandi, Buvanesh Goud B, Muntha Raju, Yashwanth Kumar Chary Vadla, Prudvi Guba, Aditya Lingampally
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: In the face of rapidly developing urban cities, the traditional static traffic signal systems operate on fixed timers, which fall short in adapting to real-time signal management, as some lanes experience high vehicle density while others experience low density. This results in delay in reaching destinations, consuming excessive fuel, which causes pollution and stress-related health issues. This research introduces a real-time integrated adaptive traffic signal control system and signal violation monitoring. The system leverages YOLO (You Only Look Once) object detection for vehicle detection and counts vehicles in each lane to assess traffic density to dynamically adjust signal timings. The system supports emergency vehicle detection, such as ambulance and fire trucks, to prioritize lane traffic signals accordingly. The lane in which emergency vehicle is detected will get an immediate green light. Additionally, time-stamped visual evidence of traffic signal violations is saved in the GUI dashboard for enforcement. Built using Python, OpenCV, ByteTrack, and YOLOv11, this system offers a cost-effective, scalable solution for smart city traffic signals which can result in an 18% increase in traffic flow and 22% reduction in vehicle wait time near signal intersections after deployment.

title: Scalable, Secure Integration of Heterogeneous Healthcare Systems using AI-Enhanced Middleware
authors: Manoj Kota
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: The growing decentralization of the databases of various hospitals and clinics poses enormous obstacles in the centralized treatment of patients and big-data health insights. In this study, an enhanced middleware framework based on AI is suggested in order to integrate heterogeneous healthcare systems securely and maintain privacy in a healthcare setting. The middleware is a smart translator that can support interoperability between incompatible Electronic Health Record (EHR) formats and standards without data, making it centralized. The data harmonization, anomaly detection, and secure data exchange by encryption and access control mechanisms are implemented by advanced machine learning algorithms embedded into the system. The suggested Support Vector Machine (SVM) system can be scaled, and including new healthcare institutions into it can be carried out with minimum setup work. Experimental analysis proves that the framework is effective in providing reduced complexity in integrating data, enhancing consistency and easy data, and efficient time in multi-institutional collaboration work. This would enable healthcare providers to deliver more data-driven care in a more coordinated fashion and allow safe large-scale medical research, which would, in turn, help improve the healthcare delivery process and patient outcomes without breaking data privacy laws.

title: Leveraging AI Agents for Intelligent Web Development Enhancing User Experience through Cloud-based Data Management
authors: Rajashekar Donthi
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: The fusion of AI and cloud computing is changing the game when it comes to web development, as smart and highly tailored digital experiences become the norm. This paper takes a look at how AI agents would strategically be deployed in the U.S. tech ecosystem, which has some of the highest expectations, but also some of the strictest regulations and most intense innovation. Through combining AI with the cloud-based data management, developers can bring to market scalable and responsive web applications that can perform real-time behavior analysis and deliver dynamic content. The proposed framework is tested in real applications in e-commerce and healthcare, and the performance is evaluated for latency, scalability, and user engagement. The paper also raises ethical concerns such as, data privacy and algorithm transparency, and highlights future opportunities including explainable AI and edge computing—to keep the progress of the intelligent web development under the banner of significant and responsible.

title: Improving Leukemia Diagnosis with EfficientNetB0: A Blood Smear Image Classification Study
authors: Nagendar Yamsani, Shanvi Chauhan, Ritika Badhani, Ashwani Kharola
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia (ALL) progresses at a high speed through the blood tissues to primarily affect children and young adults. Early and accurate diagnosis remains essential to enhance patient results while following quality healthcare standards and decreasing mortality numbers. The current diagnostic approach for ALL assessment depends on expert-investigator evaluation of peripheral blood smear (PBS) images through manual microscopic analysis despite experiencing time-intensive and subjectively variable examination methods. Research development focuses on creating an automatic diagnosis system which classifies PBS images into Benign, Pre, Pro, and Early types needed for proper leukemia treatment management. The study adopted the EfficientNetB0 as their deep learning model as it offered a better performance compared to other deep learning models, and evidence based was that it is computationally effective as well. This study two 3,256 annotated PBS images of which 2,604 were to be used as training and 652 to be used as testing. The test accuracy in the model attained success; 94% demonstrating potential of the model in the diagnostics medical tools. Our strategy facilitates realism in terms of good health and well-being gains and catalyzes the invention of digital diagnostics and consolidates so as to encapsulate sustainable medical technologies during industry-academic collaborations. The outcomes of the research point to the fact that the deep learning automation is helpful in early diagnosis of leukemia that would foster better medical care in the entire world and enhance sustainable development in diagnostic science.

title: Embedded C-based Adaptive MPPT Controller with Boost Converter for High-Efficiency Solar-Powered Electric Vehicle Charging Applications
authors: R.Tamilamuthan, T.Sridevi, Murugan P, N.Navaprakash, B.T.Geetha, M.Lakshmanan
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: The increasing penetration of electric vehicles (EVs) has created a pressing demand for efficient, renewable, and intelligent charging systems. Conventional solar charging systems often utilize fixed-step Perturb and Observe (P&O) algorithms, which suffer from slow convergence, oscillations around the maximum power point (MPP), and poor adaptability under fluctuating irradiance conditions. To overcome these limitations, this paper proposes a novel embedded C-based adaptive MPPT controller integrated with a Boost converter for solar-powered EV charging applications. The proposed approach employs a real-time C-coded P&O algorithm capable of dynamically tuning the converter’s duty cycle to extract maximum power from the photovoltaic (PV) array while ensuring stable and ripple-free battery charging. The system was designed and simulated in MATLAB/Simulink, with the embedded code integrated for microcontroller deployment. The PV array delivers a maximum output power of 4379 W, corresponding to a PV voltage of 335.9 V and current of –13.05 A, while maintaining a battery charging voltage of 335.9 V and 90.04% state of charge (SoC). The proposed controller achieved an MPPT efficiency of 97%, converter efficiency of 96%, and reduced the current ripple by 33% with a 31% faster settling time compared to the conventional fixed-step P&O method. These results confirm that the embedded C-coded control strategy provides higher precision, faster dynamic response, and real-time hardware adaptability, offering a scalable and efficient solution for next-generation renewable energy–driven EV charging infrastructures.

title: Machine Learning and Smartphone Data-Assisted BER Prediction in nLOS Mission-Critical Environments
authors: Md Mahfuzur Rahman, Nishith Tripathi, Jeffrey H. Reed, Lingjia Liu
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: In mission-critical military operations, maintaining reliable wireless communication is essential, particularly in non-line-of-sight (nLOS) environments caused by terrain obstructions such as hills, buildings, or mountains. These conditions signif-icantly degrade channel performance and pose challenges to coordination and situational awareness. This work presents a machine learning-based framework to predict bit error rate (BER) in Long Term Evolution (LTE) networks using physical layer measurements collected from commercial off-the-shelf (COTS) smartphone user equipment (UE). The study focuses on nLOS conditions representative of tactical deployment scenarios. We utilize features including channel quality indicator (CQI), signal-to-noise ratio (SNR), modulation and coding scheme (MCS), resource block (RB), and power headroom report (PHR), obtained through controlled LTE experiments conducted in an indoor lab environment and emulating nLOS conditions. Multiple regression models, including Ridge Regression, Support Vector Regression (SVR), and K-Nearest Neighbors (KNN) Regression, are trained and evaluated for BER prediction accuracy. Results show that BER can be effectively inferred from these observable metrics, enabling real-time channel quality assessment without requiring access to full channel state information (CSI). This approach enhances the adaptability and resilience of communication systems in obstructed radio environments using only smartphone UEs.

title: A Low-noise PGA With High-gain Chopper Offset-stabilized Amplifier Combining Ping-Pong Auto-zero For TMR Analog Front-End
authors: Hui Wang, Guifa Yan, Mingqi Pan, Bo Wang, Jianhui Wu, Xin Li
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Integrated Circuits and Microsystems (ICICM)
abstract: This paper presents a low-noise programmable gain amplifier(PGA) for tunneling magnetoresistance(TMR) analog front-end(AFE) applications. A comprehensive system-level analysis is performed for a two-stage PGA architecture followed by a passive-active cascaded LPF. To achieve superior noise performance, a high-gain chopper offset-stabilized amplifier combining Ping-Pong auto-zero scheme is proposed. Furthermore, the sensor’s offset in TMR is calibrated in the second stage through a current-steering DAC. Simulated in a standard $0.18 \mu \mathrm{~m}$ CMOS process, the input-referred noise of the PGA is $55 \mathrm{nV} / \sqrt{\mathrm{Hz}}$. Under the $\mathbf{F F}$ and $\mathbf{8 5}^{\circ} \mathbf{C}$ cornor, the maximum integrated noise within the 300 kHz bandwidth is $19.76 \mu \mathrm{~V}_{\text {rms }}$, the maximum effective resolution is 16.19 bits, the THD is -81 dB, and the power consumption is 2.16 mW.

authors: Tongxu Huang, Jiaxian Sun, Zihao Wu, Yiting Wei, Wenjun Chen
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Integrated Circuits and Microsystems (ICICM)
abstract: The mechanical properties of two-dimensional (2D) transition-metal thiophosphites (TMTs) remains unexplored, restricting their applications in flexible and integrated electronics. Here, we first measure the mechanical properties of 2D MnPS 3 through wrinkle engineering. Uniaxial wrinkles are fabricated in 2D MnPS3 using a pre-strain method, then atomic force microscopy is used to determine the thickness of the flake, the wavelength, and height of the wrinkles. Accordingly, it is found that few-layer MnPS<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</inf> with the thickness of $\sim 6.5 \mathrm{~nm}$ exhibits a Young’s modulus of $\mathbf{4 0. 0} \pm \mathbf{5. 2 ~ G P a}$ and a breaking strength of $\mathbf{7. 0} \pm 1.0 \mathrm{keV}$. In addition, the mechanical properties of 2 D MnPS 3 are layer-dependent. This work enriches the documentation of the physical properties of $2 \mathrm{D} \mathrm{MnPS}_{3}$, offering the basis for the construction of related integrated and flexible electronics.

title: The Effective Resistance Calculation Method Based on Matrix Partitioning Takahashi Algorithm
authors: Meng Li, Yu Chen, Jingrui Chen, Yaokai Zhang, Jinyu Zhang, Xiaolue Lai
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Integrated Circuits and Microsystems (ICICM)
abstract: A matrix-partitioned Takahashi algorithm is proposed to calculate many-to-one effective resistances for a resistance network. Numerical experiments by MATLAB demonstrate a nearly 2.5 X speedup over the original, non-partitioned method under serial execution. This method resolves the inherent parallelization challenges in the traditional Takahashi algorithm. The algorithm delivers substantial gains in computational throughput and parallel scalability without compromising numerical accuracy in effective resistance calculation. Higher speedup is expected in a parallel environment.

title: AI Autonomous Cyber Defence System: An Ensemble Learning Approach for IoT Security
authors: Armaan Sharma, Kuldeep, Ishan Bhardwaj, Nidhi Mishra
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: The exponential growth of Internet of Things (IoT) devices has created unprecedented cybersecurity challenges, rendering traditional security mechanisms inadequate. Traditional Intrusion Detection Systems (IDS) often depend on static, signature-based approaches that fail to recognize emerging zero-day attacks and polymorphic threats. This research presents an Artificial Intelligence (AI)-driven Autonomous Cyber Defence System capable of detecting, classifying, and mitigating network threats in dynamic environments. The system employs an innovative ensemble of dataset-specific Random Forest (RF) classifiers trained on heterogeneous benchmark datasets: CI-CIDS2017, CICIDS2018, and UNSW-NB15. Predictions from these specialized models are aggregated using a majority-voting mechanism, significantly enhancing both detection accuracy and generalization. For fine-grained threat identification, a Decision Tree classifier trained on the IoT-23 dataset performs multi-class attack classification on anomalies flagged by the ensemble. Experiments demonstrate that the ensemble model achieves over 99.9 percentage detection accuracy. Furthermore, the integration of honeypot-generated data from the Cowrie honeypot enriches the system with realistic attack patterns, creating a robust and adaptive defence mechanism against modern cyber threats.

title: Optical Coherence Tomography for Efficient Diagnosis of Ophthalmological Optical Pathway Disease using Machine Learning
authors: A.Chitra, R.Umamageshwari, L.Sharmila, R.Anitha, Suriya B, N.R.Rajalakshmi
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: The development of modern science and technology are more and more reflect the intersection and penetration of multiple disciplines. A new three-dimensional digital image modeling system integrating medical science, biomechanics, mechanics, materials science, computer graphics, mathematical analysis, automatic control and other multidisciplinary fields is currently in rapid development. This has led to great changes in the methods and concepts of modern medical diagnosis and treatment. In recent years, with the development of CT, MRI and other image diagnostic instruments, the application of computer virtual reality technology in medicine has been rapidly developed. Computers use this image information to model three-dimensional data images, providing surgeons with objective, accurate, intuitive, and scientific methods for surgical simulation, surgical navigation, surgical positioning, and surgical planning .At the same time, it also provides objective and accurate reference value for imaging diagnosis and interventional treatment.

title: Scenario-Driven Deduction and Dual-Timescale Optimization Approach for Digital Twin of Hybrid AC/DC Microgrid
authors: Keguang Shen, Jiaming Weng, Dong Liu, Pengfeng Lin
publish: IEEE Transactions on Smart Grid
abstract: Hybrid AC/DC microgrids (MGs) are compatible with legacy AC grids and enable the integration of renewable distributed energy resources (DERs). However, emergencies such as unscheduled islanding expose a mismatch between day-ahead scheduling and sub-second dynamics. A digital-twin (DT) enabled dual-timescale framework is proposed that unifies upper-level optimal power flow (OPF) scheduling and lower-level model predictive control (MPC) via scenario-driven deduction in a bilevel formulation. Validated on an oil-and-gas well-station MG, the strategy issues consistent pre- and post-event process commands and preserves steady-state optimality. Relative to a second-order cone programming (SOCP) based OPF baseline, average AC frequency deviation and DC bus voltage deviation during islanding are reduced by 74.1% and 49.6%, respectively. Against two state-of-the-art methods, the tracking consistency between dispatched commands and measured transients improves by 23.8% and 31%. Computation for transient sequences completes within 6–10 s across scenarios, supporting real-time deduction on commodity hardware.

title: Asymmetric Underlap-Overlap 2T Gain Cell Enabling Voltage-Sensing Readout with Minimized Capacitive Coupling
authors: Jay Sonawane, Sunbin Deng, Chengyang Zhang, Omkar Phadke, Faaiq Waqar, Suman Datta, Shimeng Yu
publish: IEEE Electron Device Letters
abstract: This work introduces an asymmetric structure for a 2-transistor gain cell realized by a write transistor with gate-to-source/drain underlap and an overlapped read transistor. This asymmetric topology enables voltage sensing while substantially minimizing the word line to storage node capacitive coupling. Utilization of an underlapped write transistor reduces the storage node voltage disturbances during word line toggling. The overlapped structure of the read transistor increases the storage node capacitance, thereby improving the sense margin for robust voltage sensing. The concept is experimentally demonstrated using an amorphous oxide semiconductor-based asymmetric 2T gain cell, paving the way for monolithic 3D-integrated last-level cache at the back-end-of-line.

title: Building a Bridge Between Control and Communication via Topologies
authors: Yue Liu, Yang Xiao, Tieshan Li
publish: IEEE Transactions on Cybernetics
abstract: The topology of a communication system is crucial in determining data transmission. Although significant research has been conducted on the integration of control and communication, existing studies on communication for control systems predominantly emphasize control aspects and warrant further exploration. Furthermore, there is a lack of research on the impacts of topology changes on control systems. This article aims to establish a connection between control and communication via communication topology, examining how communication topologies affect controllers. This article also analyzes the relationship between communication and control in depth. For static topologies, specific controller forms are derived from a general controller to illustrate the impacts of static topologies on controllers. In dynamic topologies, communication is nondeterministic, so whether a controller can receive data from other nodes is nondeterministic. Therefore, controller forms in which some coefficients are random variables following a probability distribution are derived. We utilize them to establish a close connection between control and communication. Furthermore, extensive simulations are conducted to investigate the impact of different topologies on the control system.

title: SCAFNet: A Semantic Compensated Adaptive Fusion Network for Remote Sensing Images Change Detection
authors: Yunzuo Zhang, Jiawen Zhen, Shibo Sun, Ting Liu, Lei Huo, Tong Wang
publish: IEEE Geoscience and Remote Sensing Letters
abstract: Current CNN-Transformer hybrid methods for remote sensing change detection aim to address the limitations of CNNs’ constrained receptive fields and Transformers’ local detail insensitivity. However, these methods suffer from semantic misalignment and non-adaptive fusion between the dual branches, resulting in persistent sensitivity to pseudo-changes. To address these issues, we propose SCAFNet, a Semantic Compensated Adaptive Fusion Network, featuring three core components: 1) The Semantic Compensation Module (SCM) that aligns local-global features via cross-attention to resolve spatial-semantic mismatches; 2) The CNN-Transformer Feature Adaptive Fusion (CTFAF) module improving feature integration by dynamically balancing the local details of CNN and the global context of Transformer through cross-branch attention interactions and dynamic parameterization; 3) The Change Feature Identification Module (CFIM) computing channel and spatial weights, enhancing true changes while suppressing disturbances such as seasonal variations. Experiments on CDD and WHU-CD datasets demonstrate SCAFNet’s superior robustness and accuracy, outperforming existing methods through effective feature fusion. The source code and supplementary materials will be made available at https://github.com/Gyroprime/SCAFNet.
