title: An Ultra-low Power 2× / 4× Reconfigurable Charge Pump for RF Energy Harvesting System
authors: Xuanchen Mei, Xin Liu, Junhui Ou, Yanqi Zheng, Mo Huang, Xiuyin Zhang
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Integrated Circuits and Microsystems (ICICM)
abstract: This paper presents a fully integrated ultra-lowpower $2 \times / 4 \times$ reconfigurable charge pump (CP) for RF energy harvesting system to enable switching of the number of operating CP stages at different input levels. The reconfiguration is achieved by an intermediate node voltage detection circuit, which enables timely switching of the switching control signals with fairly low power consumption. Moreover, this CP employs dynamic body bias (DBB) technique to improve driving ability as well as settling time. The output is regulated by a low dropout regulator (LDO) to obtain a ripple-free and stable output voltage without significantly affecting efficiency and power consumption. The design was simulated in a $65-\mathrm{nm}$ low-power CMOS process and the layout occupies an area of $0.25 \mathrm{~mm}^{2}$. This reconfigurable CP can boost a $\mathbf{2 5 0}-\mathbf{m V}$ or $\mathbf{5 0 0}-\mathbf{m V}$ input voltage to $\mathbf{1}-\mathbf{1. 2 ~ V}$ through $\mathbf{2} \boldsymbol{\times} \mathbf{4} \boldsymbol{\times}$ mode switching and further regulate it to an $800-\mathrm{mV}$ stable output, covering both low and high input power range. It also achieves an ultra-low power consumption of 80 nW. Keywords-Reconfigurable charge pump (CP), ultra-low power, CMOS, RF energy harvesting, power management, dynamic body biasing (DBB), low dropout regulator (LDO).

title: An End-to-End Compact Shape-Aware Macro Placer Using Reinforcement Learning
authors: Hailiang Li, Xiao Wang, Xu Yang, Miaohui Hao, Yan Huo, Beiping Yan
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Integrated Circuits and Microsystems (ICICM)
abstract: In modern chip design, the placement of millions of circuit modules poses a significant challenge. However, macro placement can significantly enhance this process by enabling greater modularization of the chip design. In many cases, macros can occupy more than half of the die area, making their placement a critical factor in defining the die’s overall shape. Despite its importance, existing algorithms often either neglect this aspect or fail to address it adequately. This paper presents a novel macro placer that enhances reinforcement learning architectures to produce compact and shape-optimized placements. Our research demonstrates that strategically decoupling standard cells during macro placement can significantly reduce network complexity, enabling an efficient relinking solution. Additionally, we introduce a shape force mask into the reinforcement learning-based visual representation learning framework. The approach proposed in this paper enables the creation of compact and shape-optimized chip designs. Experimental results validate that our algorithm can produce more compact and regular macro placements while consistently maintaining other key performance metrics.

title: A Radiation Tolerant CMOS Voltage Reference Circuit for High Energy Physics Experiments
authors: Wei Ming Yang, Jia Wang, Xiayu Wang, Ran Zheng, Xiaomin Wei, Yongcai Hu
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Integrated Circuits and Microsystems (ICICM)
abstract: The performance of bipolar transistors used in bandgap voltage reference (BGR) can be degraded by strong radiation, which usually appears in high energy physics experiments. This paper presents a radiation tolerant voltage reference circuit based on a commercial standard $\mathbf{1 8 0 n m}$ CMOS process. MOS transistors operating in the sub-threshold region were used to replace the bipolar transistors (BJTs) to improve radiation tolerance. The post-layout simulation results demonstrate that the output voltage of the proposed voltage reference circuit is 391 mV with a temperature coefficient (TC) of $100.538 \mathrm{ppm} /{ }^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$, when the temperature ranges from $-40^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ to $125^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$. The voltage Line Sensitivity (LS) is $0.259 \% / \mathrm{V}$, and the power supply rejection (PSR) is $\mathbf{- 9 0. 1 ~ d B} \text{@} D C$ and $\mathbf{- 3 7 ~ d B} \text{@} 1$ MHz. The power consumption is $44.9 \mu \mathrm{~W}$ at $27^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$, with a die area of $0.0072 \mathrm{~mm}^{2}$.

title: An Efficient Scene Identification Approach to Enhance the Performance of Autonomous Driving Systems using Deep Learning Principle
authors: Arul Prasath A, Navaz K
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: the quest to achieve more precise and effective neural networks in resource-limited systems has turned out to be a significant research effort in order to scale the application of neural networks to robotics and autonomous automobiles as well as smart assistance. The research themes one of them is optimization of machine learning models and learning parameters. In this research, we learned a technique of optimizing hyperparameters in an adaptive learning system to identify and recognize scenes. Our proposed Deep Regression Attention Branch Network (Deep-RABN) model constructed using a procedure that chooses the most suitable learning hyperparameters through our Proposed Model-based Hyperparameter Optimization (P-MHO). With this infrastructure, evaluation was done on a former CNN model using data gathered through the effective operation of advanced driver assistance systems (A-DAS) equipment. The experiments indicate that the proposed Deep-RABN model can enhance the effectiveness of end-to-end self-driving systems and resulting in an overall testing accuracy of 99.38% and a loss value of 0.68%. Experimental outcomes indicate that our suggested model outperforms conventional methods.

title: Establishing MQTT Covert Channels Through Public Brokers
authors: Erkin Kirdan, Karl Waedt
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: This paper explores the use of the MQTT protocol for covert channel communication, focusing on both storage-based and timing-based methods. While such channels have been previously studied, our work distinguishes itself by demonstrating their practical feasibility using publicly accessible MQTT brokers as intermediaries. In our setup, endpoints communicate covertly through these public brokers without requiring any modification or influence over the broker itself. This approach enables covert data exfiltration or unauthorized command injection between clients while blending into legitimate MQTT traffic. We validated our implementation using six available public brokers and achieved reliable covert communication through both storage and timing channels. The use of public brokers introduces several critical implications: endpoints can bypass network-level filtering or firewall restrictions, evade detection by security monitoring systems due to the use of legitimate and commonly trusted infrastructure, and potentially scale covert operations across multiple distributed receivers. These findings underline the security risks inherent in permissively configured or widely trusted MQTT infrastructure, and they highlight the need for more strict broker policies and network-level anomaly detection to mitigate covert misuse.

title: Advanced Multi-Source Energy Management with Adaptive Fuzzy-PI Control for Enhanced V2G/G2V Smart Grid Integration
authors: Lavenya D, Thamizharasan R, S.Karthick, Leena Rose R, Carmel Mary Belinda M J, S. Gomathi
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: This study compares the Fuzzy Logic Controllers (FLC) with the traditional PI controllers with the hybrid renewable energy system plus Vehicle-to-Grid (V2G) and Grid-to-Vehicle (G2V) technologies. The model is based on multi-input system that includes photovoltaic (PV) panels, wind power, and electric vehicle battery storage with SEPIC and buck-boost topologies. The analysis of the critical time-domain parameters such as rise time (Tr), peak time (Tp), settling time (Ts), and steady-state error (Ess) of both the voltage and current responses are analysed. It has been experimentally shown that FLC based control systems have much better transient performance with a 87 percent reduction in rise time (0.07s vs 0.53s), 85 percent reduction in peak time (0.09s vs 0.62s) and 91 percent reduction in settling time (0.10s vs 1.13s) than PI controllers. The steady-state error was decreasing 89 percent (0.15V vs 1.38 V) in voltage regulation. Using the current control characteristics, similar performance improvements were also found, which makes FLC a more effective control strategy in complex multi-source energy management systems used in modern smart grids. Such innovations as real-time controller adaptation depending on the size of errors, ML-based energy demand prediction with 92.3 percent accuracy, and advanced battery management with state-of-charge awareness are the key ones. It focuses on improving energy efficiency while fostering innovation in sustainable energy technologies. End-to-end simulation outcomes show that there are great improvements in performance and can be highly applicable in the contemporary smart grid infrastructure that needs strong, efficient, and adaptive energy management features.

title: Expanding the Direction Finding Field of View of Sparse Digital Arrays
authors: Nolan Egging, Payam Nayeri, Randy Haupt
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: Electrically large arrays offer high resolution, however since cost is proportional to the number of elements, large dense arrays have a high cost. Sparse arrays on the other hand offer a cost-effective solution with less number of elements, but the problem is that with large element spacing, grating lobes, or equivalently aliasing, appears in the radiation pattern of analog sparse arrays. In this work, we show that in digital sparse arrays, this results in false detection of targets in direction finding applications. As a solution to this problem, we propose sparse digital arrays where the element locations are determined by shifted low discrepancy sequences. We present numerical results and show that the field of view of sparse digital arrays can be extended significantly by using our proposed approach.

title: Design of Power Amplifier for Short Message Application of BDS-III Communication Terminal
authors: Zhenbing Li, Weijun Li, Haoyang Sun, Jiaxin Li u, Jialong Fu, Yaocheng Shang
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Integrated Circuits and Microsystems (ICICM)
abstract: For the application requirements of the short message function of handheld Beidou satellite communication terminal, this paper proposes an L-band power amplifier chip with high gain, high efficiency and high integration, which is designed based on InGaP/GaAs HBT and LGA PCB packaging process, and a multi-physics collaborative simulation and optimization platform suitable for the design of similar RF power amplifier chips. The simulation results show that under 3.5 V supply voltage, the linear gain of the chip can reach $38.7 \mathrm{~dB}, \mathrm{P}_{1 \mathrm{~dB}}$ can reach 35.1 dBm, PAE can reach 48.2%, the second, third and fifth harmonic suppression ratio is better than -65 dBc, and the chip size is only $4 \mathrm{~mm} \times 6 \mathrm{~mm} \times 1 \mathrm{~mm}$. This design has obvious advantages over the same type of designs, and can meet the short message function of the hand-held Beidou satellite navigation communication terminal in a variety of application scenarios.

title: Anomaly Detection in Containerized Tactical Systems Using Temporal Graph Neural Networks
authors: Soonhong Kwon, Wooyoung Son, Jong-Hyouk Lee
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: On October 23, 2024, the U.S. Department of Defense announced the adoption of DevSecOps v2.5, transitioning to an agile, Kubernetes-based containerized ecosystem. However, existing anomaly detection systems for containers often rely on unrealistic datasets or static models, failing to capture temporal characteristics. To address this, we propose a lightweight, temporally-aware container anomaly detection system based on the Temporal Graph Attention Network (TGAT), validated on a realistic dataset collected from an actual container environment. Experimental results demonstrate our TGAT model achieves significantly higher accuracy than baseline models: outperforming GIN by 2.96% in system anomaly detection and GraphSAGE by 19.79% in network anomaly detection. Compared to a variant without temporal encoding (TGAT w/o), our model also shows improvements of 1.18% and 34.04%, respectively. These findings underline the critical role of temporal information in securing containerized tactical systems.

title: Advances in Detecting Deepfake Threats, Methods and Societal Implications
authors: Navya Damodar, Asha S Manek
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: Deepfake is an Artificial Intelligence Technology through which fake videos, images, audios and texts are generated using Generative Adversarial Network (GAN). Deepfakes use AI to manipulate content, making it appear real. Since Deepfake Technology is updating rapidly, it has become very difficult to identify such fake content. Different methods have been discovered to detect such contents. This paper projects the recent advances and ethical challenges in detecting manipulated content. This paper presents a comprehensive review of recent advances in deepfake detection methods, alongside an analysis of their broader societal implications. The study examines state-of-the-art detection approaches, including convolutional neural networks (CNNs), recurrent and transformer-based architectures, multimodal fusion techniques, and frequency-domain and physiological signal–based analyses. Emphasis is placed on the evolution of detection systems from handcrafted feature extraction to end-to-end learning frameworks capable of identifying subtle spatial–temporal inconsistencies and cross-modal discrepancies. Additionally, the paper highlights emerging challenges such as adversarial attacks, dataset bias, generalization across unseen manipulation techniques, and real-time detection constraints. Beyond technical considerations, this work explores the societal impact of deepfakes, including their role in misinformation campaigns, political manipulation, financial fraud, and erosion of public trust in digital media. Legal, ethical, and policy-related responses are discussed, with attention to regulatory frameworks, digital watermarking, and public awareness initiatives aimed at mitigating misuse. By bridging technical advancements with societal perspectives, this paper underscores the necessity of interdisciplinary collaboration among researchers, policymakers, and industry stakeholders.

title: Wireless IoT System for Transformer Fault Diagnosis and Grid Line Monitoring
authors: Radhakrishna K.R., Kiran Chand Ravi, MD Ayub Khan, Swetha Kannepally, K.P.Boopathiraja, Jarabala Ranga
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: The rapid increase in transformer failures and grid instability has underscored the need for intelligent, real-time monitoring systems. In this work, a wireless IoT-based system of fault diagnosis and grid line monitoring is introduced based on NB-IoT communication, edge-computing with the STM32 platform, and grid-wide analytics on the cloud. Devices like temperature, dissolved gas, vibration, current and line sag sensors are placed on transformers, distribution lines to detect early fault indicators. Kalman filtering and threshold-triggered logic reduce communication overhead by preprocessing edges prior to securely delivering data to AWS IoT through MQTT/TLS. An automated fault detection and predictive maintenance is performed using a hybrid CNN-LSTM model. In vivo testing of ten transformer units and ten grid line nodes show performance. The system had 95.2 % fault prediction, 96 % packet delivery and 220 ms average communication latency. Overheating and insulation degradation in T4, T7 and T9 were correctly detected on the basis of dissolved gas analysis and temperature monitoring. L3, L4, L7 and L9 grid overload conditions were identified with 93% accuracy. The secure cloud interface provides real-time visualization and alerts, as well as role-based access to utility operators and maintenance teams. In general, the presented system positively improves reliability, situational awareness, and diagnostic speed in power distribution networks. It combines edge intelligence, NB-IoT connectivity, and AI-based analytics to reduce or eliminate unplanned outages, decrease maintenance costs, and allow condition-based monitoring. The findings show that the solution can be used in smart grid modernization programs and be flexible to new AI-based energy management systems.

title: Design of a Multi-Dimensional and Multi-Precision Tensor Computation Unit Based on FPGA
authors: Yupeng Fang
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Integrated Circuits and Microsystems (ICICM)
abstract: As deep learning models expand in scale, TPUs (Tensor Processing Units) offer enhanced efficiency and accelerated computing capability. The multi-dimensional, multiprecision tensor computing units are engineered to process largescale matrices and operations across various data precisions, fulfilling the computational demands of diverse scenarios. Furthermore, they provide mixed-precision (fp16 and fp32) computing, diminishing memory consumption while preserving data accuracy. The tensor computing unit’s design incorporates block matrices and systolic arrays, enhancing the efficiency of matrix operations and minimizing computational waste. The multipliers for various data precisions employ the Redix-4 Booth algorithm in conjunction with a novel Wallace tree compression architecture, whereas the addition operations utilize a Carry-Lookahead adder chain structure, facilitating resource reutilization across different data precisions and further reducing resource consumption. Experiments indicate that the multi-dimensional and multi-precision tensor computing unit utilizing FPGA attains average accuracy rates of $100 \%, 100 \%$, $98.7 \%, 99.74 \%$, and 98.05% for INT4, INT8, FP16, FP32, and FP16_FP32 data operations, respectively, with a clock frequency of 250 MHz and an energy efficiency of $7.65 \mathrm{GFLOPS}{ }^{*} \mathrm{~W}^{-1}$. This demonstrates exceptional accuracy, rapid calculation, and superior efficiency in executing large-scale, multi-precision matrix operations, significantly enhancing the computational efficacy of deep learning.

title: Neural Network-Based Method for Magnetic Field Inversion of Energized Conductors in Printed Circuit Boards
authors: Qi Li, Yiling Liang, Zhen Liu, Lulu Tian
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Integrated Circuits and Microsystems (ICICM)
abstract: This paper presents an innovative methodology for three-dimensional magnetic field reconstruction of electronic circuits on printed circuit boards. By integrating multiple neural network architectures with associated optimization algorithms, the proposed approach substantially enhances the magnetic field prediction accuracy compared to conventional physics-based reconstruction methods. The core principle of the proposed methodology lies in leveraging neural networks to precisely fit the dipole moments generated by electronic circuits on the PCB, subsequently constructing an equivalent dipole model based on the fitted results to substitute for the actual magnetic field sources produced by the operational PCB circuitry. Through rigorous simulation validation, the neural network-based threedimensional magnetic field reconstruction method for PCBs proposed in this study achieves prediction errors constrained within 5%, with magnetic field accuracy reaching the nanotesla scale. These results comprehensively demonstrate the superior performance of the proposed approach in PCB spatial magnetic field visualization, thereby establishing a robust foundation for addressing practical engineering challenges such as fault diagnosis and defect localization in subsequent applications.

title: Enhanced Edge Computing for Digital Twin Applications in Energy-Intensive Industrial Systems
authors: M. Rajesh, R. Sitharthan
publish: IEEE Power Electronics Magazine
abstract: This article presents an integrated framework combining 5G-enhanced edge computing with digital twin technology for energy-intensive industrial systems. The proposed approach utilizes 5G’s ultra-low latency, high reliability, and massive connectivity alongside intelligent edge computing to enable real-time, adaptive, and predictive control independent of centralized infrastructures. Advanced federated learning models are deployed at the edge to support decentralized analytics while preserving data privacy. To further enhance sustainability, AI-driven optimization algorithms dynamically manage production and energy consumption, reducing carbon emissions. Blockchain-based authentication ensures secure and immutable communication between digital and physical assets. Experimental analysis demonstrates significant improvements in energy efficiency, system resilience, and decision-making accuracy, advancing the realization of intelligent, sustainable, and autonomous industrial ecosystems.

title: HybridSYN: An Efficient Logic Synthesis Methodology
authors: Ke Wang, Yue Wu, Xiaoyan Yang
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Integrated Circuits and Microsystems (ICICM)
abstract: As the complexity of modern circuits increases, logic synthesis faces growing challenges. Reinforcement learning (RL) shows promise for efficient logic optimization. However, current RL methods rely solely on a single Boolean circuit represen-tation-typically And-Inverter Graphs (AIG). This constraint hinders the exploration of larger optimization spaces, leading to suboptimal outcomes. This study introduces HybridSYN, a hybrid RL framework combining optimization algorithms from AIG and Majority-Inverter Graphs (MIG) to address the limitations of synthesis methods relying on a single logic graph representation. By expanding the action space, HybridSYN enables the exploration of better LUT-level solutions. To improve state representation, HybridSYN processes topological features from both AIG and MIG using independent Graph Convolutional Network (GCN) encoders. The resulting features are fused and passed through a fully connected network, where the final layer jointly predicts the type of operator and its parameters. Experimental results on the EPFL benchmark suite show that HybridSYN achieves a 9.7% reduction in LUT count compared to existing RL methods and a $\mathbf{1 7. 1 \%}$ improvement over baseline approaches.

title: TRACER, the Next Generation Ultra-wideband Spectrum Processor
authors: Matthew French, John Paul Walters, Kenneth Zick, Andrew Rittenbach, Connor Imes, Dong-In Kang, Andrew Schmidt, Ali Rasteh, Sundeep Rangan, Brandon Reagan, Mark McHenry, Ihsan Akbar
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: This paper introduces TRACER, the Tasklet Reconfigurable Agile Spectrum Processor, which promotes RF waveform timescale switching (<100ns) as a first-class design principle along with processing throughput, in order to address dynamic processing of very wideband (0-40GHz) spectrum sensing applications. The architecture is a novel hybrid multi-core, Coarse Grained Reconfigurable Array (CGRA), which enables a balance of fast reconfiguration and flexibility with high performance processing of common RF application kernels. TRACER provides 3 ultra-fast, reactive Lightning switching mechanisms that can switch tasklets in 5-42 ns, and slower, deliberative Thunder switches that operate at up to 12,500ns. A 5x4 array instantiation can achieve 7.86 TFLOP/s on half precision floating point in 42.3 mm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> TSMC12, utilizing 6W. TRACER’s switching capabilities provide high value where the RF signal environment is not well known a priori, showing up to a 293x throughput gain in spectrum sensing applications over a static implementation.

title: A 10-bit 3-GS/s Single-Channel Pipelined ADC with Parallel Time-Domain Quantization Based on Dynamic Residue Amplifier
authors: Depan Li, Xin Zhao, Dengquan Li, Zhangming Zhu
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Integrated Circuits and Microsystems (ICICM)
abstract: This paper presents a single-channel 10-bit pipelined analog-to-digital converter (ADC) with parallel time-domain (TD) quantization running at $3 \mathrm{GS} / \mathrm{s}$. By sharing the discharge current of a dynamic residue amplifier (D-RA), parallel voltage amplification and voltage-to-time (V-T) conversion are realized. Simultaneously, the generated time signal is quantized by a time-to-digital converter (TDC). The parallel execution of amplification and quantization relaxes the timing constraints on the residue amplifier. In addition, a dynamic flipped voltage follower (DFVF)-based residue transfer scheme is employed, which is activated during the settling phase of the capacitor array and deactivated afterward, minimizing timing overhead. The ADC is simulated with a $28-\mathrm{nm}$ CMOS process and $1-\mathrm{V}$ supply voltage, it achieves a $\mathbf{5 6. 9 - d B}$ signal-to-noise and distortion ratio (SNDR) and a $69.2-\mathrm{dB}$ spurious-free dynamic range (SFDR) at Nyquist input frequency leading to a $\mathbf{1 5. 0 - f J}$ /conversion-step Walden figure-of-meriti.

title: WHIRLS: Wideband High-Resolution Labeling of Signals for Spectrum Sensing Applications
authors: Tianyi Zhao, Benjamin W. Domae, Connor Steigerwald, Luke B. Paradis, Tim Chabuk, Danijela Cabric
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: Wideband spectrum sensing and awareness is important to ensure wireless security. Specifically, accurate detection and labeling of active transmissions is necessary for further analysis and classification. In this work, we propose WHIRLS, a digital signal processing method for detecting and labeling RF signals in a wideband spectrum. WHIRLS is able to generate accurate labels with independent time and frequency resolutions, making it flexible in various RF environments. We demonstrate the effectiveness and consistency of WHIRLS in both synthetic and over-the-air dataset and make the code public for future research.

title: A Modular Approach to Adaptive Manufacturing: The AGILEHAND Architecture
authors: Mansoor Ahmed, Ruben Costa, Rui Branco, Jorge Calado, José Ferreira, Filippo Ciarapica, Francisco Fraile, Mohamed Lamine Mekhalfi
publish: IEEE/CAA Journal of Automatica Sinica
abstract: Dear Editor, This letter presents a comprehensive overview of the AGILEHAND project's technical architecture and its role in developing innovative solutions for the grading, handling, and packaging of soft, deformable products within agile and reconfigurable manufacturing lines. The letter focuses on the architectural blueprint of AGILEHAND, detailing its functional and technical specifications. It also describes the integration process of solutions, highlighting the methods used to ensure seamless interoperability and data flow across different systems. Furthermore, the letter demonstrates the application of AGILEHAND solutions through two specific scenarios, showcasing their effectiveness and adaptability. This comprehensive overview underscores the significance of the AGILEHAND architecture in enhancing manufacturing efficiency and flexibility.

title: Extending Communication Range with 5G NR Multi-Hop UE-to-UE Relays
authors: Samantha Gamboa, Thomas R. Henderson, Wesley Garey, Chunmei Liu, Richard Rouil
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: This paper describes how fifth-generation (5G) New Radio (NR) sidelink (SL) multi-hop UE-to-UE (U2U) relays can extend communication range in off-network scenarios, where UE denotes User Equipment. We focus on key challenges introduced by SL’s distributed resource allocation (Mode 2) in multi-hop topologies, particularly when semi-persistent scheduling (SPS) is used. We use system-level simulations to evaluate a tactical scenario with mission-critical push-to-talk (MCPTT) traffic over a multi-hop U2U topology. Our results show how compounded intra-path interference and losses due to half-duplex operation can degrade end-to-end communication performance. We further identify specific scheduling configuration settings that influence these effects and impact the attainable communication range.

title: Automated Recognition of Wheat Leaf Diseases through Fine-Tuned VGG16 in Smart Agriculture
authors: Srinivas Aluvala, Goldy Verma, Sonali Gupta, Vartika Aarwal
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: Wheat is an important crop worldwide, but foliar diseases like Brown Rust, Loose Smut, Septoria and Yellow Rust heavily affect the yield of this crop. Conventional ways of detecting diseases are based on manual observation, which can be quite laborious, prone to error, and inapplicable to large scale farming. To overcome this issue, this paper presents a fine-tuned VGG16 network to classify wheat leaf disease automatically. This dataset was obtained on the open-source Kaggle platform and includes 5,597 images which are divided into 5 classes: Brown Rust, Healthy, Loose Smut, Septoria, and Yellow Rust. Transfer learning was then used to fine-tune the VGG16 model with ImageNet weights and further classifier layers were incorporated to improve the classification efficiency. The model was tested on an experimental basis with results showing an overall accuracy of 96% in the correct classification of visually similar classes of disease. The suggested solution emphasizes the possibilities of deep learning in monitoring and detecting diseases in real-time, scaled, and reliable to aid farmers in managing crops sustainably and promote precision agriculture.

title: Computational Discourse Analysis of Media Representations of Immigrant Women: A Comparative Study of Human Journalists and DeepSeek
authors: Jingxia Wang, Lingshuai Kong
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conferences on Internet of Things (iThings) IEEE Green Computing &amp; Communications (GreenCom) IEEE Cyber, Physical &amp; Social Computing (CPSCom) and IEEE Smart Data (SmartData) and IEEE Congress on Cybermatics (Cybermatics)
abstract: The present study combines Critical Discourse Analysis and Computational Linguistics to compare the representations of immigrant women in human-written news versus DeepSeek-generated ones. A parallel corpus of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1 2 0}$</tex> news articles (60 human-written and 60 AI-generated) was created, and lexical patterns were examined using lexical clustering keyword analysis. Subsequently, the present study employed social actor framework to investigate the representation of immigrant women. Findings reveal that human journalists predominantly frame immigrant women through personal narratives and social integration themes, emphasizing individual lived experiences and emotional dimensions, whereas AI texts focus on policy analysis and institutional critique while to some degree lacking contextual depth and humanistic concern. Further, though both text types construct immigrant women as passive victims, AI texts amplify this through highfrequency terms like “violence” and “detained”. Regarding identity representation, human news uses multiple labels (e.g., geography, ethnicity, economic status) to intersect the composite identities of immigrant women, whereas AI texts rely on the abstract “immigrant” label, showing significant “decontextualization” characteristics. The study demonstrates that large language models (LLMs) are yet capable of addressing societal issues like immigration, probably due to limitations in training data and safety mechanisms. We argue for a safe and equitable treatment of minoritized communities in LLM design and training.

title: Dynamic Feature Analysis using Deep Learning with Mean Baikal Loss Function for Malware Detection in Android Devices
authors: Peddaaswarthu Ramesh, B.V. Krishna
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: The fast growth of Android devices and applications has turned the platform into an appealing target for cybercriminals, leading to a tremendous increase in Android malware. Given that traditional signature-based detection techniques can no longer keep pace with rapidly evolving threats, advanced detection techniques based on Deep Learning (DL) have emerged as effective alternatives. Hence, an effective technique named Deep Residual Network with Mean Baikal loss (DRN-MB) is developed for malware detection in Android devices. At first, the Android device model is considered, and the feature extraction process is executed based on the statically extracted information, dynamically observed behaviors, and PCAP of the network traffic. Next, feature selection is performed by using a Random Forest classifier. The selected features are further subjected to the malware detection process. Here, malware detection is done by the novel DRN-MB, which is developed by modifying the loss function of the Deep Residual Network (DRN) using the Mean Baikal (MB) loss. The MB-loss function is devised by integrating the Mean Absolute Error (MAE) with the Baikal loss. Moreover, the DRN-MB method achieved an accuracy of 96.588%, a recall of 97.279%, and a precision of 96.357% by utilizing the Android malware dataset with the k-value 8.

title: A 2.4-2.6 GHz CMOS High Linearity Power Amplifier with MGTR and Harmonic Trap Techniques
authors: Runxun Zhang, Gengzhen Qi
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Integrated Circuits and Microsystems (ICICM)
abstract: This paper presents the design of a linear RF power amplifier (PA) operating from 2.4 to 2.6 GHz using 65 nm CMOS technology. To address the challenge of poor linearity in CMOS PAs, Multi-Gated Transistor (MGTR) technology and second-harmonic trap circuits are introduced to suppress third-order intermodulation and harmonic distortion. Post-layout simulations demonstrate a saturated output power of 30.32 dBm, OP1dB of 28.48 dBm, OIP3 of 38.58 dBm, and power-added efficiency (PAE) of 43.21% (Peak) / 23.41% (6 dB PBO), achieving a good balance of linearity, efficiency, and integration.

title: SAJD: Self-Adaptive Jamming Attack Detection in AI/ML Integrated 5G O-RAN Networks
authors: Md Habibur Rahman, Md Sharif Hossen, Nathan H. Stephenson, Vijay K. Shah, Aloizio Da Silva
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: The open radio access network (O-RAN) enables modular, intelligent, and programmable 5G network architectures through the adoption of software-defined networking (SDN), network function virtualization (NFV), and implementation of standardized open interfaces. It also facilitates closed-loop control and (non/near) real-time optimization of radio access network (RAN) through the integration of non-real-time applications (rApps) and near-real-time applications (xApps). However, one of the security concerns for O-RAN that can severely undermine network performance and subject it to a prominent threat to the security & reliability of O-RAN networks is jamming attacks. To address this, we introduce SAJD – a self-adaptive jammer detection framework that autonomously detects jamming attacks in artificial intelligence (AI) / machine learning (ML)-integrated O-RAN environments. The SAJD framework forms a closed-loop system that includes near-real-time inference of radio signal jamming interference via our developed ML-based xApp, as well as continuous monitoring and retraining pipelines through rApps. Specifically, a labeler rApp is developed that uses live telemetry (i.e., KPIs) to detect model drift, triggers unsupervised data labeling, executes model training/retraining using the integrated & open-source ClearML framework, and updates deployed models on the fly, without service disruption. Experiments on O-RAN-compliant testbed demonstrate that the SAJD framework outperforms state-of-the-art (offline-trained with manual labels) jamming detection approach in accuracy and adaptability under various dynamic and previously unseen interference scenarios.

title: Real-Time Fingerprint-based Access Control System for Examination Security
authors: Amrita Jakaraddi, Chandan G Y, Charith B R, Chinmayi C, Jyothi S K
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: Fingerprint authentication is employed to automate exam hall entry verification, enhancing security and operational efficiency by eliminating manual hall-ticket inspection. By Integrating a Fingerprint sensor with a microcontroller, the proposed model ensures that only authorized students gain access, reducing errors and impersonation risks. The system stores fingerprint data in a database and matches it in real time during Verification. Experimental results demonstrate high accuracy and speed, making it suitable for large-scale academic environments. This innovation enhances examination security and simplifies administrative procedures. In many educational institutions, manual hall ticket checking during examinations is time-consuming and vulnerable to mistakes or impersonation. This paper presents a smart exam hall authentication system designed to address these issues using fingerprint-based verification. The system combines a fingerprint sensor, microcontroller, and real-time database matching to confirm student identity before permitting entry. When a student scans their finger, the system quickly retrieves and verifies their biometric record, ensuring seamless and secure access. The proposed system highlights the system’s efficiency, accuracy, and suitability for large academic settings. By reducing human intervention and enhancing reliability, this approach modernizes the exam admission process and contributes to a more secure examination environment.

title: A Comparative Analysis of Different Comparators for Analog-to-Digital Convertor Applications: A Review
authors: Dasamandam Venkata Supriya, Saleem Syed, E. Kalyana Pallavi, A. Sahithi, Yadiki Ankitha, Thogata Bharath Kumar
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: In this study, we look at two technologies Carbon Nano Tube Field Effect Transistors (CNTFETs) and CMOS-based dynamic comparators. Six CNTFET-based comparator architectures two-stage, push-pull, and double dynamic comparators are implemented by using hspice tool in 32nm technology, and using the cadence vistuso tool in 180nm technology, a CMOS-based dynamic comparator is created and simulated 500 MHz. Important performance matrix is evaluated, including area, average power and latency. The result reveals the CNTFET-based comparators achieve up to three times reduced power consumption, higher speed, and increased robustness under temperature and supply variations. In comparison, the CMOS two-stage device uses 32% less power and work 20% faster than typical CMOS designs make considerable advances, CNTFET-based circuits are more efficient and scalable, making them viable options for next-generation low-power, high-speed ADCs.

title: Post-Routing Compression Algorithm for Area-Efficient Layout design of Analog Integrated Circuit
authors: Xiaoyue Wu, Yubo Zhang, Wei Zhang, Bijian Lan, Jing Wan
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Integrated Circuits and Microsystems (ICICM)
abstract: Routing is a crucial part of analog integrated circuit design. For inter-block routing in analog circuit layouts, existing routing algorithms fail to achieve full connectivity across all scenarios while minimizing track usage, ultimately leading to wasted chip area and increased production costs. This paper proposes a post-routing optimization algorithm for inter-block routing regions in analog circuit layouts. The post-routing optimization algorithm enhances track utilization by reusing tracks in channel routing regions and applying single-layer rerouting in single-sided pin regions, reducing amount of track. In channel routing regions without wire-ordering constraints, track usage, area occupation, and wire length are reduced by $23.37 \%, 25.05 \%$, and 17.83%, respectively. For single-sided pin regions, these parameters are reduced by with $49 \%, 49.34 \%$ and 4.77%. The algorithm is further extended to address specific global layout optimization. Through the integration of intraregion optimization and wire-ordering constraints, 8 tracks are reduced with an area saving of $377.66 \mu \mathrm{~m}^{2}$. The research provides a practical solution for area-efficient analog integrated circuit design with significant cost-reduction implications.

title: Improving Wheat Leaf Disease Detection and Classification with Deep Learning Approach: A Study and Comparison
authors: Sivakumar R
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: Wheat, a global staple food crops, is very vulnerable to numerous foliar illnesses that substantially decrease output and harvest quality. Prompt and exact identification of these illnesses is important for enhancing productivity and safeguarding food security. This work targets to enhance the detection and categorization of wheat leaf disorders by advanced deep learning (DL) methods, integrating several convolutional neural network (CNN) architectures to get enhanced performance and interpretability. A thorough dataset gathered from both field and controlled contexts was preprocessed. Multiple advanced models, including VGG16, VGG19, InceptionV3, Xception, and MobileNet, were trained and assessed comparatively based on performance criteria like accuracy, precision, recall, and F1-score. The findings indicated that MobileNet attained a classification accuracy of up to 98%, surpassing previous models. This research underscores the potential of DL algorithms for enhancing precision agriculture and sustainable wheat production.

title: CNBI-Scale: A Cloud-Native Business Intelligence Framework Leveraging Serverless Analytics and Adaptive Data Pipelines for Scalable, Real-Time Decision-Making
authors: Geetha Manoharan, Amruta Ramdas Sane, R.Krishnamoorthy, D. Baburao, Lalitha Palthiya, N. Vishnu Devi
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: The increasing complexity and volume of data across multi-cloud environments demand scalable and efficient business intelligence (BI) solutions that provide real-time decision-making capabilities. This paper presents a novel cloud-native BI framework that integrates federated query processing, reinforcement learning-based adaptive data pipeline orchestration, and serverless GPU-accelerated analytics to address scalability, latency, and cost challenges inherent in modern data ecosystems. The framework executes analytics directly on distributed datasets across Azure and Google Cloud Platform, eliminating data migration overhead and preserving data locality. An RL-driven orchestrator dynamically optimizes ETL/ELT workflows for variable workloads, while serverless GPU instances accelerate complex predictive analytics tasks. Columnar storage combined with semantic vector indexing further enhances real-time query performance. Additionally, the framework incorporates event-driven CQRS architecture for low-latency dashboard updates, streaming feature stores for inline AI insights, and differential privacy mechanisms to ensure compliance without compromising data utility. Extensive experiments demonstrate that federated query processing reduces average latency by 52%, while RL-based orchestration improves throughput by 7 queries per second and cuts latency by 35%. GPU acceleration halves query execution time for compute-intensive workloads. Semantic indexing reduces retrieval time by over 50%, and differential privacy preserves compliance with minimal accuracy loss (<0.4%). Overall, the framework achieves over 99.4% accuracy in analytics results across all modules, proving its effectiveness in enabling scalable, secure, and cost-efficient real-time BI across multi-cloud platforms.

title: A Novel LDPP-MADDPG Approach for Distributed Power Allocation in mmWave Cellular Networks
authors: Xin Yao, Arupjyoti Bhuyan, Xiang Zhang, Mingyue Ji
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: This paper considers the problem of distributed beam scheduling and power allocation in millimeter-Wave (mmWave) cellular networks, where multiple Base Stations (BSs) operate as independent operators over a shared spectrum. We propose a novel learning-aided approach that integrates the Lyapunov Drift-Plus-Penalty (LDPP) framework and Multi-agent Deep Deterministic Policy Gradient (MADDPG) reinforcement learning algorithms. This offers a powerful approach to learning stable and constraint-aware policies, reaping the joint benefits of both LDPP and MADDPG in complex multi-agent environments. The main challenge lies in integrating these two approaches effectively. The key idea to solve this problem is to introduce a novel feature of local observation that incorporates potential negative value of the reward function due to the stochastic constraints introduced by the LDPP framework. Empirical results demonstrate that our proposed scheme outperforms baseline methods under various conditions.

title: Distributed Transmit Beamforming Gain Achievability Bound
authors: A. Minot, J. Khan, M. Cui-Stein, B. Kurien
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: We propose a method for predicting transmit beam-forming performance using a distributed array. There is a well known upper bound of N<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> for the transmit beamforming gain of a system with N transmitters, with one factor of N due to power gain together with another factor of N from array directivity. In this work, we consider a distributed transmit array where each transmitter is on a separate platform and geographically sparse. For practical distributed array systems, the achievable beamforming gain is degraded by both error in the channel estimates and the distributed geometry of the transmit nodes. We derive a performance guarantee on transmit beamforming gain for scenarios where individual transmit nodes can coordinate to send common data to a multi-antenna receiver. This guarantee is expressed in terms of a system figure-of-merit called the error-gap ratio, which incorporates both the impacts of channel estimation error and geometry.

title: ClickDT: Building Scalable and High-Resolution Wireless Digital Twins with a Few Clicks
authors: Yiming Li, Scarlett Francini, Zhihui Gao, Tingjun Chen
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: Ray tracing (RT) tools serve as a crucial component for building wireless digital twins (DTs) by simulating the interactions between radio frequency (RF) signal propagation and the physical environment. However, existing open-source RT frameworks often require complex setup and configuration procedures, hindering their rapid adoption by and accessibility to a broader audience. We demonstrate ClickDT, a streamlined framework for the rapid construction of high-resolution wireless DTs with just a few mouse clicks. ClickDT is open-sourced and designed to facilitate the generation of realistic 3D scenes and the execution of RT simulations through a web-based user interface.

title: Secure User Authentication using Deep Learning on Graphical Passwords
authors: Ramesh Yegireddi, Mounika Lakkoji, Gangu VijayKumar, H. Swapna Rekha
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: The secure user-graphical password authentication(GPA) is the new mechanism for authentication having more security and usability when compared to the traditional alphanumeric passwords. Remembering the text as passwords maybe a cumberstone to everyone. The graphical password authentication system involves selecting the image and selecting some points in that image and making the passpoints as password. The objective is to integrate the ml and dl models to those passpoints and analyse the features like user behaviour, number of clicks,number of attempts ,time taken to select the passpoints for authentication. In this document, machine learning classifiers random forest and support vector machine have taken but comparing with ML classifiers, DL model lstm(long-short term memory) model works better and ensures more security by understanding complex passwords. Calculation is done for the performance metrics like accuracy(Acc), precision(pre),recall(rec) and f1-score of all the ML and DL models. From experimental work, the observation is, DL outperforms than the ML classifiers. From experimental observation, this revealed that the lstm model performs well and provides absolute security and obtained the performance acc,pre,rec,f1-score. Accuracy is 97.75% and precision is (1.0000),recall(0.98),f1-score(0.9631). From experimental work, the random classifier has the accuracy 90.76% and support vector machine has the accuracy of 89.09%. The study demonstrate that LSTM works poorful for long term passwords and detects the real user. Results show the proposed approach increases password entropy and resists common observation attacks while maintaining quicker recall than complex text passwords. The scheme is suitable for deployment on touch screen devices and can be tuned for different security-usability trade-offs.

title: Hybrid IoT–Edge AI Framework for Ultra-Low Latency Structural Health Monitoring in Smart Buildings
authors: S. Banupriya, R. Ruthra, Rakesh Kanna R, Venkatesh S, Abirami K, Srimathi S
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: SHM is undergoing fast evolution in the smart city era due to advancements in the IoT, AI, and big data analytics. These advancements pave the way for smart building SHM with ultra-low latency, which in turn enables analysis of data in real-time and responsive maintenance. The flexibility and resilience of AI-based solutions to tackle complicated structural and environmental problems have made them a hot topic in SHM. Because of their sensitivity to degradation, transportation assets like bridges are best served by SHM systems that function continuously throughout the asset's lifetime. Focussing on deep data modelling and effective data preprocessing areas that have frequently been overlooked in favour of model training this study provides an analytical overview of current advancements in AI-driven SHM. In order to improve the performance of SHM applications in terms of feature extraction, selection, and prediction, a hybrid model called CatBoost-Deep Cross Network is suggested. Results from comparisons show that the CatBoost-DCN model outperforms the state-of-the-art algorithms, reaching a precision of 94.02%. Intelligent, adaptable, and resilient SHM systems in smart buildings are made possible through the integration of AI with ultra-low latency IoT frameworks. This integration greatly improves the sustainability and safety of current urban infrastructures.

title: Adaptive Resource Allocation in Operating Systems
authors: Ansh Gupta, Durgesh M. Sharna
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: The modern operating systems are challenged as never before by the need to manage computational resources efficiently in a wide range of workloads and with varying hardware architectures. In the current paper, the review of adaptive resource allocation mechanisms is carried out within the framework of modern operating systems, filling the existing gaps in critical research questions of the dynamic allocation scheme, machine learning-based approaches, and practical implementation strategies. We do a comparative analysis of CPU scheduling, memory allocation, I/O bandwidth, and energy-aware resource allocation in terms of the algorithm description and performance comparison. As per our systematic assessment, adaptive resource allocation attains 25-40% enhancement in system throughput as well as energy intake reduction by up to 30% to conventional fixed approaches. The originality of this work is found in the fact that it offers an integrated platform on how to interpret adaptive mechanisms, offers a quantitative comparative study on various resource domains, and also arrives at certain implementation trade-offs that inform practical deployment decisions.

title: Anomaly Detection in Crowd Behavior for Public Safety Assurance
authors: Kamaleshwar T, Dunesh Kumar Madasu, Vishnu Pranavi Damacharla
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: Public ceremonies, such as events, classes, places of worship, or exhibitions, often include a high concentration of people in limited indoor places. In such an environment, health issues, imbalances or conflicts increases the risk of accidental human fall. Traditional monitoring and manual monitoring systems fail to immediately detect or provide an alert for such important events, leading to delayed reactions that can spoil the results of the injury or even cause congestion nervousness. Addressing this challenge, our project proposes a real-time software solution that takes advantage of AI and Computer Vision to detect human falls and immediately informs security personnel or carers for timely intervention. The system uses a live video feed from existing CCTV or IP cameras and applies advanced deep learning models such as YOLOv 8 for human identity jointly with pose assessment framework to track body movement. When the sudden loss of posture or horizontal decline is detected, the system sends an automated alert through integrated services such as firebase cloud messaging or Twilio SMS API. Alerts can be configured to access mobile devices, web dashboards or alerting systems in real time, which ensures rapid response from on-ground personnel. Major features of the proposed system include monitoring non-grace (no need for wearable equipment), compatibility with existing infrastructure, scalability and congestion settings at many places include high accuracy (tests with 40–50 individuals per room). The modular architecture of the system includes video stream handling, fall detection engine, alert module and monitoring interfaces for logging and visualization. This solution increases safety in public places by reducing dependence on manual observation and enabling early emergency response. The project shows how artificial intelligence can be applied for social good by improving mob safety and real-time phenomenon. Future work can focus on external landscapes, obstacles handling and multi-camera integration to further improve reliability and coverage.

title: A Ka Band High Back-off PAE Power Amplifier with Adaptive Bias Circuits in 65 nm CMOS
authors: Ran Zhang, Xiaodong Zhao, Hangbiao Li
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Integrated Circuits and Microsystems (ICICM)
abstract: Based on 65 nm CMOS technology, an adaptive bias circuit and its application in a Ka band differential power amplifier (PA) with compact chip area is introduced in this paper. The proposed adaptive bias circuit is able to adjust the PA’s bias voltage dynamically in response to input signal variations. It highly improves PAE $_{\text {P1dB }}$ (PAE at $\mathbf{1 d B}$ compression point) from 14.7% to 24.5%, and PAE $_{\text {6dB-backoff }}$ (PAE at 6dB-backoff from 1dB compression point) from $\mathbf{4. 5 \%}$ to $\mathbf{1 2. 4 \%}$. The proposed PA also achieves excellent port matching and linearity performance.

title: Satellite Optimization in LEO Constellations: A Capacity-Driven Trade-off Between Antennas and Deployment
authors: Joan Muñoz Sanchis, Miguel Ángel Vázquez
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: This paper introduces a framework for optimizing and analyzing LEO satellite constellations through the joint design of orbital parameters and payload configuration (i.e space segment antenna) to maximize system downlink capacity. The approach integrates constellation geometry with antenna allocation per satellite, using sum-capacity in multi-user multiple-input single-output (MU-MISO) scenarios. To address the computational cost of evaluating each candidate design, Bayesian Optimization is employed as a sample-efficient black-box search method. Simulation results demonstrate that highlight the value of combining accurate capacity modeling with integrated constellation and hardware co-design.

title: Quantum-Enhanced Word Sense Disambiguation using Quantum Parallelism and Hybrid Quantum-Classical Models
authors: Dalydas Karanath, Udai Shankar
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: The paper proposes a quantum-classical hybrid method of Word Sense Disambiguation (WSD) to combine quantum inspired computation on WSD with classical natural language processing methods. The quantum state encoding is proposed to make ambiguous words coded in the framework as quantum superposition of all the possible senses, and semantic interpretations can be explored by encoding quantum states. A simulation of quantum circuits based on simulated quantum interactions was used to create a hybrid model involving variational quantum circuits and classical neural layer using the PyTorch platform. The system was trained and tested on a manually annotated collection of 5,000 polysemous sentences spanning various domains and tested on WordNet synsets. The experimental findings reveal that the hybrid quantum-classical model of WSD has 94.7 per cent accuracy and weighted F1-score of 94.0 per cent, which is better than CNN-LSTM and Transformer (BERT-base) baselines. The confusion matrix affirms enhanced sense differentiation and less semantic duplicity. The suggested architecture illustrates the possibility of quantum-enhanced natural language processing to be used in order to reach a higher contextual accuracy without compromising the computational efficiency that would be suitable with near-term quantum hardware.

title: Evidence-based Hiring: A GitHub-Centric Approach to Candidate Assessment
authors: G. Kiran Kumar, Bokka Daivik Reddy, Sheelam Vihas Reddy, Anila Macharla, S. China Ramu
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: Resume shortlisting is the first round of candidate evaluation in the recruitment process. The current method Automated Resume Parsers (ARPs) that use keyword matching to assess the claimed skills of the candidate. This creates a gap between qualifications and actual abilities, more specifically in terms of projects, code quality, etc. The current approach doesn’t check if the candidate actually used their skills, can’t find copied work, and doesn’t access the progress over time. Tool like CVExplorer and SkillsMap try to use GitHub data and evaluate the candidate’s skills, but they don’t support many languages, they’re not very accurate, can’t access the quality of their work. The GitMeter system, which was introduced in this paper, is a better option because it uses a smart analysis method to determine both hard and soft skills from publicly available projects on their GitHub. But it still has some issues: it only looks at public GitHub activity, works with just Python and Java, can’t catch copied or AI-generated code, and doesn’t assess important soft skills like teamwork or empathy.To fix these problems, our improved system adds support for more languages using tools like CodeQL, checks if code is original with the help of AI models and plagiarism tools,and academic profiles to build a more complete and reliable way to hire.

title: Privacy-First, AI-Driven Web Analytics: An Architecture for Schema Governance, Consent Compliance, and Intelligent Policy Enforcement
authors: Sampath Alampalli
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: Web analytics platforms face growing challenges in manual tagging inefficiencies, schema drift, and regulatory compliance. This paper presents a privacy-first, AI-driven architecture that integrates privacy-preserving data collection with automated schema governance and adaptive compliance enforcement. On the client side, a lightweight JavaScript SDK validates event payloads against strict JSON Schemas, masks sensitive fields, and enforces user choices via Global Privacy Control (GPC) and consent management platforms (e.g., One Trust). On the server side, a policy-as-code framework applies regional and purpose-specific rules, ensuring no event is transmitted without explicit consent. The architecture incorporates three AI-based modules: Auto-Schema Agent – Generates and maintains event specifications dynamically. Drift & Anomaly Detector – Identifies schema inconsistencies and shifts in data distribution. Policy Recommender – Suggests updates to deny-lists as new fields emerge. Methods: Synthetic evaluations were performed using simulated event streams with schema mutations, consent toggles, and anomaly injection. Performance was measured against baseline manual schema governance and static policy enforcement. Results: Findings indicate that schema governance effort is reduced by ~70%, setup time shortened by 75%, and schema drift detection accelerated from multiple days to hours. Consent-aware policy enforcement achieved 100% compliance in simulated GPC and regional policy scenarios. This work contributes a deployable reference architecture, an AI-assisted schema governance model, and a policy evaluation framework for next-generation, compliance-ready web analytics systems.

title: Multiclass Brain Tumor Classification Using VGG16-Based Transfer Learning
authors: Paramita Mitra, Jathin C Dutta, K. Vishnu Charan, Jeevan Gowda M
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: Brain tumor classification using magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) is a key component in early diagnosis and treatment planning. Manual MRI analysis is labor-intensive and prone to diagnostic errors. This work introduces an automated classification methodology that utilizes the pre-trained VGG16 network within a transfer-learning setup to recognize four categories: glioma, meningioma, pituitary tumors, and normal brain images. Dense and dropout layers enhance generalization and minimize overfitting. Furthermore, a hybrid ensemble integrating VGG16, ResNet, and EfficientNet enables feature-level fusion to improve accuracy. The suggested method was tested and confirmed using a public MRI dataset, with evaluation based on accuracy, precision, sensitivity, and F1-score. Experimental results confirm that the hybrid model surpasses individual architectures, demonstrating the efficacy of transfer learning and model fusion for reliable computer-aided brain tumor diagnosis.

title: PhantomRift: A Novel Framework for Stealthy Microservice Disruption via Inferred Gateway Semantics and Deep Dependency Mapping
authors: Xiaofeng Zhang, Jinfa Wang, Jie Liu, Tianheng Qu, Mingdong Liu, Rongrong Xi, Hongsong Zhu
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: Microservice architectures, while scalable, often harbor intricate execution dependencies forming critical performance bottlenecks. These vulnerabilities are exploited by sophisticated low-rate Distributed Denial of Service (DDoS) attacks that cause severe operational disruptions yet evade conventional detection due to their subtlety, posing significant risks to critical infrastructure and systems that demand high operational assurance, including those in national security contexts. Orchestrating stealthy, high-impact attacks against these opaque dependencies is a considerable challenge. This paper introduces PhantomRift, a novel framework that enhances attack stealth and efficacy by integrating LLM-assisted semantic path discovery for comprehensive surface mapping—uncovering elusive, dynamically triggered paths—with deep quantitative modeling of inter-path dependency strengths and complex relational typologies. Experimentally, PhantomRift’s optimized strategies achieve substantial performance degradation (e.g., a 12-fold increase in average response time, with approximately 35% less request traffic than the baselines), while its efficiency and precise, sub-detection-threshold millisecond-level bottleneck control ensure enhanced stealth via a minimized operational footprint. This research highlights the transformative potential of Large Language Models in automating sophisticated network attacks. It underscores the urgent security challenges faced by contemporary systems, particularly those underpinning strategic capabilities in contested digital environments.

title: Deep Learning-based Retinal Image Analysis for the Detection of Diabetic Retinopathy, Cataract, and Glaucoma
authors: Bura Vijay Kumar, Ruchika Bhuria, Sonali Gupta, Vartika Aarwal
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: Retina diseases like diabetic retinopathy, cataract, and glaucoma are some of the most significant causes of visual impairments and blindness in most parts of the world especially where there exists a lack of ophthalmic experts. Conventional techniques of detection such as manual examination of the fundus, optical coherence tomography and slit-lamp examination are effective, but they are labor intensive, time consuming and lacking inter-observer consistency. New developments in artificial intelligence, especially, deep learning, have shown to be transformative in automated retinal disease classification. In this paper, the proposed model is a multi-class convolutional neural network (CNN)-based model to classify retinal images into normal, diabetic retinopathy, cataract, and glaucoma. The preprocessing and augmentation of a curated dataset of images of various public sources were done to enhance the model robustness. The CNN-fine-tuned model had an average accuracy of 97% and high precision, recall and F1-scores in all the categories with limited misclassifications in the confusion matrix. The results outline the possibilities of deep learning models to become scalable diagnostic tools, which would be helpful to conduct early disease diagnostics and perform effective screening of diseases in clinics and communities. This paper helps advance the adoption of AI-based systems in ophthalmology by providing a framework that is both accurate, generalized, and clinical in practice.

title: Hardware-Accelerated Edge Detection and Pixel Enhancement on PYNQ-Z2 for Portable Medical Diagnostics
authors: Arunkumar K, Navaneethan S, Naresh Kumar R S, Mugilan J
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: Edge detection is an important part of application for medical image processing with particular significance for detection of structural defects like bone fractures in X-rays. Conventional software-based implementations often face real-time performance limitations owing to high computational needs. As an answer to this shortcoming, the manuscript introduces a hardware-based approach using FPGA technology supporting Sobel-based edge detection in combination with pixel enhancement. The proposed design has been applied to the board-based PYNQ-Z2 focusing on parallel processing using Verilog HDL to achieve high-speed operation with low latency. The essence of innovation in this study is combining Sobel-based edge detection with real-time pixel enhancement at the level of FPGA hardware to enable diagnostically relevant images with low computational overhead. The system proposed here produces enhanced grayscale X-ray images to be displayed externally and hence is applicable to portable diagnostic medical applications. The aim is to achieve resource optimization with low costs and real-time support toward imaging in healthcare facilities where immediate and accurate preprocessing is required.

title: CuraSense: AI-Powered Mobile Application for Personalized Skincare Recommendations
authors: Sudha J, Hema C, Dhivyasathya R, Shanchitha M, Sri Abirami R
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: Maintaining healthy skin has become a significant challenge due to diverse skin types, changing environmental conditions, and the overwhelming number of skincare products available on the market. Many existing skincare applications provide limited guidance and fail to integrate multiple aspects of skincare into one platform. This paper presents CuraSense, an AI-powered mobile application that analyses skin using camera-based scanning, integrates local weather conditions, recommends natural home remedies, and provides product suggestions from leading e-commerce platforms such as Amazon and Flip kart. By combining advanced image analysis, personalized skincare advice, and direct product purchase links, CuraSense creates a seamless end-to-end skincare management solution.

title: Anomaly Detection and Mitigation in O-RAN Networks using an LSTM-RNN Autoencoder and Secure Slicing
authors: Joshua Moore, Aly Sabri Abdalla, Zehran Reshi, Vuk Marojevic
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: The disaggregation of 5G networks, particularly through the introduction of the Open RAN Intelligent Controller (O-RAN RIC), creates new opportunities for fine-grained network control but also introduces novel attack surfaces. Malicious actors can exploit this architecture to launch sophisticated Denial of Service (DoS) attacks, such as throttling the throughput of specific User Equipment (UE), which can be difficult to detect with traditional security methods, and also lack the potential for mitigation. This paper introduces an intelligent, two-part framework for automated anomaly detection and mitigation, operating as xApps at the Near-Real-Time RIC (Near-RT RIC). We design an Intrusion Detection xApp (ID xApp) that leverages a Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) and Recurrent Neural Network (RNN) Autoencoder to analyze temporal UE behavior based on collected Key Performance Indicators (KPIs) and identify anomalous patterns characteristic of a DoS attack. Upon detection, the ID xApp triggers a Secure Slicing xApp (SSxApp), which automatically isolates the malicious UE by moving it to a secure network slice with no allocated resources, effectively neutralizing the threat without impacting other users. We demonstrate the effectiveness of this approach in accurately detecting and autonomously mitigating DoS attacks, presenting a robust AI-driven security solution for next-generation cellular networks.

title: OFDM Based Bistatic Integrated Sensing and Communication: Sensing Beyond CP Limit
authors: Cuneyd Ozturk, Cagri Goken
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: This work investigates a bistatic OFDM-based integrated sensing and communication (ISAC) system under a single-target scenario, considering both line-of-sight (LOS) presence and LOS blockage cases. A sliding window-based sensing receiver architecture is proposed to extend the intersymbol interference (ISI)-free sensing range beyond the cyclic prefix (CP) duration by exploiting pilot symbols embedded in the time-frequency grid. The performance of the proposed receiver is evaluated in terms of range and velocity estimation accuracy and is compared against the Cramer-Rao bounds (CRBs) for the bi-static ISAC setting. Numerical results confirm that the proposed method achieves estimation performance that closely approaches the CRBs in the high signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) regime.

title: Effects of Age of Channel State Information on Throughput for Collaborative Beamforming Link
authors: Michael V. Lipski, Clement Kam, Sastry Kompella, Anthony Ephremides
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: We examine a simplified coherent distributed collaborative beamforming (DCB) link consisting of two transmitters sending a single data stream to a receiver. The novel elements introduced are a method for computing expected link throughput and an analysis of performance when operating over wireless channels with significant time-varying phase distortion. To offset the channel phase distortion, each transmitter samples the state of its channel using a periodic sounding waveform sent by the receiver. As the age of the last sampled channel state increases, so does the probability of phase error between the beamforming components. A quantized phase space model is introduced for the wireless channel and the DCB gain performance is analyzed with respect to age of channel state information (AoCSI). Additionally, we introduce a framework for computing expected throughput of the DCB link, whereby the channel sensing period is optimized to the wireless channel conditions. Future network planning for WSNs or MANETs can use this framework for incorporating DCB links. Adding DCB links to a wireless network does not necessarily require additional hardware and provides benefits such as greater link ranges, increased throughput, reduced transmit power, and reduced interference.

title: Reconfigurable SRAM Computing-In-Memory Macro Based on Local Computing Cell
authors: Chenghu Dai, Chaoyi Wang, Zeyi Liu, Qiang Zhao, Chunyu Peng
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Integrated Circuits and Microsystems (ICICM)
abstract: Computing-in-memory (CIM) performs computation inside the memory, which shows high energy efficiency and high bandwidth. Though many efforts have been made to enhance its functions, CIM macro still suffers from fixed computational modes and nonlinearity issues. In this work, we propose a configurable SRAM CIM macro, which supports SRAM, Boolean logic operations, binary multiply-accumulate (MAC), and 4bit MAC operations. A 4bit SAR ADC with singleended comparator reduces $\sim 9 \%$ power efficiency compared with conventional ADC. In 28 nm CMOS process, simulation results show the energy efficiency of NOR operation, binary MAC and 4bit MAC are 136.4-673.8, 189.7-453.2, and 4.7-59.68 TOPS/W at a supply voltage range from $0.7 \mathrm{~V}-1.1 \mathrm{~V}$, respectively. The proposed CIM macro helps to enhance hardware utilization and flexibility of SRAM, and offer high performance and energyefficient method to convolutional neural networks acceleration.

title: Indirect Herding Control Through a Chain-of-Influence by Uncertain Intermediaries
authors: Jhyv N. Philor, Cristian F. Nino, Patrick M. Amy, Warren E. Dixon
publish: IEEE Control Systems Letters
abstract: Herding is an established class of problems where a herding agent seeks to influence a target agent to move to a desired location. Motivated by scenarios where the herder cannot directly influence a target or the herder desires to conceal its influence, this paper examines a new generalization of the herding problem where the herding agent influences a target agent through a set of intermediate agents (i.e., multi-hop chain of influence). The interconnected influences result in challenging coupled dynamics within the group of agents. Motivated by this challenge, robust control techniques are used to compensate for the complex chain of influences among the group, and a Lyapunov-based analysis is used to prove the target is exponentially regulated to a desired location by the herding agent.
