title: High-Performance Interleaved Boost Converter For EV Battery Charging
authors: Athikesavan S, Charmitha P S, Karna S, S. Banumathi
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: The rapid adoption of Electric Vehicles (EVs) has created a significant demand for efficient, reliable, and flexible battery charging systems. Conventional boost converters commonly used in EV chargers face challenges such as high current ripple, increased switching stress, lower efficiency at high power, and limited integration with multiple energy sources. To overcome these limitations, this paper proposes a high-performance interleaved four-port boost converter for EV battery charging. The four-port topology allows simultaneous connection of grid supply, solar photovoltaic (PV) input, battery storage, and auxiliary power, making it highly suitable for hybrid and renewable-based charging systems. The interleaved configuration with a 90° phase shift significantly reduces input and output current ripple, ensures balanced current sharing among switches, and improves thermal management. The proposed converter achieves efficiency exceeding 90%, maintains stable voltage levels, and enhances component longevity. Moreover, the multiport design provides greater flexibility, enabling seamless integration of renewable energy sources without compromising charging performance. Simulation and experimental results demonstrate the superior performance of the proposed topology compared to traditional converters, exhibiting lower ripple, improved stability, and more efficient power delivery.

title: Multi-Network Contrastive Learning Model for Financial Risk Assessment and Prediction
authors: Nageshbabu Dasari, Bhuvanagiri Venkata Subrahmanya Sastry, Pucha Venkata Subbarama Sarma
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: After the global financial crisis, financial institutions realised how important it was to assess operational and credit risks. Bad decisions can lead to huge losses. The inability to consistently differentiate between applicants with good credit and those prone to default is a major obstacle, particularly considering that conventional credit granting was dependent on human experts' subjective assessments and rule-based determinations. This paper has strengthened credit risk evaluation, improved cash flow, reduced financial risks, and supported sound managerial decisions by adopting more systematic methodologies like behavioural management and credit scoring to tackle these problems. This study delves into the ways data preprocessing, particularly Truncated SVD, impacts the precision and resilience of financial risk assessment and prediction. Feature extraction is carried out using PCA. This study proposes a MNCGF. The convolutional network may extract global or local picture characteristics. Comparing and contrasting embedding pairs from different networks trains the model to learn features at different image scales. With an F1-Score of 94.96%, the experimental findings show that the MNCGF model works well. These results demonstrate the importance of sophisticated preprocessing and fusion methods for improving financial risk prediction, providing a solid resource for operational and credit risk management for financial organisations.

title: A Service-Differentiated Routing Scheme for Hybrid-Trusted Quantum Key Distribution Network
authors: Qingzhu Han, Liquan Chen, Jingqi Chen, Yinghua Jiang, Nan Li
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: Hybrid-trusted Quantum Key Distribution (QKD) networks face unique security challenges due to semi-trusted nodes. These nodes may introduce security threats such as man-in-the-middle attacks and key storage side-channel leakage. With the increasing complexity of QKD network architectures and expanding application scenarios, substantial divergences have emerged between user requirements for communication duration and cryptographic security demands. To address security challenges in hybrid-trusted QKD environments and provide differentiated services for users with varying requirements, this paper proposes a Service Requirement-based Hybrid-Trusted QKD Network (SRHT-QKDN) routing scheme. We propose a time-slot allocation model for QKD that employs time-slot resources as substitutes for key-generation resources in resource allocation processes. For sustained key distribution required by prolonged communications, the scheme implements two distinct time slot allocation algorithms: continuous-consistent and discrete-inconsistent allocation, enabling periodic quantum key updates. Concurrently, QKD requests are classified into three security levels, with corresponding routing strategies developed for each tier to achieve security service differentiation while maintaining routing success rates. Simulations conducted under four distinct operational conditions demonstrate that the SRHT-QKDN routing scheme not only effectively fulfills key continuity requirements but also achieves optimal overall performance in request success rate and security assurance, outperforming two benchmark routing schemes.

title: Performance Analysis of Machine Learning Model of Speech and Tic Recognition for Early Diagnosis of Tourette Syndrome
authors: Aldaruhz T. Darkis, Patrick D. Cerna
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: This study presents an AI-powered object detection framework for the automated recognition of tic behaviors associated with Tourette Syndrome, specifically targeting early diagnosis among Filipino youth. Using the Roboflow 3.0 Object Detection (Accurate) model, the system was trained and validated on a curated dataset consisting of annotated video sequences representing both motor and facial tics. The proposed model achieved a validation mAP@50 of 81.8%, with corresponding precision and recall scores of 68.8% and 78.4%, respectively. These results demonstrate the model’s capability to accurately detect and classify tic-related movements, thereby meeting the primary objective of developing an automated bioTic classification framework for Tourette Syndrome analysis. While the results confirm effective generalization across the dataset, the performance under stricter thresholds—mAP@50:95 plateauing between 0.48 and 0.55—reveals persistent challenges in fine-grained spatial localization. This limitation aligns with prior studies employing YOLO and CNN-based architectures for tic detection, where models exhibited strong overall recognition but struggled with precise localization under higher Intersection-over-Union (IoU) criteria. Despite these constraints, the findings affirm that the proposed model provides a promising foundation for AI-assisted early screening and monitoring of Tourette Syndrome. The integration of localized datasets and advanced feature extraction techniques underscores the system’s potential for deployment in clinical and educational settings to support early intervention efforts.

title: Deep Learning Interference Suppression for Cyclostationary Signals
authors: Badhrinarayan Malolan, Daniel J. Jakubisin, Jeffrey H. Reed
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: This paper introduces a novel approach to interference suppression in wireless communication systems by exploiting cyclostationary signal characteristics of the signal. We demonstrate that partitioning interfered waveforms into cyclostationary phase-aligned segments, each processed by a dedicated Convolutional Autoencoder, outperforms conventional methods. Our proposed architecture achieves greater than 70% of baseline Error Vector Magnitude (EVM) performance while requiring 85% fewer parameters. Results show faster convergence, enhanced stability, and parallelizable processing suitable for resource-constrained applications. This phase-specific modeling approach enables efficient interference mitigation even in narrow signal segments, making it ideal for IoT edge devices and real-time communication systems.

title: Revenue Optimization in Video Caching Networks with Privacy-Preserving Demand Predictions
authors: Yijing Zhang, Ferdous Pervej, Andreas F. Molisch
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: Performance of video streaming, which accounts for most of the traffic in wireless communication, can be significantly improved by caching popular videos at the wireless edge. Determining the cache content that optimizes performance (defined via a revenue function) is thus an important task, and prediction of the future demands based on past history can make this process much more efficient. However, since practical video caching networks involve various parties (e.g., users, (wireless) internet service provider (ISP), and content service provider (CSP)) that do not wish to reveal information such as past history to each other, privacy-preserving solutions are required. Motivated by this, we propose a proactive caching method based on users’ privacy-preserving multi-slot future demand predictions—obtained from a trained Transformer—to optimize revenue. Specifically, we first use a privacy-preserving federated learning (FL) algorithm to train a Transformer to predict multi-slot future demands of the users. However, prediction accuracy is not perfect and decreases the farther into the future the prediction is done. We model the impact of prediction errors invoking the file popularities, based on which we formulate a long-term system revenue optimization to make the cache placement decisions. As the formulated problem is NP-hard, we use a greedy algorithm to efficiently obtain an approximate solution. Simulation results validate that (i) the FL solution achieves results close to the centralized (non-privacy-preserving) solution and (ii) optimization of revenue may provide different solutions than the classical cache hit ratio (CHR) criterion.

title: MindCommand: A Thought-Driven Robotic Assistance Framework using Non-Invasive EEG
authors: Benetta M Thomas, Steve Thomas, R Chitra, S Stewart Kribakaran
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: The MindCommand framework presents a non- invasive Brain–Computer Interface (BCI) system that uses thought-driven robotic control to help people with motor disabilities. In order to determine user intent, the system records electroencephalography (EEG) data and applies machine learning algorithms to process them. Users can operate assistive equipment without moving by using these classified mental commands, which are subsequently converted into robotic actions. To confirm the viability of brain-controlled assistive robotics, the framework was put into practice in a 3D simulation. Promising potential for future real-world applications in rehabilitation and healthcare aid is demonstrated by experimental assessments that show EEG signals may be efficiently mapped to basic robotic operations including movement and object interaction.

title: A 0.6-3 GHz Active Double-Balanced Mixer Circuit Design
authors: Jing Wang, Jun Liu, Xuezhen Zhao, Guodong Su
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Integrated Circuits and Microsystems (ICICM)
abstract: This paper presents a $0.6-3 \mathrm{GHz}$ active double-balanced mixer model, which employs a passive double-balanced mixer ring as its core structure. The RF and LO baluns adopt an improved triple-coupled line Marchand balun configuration, while the local oscillator enhancement-type driver amplifier is incorporated to achieve mixing functionality across the target frequency band. By integrating nonlinear characteristic theory with the mixer’s performance attributes, an effective modeling approach is developed for conversion loss and nonlinearity. Comparative analysis between simulation results and measured data demonstrates excellent agreement, with the simulated curves closely matching the actual measurement patterns. This strong correlation validates the engineering application potential of the proposed mixer model in broadband communication systems.

title: Design of High-reliability and High-dynamic Analog Front-end for DC Carrier Chip
authors: Quan Sun, Gang Chen, Changyou Men, Shuang Wu
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Integrated Circuits and Microsystems (ICICM)
abstract: DC carrier communication technology has broad application prospects in smart grids, power line communications, and other fields. This paper designs a high-reliability, high-dynamic-range analog front-end architecture to meet the special requirements of DC carrier chips. This circuit utilizes key technologies such as adaptive gain control, multi-stage filtering, and dynamic bias adjustment to achieve stable operation over a wide input voltage range $(12 \mathrm{~V}-1000 \mathrm{~V})$. Experimental results demonstrate that the designed analog front-end achieves a signal-to-noise ratio of 65 dB, a dynamic range exceeding 80 dB, and a total harmonic distortion of less than 0.1% over a temperature range of $-\mathbf{4 0}^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ to $+\mathbf{8 5}^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$, meeting the stringent requirements of DC carrier communication systems.

title: Satellite Assignment Policy Learning for Coexistence in LEO Networks
authors: Jeong Min Kong, Eunsun Kim, Ian P. Roberts
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: Unlike in terrestrial cellular networks, certain frequency bands for low-earth orbit (LEO) satellite systems have thus far been allocated on a non-exclusive basis. In this context, systems that launch their satellites earlier—referred to as primary systems—are given spectrum access priority over those that launch later, known as secondary systems. For a secondary system to function, it is expected to either coordinate with primary systems or ensure that it does not cause excessive interference to primary ground users. Reliably meeting this interference constraint requires real-time knowledge of the receive beams of primary users, which in turn depends on the primary satellite-to-primary user associations. However, in practice, primary systems have thus far not publicly disclosed their satellite assignment policies; therefore, it becomes essential for secondary systems to develop methods to infer such policies. Assuming there is limited historical data indicating which primary satellites have served which primary users, we propose an end-to-end graph structure learning-based algorithm for learning highest elevation primary satellite assignment policies, that, upon deployment, can directly map the primary satellite coordinates into assignment decisions for the primary users. Simulation results show that our method can outperform the best baseline, achieving approximately a 15% improvement in prediction accuracy.

title: Low Power Full Adder with Tri-State Buffer based on Reversible Logic
authors: Syed Saleem, Kamireddy Sireesha, Dasamandam Venkata Supriya, Korrapadu Mahammad Haneef, Khaderabad Abdul Khader, Mitta Pavithra
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: A key demand in contemporary VLSI design is minimizing power consumption, particularly in arithmetic circuits where switching activity predominates. Conventional irreversible architectures, which are based on NAND and NOR circuitry, generate heat and are less efficient since they automatically destroy information during computing. This restriction is overcome by reversible logic, which maintains information, guarantees bijective input-output mapping, and minimizes energy loss. In contrast to conventional reversible designs based on Feynman and Peres gates, this paper suggests a reversible full adder with just 12 transistors, which represents an 81% reduction in transistor count and roughly 78% lower power dissipation. In order to maximize resource utilization and energy efficiency, the design generates restricted trash outputs and uses a constant input to preserve reversibility. HSPICE simulation results show that the circuit operates steadily at supply voltages between 0.5 and 1.5 volts. Additionally, the suggested design's energy efficiency is confirmed by the constantly low power-delay product (PDP) and energy-delay product (EDP) values. The suggested complete adder is ideal for low-power processors, energy-constrained VLSI applications, and next-generation reversible computing because of its fewer transistors, small area consumption, and stable performance under voltage scaling.

title: A DDR Controller Circuit Gate-level Post-simulation Method in SoC Design
authors: Yande Jiang, Jingbo Ma, Guangda Zhang, Huiquan Wang, Bingxi Pei, Na Chen, Jian Fang
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Integrated Circuits and Microsystems (ICICM)
abstract: As the complexity of System-on-Chip (SoC) designs increases, the gate-level post-simulation functional verification of SoCs has become increasingly critical. In addition, to enhance bandwidth, modern SoCs integrate high-performance DDR controller circuits. However, the gate-level post-simulation verification of DDR controllers in SoC designs demands substantial time and human resources. To address this challenge, we propose an efficient multi-level gate-level post-simulation methodology. To validate the proposed method, we design a SoC chip circuit which integrates 2 DDR4 controllers, 4 CPU cores, and employ the commercial Electronic Design Automatic (EDA) tools to obtain the DDR controller circuit netlist, and Standard Delay Format (SDF) files as the post-simulation input files. The experimental results demonstrate that our proposed multi-level gate-level post-simulation method achieves a $4 \times$ speedup in functional post-simulation for the DDR controller circuit in SoC design, while also validating the effectiveness of the approach.

title: mmPrism: High-Throughput Perception-Aware mmWave Radar Object Recognition in Contested Environments
authors: Zihan Shan, Md Iftekharul Islam Sakib, Matthew Caesar, Tarek Abdelzaher, Jae Kim, Peter Wittenberg
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: Millimeter-wave (mmWave) radars have demonstrated strong performance under challenging visibility conditions and support high-resolution imaging through techniques such as synthetic aperture radar (SAR). The increasing availability of compact, low-cost mmWave systems has made them particularly appealing for low-power platforms in mission-critical tactical scenarios. However, traditional SAR imaging demands extensive sampling, leading to significant delays and excessive data collection—particularly in environments where only a small subset of the scene contains mission-relevant information.To overcome this inefficiency, we introduce mmPrism, a perception-aware attention scheduling framework for mmWave radar that intelligently concentrates sensing and computation on Target Areas of Interest (TAIs). By combining rapid coarse scanning with spotlight-mode SAR under the control of a perception-aware TAI scheduler, mmPrism reduces unnecessary overhead while preserving task-relevant detail. Experimental results demonstrate substantial improvements in recognition throughput and latency, with minimal compromise in imaging resolution.

title: A Review of Speech Emotion Recognition: An Overview, Recent Developments, and Opportunities
authors: Sandip Turakne, Vijayshree More, Sailee Panchbhai
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: Speech emotion recognition (SER) is an important field of study because we need better ways for computers and people to communicate. People’s feelings play a significant role in their conversations. It could be useful for machines to recognize and respond to human emotions in various areas, such as healthcare, education, customer service, and virtual assistants. Deep learning technologies have made significant strides in recent years, improving the performance of systems that handle speech-related tasks. SER has also seen major advancements due to the development of complex neural network designs. This paper offers an in-depth look at current research in SER, focusing on studies that use deep learning techniques. It compares the most effective models, including convolutional neural networks (CNNs), long short-term memory (LSTM) networks, transformers, and hybrid models. This study also talks about the most important things that affect SER performance, such as choosing speech emotion datasets and features. This review additionally discusses about the problems and limitations that current SER research faces. For example, datasets are not very diverse, emotions are hard to represent, speakers and languages are dependent on each other, and it is hard to use the technology in real time. This paper seeks to provide substantial insights for researchers on SER by synthesizing findings from multiple recent studies.

title: Enhanced Sleep Apnea Detection Through Multiscale Temporal Modeling with Transformers
authors: Manikandan J, Suhas Singh, Nishan Chakraborty, Ansh Raut, Komal Srivastava, Parth Krishna
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: Sleep apnea is a severe sleep disorder characterized by repeated breathing interruptions, leading to oxygen deprivation and predisposing an individual to cardiovascular and neurological complications. Despite PSG being considered the gold standard for diagnosis, it still remains an expensive, time-consuming modality that is not widely available for mass screening. This paper presents an enhanced machine learning framework for automated, low-cost detection of sleep apnea. This system combines a multi-modal CNN for feature fusion, a lightweight Deep Sequential LSTM for modeling temporal dependencies, an Explainable 1D-CNN with Grad-CAM for interpretability, and a Multiscale Transformer for capturing long-range dependencies with efficiency. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed model significantly improves upon the current state-of-the-art performance of several CNN-LSTM and CNN-Transformer architectures in terms of accuracy, efficiency, and reliability. This provides a clinically meaningful and scalable solution for early detection of sleep apnea.

title: Gym-Ready HealthSim: A PyTorch–SimPy Pattern for RL-in-the-Loop Operations Science
authors: Himanshu Arora
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: This paper presents a reproducible integration pattern that couples deep reinforcement learning agents built in PyTorch with discrete-event simulations in SimPy, exposing a minimal reset/step/render contract to support experiment design, ablation, and benchmarking across environments. The framework formalizes environment state vectors, reward shaping, action legality, and episodic training loops to enable data-science workflows such as policy evaluation, sample-efficiency analysis, and hyperparameter sweeps under consistent interface guarantees. As a reference case, an acute-care capacity simulation is instrumented to compare Double DQN and Dueling Double DQN variants (including noisy layers, prioritized replay, bootstrapping/bagging), reporting learning trajectories and policy stability rather than task-specific KPIs. The design emphasizes portable experiment code, clear separation of data collection from learning logic, and compatibility with Gym-style agents to accelerate reproducibility and cross-study comparisons. Beyond the exemplar, the pattern generalizes to other stochastic service systems, providing a data-science scaffold for safe reward exploration and pre-training before transfer to real-world operations.

title: Optimized Electric Vehicle Charging using a Hybrid Reinforcement–Supervised Learning Framework
authors: Pucha Venkata Subbarama Sarma, Morla Dinesh Sai, Nageshbabu Dasari
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: In order to achieve widespread adoption of EV, which has several advantages including less fuel costs and less greenhouse gas emissions, it is necessary to build charging networks that are both efficient and easy for users to use. As a result, new approaches to charging EVs are appearing on the market, with WEVC showing great promise over older, more inconvenient methods. WEVC is particularly appealing for EV and PHEV applications in fixed contexts since it avoids plug-in issues while giving greater convenience, simplicity, and reliability. This study investigates a data-driven charging method that makes use of vibration signals to extract three charging features at the segment level using feature extraction techniques; the goal is to push this area forward. Afterwards, these features are fed into an RL-SVM model, which uses RL to optimise hyperparameters and boost the efficiency of SVM for charging problem diagnostics. A public rolling bearings dataset was used for experimental validation, which proved that the model was better than other methods. In terms of MAE, the RL-SVM model outperforms RL, SVM, and K-means by 9.47%, 4.50%, 1.65%, and 16.28%, respectively. According to these results, the RL-SVM model is an excellent choice for improving dependable EV charging infrastructure.

title: Adaptive Spectral–Temporal Encoding (ASTE) with Hybrid Neural Architectures for Intelligent Financial Risk Forecasting
authors: Xian Yu, Chunhong Shen, Yating Huang
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: In the context of intelligent prediction models, this study proposes an intelligent financial risk prediction algorithm based on Adaptive Spectral–Temporal Encoding (ASTE) and a hybrid neural network architecture. This model can account for the high-dimensional, non-stationary, and nonlinear characteristics of financial market data. As the basis of modeling, the ASTE method adaptively encodes the importance of information at different frequencies and time scales through a learnable spectral–temporal weight mechanism. This operation can achieve dynamic extraction of short-term fluctuations and long-term trends. The model then inputs the encoded features into a hybrid neural network. The network integrates convolution, recursion, and self-attention modules and can simultaneously capture local nonlinear patterns, short-term and long-term dependencies, and global feature interactions. In order to improve the generalization ability of the model, the final model also introduces temporal smoothing and entropy regularization constraints. The experimental validation phase adopted the multidimensional time series data from major markets in China, the United States, and Europe from August 2015 to August 2025. The training, validation, and test sets are collections of approximately 720,000 data points. State-of-the-art models like as ARIMA, LSTM, CNN-LSTM, Attention-LSTM, and SSA-MLP were used in the comparative research. The experimental findings show that metrics like AUC, RMSE, and cross-market AUC are significantly improved by the ASTE-Hybrid model. The cross-market AUC increased by more than 10%, the RMSE dropped by 15.9%, and the AUC improved by 11.9% when compared to the top competitive model. The robustness of the model was further confirmed by multi-factor ablation tests. In particular, the AUC reductions of roughly 3.7%, 5.2%, and 8.5% were obtained by eliminating price, volatility, and macro effects, respectively.

title: A Smart NDVI and Classification-based System for Monthly Forest Change Detection and Alert Notifications
authors: Mythili M, Navishna N, Nikithaa S, Nivetha K, Rasmitha R
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: Deforestation is one of the major issues that threatening ecosystems in worldwide. It causing the biodiversity loss, climate imbalance, and soil degradation. For this Traditional monitoring methods are manual, time-consuming, and lack in real-time accuracy. The forest departments struggled to take quick action and felt difficult to maintain the ecosystem. To overcome these struggles, we propose a detection system that to analyze and identify the forest loss in specified range of forest. Sentinel-2 satellite image is used to discover the deforestation by applying the Normalized Difference Vegetation Index (NDVI) and Change Detection algorithms, which are widely used to measure vegetation health and detect variations in forest cover. By comparing old and new satellite images on a monthly basis, the system predicts changes in vegetation and calculates key indicators such as NDVI %, Change %, and Tree Loss %. The results are then delivered through a role-based platform, where administrators can manage analyses and generate reports, while forest officers receive timely alerts whenever NDVI predicts forest’s critical condition. This approach ensures accurate, software-based, and efficient monitoring, solving the struggles of manual surveys by enabling faster detection, reliable reporting, and proactive forest conservation measures.

title: Beyond Signature-based Defense: Deep Learning Frameworks for Concealed Cyber Exploit Detection
authors: S. Hariharasudhan, S. Rajeshwari, S. V. Priyadharshini, Vishnu Priya K, S. P. Santhoshkumar, Gajalakshmi S
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: The emergence of intelligent manufacturing due to Industry 4.0 and 5.0 frameworks increased the exposure to dependence on deep learning systems, which are ideal targets of advanced cyber-attacks. Traditional cybersecurity techniques are becoming insufficient to deal with the emerging trends, including covert attacks like backdoor attacks that interfere with the model integrity during the training of the model and interfere with outputs. A new, multi-layered smart cyber defence framework demanding a combination of threat modelling, data protection, and model protection has been presented in this paper to protect deep learning concept. The framework model is a permutation of both statistical and intelligent methods to avoid data privacy and confidentiality and extends structural measures of security management in terms of policies and procedures. It also presents ways of improving the sturdiness of models alongside attacks with the help of an adaptive threat model to identify the vulnerable points and implement countermeasures efficiently. An overview of back door attacks and defence mechanisms to back door attacks is given and a qualitative comparison of strategies in existence has been made. Last but not least, the paper identifies the future research directions to enhance exploit detection in deep learning by providing detailed suggestions on how the research can be taken further to promote research in resilient cyber defence towards the smart manufacturing systems.

title: Scalable Tea Leaf Disease Detection using the Fine Tuned EfficientNet-V2B3 Model
authors: Nagendar Yamsani, Shanvi Chauhan, Ritika Badhani, Ashwani Kharola
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: One of the beverages that is consumed universally is tea and its production is critical in promoting agricultural stability and enhancement within the economies of most developing economies. The development of tea is however greatly affected due to different types of Leaf disease which include Red Leaf Spot, Algal Leaf Spot, Birds Eyespot, Gray Blight, White Spot, Anthracnose, and Brown Blight that have disrupted yield and quality of tea. These diseases need to be early identified and corrected to have a sustainable agriculture, responsible consumption and food security into place. This paper presents an automated methods approach of disease classification of tea leaves utilizing a deep learning-efficientnet-v2b3 model. The dataset has 885 images, which are categorized into eight different classes and 708 images wherein they are used as training and 177 images as validation. An accuracy of 90% has been obtained with the proposed model on the validation set, showing that it is efficient enough to be able to differentiate the healthy and diseased leaves. EfficientNetV2B3 can be used to achieve the optimal performance at lower computational cost and therefore reduces the goal of climate action by supporting precision agriculture and reducing the use of chemicals. The study can add to sustainable farming practices through allowing smart disease monitoring systems that can lead to zero hunger, good health and well-being, and sustainable industrial innovation in the food industry.

title: Deep Learning based Image Inpainting and Restoration System using Partial Convolutional Networks, Autoencoders, and U-Net Architectures
authors: Yerugudidinne Anjaneyulu, Paradesi Mary Swetha, Vandavasi Priyanka, K. Vinod Kumar, Jayamangala Sristi, G Neelima
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: This paper introduces a deep learning-based image inpainting and restoration algorithm that takes into consideration both irregular and structured degradations using Partial Convolutional Networks (PConv), convolutional autoencoders and U-Net networks. The pipeline of the framework has three stages, PConv, Autoencoder, and U-Net, each with specialized roles: PConv performs a structure-aware filling of missing or corrupted sections of the picture, the autoencoder smooths out fine details and removes noise artifacts, and U-Net balances global and local features to be perceptually consistent. A hybrid loss function that incorporates masked reconstruction loss, structural similarity index measure (SSIM), and perceptual losses is used to direct the model to create visually plausible output. The learning method is tested on several official benchmark datasets that include free-form masks and real-life degradation patterns, where its performance in the peak signal-to-noise ratio (PSNR), SSIM, and learned perceptual image patch similarity (LPIPS) is compared to existing state-of-the-art techniques, showing an improvement by large margins. The experiments validate the performance of hybridization of structure-aware completion, feature refinement, and multi-scale semantic integration to restore image robustly.

title: Affine Frequency Division Multiplexing (AFDM) for 6G: Properties, Features, and Challenges
authors: Hyeon Seok Rou, Kuranage Roche Rayan Ranasinghe, Vincent Savaux, Giuseppe Thadeu Freitas de Abreu, G. David González, Christos Masouros
publish: IEEE Communications Standards Magazine
abstract: Affine frequency division multiplexing (AFDM) is an emerging waveform candidate for future sixth-generation (6G) systems offering a range of promising features, such as enhanced robustness in heterogeneous and high-mobility environments, as well as inherent suitability for integrated sensing and communications (ISAC) applications. In addition, unlike other candidates such as orthogonal time-frequency space (OTFS) modulation, AFDM provides several unique advantages that strengthen its relevance to practical deployment and standardization in 6G. Notably, as a natural generalization of orthogonal frequency division multiplexing (OFDM), strong backward compatibility with existing conventional systems is guaranteed, while also offering novel possibilities in waveform design, for example to enable physical-layer security through its inherent chirp parametrization. In all, this article provides an overview of AFDM, emphasizing its suitability as a candidate waveform for 6G standardization. First, we provide a concise introduction to the fundamental properties and unique characteristics of AFDM, followed by highlights of its advantageous features, and finally a discussion of its potential and challenges in 6G standardization efforts and representative requirements.

title: ToothSeg: Robust Tooth Instance Segmentation and Numbering in CBCT using Deep Learning and Self-Correction
authors: Niels van Nistelrooij, Lars Krämer, Steven Kempers, Michel Beyer, Federico Bolelli, Tong Xi, Stefaan Bergé, Max Heiland, Klaus H. Maier-Hein, Shankeeth Vinayahalingam, Fabian Isensee
publish: IEEE Journal of Biomedical and Health Informatics
abstract: Accurate interpretation of cone-beam computed tomography (CBCT) scans is critical for oral diagnosis and treatment planning. Existing methods for automated tooth segmentation in CBCT face challenges, such as difficulties in generalizing across imaging artifacts and anatomical variations, as well as requiring manual revisions in many cases. To address these limitations, this study introduces ToothSeg, a fully automated approach for tooth instance segmentation and numbering in CBCT using deep learning and self-correction. ToothSeg combines semantic and instance segmentation into a unified method where their respective strengths are complemented. In particular, self-correction is employed when combining the segmentations, resolving merged or split teeth and determining the optimal sequence of tooth numbers for each dental arch. We conducted a comprehensive evaluation using a diverse in-house dataset (n = 1282, 25+ devices) and the publicly available ToothFairy2 challenge dataset (n = 480, 1 device), including an ablation study, a comparison to state-of-the-art methods, and an analysis of challenging cases. Compared to an optimized semantic segmentation model, including instance segmentation and self-correction consistently improved tooth segmentation (True Positive Dice: 93.6% to 94.3%) and tooth detection and numbering (multiclass instance F1: 94.2% to 95.5%). Furthermore, ToothSeg outperformed the other methods on both datasets (True Positive Dice: <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\boldsymbol{\ge }$</tex-math></inline-formula> +0.4%, multiclass instance F1: <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\boldsymbol{\ge }$</tex-math></inline-formula> +1.8%), particularly for challenging cases. This study provides a promising approach for automated tooth segmentation and numbering in CBCT, which is significant for reducing manual workload and supporting scalable, data-driven research in oral and craniofacial health. Code and models are publicly available at <uri xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">https://github.com/MIC-DKFZ/ToothSeg</uri>.

title: Solution Approaches for the Dynamic Naval Air Defense Planning Problem_supp3-3648686.mp4
authors: Caner Arslan
publish: N/A
abstract: The naval air defense planning (NADP) problem entails the defense of a naval fleet against aerial threats. This complex and dynamic problem requires real-time decision-making and adaptation to evolving warfare environment. While our previous work addressed the static NADP problem by proposing a mathematical model and heuristic solutions for sensor allocation, engagement scheduling, and ship routing, this study extends to the dynamic NADP problem. Unlike the static version, which assumes complete knowledge of future threats, the dynamic NADP problem requires continuous updates and real-time adjustments to decisions as new threats emerge and situational parameters change. We present modifications in the mathematical formulation, which is based on a mixed-integer nonlinear programming (MINLP) model, alongside a comprehensive simulation structure. We employ heuristic solution approaches that utilize a combination of a genetic algorithm, construction of an engagement graph to solve the shortest path problem, and dynamic programming (DP) techniques. Computational experiments are conducted to evaluate the effectiveness of these methods in addressing the dynamic NADP problem. The study also explores machine learning models for threat prioritization, offering innovative solutions to the challenges posed by dynamic naval air defense scenarios.

title: An Ant Colony System for Passenger Assignment and Route Design of Urban Customized Bus With Flexible Pick-Ups and Drop-Offs_supp1-3648151.pdf
authors: wei-neng chen
publish: N/A
abstract: Urban customized bus (UCB) has become an important mode of urban transportation in recent years. To further enhance the applicability of UCB, we develop a UCB model that accommodates flexible pick-ups and drop-offs in this article. In our model, when a bus passes through a station, it can drop off passengers whose destination is exactly this station and pick up new passengers as long as constraints are satisfied. By eliminating fixed boarding and alighting regions that were commonly adopted in prior studies, we can provide travel services for both prebooked and real-time orders across broader temporal and spatial ranges. Under such a scenario, it is more challenging to decide when and where to pick up which passenger with which bus, and which route the bus chooses. To solve these intractable problems, we proposed an approach including passenger assignment and route design. For passenger assignment, we devise an ant colony system (ACS) method and a greedy method to assign prebooked and real-time passengers to buses, respectively. ACS represents the correlation among different passengers numerically through a pheromone matrix and updates it iteratively based on the good results. Therefore, prebooked passengers with higher correlations are more likely to be assigned to the same buses. The greedy method always selects passengers with the highest heuristic value to have a fast response in real-time passenger assignment. For route design, we adapt a Dijkstra-based greedy method to efficiently design routes for each bus in both static and dynamic situations. At last, experiments based on both generated data and real data demonstrate the superiority of the proposed method.

title: Ultrafast gated hyperspectral imaging system for spatial-spectral-temporal-resolved electroluminescence of miniaturized light emitting diodes
authors: Yi Lin, Lihong Zhu, Yunfeng Jiang, Guobao Zhao, Hongfei Liu, Shibiao Liu, Shouqiang Lai, Tingzhu Wu, Weijie Guo, Huanting Chen, Zhong Chen, Yijun Lu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
abstract: Miniaturized light-emitting diodes (Mini-/Micro-LEDs) for next-generation displays exhibit complex optoelectronic behaviors due to the shrunk chip size. Comprehensive multi-dimensional characterization is critical yet remains challenging for conventional techniques. In this work, we proposed an ultrafast gated hyperspectral imaging (UGHSI) system that synchronously captures spatial, spectral, and temporal dynamics in miniaturized LEDs, addressing the growing demand for high-resolution, multi-dimensional analysis of their complex transient behaviors. High-resolution two-dimensional (2-D) time-resolved electroluminescence (TREL) measurements are applied to demonstrate the system’s sub-micron spatial resolution and 500 picosecond temporal resolution. To enhance measurement accuracy, an optimized fitting model is developed to compensate the impact of the falling time of the electrical pulse signal on fluorescence lifetime. The 2-D fluorescent lifetime mappings for green Mini/Micro-LEDs derived from the 2-D TREL reveal distinct carrier distribution patterns and luminescence behaviors. In particular, the lifetime mappings clarify the enhanced anomalous emission at the sidewalls of the Mini/Micro-LEDs. In general, the proposed system achieves multi-dimensional optoelectronic characteristics with improved resolution and flexibility, providing a cutting-edge tool for studying complex behaviors of the next-generation devices and materials at microscopic and picosecond scales.

title: Order Shifting Temporal Phase Unwrapping for High-fidelity Dynamic 3D Measurement
authors: Jiayi Qin, Yansong Jiang, Yiping Cao
publish: IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
abstract: Fringe projection profilometry (FPP) has advanced from accurate 3D surface acquisition to achieving real-world sensing. A dynamic 3D measurement method based on order shifting temporal phase unwrapping (OSTPU) is proposed. It integrates true free-space adaptability, true color detection, and true 3D measurement. Unlike conventional phase unwrapping methods, OSTPU encodes fringe order shifts using Gray-coded patterns instead of assigning absolute fringe order values. This approach significantly reduces the number of independent numbers needed for accurate encoding. By encoding only eight unique codewords, both the efficiency and the robustness within a predefined depth range are effectively enhanced. Its transferable encoding strategy reduces complexity and enables plug-and-play. Channel-wise chromatic independence preserves high-fidelity color reproduction. Experimental results show the validity in real-world dynamic 3D measurement scenarios.

title: Study of Slide Ablation Characteristics during Pantograph-Lowering Based on Simulation and Arc Voltage Measurements
authors: Xiaokang Wang, Fuchuan Duan, Yang Song, Zhigang Liu, Long Chen
publish: IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
abstract: The process of pantograph-lowering in electric locomotives generates intense transient arcing, which significantly influences the service life of the pantograph-catenary (PC) contact pair. This paper investigates slide ablation during pantograph-lowering by incorporating heat dissipation from material evaporation, a factor not addressed in prior studies. First, a high-precision arc voltage acquisition system was developed and implemented under real railway conditions. This system served as the basis for validating the proposed Multiphysics-coupled transient arcing model. Subsequently, an ablation model was established to account for the effect of material evaporation on surface temperature evolution under transient arcing. Then, numerical simulations were conducted to reveal the temperature field distribution on the slide surface. Finally, the effects of pantograph-lowering voltages, pantograph-lowering speeds, and ambient wind speeds on the slide ablation were systematically analyzed. The results indicate that reducing the pantograph-lowering voltage and increasing the pantograph-lowering speed can effectively mitigate slide surface ablation. Furthermore, the transient arcing produces an arc-shaped ablation pit on the slide surface, with the peak temperature stabilizing at approximately 4000 K, close to the carbon sublimation point.

title: Reflectance of solar light from wet snowpack: direct and inverse problems
authors: Alexander Kokhanovsky, Karl Segl, Jörg Bendix
publish: IEEE Transactions on Geoscience and Remote Sensing
abstract: Wet snow is an important component of the cryosphere. It appears darker in the visible as compared to the fresh dry snow. This indicates the increased levels of light absorption in snow, which leads to the acceleration of snowmelt further increased by the exposure of light absorbing impurities, in turn having important climatic effects. In this paper a simple analytical model for the wet snow spectral reflectance is introduced and applied to remote sensing of snow from ground and space. The accuracy of the model is studied using experimental measurements of the light reflectance from wet snow.

title: Enhanced Segment Tree Approach for Multi-Attribute Numerical Data in k-Anonymization for Data Privacy
authors: Priyank Jain, Yashwant Aditya, Kolli Rakesh, Manasi Gyanchandani
publish: IEEE Transactions on Privacy
abstract: This research focuses on improving the k- Anonymization for numerical attributes by optimizing the critical phases of clustering and generalization through a novel Segment Tree-Based k-Anonymization (STKA) framework. Traditional methods face significant limitations: sorted-based approaches require costly re-sorting (O(n log n)) for dynamic updates; unsorted methods rely on inefficient linear scans (O(n)) for range queries; and dynamic methods suffer from frequent recalculations causing performance bottlenecks. Beyond computational efficiency, ensuring robust data privacy while minimizing information loss remains a central challenge in anonymization. Excessive generalization often safeguards privacy at the expense of data utility, whereas insufficient anonymization risks sensitive information disclosure. The proposed STKA framework effectively balances this trade-off by achieving optimal partitioning that enhances privacy protection while preserving high data usability. The proposed STKA framework addresses the aforementioned limitations by achieving logarithmic time complexity O(log n) for both min-max range queries and updates, eliminating resorting and recalculations. Compared to traditional approaches, STKA demonstrates: (1) 67% faster build time than sortedbased methods like ISKA/IAKA when handling dynamic updates; (2) 89% improvement in query response time over unsorted methods like WF-C-means and PCAA; (3) 35% reduction in information loss compared to dynamic approaches like CASTLE and FAANST; and (4) superior scalability for both batch and streaming data with minimal computational overhead. The experimental evaluation on datasets up to 1M records shows that STKA consistently outperforms state-of-the-art methods (MRA, SKA, IAKA, ISKA, MIAE) across multiple k-values, achieving 14.8-24.1% information loss compared to 31.2-53.1% for traditional methods, thereby delivering a more privacypreserving yet information-rich anonymization framework for large-scale data environments.

title: Ratio-Enhanced Feature Interaction for Few-Shot User Authentication Using Running Data in IoT Wearables
authors: Zhen Chen, Zhihua Ding, Niangen Ye, Jiayi Zhu, Wei Yuan, Weiqiang Sun
publish: IEEE Internet of Things Journal
abstract: With the rapid growth of wearable devices and the Internet of Things (IoT), users increasingly rely on smartwatches and fitness trackers for services in connected environments. These devices collect sensitive physiological and behavioral data, requiring reliable user authentication to ensure secure access by authorized users. However, few-shot scenarios with significant intra-class variability and limited training data make it challenging for models to capture complex feature interactions. In this paper, we propose a Ratio-Enhanced Feature Interaction (RE-FI) framework designed for wearable running data. RE-FI systematically constructs pairwise product and ratio-based cross features to explicitly model second-order interactions and applies information gain–based feature selection to retain the most discriminative features. We provide theoretical justification for these design choices across linear models, tree-based classifiers, and deep neural networks. We validate RE-FI on real-world running data using nine representative classifiers. Results show that RE-FI consistently outperforms the baseline feature set across all classifiers, achieving an average accuracy improvement of 4.2% and up to 6.2% in F1-score. In extreme few-shot settings with only five samples per user, RE-FI maintains robust performance, with Random Forest achieving an average accuracy of 86%. Overall, this work offers a computationally simple feature-interaction solution that is compatible with diverse supervised models on session-level wearable statistical features and provides a principled approach for wearable security and personalized health monitoring in IoT applications.

title: A Novel Complex-Variable Prediction-Correction Method Applied to Beamforming Design
authors: Sai Wang, Yi Gong
publish: IEEE Signal Processing Letters
abstract: Complex-variable matrix optimization problems are fundamental in signal processing and related engineering applications, yet existing methods often become computationally inefficient when handling high-dimensional variables and nonlinear constraints. In this paper, we propose a novel prediction-correction method for complex-variable optimization based on a variational inequality framework. This method directly operates in the complex domain and achieves an ergodic convergence rate of <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\mathcal {O}(1/t)$</tex-math></inline-formula> under mild conditions. Numerical results on a practical beamforming design problem demonstrate that the proposed approach achieves comparable solution accuracy to conventional methods while reducing the computational time by more than three orders of magnitude.

title: Signal Whisperers: Enhancing Wireless Reception Using DRL-Guided Reflector Arrays
authors: Hieu Le, Oguz Bedir, Mostafa Ibrahim, Jian Tao, Sabit Ekin
publish: IEEE Transactions on Machine Learning in Communications and Networking
abstract: This paper presents a multi-agent reinforcement learning (MARL) approach for controlling adjustable metallic reflector arrays to enhance wireless signal reception in non-line-of-sight (NLOS) scenarios. Unlike conventional reconfigurable intelligent surfaces (RIS) that require complex channel estimation, our system employs a centralized training with decentralized execution (CTDE) paradigm where individual agents corresponding to reflector segments autonomously optimize reflector element orientation in three-dimensional space using spatial intelligence based on user location information. Through extensive ray-tracing simulations with dynamic user mobility, the proposed multi-agent beam-focusing framework demonstrates substantial performance improvements over single-agent reinforcement learning baselines, while maintaining rapid adaptation to user movement within one simulation step. Comprehensive evaluation across varying user densities and reflector configurations validates system scalability and robustness. The results demonstrate the potential of learning-based approaches for adaptive wireless propagation control.

title: Solving Volume Scattering Ambiguity between Forests and Urban Areas in PolSAR Data Considering Backscatter's Wavelength Dependence
authors: Dingfeng Duan, Yong Wang
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: A method developed for the L-band PolSAR data analysis was migrated to the C-band case in this study. The scattering models of upland forests are optimized and revised considering the uniqueness of the radar C- and L-bands. Then, the separation factor for the L-band data was revised and improved to solve the volume scattering ambiguity between upland forests and oriented urban areas at the C -band. We verified the effectiveness of the proposed method using the Radarsat-2 C-band PolSAR data from San Francisco, CA, USA. With the improved separation factor, the upland forests' correct classification rate was 88.6%, a 2.4% increase before the improvement. The rate of the urban targets was 58.7%, an increase of 11.8% without the improvement. The study should further the understanding of PolSAR data through the PolSAR decomposition in forested and urban environments as the anticipated wavelength dependence of radar backscatter is investigated and addressed.
