title: A PRS-less Resonant Cavity Antenna with Suppressed Sidelobe and Compact Size
authors: Qing-Yi Guo, Mingxuan Liang, Hang Wong
publish: IEEE Transactions on Antennas and Propagation
abstract: Reducing size and side lobe level (SLL) is essential for resonant cavity (RC) type antenna. This paper proposes a PRS-less RC antenna with compact size, low profile and sidelobes. It is the first attempt to apply a hybrid cavity with a dielectric slab and a shaped ground with power manipulation (SGPM) function. Different from traditional un-equal power dividers utilized in array, herein, we proposed the SGPM to manipulate power distribution on the radiation aperture of a RC antenna. In addition, due to the utilization of the dielectric slab, intrinsic partially reflection can be occurred at the aperture interface between the dielectric and air. This achieves RC response while eliminating the usage of a separate partially reflective surface (PRS), which is often independently required in a conventional RC antenna. For validation, a prototype using the proposed design method is fabricated and measured. Its profile is 0.25 λ<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">0</sub>. The SLL of the design is less than 18 dB across the operating band. Its peak aperture efficiency can reach to 69.1%. The overlapped operating bandwidth exceeds 13%. Compared to other RC antennas, the proposed design has characteristics of miniaturization, wideband, PRS-less, low SLL and low-profile.

title: Map-Guided Cross-Training for Building Detection
authors: Anna Zawadzka, Mateusz Żarski, Kamil Drejer, Przemysław Głomb, Michał Romaszewski, Michał Cholewa
publish: IEEE Geoscience and Remote Sensing Letters
abstract: Extraction of building footprints from freely available, high temporal resolution satellite imagery is important for applications ranging from disaster response to monitoring informal settlements. While Sentinel-2 is globally available, limited spatial resolution restricts the reliable detection of small or densely packed structures. We propose a novel framework that re-targets a super-resolution backbone (ESRGAN) to generate cartographic map-style outputs directly and fuses it with a semantic segmentation network through joint training. Unlike pipelines treating super-resolution and detection as sequential tasks, our approach leverages map-centric supervision, unifying enhancement and building delineation. For evaluation, we introduce the S2-BDOT-PL dataset, integrating Sentinel-2 imagery with OpenStreetMap and BDOT10k ground truth. Results demonstrate improved precision and robustness in small-building detection compared to native resolution baselines.

title: DTLN: Deep Transformer Learning Network for Multi-Wavelength Strain Classification in Sports Wearables
authors: R. Gopi, S. Manikandan, Sunita Nitin Dhote, Srinath Doss, S. Baskar, R Sampath, Mohamed Shakeel Pethuraj
publish: IEEE Sensors Journal
abstract: Wearable Piezoresistive pressure sensors measure the electrical resistance change under mechanical strain, but existing methods struggle with heterogeneous wavelength classification due to amplitude overlaps and intensity variations. Additionally, changes in electrical resistance caused by mechanical strain are utilized for detecting and mapping Stress and strain during physical activity, as well as identifying surface roughness and its impact on the athlete. This article introduces a Deep Transformer Learning Network (DTLN) based solution that combines transformer-based self-attention mechanisms with deep learning classifications to enhance strain detection accuracy. The DTLN addresses wavelength signal differences based on ascending intensities to compute the maximum difference between the impacting outputs and also classifies negative and positive differences. These outputs are correlated with the maximum strain acceptance factors to ensure that identified impacts on the sportsperson are accurately assessed. Therefore, the transformer learning classification is updated based on the previously trained difference to identify various wavelength intensities. Thus, the proposed method detects strain impacts over the sportsperson’s practice sessions. The proposed method improved strain detection by 13.2% and difference classification by 14.01%, reducing the error factor by 14.53% for average pressure. This work advances wearable sensor analytics by providing a scalable and accurate method for real-time strain impact assessment in athletic applications.

title: Design and Fabrication of AIN Thick Film Arc-Shaped Piezoelectric Energy Harvester
authors: Ting Lv, Vasiliy Pelenovich, Chang Xu, Xiaomei Zeng, Dongyang Hou, Fang Dong, Sheng Liu
publish: IEEE Sensors Journal
abstract: To achieve more efficient energy harvesting, an arc-shaped piezoelectric thick film energy harvester is proposed in this work, which is fabricated by depositing the 10 μm aluminum nitride (AlN) piezoelectric film on a stainless steel (SS) substrate using magnetron sputtering technique. Through theoretical analysis and simulation, the structural design and stress distribution in the arc-shaped piezoelectric thick film harvester are optimized, which enhances the electrical signal output of the sensitive unit, thus improves the output power. Additionally, the SS as a substrate not only enhances the adaptability of the device to environmental vibration, but also avoids complex and costly photolithography and etching processes. The AlN thick film deposited on the SS substrate exhibits good c-axis orientation and density. Under 1 g acceleration, corresponding to matching resistance of 125 kΩ, the arc-shaped piezoelectric energy harvester delivers a maximum V<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">RMS</sub> output of 2.38 V at 355 Hz resonant frequency, yielding an output power of 45.3 μW. The optimization of piezoelectric thick film and structure paves a new path for high-performance piezoelectric energy harvesters.

title: Spiking Neural P Systems for Conversion between Number Systems
authors: Hongsen Zhang, Ping Guo, Xiaotong Liu, Chaoliang Li, Maosheng Zhong
publish: IEEE Transactions on NanoBioscience
abstract: A number system is a method for representing numbers. Efficient conversion between digital systems is crucial in human-computer interaction and computer information processing. This paper first constructed two SNP systems for the conversions between decimal and binary. Then, a family of SNP systems is constructed, which can convert between two arbitrary number systems. Examples are given to illustrate and verify the feasibility and effectiveness of these SNP systems. Compared with advanced similar systems, the proposed SNP system requires only approximately 1/3 the time slices for decimal-to-binary conversion and approximately 43% for binary-to-decimal conversion.

title: Shear Phase-shifting and Common-Mode Suppression for Displacement Interferometry
authors: Jiakun Li, Yibin Qian, Hongyu Sun, Xiao Wang, Shuai Han, Qibo Feng
publish: IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
abstract: High-end equipment development (e.g., CNC machine tools, lithography machines) drives demand for miniaturized, embedded, high-precision multi-degree-of-freedom motion measurement technologies. While laser interferometry provides non-contact, long-range precision measurements, conventional homodyne interferometry is environmentally sensitive, which limits its applications. Traditional methods usually use multiple beam-split elements to achieve spatial phase-shifting and collect interference signals with fixed phase differences through four incompletely co-pathed photodetectors to achieve common-mode suppression. However, it fails to eliminate path-specific noise and increasing system bulk. This paper proposes a novel method of shear phase-shifting and common-mode suppression for displacement interferometry. Polarization shearing is innovatively used to realize interferometric phase-shifting, and a Birefringent Crystal (BC) takes the place of the traditional complicated splitting and phase delay components. The new optical structure combined with the linear array photodetector can easily collect the interference signal with a fixed phase difference. Then, by parallel differential operation, the common-mode suppression can be realized in real time. The correction for DC error, AC amplitude inequality error, and non-orthogonality error is implemented by embedded digital processing. Compared with the traditional method, the proposed method has obvious anti-interference advantages and greatly simplifies the opto-mechanical structure. A prototype device was tested on a commercial linear stage, demonstrating 0.028 μm stability over 60 minutes and repeatability errors of ±0.032 μm, ±0.063 μm, ±0.046 μm, and ±0.110 μm at 25 mm, 50 mm, 75 mm, and 100 mm ranges, respectively,, which verifies the effectiveness of the proposed method and provides a new scheme with a simple structure and high precision for displacement interferometric measurement. The subsequent instrumentation design is capable of fulfilling the requirements of miniaturized embedded measurement.

title: DA-GAN: Dual-Attention GAN for Underwater Image Enhancement with Contrast and Color Correction
authors: Xiaopeng Liu, Honghao Xu, Yakun Ju, Shengke Wang, Cong Liu, Long Chen
publish: IEEE Transactions on Geoscience and Remote Sensing
abstract: Underwater images typically suffer from severe color distortion, low contrast, and poor visibility due to light absorption and scattering in aquatic environments. To address these challenges, we propose a novel Dual-Attention GAN (DA-GAN), specifically designed to enhance contrast and correct color distortions in underwater images. DA-GAN features three key innovations: a Hybrid CNN-Attention Bottleneck Layer (HCABL) for efficient enhancement of local and global features, a Transformer-based Channel Attention Module (TCAM) for color distortion removal, and a Multi-Color Space Loss function to improve contrast and visibility. HCABL employs parallel attention mechanisms and depth-wise separable convolutions to enhance both global context and local spatial details. TCAM enhances the model’s sensitivity to various color channels, enabling effective correction of complex color distortions. Furthermore, the Multi-Color Space Loss function, tailored for the HSV color space and the image’s bright and dark channels, further enhance contrast and visibility. Comprehensive ablation studies validate the effectiveness of each component, while extensive comparison experiments demonstrate that DA-GAN achieves state-of-the-art or comparable performance across six public underwater image datasets (SUIM, UIEB, EUVP, LSUI, UCCS and SQUID). The source code is publicly available at https: //github.com/littlebearRedgood/DAGAN.

title: P3-FSLNet: A Compact Spatio-Temporal Model With Contrastive Few-Shot Learning for Subject-Independent P300 Detection in Devanagari Script-Based P300 Speller
authors: Vibha Bhandari, Narendra D. Londhe, Ghanahshyam B. Kshirsagar
publish: IEEE Transactions on Human-Machine Systems
abstract: Brain–computer interface (BCI) systems frequently necessitate time-intensive subject-specific calibration, thereby motivating the development of subject-independent P300 detection approaches. Existing methodologies that employ transfer learning and knowledge distillation encounter challenges with limited generalizability due to substantial intersubject variability and constrained data availability. Furthermore, their applicability is often questioned, as most lack comprehensive external validation and cross-script evaluation. To address these limitations, we introduce P3-FSLNet, a few-shot metalearning framework that integrates prototypical networks and contrastive learning within a spatial-temporal convolutional neural network augmented by dual-channel attention for the selection of relevant electroencephalogram channels. Episodic metatraining facilitates the transfer of robust knowledge across different subjects. Evaluated on a self-recorded Devanagari script dataset, P3-FSLNet attains a classification accuracy of 93.17%, surpassing state-of-the-art methods by 1%–14%, while simultaneously reducing trainable parameters by up to 400 times. External validation using English-script datasets from BCI Competition II and III confirms its robustness in cross-subject and cross-script generalization. These findings demonstrate the efficacy of P3-FSLNet and represent a substantial advancement toward the development of script-agnostic P300 spellers that are lightweight, scalable, and conducive to multilingual applications.

title: A Macro-to-Micro Layout Optimization Scheme for Functional Interwoven Areas of Commercial Complex
authors: Jingxuan Peng, Zhonghua Wei, Xueying Tong, Xuwen Jia, Yanyan Chen, Yongxing Li, Fujiyama Taku
publish: IEEE Transactions on Computational Social Systems
abstract: In commercial complexes, the functional interwoven areas (FIA) with multiple attributes shops accommodate diverse population of pedestrians with heterogeneous travel purposes. A well-designed layout scheme of FIA can effectively increase the revenue while reduce the pedestrian congestion. However, existing layout schemes are more developed from the operator’s perspective, focusing on maximizing rents while neglecting shop attributes and pedestrians heterogeneity, which results in excessive corridor congestion and suboptimal store visit rates. To address these issues, this article proposes a novel macro-to-micro layout optimization framework that enhances pedestrian in-store rate while mitigating internal congestion. The proposed framework consists of two stages: 1) a macrolevel optimization model which generates multiple feasible layout schemes by using shop attributes based attractiveness algorithm; and 2) a microlevel simulation model which evaluates pedestrian movement dynamics and corridor density under different layouts by integrating an attractive potential based social force model (AP-SFM). Based on parameters calibrated from real collected data, we conduct extensive numerical and simulation experiments across two distinct commercial complexes: 1) China World Mall (CWM); and 2) Shin Kong Place (SKP). The results demonstrate that the optimized layouts significantly increase pedestrian in-store rates while effectively reducing average corridor density and alleviating local congestion, without altering the total pedestrian volume. Furthermore, the successful application in two distinct commercial complexes proves the validity, rationality, and generality of the proposed framework. Our research effectively integrates shop diversity and pedestrian heterogeneity into shop layout optimization, providing a practical and scalable decision-support tool for layout design and management.

title: Accelerated Physics-Guided Diffusion Model for 3D Limited-Angle Reconstruction of Cardiac Computed Tomography
authors: Shuo Han, Bahareh Morovati, Yongtong Liu, Changsheng Fang, Shuyi Fan, Li Zhou, Yu Shi, Ge Wang, Hengyong Yu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Radiation and Plasma Medical Sciences
abstract: Cardiovascular diseases (CVDs) remain the leading cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. Computed tomography (CT) plays an important role in the diagnosis and management of CVDs. However, the temporal resolution of current cardiac CT imaging techniques is still insufficient to freeze the beating heart. One solution to improve temporal resolution is fast data acquisition for a limited-angle range. Unfortunately, this approach introduces significant limited-angle artifacts that compromise image quality. Diffusion models have shown promising results to address this issue by effectively reconstructing missing data, but the process is typically time-consuming. In this paper, we propose a novel method for 3D limited-angle reconstruction using a diffusion model, optimized to significantly reduce computational time. Specifically, our approach integrates the regularized derivative least square (RDLS) algorithm with denoising diffusion implicit models. The numerical simulations and clinical data experiments demonstrate that the proposed model outperforms the existing methods both quantitatively and qualitatively. Compared with DDS, our method delivers a 1.8× speedup on the simulated dataset and a 3.4× speedup on the real clinical dataset.

title: Cooperative Spectrum Sensing and Sharing in PD-NOMA Cognitive Radio Networks
authors: Gilbert W. Machani, Tom Walingo
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: Spectrum efficiency, spectrum sensing (SS) and sharing are core requirements of a reliable communication network to maximize the utilization of the scarce radio frequency spectrum. This research advances the development of efficient spectrum sharing techniques in CRN by integrating cooperative spectrum sensing and power domain non-orthogonal multiple access (PD-NOMA). As wireless systems are expected to utilize the spectrum resources efficiently, they must be able to mitigate interference with primary users and operate within the required throughput levels. Existing works consider either spectrum sensing or spectrum sharing separately, and often ignore the effect of cooperation and hybrid spectrum sharing on the overall system performance. This work presents and evaluates a novel framework that combines cooperative spectrum sensing and a hybrid interweave-underlay spectrum sharing mode for application in IoT-CRN. The network features multiple cognitive users (CUs) switching between interweave and underlay modes depending on availability of spectrum holes. This hybrid mode combines the advantages of opportunistically accessing the channel and transmitting with controlled power and interference. The model features a Gaussian mixture model (GMM)-based channel estimator sensing mechanism that enables individual CUs to determine the availability of holes. The formulated channel occupancy problem is evaluated using adaptive particle swarm optimization (PSO). The occupancy is cooperatively shared to the fusion center (FC) for the final decision on the availability of PUs with penalties applied to misbehaving CUs. The results of the proposed model show a 28% and 35% better throughput performance than the existing models and a 15% higher probability of detection while accommodating different CU traffic.

title: Scaling Through Pruning for Resource-Aware Embedded Intrusion Detection on the Edge
authors: Alexandre Broggi, Nathaniel D. Bastian, Lance Fiondella, Gokhan Kul
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: Artificial neural network pruning is a method in which artificial neural network sizes can be reduced while attempting to preserve the predicting capabilities of the network. This is done to make the model smaller or faster during inference time. In this work we analyze the ability of a selection of artificial neural network pruning methods to generalize to a new cybersecurity dataset utilizing a simpler network type than was designed for. We analyze each method using a variety of pruning degrees to best understand how each algorithm responds to the new environment. This has allowed us to determine the most well fit pruning method of those we searched for the task. Unexpectedly, we have found that many of them do not generalize to the problem well, leaving only a few algorithms working to an acceptable degree.

title: Reinforcement Learning-Based Feeder Link Switchover for Handover Optimization in NTN
authors: Min-Sik Kim, Jae-Yeol Lee, Jae-Hyun Kim
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: Low Earth orbit (LEO) satellite networks provide global broadband. However, their high orbital velocity (7–8 km/s) causes frequent communication link variations, requiring feeder link switchover (FLSO) between LEO satellites and ground gateways (GWs). In the hard FLSO policy, LEO satellites trigger simultaneous user equipments (UEs) handovers (HOs) during FLSO, degrading service quality and increasing latency in non-terrestrial networks (NTN). In battlefield scenarios, frequent HOs in battery-powered equipments lead to power consumption, delay, and outage, impairing communication. In this paper, we proposes a reinforcement learning-based FLSO using a dueling deep Q-Network (DQN) to optimize FLSO and UE HO in dynamic environments. We achieve lower FLSO and UE HO occurrences and longer time-of-stay (ToS) compared to other algorithms, while maintaining satisfactory reference signal received power (RSRP) and channel capacity. The proposed algorithm also yields the fewest HOs across varying UE spatial dispersions.

title:
A 0.47 nJ/Conversion CMOS Temperature Sensor with 0.00786 mm
                    <sup>2</sup>
                    Core in 65nm CMOS
authors: Hangfei Song, Yichi Zhang, Aili Wang
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Integrated Circuits and Microsystems (ICICM)
abstract: This paper presents a CMOS transistor-based temperature sensor for heat management. The temperature sensor generates proportional to absolute temperature (PTAT) and complementary to absolute temperature (CTAT) voltages through a 4-transistor front-end sensing structure leveraging both native NMOS and standard NMOS. Using this structure brings three benefits: 1) the lower supply sensitivity; 2) the better linearity of PTAT and CTAT voltages with the same area overhead; 3) the lower power consumption. A novel 8-bit successive approximation register (SAR) quantization scheme adjusts the capacitor ratio to drive the CTAT voltage to the PTAT voltage, achieving a linear output code. The sensor has a core area of $0.00786 \mathrm{~mm}^{2}$ in standard 65 nm CMOS technology. After a 2-point calibration, the sensor achieves $-0.69 /+0.77^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ inaccuracy over the temperature range of $0^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ to $100^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$. The supply sensitivity is $1.25^{\circ} \mathrm{C} / \mathrm{V}$ when measured across the supply range of 0.9 V to 1.3 V. At a conversion time of $182 \mu \mathrm{~s}$, a resolution of $0.51{ }^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ is achieved. Operating from a supply of 1.2 V, it consumes $2.58 \mu \mathrm{~W}$, which yields a $0.123 \mathrm{~nJ} \cdot \mathrm{~K}^{2}$ resolution figure-of-merit (FOM).

title: A Novel Self-adaptive Dead-time Control Circuit Design for GaN Gate Drive Circuit
authors: Shupeng Yan, Shengqi Yu, Yi Huang, Junjie Yi, Pengyu Wang
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Integrated Circuits and Microsystems (ICICM)
abstract: Gallium Nitride (GaN) power electronic devices represent a core technology of the third generation of semiconductor materials, with primary applications in high-efficiency power conversion and high-frequency, high-power systems. In half-bridge configurations, a dead time must be introduced to prevent shoot-through. However, due to the lack of an intrinsic body diode in GaN devices, the reverse conduction voltage drop during the dead time is significantly higher than that of silicon-based devices, leading to substantial reverse conduction losses. These losses are further exacerbated at high frequencies due to increased switching and reverse conduction losses. Therefore, adaptive dead-time control is essential for optimizing the trade-off between efficiency and reliability. This paper analyzes the impact of dead time on the efficiency and reliability of GaN gate driver integrated circuits and proposes a novel dead-time logic control architecture design. The proposed design comprises four key modules: a negative voltage detection module (NVDM), a negative voltage control module (NVCM), a dead-time logic control module (DTLCM), and a slope current detection module (SCDM). The NVDM identifies negative voltage within 5 ns, while the NVCM enables near-zero-latency dead-time adjustment. The SCDM estimates current switching based on the voltage slew rate at the switching node. The proposed design achieves a minimum dead time of 0.7 ns and a maximum of 10.5 ns. The variation range of the falling-edge dead time is 22.2% wider compared to existing dead-time architectures.

title: Deep Learning for Retinal OCT Disease Classification using EfficientNetB0: A Transfer Learning Approach
authors: Nagendar Yamsani, Parul Nasra, Ritika Badhani, Ashwani Kharola
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: Retina diseases that may permanently blind are choroidal neovascularisation (CNV), diabetic macular oedema (DME), and drusen. This brings out the importance of identifying them at an early age so that they can be treated and individuals do not end up blind. Nevertheless, retinal Optical Coherence Tomography (OCT) images are difficult to assess manually, highly specialised and susceptible to observer variability thus posing a bottleneck in ocular diagnostics. This study introduces an automated sickness classifier of retinal OCT, having used the architecture of EfficientNetB7, a deep convolutional neural network with a distinguished characteristic of having outstanding scalability and accuracy through scaling of compounds. The proposed system is based on the OCT2017 dataset, containing approximately 84,000 OCT images that are classified into 4 categories: CNV, DME, drusen, and normal. Sizing down of images, normalisation of images and inclusion of lots of new data are all done to ensure that the model is capable of adjusting to variations in scan quality, patient demographics and imaging conditions. The model modulates the feature representations based on the characteristics of retinal disorders using the transfer learning using ImageNet-pretrained EfficientNetB7 weights. The validity of the system is experimentally determined to be very high, and accuracy of the system is balanced, as there is no difference in terms of precision, recall and the F1 scores between the different types of diseases. The confusion matrix analysis confirms that a reliable differentiation can be made even under the circumstances when it seems that two things are similar visually. It is a deep learning based solution that offers a scalable, high-performance, and effective solution in assisting eye doctors to make clinical judgements. It is beneficial to patients in the long run because it allows them to make diagnoses more accurately and faster.

title: Supply Chain Exploitation of Secure ROS 2 Systems: A Proof-of-Concept on Autonomous Platform Compromise via Keystore Exfiltration
authors: Tahmid Hasan Sakib, Yago Romano Martinez, Carter Brady, Syed Rafay Hasan, Terry N. Guo
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: This paper presents a proof-of-concept supply chain attack against the Secure ROS 2 (SROS 2) framework, demonstrated on a Quanser QCar2 autonomous vehicle platform. A Trojan infected Debian package modifies core ROS 2 security commands to exfiltrate newly generated keystore credentials via DNS in base64-encoded chunks to an attacker-controlled nameserver. Possession of these credentials enables the attacker to rejoin the SROS 2 network as an authenticated participant and publish spoofed control or perception messages without triggering authentication failures. We evaluate this capability on a secure ROS 2 Humble testbed configured for a four-stop-sign navigation routine using an Intel RealSense camera for perception. Experimental results show that control-topic injections can cause forced braking, sustained high-speed acceleration, and continuous turning loops, while perception-topic spoofing can induce phantom stop signs or suppress real detections. The attack generalizes to any data distribution service (DDS)-based robotic system using SROS 2, highlighting the need for both supply chain integrity controls and runtime semantic validation to safeguard autonomous systems against insider and impersonation threats.

title: Next-Generation AI-Enabled Incident Responses for Military Cloud Networks
authors: Vasil Boshnakov, Konrad Wrona, Caglar Ege Baser
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: We explore the feasibility of a next-generation AI-enabled automated incident response approach for military networks hosted on cloud infrastructure, utilizing infrastructure-as-code principles to enable rapid and scalable recovery mechanisms. The methodology includes isolating compromised components, preserving evidence for forensic analysis, and rebuilding affected resources to ensure the continuity of critical military services. The proposed approach provides a resilient, automated, and scalable solution to maintain critical service availability during cyber incidents. The experimental results are analyzed to validate the effectiveness of the methodology in real-world military network scenarios. We describe the challenges faced while executing incident response in the cloud. We also discuss the integration of autonomous cyber defense agents for automating incident detection and response. The paper outlines the possible further implementations of decoys, transforming the environment into a continuous training ground for the red team and eventual AI vs. AI playground.

title: Financing Power Startups: Strategies for Maintaining Control With Long Development Cycles [Entrepreneur’s Viewpoint]

title: A Sub-nanosecond Delay and 200V/ns CMTI Level Shifter for GaN HEMTs Gate Driver
authors: Shengqi Yu, Pengyu Wang, Junjie Yi, Shupeng Yan, Yi Huang
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Integrated Circuits and Microsystems (ICICM)
abstract: In next-generation power electronics technology, GaN devices show outstanding characters to the requirements of high-frequency and high-power density. The core role in highreliability GaN gate drivers is high-speed and noise-resistant level shifter. However, existing level shifter solutions suffer from issues such as the excessive signal transmission delay and weak common mode transient immunity (CMTI), which severely limit the performance of GaN devices. This paper addresses these issues by incorporating two auxiliary capacitors in the two pulse control branch nodes of the level shift main circuit, leveraging their charging and discharging characteristics to significantly reduce signal transmission delay. Implemented in $0.18 \mu \mathrm{~m}$ HV SOI CMOS process, simulation results show the proposed design reduces up to 56.08% delay for the rising edge and 50.43% delay for the falling edge when compared with existing scenarios. Additionally, the proposed design gains dV/dt noise suppression capability up to $200 \mathrm{~V} / \mathrm{ns}$.

title: SpeakSmart: An NLP-based Conversational Tutor for Language Learners
authors: Kasilingam N, Saakshi S Moolya, Sushma Umesh Manappanavar, Vijayashri J M, Kavana Y S
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: This paper presents the development of a chatbot designed for language learning, which uses English as the medium of instruction to help students learn Kannada. By leveraging conversational AI and natural language processing (NLP) techniques, the chatbot enables interactive, real-time dialogues that promote vocabulary expansion, grammatical comprehension, and conversational fluency. Unlike traditional learning methods, the chatbot reflects real-world communication scenarios for practical usage, provides personalized feedback, and adapts to the learner’s proficiency level. By combining multilingual text processing, context-aware dialogue management, and translation modules, the system fosters a self-paced learning environment. The chatbot is a promising digital tool for second-language acquisition, particularly in low-resource languages like Kannada, as evidenced by experimental assessments and user feedback showing its effectiveness in improving learner engagement and retention.

title: Secure Key Derivation via RF Sensing with ISAC in 5G/6G Tactical Systems (Demo)
authors: Robert Zakrzewski, Mark A. Beach
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: Widespread wireless communication demands robust security management to prevent adversaries from exploiting ubiquitous radio signals. Traditionally, such security is enforced through mitigation strategies implemented at higher layers using symmetric and/or asymmetric cryptography. However, this introduces increasing complexity, particularly due to the key derivation and exchange mechanisms required. This challenge is further exacerbated in private networks, which often necessitate configuration and deployment at the tactical or ad-hoc level in hostile environments, where physical interception or cryptanalysis by adversaries is a significant risk.To address this, we propose a solution that performs key derivation by exploiting 5G waveforms and integrated sensing and communication (ISAC). This approach enables the extraction of highly correlated data between legitimate parties by leveraging the reciprocity of radio channels, while preventing eavesdroppers from replicating the key derivation process.In this demonstration, we show that incorporating physical-layer information introduces geographical awareness between communicating parties, without compromising the entropy and keys generation rate. Furthermore, we demonstrate that our method effectively prevents eavesdroppers from obtaining the information needed to compromise the derived keys. Finally, we implement the system using software-defined radio within the 5G FR1 frequency bands, achieving a 100% key agreement rate with high entropy across a range of environments.

title: Fix My Ride: A Machine Learning-Enabled Platform for Intelligent Automotive Assistance
authors: Gnanakumar D, Pavan Siva Kumar S, Omkara Anjaneya Kumar R, Jnapika Naga Deepthi P, Yuva Rami Reddy G
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: The main problem for vehicle owners today is lack of trust between mechanics and users, language communication issues, and no proper online presence for many small mechanics. To solve this, Fix My Ride is designed as a location-based web and mobile platform that shows nearby mechanics, charging points, petrol stations, and service facilities using live maps. The system uses a machine learning model to recommend the best mechanic in the user's area based on factors like service quality, price history, customer ratings, and language support. Mechanics can register and update their profile, while users can see verified details, estimated costs, and book services directly. The platform includes ‘Save Our Souls’ (SOS) emergency help, multilingual interface, and premium listing options for service providers. This approach improves transparency, reduces fraud, and ensures users get faster and more accurate (91%) suggestions, while giving mechanics better visibility and digital presence.

title: QIH-FoodNet: A Quantum-Inspired Hybrid Deep Learning Model for Real-Time Food Quality Assessment
authors: Mary Harin Fernandez F, Srikanth Lakumarapu, Venkata Ramana T, Ramya R, Mahammad Shabana
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: Food quality and safety maintenance are needed in preventing foodborne illnesses and wastage reduction. Conventional food quality assessment machine learning models are inefficient in feature extraction, computationally expensive, and sensor data fusion limited. In this study, we propose QIH-FoodNet, a Quantum-Inspired Hybrid Deep Learning Model that is a fusion of Quantum Neural Networks (QNNs), Capsule Networks, and Graph Neural Networks (GNNs) for real-time food quality assessment. The QNN enhances image-based feature extraction, the Capsule Network facilitates spatial feature representation, and the GNN addresses multimodal sensor data (pH, gas levels, temperature, and moisture). The proposed model is implemented in RStudio and evaluated on real-world food quality datasets. Experimental results demonstrate that QIH-FoodNet achieves 98.1% accuracy, outperforming traditional CNN-LSTM (92.5%) and Transformer-based (94.6%) models. Comparative assessment and visualization of food images, sensor data distributions, and classification metrics further attest to the stability of the proposed model. This study demonstrates QIH-FoodNet as an innovative, efficient, and interpretable AI-based food safety system suitable for real-time deployment in supply chains and smart food monitoring.

title: MineSmart: IoT-based Smart Safety Helmet for Mining Workers
authors: Rithika G, Suresh Maruthai, Sai Ananya R
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: Mining is a risky job, with miners face a host of hazards, including toxic gasses, restricted oxygen, poor visibility, and the ever-present chance of accidents. Reducing casualties and injuries requires real-time safety monitoring and prompt responses. This project proposes an Internet of Things (IoT)-enabled intelligent helmet, designed to improve miner safety. It will use sensors, radio frequency (RF) transmission, and location tracking with beacons. The system keeps a constant watch on environmental factors, identifying potential dangers. It then triggers immediate alerts, using both a buzzer and LED lights to signal the issue. Simultaneously, it relays real-time position data to a control center. This allows the supervisor, stationed there, to monitor the miners' activities below ground and react instantly if something goes wrong. The system's primary goal is to reduce the time it takes to respond and improve the effectiveness of rescues. The novelty of the system combines real-time radio frequency position tracking with sensor-based hazard detection. This allows for proactive safety measures, rather than reactive ones, which sets it apart from typical intelligent helmets that rely on health monitoring or gas detection.

title: Lightweight Reinforcement Model for IoT Channel Access and Interference Control
authors: Kodeeswari K, M Sakthi, R. Rajesh, Rakhi Mutha, Harishchander Anandaram, Hirald Dwaraka Praveena
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: This paper tackles the issue of dynamic channel access and interference in highly dense IoT deployments under resource constrained environment and proposes a lightweight, adaptive deep reinforcement learning based (DRL based) framework for on device implementation. An online adaptation module, which is founded on causal drift detection and fast fine tuning, allows for quick reaction to not stationary interference (ON–OFF jammers, for instance). The proposed method evaluates the approach in an NS 3 simulator (Rayleigh fading + AWGN, 1 MHz channel, 50 devices and Poisson traffic λ=0.1) against heuristic allocation, UCB MAB (which employs a conservative device disturbance component), traditional DQN and multi agent DRL. Our results show consistent gains across all metrics: the proposed agent achieves throughput 3.8, packet success rate 90, latency 60, energy per device 0.61 and fairness index 0.89 retaining model size ≈0.35M parameters cancelling out performance of baselines over throughput, reliability, latency and energy efficiency. Its light weight and online adaptability enable the approach for being deployed on embedded IoT nodes, and there are obvious ways to further validate it through testbed and even distributed learning.

title: Deep Reinforcement Learning with Deep Double Q-Network Against Smart Jammers
authors: Lan K. Nguyen, Duy H. N. Nguyen, Nghi H. Tran, David Brunnenmeyer
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: This paper investigates a deep reinforcement learning technique based on deep double Q-network (DDQN) to optimize user’s connectivity against smart jammers without knowing the jammer’s attacking models. DDQN combines the double Q-learning technique with a deep neural network to remove the overestimation inherently in the action value of the deep Q-network (DQN) and Q-learning algorithms. In addition, assuming the estimate error of the action value of the DQN follows a zero mean Gaussian distribution, we analytically derive the expected loss. Results from computer simulations demonstrate the superior performance of DDQN over DQN and Q-learning in scenarios characterized by many channels and jammers.

title: Smart Wireless Insole with Self-Powered Triboelectric Pressure Sensors for Gait Detection
authors: Yuhan Wang, Yue Yao, Enze Li, Sifan Liang, Lei Li
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Integrated Circuits and Microsystems (ICICM)
abstract: Plantar pressure monitoring is a valuable tool for assessing gait and foot health, but conventional platforms are bulky, costly, and unsuitable for daily use. Existing rehabilitation insoles also face limitations such as large sensor size, unstable power supply, and poor portability. This paper presents a wireless self-powered smart insole system that integrates a multilayer polytetrafluoroethylene-copper (PTFE-Cu) triboelectric nanogenerator (TENG) array, low-power wireless electronics, and machine learning algorithms for real-time gait monitoring. The flexible TENG array, distributed across key plantar regions, enables spatially resolved pressure sensing without external power. Collected signals are transmitted via Bluetooth Low Energy (BLE) to a microcontroller and analyzed through intelligent algorithms to recognize normal gait as well as abnormal patterns. Experimental demonstrations confirm that the system can accurately capture plantar pressure waveforms, visualize gait dynamics, and classify abnormal gait with high reliability. By combining flexibility, portability, and autonomous power supply, the proposed smart insole provides a multifunctional platform for daily gait health management. It holds strong potential for preventive healthcare, clinical auxiliary diagnosis, rehabilitation assessment, and sports performance monitoring.

title: AAVs-WCVs Joint Scheduling for Efficient Far-field Wireless Charging in Lake Monitoring
authors: Ziqing Lin, Xilong Liu, Bo Wu, Jingkun Yan
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conferences on Internet of Things (iThings) IEEE Green Computing &amp; Communications (GreenCom) IEEE Cyber, Physical &amp; Social Computing (CPSCom) and IEEE Smart Data (SmartData) and IEEE Congress on Cybermatics (Cybermatics)
abstract: In the wireless rechargeable sensor network (WRSN)-facilitated lake monitoring scenario, the remote and widespread distribution of sensor nodes (SNs) causes difficulties in their energy supply. Wireless energy transfer (WET) technology is promising to extend the lifespan of the SNs, which greatly promotes the sustainable development of lake monitoring networks. Jointly leveraging autonomous aerial vehicles (AAVs) and wireless charging vehicles (WCVs) with WET is a viable approach to surmount the energy supply issue. AAVs are with extraordinary flexibility and WCVs are with relatively abundant battery capacities. However, advanced AAVs and WCVs joint scheduling for efficient far-field wireless charging remains scarce. In this paper, we propose the SNs' wireless energy reception model, as well as energy consumption models for the AAVs and WCVs. We concentrate effort on the optimization problem on minimizing the energy consumption of the AAVs and WCVs, while ensuring more SNs can be fully powered. As this problem is proved to be NP-hard, we further propose a two-step solution featuring corresponding heuristic algorithms to efficiently resolve it. The solution strategically determines the AAVs' flying trajectories and the WCVs' anchor points. Finally, extensive simulation results have validated the superiority of our proposed solution.

title: Fresh and Rotten Fruits and Vegetables Classification using Hybrid ResNet-18–ViT Model
authors: V. Karunakaran, Vinoth Kumar Sathish Kumar, Mohanasundaram Gunasekaran, Bharani Dharan M, Naveen Kumar Thirugnanam
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: Accurate identification of spoiled versus fresh fruits and vegetables is important for quality control in agriculture. Traditional manual inspection is slow and inconsistent. This work compares a standard ResNet-18 model against a hybrid ResNet-18–Vision Transformer ResNet-18 ViT model for classifying fresh and rotten fruit and vegetable images. This work used a ResNet-18 backbone for feature extraction from the image, and the pre-trained ViT-B16 is used for the classification. Both the models are trained, tested, and validated on the Fresh and Rotten Classification dataset. The model is evaluated with the following performance metrics, such as accuracy, precision, recall, F1-score, and ROC-AUC for training, testing, and validation datasets. The ResNet-18 model achieves 98.77 percent training accuracy, 97.76 percent testing accuracy, and 98.40 percent validation accuracy. While the ResNet-18 ViT model achieves 99.40 percent training accuracy, 99.26 percent testing accuracy, and 99.37 percent validation accuracy. Our hybrid model consistently outperforms the standard ResNet-18, demonstrating that combining convolutional feature extractors with transformer-based global attention can improve classification of fruit and vegetable freshness. These results suggest that hybrid ResNet-18 transformer architectures are promising for image-based food quality assessment.

title: CHEFSPHERE : An AI-Powered Personalized Cooking and Recipe Platform Integrating Smart Kitchen Innovation and Sustainable Food Practices
authors: Vaishnavi J, Dhivashya M R, Kavitha N, Swathi S P, Sangavi B
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: The increased demand for customized food expe riences has boosted the adoption of artificial intelligence (AI), smart kitchens, and interactive technologies in the food industry. Chefsphere is a personalized cooking and lifestyle platform based on AI that facilitates recipe customization, meal planning, ingredients, and cooking techniques using cutting edge digital solutions. The platform leverages AI encouraged dietary analysis, personality based taste suggestions, and sustainable ingredient selection to optimize user enjoyment while encouraging sustainability. An integrated real time chef collaboration feature enables users to visualize, tune, and complete dishes in real time with culinary professionals. Virtual coins, cooking challenges, and interactive mini games are gamification features that encourage ongoing user interaction and learning through communities. By tapping into AI algorithms, natural language processing, com puter vision, and recommendation systems, Chefsphere simplifies the recipe personalization process, minimizes food wastage, and enhances cooking efficiency. This article provides the conceptual design, technological model, and comparative assessment of Chefsphere based on a comprehensive literature review of current IEEE research in food recommendation systems, intelligent cooking technology, and meal customization. The new model fills current gaps in multi cuisine personalization and the convergence of AI, AR, and gamification on cooking platforms, placing Chef sphere as a next generation culinary personalization system for sustainable, interactive, and customer focused personalization.

title: GNN-Enabled Reinforcement Learning for Robust Task Admission and Routing in IoBT Environments
authors: Athanasios Gkelias, Kin K. Leung, Patrick J. Baker, Olwen Worthington
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: Internet of Battlespace Things (IoBT) deployments in adversarial environments face critical challenges in network resource management, where rapid environmental changes and dynamic threats render traditional optimization approaches inadequate. The inherently volatile nature of these environments, where network conditions can change within seconds, necessitates algorithms that prioritize speed over perfect optimization to maintain operational effectiveness. This paper presents a novel Graph Neural Network (GNN) based Deep Reinforcement Learning (DRL) framework specifically designed for combinatorial task admission and routing optimization in dynamic IoBT networks. Our approach integrates Graph Attention Networks (GATs) for capturing network topology dependencies, Deep Sets encoders for permutation-invariant task processing, Adaptive Path GNNs for learning path representations, and statistical feature encoders that complement learned embeddings with interpretable routing heuristics. The system formulates network optimization as a Markov Decision Process, enabling real-time decision-making that maximizes task utility while respecting capacity constraints and adapting to topology changes. Comprehensive experimental evaluation across multiple network scenarios demonstrates that our Deep Q-Network (DQN) agent consistently outperforms greedy baselines by 5-58%, achieving near-optimal utility with sub-second inference times compared to Mixed Integer Programming solvers that require hundreds of seconds. The framework shows strong generalization capabilities, with agents trained on smaller task sets effectively scaling to larger workloads, and exhibits superior performance when trained under dynamic conditions rather than static environments.

title: Demo: Real-World Integration and Evaluation of Open-Source 5G Core with Commercial RAN
authors: Guoying Zu, Joshua Ofori Boateng, Varun S. Advani, Taimoor Ul Islam, Vincent Lee, Sarath Babu, Md Nadim, Daji Qiao, Mohamed Y. Selim, Hongwei Zhang
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: Open-source ecosystems are rapidly transforming cellular infrastructure by decoupling proprietary vendor stacks and fostering rapid innovation across both the radio access network (RAN) and the core network. Although open-source 5G cores, such as Open5GS, have matured in recent years, demonstrations of their interoperability with commercial RANs remain scarce. This demo showcases the first end-to-end integration of Open5GS with Ericsson’s commercial RAN, deployed as part of the publicly-available ARA wireless living lab. Real-world field measurements and characterization demonstrate the carrier-grade performance and robustness of open-source cores when integrated with commercial RAN infrastructure. We demonstrate how researchers can leverage this platform for their cutting-edge research, deploy and test custom core network functions, configure gNB parameters via Moshell-based APIs, and monitor real-time performance metrics.

title: MCU-Free Backscatter Communication with Light-Enabled Frequency Control for Ambient IoT
authors: Boxuan Xie, Jari Lietzén, Kalle Koskinen, Lauri Mela, Kalle Ruttik, Riku Jäntti
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on 6G Networking (6GNet)
abstract: Ambient Internet of Things (A-IoT) adopts energy-neutral devices to conduct communication and sensing tasks, leveraging energy harvesting (EH) from ambient energy resources, such as solar, radio frequency (RF) signals, and vibrations. Using ambient backscatter communication (AmBC), a backscatter device (BD) can modulate and reflect existing RF carrier waves to transmit its local sensing data obtained from the embedded sensors. In this paper, we propose a novel A-IoT scheme, where the BD uses modulated visible light as both energy source and communication frequency controller. Specifically, the alternating current (AC) component of photovoltaic-converted light controls the frequency of communication subcarriers, eliminating the use of a microcontroller unit (MCU) for such purpose. We model the link budget of the proposed system, including the optical link and RF backscatter link. To demonstrate the implementation feasibility of the proposed scheme, we present a proof-of-concept experimental setup using the commercial off-the-shelf (COTS) electronic components. The experimental results show that the intermediate or subcarrier frequency of the backscattered signal can be shifted up to 10 MHz from the carrier, by configuring the modulation frequency of the visible light. The investigation demonstrates the feasibility of using visible light to control the subcarrier frequency of AmBC without MCUs, thereby providing extra flexibility for spectral arrangement and reducing the device cost in A-IoT systems.

title: Seeing Smiles Clearly: Automated Detection of Common Dental Conditions with ResNet18
authors: G Sunil, Shanvi Chauhan, Saurabh Fulara, Chandra Kishore
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: The worldwide health problem of oral diseases affects individuals of every age and causes persistent pain together with life-quality reduction. The correct identification and on-time detection of oral conditions stands essential for proper therapy management alongside disease prevention that maintains good health and well-being. This research examines deep learning automation for dental disease classification through assessment of six distinct oral conditions which include Calculus along with Caries and Gingivitis and furthermore integrates Ulcers with Tooth Discoloration and Hypodontia diagnosis. Medical imaging data availability requires dental professionals to receive reliable diagnostic support tools while education quality improves in dental AI technologies to enhance diagnostic accuracy. Labeled images of the six disease classes formed the basis of this research and were processed into training, validation and testing subsets. The research implemented the ResNet-18 model as the convolutional neural network for classification because it provides both deep feature extraction and efficient architecture design. The examination of the model through training and evaluation methods showed excellent performance on all six classes. The proposed method delivered a 88% success rate when classifying various categories of oral diseases during its evaluation phase. The solution promotes healthcare sustainability while simultaneously working to eliminate diagnostic solution disparities among different populations.

title: CyberStack: Deep Reinforcement Learning in Stackelberg Games for Military Network Defense
authors: Aws Jaber, Angel D. Genchev, Gudmund Grov, Tsvetelin Tsonev
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: Securing military communication networks against advanced persistent threats (APTs) is critical for mission success. We introduce CyberStack, a cyber-defense simulation that integrates deep reinforcement learning (DRL) and Stackelberg Markov Security Games (SMSG) to optimize adaptive defensive strategies. Leveraging real-world Suricata EVE JSON logs, CyberStack models a defender and a Bayesian attacker in a high-fidelity cyber range, enabling the selection of optimal Courses of Action (CoAs), such as IP blocking and server isolation. A deep RL agent, combining Actor-Critic and Deep Q-Network (DQN) models. This work advances AI-driven cybersecurity, offering a scalable defense mechanism for military networks and critical infrastructure.

title: How to Combat Reactive and Dynamic Jamming Attacks with Reinforcement Learning
authors: Yalin E. Sagduyu, Tugba Erpek, Kemal Davaslioglu, Sastry Kompella
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: This paper studies the problem of mitigating reactive jamming, where a jammer adopts a dynamic policy of selecting channels and sensing thresholds to detect and jam ongoing transmissions. The transmitter–receiver pair learns to avoid jamming and optimize throughput over time (without prior knowledge of channel conditions or jamming strategies) by using reinforcement learning (RL) to adapt transmit power, modulation, and channel selection. Q-learning is employed for discrete jamming-event states, while Deep Q-Networks (DQN) are employed for continuous states based on received power. Through different reward functions and action sets, the results show that RL can adapt rapidly to spectrum dynamics and sustain high rates as channels and jamming policies change over time.

title: FynVerse: A RAG-Enhanced AI Stock Trading Simulator for Portfolio Learning
authors: Zubair Ahmed Mohammad, Kolli Jagan Mohan Rao, B. V. Satish Babu
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: Educational stock trading simulators typically lack intelligent analytics and personalized guidance. We present FynVerse, an iOS stock trading simulator that integrates four components: real-time NSE data for 2,151 stocks, a five-factor portfolio scoring system, machine-learning risk assessment using Random Forest, and a retrieval-augmented generation (RAG) conversational assistant powered by Google Gemini 2.0 Flash. FynVerse uses a Swift/SwiftUI frontend with a FastAPI backend and Firebase storage. The Random Forest model achieves R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> = 0.762 on portfolio risk prediction using 15 engineered features, while the RAG assistant builds portfolio-aware context in 25–45 ms with 94% response relevance. System measurements show 99.8% data availability and sub-200 ms API response times. In a four-week study with 25 university students, the experimental group improved portfolio quality by 19.8% (p<0.001, Cohen’s d = 1.28) versus 5.5% in the control group. These results indicate that combining trading simulation, analytics, and RAG-based conversational support can enhance equity portfolio learning for novice investors.

title: Quaternary Full Adder Design using GNRFET
authors: Rupanagudi Charishma, Annareddy Sravani, Elamarthi Kalyana Pallavi, Saleem Syed, Khaderabad Abdul Khader, S.Md. Zubeir
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: In this research, quaternary basic logic and arithmetic circuits employing graphene nanoribbon field-effect transistors (GNFETs) are designed and their performance evaluated. Inspired by the benefits of multi-valued logic (MVL) over traditional binary logic, the proposed study shows how GNFET technology may be effectively used to create quaternary inverters, logic gates, decoders, and arithmetic units like half and full adders. It is estimated that the suggested GNFET-based quaternary circuits outperform CNFET designs in terms of power reduction by up to 21.76%, propagation delay by about 20%, and power–delay product by up to 71.52% for the complete adder. Comparative findings show that, in comparison to their CNFET counterparts, GNFET-based circuits significantly improve propagation delay, power dissipation, and power–delay product (PDP). The suggested method's scalability for increasingly intricate arithmetic systems is further demonstrated by the modular full adder implementation. nanotechnology. All things considered, this study highlights GNFETs' promise as a viable substitute for low-power, high-performance MVL circuit design in next nanoelectronics. HSPICE were used to model device I–V and circuit behavior through simulations.

title: Lightweight and Breach-Resilient Authenticated Encryption Framework for Internet of Things
authors: Saif Eddine Nouma, Attila A. Yavuz
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: The Internet of Things (IoT) relies heavily on resource-limited devices to communicate critical (e.g., military data) information under low-energy adversarial environments and low-latency wireless channels. Authenticated Encryption (AE) guarantees confidentiality, authenticity, and integrity, making it a vital security service for IoT. However, current deployed (lightweight) AE standards lack essential features like key compromise resiliency and compact authentication tags, as well as performance enhancements such as offline-online cryptography. To address these gaps, we propose Graphene, the first (to our knowledge) symmetric Forward-secure and Aggregate Authenticated Encryption (FAAE) framework designed for the performance and security demands of low-end IoT infrastructures. Graphene innovates by synergizing key evolution strategies and offline-online cryptographic processing with Universal Message Authentication Codes (UMACs) to guarantee breach-resiliency, near-optimal online latency, and compactness. We demonstrate Graphene’s efficiency through two distinct instantiations, each balancing unique performance trade-offs with extensibility for diverse MACs. Our experimental evaluation on commodity hardware and 32-bit ARM Cortex-M4 microcontroller shows Graphene’s significant performance gains over existing alternatives. Graphene is also backward compatible with standard-compliant cryptographic implementations. We release our implementation as open source for public testing and adaptation.
