title: A Novel Oyster Freshness Prediction Model Based on Hierarchical Feature Fusion with XGBoost and CNN-LSTM for Edge Deployment
authors: Aixiang He, Guangfen Wei
publish: IEEE Sensors Journal
abstract: Oysters, as highly perishable seafood, undergo rapid quality deterioration influenced by storage temperature and duration. This paper presents a hybrid XGBoost-CNN-LSTM model for real-time quality assessment, which synergistically integrates electronic nose data with multimodal freshness indicators-sensory scores, Aerobic Plate Count (APC), and Total Volatile Basic Nitrogen (TVB-N). The proposed architecture employs a dual-path feature fusion strategy, combining raw sensor inputs with XGBoost-optimized features to construct a discriminative hierarchical feature matrix. A CNN layer extracts local patterns from the fused features, followed by a single-layer unidirectional LSTM with 32 hidden units to capture temporal dependencies. The decoder efficiently maps final hidden states through fully connected layers to simultaneously predict sensory, microbiological (APC), and chemical (TVB-N) freshness indicators. Comparative evaluations against two baseline models (TCN and SqueezeNet) demonstrate the superior performance of the proposed model in both prediction accuracy and computational efficiency. Validated on embedded platforms (Raspberry Pi 4B and Jetson TX2 NX), the model achieves high inference speed with minimal resource consumption, establishing a practical and efficient framework for intelligent seafood quality monitoring in edge environments.

title: Adaptive Offline Parameter Identification of PMSM with Nonlinear Compensation in Self-Commissioning
authors: Junyu Zhao, Jun Gu, Yuting Wu, Dianguo Xu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Power Electronics
abstract: Accurate offline parameter identification of unknown permanent magnet synchronous machines (PMSMs) without tuned current controllers remains challenging due to nonlinearities and safety constraints. Therefore, this paper proposes a hybrid open/closed-loop identification strategy incorporating nonlinear compensation for automated parameter identification. An excitation-adaptive amplitude-frequency open-loop injection scheme is proposed to safely excite unknown PMSMs while eliminating phase-measurement errors in identification, thereby enabling efficient and high-precision open-loop parameter identification. Within a single closed-loop ramp current injection procedure, simultaneous stator resistance identification and inverter nonlinearity compensation are achieved, enhancing the speed and accuracy of identification. Furthermore, skin effect compensation is implemented via analysis of mid- and high-frequency current responses to improve inductance identification precision. The framework uniquely integrates compensation for critical nonlinearities while eliminating manual intervention. Validation on a 750W PMSM confirms enhanced accuracy, operational efficiency and reliability.

title: Dynamic Authentication and Granularized Authorization With a Cross-Domain Zero Trust Architecture in Large-Scale IoT Networks
authors: Xiaoyu Ma, Fang Fang, Tianlong Liu, Xianbin Wang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Network Science and Engineering
abstract: With the increasing number of connected devices and complex networks involved, current domain-specific authentication mechanisms become inadequate for the dynamic access demands of large-scale Internet of Things (IoT) systems. Cross-domain authentication and authorization could enhance device interoperability across different security domains. However, they face new challenges including increased authentication latency, non-transferable trust, and excessive authorization computational overhead. To address these issues, in this paper, we propose Dynamic Authentication and Granularized Authorization (DAGA), a cross-domain Zero Trust Architecture (ZTA)-based framework that enables efficient, adaptive, and scalable authentication and authorization for large-scale IoT systems. Rather than relying on full authentication for every request, DAGA introduces a cross-domain pre-authentication phase that estimates device trustworthiness in advance. Specifically, DAGA leverages Federated Learning (FL) and Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM)-based dynamic trust management to minimize unnecessary trust score computations, thereby accelerating cross-domain pre-authentication. At the same time, DAGA employs multi-level and cached fast authorization to achieve adaptive granularized access control, enhancing the accuracy and efficiency. Experimental results demonstrate that DAGA achieves notable reductions in communication and computation overhead compared to ZTA, blockchain-based, and lightweight mechanisms, significantly reducing authentication latency. Despite its efficiency gains, DAGA achieves a superior accuracy–latency trade-off over other baseline approaches, effectively balancing security and efficiency through adaptive optimization.

title: Apple Leaf Disease Classification using Transfer Learning with MobileNetV2
authors: G Sunil, Seerat Singla, Sonal Malhotra, Kamlesh Kukreti
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: Apple leaf diseases significantly threaten the health and productivity of apple orchards worldwide, necessitating early and accurate detection for effective crop management. In this study, we propose a deep learning-based classification utilizing the MobileNetV2 model to identify and categorize apple leaf diseases. The research leverages the Apple Leaf Disease Classification Dataset from Kaggle, encompassing a total of 9,721 images across four classes: Apple Scab, Black Rot, Cedar Apple Rust, and Healthy. To ensure robust performance, extensive preprocessing was carried out including resizing images, normalization, and data augmentation techniques. The model architecture integrates MobileNetV2 evaluation of the model was based on key metrics such as accuracy, precision, recall, and F1-score. The proposed model achieved an impressive overall accuracy of 93%, with respective class-wise metrics showing high precision and recall, the model demonstrates high efficacy in multiclass classification tasks and offers potential for real-world deployment in automated agricultural disease monitoring systems.

title: A Fault Tolerant Routing Method for 3D Network on Chip without Redundant TSV or Router-Avoidance
authors: Zeyi Lin, Duo Yu, Yanzhou Tang, Naifeng Jing, Jianfei Jiang, Weiguang Sheng, Lifu Cheng, Qin Wang
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Integrated Circuits and Microsystems (ICICM)
abstract: 3D integrated chips are key technologies for mitigating the impending failure of Moore’s Law. In current 3D chips, network on chip is commonly employed to facilitate intercore communication. However, in 3D NoC, failures of Through-Silicon Via (TSV) links in the vertical direction can lead to communication breakdowns, necessitating targeted fault-tolerant designs. Existing approaches typically address this problem either by incorporating redundant TSV or by routing around faulty routers during path computation; the former incurs substantial hardware overhead, while the latter degrades network performance. This paper presents a novel fault-tolerant scheme that does not require redundant TSV and effectively exploits the remaining functional links in routers with TSV failures. The proposed method introduces a mere 6.9% area overhead, yet maintains 99.3% of the pre-failure TSV network performance, demonstrating negligible performance loss.

title: A Low-Power High-Accuracy Phase Frequency Detector and Charge Pump Design for CPPLL in 28 nm CMOS Technology
authors: Zhigang Li, Hao Lei, Zhihao Liu, Lingrui Yan, Qiang Zhao, Shan Gao, Xiulong Wu
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Integrated Circuits and Microsystems (ICICM)
abstract: Conventional charge-pump phase-locked loops (CPPLLs) suffer from inherent trade-offs between dead-zone elimination, linear detection range, and current mismatch in the design of the phase frequency detector (PFD) and charge pump (CP). To address these issues, this paper presents a novel PFD architecture incorporating a 4-bit digitally-programmable delay cell, offering 16 programmable delay steps to eliminate dead-zone effects while extending the linear phase detection range to $(-1.967 \pi, 1.967 \pi)$. The proposed CP employs a source-switched single-ended topology with an embedded rail-to-rail operational amplifier and a 4-bit digital-to-analog converter (DAC), achieving a current mismatch below 0.2% across the full 0.04 V to $V_{D D}(1 \mathrm{~V})$ output range while maintaining stable voltage regulation. Postlayout simulation results demonstrate a peak power consumption of $729.33 \mu \mathrm{~W}$ and a phase noise of $-136.63 \mathrm{dBc} / \mathrm{Hz}$ at 1 MHz frequency offset. Moreover, the design is implemented in a 28 nm CMOS process and occupies an area of $0.0195 \mathrm{~mm}^{2}$.

title: Secure File Sharing in Modern Browsers: Implementing End-to-End Encryption and User-Centric Access Control Mechanisms
authors: P Chinnasamy, R. Shashidhar Reddy, Y. Lohith Kiran, D. Prathap Reddy, G Siva Nagendra Reddy
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: In the age of using technology to work together remotely, the inability to share files in a secure manner is a problem often faced since many online sharing options available do not have good protection on their sharing options and do not safeguard against unauthorized use of the files. This paper presents a secure file sharing portal that has end to end encryption and user-based access controls and that works inside a web browser. The system uses the Web Crypto API interface to provide local encryption on the user’s devices using the AES-GCM encryption algorithm, so that the user’s plaintext documents do not leave the device. A separate layer of protection exists in the system. It is not enough for a user to just receive the encrypted file. The user has to receive a decryption key that the sender has to share through a separate channel. Access is for members only which requires sender approval and we have features like secure QR code share, session monitoring, digital certificates for identity proof and policy enforcement for compliance. Also, we have a "Secure Space" module which is for ephemeral work groups that has in space chat, multi user invites, controlled key exchange and one click revocation which in turn puts power back in the users’ hands. We combined zero knowledge structure with audit able workflows to present a privacy first, scalable and easy to use solution. Also, we show how we used modern web tech to create a trusted setting for sensitive file share which at the same time does not sacrifice ease of use or performance.

title: Specific Emitter Identification Impacts Due to Collection, Frequency Band, and Antenna Changes
authors: Joshua H. Tyler, Colin J. Keeter, Donald R. Reising
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: The proliferation of Wireless Internet of Things (IoT) devices has improved day-to-day automation, but at the cost of increased exploitation due to unaddressed security concerns. Specific Emitter Identification (SEI) is a physical layer security approach designed to address IoT security concerns by exploiting unintentional defects and distortions imparted to the signal by the IoT device’s radio frequency front-end. Despite significant research, SEI still faces barriers limiting its practical implementation. One barrier is cross-collection SEI, which occurs when an SEI process is trained to identify emitters using a single set of collected signals and then used to identify those identical emitters using signals collected hours, days, or even long after the initial training signals. This requires learning of collection-agnostic emitter-specific features. With this in mind, cross-collection SEI is investigated while considering the impacts of antenna characteristics and frequency band. The results show that cross-collection SEI performance is higher when the emitters operate in higher frequency bands using high-gain antennas. This is attributed to the antenna’s amplification of emitter-specific features and increased stress on the RF front-end due to the higher operating frequency.

title: Symbol-Level Precoding for Multipath-Tolerant Physical-Layer Secured Communication with Space-Time Modulated Metamaterial Antennas
authors: Hariharan Venkat, Shaghayegh Vosoughitabar, Shuping Li, Chung-Tse Michael Wu, Narayan B. Mandayam, Waheed U. Bajwa
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: Physical layer security (PLS) in a space-time modulated metamaterial (MTM) antenna array system has relied on finding the "optimal" space-time modulation code sequence that would steer the main beam towards the desired user, while nulling any resulting interference terms. However, limited analysis in multipath environments, the complexity of the optimization problem, and beam squint effects due to the array’s frequency dependent characteristics motivate the need for an improved code design. Furthermore, if an eavesdropper knew the "optimal" code matrix, they could undermine the PLS of the system. To overcome these drawbacks, we introduce a new channel model for multipath environments for this system along with the use of Symbol-Level Precoding (SLP) to achieve PLS in the multipath channel for an Orthogonal Frequency Division Multiplexing (OFDM) space-time modulated MTM antenna array system. The system framework presented also accounts for beam squint effects. Finally, the use of randomized code sequences is discussed and simulation results are presented to verify the proposed design.

title: RAN Tester UE in Action: Declarative, Automated Security Evaluations for O-RAN deployments
authors: Joshua Moore, Aly Sabri Abdalla, Charles Ueltschey, Anoop Mishra, Vuk Marojevic
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: Open RAN (O-RAN) introduces security challenges due to its disaggregated, software-defined architecture and exposed fronthaul interfaces. We present RAN Tester UE (Soft-T UE), a modular, containerized platform for automated, UE-centric security testing of O-RAN environments. Our demo showcases fronthaul disruption in a split 7.2 setup using srsRAN’s RU Emulator, and replaying manipulated packets from two key injection points, the DU or the RU, which highlights Soft-T UE’s automated testing capabilities in uncovering vulnerabilities in O-RAN systems.

title: Optimizing Spectrum Sharing: A Novel Approach to Radar Detection Using 5G Sounding Reference Signals
authors: Kevin Naranjo, David Li, Harish Ramchandran, Masoud Farshchian
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: Spectrum sharing has become increasingly vital as commercial 5G networks expand into frequency bands currently occupied by government systems, such as radar. This paper presents a novel method for sensing incumbent radar waveforms by leveraging the Sounding Reference Signal (SRS) in cellular networks, which is used for uplink channel estimation in 5G systems. The proposed approach was evaluated through MATLAB simulations and a testbench implementation utilizing software-defined radios (SDRs) and the OpenAirInterface (OAI) software stack. Experimental results demonstrate radar detection using SRS measurements under sufficient radar power. One caveat is that detection relies on the overlap between radar pulses and SRS symbols, which may not always occur. Nevertheless, the method introduces minimal overhead and provides a rapid, cost-effective situational awareness layer that complements more advanced sensing techniques.

title: An IoT-Enabled Hybrid Deep Learning Framework for Smart Town Traffic Accident Prevention
authors: Y. Chitti Babu, Goretla Alekhya
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: A crucial part of developing smart cities is preventing traffic accidents in smart towns. However, it is still difficult to forecast and identify traffic accidents since road networks are complicated and constantly changing, especially at big crossings. To better manage these ever-changing circumstances, this proposed need reaction and monitoring technologies that can boost safety while reducing congestion in real-time. Urban infrastructure that incorporates intelligent accident detection and prediction technologies can greatly enhance road safety and overall living conditions. In order to clean the dataset and extract deeper insights, this study applies data reduction techniques and encodes high-frequency categorical features. It then uses computer vision to analyse spatial-temporal traffic patterns. Hybrid deep learning models that combine CNN and LSTM networks are suggested as a solution to the shortcomings of conventional machine learning approaches. This model is great for accident prediction since it uses CNNs to extract spatial features and LSTMs to deal with temporal dependencies. The CNN-LSTM model outperformed previous methods with an accuracy of 96.45% on a benchmark dataset. These findings show that deep learning has the ability to make urban transport networks safer and smarter by allowing for accurate accident prevention systems to operate in real-time.

title: Stochastic Resource Allocation Leveraging Adaptive Network Monitoring and Tactical Edge Networks
authors: Kevin Chan, Julia Deeb-Swihart, Matthew Dwyer, Eric Graves, Sean Harding, Olena Tkachenko
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: In tactical networks, applications and services depend on awareness of dynamics and uncertainty of the environment. These approaches also must deal with resource limitations of the nodes running the applications and of the limited available bandwidth for these nodes to exchange information. These systems might employ a set of applications that demonstrate a range of performance metrics (e.g., processing latency and training accuracy of deployed models). Services managing these networks must resource-efficiently maintain understanding and awareness of available resources to execute these applications. They must then make complex decisions on how and where to execute these applications. With poor understanding of the available resources, this problem is even more difficult and the performance of the system might be suboptimal. In this paper, we explore monitoring strategies that can adapt to the degree of dynamics of the environment and test out task allocation strategies that account for environmental dynamics. Through empirical study, we study the impact of monitoring strategies on compare the performance for various adaptive resource monitoring and resource allocation strategies.

title: Dual-Input High-Gain Expandable Switched-Capacitor-Inductor Cell DC-DC Boost Converter
authors: Miteshkumar Bharatbhai Patel, Jayaram Nakka, Praveen Kumar Bonthagorla
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: A new non-isolated high-gain DC-DC boost converter with a dual-input single-output expandable topology is presented in this work. The proposed design provides the dual-input high-gain expandable switched-capacitor-inductor cell (DIHGESCIC) converter for advanced power conversion applications using the switched-capacitor (SC) and switched-inductor (SI) techniques to obtain a higher voltage gain. The operating principle of the switched-capacitor-switched-inductor cell is to discharge in series and charge parallelly. The proposed topology produces high gain with comparatively low electrical stress on semiconductors and low current or voltage ripples. It provides common grounding, continuous input current, and allows for increased higher voltage gain by expansion in the proposed structure. Also, the expansion in analogous SC and SI cells do not impact on order of transfer function, which reduces the controller design and tuning complexity. A comprehensive analysis of the operational modes, along with all relevant calculations, is conducted under steady state and continuous conduction mode (CCM). This paper includes state-space analysis, PI based voltage controller design, and comparative analysis. The proposed dual-input 400 V/50 kHz/500 W converter is validated experimentally using TMS320F28379D microcontroller.

title: Residual Feature Enhancement for Large Language Models: Methodology and Applications
authors: Qidong Yan, Chenglin Jiang, Yingjie Li, Ning Ma
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: Large language models (LLMs) have achieved remarkable progress in natural language processing, yet their ability to perform complex logical reasoning remains limited. Existing approaches such as prompting, retrieval-augmented generation, and parameter-efficient fine-tuning (PEFT) provide partial improvements but often suffer from prompt sensitivity, semantic compression, or additional computational cost. In this work, we propose a Residual Feature Enhancement (RFE) module, a lightweight architectural component designed to strengthen reasoning ability while maintaining computational efficiency. RFE integrates a dimension-preserving linear transformation, SwiGLU nonlinear activation, and residual connections to enrich attention outputs without altering the backbone structure. We conducted comprehensive experiments across six reasoning and comprehension benchmarks—LogiQA, ReClor, LogiQA2.0, GSM8K, HellaSwag, and MBPP—covering deductive reasoning, standardized test comprehension, commonsense inference, and program synthesis. Results demonstrate that ChatGLM4-9B augmented with RFE consistently achieves superior performance compared with both adapter-based methods and larger-scale baselines. Specifically, ChatGLM4-9B+RFE attains 68.20% on LogiQA, 82.00% on ReClor, 79.74% on LogiQA 2.0, 95.68% on GSM8K, 72.42% on HellaSwag, and 56.82% on MBPP, all of which surpass the Adapter mechanism (67.68%, 81.15%, 78.52%, 94.47%, 66.85%, 55.02%) and show clear advantages over open-source baselines such as Qwen1.5-MoE-A2.7B, Llama3.1-8B, and DeepSeek distilled models. Ablation studies further confirm that removing RFE leads to performance degradation of up to 3.84 percentage points, and convergence analysis shows improved stability and faster training.

title: Time-Series JEPA for Predictive Remote Control under Capacity-Limited Networks
authors: Abanoub M. Girgis, Alvaro Valcarce, Mehdi Bennis
publish: IEEE Internet of Things Journal
abstract: In remote control systems, transmitting large data volumes (e.g., images, video frames) from wireless sensors to remote controllers is challenging when uplink capacity is limited (e.g., RedCap devices or massive wireless sensor networks). Furthermore, controllers often need only information-rich representations of the original data. To address this, we propose a semantic-driven predictive control combined with a channel-aware scheduling to enhance control performance for multiple devices under limited network capacity. At its core, the proposed framework, coined Time-Series Joint Embedding Predictive Architecture (TS-JEPA), encodes high-dimensional sensory data into low-dimensional semantic embeddings at the sensor, reducing communication overhead. Furthermore, TS-JEPA enables predictive inference by predicting future embeddings from current ones and predicted commands, which are directly used by a semantic actor model to compute control commands within the embedding space, eliminating the need to reconstruct raw data. To further enhance reliability and communication efficiency, a channel-aware scheduling is integrated to dynamically prioritize device transmissions based on channel conditions and age of information (AoI). Extensive simulations on inverted cart-pole systems demonstrate that the proposed framework achieves a 98.95% reduction in communication cost, a normalized prediction error of 0.004, and 74.48% control accuracy, outperforming conventional control baselines. Furthermore, the proposed framework maintains robust control performance on 15-step prediction horizons and supports up to 16× more devices than round-robin and opportunistic scheduling schemes with conventional control baselines under similar network conditions.

title: BASAT: BLE AOA–based Spatio-temporal Acoustic TOA Estimator
authors: Can Xue, Huixin Zhuge, Zhi Wang
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: In severely reverberant indoor environments, acoustic Time-of-Arrival (TOA) localization on commercial smartphones is prone to multipath-induced bias and unreliable ranging. This article presents a Bluetooth Angle-of-Arrival (AOA)–assisted spatiotemporal multipath suppression framework for acoustic TOA estimation. First, a soft conic geometric prior is constructed from AOA, and the associated angular uncertainty is mapped to the distance–time domain to enable temporal gating that preserves the direct-path component while suppressing late reverberation. Second, a Gaussian-mixture intensity prior is established using the Received Signal Strength Indication (RSSI). By inverting the Log-Distance Path Loss (LDPL) model with variance propagation, a distance–time distribution is derived and intersected with the AOA reachability bound to form a Bayesian Geometric TOA window (BG-TOA), followed by soft gating to attenuate outlier paths. Finally, under BG-TOA constraints, the joint covariance is updated online and eigenvector-based spatial filtering is performed to enhance the direct path and suppress multipath clusters, yielding the earliest consistent TOA estimate. Field experiments in an office and a large indoor space achieve mean static and dynamic localization errors of 0.11 m and 0.13 m, respectively, substantially outperforming single-sensor baselines and conventional fusion methods. The proposed framework is fully compatible with existing smartphone hardware, offering low cost and deployment simplicity.
