title: Rethinking Signaling Design for ISAC: From Pilot-Based to Payload-Based Sensing
authors: Yunxin Li, Ying Zhang, Christos Masouros, Sofie Pollin, Fan Liu
publish: IEEE Communications Standards Magazine
abstract: Integrated Sensing and Communications (ISAC) is emerging as a key enabler for 6G networks, with signaling design at the core of its evolution. This paper reviews the paradigm shift of ISAC signaling designs from pilot-aided sensing to data payload-based approaches, with a particular focus on how these techniques can be realized within existing 5G New Radio (NR) structures. We commence with the reuse of pilots and reference signals that exploit existing 5G NR structures for sensing. Then, we extend to more advanced approaches that integrate the data payload through novel constellation shaping, modulation bases, and pulse shaping filters. We highlight the opportunities and tradeoffs that arise when extending sensing from sparse pilot and reference signal resources to the full communication frame, emphasizing how constellation properties and modulation choices directly determine sensing performance. To illustrate practical feasibility, a case study on sensing-assisted NR Vehicle-to-Infrastructure (V2I) networks demonstrates how exploiting both reference signals and payload echoes can reduce signaling overhead and enable proactive beam management and handover.

title: FSFNet: Frequency-Spatial Domain Fusion Network for Infrared Small Target Detection
authors: Riyao Chen, Wenxiao Tang, Mingchao Yang, Wenxiong Kang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Geoscience and Remote Sensing
abstract: Infrared small target detection (IRSTD) is inherently challenging due to the weak feature representation of small targets and significant interference caused by complex backgrounds. Recent mainstream IRSTD methods predominantly emphasize feature extraction in the spatial domain but often neglect crucial complementary information contained in the frequency domain, resulting in limited detection performance. To address this issue, we propose a novel Frequency-Spatial Fusion Network (FSFNet), which explicitly integrates spatial-domain features and frequency-domain information through two innovative modules: the Frequency-Spatial Block (FSBlock) and the Frequency-Spatial Feature Fusion Module (FSFFM). Specifically, the FSBlock, equipped with a Spectral Band Gate (SBG) module, selectively emphasizes informative spectral bands to capture global contextual patterns and periodic characteristics in the frequency domain, thereby complementing traditional spatial-domain local representations and enhancing the network’s ability to distinguish small targets from cluttered backgrounds. Furthermore, the FSFFM adaptively combines these multi-domain features via a frequency-guided cross-channel attention mechanism, effectively bridging the semantic gap between the spatial and frequency domains. Extensive experimental evaluations on three publicly benchmark datasets demonstrate that the proposed FSFNet consistently achieves superior detection accuracy and robustness compared with state-of-the-art methods.

title: Efficient Bilevel Source Mask Optimization
authors: Guojin Chen, Peng Xu, Hongquan He, Hao Geng, Bei Yu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Computer-Aided Design of Integrated Circuits and Systems
abstract: Resolution Enhancement Techniques (RETs) are critical for meeting the stringent requirements of advanced technology nodes in semiconductor manufacturing. Source Mask Optimization (SMO), a prominent RET methodology, simultaneously co-optimizes photomask patterns and illumination sources to maximize the lithographic process window; nevertheless, existing SMO approaches typically separate source and mask optimization into sequential steps, resulting in substantial computational overhead and lacking convergence guarantees. In this work, we present BiSMO, a unified bilevel optimization framework that formulates SMO as a nested optimization problem and leverages three novel gradient-based algorithms for efficient and provably convergent solution search. To further enhance practical performance, we introduce BiSMO-RL, a reinforcement learning–driven extension that dynamically adjusts bilevel optimization hyperparameters to accelerate convergence and improve solution robustness. Experimental results on representative lithographic patterns demonstrate that BiSMO-RL reduces critical lithographic error metrics by up to 40% and achieves more than an 8× improvement in computational efficiency compared to state-of-the-art RET methods. All code and experimental settings are open-sourced at https://github.com/dekura/BiSMO.git.

title: A Physics-Constrained Neural Network Method for Compact Modeling of Semiconductor Devices
authors: Fu Gong, Xinyu Zou, Yuhang Zhang, Yang Shen, Bingyi Ye, Xiaojin Li, Shaoqiang Chen, Fei Lu, Xinyu Dong, Ziyu Liu, Yabin Sun
publish: IEEE Transactions on Computer-Aided Design of Integrated Circuits and Systems
abstract: This work proposes a physics-constrained neural network (PCNN) method for automated and physically consistent compact modeling of semiconductor devices. Traditional ANN-based approaches often exhibit limited enforcement of physical monotonicity and symmetry, suffer from poor generalization, and require complex manual data preprocessing. The proposed method addresses these challenges through two core innovations: a self-adaptive data preprocessing strategy that eliminates manual intervention, and a weight-generation neural architecture that embeds physics-inspired constraints to ensure monotonicity and symmetry. Extensive device- and circuit-level evaluations demonstrate the effectiveness of the method. On average, a 3.2× reduction in mean relative error (MRE) is achieved in modeling I-V and C-V characteristics across the devices evaluated in this work compared with ANN-based models. In circuit-level simulations, the method reduces the power-delay product (PDP) error from 50% to 7% in a 17-stage ring oscillator and lowers the gain error from 5.7% to 0.4% in a common-source amplifier. Additionally, transient simulation time is reduced by up to 70% compared to ANN-based models. These results highlight that the proposed method not only improves physical consistency and modeling accuracy but also enables scalable and efficient SPICE-level simulation, paving the way for practical AI/ML-assisted compact model development.

title: Few-Shot Object Detection on Remote Sensing Images Based on Decoupled Training, Contrastive Learning and Self-Training
authors: Shun Zhang, Xuebin Zhang, Yaohui Xu, Ke Wang
publish: IEEE Journal of Selected Topics in Applied Earth Observations and Remote Sensing
abstract: Few-shot object detection (FSOD) in remote sensing imagery faces two critical challenges compared to general methods trained on large datasets: (1) Only a few labeled instances leveraged as the training set significantly limit the feature representation learning of deep neural networks; (2) Remote sensing image data contains complicated background and multiple objects with greatly different sizes in the same image, which leads the detector to large numbers of false alarms and miss detections. This paper proposes a FSOD framework (called DeCL-Det) that applies self-training to generate high-quality pseudo-annotations from unlabeled target domain data. These refined pseudo-labels are iteratively integrated into the training set to expand supervision for novel classes. An auxiliary network is introduced to mitigate label noise by rectifying misclassifications in pseudo-labeled regions, ensuring robust learning. For multi-scale feature learning, we propose a gradient-decoupled framework, GCFPN, combining Feature Pyramid Networks (FPN) with a Gradient Decoupled Layer (GDL). FPN is to extract multi-scale feature representations, and GDL is to decouple the modules between the Region Proposal Network (RPN) and RCNN head into two stages or tasks through gradients. The two modules, FPN and GDL, train Faster R-CNN in a decoupled way to facilitate the multi-scale feature learning of novel objects. To further enhance the classification ability, we introduce a supervised contrastive learning head to enhance feature discrimination, reinforcing robustness in few-shot object detection. Experiments on the DIOR dataset indicate that our method performs better than several existing approaches and achieves competitive results.

title: Solution Approaches for the Dynamic Naval Air Defense Planning Problem_supp1-3648686.mp4
authors: Caner Arslan
publish: N/A
abstract: The naval air defense planning (NADP) problem entails the defense of a naval fleet against aerial threats. This complex and dynamic problem requires real-time decision-making and adaptation to evolving warfare environment. While our previous work addressed the static NADP problem by proposing a mathematical model and heuristic solutions for sensor allocation, engagement scheduling, and ship routing, this study extends to the dynamic NADP problem. Unlike the static version, which assumes complete knowledge of future threats, the dynamic NADP problem requires continuous updates and real-time adjustments to decisions as new threats emerge and situational parameters change. We present modifications in the mathematical formulation, which is based on a mixed-integer nonlinear programming (MINLP) model, alongside a comprehensive simulation structure. We employ heuristic solution approaches that utilize a combination of a genetic algorithm, construction of an engagement graph to solve the shortest path problem, and dynamic programming (DP) techniques. Computational experiments are conducted to evaluate the effectiveness of these methods in addressing the dynamic NADP problem. The study also explores machine learning models for threat prioritization, offering innovative solutions to the challenges posed by dynamic naval air defense scenarios.

title: Physics-informed Generative Self-attention Framework for Sliding Bearing Fault Diagnosis
authors: Mingyu Cai, Yang Liu, Jun Zhao, Wei Wang, Witold Pedrycz
publish: IEEE Sensors Journal
abstract: Timely detection of sliding bearing oil-film faults is critical for preventing costly failures and ensuring equipment reliability. Yet, diagnosis accuracy is often hindered by data scarcity and severe class imbalance in industrial environments. To overcome these challenges, this study proposes a physics-informed generative framework that couples sliding bearing mechanics with data-driven modeling. The Reynolds equation is embedded into a physics-informed neural network to generate physically consistent samples for data augmentation, while a self-attention–enhanced convolutional neural network is employed to extract features from three-dimensional oil-film pressure distributions. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first work to integrate physics-informed generative modeling with self-attention mechanisms for sliding bearing fault diagnosis. Comparative experiments against conventional finite difference and other imbalanced approaches demonstrate that the proposed method not only solves the oil-film pressure field with higher efficiency but also improves fault classification accuracy on imbalanced datasets by up to 37.5%, thereby offering a new paradigm for robust diagnosis under limited data conditions.

title: XGBoost-Powered Predictive Modeling for Myalgic Encephalomyelitis/Chronic Fatigue Syndrome
authors: K. Vanitha K. Vanitha, Preethi U, Suvetha R, Sruthi S
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: Myalgic Encephalomyelitis/Chronic Fatigue Syndrome (ME/CFS) is a multifaceted, heterogeneous condition marked by constant fatigue and multisystem dysfunction. Identifying ME/CFS patients quickly and reliably based on clinical and patient-reported data is critical to advancing care as well as research. Myalgic Encephalomyelitis/Chronic Fatigue Syndrome (ME/CFS) is a complex condition that often goes unrecognized in studies. It is marked by fatigue that lasts longer than expected, cognitive issues, and malaise after exertion. Due to the significant overlap of symptoms with other medical conditions and a lack of clear biomarkers, ME/CFS is hard to detect through standard clinical methods. This study outlines a machine-learning framework for identifying ME/CFS early by using publicly available physiological and biological datasets, including data from wearable devices and features from omics. To improve interpretability and efficiency, we used model feature selection methods such as ANOVA, Linear Discriminant Analysis (LDA), and impurity-based scores. We measured the classification accuracy of three supervised learning algorithms: Extreme Gradient Boosting, Random Forest, and Support Vector Machine classification. We utilized standard metrics like accuracy, precision, recall, and F1 score. Among all the models examined, XGBoost was the most accurate, showing a strong ability to find complex, non-linear patterns in biomedical data. The results suggest that AI-based methods could help diagnose ME/CFS more quickly and provide a foundation for scalable, data-driven healthcare solutions.

title: Natural Language Interaction with Databases on Edge Devices in the Internet of Battlefield Things
authors: Christopher D. Molek, Roberto Fronteddu, K. Brent Venable, Niranjan Suri
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: The expansion of the Internet of Things (IoT) in the battlefield, Internet of Battlefield Things (IoBT), gives rise to new opportunities for enhancing situational awareness. To increase the potential of IoBT for situational awareness in critical decision making, the data from these devices must be processed into consumer-ready information objects and made available to consumers on demand. To address this challenge we propose a workflow that makes use of natural language processing (NLP) to query a database and return a response in natural language. Our solution utilizes Large Language Models (LLMs) sized for edge devices to perform NLP, as well as a graph database. These types of databases are well suited for the dynamic, connected networks pervasive in the IoBT. Our architecture employs LLMs for both mapping questions in natural language to Cypher database queries as well as to summarize the database output back to the user in natural language. We evaluated several medium-sized LLMs for both of these tasks on a database representing publicly available data from the US Army’s Multi-purpose Sensing Area Multi-Purpose Sensing Area (MSA) at the Jornada Range in Las Cruces, NM. We observe that Llama 3.1 (8 billion parameters) outperforms the other models across all considered metrics. Most importantly, we note that, unlike current methods, our two step approach allows the relaxation of the Exact Match (EM) requirement of the produced Cypher queries with ground truth code and, in this way, it achieves a 19.4% increase in accuracy. Our workflow lays the groundwork for deploying LLMs on edge devices to enable natural language interactions with databases containing information objects for critical decision making.

title: Authentication and Access Control in Fog-IoT Enabled Framework based on Blockchain Technology: A Survey
authors: Priyanka S. Yengantwar, Ujwal A. Lanjewar
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: In today’s world rapid development in technology has produced large number of smart devices, such as tabs, smart phones, smart watches, etc. This leads to a digital world where all day-to-day activity data is saved online from any where, any time and using numerous of smart devices. At the same time, Authentication and Access Control plays an important role in the concept of smart spaces. Authentication of user is a process to verify the user’s identity that protects the user's personal information stored on his/her personal devices such as smart watches, phones and tabs such as online banking and also on customized services which are available in smart spaces such as smart homes. Traditional authentication methods have recently been repeatedly demonstrated to be vulnerable to attacks. To overcome these problems blockchain can provide tamper proof data, security and integrity. Researchers nowadays have invented many new mechanisms for authentication of the user and their access control. In this survey, we will describe an introduction to authentication and access control and blockchain, we presents a thorough background details of authentication, access control mechanism and blockchain technology, the need of integrating blockchain in authentication and access control. Then, we construct classification of available methods according to their category, application and use of blockchain.

title: Bean Leaf Lesion Classification using Fine-Tuned EfficientNetV2 for Early Disease Detection
authors: Sripelli Jagadish, Bhoomika, Manisha Aeri, Aanchal Rawat
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: Reliable sustainable agricultural output and protection of crop health depend mostly on precise and quick diagnosis of plant diseases. Using a deep learning approach with a fine-tuned EfficientNetV2 model, this work targets three primary categories: healthy leaves, angular leaf spot, and bean rust to classify bean leaf diseases. Drawn from the open-source Kaggle platform, the 1, 167 high-resolution photographs used in the dataset include 133 for testing and 1,034 images used for training. Attaching an amazing 97% classification accuracy with great precision, recall, and F1-scores across all classes, the model Performance review using loss/accuracy curves and a confusion matrix revealed excellent learning behaviour, strong generalization, and little overfitting. These results reveal the program's ability to identify quite consistent leaf diseases. The proposed method enables early diagnosis and informed decision-making that help to include deep learning into agricultural disease monitoring systems, hence enabling improved crop management and productivity.

title: ResNet50-based Framework for Accurate Identification of Orange Fruit Diseases
authors: Sripelli Jagadish, Seerat Singla, Manisha Aeri, Aanchal Rawat
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: Orange cultivation plays a vital role in the global citrus industry, but its productivity and marketability are significantly hindered by various diseases. Accurate and early identification of such diseases is crucial for sustainable agricultural practices. This study presents an automated classification approach for orange fruit diseases using the Orange Fruit Dataset obtained from Kaggle, which comprises 8,600 images across three distinct classes: Citrus Canker, Healthy, and Melanose. The model was fine-tuned with custom dense layers and trained using stratified sampling with an 80-10-10 split for training, validation, and testing, respectively. Data augmentation and preprocessing techniques were applied The model's performance was evaluated using classification metrics such as accuracy, precision, recall, and F1-score. The proposed ResNet50-based model achieved a remarkable overall accuracy of 97%, with a precision of 0.97, recall of 0.97, and F1score of 0.97, demonstrating robust and reliable performance across all three disease classes. These results confirm the model’s effectiveness in supporting automated disease diagnosis in smart agriculture systems.

title: Voltage-Time Hybrid Domain ADC with PVT Tracking for High-Frame-Rate CMOS Image Sensor
authors: Xin Li, Ziheng Wang, Bin Qiang, Chunyu Peng, Qiang Zhao, Xiulong Wu
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Integrated Circuits and Microsystems (ICICM)
abstract: This paper proposes a high-speed, area-efficient an alog-to-digital converter (ADC) tailored for CMOS image sensors (CIS). The architecture integrates a Successive Approximation Register (SAR) ADC for coarse voltage-domain quantization and a Time-to-Digital Converter (TDC) to achieve fine time-domain quantization. In this scheme, the inherent process-voltage-temperature (PVT) robustness is enhanced by establishing a current-based relationship between the Voltage-to-Time Converter (VTC) and TDC, there by reducing power consumption and circuit complexity. The prposed ADC is designed in a Nyquist sampling rate of 20 MS/s in 65 nm CMOS process, achieving a SNDR of 67.92 dB and a SFDR of 76.04 dB, respectively. Along with a Schreier figure-of-merit (FoM) of $\mathbf{2 0 7. 5 ~ f J} \boldsymbol{/} \mathbf{C o n v}$-step.

title: Adaptive Hybrid Learning Architecture for Robust Early Prediction of Chronic Kidney Disease
authors: Vignesh S, Dharanish N, DineshKarthick S S
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: This research work proposes a machine learning-based diagnostic tool called the CKD Prediction Web Application to assist professionals in identifying chronic kidney disease (CKD) early on. It uses Streamlit for hosting and is written in Python. Age, blood pressure, specific gravity, albumin, sugar, hemoglobin, diabetes, and hypertension are among the demographic and laboratory test patient data that the app uses to predict chronic kidney disease (CKD). The CKD prediction can be made by either uploading a dataset or entering individual patient data. The model is subjected to a number of key preprocessing steps including data cleaning, label encoding, feature selection using Select K Best, and feature scaling. Model evaluation results using a confusion matrix and classification report indicated the model performed with high accuracy on the test set. The model performed effectively at identifying CKD and non-CKD cases. Through an interactive web-based interface, the user can receive instant results, meaning either a single individual can have CKD predicted or a batch of dataset can be uploaded and predictions provided for each unique record. This project is a practical illustration of AI in healthcare that is affordable, easily accessible, and dependable to assist clinical decision-making and enhance patient outcomes.

title: Rainfall-based Flood Prediction using an Improved SqueezeNet Architecture
authors: Vanam Yoganand, Sheela Rani B, Nagamani Kattukota
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: Rainfall-based flood prediction is essential as the key cause of flood is due to rain. The existing methods struggle in handling large, complex data, which is insufficient for accurate real-time flood prediction. Deep Learning models are the most promising models to make accurate predictions. This paper intends to propose a rainfall-based flood prediction model with the following steps: a min-max normalization method in the preprocessing step, and an improved squeezeNet technique for accurate flood prediction. The standard squeezeNet model includes a limited number of layers and filters, which is not suitable for learning complex patterns and for accurate flood prediction. To overcome these limitations, this paper proposes an improved SqueezeNet that includes an advanced mixed pooling layer along with ten fire modules to improve the flood prediction accuracy. The analysis of the proposed work ensures satisfactory results in terms of precise prediction.

title: T1C-Enhanced TFT-Integrated Gate Driver Circuit Design for Reliable In-cell Touch Sensing Displays
authors: Congwei Liao, Yong Wang, Chao Teng, Yi Shen, Yudong Liu, Shengdong Zhang
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Integrated Circuits and Microsystems (ICICM)
abstract: A thin-film transistors (TFTs) integrated gate driver is presented for time-division in-cell touch sensing display. The proposed gate driver consists of two cascaded functional stages: a touch-sensing stage and a non-touch-sensing stage. In the touch-sensing stage, an additional TFT and one capacitor are introduced into the input module to effectively suppress prolonged positive gate-to-source stress of the driving TFT. The non-touch-sensing stage employs a compact 5-TFT 1-capacitor schematic. A key advantage of this design is its ability to maintain continuous clock signals throughout both touch-sensing and display intervals, thereby significantly simplifying the external clock generation circuit. The gate driver circuit is thoroughly verified based on amorphous silicon (a-Si:H) TFTs using SPICE simulation tools, confirming reliable voltage bootstrapping operation even during touch-sensing intervals exceeding $400 \mu \mathrm{~s}$. The proposed gate driver is promising for compact and reliable in-cell touch sensing display applications.

title: Autoencoder-Based Gaussianity for Low Probability of Intercept Detection in Terahertz Communications
authors: Abigail O. Oyekola, Majumder Haider, Imtiaz Ahmed, Danda B. Rawat
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: This paper addresses the challenges of signal interception and detection in Terahertz (THz) networks. We explore how preserving the Gaussianity of transmit signals enhances Low Probability of Intercept and Detection (LPID) features using a data-driven autoencoder in THz band communication systems. By analyzing the probability distribution function (PDF) of THz band transmit signals, we evaluate their impact on LPID performance. Given the high sensitivity of THz systems to Phase Noise (PN) and the In-phase and Quadrature (IQ) imbalance impairments, we illustrate the importance of maintaining Gaussianity under varying PN conditions to ensure reliable and secure LPID transmission. Through comprehensive simulations, we demonstrate that PN does not compromise the Gaussianity of autoencoder-based THz band transmit signals. These results highlight the robustness of Gaussianity preservation, offering critical insights for designing THz band autoencoder-based LPID networks resilient to eavesdropping, jamming, and unauthorized interception. Our proposed autoencoder framework not only enhances LPID but also mitigates PN and IQ imbalance impairments, paving the way for secure, efficient, and reliable communication in next-generation THz networks.

title: NEXERA: A Unified Smart Education Platform With AI-based Bus Attendance Verification, Tracking and Academic Monitoring
authors: Sandhiya S, Swathi B, Thrishalini S P, Varshini J, Sudha J
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: Educational institutions increasingly rely on digital platforms to manage academic activities and transport operations. However, most systems operate in isolation, leading to fragmented data, manual workload, and limited safety mechanisms. This paper presents NEXERA, an integrated smart education platform that unifies AI-enabled bus attendance verification, IoT-based GPS tracking, and cloud-driven academic management. The system incorporates GPS modules and QR-based identification to accurately log student boarding and de-boarding events while transmitting live geolocation data through a cloud server. AI models detect route deviations and inconsistent boarding patterns to enhance travel safety. In parallel, NEXERA provides modular web portals for students, teachers, parents, and administrators to access academic records, fee details, attendance analytics, performance dashboards, and alerts. Experimental evaluation confirms 98% QR-scan accuracy, 10-second GPS update latency, and major reductions in manual data processing. The platform demonstrates significant potential in modernizing institutional workflows while ensuring student safety, transparency, and data-driven decision-making.

title: IoT-based Solar-Powered Thermal Management of EV Batteries with MPPT and Intelligent Control
authors: Subramaniam G, Kasivisvanathan K, Fahmitha H, Karthick R
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: Electric vehicles (EVs) have shown a high rate of development, which requires advanced battery management systems that provide safety, performance, and durability. The main issues that impact the battery life and reliability of the vehicles are overheating and bad usage of energy. The presented paper outlines an EV battery solar-powered thermal management system based on the IoT with Maximum Power Point Tracking (MPPT) and smart control. The system uses a solar panel to extract useful renewable energy without wastage and the MPPT algorithm optimizes power output during different sunlight conditions. A microcontroller (Atmega328) constantly measures temperature and voltage of the battery. A cooling fan powered by a relay is turned on when the temperature is too high according to a set of pre-established limits and a buzzer notifies the user. Smoke detection sensor also contributes to the safety of the area by turning the motors off automatically in unsafe situations. An LCD displays all problematic parameters, such as battery voltage, temperature, solar voltage, and system status and sends them in real-time to an IoT cloud platform where it can be monitored and controlled remotely. It has been experimentally shown that the combination of solar power and intelligent thermal management can enhance the reliability of the battery, safety of the operation, and efficiency of power consumption. Such a solution is a long-term one, as it will decrease the reliance on grid power and will provide an opportunity to operate EV in a smart and efficient manner.

title: Automated Identification and Classification of Colon Cancer with Deep Learning Techniques: A Comparative Analysis
authors: Rajendran Sivakumar
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: Colon cancer continues to pose a significant worldwide health concern, necessitating effective detection and prompt classification for successful treatment and enhanced patient outcomes. Recent advancements in deep learning (DL) have transformed automated medical image processing, facilitating improved diagnosis and classification precision for colorectal cancer. This work offers a comparative comparison of advanced DL architectures, including convolutional neural networks (CNNs), and diverse transfer learning techniques like Xception, VGG16, VGG19, ResNet, and Inception, utilised on colonoscopy and histology image datasets. Quantitative analysis reveals that models like ResNet and Inception attain outstanding outcome, with accuracy, sensitivity, and specificity exceeding 97%, 96%, and 98% respectively. The research emphasises the significance of explainable artificial intelligence (AI) in fostering clinician trust, employing visual explainability tools to elucidate model decisions. The results highlight that DL methodologies provide effective, scalable solutions for colon cancer screening and substantially assist doctors in early diagnosis, localisation, and treatment planning. Future endeavours will concentrate on the integration of multimodal imaging and the enhancement of model interpretability for practical clinical implementation.

title: A Review on Smart Piezoelectric Sensor-based Welcome Mat for Real-Time Visitor Detection and Greeting Systems
authors: A.R. Kalaiarasi, D. Girivasan, J.Abdul Rasith, G.Vamsi
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: Traditional visitor identification systems, such as doorbells and motion sensors, usually face poor response rates, expense, and complicated installations, making them inefficient. This work presents a Smart Piezoelectric Sensor-Based Welcome Mat that identifies footsteps in real time by the use of a piezoelectric sensor and an Arduino microcontroller. Pressure applied generates electrical pulses, which the Arduino then uses to activate a buzzer to produce an instant audio response. The system is designed to offer a low-cost, energy-saving, easy-to-use visitor identification mechanism while bringing enhanced security to homes as well as offices. The novelty is the adoption of a plain piezoelectric mat as the intuitive, instant, easy-to-setup solution to visitor identification as well as automated greetings.

title: AI based Intelligent Power Management Framework for Efficient Power Distribution System
authors: M. Hariprabhu, Giri Prasath K, Jagantheeswari E, Kosalaraman T
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: The integration of renewable energy sources (RES), such as wind and solar, into modern power grids has significantly transformed traditional energy management systems. However, the intermittency and unpredictability of these sources pose challenges to grid stability, reliability, and optimal utilization. This study proposes an AI-based intelligent power management framework that combines Artificial Neural Networks (ANN) and Fuzzy Logic to enhance decision-making in energy distribution. The ANN predicts future load demand and renewable generation, while the Fuzzy Logic controller dynamically allocates power among generation units, storage systems, and connected loads. The system also incorporates an islanding mode, enabling autonomous operation during grid failures by balancing local generation with consumption. Simulation results demonstrate significant improvements in system reliability, energy efficiency, and reduced dependence on conventional sources. Additionally, the proposed framework enables intelligent battery management, extending storage lifespan and ensuring efficient energy utilization. The solution is scalable, adaptive, and applicable to both grid-connected and islanded microgrids, contributing to the advancement of smart grid technologies.

title: AI-Powered Conversational Teaching: Revolutionizing Interactive Education Through Natural Language Processing
authors: M. Nagaraju Naik, Vamsi Krishna B, Shaik Wafiya, B. Shiny Sucharitha
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: In recent years, education has become increasingly digital, with platforms like Moodle, Canvas, Open edX, and Blackboard transforming learning by providing greater flexibility and efficiency. However, these platforms often fall short of meeting the diverse needs of teachers and students due to their rigid, one-size-fits-all approach to delivering information. Advances in artificial intelligence and natural language processing have introduced innovative tools such as text analysis, automated content translation, text categorization, sentiment analysis, voice recognition, and recommendation systems. These technologies make it possible to create adaptive, personalized learning experiences that align with individual preferences and learning styles. This article explores how AI and NLP are shaping the future of online education, highlighting their potential to enhance content design for educators and improve navigation and learning experiences for students. It also addresses the challenges of integrating these technologies into existing educational platforms, pointing toward more innovative, learner-centered digital education solutions.

title: An Open-Source Framework for IEEE 802.11bf Evaluation Under Lossy and Jittery Conditions
authors: Tanguy Ropitault, Steve Blandino, Nada Golmie
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: Integrated Sensing and Communication (ISAC) is emerging as a key enabler for future wireless systems, offering dual communication and sensing capabilities using the same hardware. A leading realization of this paradigm is Wi-Fi sensing, now being standardized in IEEE 802.11bf, which expands Wi-Fi’s role into environmental awareness. Wi-Fi sensing can support diverse applications, from smart homes to healthcare, and is highly relevant for military and security use, enabling intrusion detection, silent perimeter monitoring, and situational awareness, without dedicated radar infrastructure. However, like conventional IEEE 802.11 networks, 802.11bf sensing is prone to delays and losses from contention-based access, interference, collisions, and congestion. These issues can significantly degrade sensing, which relies on consistently timed and complete measurements.This paper presents an extension of the open-source ISAC-Physical Layer Model (PLM) framework to enable the evaluation of Wi-Fi sensing under lossy and irregular timing. In an indoor military surveillance scenario, results show that velocity accuracy significantly degrades with the packet loss and timing irregularities. These findings highlight the need for resilient sensing algorithms and robust, reproducible testing environments, both of which being supported by our proposed platform.

title: A Unified Swin Transformer Framework for Inverse Lithography and Lithography Simulation
authors: Jiajun Tan, Ling Liang, Ming Zhu
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Integrated Circuits and Microsystems (ICICM)
abstract: Inverse Lithography Technology (ILT) and lithography simulation are two core components in modern computational lithography, yet they are typically handled separately due to their distinct objectives and modeling requirements. To enable joint optimization and simulation, a unified multitask framework, Swin-LithoNet, is proposed based on the Swin Transformer to perform ILT mask optimization and resist image simulation. Our architecture integrates a shared Swin Transformer encoder with task-specific U-Net decoders, enabling joint learning and improved generalization across both tasks. To guide the learning process, task-specific loss functions are constructed by incorporating physical and geometric constraints, including Process Variation Band (PVB), Edge Placement Error (EPE), and Mean Squared Error (MSE). Extensive experiments on the ICCAD-2013 benchmark demonstrate that our method achieves up to 39.3 % reduction in L2 loss and 83.8 % reduction in EPE compared to prior ILT models, while maintaining competitive performance in lithography simulation. Our results highlight the effectiveness of multi-task learning for EDA applications and offer a scalable foundation for future research in manufacturability-aware design automation.

title: From Data to Decisions: Machine Learning Frameworks for Optimizing Mechanical Production Processes
authors: Suvika K V, Spandana S G, Nandini S, Jyothi M V
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: Data-driven methods are being used more and more in mechanical production systems to improve productivity, quality, and affordability. By combining data collection, preprocessing, predictive modeling, and multi-objective optimization, this research offers a machine learning framework for production process optimization. While optimization techniques balance trade-offs between quality, cost, and production time, the framework uses regression and classification models to forecast important outcomes including surface roughness, tool life, and defect rates. Experiments show that ensemble-based models out- perform baseline methods in terms of predicted accuracy, and that process parameter optimization results in quantifiable gains in resource efficiency and product quality. The study highlights the relevance of machine learning for real-time decision-making in mechanical sectors and further confirms its findings against contemporary literature. By integrating machine learning, this effort advances the development of intelligent, flexible, and sustainable production systems.

title: Enhancing Spectrum Sensing Through Coupled Hidden Markov Models
authors: Haodong Yang, Joshua Kortje, Biao Chen, Pramod Varshney, Jithin Jagannath, Anu Jagannath
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: This paper studies spectrum map recovery with distributed spectrum sensors by exploiting frequency and spatial correlation to reconstruct a more refined spectrum map at each sensor location. Hidden Markov models (HMM) are proposed to model the spectrum sensing output at each sensor to capture the frequency correlation; spatial correlation is captured by coupling the hidden states across different HMMs. As a result, spectrum map recovery is reduced to simultaneous state estimation for a collection of HMMs of equal length, where the states exhibit horizontal correlations across the HMMs. Maximum-entropy formulation is employed to estimate the joint distribution of multiple HMM output sequences. Subsequently, the forward-backward algorithm is implemented to infer the hidden states. Numerical experiments are conducted to demonstrate the advantage of the proposed approach in constructing a more refined spectrum map compared with approaches that do not account for frequency and spatial correlations.

title: RLMBFF: Multi-bit Flip-Flops Merging using Deep Reinforcement Learning
authors: Zeqi Chen, Zhaori Bi, Changhao Yan, Ming Zhu, Xiulong Wu, Xuan Zeng
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Integrated Circuits and Microsystems (ICICM)
abstract: Multi-bit flip-flop (MBFF) merging has been proven to be an effective way to save dynamic power and reduce the utilization rate of the chip area. Most of the existing work uses either a clustering method or an analytical way to merge multiple single-bit flip-flops (SBFFs) into MBFFs. In this paper, inspired by the recent success in deep reinforcement learning, we propose a novel MBFF merging method leveraging neural network. The approach can be divided into two steps: (i) placing MBFFs by a pretrained RL agent, and (ii) mapping the pin pairs of the original SBFF to the MBFF cell. Experimental results show that our method can significantly save power and area, without large perturbations to the timing.

title: Configurable Framework for Adaptive UAV Platoon Planning under Limited Communication Range
authors: Baisakhi Chatterjee, Rudra Dutta
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: Unmanned Aerial Vehicles (UAVs), especially multi-UAV groups, have a variety of applications, making them a focus of growing research interest. With estimates saying that millions of UAVs will take to the skies in the near future, coordinated adaptive planning has become a critical element in completion and correctness of mission execution. Effective collaborative decision-making requires seamless communication among agents, which introduces a variety of challenges. In this work, we have focused on addressing the problem of maintaining coordination while performing missions when communication range is limited. UAVs are often expected to be able to perform in remote, infrastructure-less locations while maintaining communication. In a large domain, as the agents spread out, this may become difficult, leading to a breakdown in collaboration and end in mission failure. To address this, we propose a configurable framework that enables agents to adaptively plan their trajectories and rely on fallback strategies when communication becomes infeasible. Using Plume Wrapping as an exemplar, we have proposed two algorithms – AeroSweep and AeroBeam – which allow the platoon to use alternate options like limiting interUAV distance or following a clock-based synchronization strategy in order to continue the mission. The goal of our work is to demonstrate that our framework can not only complete the task successfully, but can also be tuned to produce required coverage within acceptable cost bounds based on mission specifications and domain knowledge.

title: Beyond Transcripts: A Learner-Centred Review for Closing the Graduate Skills Gap
authors: Hasib Mohammad Khan, Monisha Singh, Lakshmi R
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: The majority of the university graduates leave their courses with high grades, but they usually do not have the necessary skills needed in the working environments including teamwork, problem-solving and digital skills. This disconnect between higher education training and the needs of the industry is what is referred to as the graduate skills gap. The article consists of a literature review from 2020-2025 to explore how learner-centred pedagogy can be used to reduce this gap. The results have shown that project-based learning, real-life assessment, internship and micro-credential equip students better than conventional exams. Employers prefer technical and soft skills to academic performance, but most universities are facing problems with stiff curricula and lack of faculty training. This review proposes the incorporation of practice projects, industry partnership, and online skill records to fill the gap. These are some of the strategies that can be used to equip the students with the competencies needed in the current dynamically changing labour market.

title: Anime Recommendation System using Machine Learning and React
authors: Bhaskaruni Harini, Gangula Gowtham Reddy, T. Kamaleshwar
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: In today’s digital media ecosystem, it can be difficult for audiences to determine which anime shows would work well for them with the rise of anime series and availability for viewing. In this paper, we recommend a hybrid system consisting of machine learning (ML), data processing, and a React-based web interface, to provide smart and personalized predictions for anime recommendations. The proposed system collects user data from previous viewing histories , and previously assigned ratings and genre preferences and then applies ML models to identify trends in user behavior and ultimately create a model to estimate the user’s model. The backend uses content-based filtering and collaborative filtering techniques to generate scores of similarity between users and anime, and ultimately generate recommendations for each user. The front end, built in React, provides an interactive and responsive interface for users to explore, rate, and receive recommendations in real time. The model also incorporates continuous feedback to make accurate predictions in real time. This research contributes to the field by (1) applying ML algorithms to personalize anime recommendations from user behavior and content similarity, (2) offering a responsive React interface for interaction in real-time, and (3) showcasing an adaptive environment for recommendations that improve user draw in digital entertainment. Our model demonstrates the opportunity for efficiency, scalability, and design in machine learning in conjunction with upgraded web construction technology to generate user-centered recommendation systems.

title: A Compact Active Phase Shifter for 110-150 GHz Phased Arrays in 130 nm BiCMOS
authors: Shuguang Liu, Jinhao Zhou, Yuyang Liu, Hu Lian, Yaxin Zhang, Ziqiang Yang
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Integrated Circuits and Microsystems (ICICM)
abstract: A D-band vector modulator-type phase shifter (VMPS) is presented using an $130-\mathrm{nm}$ BiCMOS process. A transformer-based fully differential hybrid is designed to generate high-precision orthogonal signals, which presents a compact layout and effectively widens the operating bandwidth. A D-band output signal is generated after the IQ signal is synthesized by the vector summation network controlled by the transistor base control signal. The measured results exhibit that the proposed circuit achieves a 360° phase shifting range with 5.625° step in the wideband from 110 GHz to 170 GHz. The measured RMS phase and amplitude error are under 1.38° and 0.76 dB at 145 GHz, respectively. The average gain is about 1.16 dB. Thanks to the proposed quadrature generator, the core area of the phase shifter is $\mathbf{2 3 0} \times \mathbf{1 8 0} \boldsymbol{\mu} \mathbf{m}^{\mathbf{2}}$.

title: Physics-Constrained TCN-ConvLSTM Model for Sea Surface Temperature Prediction
authors: Minghao Gu, Xiaoyong Li, Song Wu, Mingkun Tan, Xingyu Zhu
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conferences on Internet of Things (iThings) IEEE Green Computing &amp; Communications (GreenCom) IEEE Cyber, Physical &amp; Social Computing (CPSCom) and IEEE Smart Data (SmartData) and IEEE Congress on Cybermatics (Cybermatics)
abstract: Sea surface temperature (SST), as a fundamental variable in the ocean-atmosphere coupled system, plays a critical role in regulating marine ecosystems. Accurate prediction of SST is essential for understanding climate variability, supporting ecological assessments, and informing human-related decision-making in coastal and oceanic regions. Although traditional data-driven prediction models can capture the spatiotemporal features of sea surface temperature, they often violate ocean dynamic principles by neglecting underlying physical laws. To address this issue, this paper proposes a Physics-Guided ConvLSTM (PGConvLSTM) model that integrates physical constraints with Temporal Convolutional Network (TCN) and ConvLSTM, which enhances prediction accuracy and physical consistency by incorporating the ocean density equation constraints into the loss function. Experimental results show that, compared to the baseline ConvLSTM model, PG-ConvLSTM achieves: <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$5.2 \%-8.7 \%$</tex> reduction in Root Mean Squared Error (RMSE) for 12-month global SST forecasts, 12.3% decrease in density deviation. The predictions generated by the proposed model better adhere to physical laws, such as ocean density stratification. In a word, this approach offers a novel solution that balances prediction accuracy and physical consistency in sea surface temperature (SST) forecasting.

title: Federated Blockchain–IoT Framework for Transparent and Intelligent Carbon-Credit Management in the Automotive Sector
authors: C.Madhusudhana Rao, Praveen Kumar Naidu Rayanki, Polepalli Rajeev Meenon, Salapakshi Jai Kumar, Ganga Kaveri Nimmakayala
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: Massive growth of the Chinese carbon-credit market has been characterized by endemic data obscurity, certification latency, and fraud, specifically in the Passenger Cars Corporate Average Fuel Consumption and New Energy Vehicle Credit Regulation (PCFN) scheme in the automotive industry. Its present centralized management system is not transparent and has information asymmetries and is very prone to manipulation results in erroneous carbon-credit determination, inefficient dealings, and the deteriorating stakeholder confidence. This paper offers a federated blockchain-IoT information infrastructure to deal with these severe inadequacies, namely, the provision of end-to-end transparency, tamper-resistance, and autonomous functionality in managing carbon-credit. The framework uses radio frequency identification (RFID) to capture real-time emission data, delegated proof-of-stake (DPoS) consensus to provide scalable verification and uses smart contracts to provide a decentralized credit assessment and trading. Besides, an AI-based predictive analytics control is incorporated to dynamically predict credit prices and identify anomalies on distributed nodes. Experimental comparison with national automotive carbon datasets reveals that the 72.6% latency of credit verification is reduced, the 38.2% transparency of audit is increased, and the 93.5% accuracy of fraud detection is achieved rather significantly in comparison to the traditional centralized model. The suggested framework will offer a platform on which the cross-sector carbon-credit markets of China can be scaled and verified to speed up the process of the country achieving its carbon neutrality targets of 3060.

title: VF-RRT*-PSO: A Decentralized Planning Framework for Multi-UAV Systems in Cluttered Environments
authors: Mohammad Ibrahim, Andreas Mauthe, Thies Möhlenhof
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: We present VF-RRT<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">⋆</sup>–PSO, a fully decentralized framework for Multi-UAV Cooperative Path Planning (MUCPP) in partially known, obstacle-dense environments. The system integrates (i) vector field–guided RRT<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">⋆</sup> for fast, goal-oriented global path initialization, (ii) particle swarm optimization (PSO) with adaptive topology switching for multi-objective trajectory refinement, and (iii) a lightweight leader–follower coordination scheme for scalable conflict resolution. Consistent vector field guidance in both planning and refinement preserves path quality and enhances obstacle avoidance in cluttered environments. Across diverse benchmark scenarios, VF-RRT<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">⋆</sup>–PSO reduces collisions, shortens path lengths, and maintains sub-quadratic runtime growth for large UAV teams, outperforming established baselines in safety, efficiency, and scalability.

title: Adaptive Interventional Robotic System using Temporal Convolutional Network for Predictive Force Control in Retinal Microsurgery
authors: Reena S Rajan, H Vennila
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: Retinal microsurgery demands precise force regulation due to the extreme delicacy of intraocular tissues and the absence of natural tactile feedback. This study introduces an Adaptive Interventional Robotic System (AIRS) incorporating a Temporal Convolutional Network (TCN) for predictive control of scleral interaction forces. The developed system integrates high-frequency Fiber Bragg Grating (FBG) force sensing with a real-time adaptive admittance controller to prevent unsafe tool-tissue contact during surgical procedures. Experiments were conducted on a retinal phantom model that simulates scleral biomechanics, where the FBG sensors continuously captured orthogonal force components and insertion depth. The TCN processes multivariate temporal sequences to forecast near-future force values and dynamically adjust control parameters, enabling predictive stabilization. Comparative evaluation against stacked and single Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) networks demonstrated the superior learning and response performance of the AIRS-TCN framework. The model achieved a Coefficient of Determination (R2) of 0.987, Mean Squared Error (MSE) of 0.0016, Mean Absolute Error (MAE) of 0.029, F1-Score of 95.6% and an average Prediction Time of 8 ms. These results confirm the TCN’s ability to capture long-range temporal dependencies while maintaining real-time inference capability. The agreement between predicted and measured forces highlights the model’s robustness, stability and clinical potential for ensuring safe, compliant and precise motion behavior in robot-assisted retinal microsurgery.

title: Multi-Layer Secret Sharing for Cross-Layer Attack Defense in 5G Networks: a COTS UE Demonstration
authors: Wai Ming Chan, Rémi Chou, Taejoon Kim
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: This demo presents the first implementation of multi-layer secret sharing on commercial-off-the-shelf (COTS) 5G user equipment (UE), operating without infrastructure modifications or pre-shared keys. Our XOR-based approach distributes secret shares across network operators and distributed relays, ensuring perfect recovery and data confidentiality even if one network operator and one relay are simultaneously lost (e.g., under denial of service (DoS) or unanticipated attacks).

title: An Efficient Three-Level Hybrid Caesar-Vigenère Cipher Converter with LFSR
authors: Swarali Kulkarni, Sanika Kirve, Manali Khare, Neha Biradar, Prachi Mukherji, Seema Rajput
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: This study presents a lightweight hybrid encryption architecture that combines Caesar and Vigenère Ciphers with a Linear Field Shift Register(LFSR) generated random key with power of 181.9 μW and speed of 4720 Mbps to enhance security while preserving hardware efficiency. The suggested design reduces predictable patterns and increases resistance to classical attacks by supporting the entire 128-character ASCII range, in contrast to conventional alphabet based implementations. The entire system is implemented in 45 nm CMOS using Cadence Virtuoso with minimal logic of XOR gates, adders, D-flip flops, and shift registers to achieve low power, low delay and compact hardware. The hybrid structure is appropriate for embedded and Internet of Things applications because it raises security without appreciably increasing hardware complexity. The findings show that the suggested architecture outperforms standalone classical Ciphers in terms of security and performance, providing a workable solution for low-power systems.

title: Enhancing Cybersecurity and IT Service Desk Support with Artificial Intelligence, SIEM Tools, MFA Integration, and Incident Response
authors: Ashish Pulivarthy
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: The fast-changing digital environment, increasingly targeted by cyber-attacks, demands a dynamic approach to safeguarding organizational assets and providing effective IT service desk support. In this paper, it is stated that the application of Artificial Intelligence (AI), Security Information and Event Management (SIEM) tools, Multi Factor Authentication (MFA) and incident response plans can be interlinked to assist in enhancing cybersecurity, along with the IT service desk efficiency. We examine the application of AI: to automate threat detection and response through automation of SIEM in the form of AI-driven SIEM automation, to attack real-time Security Monitoring with SIEM tools and as one of the key dimensions of ensuring the enhancement of the access control via Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA). In addition, the paper also explains the role that a joint incident response mechanism has in alleviating the effects of breaches and enhancing the organizational resilience of large organizations. Implementing these technologies will allow institutions to achieve more precise detection and faster response times, and less overhead, which will eventually lead to more investment in cybersecurity and IT support systems. The paper also provides a case study and implementation issues to provide a full picture of the practical implications of the integrated solutions.

title: Machine Learning-Driven Angle of Arrival Estimation for a Moving Signal Source
authors: Jin Feng Lin, Charles Montes, Nathaniel D. Bastian, Ruolin Zhou
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: This paper proposes a hybrid deep learning architecture that combines Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN) and Bidirectional Long Short-Term Memory (BiLSTM) networks for robust single-source Angle-of-Arrival (AoA) estimation. The model is trained on a synthetic RF dataset and evaluated on both real-world acoustic signals from the LOCATA Challenge and a live over-the-air (OTA) RF testbed. Experimental results show that the proposed CNN-BiLSTM model achieves real-time AoA tracking on a CPU-only system with inference latency under 20 ms per frame. It closely tracks the theoretical Cramér–Rao Lower Bound (CRLB) at low SNR and outperforms traditional deep learning baselines across SNRs. Compared to the classical MUSIC algorithm, the proposed approach achieves superior performance at low SNR and significantly lower cumulative RMSE when averaged across all conditions. Importantly, the CNN-BiLSTM model maintains constant inference complexity, making it suitable for deployment in time-sensitive or large-scale antenna array systems.

title: Oral Lesion Malignancy Detection using Pretrained Xception Model
authors: G Sunil, Seerat Singla, Sonal Malhotra, Kamlesh Kukreti
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: Oral cancer is a major global health issue, and the early identification of malignant lesions is critical in enhancing patient outcomes. This study aims to explore automated oral lesion classification between benign and malignant types through deep learning algorithms. The research uses the Oral Lesions Malignancy Detection dataset collected from Kaggle, which contains a total of 2,593 images 323 original and 2,270 augmented distributed under two classes: oral lesions benign and oral lesions malignant. For conducting the classification task, a transfer learning process was adopted using the Xception model, which is well known for being efficient in extracting high-level features from image data. The dataset was divided into training, validation, and test sets according to an 80:10:10 ratio after preprocessing. The model was tested according to primary performance measures such as accuracy, precision, recall, and F1-score. An overall accuracy of 98% with a precision of 0.98, recall of 0.98, and an F1-score of 0.98 was obtained with the presented model, proving its reliability and efficiency in support of clinical diagnosis of oral lesion malignancy.

title: On Forecasting CBRS Spectrum Availability
authors: Haochen Wang, Abhishek Chakraborty, Ramesh R. Rao
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: In the Citizens Broadband Radio Service (CBRS) spectrum’s opportunistic spectrum access, the General Authorized Access (GAA) and the auctioned primary access license users experience unstable spectrum availability concerning the uninformed incumbent movements in a targeted service region. Such unstable CBRS spectrum availability manifests in frequent grant suspensions and sporadic authorizations of the requesting non-incumbent devices, controlled by a centralized cloud administrator known as the spectrum access system, restraining the non-incumbent devices from providing time-critical services to the end users. Utilizing measured information communication logs from an installed GAA CBRS Device (CBSD), that record State Transitions (STs), in this paper, we evaluate the potential of a few state-of-the-art machine learning models to forecast CBRS spectrum availability from a non-incumbent user’s perspective near an incumbent-dominated region of San Diego County. Specifically, we model the CBSD STs as a marked temporal point process, a framework for modeling temporal event sequences. Our one-step-ahead prediction experiments reveal that while high accuracy (⩾90%) can be achieved in predicting the next CBSD state, accurately estimating the timing of the next ST remains challenging (e.g., mean absolute error ⩾0.2 hours and root mean squared error ⩾ 2.8 hours) due to the unpredictable nature of incumbent activities.

title: Hybrid Machine Learning–Rule-based Decision Support Framework for Enhancing Operational Intelligence and Business Process Automation in ERP Systems
authors: Ketan Rathor
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: To ensure consistency and efficiency across operations, Enterprise Resource Planning solutions automate and integrate critical corporate processes including finance, supply chain management, human resources, and customer relationship management. But, satisfying the changing, data-intensive expectations of contemporary organisations can be a struggle for classic ERP systems. As a strategic approach to improve operational intelligence and business process automation, integrating Artificial Intelligence into ERP systems has arisen to solve these limitations. The research presented here uses preprocessing and standardisation to prepare Big Data, and then it uses PCA and ICA to extract features. In order to increase classification performance, the research presents a new architecture for transfer learning that combines the Rapid Wavelet Transform and the Separator Wavelet Network. This design replaces the traditional Support Vector Machine and AlexNet models. Furthermore, in order to simplify categorisation and improve intelligent detection, a fuzzy DSS is created using fuzzy logic. While the DSS-CNN model obtains an amazing accuracy of 98.02%, experimental evaluations show that the suggested SWN-based classifier produces improved classification rates and computational efficiency. These findings highlight the fact that ERP adaptability, decision-making, and overall organisational effectiveness are greatly enhanced by AI-driven automation and operational intelligence.

title: Deep Learning-based Binary Classification of Bone Fractures using a Hybrid MobileNetV3-CNN Architecture and Clinical X-ray Dataset
authors: Jona. J. B, Kartheeban K, D. Kalpanadevi, Jeevitha S, Sri Ram Ganesh M, Somasundaram R S
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: Identifying the presence of bone fractures from radiographic images is a clinically important and time-consuming task that is limited by inter-observer variability or availability of radiologists. This research proposes an end-to-end deep learning framework for the automated classification of fractures using a hybrid architecture of MobileNetV3-Small and specifically designed new convolutional layers. The framework was trained and validated on the Fracture Multi-Region X-ray dataset, a publicly available dataset containing 10,580 grayscale X-ray images labelled from different anatomically connected regions (bones of limbs, spine, hips, knees). To improve diagnostic accuracy and freedoms, we implemented transfer learning, data preprocessing, a comprehensive and internal augmentation pipeline (including flipping, rotation, contrast, and zoom), etc. MobileNetV3-Small was used as a lightweight feature extractor and further optimized with our convolutional blocks, batch normalization, dropout, and global average pooling. Our training strategy included two separate phases, where the first phase aimed to solely extract the features, with the second phase featuring feature extraction and then fine-tuning, while optimization was executed using AdamW with a fully adaptive learning schedule. Evaluation performance on the test set resulted in isolated classification accuracy of 97%, and was candidates set against DenseNet121, VGG-16, and ResNet50. The findings validate the effectiveness of using lightweight architectures enhanced with domain-specific features for precise medical image analysis. Due to its computational efficiency, the model is suitable for real-time and resource-constrained applications, such as point-of-care and mobile health systems. This work establishes a foundation for future improvement through transformer-based architectures, multimodal data types, and explainable AI to facilitate diagnostic confidence and opportunities for clinical decision-making.

title: A Hybrid DTN/NDN Middleware Gateway Controller for UAV Applications
authors: Ronald Langrin, Jeremy Blackstone
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: This paper introduces a hybrid middleware system for Unmanned Arial Vehicles (UAV) that can seamlessly alternate between Delay/Disruption Tolerant Networking (DTN) and Named Data Networking (NDN) without any changes to the application protocols. We first describe the middleware gateway controller system design, then, discuss the implementation details of the prototype built as containerized docker micro-services, and finally, show preliminary evaluations with practical UAV application use cases highlighting the efficacy of mixing the two protocols for time-sensitive data dissemination in highly dynamic heterogeneous network environments. The preliminary results highlight improved interoperability and resiliency in the hybrid protocol approach, laying the groundwork for future research in information sharing in highly contested environments.

title: Frequency Control in Microgrids: A Fuzzy Neural Network-Based Adaptive Virtual Synchronous Generator
authors: Waleed Breesam, Rezvan Alamian, Nima Tashakor, Brahim Elkhalil Youcefa, Stefan M. Goetz
publish: IEEE Transactions on Smart Grid
abstract: The reliance on distributed renewable energy has increased recently. As a result, power electronic-based distributed generators replaced synchronous generators which led to a change in the dynamic characteristics of the microgrid. Most critically, they reduced system inertia and damping. Virtual synchronous generators emulated in power electronics, which mimic the dynamic behaviour of synchronous generators, are meant to fix this problem. However, fixed virtual synchronous generator parameters cannot guarantee a frequency regulation within the acceptable tolerance range. Conversely, a dynamic adjustment of these virtual parameters promises robust solution with stable frequency. This paper proposes a method to adapt the inertia, damping, and droop parameters dynamically through a fuzzy neural network controller. This controller trains itself online to choose appropriate values for these virtual parameters. The proposed method can be applied to a typical AC microgrid by considering the penetration and impact of renewable energy sources. We study the system in a MATLAB/Simulink model and validate it experimentally in real time using hardware-in-the-loop based on an embedded ARM system (SAM3X8E, Cortex-M3). Compared to traditional and fuzzy logic controller methods, the results demonstrate that the proposed method significantly reduces the frequency deviation to less than 0.03 Hz and shortens the stabilizing/recovery time.

title: GaN-on-Si Double-Channel Bi-Directional Switch Free of Back-Gating Effects by Synchronized Photonic-Electronic Driving Scheme
authors: Zheng Wu, Zongjie Zhou, Longge Deng, Yat Hon Ng, Yutao Geng, Yan Cheng, Tao Chen, Kevin J. Chen
publish: IEEE Electron Device Letters
abstract: A GaN-on-Si bi-directional switch (BDS) in the common-drain configuration is typically confronted with the back-gating effects that induce electron trapping in the buffer layer, resulting in severe dynamic on-resistance (RON) degradation and distortion in the chopping waveform that are currently addressed by active substrate control. In this work, a holistic approach is demonstrated to eliminate the back-gating effects in the GaN-on-Si BDS without using the active substrate control. Different from the conventional single-channel design, the proposed device features two closely coupled 2DEG channels in between there exists a hole-storage/spreading channel. With a synchronized photonic-electronic driving (SPED) scheme, in the on-state, electron-hole pairs (EHPs) are generated in the source-to-gate and gate-to-drain access regions by photons with an above-bandgap energy of ~3.65 eV from an off-chip photon source. The EHPs are separated by the vertical electric field, with the holes in the upper channel subsequently blocked by the thin inserted AlN barrier layer in the double-channel structure and spreading along the hole-storage/spreading channel to the gated region, providing effective shielding to the upper channel and inducing electrons in the lower channel to compensate for reduced 2DEG density. As a result, the double-channel BDS (DC-BDS) is free of back-gating effects.

title: Virtual Speech Therapy Room: A Machine Learning based Neuro-Behavior Sensing Virtual Reality System for Aphasia Assessment and Treatment through Multimodal Fusion
authors: R. Vaitheeshwari, Chia-Chun Kao, Rei-Xhe Wu, Chun-Chuan Chen, Po-Yi Tsai, Shih-Ching Yeh, Eric Hsiao-Kuang Wu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Neural Systems and Rehabilitation Engineering
abstract: Aphasia is a common condition following brain injury, traditionally assessed and treated by speech therapists through manual evaluations and conventional language rehabilitation. However, these methods are time-consuming, reliant on professionals, and subject to subjective biases. This study aims to develop a virtual speech therapy room with an automated assessment model to assist clinicians in evaluation. It provides immersive virtual reality (VR) language training modules, combining analysis of physiological data to achieve the goal of smart healthcare. Twenty individuals with aphasia (IWA) and ten healthy participants were involved, with aphasia subjects randomly assigned to the experimental and control group A, and healthy participants forming control group B. Clinical scales, VR tasks, and neurobehavioral data were measured as needed. Statistical analysis confirmed that using virtual reality can enhance the effectiveness of aphasia treatment interventions. Utilizing virtual reality and behavioral sensing technology, significant differences were observed in the left frontal and occipital regions between IWA and healthy participants, aligning with clinical observations of impaired language and visual processing areas. The assessment model, established through these data, achieved an average classification accuracy of 97% in distinguishing between individuals with aphasia and healthy participants using multimodal fusion with repeated cross-validation, indicating its potential as an auxiliary tool for physician assessment and treatment.

title: An Intelligent Framework for High-Precision Dynamic Force Measurement of Large Sources Based on GAARBP and Bayesian Optimization
authors: Chengbo Zhou, Mingyi Xia, Zaojun Fang, Chi Zhang, Guilin Yang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Industrial Informatics
abstract: The measurement of dynamic forces within spacecraft sources is critical for safeguarding mission accuracy and stable operation. Two major challenges impede accurate measurement of dynamic forces from large sources: the severe nonlinearity of platforms; leading to inaccuracies in traditional methods; and the explosion of redundant sensor combinations, lowering optimization efficiency. To address these issues, this article proposes an intelligent framework that synergistically integrates the genetic algorithm with adaptive-learning-rate-based back propagation (GAARBP) and Bayesian optimization (BO). The GAARBP module addresses the nonlinear input-output mapping problem of the platform, and enhances the efficiency and accuracy of model training through adaptive learning rate adjustment. The BO module employs a blockwise Matérn kernel function tailored for sensors on horizontal and vertical planes to construct a Gaussian process surrogate model, alongside an expected improvement-based acquisition function for efficient optimization. These two modules operate in a closed loop, wherein GAARBP provides accurate fitting errors to guide BO’s selection, and BO feeds back optimal sensors to enhance GAARBP’s model training. Experimental results show that the framework achieves higher measurement accuracy (error: 2.28%) and superior decoupling performance (error: 1.13%), sufficient to satisfy the measurement requirements of large vibration sources in spacecraft. Moreover, compared with conventional methods (exhaustive search, D-optimization, particle swarm optimization, etc.), the proposed framework selects the best sensor combination more effectively for the optimization problem of six sensors selected from 24, with outcomes that are virtually globally optimal. This article offers a novel, effective approach to synergistically solving nonlinear dynamic force measurement and sensor optimization in complex environments. It thereby promotes the intelligent advancement of testing technologies in these fields.

title: A Server-Side Model Intellectual Property Protection Method for Federated Learning against Model Theft
authors: Wenxiong Chen, Xuantao Tang, Dan Wang, Ju Ren
publish: IEEE Internet of Things Journal
abstract: Federated Learning (FL) has gained significant attention for enabling collaborative model training while preserving data privacy. However, protecting the intellectual property (IP) of models in FL, particularly against model theft by malicious clients, remains a critical challenge. Existing works often employ watermarking techniques to embed watermarks into models for ownership verification, but most of them can only verify ownership after the model has been stolen and cannot proactively defend against malicious clients attempting to steal the model. To address this limitation, this paper proposes FedLock, a novel server-side watermarking mechanism designed to resist model theft and safeguard the IP of global models. Specifically, FedLock leverages Split Federated Learning (SFL) to partition the model, effectively preventing malicious clients from accessing the complete set of global model parameters. To enhance security, FedLock incorporates an autoencoder for label encoding, safeguarding the server-side model from reconstruction attacks. Furthermore, FedLock introduces an additional backdoor client to embed a black-box watermark into the global model, enabling remote verification of model ownership. Experimental results demonstrate that FedLock achieves robust watermarking with minimal impact on model performance, effectively resisting various attacks, including model theft, pruning, and fine-tuning.

title: A Tuning-Fork Network for Improved Building Footprint Extraction
authors: M. Ahmad Waseem, Muhammad Tahir, Zubair Khalid, Momin Uppal
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: This paper considers the problem of extracting building footprints from satellite imagery. We propose a novel Tuning-Fork Network (TFNet) design for deep semantic segmentation that not only performs well for widely-spaced buildings but also has good performance for buildings that are closely packed together. The novelty of the TFNet architecture lies in a single encoder followed by two parallel decoders to separately reconstruct the building footprint and the building edge. For performance comparisons, we utilize the SpaceNet2 dataset as well as a dataset from an area in Lahore, Pakistan that captures closely connected buildings. The proposed methodology is found to perform consistently across various spatial regions and outperforms benchmark methods.
