title: Enhanced Residual Tensor Norm Minimization for Multiview Subspace Clustering_supp1-3648433.pdf
authors: Qinghai Zheng
publish: N/A
abstract: The low-rank tensor constraint is widely used in multiview subspace clustering (MSC) and has demonstrated promising clustering performance on many datasets. The key challenges in most existing low-rank tensor constraint-based methods include: 1) the choice of surrogate functions for the tensor rank and 2) the rotation operation applied to the tensor formed by stacking multiple subspace representations along the third mode. The latter plays a critical role in enhancing clustering performance in multiview settings. In this work, we rethink the low-rank tensor constraint and present the enhanced residual tensor norm (ERTN) for multiview subspace clustering, dubbed ERTN-MSC. To be specific, ERTN employs a novel surrogate for the tensor rank, based on the residual learning of singular values, which facilitates better exploitation of the structural information in multiview data. Furthermore, ERTN applies the tensor-singular value decomposition (t-SVD) on three modes of the tensor constructed by multiple subspaces, which generalizes the rotation operation of tensor and enables comprehensive exploration of both intraview information and interview information of multiview data. An augmented Lagrangian multiplier-based algorithm with a convergence guarantee is designed for optimization. Experiments conducted on several real-world multiview datasets demonstrate the effectiveness and competitiveness of our ERTN-MSC.

title: An HCAI Methodological Framework: Putting it Into Action to Enable Human-Centered AI
authors: Wei Xu, Zaifeng Gao, Marvin J. Dainoff
publish: IEEE Transactions on Human-Machine Systems
abstract: Human-centered artificial intelligence (HCAI) is a design philosophy that prioritizes humans in the design, development, deployment, and use of AI systems, aiming to maximize AI’s benefits while mitigating its negative impacts. Despite its growing prominence in literature, the lack of methodological guidance for its implementation poses challenges to HCAI practice. To address this gap, this article proposes a comprehensive HCAI methodological framework (HCAI-MF) comprising five key components: HCAI requirement hierarchy, approach and method taxonomy, process, interdisciplinary collaboration approach, and multilevel design paradigms. A case study demonstrates HCAI-MF’s practical implications, while the article also analyzes implementation challenges. Actionable recommendations and a “three-layer” HCAI implementation strategy are provided to address these challenges and guide future evolution of HCAI-MF. HCAI-MF is presented as a systematic and executable methodology capable of overcoming current gaps, enabling effective design, development, deployment, and use of AI systems, and advancing HCAI practice.

title: Design and Control of a Coarse-fine Inverted Span-scale Positioning Stage with Smooth Switching for Antagonistic Piezo-actuation
authors: Yanding Qin, Haitao Wu, Zhongbo Yu, Bijan Shirinzadeh, Jianda Han
publish: IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
abstract: Dual-servo systems are highly expected in span-scale manipulations where both large stroke and high positioning precision are required. This paper presents a new coarse-fine inverted span-scale positioning stage with antagonistic piezo-actuation configuration. Different from conventional designs for coarse-fine positioning stages, in the proposed stage, the coarse stage is mounted on the moving platform of the fine stage. This coarse-fine inverted configuration helps to utilize the high out-of-plane stiffness of the fine stage and to guarantee the workspace of the overall system. To address the measurement signal allocation and chattering problems in antagonistic actuation, a Sigmoid function is used instead of the common Step function. A prototype is fabricated and its positioning and tracking performances are assessed. Experimental results show that the stage achieves a positioning error of ±25 nm and a resolution of 8 nm across a centimeter scale stroke, showing excellent span-scale positioning performance. Further, different trajectories are used to assess the tracking performance. It is found that the root-mean-square tracking error can be reduced to several tens of nanometers, corresponding to a tracking error within 1% of the trajectory span. These results demonstrate the applicability of the stage in span-scale tasks, such as single-molecule manipulation.

title: M-SIALNS for Air–Ground Collaborative Inspection: Spatio-Temporal Conflict Mitigation in Complex Bi-Layer Networks
authors: Miaohan Zhang, Yuanhao Xu, Xuewei Yu, Chunyan Zhang, Jianlei Zhang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Intelligent Transportation Systems
abstract: Multi-vehicle–UAV collaborative inspection systems face critical challenges in complex environments, where spatiotemporal node conflicts, coupled scheduling, and congestion severely affect operational efficiency. To address these issues, we define the Multi-UAV–Multi-Vehicle Collaborative Inspection Vehicle Routing Problem in a Bi-Layer Road Network (MUMV-CIVRP-BLRN). The model captures realistic inspection scenarios through (i) spatiotemporal node-conflict constraints that prevent simultaneous vehicle access to occupied nodes and (ii) flexible UAV operations, enabling chained multi-task sorties and cross-vehicle recovery. To solve this NP-hard problem, we propose a Multi-Strategy Improved Adaptive Large Neighborhood Search (M-SIALNS) algorithm. Beyond standard ALNS frameworks, M-SIALNS incorporates a cluster-based initialization method, task-chain destroy–repair operators, and air–ground coordination strategies specifically tailored for the bi-layer structure. These strategies enhance global search, solution feasibility, and robustness. Comprehensive experiments on benchmark datasets and a power-grid case study demonstrate the advantages of M-SIALNS. Compared with state-of-the-art algorithms, it reduces inspection duration by 1.6%–11.0%, consistently delivering statistically significant improvements. Ablation and sensitivity analyses confirm the contribution of tailored operators and provide managerial insights into optimal fleet configurations and resource allocation thresholds. This work advances both the theoretical modeling of bi-layer vehicle–UAV routing and its practical deployment in large-scale inspection missions.

title: Nash-Minmax Capturing Strategy for Multiagent Pursuit-Evasion Differential Games Under Directed Graphs
authors: Ran Shi, Hai-Tao Zhang, Jialuo Li, Fulong Hu, Yifan Hu, Jiayu Zou
publish: IEEE Transactions on Industrial Informatics
abstract: In this article, a heterogeneous multiagent pursuit-evasion (MPE) differential gaming problem is addressed. Therein, the pursuers aim to cooperatively capture the sole escaping evader. The theoretical analytical challenge lies in designing the Nash-minmax gaming strategy for such MPE games under directed graphs with external disturbances. Intra-alliance cooperation (pursuers and their peer neighbors) is regarded as a nonzero-sum game, while interalliance confrontation (multiple pursuers versus one evader) is treated as another zero-sum game. To tackle this issue, a hierarchical gaming framework is established to solve the associated coupled Hamilton-Jacobi-Isaacs (HJI) equation and accordingly derive the associated distributed gaming protocol. Finally, both numerical simulations and lake-based multi-autonomous surface vehicle (ASV) gaming experiments are conducted to verify the effectiveness of the present MPE gaming strategy.

title: Deep Residual Learning Framework for Automated Coffee Bean Classification Across Roast Levels
authors: Komuravelly Sudheer Kumar, Goldy Verma, Shraddha Kaparwan, Royal Madan
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: Coffee is among the most consumed drinks in the world, and its quality is strictly linked to the grouping of coffee bean with type and degree of roasting. Conventional classification systems are based on manual inspection, which is tedious, subjective and liable to inconsistencies. To solve the problems, this research suggests a deep learning-based solution with the fine-tuned ResNet50 model to automatically classify coffee beans into four categories; green, light roast, medium roast, and dark roast. The data set, retrieved in the open source Kaggle platform, is composed of 4,800 high-resolution images equally distributed in the four categories. To increase variability and decrease overfitting, preprocessing steps, such as resizing, normalization, and augmentation were used. The experimental findings revealed a high accuracy of 98%, a high precision, recall, and f1-scores of all classes. The results demonstrate the promise of deep learning as a stable, effective, and scalable approach to assessing the quality of coffee beans and automating agriculture.

title: Passband Signal Detection at the Edge
authors: Gavin Parpart, Peter Martin, Stephen Jones, Noah Elmore, Jeremiah Rounds
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: Algorithms for radio frequency (RF) spectrum awareness need to be compatible with edge hardware to be practical for many applications. We developed a signal detection and classification model for the ZCU111 RF System-on-a-Chip (RFSoC) that operates on the fast Fourier transform of passband RF data. The system can detect and classify multiple signals of interest and display the predictions in real-time. The model consists of a modified ConvNeXt backbone and YOLOv3 head to operate on the Deep Learning Processing Unit on the RFSoC. We gathered datasets for training and testing by using a software defined radio to transmit example signals of Wi-Fi 802.11 b/g, Wi-Fi 802.11 n, FM Radio, LTE and LTE-M. By leveraging multiple inputs on the RFSoC frontend, the datasets span up to 4 GHz of bandwidth. The models showed high performance in classification accuracy, center frequency error, bandwidth error, and detection accuracy for both single and multi-signal datasets.

title: Standardized Machine-Readable Point-Data Format for Consolidating Wireless Propagation Across Environments, Frequencies, and Institutions
authors: Dipankar Shakya, Naveed A. Abbasi, Mingjun Ying, Isha Jariwala, Jason J. Qin, Ishaan S. Gupte, Bridget Meier, Guanyue Qian, Daniel Abraham, Theodore S. Rappaport, Andreas F. Molisch
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: The necessity of new spectrum for 6G has intensified global interest in radio propagation measurements across emerging frequency bands, use cases, and antenna types. These measurements are vital for understanding the fundamentals of radio channel properties in diverse environments, and involve time-consuming, labor-intensive, and expensive campaigns. A major challenge for the effective utilization of the data generated from propagation measurement campaigns has been the lack of a standardized format for reporting and archiving results. Although organizations such as NIST, NGA, and 3GPP have made commendable efforts toward data pooling, a unified machine-readable data format for consolidating measurements across different institutions and frequencies remains a critical missing piece in advancing global standardization efforts and maximizing the utility of collected data. This paper introduces a new, standardized point-data format for wireless propagation measurements and demonstrates how multiple institutions may merge disparate measurement campaigns into a common format for global access. This data format, when used alongside an environmental map and a measurement summary metadata table, enables the seamless integration of radio propagation data from disparate sources by using a structured representation of key propagation parameters. Here, we show the efficacy of the proposed point-data format standard using data gathered from two independent sub-THz urban microcell (UMi) campaigns: 142 GHz measurements at New York University (NYU) and 145 GHz measurements at the University of Southern California (USC). A joint path loss analysis using the close-in path loss model with a 1 m reference distance yields a refined estimate of the path loss exponent (PLE) employing the proposed standard to pool measurements from the two different organizations. Other key statistics such as RMS delay spread and angular spread are determined using datasets from the two different institutions cast in the standardized format. Adopting this simple, unified format will accelerate comprehensive channel model development, build multi-institutional datasets, and feed AI/ML applications with reliable training data in a common format from many sources.

title: Dynamic Reward Weighting Based Deep Q-Learning for Routing in Advanced Packaging
authors: Shubin Chen, Qinghai Liu, Xiaowei Wu, Jun Xu, Xiaolin Xu
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Integrated Circuits and Microsystems (ICICM)
abstract: In the contemporary electronics industry, advanced packaging technology has emerged as a critical avenue for overcoming performance bottlenecks in the semiconductor sector. Among these, redistribution layer (RDL)-a pivotal component of electronic design automation (EDA)-face significant challenges, including low routing efficiency and suboptimal outcomes. To address these limitations, this study introduces a deep Q-learning (DQN)-based approach for the dynamic adjustment of reward weights in the context of RDL global routing for multi-chip packaging (MCP). By training a set of weight vectors to adaptively regulate the relative importance of sub-objectives within the overall reward function in real time, the proposed method enhances both flexibility and efficiency during training and inference. Experimental results demonstrate that the approach achieves a $\mathbf{1 0. 7 \%}$ reduction in overall routing length compared with conventional strategies employing fixed reward weights.

title: An Ultra-Low-Power True Random Number Generator Based on Volatile RRAM
authors: Qi Luo, Zhen Wang, Xuemeng Fan, Pengtao Li, Guobin Zhang, Yishu Zhang
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Integrated Circuits and Microsystems (ICICM)
abstract: With the rapid deployment of Internet of Things (IoT) devices in resource-constrained environments, lightweight and energy-efficient random number generation has become increasingly crucial. To address the resource overhead and energy efficiency challenges of conventional designs, this paper presents a self-clocking true random number generator (TRNG) based on volatile memristors. Built upon the device-level strengths of $\mathrm{Ag} / \mathrm{GaO}_{\mathrm{x}} / \mathrm{Pt}$ memristor, particularly its high-speed oscillation and low-power behavior, the proposed TRNG design incorporates these features into its core architecture. We introduce a novel high-entropy approach that exploits stochastic fluctuations during memristor oscillation to generate true random bits. Experimental results show that TRNG achieves a generation rate of $167 \mathrm{~kb} \mathrm{~s}^{-1}$ and an energy consumption of $6.36 \mathrm{fJ} \mathrm{bit}^{-1}$, making it well-suited for future energy-efficient and lightweight security applications.

title: Performance Analysis of Fluid Reconfigurable Intelligent Surface Over Covert Communications
authors: Farshad Rostami Ghadi, Masoud Kaveh, Hanjiang Hong, Kai-Kit Wong, Riku Jantti, F. Javier Lopez-Martinez
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on 6G Networking (6GNet)
abstract: This paper investigates the impact of the recently proposed concept of fluid reconfigurable intelligent surfaces (FRIS) on covert communications. Specifically, we consider a communication scenario where a legitimate transmitter aims to covertly deliver information to its intended receiver through a planar FRIS, while an adversary attempts to detect whether any transmission is occurring. In this context, we analyze the false alarm (FA) and missed detection (MD) probabilities, and derive a closed-form expression for the covertness outage probability (COP). Furthermore, the success probability is characterized under the optimal detection threshold, providing new insights into the trade-off between covertness and reliable transmission. Numerical results reveal that FRIS provides a clear advantage over fixed-position RIS at low-to-moderate transmit powers by improving reliability and enhancing covertness, while at very high power levels, fixed-position RIS may sustain slightly higher success probability due to reduced leakage toward the adversary.

title: Probabilistic Latency Modeling for Heterogeneous Inference Tasks in Resource-Constrained Networks
authors: Cleon Anderson, Scott Brown, Matthew R. Dwyer, David Harman, Tian Lan
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: In dynamic and resource-constrained environments, such as edge-cloud networks, accurate prediction of end-to-end inference latency is critical to optimize system performance and enable time-sensitive decision making. This paper presents a Bayesian Neural Network (BNN) based framework for predicting per-frame latency across heterogeneous devices and varying network states. We decompose total latency into modular components: frame duration, inference time, and data transfer latency, and model each using probabilistic machine learning techniques capable of uncertainty quantification and extrapolation.Our dual-model approach first estimates frame duration based on system configurations (e.g., data compression, model type, compute resources) and then uses this intermediate output to predict overall task latency. We further assess generalization on a previously unseen dataset, simulating real-world conditions with fluctuating bandwidth, image quality settings, and computational heterogeneity. Experimental results demonstrate high predictive accuracy (R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> > 0.99 for frame duration and R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> > 0.99 for inference latency), with well-calibrated confidence intervals (PICP approx95%).The proposed framework enables robust, real-time latency forecasting in volatile communication networks and supports risk-aware task placement, autonomous scheduling, and resource management. This work contributes a scalable and uncertainty-aware solution for mission-critical environments where bandwidth scarcity, node mobility, and compute variability challenge conventional predictive models.

title: A 10T1C SRAM-Based Computing-in-Memory Unit Supporting Logic and MAC Computing for Energy- Efficient Edge AI Chips
authors: Zhiting Lin, Chenglong Duan, Miao Long, Juntao Ge, Fugui Jiang, Yang Yang, Xiulong Wu
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Integrated Circuits and Microsystems (ICICM)
abstract: This paper proposes an innovative compute-inmemory (CIM) integrated circuit based on a 10T1C SRAM. The design augments a standard 6T-SRAM cell with four NMOS transistors and one capacitor, enabling simultaneous data storage and in-memory AND/XNOR logic operations. The 10T1C cell supports three operating modes: data storage, in-memory AND, and in-memory XNOR. Furthermore, arrayed configurations enable more complex computations, including multiplyaccumulate (MAC) operations and binary neural network (BNN) inference. Simulated in a $\mathbf{2 8}-\mathbf{n m}$ CMOS process, the core achieves an energy efficiency of $18.3-41.8$ TOPS/W for Boolean operations over a $0.7-0.9 \mathrm{~V}$ supply range. This high efficiency makes it well suited for energy-constrained edge-AI applications that require both storage and logic capabilities.

title: Charge N Connect: An IoT-Enabled On-Demand Framework for EV Charging and Fuel Delivery
authors: Jisto Paul Joby, Goutamchand S, Rijo Joshy, Hail Paulson, Anil Antony, Anusree K
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: The rapid growth of electric vehicles (EVs), coupled with the sustained presence of internal combustion engine (ICE) vehicles, has intensified the demand for reliable, on-demand roadside energy assistance. Charge N Connect presents an integrated digital platform that unifies EV charging and conventional fuel delivery through an IoT-enabled, location-aware service network. The proposed model incorporates (i) a geospatial nearest-neighbor discovery algorithm for optimal service selection, (ii) a reservation-based assignment and scheduling mechanism to minimize user waiting time, and (iii) a secure, cloud-linked communication layer for real-time coordination between consumers and providers. Experimental evaluation using a simulated city-scale dataset of 100 charging nodes and 5 000 trip requests demonstrated a 61 % reduction in service discovery time, 70 % reduction in waiting time, and a 7.6 % improvement in session success rate compared with traditional distance-based approaches. The novelty of Charge N Connect lies in its hybrid energy-assistance framework that integrates decentralized charging providers with predictive, AI-ready scheduling for both EV and fuel vehicles. This work advances the state of the art by ensuring ubiquitous, responsive, and scalable roadside energy accessibility, thereby addressing the critical challenge of range anxiety in modern transportation systems.

title: Generative Model-Driven Code Creation and Vulnerability Analysis for Developmental Applications
authors: Noah Reneau, Kyle Stein, Brian Walker, Seth Vinson, Lanier Watkins
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: With the recent societal implications of generative artificial intelligence (AI), particularly in the realm of software development, concerns about the reliability and security of AI-generated code becomes paramount in the minds of researchers and organizations alike. This paper examines whether large language models (LLMs) can develop effective and secure tools for auditing AI-developed autonomous agents in a competitive game environment. To model this scenario, we focus on a modified version of weighted Rock-Paper-Scissors, specifically Glico, as a testbed for adversarial AI competition. We then prompted the LLM to generate various strategy bots to play the game, including: a pattern-based bot, a cyclic-strategy bot, a random-move bot, and a reinforcement learning bot using Q-learning. The bot development process was iterative, with the LLM refining code in response to functional errors identified through custom dynamic testing strategies. We evaluated the performance of each bot (win/loss rates, time to win), as well as analyzed the security of the AI-generated code using static analysis tools. Our results demonstrate that while LLMs can generate functional game-playing agents, doing so requires multiple prompt iterations and human guidance. Even then, security vulnerabilities remain when deploying AI-generated code in user-created environments like the tested gaming platform. The results of this project aim to provide insight into the practical potential of LLMs to develop AI within restricted, goal-driven environments.

title: Cybersecurity in Smart Grids using Machine Learning: A Systematic Literature Review
authors: Norman Nelufule, Crestinah Mudau, Boitumelo Nkwe, Samson Chishiri, Lungisani Mncwango, Muyowa Mutenwa
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: The Smart Grids due to their reliance to the connectedness of Internet of Things technologies, advanced metering infrastructure, and real-time communication are faced with significant cybersecurity and privacy risks. In this work a synthesized insights from recent literatures are presented which critically evaluate Machine Learning, Deep Learning, and privacy-preserving techniques for securing smart grids against cyber-attacks. The critical analysis of this review spans across several themes and topics such as ensemble ML models, federated learning, graph neural networks and blockchain-based protocols, scalability, and privacy-aware communication frameworks. However, there are several limitations such as reliance on simulated datasets, computational complexity, adversarial vulnerabilities, scalability issues, and lack of real-time data validation which limits their practical deployment in a real-world environment. This survey has also proposed some research solutions such as standardized real-world datasets, lightweight algorithms, adversarial training, explainable AI, and interoperable blockchain frameworks to enhance robustness, scalability, and trust. This study addresses key research questions on the effectiveness of learning based techniques, and the role of emerging technologies such as 5G technologies and explainable AI in securing a smart grids environment.

title: Real-Time AI Driven Defect Detection System using Vision and Weight Sensing for Plastic Bottle Inspection
authors: Thanu Kurian, Ronit Raturi, P.Pranisree P. Pranisree, P. Shainy, Sammeta Dharmika, Shravya Shetty
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: Manufacturing industries depend heavily on consistent quality control, especially in large-scale production lines such as plastic bottle manufacturing. Maintaining product quality in such manufacturing settings using conventional manual inspection techniques is unreliable and ineffective, especially in situations involving large production volumes. To overcome these challenges,To address the limitations of manual inspection, this work presents an automated defect detection system powered by computer vision and weight sensing. The work combines physical weight validation along with computer-vision-based on deep learning for real-time defect detection on plastic bottles. The system uses MobileNetV2 on a Raspberry Pi to classify visual defects from bottle images. A load cell connected to an Arduino Uno weighs the bottle and sends the data to the Raspberry Pi via serial communication in order to identify minute defects like leakage or underfilling. A simple fusion rule combines both the visual output and weight reading to finalize whether a bottle is defective or not. For analytics and traceability, every result including pictures, weights, and classification choices is recorded in a structured database. With an accuracy of over 95%, the system provides a viable and scalable solution for smart factories and Industry 4.0 environments and can be easily extended to other manufacturing domains.

title: CAMTEC: Context-aware Adaptive Inference for Machine Task Execution in Complex Environments
authors: Sharon L.G. Contreras, Marco Levorato, Hyomin Choi, Fabien Racape, Subhramoy Mohanti
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: The rise of smart factories is transforming manufacturing and service delivery using robots and unmanned ground vehicles (UGVs) for advanced tasks like autonomous navigation. While over-the-top (OTT) solutions reduce local compute and energy demands by offloading machine learning (ML) tasks to remote servers, they lack task-aware optimization. This limitation is critical for complex applications like autonomous navigation, where performance depends on dynamic device and network conditions. To bridge this gap, we propose Context-aware Adaptive inference for Machine-Task Execution in Complex environments (CAMTEC). It incorporates performance metrics from compute, energy, network, and ML to generate the context of machine task performance (e.g., UGV navigation). CAMTEC utilizes a deep reinforcement learning (DRL) agent to learn from this context information to determine the optimal inferencing mode (local, remote, or split) and vehicle speed to ensure optimal performance of an off-the-shelf object detection-based navigation algorithm. Extensive real-world testbed evaluations demonstrate CAMTEC’s efficacy in achieving collision-free autonomous navigation. CAMTEC adheres to a computationally optimal allocation strategy throughout the vehicle’s trajectory, ensuring that the actual-to-target speed variation remains below 20% even under battery-constrained conditions. Furthermore, even when network bandwidth is severely limited, CAMTEC ensures that the UGV converges to the optimal path while keeping the actual-to-target speed variation below 30%.

title: Fly Aware: Lightweight Real-Time Anomaly Detection and Classification in UAV Telemetry
authors: Ethan Silverstein, Milind Kathiari, Angel Todorov, Ying Wang
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: Unsupervised anomaly detection in UAV telemetry is essential for ensuring safe and reliable autonomous flight. This paper presents a sequence-to-sequence LSTM autoencoder with a bidirectional encoder and Bahdanau-style attention decoder to capture short-term temporal dependencies in multivariate telemetry data. The model is trained on fixed-length sequences extracted from MAVLink logs containing 17 key features related to attitude, velocity, and position. To increase data diversity and coverage, we generated additional training sequences through high-fidelity flight simulation. A custom QGroundControl plugin was developed to efficiently filter and log only the most relevant MAVLink packets, enabling streamlined and targeted data acquisition. By learning compact latent representations, the autoencoder distinguishes nominal behavior from anomalies using reconstruction error. For deployment, the model is compiled to ONNX and served via a FastAPI-based inference system with WebSocket support for real-time monitoring. Sensitivity analysis reveals which sensor modalities most influence reconstruction quality. Our system demonstrates competitive performance on both simulated and real-world datasets, offering a scalable, interpretable, and lightweight solution for UAV anomaly detection.

title: Implementation-Aware AI Management Framework for AI-Native Networks
authors: Sławomir Kukliński, Robert Kołakowski, Bartłomiej Mastej
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on 6G Networking (6GNet)
abstract: The paper concerns the implementation of AI Function (AIF) management in AI-native networks, i.e., networks in which AIFs are densely deployed across any network plane. The management of such functions involves observing their behaviour and making decisions on whether to retrain or update the ML model. The 3GPP and ITU-T have already addressed the problem, but so far, no comprehensive solution has been proposed for the networking environment, and the existing descriptions are at a very high level. The main contributions of the paper are: the definition of the internal structure of a generic manageable AIF, the AIF Runtime Pipeline (RTP) and Model Training Pipelines (MTP) used for AIF model observation, training, and update, and additional components for efficient integration of the approach with the network Management Plane (MP) and Network Digital Twin (NDT). Three variants of training have been proposed: local (in situ), using an operator cloud, and using an external Machine Learning Operations (MLOps) platform, along with guidelines for selecting the training variant based on performance.

title: A Comprehensive Survey of Hybrid Deep Learning Techniques for Hand Gesture Recognition in Smart Healthcare and Elderly Support Systems
authors: K. Ramanathan, J. Jeyabharathi
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: Hand gesture detection, which has uses in robotics, virtual reality, healthcare, and sign language translation, is a key component of human–computer interaction. Since movement-based dynamic hand gestures vary over time, look similar across categories, and are influenced by lighting or background, they are more difficult to recognize. In contrast to deep learning, which can automatically learn both geographical and temporal information, traditional approaches that rely on manually created features frequently perform poorly across datasets. Convolutional neural networks (CNNs) are used in this paper to capture spatial details such as hand forms and finger locations, whereas recurrent neural networks (RNNs), specifically long short-term memory (LSTM) units, are used to learn temporal patterns like motion dynamics. By efficiently modeling both static hand postures and motion dynamics, our hybrid approach enhances the system's recognition performance on benchmark datasets. When it comes to complicated gestures that involve fine finger movements or overlapping motions, experimental results show better accuracy and robustness than traditional CNN-only or RNN-only models. In real-world applications where high accuracy, flexibility, and real-time recognition are essential, the study also highlights the viability of such hybrid designs. In order to promote advancements in touch less interfaces, immersive gaming, and assistive technology for people with impairments, the work demonstrates a path toward more dependable and natural interaction systems by integrating the advantages of complementing deep learning models This work provides an important information for researchers and those interested in improving the human-machine communication which highlights the potential of hybrid deep learning models for dynamic hand gesture detection.

title: Is Synthetic Flow Data from Generative Models Ready for Network Intrusion Detection Systems?
authors: Jiefei Liu, Qixu Gong, Wenbin Jiang, Pratyay Kumar, Abu Saleh Md Tayeen, Huiping Cao, Satyajayant Misra, Jayashree Harikumar
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: Network Intrusion Detection Systems (NIDS) are critical components of modern cybersecurity infrastructure. Developing robust machine learning (ML)-driven NIDS requires extensive network traffic datasets, where flow-based analysis is essential for detecting suspicious traffic patterns and improving model performance. Since network traffic data often contains sensitive information and is subject to strict privacy and security regulations, there is a notable scarcity of publicly accessible, realistic network traffic flow datasets for research. Moreover, many existing open-source datasets are highly class imbalanced, posing significant challenges for researchers. While some researchers have created NIDS datasets using testbeds or network simulations, configuring complex network topologies is often time-consuming, costly, and difficult to customize. To the best of our knowledge, the generation of realistic network flow datasets remains a major obstacle in NIDS research. Recently, generative artificial intelligence (AI) methods, including large language models (LLMs), have demonstrated strong capabilities in generating various types of synthetic data across domains. However, to date, no existing work has explored their application in generating datasets to facilitate NIDS research. This study establishes a comprehensive evaluation pipeline to assess the effectiveness of several representative and state-of-the-art generative AI models for synthetic flow data generation in the NIDS domain. Our extensive experiments on three widely used NIDS datasets demonstrate that ML models trained on synthetic flow data generated by LLM-based generative AI methods can achieve macro-average F1 scores of up to 86%, outperforming other generative AI approaches in classifying benign and attack types.

title: Performance Evaluation of Deep Learning Models for MRI Image Enhancement and Tumor Classification
authors: Sripriya Arunachalam, A. Jenita Mary, Usha Nandhini A
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: This study assesses the efficacy of four deep learning architectures ConvRESNAS152, RESNET152, NASNetMobile, and ConvNeXtTiny in enhancing and classifying medical images. The models were tested using classification metrics like Accuracy, Precision, and F1-score, as well as fundamental image quality measures like Entropy, Structural Similarity Index (SSIM), and Mean Squared Error (MSE). The findings show that RESNET152 has the best accuracy and F1-score because its deep residual learning architecture makes it easier to extract useful features. This is why it has the best categorization performance. By getting the lowest MSE, the highest PSNR, and the strongest SSIM, NASNetMobile shows that it can keep the structure of an image intact while minimizing distortion. This makes it better than other models in terms of image improvement measures. ConvRESNAS152 has room to grow because it often does poorly on several different measures. Even though ConvNeXt Tiny is efficient, its small architecture makes it perform significantly worse than other models when it comes to augmentation and classification tasks. The results show that both models have their pros and cons. RESNET152 is better for classification tasks, while NASNetMobile is better for picture improvement. The results make it much easy to pick the optimal deep learning framework for medical imaging.

title: Developing an NTN Architecture for End-to-End Performance Evaluation
authors: Md Mahfuzur Rahman, Nishith Tripathi, Jeffrey H. Reed, Lingjia Liu
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: Non-Terrestrial Networks (NTN) are emerging as critical enablers of global connectivity, particularly in remote, unserved, underserved, or maritime regions lacking traditional infrastructure. While much of the existing work on NTN focuses on theoretical or simulated evaluations, practical implementations remain limited. In this paper, we present SpaceNET, a transparent NTN testbed that leverages the Starlink Low Earth Orbit (LEO) satellite constellation in conjunction with Mininet-based emulation to perform end-to-end performance assessments across real-world maritime and terrestrial endpoints that can also be applied to 5th generation (5G). Specifically, we establish a bidirectional link between a ground terminal located in Blacksburg, Virginia, and a maritime terminal aboard a cruise ship near Key West, Florida. We report detailed transmission control protocol (TCP) throughput, user datagram protocol (UDP) throughput, and latency measurements using two different user terminals - a) Smartphone, and b) very small aperture terminal (VSAT), emphasizing the transparent nature of the NTN payload, where the satellite acts solely as a relay node. Our results provide new insights into the performance limits and reliability of commercial LEO-based NTN applications. The SpaceNET testbed offers a reproducible and extensible platform for future research in NTN routing, mobility support, and cross-layer optimization.

title: A Blockchain-based Framework for Securing Cybernetics Control Networks in Smart Cities
authors: Chinnam Yuvaraju, S. Kaliappan, M Nagabhushana Rao, Bakka Rajeev Gandhi, Arvind Kishanrao Rathod, Gogineni Saikiran
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: The high rate of cyber-physical systems and intelligent infrastructures spread in smart cities poses new problems to cybernetics control nets, especially in terms of data integrity, control of accesses, and guaranteeing trust in real time. The conventional approach of secured solutions that utilize the centralized approach is becoming improper to secure distributed and autonomous systems that are embedded within urban settings. The current paper introduces a new blockchain-enabled paradigm which can be used to secure the cybernetics control networks and it makes use of decentralized consensus, cryptographic validation of transactions and impenetrable lists. The structure suits lightweight blockchain nodes in partnership with industrial control systems and Internet of Things (IoT) units to guarantee secure communication, verifiable execution of commands, and tamper-free tracking of events. Hybrid architecture that uses permission blockchain and smart contracts is a method to achieve granular access control, anomaly detection, and safe firmware upgrades over large cityscale networks (traffic control, energy grids, and public surveillance). Through experimental analysis, it has been shown how the framework is effective in its ability to prevent and subdue cyber-attacks like the attack of spoofing, replay, and unauthorized access to the system with minimal latency and scalable to the level seen during the urban deployment mode. The suggested method offers a long-term, strong, and clear process to make the security of cybernetics control networks stronger, which creates an outstanding basis of the trust-based development of next-generation smart cities.

title: Post-Quantum SIM-Less Authentication: Scalable and Secure Solutions for FutureG IoT Networks
authors: Abhisek Kumar Jha, SeyedMohammad Kashani, Sang Wu Kim, Ashfaq Khokhar, Farid Nait-Abdesselam
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: Current cellular authentication mechanisms rely primarily on SIM-based Authentication and Key Agreement (AKA), which have scaled successfully worldwide but face challenges as the Internet of Things (IoT) grows to billions of devices. SIM provisioning and lifecycle management become increasingly costly, while reliance on long-term symmetric keys limits revocation flexibility and cross-operator support. To address these issues, we propose a SIM-less, certificate-based authentication framework that integrates Public Key Infrastructure (PKI) with post-quantum cryptography (PQC). Specifically, the framework employs Kyber for key encapsulation and Dilithium for digital signatures, providing quantum-resistant protection for future networks. A key challenge is the computational overhead of PQC on constrained IoT devices; we address this by offloading cryptographic operations to trusted edge servers, whose integrity is validated using attestation mechanisms such as Trusted Platform Modules (TPMs) or secure enclaves. We implement and evaluate the framework in a simulated FutureG environment, comparing IoT-only execution against edge-assisted configurations. Results show that edge offloading reduces TLS handshake latency by up to 96% while maintaining minimal resource usage on devices. These findings demonstrate that PQC-enabled PKI, combined with edge-assisted execution, offers a scalable and practical complement to SIM/AKA for secure and quantum-resilient authentication in FutureG IoT deployments.

title:
HEA
                    <sub>2</sub>
                    -MAC: A Hybrid Exponent-Aware Approximate MAC for Efficient CNN Processing
authors: Weixuan Wang, Zihan Zou, Xin Cao, Xuefeng Cai, Hao Cai, Bo Liu
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Integrated Circuits and Microsystems (ICICM)
abstract: Convolutional neural networks (CNNs) have been widely deployed in industrial edge devices and the Internet-of-Things. Although the efficient inference of CNNs is deeply optimized with dedicated hardware, the training requirement is not fully solved due to the resource-constrained nature of edge devices. The major bottleneck is the high overhead of floating point (FP) multiplication and accumulation (MAC), which requires high-precision computation and data movement. To this end, we propose a Hybrid Exponent-Aware Approximate MAC ($\mathrm{HEA}^{2}$-MAC) acceleration method in a software and hardware co-design manner. The main contributions are: (1) an adaptive block floating point (BFP) data format that reduces the average data bit-width, (2) a precision-adjustable approximate mantissa multiplier that exploits the error tolerance of CNNs to reduce FP mutiplication consumption, and (3) an exponent-aware mixed-precision accumulator that mitigates FP accumulation costs. Implemented in a 28 nm CMOS technology, $\mathrm{HEA}^{2}$-MAC achieves up to a $3.66 \times$ improvement in energy efficiency compared to the BFP12-FP32 MAC unit. Meanwhile, the accuracy loss (<1%) is significantly maintained across numerous CNN benchmarks.

title: Transformer-Based Spatio-Temporal Change Detection Network Using Satellite Image Time Series: A Case Study of Forest Disturbance in Trentino, Italy Following the Vaia Storm
authors: Khatereh Meshkini, Francesca Bovolo
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: High-resolution Satellite Image Time Series (SITS), combined with advanced deep learning approaches such as transformers, enable reliable change detection by effectively using large amounts of temporal data. While most existing change detection methods overlook temporal dynamics and focus primarily on spatial features, Transformers are well-suited to capture both spatial and temporal features. This paper presents a Transformer-based spatio-temporal architecture for multi-annual change detection that integrates two key components: an Adaptive Swin Transformer Encoder (ASTE) for hierarchical feature extraction and a Feature Difference Module (FDM) to highlight changes for generating change detection maps. ASTE incorporates a Cross Attention Fusion (CAF) module, which integrates convolutional operations for spatial feature extraction and Swin Transformer to extract spatio-temporal dependencies. FDM refines the difference features, enhancing feature interaction for optimization and accurate change detection. The method was tested in the Trentino region of Italy, focusing on deforestation caused by the Vaia storm.

title: Efficient Multi-View Ensemble Deep Learning for Robust Brain Tumor Grade Classification
authors: N. Krishnavardhan, A. Srinivasa Reddy
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: The prognosis of patients and clinical treatment planning depend on the accurate and timely identification of brain tumor grade. Medical image analysis has greatly benefited from deep learning, however single-model architectures frequently have poor generalization and sensitivity to imaging differences. In order to accomplish effective and extremely accurate brain tumor grade classification from MRI scans, this research suggests a novel Multi-View Ensemble Deep Learning Framework (MVE-DLF) that combines the complementary strengths of CNN, Transformer-based, and lightweight attention networks. The ensemble combines predictions from ResNet-50, EfficientNet-B3, and a modified Swin-Transformer branch using a weighted adaptive fusion module. The suggested model outperforms state-of-the-art techniques with 94.8% classification accuracy, according to experimental results on the BraTS2021 dataset. There is a lot of promise for real-time clinical implementation with the suggested architecture.

title: VCIL: An Open-Source Pipeline-Tight HIL Framework for Cycle-Accurate RISC-V Coprocessor Verification
authors: Xian Lin, Xin Zheng, Zhixin Fan, Huaien Gao, Shuting Cai, Xiaoming Xiong
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Integrated Circuits and Microsystems (ICICM)
abstract: The open-source RISC-V instruction set architecture (ISA) enables custom instructions to implement coprocessors, which requires higher verification speed and timing accuracy. However, most existing hardware-in-the-loop (HIL) approaches fail to meet these. To this end, this brief proposes Virtual-Coprocessor-in-the-Loop (VCIL), a pipeline-tight HIL framework for cycle-accurate RISC-V coprocessor verification. It bypasses the TLM2.0 bus and tightly couples the coprocessor to the pipeline via UART, which reduces transmissions and improves simulation speed. Additionally, a timing dynamic calibration method is introduced to enhance timing accuracy and enable early detection of timing violations. Compared to the state-of-the-art Virtual-Peripheral-in-the-Loop (VPIL) framework, VCIL improves simulation speed by $4.8 \times$ and reduces timing errors by 35.9%. Experiments conducted on the SM3/SM4 coprocessor demonstrate that VCIL reduces verification time by 53.4%, and the timing error is only 3.5% compared to the RTL full-system. Our code will be available at https://github.com/LX-IC/VCIL.

title: An AI-Driven Federated Trust and Energy Optimization Framework for Secure IoT-Enabled Sensor Networks
authors: Vadala Nagamani, K. Annapurna
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: In next-generation Internet of Things (IoT) systems, Wireless Sensor Networks (WSNs) face concurrent challenges of energy imbalance, insecure communication, and unreliable routing due to the dynamic and distributed nature of sensor nodes. This paper presents an AI-driven Federated Trust and Energy Optimization (FTEO) framework that integrates Adaptive Clustering and Trust-Aware Routing (ACTAR) principles, a Non-Uniform and Optimized Clustering Mechanism (NUOCM), and a hybrid multi-objective optimization model to achieve secure and energy-efficient communication. The framework operates in three intelligent phases: (i) Smart Hybrid Clustering (SHC), which employs a Firefly–PSO–Genetic hybrid optimizer to form non-uniform clusters for minimizing energy imbalance; (ii) Intelligent Cluster Head Optimization (ICHO), which applies reinforcement learning for optimal cluster head rotation to balance residual energy and reduce latency; and (iii) Blockchain-Enabled Trust Routing (BETR), which employs federated learning-assisted trust computation and blockchain-based authentication to ensure secure and tamper-proof routing. Comprehensive MATLAB simulations demonstrate that FTEO outperforms conventional ACTAR, HTBR, and LEACH protocols by achieving 47.6% higher energy efficiency, 41% lower routing overhead, and 96.8% malicious node detection accuracy, while maintaining a packet delivery ratio (PDR) of 94.7% under 40% malicious node intrusion. The results confirm that the integration of NUOCM-based clustering, hybrid optimization, and federated trust routing significantly enhances network lifetime, reliability, and security in IoT-enabled WSNs.

title: Genetic Algorithm-Fuzzy Logic Hybrid Framework for Privacy Preservation and Access Control in Educational Social Networks
authors: Y. Chitti Babu, Bachu Naga Vamsi Krishna
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: Users frequently expose sensitive information when posting on OSN, mostly because of inflexible access control systems and a lack of user education regarding data protection. When it comes to educational social networks, this problem becomes much more pressing because it is essential to safeguard both students and teachers while encouraging engagement through strong access control and privacy preservation measures. To solve this problem, the research presents a hybrid optimization approach that can improve data management and network security. The raw social network data is preprocessed before feature extraction using the LRM technique is carried out. To get around the drawbacks of each strategy, they create a new hybrid approach that uses fuzzy logic for parameter adjustment and combines GA and PSO. By combining GA with Fuzzy-PSO, we may take advantage of the best features of both optimization methods, and the use of fuzzy logic guarantees fair results. The suggested solution achieves a maximum accuracy of 98.10% and routinely beats standalone GA and PSO, according to experimental data based on benchmark mathematical functions. These results show that the hybrid method greatly improves optimization efficiency, providing a strong answer to the problems of educational social networks' privacy protection and access control.

title: A Hybrid AI-Cloud Framework for Real-Time Data Analytics in Distributed Systems
authors: Nikhil Reddy Gaddam
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: This paper presents a hybrid AI-Cloud framework designed for real-time data analytics in distributed systems. The framework combines edge-based lightweight AI modules with cloud-native scalable processing to achieve low-latency inference, high-throughput batch analytics, and robust fault tolerance. We propose an architectural blueprint, communication protocols, model management strategies, and an adaptive orchestration layer that dynamically partitions workloads across edge and cloud based on context, network conditions, and analytics requirements. Through simulation and a prototype deployment on a mixed edge-cloud cluster, we demonstrate improvements in end-to-end latency, bandwidth utilization, and cost-efficiency compared to cloud-only and edge-only baselines. We also present a set of evaluation metrics and an empirical study using synthetic and real-world streams to validate the framework.

title: Balanced-IDS: A Deep Hybrid Model to Overcome Class Imbalance in Network Intrusion Detection
authors: Jishnu S, Ruban B, Balakrishnan D, C Rajan
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: The rapid growth of digital communication systems has increased exposure to sophisticated cyberattacks, creating a strong need for intrusion detection methods that can adapt and respond intelligently. Traditional Intrusion Detection Systems (IDS) struggle with identifying uncommon or newly emerging threats because real-world network data typically contains far more normal traffic than malicious activity. This imbalance causes models to learn unevenly, often leading to biased predictions and higher false-negative rates.To address these shortcomings, this work introduces Balanced-IDS, a hybrid deep-learning model that combines Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs) with Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) networks, supported by both data-level and model-level balancing strategies. The CNN layers extract spatial features from network traffic, while the LSTM component captures their sequential patterns. To ensure fair learning across classes, the framework incorporates the Synthetic Minority Oversampling Technique (SMOTE) along with cost-sensitive training, enabling the model to give appropriate attention to underrepresented attack types during optimization. Comprehensive experiments performed on benchmark datasets—including NSL-KDD, CICIDS2017, and UNSW-NB15—show that Balanced-IDS delivers significant upgrades in accuracy, recall, and F1-score compared with existing IDS approaches. The results confirm that the proposed system reduces false negatives and strengthens detection performance across a wide range of attack scenarios, making it a reliable and scalable choice for large-scale cybersecurity environments.

title: Deep Learning-Assisted Sub-6 GHz Environment Sensing via Reconfigurable Intelligent Surfaces
authors: Mohammed Ayoub Toubal, Tirchas Panagiotis, Youssef Nasser, George Karetsos, Julien de Rosny, Geoffroy Lerosey
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on 6G Networking (6GNet)
abstract: This paper introduces an approach to recognizing human posture using reflected wireless signals and Deep Learning (DL). The system combines Frequency-Modulated Continuous Wave (FMCW) signals with Reconfigurable Intelligent Surfaces (RIS) to reflect the signals throughout the space to improve signal diversity. It uses two software-defined radios (USRPs), one as a transmitter and one as a receiver. This setup helps the system pick up useful reflections regardless the person's position in the space, whether they're closer to the transmitter, the receiver, or somewhere in between. At the receiver's end, we process the reflected signals by performing Fast Fourier Transformation (FFT) analysis to generate Power Spectral Density (PSD) plots, which we convert into image data. These are then fed into a DL model combining a Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) module which extracts spatial features from each frame and a Long-Short Term Memory (LSTM) module that captures temporal patterns across multiple frames. This combination allows the system to make accurate posture predictions in real time.

title: Enhanced Deep Learning Based Multi-omics Oral Cancer Survival Prediction System
authors: S. Mohideen Badhusha, Loyston Veigas, Srujan B N, Swanjith A K, Shashank S S
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: A major therapeutic problem that necessitates precise, individualized survival prediction is oral squamous cell carcinoma. The Cancer Genome Atlas Head and Neck Squamous Cell Carcinoma (TCGA-HNSC) cohort’s clinical and multi-omics data are integrated in this paper’s thorough deployment and assessment of DeepOmnicsSurv. With a concordance index of 0.792, the proposed implementation significantly outperformed random survival forests (C-index: 0.764) and conventional Cox proportional hazards models (C-index: 0.694). For computational interpretability, this work uses convolutional neural networks and multi-head attention mechanisms with SHAP analysis. Compared to clinical-only models, multi-omics integration increased performance by 12%. The findings show promise for future clinical validation by showing that deep learning-based multi-omics techniques greatly improve survival prediction accuracy while preserving interpretability.

title: A 0.4 to 8GHz Broadband High-linearity I/Q Active Mixer in 130nm BiCMOS Technology
authors: Qipeng Li, Zhenghao He, Chun Zhu, Yifan Huang, Qin Li
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Integrated Circuits and Microsystems (ICICM)
abstract: This paper presents a 0.4 to 8 GHz Gilbert-cell up-conversion mixer designed in a $\mathbf{1 3 0}-\mathbf{n m}$ SiGe BiCMOS process. The mixer translates baseband signals to the radio frequency (RF) signals. To enhance the third-order intermodulation (IM3) performance, a collector cross-coupling technique is employed across the transconductance amplifiers. Furthermore, a series resistor-inductor (RL) network is utilized at the load to boost the high-frequency gain, thereby improving in-band gain flatness. The designed mixer achieves an output 1-dB compression point(OP1dB) of $\mathbf{1 0. 5 ~ d B m}$ and an output third-order intercept point(OIP3) of 22.07 dBm at 1 GHz. The carrier suppression ratio is better than 52 dBc across the entire LO frequency range of 0.4 GHz to 8 GHz. Image rejection ratio exceeds 45 dBc. The chip occupies a core area of $0.15 \mathrm{~mm}^{2}$ and consumes 295 mW of DC power.

title: Supercritical Fluid-Engineered p-GaN Thin Films with Improved Electrical and Optical Properties
authors: Yao-Li Chuang, Lei Li, Lei Lu, Kuan-Chang Chang
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Integrated Circuits and Microsystems (ICICM)
abstract: High contact resistance and incomplete Mg-acceptor activation persist as critical bottlenecks for p-type GaN, largely due to deep acceptor levels and compensation effects that limit hole concentration. This work demonstrates that low-temperature supercritical fluid (SCF) treatment effectively addresses these limitations. Through systematic electrical measurements, Hall effect analysis, and material characterizations, Significant improvements were observed, with the contact resistance decreasing by 35 to 61.5 percent (from 31.6/40.5 kiloohms to 20.5/17.5 kiloohms) for different electrode configurations, while the Hall mobility increases from 7.9 to 9.0 square centimeters per volt-second. Energy band analysis reveals a reduced Schottky barrier height at the metal/p-GaN interface, facilitating enhanced hole injection and ohmic contact behavior. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) confirms weakened Mg-H bonding and promoted Mg activation, whereas Raman spectroscopy verifies no induced lattice stress. Photoluminescence (PL) shows intensified near-band-edge (NBE) and blue luminescence (BL) emissions, indicating suppressed non-radiative recombination and higher acceptor activation. These findings establish SCF processing as a non-destructive, scalable method to engineer high-performance p-GaN for optoelectronic and power devices.

title: Secure Time-Modulated Intelligent Reflecting Surface via Generative Flow Networks
authors: Zhihao Tao, Athina P. Petropulu
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: We propose a novel directional modulation (DM) design for OFDM transmitters aided by a time-modulated intelligent reflecting surface (TM-IRS). The TM-IRS is configured to preserve the integrity of transmitted signals toward multiple legitimate users while scrambling the signal in all other directions. Existing TM-IRS design methods typically target a single user direction and follow predefined rule-based procedures, making them unsuitable for multi-user scenarios. Here, we propose a generative AI-based approach to design good sets of TM-IRS parameters out of a set of all possible quantized ranges of parameters. The design objective is to maximize the sum rate across the authorized directions we formulate in this work. We model the TM-IRS parameter selection as a deterministic Markov decision process (MDP), where each terminal state corresponds to a specific configuration of TM-IRS parameters. GFlowNets are employed to learn a stochastic policy that samples TM-IRS parameter sets with probability proportional to their associated sum rate reward. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed method effectively enhances the security of the TM-IRS-aided OFDM systems with multi-users. Also, despite the vast size of the TM-IRS configuration space, the GFlowNet is able to converge after training on fewer than 0.000001% of all possible configurations, demonstrating remarkable efficiency compared to exhaustive combinatorial search. Implementation code is available at https://github.com/ZhihaoTao/GFN4TM-RIS to facilitate reproducibility.

title: Quantum-Resistant Identity and Access Management (IAM) System for Enterprises
authors: K. Venkatesh, M. Caleb Gunalan, Mokshith Kanaparthi, Manoj Hariharan R, Rahul S
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: This paper presents a Quantum Resistant Identity and Access Management (IAM) System tailored for enterprise deployments to mitigate the emerging risk posed by quantum-capable adversaries to classical public-key cryptography. The system integrates NIST-aligned post-quantum cryptographic primitives, a Zero-Trust policy engine, multi-factor and biometric authentication, behavioral analytics driven by machine learning, and a quantum-safe blockchain-based audit trail. Implemented with a React + TypeScript frontend and a Supabase (PostgreSQL) backend, the design prioritizes modularity, scalability, and standards compliance. We describe the system architecture, key modules (cryptographic layer, zero-trust engine, authentication and authorization layers, and governance services), and a testing methodology that includes quantum-attack simulation, behavioral anomaly detection, and performance benchmarking. Experimental validation on a prototype demonstrates acceptable authentication latency, sub-100 ms trust score evaluation, and quantum-resistant key generation within practical bounds for enterprise use. Comparative analysis shows the solution provides unique quantum-resilience and integrated governance advantages against mainstream IAM offerings. We conclude with a roadmap for QKD integration, FIDO2 hardware token support, and AI-driven governance for continued robustness as quantum capabilities evolve.

title: Performance Characteristics of TCP and QUIC over V2V Wi-Fi in Urban Scenarios
authors: Chunghan Lee, Seyhan Ucar, Onur Altintas, Kentaro Oguchi
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: Wi-Fi is widely adopted for reliable data transfer, supported by transport layer protocols such as TCP and QUIC. While Vehicle-to-Vehicle (V2V) Wi-Fi holds promise for connected vehicles, existing research has focused on Vehicle-to-Infrastructure (V2I) communications using legacy Wi-Fi standards. Despite the maturity of Wi-Fi technology, its performance in V2V scenarios, especially with transport protocols (TCP and QUIC), remains underexplored. In this paper, we conduct outdoor field trials with vehicles in urban road environments to evaluate TCP and QUIC performance with congestion control algorithms (CUBIC and BBR) over V2V Wi-Fi. Our field trial experiments show that TCP with BBR delivers the highest performance, achieving up to 250 Mbps at intersections. V2V Wi-Fi maintains generally stable connections, even under Non-Line-of-Sight (NLoS) conditions, though throughput can drop significantly when obstructed by large vehicles.

title: Smart Turbo Current Generator
authors: Udhaya T, Dhaksan M, Dhanush Kumar S
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: By converting the airflow beneath moving vehicles into electrical energy, the Smart Turbo Current Generator (STCG) plays a vital role in improving vehicle energy efficiency and promoting sustainable transportation. Conventional vehicles waste a large amount of kinetic airflow energy while in motion, leading to energy loss and increased fuel dependency. This study introduces a compact system that integrates a Vertical-Axis Wind Turbine (VAWT) under the vehicle to capture this airflow and convert it into electrical power. The generated energy is stored in a battery and managed by a smart power control unit that ensures efficient charging and safe energy distribution. The system was tested under different vehicle speeds and airflow conditions, showing improved energy recovery and reduced power wastage. The proposed design supports green energy innovation by reducing fuel use, extending battery life, and promoting eco-friendly mobility. This work demonstrates the potential of on-road wind energy harvesting as a sustainable solution for modern and future electric vehicles.

title: Architecting Adaptive Command and Control Systems with Autonomic Computing
authors: Erwin Franz, Christopher Rouff, Ali Tekeoglu
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: This research applies autonomic computing principles to enhance the adaptability, effectiveness, and resilience of command and control (C2) systems from the perspective of agent communication. Traditional centralized C2 architectures often create bottlenecks, single points of failure, and limited flexibility in dynamic environments. By integrating self-managing agents capable of self-configuration, self-optimization, self-healing, and self-protection, we demonstrate that C2 networks can better adapt, recover from disruptions, and maintain operational continuity. Using graph theory and computer-based simulations, we define and analyze structural properties of autonomic agent networks that support resilience and adaptability. This research proposes a novel C2 paradigm that combines centralized command structures with distributed intelligence, offering an innovative architectural approach for designing adaptive, fault-tolerant systems with potential applications in defense, autonomous networks, and large-scale multi-agent environments.

title: Federated Learning-Based Anomaly Detection Approach for High-Performance Research Networks
authors: Ehsan Saeedizade, Shamik Sengupta, Jay Thom
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: The security and reliability of high-performance research networks (HPRNs) are of paramount importance, as they facilitate large-scale scientific data transfers yet remain susceptible to network anomalies and cyber threats. Traditional anomaly detection methods based on machine learning typically depend on centralized training, which not only poses privacy risks but also encounters challenges related to scalability and limited generalization across heterogeneous networks. To address these issues, we propose an anomaly detection approach based on federated learning that facilitates decentralized model training while safeguarding the data privacy of HPRNs. By incorporating a feature-based transfer learning methodology, our approach improves model generalization across non-IID datasets and enhances robustness in environments with sparse data, thus mitigating the adverse effects of heterogeneous infrastructure conditions and limited training data availability. Our method undergoes extensive evaluation on datasets generated from various testbeds. The experimental results indicate that the proposed federated learning approach, augmented with feature-based transfer learning, achieves an accuracy of 96.56% and an F1-score of 0.9658, which significantly outperforms centralized training paradigms. Additionally, our analysis reveals that feature normalization expedites the convergence of federated learning model training, reducing the number of rounds required for stabilization from 100 to 50 rounds. These findings underscore the efficacy of our proposed federated learning-based approach in securing HPRNs and offering a scalable, privacy-preserving solution for anomaly detection in distributed research infrastructures.

title: Evaluation of 5G Signals of Opportunity for High-Altitude Platform Station Navigation
authors: Faezeh Mooseli, Will Barrett, Samer Hayek, Zaher M. Kassas
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: The feasibility of using cellular 5G signals of opportunity (SOPs) as a navigation source for high-altitude platform stations (HAPS) is investigated. First, a 5G signal model is developed and a software-defined receiver (SDR) is implemented to extract pseudorange observables from received 5G downlink signals opportunistically. Second, a signal collection payload is designed and deployed on a high-altitude weather balloon, reaching altitudes comparable to HAPS. Experimental results are presented, showing the signal tracking performance and pseudorange measurement generation across three flight segments at different altitudes, reaching 76,000 ft. Finally, the produced pseudoranges were fused with altimeter data via an extended Kalman filter (EKF) to estimate the balloon’s trajectory, achieving a three-dimensional (3D) position root mean-squared error (RMSE) of 15.92 m over a 1.105 km trajectory.

title: A –86 dBm/15.6 μW Wake-Up Receiver for Internet of Vehicles Applications
authors: Rui Chen, Yan Li, Liming Si, Xinchao Zhong, Chiu-Wing Sham, Hang Yu
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Integrated Circuits and Microsystems (ICICM)
abstract: This paper presents a novel ultra-low power WakeUp Receiver (WuRx) designed for Internet of Vehicles (IOV). The proposed design is based on a high sensitivity RF receiver integrated in an On Board Unit (OBU). Without dedicated die area, the WuRx is formed by re-using the necessary key consisting components of the $\mathbf{R F}$ receiver, while those with high-power consumption, such as the analog band-pass filter, is de-activated. To further minimize the power consumption of the WuRx, a Pulse Width Modulated (PWM) control scheme functioning at 0.7 V is implemented, and the WuRx receiving chain is thus alternatively turned ON/OFF. Fabricated using CMOS 180 nm process, only $\mathbf{2 0 0} \boldsymbol{\mu} \mathbf{m} \times \mathbf{1 0 0} \boldsymbol{\mu} \mathbf{m}$ of additional die area is required to implement the WuRx. Measurement shows that the proposed WuRx achieves a peak wake-up sensitivity of -86 dBm in the 5.8 GHz band, while the average power consumption is only $15.6 \mu \mathrm{~W}$.

title: Proactive Adversarial Defense: Harnessing Prompt Tuning in Vision-Language Models to Detect Unseen Backdoored Images
authors: Kyle Stein, Andrew Arash Mahyari, Guillermo Francia, Eman El-Sheikh
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: Backdoor attacks pose a critical threat by embedding hidden triggers into inputs, causing models to misclassify them into adversary-chosen target labels. While extensive research has focused on mitigating these attacks in object recognition models through weight fine-tuning and other reactive strategies, much less attention has been given to detecting backdoored samples directly. Given the vast datasets used in training models, manual inspection for backdoor triggers is impractical, and even state-of-the-art defense mechanisms fail to fully neutralize their impact. To address this gap, we introduce a groundbreaking method to detect unseen backdoored images during both training and inference. Leveraging the transformative success of prompt tuning in Vision Language Models (VLMs), our approach trains learnable text prompts to differentiate clean images from those with hidden backdoor triggers. Comprehensive experiments on CIFAR-10 and GTSRB covering six diverse attack families demonstrate the robustness of our detector. When exposed to unseen backdoor threats, the learned prompts achieve an average 86% accuracy at distinguishing previously unseen backdoor images from clean ones, outperforming baselines by up to 30 percentage points. These results establish prompt-tuned VLMs as an effective first line of defense against backdoor threats. Code and datasets will be available.

title: MobiSwift: Seamless multi-access connectivity for low latency applications through SRv6 and eBPF
authors: Yu Mi, Randeep Bhatia, Fang Hao, An Wang, Steve Benno, Tv Lakshman
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: The increasing need for low latency communications, driven by the envisaged growth of applications like AR/VR and autonomous vehicles, has led to renewed interest in optimizing network protocols and mechanisms. However, achieving low latency in mobile environments is particularly challenging due to their dynamic and unpredictable nature.To address this, we built a system named MobiSwift that is designed to provide low-latency and seamless connectivity in multi-access mobile networks. Its key innovations include a) Decoupling device locators from identifiers for seamless multi-access connectivity, b) Optimizing connection setup latencies through a novel overlay infrastructure, c) Routing data packets on low-latency direct paths, and d) Seamless peer-to-peer mobility handling and access switching.We developed MobiSwift using widely available, modern networking technologies like Segment Routing over IPv6 (SRv6) and eBPF to ensure efficient and flexible packet processing and forwarding. We implemented a prototype of MobiSwift on FABRIC, a wide-area programmable network testbed, to establish feasibility with a real implementation and evaluate its performance. Our results show that MobiSwift achieves near-optimal latency, and its recovery overhead from unexpected connectivity disruption is less than 40 ms, thus demonstrating its effectiveness.

title: ACT-RIC: Adaptive Cyber Threat Handling and CU-UP Migration via O-RAN Near-RT RIC
authors: Aparaajitha Gomathinayakam Latha, Linqi Xiao, Abhishek Bhattacharyya, Koteswararao Kondepu, Venkateswarlu Gudepu, Andrea Fumagalli
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: This demo presents a cyber-resilient fifth-generation and beyond (B5G) framework that activates dynamic live-migration of the Centralized Unit–User Plane (CU-UP) container in response to a cyber threat. Deployed within the near-real-time RAN Intelligent Controller (Near-RT RIC) an Adaptive Cyber Threat (ACT) xApp detects cyber threats adversely affecting the CU-UP container and triggers its migration through an Optical Transport Network (OTN). Implemented using OpenAirInterface (OAI) and FlexRIC, the demo can respond to cyber threats in around 10 seconds.

title: Chiplet-based Implementation of Decision Trees for Network Intrusion Detection
authors: Md Abrar Ibtesham, Lei Zhang, Joseph Riem, Tian Lan, Nathaniel D. Bastian, Gina C. Adam
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: Enabling cybersecurity at the network edge requires fast, lightweight, and energy-efficient hardware implementations of explainable network intrusion detection, especially in constrained environments such as the Internet of Battlefield Things (IoBT). While digital platforms like FPGAs have been used to demonstrate these capabilities, in this work, we focus on characterizing and validating an analog memristor/130 nm CMOS-based implementation using precision measurement equipment. Specifically, we employ the Keysight M3300A and M9603A to measure and analyze the behavior of decision tree structures, which are shown to enable explainable network intrusion detection, using the packet-level benchmark dataset: ACI-IoT 2023. In our architecture, each chiplet represents a decision tree leaf, with boundary values stored physically as programmable 6-bit resistances in memristor devices. These resistance values are set according to trained decision tree boundaries obtained from the dataset. Input features are translated into voltages and compared against the memristive thresholds to perform inference, with node outputs indicating either attack or benign classifications.

title: Pairwise Neural Cross-Correlation for Accurate Estimates in Low SNR
authors: Miguel Dominguez
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: Increased interest in "explainable" AI models has led to the development of neural networks that not only estimate scalar time delays, Doppler shifts, and carrier frequencies, but entire denoised cross-correlation signals, whose errors can be analyzed. Previously, this required generating ground-truth correlation signals, an additional engineering burden. We propose an alternative, Pairwise Neural Cross-Correlation (PNCC), that can learn denoised cross-correlation signals given only the noisy signals and the ground truth peak. Our neural network learns to transform each signal in a pair such that each transformed signal correlates highly with its untransformed partner at the ground truth. This produces a visible peak in cross-correlation close to the ground truth even at low (e.g. −20dB) Signal-to-Noise Ratio (SNR). PNCC reduces mean absolute error (MAE) of cross-correlation time delay estimates by 49.4%, Doppler shift estimates by 27.2%, and blind carrier frequency estimates by 76.3%. PNCC time delay estimates reduce location MAE by 22.8%, and PNCC Doppler shift estimates reduce velocity MAE by 1.57% in a Time Difference of Arrival (TDOA) and Frequency Difference of Arrival (FDOA) simulation, respectively.

title: SHARQ: Semantic HARQ for Reliable Distributed DNN Execution
authors: Ian Andrew Harshbarger, Leïla Nasraoui, Marco Levorato
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: This paper proposes a semantic version of the hybrid automatic repeat request (SHARQ) protocol embedded within an enhanced split computing framework to optimize data transmission and inference accuracy over noisy wireless channels.
