authors: Yunpeng Xia, Yu Li, Tianqi Li, Qinfei Long, Zihui Hong, Yunhe Hou, Tiande Mo
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Integrated Circuits and Microsystems (ICICM)
abstract: This paper reports a reconfigurable memory device (RMD) based on the $\mathrm{MoS}_{2} / \mathrm{CuInP}_{2} \mathrm{~S}_{6}$ (CIPS) heterostructure: by enhancing CIPS interlayer defect density via plasma-induced defect engineering and combining its ferroelectric properties, the device achieves structural simplification and functional integration, enabling multi-bit information storage under electrical pulses and reversible switching between non-volatile and volatile memory modes under optical pulses (by modulating CIPS ferroelectric polarization state). This work innovatively integrates electrical-optical dual modulation and multi-mode storage into a single heterostructure, breaking the traditional trade-off between structural complexity and functional diversity in memory devices, and provides a novel technical path for high-integration nextgeneration intelligent memory technologies.

title: A Secure and Anonymous Cloud Data Sharing Framework with Attribute-based Proxy Re-Encryption
authors: K Karthikeyan, Narendar P, Kalaiyarasu M R
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: The swift increase in data storage requirements for big data is prompting serious consideration of the privacy concerns of data, as well as securely sharing data over the cloud. The use of traditional encryption techniques, motivated through Public Key Encryption (PKE), inherently introduces the possibility of exposing the data to other users when sharing with several others and does not keep the identity of the user anonymous. Therefore, the current work is a privacy-preserving model that provides a pre-authorization privately and uses a conditional re-encryption technique for the encrypted data sharing with a group of proxies. The primary focus of this work is to provide the secure sharing of data which can be enforced by specific attribute users. The model provides a measure of assurance in that only users possessing a specified set of attributes will be able to access the encrypted data. The model uses an attribute-based authentication with a semi-trusted proxy group key with acknowledgement that the users' private key attributes will be attested to before any data is re-encrypted. Furthermore, throughout this process, the confidentiality, integrity and anonymity of the data is retained during the transmission of the encrypted data to the multiple users. The results indicated that the pre-authentication and attribute-conditional re-encryption framework improved the security levels significantly, by not revealing the users' identity and preventing other data recipients from accessing the data without authorization, while maintaining data sharing performance. As a result, the collaborative model offers a secure big data storage and data sharing model in the cloud that is efficient and offers privacy/security along with scalability.

title: Smart IoT-Enabled MPPT Solar Photovoltaic System
authors: Alagar Karthick, I.Baranilingesan, Vijay Ganesan, Soundrya Alagappan
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: The integration of renewable energy with intelligent monitoring and control systems is essential for enhancing energy efficiency and sustainability. This work presents the design and implementation of a Smart IoT-Enabled Maximum Power Point Tracking (MPPT) Solar Charge Controller, developed to optimize solar energy harvesting while enabling real-time data monitoring. The proposed system employs an MPPT algorithm to dynamically track and extract maximum power from photovoltaic (PV) panels under varying environmental conditions, ensuring efficient charging of storage batteries. Internet of Things (IoT) technology is incorporated for remote monitoring and control, enabling users to access performance metrics such as voltage, current, power, and battery status via cloud-based platforms. Experimental validation demonstrates improved charging efficiency, reduced energy losses, and seamless user interaction compared to conventional controllers. The results confirm that the IoT-enabled MPPT controller provides a reliable and scalable solution for smart solar energy management systems, promoting sustainability and grid-independence in renewable energy applications.

title: A Novel Approach for Topic Detection using Semantic Embedding with DTE And WTE
authors: T.Sunitha, Garikapati Bhanu Swetha, M. Senthil, D. Bujji Babu
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: With the rapid growth of digital information, accurate news topic classification is vital for applications such as content recommendation, opinion monitoring, and automated news systems. Traditional approaches fail to capture deep semantic and syntactic relations, limiting their accuracy. To address this, we integrate probabilistic topic models such as Latent Dirichlet Allocation (LDA) with word embeddings like Word2Vec and GloVe. Two strategies are proposed: Document-Level Topic Embedding (DTE) and Word-Level Topic Embedding (WTE), classified using Support Vector Machines (SVM) and Logistic Regression. Experiments on benchmark datasets demonstrate improved precision and recall compared to conventional methods. The proposed framework is scalable, efficient, and applicable to multilingual text classification tasks.

title: Slice-MCP — Fine-Tuned Llama-4 LLM and MCP Enabled 5G Network Slice Orchestration Platform
authors: Eranga Bandara, Safdar H. Bouk, Ravi Mukkamala, Abdul Rahman, Xueping Liang, Ross Gore, Sachin Shetty
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: 5G network slicing presents a transformative approach to deliver customizable, isolated virtual networks over shared infrastructure, tailored to meet diverse application requirements such as ultra-low latency, high reliability, or massive connectivity. However, orchestrating these network slices dynamically and efficiently remains a complex challenge due to the need for precise configuration, real-time responsiveness, and seamless coordination across heterogeneous domains (radio access network, core, and transport). In this paper, we present Slice-MCP, a novel 5G network slice orchestration platform that integrates the Model Context Protocol (MCP) with a fine-tuned Meta’s Llama-4 large language model (LLM) to simplify and automate the slice orchestration process. Slice-MCP allows users to invoke natural language queries which are interpreted by the fine-tuned LLM and mapped to the corresponding MCP functions to configure and deploy the appropriate network slices. To ensure accurate intent recognition and robust function mapping, the LLM was fine-tuned on a custom dataset comprising real-world user intents paired with their corresponding MCP server operations. The integration of MCP provides a standardized interface for dynamic context management, enabling a consistent and extensible way to translate high-level user goals into orchestrator-level instructions across network domains. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first work to apply the MCP for 5G network slice orchestration, merging AI-driven natural language interaction with telecom-grade infrastructure management. The effectiveness of the Slice-MCP is demonstrated through a real-world test-bed deployment in a sliced network scenario, utilizing multiple 5G cores (i.e., Open5GS) across Ericsson’s new RAN. Our results demonstrate that Slice-MCP significantly reduces the operational complexity of 5G slice management while enhancing responsiveness, scalability, and user accessibility.

title: Design and Development of a Smart loT-Enabled Biometric Authentication-based Intelligent Anti-Theft Security System
authors: Thamaraimanalan T, Manmohan S, Midhun R, Raja Selvin A, Ram Bahwan A K
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: There is a lack of data recording in the event of an accident or theft, and the user cannot get assistance if their bike is in a remote place as emergency services cannot be contacted. No other means of entry to the bike exist other that key. The creation of a fingerprint-based, self-starting motorbike is the primary objective of this project. With this invention, the owner may just use his fingerprint to start his motorbike. Here, the owner can see exactly where their automobile is at all times and never lose a key again. Additionally, five of the owner's acquaintances will get a message with the exact position of the car in the event of an accident. If someone tries to steal the car, it will also sound an alarm. This project suggests an alternative identification method, namely, a system that detects accidents involving bikes and uses live GPS monitoring and authentication based on fingerprints. In order to combat vehicle theft and keep riders safe, this project details the development and deployment of a biometric smart bike security system. One of the main ways to verify your identity and start the engine is using a fingerprint sensor. The bike may only be started by authorized users using registered fingerprints; any attempt to start it by someone else would immediately raise an alarm for theft. In the event of an attempted intrusion, the owner will get real-time SMS alerts via a GSM module (SIM800L). A fuel cutoff device is built in to disable engine function and prevent tampering. It uses a relay to activate a solenoid valve, limiting fuel flow. The installation of a GPS module allows for more precise tracking by relaying the current position of the vehicle to the owner in the event of a theft. In addition, the ESP32 allows for real-time video streaming, which is useful for monitoring purposes and may serve as visual proof in the event of theft. An infrared (IR) sensor-based helmet detection system verifies that the rider is wearing a helmet before allowing them to operate the bike, hence enhancing rider safety. Biometric identification, Internet of Things (IoT) theft alerts, tracking by GPS, live streaming, as well as rider safety monitoring are all part of the suggested system, which is an affordable, dependable, and user-friendly solution for two-wheeler security.

title: Learning to Transmit: RL based Adaptive Transmission for Energy-Efficient IoT
authors: Ragini Gupta, Xinyu Chen, Samvit Dedhia, Claudiu Danilov, Josh Eckhardt, Keyshla Bernard, Klara Nahrstedt
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: The rapid expansion of the Internet of Things (IoT) has enabled real-time monitoring across domains such as smart cities, environmental sensing, and healthcare. However, sustaining long-term operations of battery-powered IoT devices remains a critical challenge due to the high energy cost of frequent data transmissions. Existing adaptive sampling techniques reduce energy consumption by limiting redundant transmissions but often rely on static heuristics that fail to adapt to dynamic environments. In this work, we propose a reinforcement learning (RL)-based framework for adaptive transmission scheduling that optimizes energy efficiency while preserving data integrity. We evaluate two RL strategies—Q-Learning and Deep Q-Networks (DQN)—within a realistic simulation environment using the Internet of Battlefield Things (IoBT) dataset. Our framework employs RL agents at dynamically selected cluster heads in a distributed urban IoT network, enabling intelligent transmission decisions based on residual energy and data similarity. Experimental results demonstrate that RL-based policies significantly outperform heuristic baselines, with DQN achieving superior adaptability and faster convergence under changing conditions. Evaluated on the Internet of Battlefield Things (IoBT) dataset using Q-Learning and Deep Q-Networks (DQN), our system reduces recharge sessions by over 51% and improves unique data preservation by 31% compared to the baseline.

title: Stock Market Prediction using Machine Learning: A Comparative Analysis and Transformer-based Enhancement
authors: Manikandan Jayapal, Himanshi Raghav, Nishtha Mehar, Pratap Bahadur Singh, Anay Verma
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: This paper compares three ensemble models— XGBoost, AdaBoost, and CatBoost with a Transformer-based model (TBE — Transformer-Based Enhancement) for next-day stock closing price prediction on GOOG and GS using Yahoo Finance OHLCV data (2010-01-01 to 2025-10-15, N = 3,774 rows per stock after cleaning). We evaluate models using RMSE, MAE, and R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>, and report directional metrics (accuracy, F1, AUC) and complexity metrics (parameters, training time, inference latency). Our TBE (encoder-only Transformer with learnable positional embeddings, d<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">model</inf> = 128, W = 30) reduces test RMSE vs the best ensemble (CatBoost) by a large margin (example: GOOG RMSE 3.12 vs 5.78) while incurring higher compute cost. We release key hyperparameters, seeds, and complexity measurements to improve reproducibility. Results, ablations and practical deployment guidance are discussed.

title: Immersive Sign-Language Interaction and Multimodal Sensor Fusion for Context-Aware Business English Machine Translation under Complex Optimization Constraint
authors: Jiang Yanxiao
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: To address the issues of contextual inconsistency and response delay in business English semantic translation in multimodal environments, this study proposes an immersive sign language interaction and multi-sensor fusion machine translation model (ISMF-COT) based on complex optimization constraints. This model constructs a dynamic context-aware semantic alignment structure. This innovation enables multi-layer fusion and adaptive semantic mapping of sign language, speech, and gesture signals. The model consists of two components: a nonlinear feature decomposition module based on the Kolmogorov–Arnold network (KAN), which achieves a unified latent space mapping of multimodal features; and a context-sensitive decoding mechanism based on the ContraTrans architecture. This module achieves collaborative modeling of linguistic and non-linguistic semantics through explicit and implicit attention layers. To overcome the gradient oscillation problem in non-convex multi-objective optimization, this paper further proposes a hierarchical dual collaborative optimization model (HDCO). This model achieves a nonlinear balance between the three objectives of the semantic consistency, interactive responsiveness, and translation accuracy. To verify the effectiveness of the algorithm, we conducted a systematic experiment on the self-built Business-SL-Fusion dataset. This dataset contains three modalities: vision, audio, and action. A total of 12,000 samples. The experimental results show that ISMF-COT outperforms the mainstream control models in many indicators such as BLEU, ROUGE-L, and METEOR. Among them, BLEU increased by 16.2%, ROUGE-L increased by 14.9%, and the average response delay decreased by 7.7%. Modal ablation experiments show that visual and audio features contribute most to semantic accuracy. Gesture features provide significant auxiliary information at the emotional and pragmatic levels. The complex optimization stability index (COS) increased by 0.11. This result verifies the stability of the model under non-convex optimization conditions.

title: Multi-Class Brain Tumor Classification with MRI through a Fine-Tuned VGG16 Convolutional Neural Network
authors: R Sujitha, Rajkumar, Manisha Aeri, Aanchal Rawat
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: Brain tumor segmentation and diagnosis on the magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) scans is a vital exercise that improves the efficiency of the diagnostic outputs and helps in planning effective treatment. The deep learning algorithm has drawn significant interest due to its capacity to decrease the human factor and the enlargement of the diagnostic process and contribute to enhanced clinical decision-making. In this case, four tumor types, such as glioma tumor, meningioma tumor, pituitary tumor, and no tumor were classified by a CNN model trained on a VGG16 fine-tuned on this task. The downloaded kaggle dataset (7,023 MRI images) was balanced in terms of classes, and processed in a systematic manner before models were used to train. The architecture suggested was a combination of world average pooling, dense layers and dropout regularisation followed with warm-up training and refinement to optimal performance. The general accuracy of the model was 95 percent, whereas the classes had a precision, recall and F1-score of 0.91-0.99. The most correct was the class no tumor with 1.00 and then the glioma and meningioma with equal F1 scores of 0.93 and 0.91 respectively. Validation curves and training curves demonstrated stable convergence and no over-fitting, and confusion matrix also demonstrated that the misclassification number was smaller. These results reveal the possibility of CNN-based methods of effective, efficient, and scalable medical image classification, which facilitates quality medical care, innovation, sustainable development, enhanced well-being, and medical diagnostics resilience in accordance with international health goals.

title: 5G and Radar Coexistence: Demonstrating Pulsed Radar Interference and 5G Performance Metrics
authors: Eric Forbes, Gustave Anderson, Ying Wang
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: The escalating demand for wireless spectrum necessitates more effective coexistence strategies between commercial 5G networks and incumbent radar systems. Unlike traditional approaches that permit spectrum access to only one system at a time, this demonstration directly investigates the real time performance impacts on 5G communications under simultaneous radar interference. Our approach leverages a low cost, flexible, and modular experimental platform integrating commercial user equipment (UE) and software defined radios (SDRs). The demonstration highlights the effects of pulsed radar interference on key 5G metrics including UE throughput, uplink (UL) SINR, and downlink (DL) SNR, through live spectrum visualization and performance monitoring. Iterative test cycles allow systematic variation of radar parameters such as pulse repetition frequency (PRF) and duty cycles, fostering interactive discussions on practical coexistence scenarios. Preliminary results illustrate that simultaneous radar and 5G operation is feasible under certain conditions, providing valuable insights into optimizing future spectrum sharing deployments.

title: Hybrid VGG19–Random Forest Framework for Robust Tomato Leaf Disease Classification
authors: Rekha Deoli, Chandradeep Bhatt, Devendra Singh, Ritik Bisht
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: Diseases affecting tomato leaves detrimentally impact entire tomato ecosystems and cause economic losses throughout the world. Mitigation of crop damages and the promotion of sustainable agriculture, which eliminates the overuse of pesticides, hinges upon the identification of these diseases through the use of automation and advanced technology. This paper investigates the potential of the hybrid VGG19- Random Forest solution for identifying and classifying tomato diseases efficiently and accurately. The model was tested on the PlantVillage tomato dataset, which contains images of ten classes of diseases that are visually distinct and diverse. The VGG19 deep convolutional neural network was retrained to optimize feature extraction of diseased leaves, capturing textures and patterns associated with diseased leaf hierarchies. Global Average Pooling and Principal Component Analysis feature extraction optimizations reduced feature vector sizes, filtered noise and improved class separations of the dataset’s diseased tomato leaves. The Random Forest algorithm hierarchy was used to classify the features to improve the decision boundary and reduce overfitting normally associated with the use of CNN-Softmax classifiers. The newly proposed model achieved a performance of over 97.84% and classifying of the images with over 97% accuracy, surpassing the results achieved by the benchmark models VGG16, ResNet50, MobileNet, and EfficientNetB0. The consistency of the results achieved in this model was confirmed with the use of the confusion matrix analysis.

title: Voice Assistants in Brand Interaction
authors: P Bindhu Madhavi, H P Srinivasa, Y Sree Vani
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: In today’s era of digital media and virtual communication, the demand for creating realistic and engaging multimedia content has grown exponentially. In the Era of AI in marketing, if customers receive promotions in their own languages through voice assistants for their favorite brands, that creates a huge market virtually. Hence, our proposed problem statement aims to take a single marketing brand promotions video and turn it into unique, hyper-personalized experiences, each speaking directly to customers in their own language and voice. These Voice assistants in brand interactions need concurrent audio and video for applications with exact lip movements for a better user experience. But getting accurate lip syncing is a difficult job as per previous solutions due to several reasons, such as original audio with lip sync, speech with emotional expression for variety of languages. These systems also frequently struggle in less-than-ideal conditions, such as noisy environments, leading to noticeable synchronization failures that detract from the overall user experience. As per the survey- AI tools are less concurrent, in terms of audio and video data especially in the dubbing industry, virtual avatars disrupt the audience due to unnatural lip movements. These issues need to be addressed with all the existed limitations. To overcome these challenges, there is an urgent need for an advanced and scalable solution capable of generating high-quality, natural-looking lip-synced videos for digital brand promotions & interactions. Such a system must combine state-of-the-art models for speech synthesis, voice cloning, and lip synchronization, ensuring that audio and video not only match perfectly but also convey contextual and emotional appropriateness. By leveraging cutting-edge techniques and robust datasets, this proposed system can set a new standard in lip-sync technology, unlocking its potential for diverse applications, including virtual reality, interactive media, education, and beyond.

title: Wideband E-Shaped Antenna Design for Efficient Wireless Transmission
authors: Alagar Karthick, V Vanitha, D Ramya, U Jhanani Shree, S Regina, J. Rathanaa Ranjeni
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: This research presents a modified E-shaped microstrip patch antenna designed for C-band satellite communication. Despite their lightweight construction, small dimensions, and straightforward integration, microstrip patch antennas often struggle with limited bandwidth and reduced gain. We augment the conventional E-shaped structure with additional slots and optimize critical dimensions to address these issues. These alterations result in substantial improvements in impedance bandwidth and radiation efficiency. The engineered antenna functions well throughout the C-band frequency spectrum (2–8 GHz), providing improved return loss, elevated gain, and stable directional radiation patterns. The simulation findings confirm the antenna's efficacy for satellite communication, offering a high-performance, low-profile option. Furthermore, the antenna design is economically viable and straightforward to manufacture, making it suitable for contemporary satellite systems.

title: FMSRdiff: Efficient latent diffusion framework combining consistency model and flow matching for super-resolution
authors: QunKai Peng, GuoFeng Cai, YiHua Xu, Kuan-Chang Chang, Lei Li, GuiBo Luo
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Integrated Circuits and Microsystems (ICICM)
abstract: While diffusion-based super-resolution (SR) methods have demonstrated promising results, they still face critical limitations in practical medical imaging applications. Recent methods focus on training on real-world image datasets, but these methods are prone to losing structural information when transferred to the medical imaging domain and suffer from extremely slow inference speed. Traditional diffusion-based super-resolution models in medical imaging face key challenges including image structure inconsistency, low computational efficiency, and unstable training. To address these issues, we propose FMSRdiff, an efficient latent diffusion framework that integrates consistency models with optical flow matching. Starting with latent space diffusion, we construct an efficient low-dimensional representation learning framework. This allows the diffusion process to be performed in a compressed latent space, significantly reducing computational complexity and memory requirements while maintaining high-quality reconstruction. We then design a two-stage training strategy that first learns stable noise prediction capabilities through optical flow matching, then switches to consistent model training to achieve a direct mapping from noisy to clean latent representations. This strategy not only ensures training stability but also significantly improves inference speed, reducing the 50-100 sampling steps required in traditional diffusion models to just one, significantly improving the model’s practicality. Furthermore, we introduce a hierarchical diffusion mechanism to achieve multi-scale feature processing from coarse to fine scales, effectively addressing the structural inconsistency problem in medical image super-resolution. Through cross-scale feature fusion and conditional guidance, the model better preserves the global structure and local details of the image, resulting in more natural and realistic super-resolution results. Experiments on the IXI and BRATS datasets demonstrate that our method achieves a 30% improvement in SSIM scores compared to existing state-of-the-art methods for medical imaging data. Through latent space diffusion, computational efficiency is increased by approximately 16 times, memory usage is significantly reduced.

title: BRSMamba: Boundary-Aware Mamba for Forest and Shrub Segmentation From Diverse Satellite Imagery
authors: Zhijie He, Xiang Weng, Kai Fang, Yane Li, Yaoping Ruan, Hailin Feng
publish: IEEE Journal of Selected Topics in Applied Earth Observations and Remote Sensing
abstract: Vegetation, as a critical ecological feature and irreplaceable material resource of the Earth's surface, plays a crucial role in environmental protection, resource assessment and urban planning. The rapid advancement of remote sensing platforms and sensor technologies has facilitated the acquisition of high-resolution remote sensing imagery, providing excellent conditions for the detailed analysis of vegetation. However, vegetation segmentation in remote sensing imagery poses distinct challenges, including extreme scale variance, spectral ambiguity and complex boundary characteristics. The performance of Convolutional Neural Network (CNN)-based methods in vegetation segmentation is constrained by their limited ability to model long-range spatial dependencies. In contrast, although Transformer-based architectures effective at capturing global context, their quadratic complexity makes them impractical for processing high-resolution remote sensing images. Recently, State-Space Models (SSMs) have emerged as a promising alternative owing to their linear complexity and efficient long-range modeling capabilities. Nevertheless, existing vision SSMs have two critical limitations: (1) insufficient modeling of boundary information; and (2) the limited performance improvements offered by multi-directional scanning strategies while increasing computational cost. To address these limitations, we propose BRSMamba, a boundary-aware network that integrates two novel modules with Non-Causal State-Space Duality (NC-SSD) to enhance both boundary preservation and global context modeling. Specifically, the Boundary-Subject Fusion Perception (BFP) module extracts robust boundary features via a Laplacian-of-Gaussian Convolutional Block (LCB) and fuses them with category-centric semantics to generate a boundary-subject map. This map then directs the Boundary-Body Resolution (BBR) module to inject boundary awareness into the NC-SSD state-transition matrix, enabling selective scanning that preserves fine details and captures long-range dependencies. Experiments on four benchmark datasets demonstrated that BRSMamba achieved 78.86% mIoU on Vaihingen, 82.84% on Potsdam, 54.37% on LoveDA, and 72.24% on GID while using only 10.61 M parameters and 26.28 G FLOPs. These results validate the effectiveness of the proposed method in balancing the accuracy and efficiency of complex vegetation segmentation tasks.

title: A New PatchTST-ZTD Forecasting Model based on Different Global Climates and its performance in PPP
authors: Zhiping Chen, Hao Lu, Chiming Xu, Tao Liu, Haifeng Liu, Yu Gao, Haijun Yuan, Puhao Xu, Haiqing He, Kaiyun Lv
publish: IEEE Journal of Selected Topics in Applied Earth Observations and Remote Sensing
abstract: Accurate modeling of zenith tropospheric delay (ZTD) is crucial for real-time high-precision positioning in Global Navigation Satellite Systems (GNSS). Deep learning methods are capable of effectively capturing the complex temporal patterns of ZTD time series, which in turn contributes to improved its prediction accuracy and faster convergence in Precise Point Positioning (PPP). However, existing models generally suffer from insufficient temporal resolution, limited generalization ability, and reliance on latitude-based station division, which fails to comprehensively reflect the global error distribution characteristics. To this end, we develop a novel ZTD Forecasting model based on PatchTST (PBZTD), which more effectively captures local dependencies in time series by segmenting the ZTD data into patches. Meanwhile, the GNSS stations are categorized into five major climate types based on the Köppen-Geiger climate classification: Equatorial, Drought, Temperate, Frigid, and Polar. Three prediction schemes were analyzed to compare the performance of different models PBZTD, Informer-based ZTD, and LSTM-based ZTD), using data from 189 ZTD stations provided by the Nevada Geodetic Laboratory across five global climate types from 2012 to 2023. Additionally, the prediction results serve as external constraints in PPP to further evaluate the reliability of the proposed PBZTD model. The results reveal that ZTD prediction accuracy varies across different climate types, with the highest and lowest accuracy observed in polar and equatorial types, showing average RMSEs of 15.54 mm and 25.05 mm, respectively. The PBZTD outperforms IBZTD and LBZTD, with average accuracy improvements of 2.40% and 34.50%, respectively across five climate types. In addition, PBZTD demonstrates superior generalization ability, achieving improvements of 4.20% and 34.27% on 25 stations that were not involved in the model training. Moreover, the incorporation of PBZTD prediction results into PPP leads to faster convergence, achieving average improvements of 15.4%, 9.42%, and 26.51% in the E, N, and U directions, respectively.

title: A Causal Knowledge-Assisted Semi-Supervised Dynamical Generative Latent Variable Model for Industrial Quality Index Prediction
authors: Wenxue Han, Ze Tian, Weiming Shao, Junghui Chen
publish: IEEE Transactions on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics: Systems
abstract: Generative latent variable models (GLVMs) are prevalent in developing soft sensors for predicting industrial process quality indices owing to their exceptional capability in extracting features, reducing data dimensionality, and explaining data generation mechanisms. Dynamical GLVMs (DGLVMs) are able to effectively deal with the dynamical characteristics of industrial data changes over time, exhibiting prominence in time-series prediction and dynamical process modeling. However, the existing DGLVM-based soft sensors share an intrinsic imperfection that they focus on capturing the temporal correlations between variables while disregarding the causal relationships between variables. Based on industrial data, it is difficult to recover the causalities between variables from the correlations, resulting in compromised generalization performance of the existing DGLVM-based soft sensors. In light of this limitation, a novel causal knowledge-assisted semi-supervised DGLVM (CK-SsDGLVM) is proposed, and an ad hoc parameter learning method based on the expectation–maximization (EM) algorithm is developed to train the CK-SsDGLVM. The performance of the CK-SsDGLVM is comprehensively evaluated using an artificial numerical case and an actual industrial process. The experimental results demonstrate that the CK-SsDGLVM could achieve superior generalization accuracy and interpretability compared to benchmark models.

title: Measurement of Volumetric Current and Estimation of Non-linear Dielectric Impedance of LDPE
authors: C Iyyappan, Purnabhishek Muppala, C.C. Reddy
publish: IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
abstract: In Low-Density Polyethylene (LDPE) insulation, the non-linear nature of volumetric current - time characteristics were often attributed to its complex space charge dynamics, apart from temperature and electric field dependence. However, a scanty attention is given to the measurement related issues of volumetric current in the literature. In this paper, the authors have presented experiments conducted on measuring circuits used in electrometer as well as with the commercial electrometer, to investigate the measurement related aspects on the current characteristics of LDPE. Matching the time constants of measuring circuit impedance with the dielectric under test, would typically offset all the errors of the measurement. However, LDPE with the non-linear variation of its impedance characteristics, makes it difficult for accurate measurement, as it dynamically deviates from the fixed time constant of the measuring circuit impedance. Hence, the true volumetric current characteristics and a novel circuit model for the impedance of LDPE are proposed. Interestingly, they are observed to corroborate well with the Transient Space Charge Limited Current (TSLC) theory.

title: M3D: A Benchmark Dataset and Model for Microscopic 3D Shape Reconstruction_supp1-3646889.pdf
authors: Yuhua Qian
publish: N/A
abstract: Microscopic 3D shape reconstruction using depth from focus (DFF) is crucial in precision manufacturing for 3D modeling and quality control. However, the absence of high-precision microscopic DFF datasets and the significant differences between existing DFF datasets and microscopic DFF data in optical design, imaging principles and scene characteristics hinder the performance of current DFF models in microscopic tasks. To address this, we introduce M3D, a novel microscopic DFF dataset, constructed using a self-developed microscopic device. It includes multi-focus image sequences of 1,952 scenes across five categories, with depth labels obtained through the 3D TFT algorithm applied to dense image sequences for initial depth estimation and calibration. All labels are then compared and analyzed against the design values, and those with large errors are eliminated. We also propose M3DNet, a frequency-aware end-to-end network, to tackle challenges like shallow depth-of-field (DoF) and weak textures. Results show that M3D compensates for the limitations of macroscopic DFF datasets and extends DFF applications to microscopic scenarios. M3DNet effectively captures rapid focus decay and improves performance on public DFF datasets by leveraging superior global feature extraction. Additionally, it exhibits strong robustness even in extreme conditions. Dataset and code are available at https://github.com/jiangfeng-Z/M3D.

title: Cybersecurity of High-Altitude Platform Stations: Threat Taxonomy, Attacks and Defenses With Standards Mapping – DDoS Attack Use Case
authors: Chaouki Hjaiji, Bassem Ouni, Mohamed-Slim Alouini
publish: IEEE Open Journal of the Communications Society
abstract: High-Altitude Platform Stations (HAPS) are emerging stratospheric nodes within non-terrestrial networks. We provide a structured overview of HAPS subsystems and principal communication links, map cybersecurity and privacy exposure across communication, control, and power subsystems, and propose a stratosphere-aware threat taxonomy. The stratospheric operating regime imposes unique constraints–wide temperature cycling, radiation-induced soft errors, long-duration autonomy with intermittent backhaul, limited physical access, and heterogeneous RF/FSO links–that shape both the attack surface and the feasibility of defenses. We foreground these constraints to motivate design choices and scope realistic mitigations. We then discuss defenses feasible under HAPS constraints–including encryption and authentication, frequency agility, directional and beam-steered antennas, intrusion detection, secure boot, and software and supply-chain assurance–while highlighting how they align with emerging regulatory and standards guidance. Finally, we report a simulation-based case study using OMNeT++/INET to characterize distributed-denial-of-service (DDoS) impact on service-and control-plane availability, and summarize regulatory and standardization considerations relevant to deployment. We conclude with concrete future research directions. The study is simulation-grounded and intended to inform engineering trade-offs for real-world HAPS deployments rather than serve as an on-air validation.

title: A Learning Energy Management System for Fuel Cell Electric Buses Considering Passenger Flow Prediction and Speed Planning
authors: Huice Yang, Hong Chen, Bin Ma, Zhongchao Liang, Yunfeng Hu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Intelligent Transportation Systems
abstract: The energy management system (EMS) of fuel cell electric buses (FCEBs) significantly affects their operational costs, and its performance is closely related to driving speed. Passenger numbers impact the stop time between stations, providing foresight for speed planning. Additionally, maintaining a stable driving speed helps reduce overall energy consumption and power fluctuations, thus extending the lifespan of the fuel cell. Therefore, this paper proposes a learning-based EMS for FCEBs, which integrates speed planning that accounts for passenger flow prediction and speed stability, improving overall vehicle performance through optimized weight coefficients. The study consists of three main parts: 1) predicting passenger flow based on weather, temperature, time, and holidays, and estimating stop times; 2) planning speed with a focus on punctuality and passenger comfort, while minimizing red light waiting time to reduce frequent stop-start cycles; 3) performing multi-objective optimization weight learning, considering passenger flow prediction and speed planning. The planned speed curve is categorized into three driving modes: acceleration, steady-state, and deceleration. The weight coefficients are learned based on the power requirements in these modes, improving the overall system performance. Finally, simulations validate the effectiveness and advantages of the proposed algorithm in passenger flow prediction, punctuality, and EMS performance optimization. This approach significantly enhances passenger trust in public transportation while reducing bus operation costs.

title: Gold Nanoparticle Coating Reduces Acoustic Pressure Threshold for Perfluorohexane Nanodroplet Vaporization: Potential Mechanisms and Therapy Implications_supp1-3644373.pdf
authors: Karla P. Mercado-Shekhar
publish: N/A
abstract: Ultrasound-induced vaporization of perfluorocarbon (PFC) nanodroplets can be used for triggered drug delivery. Nanodroplets of perfluorobutane (PFB) and perfluoropentane (PFP) can vaporize spontaneously at physiological temperature, which can cause off-target effects. Using high-boiling-point PFCs, such as perfluorohexane (PFH), can overcome this limitation. However, PFH requires higher peak negative pressures for vaporization, making its in vivo use challenging. We investigated the feasibility of reducing the vaporization pressure threshold by gold-coating lipid-encapsulated PFH nanodroplets (Au-PFH-ND). We synthesized PFH nanodroplets, and the gold-coating was confirmed by UV-visible spectra. The mass of gold per nanodroplet was 5.12×10-4 pg. The size distribution peaked at 200 nm and had a mean concentration of 2×1010 droplets/ml. Au-PFH-ND demonstrated excellent stability over 8 weeks. Ultrasound imaging in vitro was used to determine the pressure threshold for nanodroplet vaporization upon exposure to 2 MHz ultrasound. The vaporization threshold for Au-PFH-ND (3.29 ± 0.93 MPa) was significantly lower than uncoated PFH nanodroplets (PFH-ND, 6.19 ± 1.25 MPa). Au-PFH-ND had a similar pressure threshold to uncoated PFP nanodroplets (PFP-ND, 2.81 ± 1.08 MPa). These findings show that the Au-PFH-ND can be vaporized at a similar ultrasound pressure as PFP-ND. Increasing pulse duration from 2 to 60 cycles enhanced vaporization of Au-PFH-ND, demonstrating the dominant role of a thermal mechanism. Even when accounting for the total ultrasound on-time and effective peak negative pressure, longer bursts (i.e., more cycles per burst) were more effective in inducing vaporization, consistent with the role of localized heating around the gold coating rather than a purely probabilistic effect. Additionally, inertial and stable cavitation emissions were quantified. Au-PFH-ND exhibited a marginally lower inertial cavitation threshold and similar second harmonic emissions than PFH-ND, suggesting that cavitation could also have played a role in reducing the pressure threshold. These findings are a step towards employing gold-coated PFC nanodroplets for multimodal drug delivery.
