title: Human Centric Private & Secure Onboarding for Network Applications in 6G
authors: Diogo E. J. Santos, Camila Fonseca, Vitor A. Cunha, João P. Barraca, Rui L. Aguiar
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on 6G Networking (6GNet)
abstract: In the 5G and emerging 6G networks, Network Applications (NAs) are critical to delivering diverse and innovative services. NAs are groups of Network Services (NSs) that provide functionalities for verticals. They have been pivotal in domains like enhanced Mobile Broadband (eMBB), Ultra Reliable Low Latency Communications (URLLC), and Internet of Everything (IoE), and their importance will only grow as we transition further into 6G. Therefore, understanding and addressing the challenges and opportunities posed by NAs are crucial as we advance towards 6G. This article proposes an approach for designing and onboarding secure and private NAs, ensuring their compliance with policies in closed loops (e.g., Security Orchestration, Automation, and Response (SOAR) loops). The introduced architecture leverages OpenSlice and incorporates best practices from DevOps with SecOps and PrivOps (DevPrivSecOps). These NAs are designed to be configurable both at the time of ordering and during runtime, with predefined characteristics that can be adjusted, for example, through Moving Target Defense (MTD) mechanisms. Furthermore, the definitions for privacy quantification services and their configuration are introduced to determine the privacy and risk scores of NAs, feeding the loop continuously. At a high level, security and privacy policies can be manually defined, or automatically generated in response to malicious attacks, and they can be dynamically translated and enforced within existing NAs. The early results show that the approach is sound, with promising results from the Proof of Concept (PoC) and custom-built tooling.

title: Space-Air-Ground Network for Direct-to-Cell Communication
authors: Abdullah Al Noman, Talip Tolga Sarı, Sunday Amatare, Gokhan Secinti, Debashri Roy
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: The growing demand for ubiquitous and resilient wireless connectivity, particularly in remote or disaster-stricken areas, highlights the limitations of traditional Direct-to-Cell (D2C) communication systems, which suffer from capacity bottlenecks, high propagation losses, and unreliable coverage. These challenges are critical barriers to achieving seamless global communication and supporting applications such as emergency response, smart infrastructure, and industrial automation, where robust connectivity directly impacts safety, operational efficiency, and societal resilience. To this end, we propose a UAV-enabled Space-Air-Ground Integrated Network (SAGIN) framework, in which UAVs operate as adaptive relays between low-earth-orbit satellites and user terminals. Our system leverages altitude-optimized UAV placement and environment-aware channel modeling, incorporating realistic ionospheric, atmospheric, multipath, and fading effects to dynamically mitigate propagation losses and optimize link reliability. We validate our approach using the NVIDIA Sionna simulator by conducting experiments across diverse environments and disaster-response scenarios. Our results demonstrate that the proposed SAGIN framework achieves a 91.7% improvement in downlink throughput compared to baseline D2C model, with a graceful degradation of 12ms end-to-end latency.

title: A 59.6GHz Broadband 3-stage Cascode LNA with Peak Detector for Bandwidth Self-healing
authors: Xinsheng Cheng, Jiacheng Guo, Juntao Liu, JingJing Lv, Yuan Du
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Integrated Circuits and Microsystems (ICICM)
abstract: This paper presents a 59.6 GHz, self-healing, 3-stage cascode low-noise amplifier (LNA) in 65 nm CMOS, using on-chip peak detection and calibration to measure and optimize its power gain (S21), input impedance (S11) and bandwidth. In the proposed LNA circuit, the utilization of the transformers and chokes within the cascode amplifier increase the gain and impedance match over a broad bandwidth. A bandwidth self-healing algorithm is implemented by varactors according output from peak detector. Measurement results show that after calibration, the LNA reaches S21 18.03 dB at 58.0 GHz and input match S11 better than 10 dB from 55.0 GHz to 67.2 GHz, with $11.2 \mathrm{GHz}-3 \mathrm{~dB}$ bandwidth from 54.4 GHz to 65.6 GHz.

title: IRS-enabled mmWave Signal Obfuscation for LEO Nanosatellites
authors: Fiona Tisdall, S. Johnson, M. Kasher, F. Dagefu, J. Choi, J. Kong, B. Kim, P. Spasojevic
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: In this paper, we investigate the link characteristics of an Intelligent Reflective Surface (IRS)-enabled signal obfuscation system at 28 GHz for Low Earth Orbit (LEO) nanosatellite applications. We aim to develop and evaluate a testbed for a covert communication stratagem in such LEO systems. The IRS in the proposed testbed facilitates obscuring signal leakage to an eavesdropper by properly designing its phase shifts, thereby establishing a low probability of interception (LPI) communication link between the legitimate transmitter and receiver.

title: Hardware Implementation and Side-Channel Security Analysis for High-Precision AI Tansformer Encoder
authors: Wentao Wang, Liji Wu, Jing Hu, Le Wu, Xiangmin Zhang
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Integrated Circuits and Microsystems (ICICM)
abstract: This paper provides a high-precision transformer encoder hardware by using fixed-point numbers with variable decimal places. The original power consumption trajectory of the feedforward neural network module was collected. It was found that there was an obvious power consumption peak in the output of this module. Therefore, we implemented the output obfuscation technology for this module and collected the protected power consumption trajectory. The verification is based on an FPGA development board xc7k160tfbg676-1 to design and verify the transformer encoder with a token of 64 and a word embedding dimension of 512. The verification results show that the usage of digital signal processing (DSP) is 552, and logic Look-Up Tables (LUT) is 96,043. In this experiment, the model’s data is quantized to 16-bit signed fixed-point numbers, with the number of decimal places varying according to different modules. A compensation coefficient is added to the matrix multiplication and a module design method of divide-and-add is adopted. The average error of the hardware implementation compared to software calculation is 0.000867, and the execution time at 200 MHz is 8.6837 ms, which is 1.657 times faster, saving approximately 39.7% of the execution time.

title: Securing High Mobility 6G Networks Using Shared Key-Based Physical Layer Security for OTFS
authors: Israt Ara, Brian Kelley
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: This paper presents a new class of Physical Layer Security (PLS) algorithms optimized for high-mobility in 6G networks. Fast-moving mobiles severely challenge the reliability and security of wireless networks. To ensure reliable and secure data transmission in high-mobility, the paper introduces a shared secret key PLS scheme that operates in Delay-Doppler domain. The scheme integrates shared key, precoding-based PLS and Orthogonal Time Frequency Space (OTFS) for robust shared secret key generation and secure data transmission at low-latency and high-mobility. This synergy represents a significant advancement for secure 6G Layer-1 communication and can overcome the long-standing limitations of prior PLS schemes sensitive to high-velocity environments. The paper formulates a shared key-based PLS for OTFS (SK-PLS-OTFS) framework, develops bit error rate (BER) models, simulates system performance under high-mobility versus signal-to-noise (SNR) conditions, and discusses latency and computational complexity of the model. The algorithm enables hyper reliable and low-latency communication (HRLLC) for emerging 6G use cases like high speed 6G-connected vehicles, unmanned aircraft systems (UAS), and low-earth orbiting (LEO) satellites. The results show resilient security performance even for extreme-velocities over 400 km/h and prove that the SK-PLS-OTFS model operates securely and reliably across a range of highly-mobile systems in terrestrial and non-terrestrial scenarios.

title: SemanticRF: Towards Robust RF Scene Retrieval Using Natural Language Supervision
authors: Trey Crump, Ali Maatouk, Kemal Davaslioglu, Sastry Kompella, Leandros Tassiulas
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: Recent advances in AI and machine learning have been driven by the emergence of foundation models, large pre-trained architectures capable of solving a wide range of downstream tasks with minimal task-specific tuning. These models, which learn unified representations from diverse, large-scale datasets, have transformed domains such as language, vision, and biology. However, RF signal processing systems have yet to fully benefit from this paradigm shift. Traditional approaches remain focused on closed-set, single-task objectives such as automatic modulation classification or emitter identification, limiting adaptability in dynamic scenarios that demand flexible, general-purpose reasoning across unseen waveforms and channel conditions. In this work, we introduce SemanticRF, a foundation model for RF scene analysis trained via multimodal contrastive learning to produce a unified signal-text embedding. Pretrained on a large-scale synthetic dataset spanning diverse modulation types, SNRs, and channel models, SemanticRF delivers strong performance on traditional RFML benchmarks but also demonstrates strong generalization to novel tasks such as RF scene tagging, highlighting a step towards adaptable foundation models in the RF domain.

title: Fast Frequency Stabilization Technique for Buck Converter Based on Adaptive PLL
authors: Kerun Li, Mei Jiang, Jianing Guo, Yuxuan Guo
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Integrated Circuits and Microsystems (ICICM)
abstract: This paper proposes a Buck converter that achieves frequency stability through an Adaptive Phase-Locked Loop (PLL) to address the issue of frequency instability in traditional Constant-On-Time (COT) architecture converters. The proposed solution employs a PLL feedback loop and an on-time generation module to compensate for input/output voltage variations, ensuring a stable switching frequency under changing load and input/output voltage conditions. To significantly enhance the frequency locking speed during the transition from light-load Discontinuous Conduction Mode (DCM) to heavy-load Continuous Conduction Mode (CCM), an adaptive frequency-following charge pump clamp circuit is designed. The Buck converter was simulated and verified using a $\mathbf{0. 1 8} \boldsymbol{\mu} \mathbf{m ~ B C D}$ process. Experimental results show that, with an input voltage of 12 V, an output voltage of 3.3 V, and a set frequency of 1 MHz, the use of the adaptive clamp circuit reduces the frequency locking time from $\mathbf{2 5 0} \mu$ s to $\mathbf{1 1 8} \mu$ s, representing a $\mathbf{5 2. 8 \%}$ improvement in locking speed. Additionally, within a load range of 0 to 5 A, the switching frequency variation rate is only $15 \mathrm{kHz} / \mathrm{A}$, effectively realizing the frequency locking function of the PLL.

title: MEMS-Enabled Computational Spectrometer Based on Cascaded Waveguide Couplers
authors: Hanxing Wang, Yan Liu, Nan Wang, Yiming Ma
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Integrated Circuits and Microsystems (ICICM)
abstract: In recent years, microspectrometers have been rapidly developed, driven by the growing demands for in-situ analysis and real-time monitoring. However, their performance is often constrained by size limitations. We propose and demonstrate a computational spectrometer based on cascaded waveguide couplers. The design of cascaded waveguide couplers not only enables more disordered interferograms but also exponentially increases the number of sampling channels, significantly enhancing the spectral resolution of the spectrometer. With a compact footprint of $\mathbf{1 0 0} \boldsymbol{\times} \mathbf{2 5 0 0} \boldsymbol{\mu} \mathbf{m}^{\mathbf{2}}$, the spectrometer achieves a spectral resolution of 40 pm in the wavelength range of 1.5-1.51 $\mu \mathrm{m}$.

title: Hybrid Knowledge Graph Integration in Large Language Models for Explainable Contextual Understanding and Improved Accuracy
authors: G Venkata Krishna, D Arthur Jebastine Sunderraj, Finito Deagesh D, Udaya Kiran M, V T Ram Pavan Kumar M, V MNSSVKR Gupta
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: The study investigated the application of Hybrid Knowledge Graphs (HKGs) to Large Language Models (LLMs) to improve contextual understanding, semantic accuracy, and interpretability. Although LLMs such as GPT and BERT can be quite strong language generators, they tend to fail and have problems in factual reasoning, entity disambiguation, and multi-hop inference because they have very weak structured knowledge. To overcome these shortcomings, a hybrid architecture was developed combining structured knowledge of Knowledge Graphs with transformer based Embeddings of LLM using embedding alignment, contextual fusion and attention-based reasoning. Several benchmark datasets, quantitative metrics, such as, perplexity, contextual coherence, semantic similarity, and reasoning accuracy, and visual analyses, such as, accuracy trends, confusion matrices, and embedding projections, were used to evaluate the model. The findings showed that the hybrid model was much more effective at contextual understanding, semantic ambiguity, and reasoning interpretability than the base LLMs. The results show that Knowledge Graph integration is semantically grounded, can enhance representational consistency, and can support human-like reasoning, which can be used to present a strong framework of explainable and context-aware AI systems.

title: Empirical Studies of the Aviris Hyperspectral Data Signatures of Different Earth Terrains
authors: Emraul Islam Emon, Afia Mubassira Islam, Christopher Ball, Joel T. Johnson, Vasit Sagan
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Hyperspectral images and optical signatures acquired by NASA's Airborne Visible/Infrared Imaging Spectrometer (AVIRIS) from multiple locations are examined. The spectral responses obtained are used to promote the development of physics-based models for these signatures with future application in improvements in hyperspectral sensing.

title: TRACER: Threat Resilience Assessment for Cyber Evaluation Readiness
authors: Tommy Chin, Samuel Best, Noah Korzak, Kun Sun
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: As adversaries increasingly blend complex cyber and physical attacks, traditional vulnerability management approaches fall short in assessing the resiliency of an organization. Scoring solutions, such as the Common Vulnerability Scoring System (CVSS), often fail to account for the contextual awareness of an environment, including system configurations, interconnected dependencies, and physical access risks, leading to suboptimal remediation strategies. In this paper, we present TRACER (Threat Resilience Assessment for Cyber Evaluation Readiness), a new framework that quantifies a resiliency score against Advanced Persistent Threats (APTs) by integrating cyber vulnerabilities and physical risk into a unified, graph-based model. Our approach dynamically evaluates the ratio of vulnerable paths to the total number of paths in an environment across cyber and physical domains. The results of our work demonstrate the adaptability of TRACER throughout environmental changes, and our graph-based model provides remediation strategies through software patching and strengthened physical security to improve the resiliency of an environment against APTs.

title: DoA of Multiple Sources with an Array of Passive Tags instead of an Antenna Array
authors: Anastasios Kleniatis, Georgios Andreadis, Omikumar B. Makadia, Georgios Vougioukas, Ivan Seskar, Narayan Mandayam, Rich Howard, Aggelos Bletsas
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: As wireless systems grow smarter and denser, the ability to pinpoint signal sources quickly and efficiently is more critical than ever. This work introduces a novel approach to direction-of-arrival (DoA) estimation that trades power-demanding antenna arrays for simple, passive backscatter radio tags. Not only it extends passive DoA techniques to handle multiple signal sources, but also leverages randomized tag topologies to enhance robustness. These randomized configurations are especially well suited to environments with synchronization mismatch, turning potential limitations into advantages. Significant gains in accuracy and scalability are demonstrated through simulations and Cramér-Rao Bound analysis, paving the way for energy-efficient, spectrum-aware systems.

title: On the Noise Robustness of Affine Frequency Division Multiplexing: Analysis and Applications
authors: Vincent Savaux, Steve Sawadogo, Hyeon Seok Rou, Giuseppe Thadeu Freitas de Abreu
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on 6G Networking (6GNet)
abstract: This paper investigates the robustness of affine frequency division multiplexing (AFDM) and orthogonal time frequency space (OTFS) modulation schemes against non-white Gaussian noise, which can model various sources of additive disturbances to the received signal. The proposed approach demonstrates that the performance of these waveforms depends on the ability of the demodulation matrix to whiten the noise–a property that is, in turn, related to the sparsity of the matrix. AFDM is shown to outperform OTFS and orthogonal frequency division multiplexing (OFDM), as its demodulation matrix is generally less sparse than those of the other waveforms. Based on this analysis, several application examples and use cases are presented, such as the use of AFDM and OTFS in narrowband signals or in coexistence with OFDM signals. Finally, simulation results confirm that AFDM achieves better performance than OTFS and OFDM in the presence of non-white noise, with gains exceeding 1 dB in most application scenarios.

title: An Integrated Framework for Digital Forensics: Linking Email, URL, and Network Analysis for Cyber Investigations using Artificial Intelligence
authors: Apoorva K A, S. Sangeetha
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: As the cyber threats increase in complexity and frequency, the defect reactive and rule-based approaches have given insufficient results for securing the crucial digital infrastructures. The experts provide a detailed review of the Artificial Intelligence (AI)-based forensic devices developed to improve the real-time threat mitigation and anomaly identification across various cybersecurity environments. The research starts by assessing the wide region of cybersecurity, highlighting the requirement for adaptive learning, continuous monitoring and scalable defense models regardless of insider threats, zero-day exploits and polymorphic attacks. Further, it narrows the concentration to the integration of AI in digital forensics, where deep learning techniques are leveraged to categorize the anomalous behavior, recognize intrusion patterns and predict future attack factors. This work presents a digital forensic investigation approach that has evolved into a multifaceted discipline, requiring the integration of diverse analytical methods to effectively investigate cyber incidents. This is a unified analytical framework that holistically analyzes digital assets by integrating three distinct investigation domains, such as email author attribution with email body contextual analysis, Uniform Resource Locator (URL) classification, and network traffic analysis. The framework is designed as a sequential pipeline, dynamically interconnected, with each stage enhancing the subsequent one through feedback loops and behavioral correlation. In the first stage, the email author attribution for forensic purposes is done using a Deep Neural Network (DNN) and model-based clustering, and then the contextual forensic analysis of emails based on the email body is done using the Density-Based Spatial Clustering of Applications with Noise (DBSCAN) algorithm. Emails with suspicious links initiate the second stage of the process, where the URL classification is carried out using the Light Gradient Boosting (LGB), which effectively detects the malicious activities through this classified URL. Detected malicious URLs inform and direct the targeted monitoring during the third stage, where the network traffic is examined. In this stage, intrusion detection and network packet classification are executed using a Coordinate Attention-based Gated Recurrent Unit (CA-GRU) model, allowing for robust intrusion detection in modern, privacy-preserving communication systems. The developed framework is adaptable, evolving with emerging threats and scalable for diverse use cases, making it an essential tool for both small-scale and enterprise-level forensic investigations. Finally, experimental validation is done to ensure the effectiveness of the developed model in cyber investigations.

title: Resource Allocation for XR with Edge Offloading: A Reinforcement Learning Approach
authors: Alperen Duru, Mohammad Mozaffari, Ticao Zhang, Mehrnaz Afshang
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: Future immersive XR applications will require energy-efficient, high data rate, and low-latency wireless communications in uplink and downlink. One of the key considerations for supporting such XR applications is intelligent and adaptive resource allocation with edge offloading. To address these demands, this paper proposes a reinforcement learning-based resource allocation framework that dynamically allocates uplink and downlink slots while making offloading decisions based on the XR headset’s capabilities and network conditions. The paper presents a numerical analysis of the tradeoff between frame loss rate (FLR) and energy efficiency, identifying decision regions for partial offloading to optimize performance. Results show that for the used set of system parameters, partial offloading can extend the coverage area by 55% and reduce energy consumption by up to 34%, compared to always or never offloading. The results demonstrate that the headset’s local computing capability plays a crucial role in offloading decisions. Higher computing abilities enable more efficient local processing, reduce the need for offloading, and enhance energy savings.

title: Enabling Trustworthy Federated Learning via Remote Attestation for Mitigating Byzantine Threats
authors: Chaoyu Zhang, Heng Jin, Shanghao Shi, Hexuan Yu, Sydney Johns, Y. Thomas Hou, Wenjing Lou
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: Federated Learning (FL) has gained significant attention for its privacy-preserving capabilities, enabling distributed devices to collaboratively train a global model without sharing raw data. However, its distributed nature forces the central server to blindly trust the local training process and aggregate uncertain model updates, making it susceptible to Byzantine attacks from malicious participants, especially in mission-critical scenarios. Detecting such attacks is challenging due to the diverse knowledge across clients, where variations in model updates may stem from benign factors, such as non-IID data, rather than adversarial behavior. Existing data-driven defenses struggle to distinguish malicious updates from natural variations, leading to high false positive rates and poor filtering performance.To address this challenge, we propose Sentinel, a remote attestation (RA)-based scheme for FL systems that regains client-side transparency and mitigates Byzantine attacks from a system security perspective. Our system employs code instrumentation to track control-flow and monitor critical variables in the local training process. Additionally, we utilize a trusted training recorder within a Trusted Execution Environment (TEE) to generate an attestation report, which is cryptographically signed and securely transmitted to the server. Upon verification, the server ensures that legitimate client training processes remain free from program behavior violation or data manipulation, allowing only trusted model updates to be aggregated into the global model. Experimental results on IoT devices demonstrate that Sentinel ensures the trustworthiness of the local training integrity with low runtime and memory overhead.

title: A Low-Cost IoT-Enabled Automatic Side Stand System for Enhancing Bike Rider Safety
authors: Venkateswara Rao Ch, Kishore J, Yadla Sai Prasanna, S V Kiranmayi Sridhara, Eswara Prasad Konakalla, G Nagaraju
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: In India, two-wheelers are the most widely used mode of transportation. With the rapid increase in population, the number of two-wheelers on the road has also grown significantly. However, the safety measures available for two-wheelers are comparatively limited when compared to four-wheelers, which are equipped with advanced protection systems such as airbags. For most two-wheeler riders, the primary safety measures are wearing a helmet and using GPS for tracking. One major safety concern in two-wheelers is the side stand issue. If a rider forgets to retract the side stand before riding, it can lead to loss of balance during turning and may result in serious accidents. In recent years (especially in BS6 model vehicles), manufacturers have started providing built-in side stand indicators or side stand engine cut-off systems to prevent such accidents. However, a large number of two-wheelers manufactured before the Bharath stage 6 (BS6) era do not include any side stand safety mechanism. Statistics show that: About 95% of two-wheelers manufactured before 2000 lack a side stand safety system. Around 70% of two-wheelers produced between 2000–2015 do not have this feature. Even among recent models, 10–15% of vehicles manufactured between 2018–2020 still lack a proper side stand safety system. These figures highlight the need for additional safety solutions, especially for the large number of older vehicles still in use. To address this issue, this work proposes an IoT-based low-cost automatic side stand safety system that can be easily installed on existing bikes. The system is integrated with the ignition mechanism, ensuring that the bike will not start unless the side stand is fully retracted, thereby preventing accidents caused by riding with the side stand down. The overall implementation cost is estimated to be around Rs. 2000 to 2500 when the system is integrated into the bike.

title: Secrecy through Precoding: a Novel Physical Layer Encryption Scheme with Optimal PAPR
authors: Clément Leroy, Tarak Arbi, Oudomsack Pierre Pasquero, Benoit Geller
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: Traditional cryptographic methods ensure data confidentiality through sophisticated and complex key management and encryption protocols. However, such approaches may be ill-suited for scenarios with limited coordination capabilities, such as military communications or the Internet of Things (IoT); Physical Layer Encryption (PLE) then offers a complementary or alternative solution by securing information directly at the signal level. Among existing PLE techniques, masking strategies have shown considerable promise. Nonetheless, many of these techniques suffer from drawbacks such as high Peak-To-Average Power Ratio (PAPR), rely on the eavesdropper’s channel knowledge, or lack of adaptability to diverse wireless environments. In this paper, we propose a novel PLE technique that overcomes these limitations. Our approach achieves optimal PAPR by design, requires no knowledge of the eavesdropper’s channel state information, and is applicable to all flat fading channels. Additionally, the method incorporates continuous randomization in signal generation, enhancing resistance to brute-force attacks. These features collectively make our solution a robust and practical candidate for secure wireless communication at the physical layer. Extensive simulations confirm the effectiveness and reliability of the proposed approach under various channel conditions.

title: AI-based Meeting Notes Generator using Whisper and BERT
authors: Kamalesh S, Manojkumar S, Kavinesh K K
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: In a workplace environment where documenting meetings has become a requirement to complete work and track decisions, we present the intelligent system, Audio's AI Meeting Notes Generator, which enables users to automatically transcript and summarize recorded meetings, capturing important discussion points, conclusions and action points, as raw audio data requiring processing by transformer-based models. The audio notes generation combines OpenAI's Whisper API to provide speech-to-text transcription accuracy with BERT for the natural language decoder to unfold natural language. An interactive web-based front end allowing the user to upload recorded meetings and see their meeting minutes organized in real time is built around the main component React.js. The backend, which can be built in Python using Flask or FastAPI, can focus on integrating AI and managing workflows, and interfacing with databases (PostgreSQL or MongoDB) handling the end-state data. This system always "Win's" determination no lost important data, plus provides a productive time-saver, while significantly reducing manual labour.

title: A Survey of Forecasting Methods for Irregular Time Series
authors: Xuanying Li, Sha Xiang, Cheng Dai
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conferences on Internet of Things (iThings) IEEE Green Computing &amp; Communications (GreenCom) IEEE Cyber, Physical &amp; Social Computing (CPSCom) and IEEE Smart Data (SmartData) and IEEE Congress on Cybermatics (Cybermatics)
abstract: Irregular time series (ITS) data are widespread across healthcare, finance, and the Internet of Things (IoT), where accurate forecasting is crucial for applications such as disease progression prediction, risk assessment, and system maintenance. However, handling irregular time series presents unique technical challenges. The core issues lie in effectively modeling the unequal time intervals, capturing long-term dependencies, and handling asynchronous observations among multiple variables. This survey systematically reviews and critically evaluates existing methods for forecasting irregular time series. We primarily focus on cutting-edge deep sequential modeling approaches, which have demonstrated superior performance and innovative solutions to these challenges. We propose a clear classification framework that categorizes current approaches into two main groups: traditional statistical and machine learning methods and deep sequential modeling methods. We further detail deep learning approaches by their architectural paradigms, specifically RNN-based, Transformer-based, and Graph Neural Networks (GNN)-based models. For each category, this paper elaborates on representative models, providing an in-depth analysis of their core principles, technological evolution, and respective advantages and disadvantages. Furthermore, we discuss the major challenges in this research area and outline promising future research directions. This work aims to provide a comprehensive perspective for researchers in the field and to inspire future research efforts.

title: IoT Integrated Smart Medication System using Machine Learning for Enhanced Rural Healthcare
authors: Jasmine Selvakumari Jeya I, Nikhil Appasaheb More, Brishab Das, Raunak Gupta, Vivek Kumar Mishra, Aldrin Joan Pandian W
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: The adoption of Machine Learning (ML) technologies in healthcare has substantially improved automation, diagnostic accuracy, and operational efficiency. This study proposes an ML-driven medication dispensing system aimed at enhancing accessibility, safety, and reliability in pharmaceutical distribution. The system integrates an ML model to recommend medications based on patient symptoms, thereby supporting clinical decision-making and reducing prescription-related errors. With IoT connectivity and data analytics, it enables real-time inventory monitoring and optimized medication management, making it suitable for diverse healthcare settings, including urban and rural regions. By providing round-the-clock automated dispensing, the system overcomes limitations of conventional pharmacy models, decreases reliance on human intervention, and minimizes potential dispensing inaccuracies. Furthermore, the embedded ML model can predict drug interactions and suggest safer therapeutic alternatives, contributing to improved patient safety and treatment effectiveness. This innovation has the potential to strengthen healthcare delivery in remote and underserved communities by ensuring timely access to essential medicines. Overall, the integration of intelligent automation and advanced analytics establishes a scalable foundation for a more efficient, connected, and patient-centered healthcare infrastructure.

title: Design and Analysis of AC/DC Converter for GaNBased Server Power Supply System
authors: Fen Guo, Tuo Li, Changhong Wang, Kang Su, Jiankai Xu, Xin Xi, Kejian Zhu, Xinxin Yuan
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Integrated Circuits and Microsystems (ICICM)
abstract: This paper presents a GaN HEMT-based AC/DC converter for server power supplies, addressing the need for high efficiency, high power density, and improved reliability in cloud and data center applications. An AIGaN/GaN HEMT structure with an InGaN back-barrier layer is designed and optimized. Its electrical characteristics are verified via simulation. A two-stage topology is adopted for the converter, comprising an interleaved totem-pole PFC (Power Factor Correction) and an LLC resonant converter. The operating principle of this topology is analyzed in detail, and the key circuit parameters are carefully designed. Under 220 V AC input, the converter achieves a rated output power of 2400 W, a DC bus voltage of $400 \mathrm{~V} \pm 5 \%$, a peak efficiency of 97.03%, and a power factor (PF) of $\geqslant 0.999$. All these performance metrics fully meet the requirements of highend server power supplies, which demonstrates that GaN technology possesses the capability to overcome the inherent efficiency-density trade-off in traditional power supply designs.

title: Detecting Airborne Objects with 5G NR Radars
authors: Steve Blandino, Nada Golmie, Anirudha Sahoo, Thao Nguyen, Tanguy Ropitault, David Griffith, Amala Sonny
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: The integration of sensing capabilities into 5G New Radio (5GNR) networks offers an opportunity to enable the detection of airborne objects without the need for dedicated radars. This paper investigates the feasibility of using standardized Positioning Reference Signals (PRS) to detect UAVs in Urban Micro (UMi) and Urban Macro (UMa) propagation environments. A full 5GNR radar processing chain is implemented, including clutter suppression, angle and range estimation, and 3D position reconstruction. Simulation results show that performance strongly depends on the propagation environment. 5GNR radars exhibits the highest missed detection rate, up to 16%, in UMi, due to severe clutter. Positioning error increases with target distance, resulting in larger errors in UMa scenarios and at higher UAV altitudes. In particular, the system achieves a position error within 4m in the UMi environment and within 8m in UMa. The simulation platform has been released as open-source software to support reproducible research in integrated sensing and communication (ISAC) systems.

title: A Demonstration of Self-Adaptive Jamming Attack Detection in AI/ML Integrated O-RAN
authors: Md Habibur Rahman, Md Sharif Hossen, Nathan H. Stephenson, Vijay K. Shah, Aloizio Da Silva
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: The open radio access network (O-RAN) enables modular, intelligent, and programmable 5G network architectures through the adoption of software-defined networking, network function virtualization, and implementation of standardized open interfaces. However, one of the security concerns for O-RAN, which can severely undermine network performance, is jamming attacks. This paper presents SAJD – a self-adaptive jammer detection framework that autonomously detects jamming attacks in AI/ML framework-integrated ORAN environments without human intervention. The SAJD framework forms a closed-loop system that includes near-real-time inference of radio signal jamming via our developed ML-based xApp, as well as continuous monitoring and retraining pipelines through rApps. In this demonstration, we will show how SAJD outperforms state-of-the-art jamming detection xApp (offline trained with manual labels) in terms of accuracy and adaptability under various dynamic and previously unseen interference scenarios in the O-RAN-compliant testbed.

title: Low-Probability of Detection Communications Using Chiral Solutions
authors: R. McKee, D. Barber, C. Nelson, C. Smith
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: Covert battlefield communication is crucial for modern military operations, yet traditional radio frequency methods are easily susceptible to detection. This paper investigates a novel approach for low-probability of detection (LPD) communication by embedding data in the polarization of light using a chiral fluid. We demonstrate that varying the path length of light through a chiral fluid allows for controlled rotation of the light’s polarization based on specific rotation principles. This rotation can be detected as changes in received intensity when using linear polarizers, as predicted by Malus’ Law, or as subtle shifts in color when employing a white light source and a commodity digital camera with a polarizing filter. Modulating the fluid level allows for the encoding of rudimentary bit patterns. Additionally, utilizing a generic white LED as the light source with polarizers, discernible color shifts were observed with changes in the sucrose solution’s path length, offering an alternative data encoding method. This technique holds promise for field-expedient LPD communication, potentially leveraging readily available light sources and cameras. An illustrative demonstration was conducted using an LED lamp, soda, and cell phone sending data symbols 15 m between adjacent rooms. In this experiment, it was seen that color shift caused by the chiral fluid, as received by a commodity CMOS sensor, was even more robust than measuring intensity alone.

title: A GAE-Based Link Prediction Model for IoT Applications at the Edge
authors: Xuri Huang, Min He, Bolong Sun, Liang Lv
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conferences on Internet of Things (iThings) IEEE Green Computing &amp; Communications (GreenCom) IEEE Cyber, Physical &amp; Social Computing (CPSCom) and IEEE Smart Data (SmartData) and IEEE Congress on Cybermatics (Cybermatics)
abstract: With the advancement of artificial intelligence and edge intelligence, link prediction technology can provide more robust support and optimization in edge intelligence, thereby enhancing the performance of real-world applications and reduce the costs. However, traditional link prediction models often focus on learning general embedding features of nodes while neglecting the direction of the links. Therefore, based on graph autoencoder (GAE), a link prediction model using graph representation called DGAAE, is proposed to estimate the communication connectivity requirements for the devices in Internet of Things (IoT). Firstly, two encoders are employed to encode directions of links as one of the features so as to embed source and target nodes and acquire the representation for link tendencies. Secondly, a dot-product attention is introduced during the encoding process to capture the structure information to improve the accuracy. Experiments demonstrate that DGAAE outperforms baseline methods in link prediction tasks on the IoT dataset of INT and other real datasets, which contributes to reducing the computation and routing costs for IoT applications, such as intelligent transportation and routing networks, by improving the prediction accuracy at the edge.

title: Smart Curriculum Mapping through AR/VR: Integrating Student Behaviour Analytics with Adaptive Learning Pathway
authors: Akash R S, Harish M, S Rajesh Kannan
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: Traditional education faces challenges while providing personalized learning experiences tailored to individual cognitive and engagement behaviors, eventually causing reduced student motivation and insufficient knowledge retention. This work addresses this challenge by suggesting an AI-powered Smart Curriculum Mapping system based on integrating AR/VR immersive learning environments with state-of-the-art student behavior analytics. The system collects multimodal information such as gaze movements, gesture, interaction measures, and performance records and utilizes Deep Belief Networks (DBNs) to extract latent cognitive and engagement features from it. These eventually feed into a Deep Q-Network (DQN) based reinforcement learning engine to dynamically optimize learning paths through selection of content modules, interaction modes, and difficulty levels in real time. Adaptive high-fidelity AR/VR interfaces are engineered to change experiential scenarios adaptively to improve engagement and comprehension. Teachers leverage an AI-powered dashboard to observe predictive engagement, cognitive overload, and knowledge retention. The novelty lies in interconnecting DBN-based feature modeling and DQN-based adaptive policy learning with immersive AR/VR technology to achieve highly personalized data-driven education with optimized academic performance and metacognitive development.

title: A Game-Theoretic Approach for Mitigating Distributed Reflection DoS Using SDN-Based Temporal Flows Rules
authors: Vianney Kengne Tchendji, Tangyie Shulem Yaweni, Mthulisi Velempini
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: Distributed reflection Denial-of-Service (DrDoS) is a DDoS attack that exploits the vulnerability of several protocols, such as the Domain Name System (DNS), to amplify the traffic sent to the victim, generally in response to a legitimate request. These attacks can cause severe damage to the availability and performance of the target network or service. In this paper, we propose a Software-Defined Network (SDN) architecture to mitigate DrDoS attacks, exemplifying with DNS reflection attacks. Our approach leverages SDN’s centralized control and programmability to dynamically monitor and create flow rules to manage the traffic in the network, allowing response traffic for a specified time slot for a prior request. We use game theory to analyze the effectiveness and efficiency of the proposed solution and optimize its performance in attack mitigation. We show that the proposed approach can reduce the impact of the attack and increase the cost for the attacker while minimizing the overhead for the defender over time.

title: A SiC Power Module Package Based on the Dual-side Cooling with Highly Thermally Conductive Graphite-Molybdenum Spacer
authors: Yucheng Xu, Jiafei Yao, Yuxuan Dai, Ziwei Hu, Fan Yang, Kemeng Yang, Binbin Xu, Zhikuang Cai, Yufeng Guo
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Integrated Circuits and Microsystems (ICICM)
abstract: To address the issue of excessive temperature in SiC power module, this work proposes a dual-side cooling (DSC) package structure with highly thermally conductive graphitemolybdenum spacer. The main feature is the high heat dissipation around the spacers by utilizing the high thermal conductivity of graphite, thereby improving the overall thermal reliability of the structure. The package structure is modeled and simulated in ANSYS based on the finite element analysis. The influences of graphite thickness on the thermal resistance and junction temperature are discussed. The results demonstrate that the optimization effect of thermal reliability will gradually decrease. When compared to conventional DSC package structure, the proposed graphite-molybdenum enhanced DSC package structure enables a 21.6% reduction of the junction temperature and a 31.5% reduction of the thermal resistance. Consequently, the thermal reliability of the SiC power module has been improved.

title: Real-Time Stroke Monitoring IoT System using Federated Learning
authors: Prisilla N, N. Gomathi
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: Stroke, still a leading cause of death and long-term disability globally, is a particularly useful case in highlighting the limitations of traditional medical approaches to brain imaging-based diagnosis in ambiguity and revertability, at least in the pre-hospital or remotely available setting. To address these limitations, a novel IoT integrated federated deep learning framework for real time stroke monitoring and detection is proposed in this study. The system detects a stroke-related facial palsy to high diagnostic accuracy with minimal and unobtrusive human intervention through automatic recognition using YOLOv8. Federated Learning (FL), a method that ensures that data privacy is preserved while performance and generalization remain unaffected, is adopted to ensure that the models are trained in a decentralized manner across the healthcare nodes that are connected to the Internet of Things (IoT). The framework, which is realized on Nvidia GPU-accelerated platforms, offers the fast computation and real-time responsiveness which are essential in emergency situations. Aided stroke detection, privacy-preserving distributed learning, continuous Internet of Things (IoT) monitoring and scalable low latency deployment represent selected major contributions. The proposed system will be a next-generation privacy-integrated diagnostic system that has higher accuracy and enhances data security and faster medical responses through combining FL, IoT sensing and AI-based analytics. Armed with intelligent tools, VETNHA creates effective real-time decision support for doctors to reach patients at the optimal time, significantly improving patient outcomes and reducing the prevalence of neurological disorders across the globe.

title: A Reliable 512-kb HZO-based 2T2C FeRAM Array with Capacitor under Bitline
authors: Jing Wang, Xiangyin Chen, Zhongguang Xu
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Integrated Circuits and Microsystems (ICICM)
abstract: This work highlights the excellent remnant polarization of Hf<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">0.5</inf> Zr<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">0.5</inf> O<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf> (HZO)-based ferroelectric capacitors fabricated in a capacitor-under-bitline (CUB) configuration. Owing to the CUB architecture, the metal/ferroelectric/metal (MFM) capacitors are formed prior to the back-end-of-line (BEOL) process, enabling post-metallization annealing (PMA) at temperatures above $500{ }^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$. The resulting structure exhibits outstanding performance, including remnant polarization (2Pr) > $30 \mu \mathrm{C} / \mathrm{cm}^{2}$ and endurance greater than $10^{11}$ cycles. In addition, based on this CUB ferroelectric capacitor structure, a 512 kb memory array using a two-transistor two-capacitor (2T2C) architecture was fabricated. The chip integrates dedicated peripheral circuits such as address decoders, a charge pump (CP), and a sense amplifier (SA), demonstrating high reliability in experimental evaluation.

title: Optimized Traffic Management using LoRa–based Vehicle-to-Vehicle Communication Framework for Emergency Vehicle Routing in Smart Cities
authors: Abishek B, Dineshkumar J, Arshitha S, Deepika N, G.Subramaniam.M.E., A.Durai Murugan.M.E.
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: Road collisions have continued to be among the leading causes of loss of life in the world especially because of the slow response to the emergency as well as ineffective traffic control. The present paper presents an automated traffic control system with LoRa-powered Vehicle-to-Vehicle (V2V) communication to make the process of ambulance navigation and emergency response faster and more efficient in smart cities. The suggested system consists of IoT sensors, PIC microcontroller, and GPS to detect accidents and accurately determine positioning. When an accident is located, the system will automatically dispatch an ambulance by use of a GSM/IoT interface and send the benefit of the incident to nearby hospitals using LoRa technology. Simultaneously, a monitoring unit which can be an ambulance is installed with biomedical sensors that can read vital parameters like heart rate, blood pressure and temperature and post them on the Thing Speak Cloud so that medical personnel can monitor the patient live. The LoRa-based coordination with the traffic lights dynamically clears the road by the emergency vehicles reducing the time it spends on traveling. Experimental analysis demonstrates that the system can greatly decrease response time, improve communication between the emergency stakeholders, and increase the rate of patient survival. The suggested integrated IoT/ Lorca communication system is a low-power, scalable and cost-effective model that can be used in implementing smart transportation and health care infrastructure within urban contexts.

title: Demonstration of Terahertz Backhaul with 0.28 Tbps-km Capacity-Distance Product
authors: John F. O’Hara, Ethan Abele, Russ Messenger, G. Levi Captain, Karl Strecker, Forrest Tuschhoff, Rajind Mendis
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: To maximize their utility, terahertz wireless backhaul systems should be proven feasible over numerous kilometer distances while maintaining high data rate in suboptimal channel conditions. The combination of long distance and ultrabroadband operation introduces difficult practical challenges, however these can be overcome, mostly with very accessible, commercial (COTS) equipment. We report updates on the performance of our terahertz wireless communication link operating at 130 GHz, which now achieves a bit rate of 49.15 gigabit-per-second (Gbps) over 5.7 km for a capacity-distance product of 0.28 Tbps-km. We consider the technical details of the system, compare it to others, and extrapolate its performance in different environmental conditions.

title: Enhancing WSN Coverage and Connectivity Under Electromagnetic Interference via an Improved Hybrid PSOGWO Algorithm
authors: Xiuchen Guo, Jiaoyan Chen
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conferences on Internet of Things (iThings) IEEE Green Computing &amp; Communications (GreenCom) IEEE Cyber, Physical &amp; Social Computing (CPSCom) and IEEE Smart Data (SmartData) and IEEE Congress on Cybermatics (Cybermatics)
abstract: Coverage and connectivity are fundamental performance metrics for sensor node deployment in Wireless Sensor Network (WSN), which are critical for continuous environmental monitoring. However, the common practice of consolidating them into a single objective function can limit performance in complex electromagnetic environments. To overcome this limitation, this paper introduces a novel fitness evaluation function that jointly optimizes network coverage and Node Data Reachability (NDR). An improved hybrid PSOGWO (IPSOGWO) algorithm is thus proposed for sensor node redeployment. Experimental evaluations with 300 nodes show that our IPSOGWO achieves performance gains of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$3.9 \%, 5.2 \%$</tex>, and 8.9 % over the SSA, FOA, and ABC algorithms, respectively, confirming its superiority over several state-of-the-art counterparts.

title: SPEAK: a Secure PUF-Enabled Authentication and Key-Exchange Protocol for IoT Devices
authors: Ian Donovan, Tarek Idriss
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: The Internet of Things (IoT) faces myriad threats, serves countless users, and is largely populated by computationally constrained devices that necessitate lightweight security solutions. Physically Unclonable Functions (PUFs) offer a promising security primitive that requires minimal computation overhead, consumes little power, and naturally resists physical tampering. In this work, we introduce SPEAK (Secure PUF-Enabled Authentication and Key-Exchange), a novel protocol leveraging TRNG-powered random obfuscation and physically unclonable functions (PUFs) to achieve efficient key exchange and built-in authentication without the need for conventional encryption or hashing. We detail the implementation of SPEAK on an ESP32-C3 microcontroller, utilizing a 128-bit XOR-2 MemPUF, and evaluate its practical deployment over MQTT. Our security analysis demonstrates SPEAK’s resilience against a range of attack vectors, including replay attacks, man-in-the-middle (MITM) attacks, and denial of service attacks. Furthermore, we conduct extensive machine learning-based modeling attacks, including those employing CMA-ES metaheuristics, and show that SPEAK maintains robust security against such adversaries. Experimental results reveal that SPEAK achieves significantly lower latency and improved throughput compared to SSL/TLS-based solutions, while remaining well-suited for ultra-lightweight IoT endpoints. These findings position SPEAK as a practical and scalable protocol for secure communication in next-generation IoT environments.

title:
A 1.7-to-3.0 GHz 201.95 dBc/Hz FOM
                    <sub>T</sub>
                    VCO With a Current-Reuse Active Inductor
authors: Xinyi Zhang, Wanqing Wu, Guoxun Dai, Jiangnan Li, Haigang Feng
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Integrated Circuits and Microsystems (ICICM)
abstract: In this paper, we propose a voltage-controlled oscillator (VCO) using a new active inductor (AI) to realize the common-mode resonance inductor. Compared with the classic VCO using a passive inductor, the proposed AI greatly reduces the chip area and improves the figure of merit (FOM) across the full frequency band by utilizing a feedback resistor. The AI is designed using only MOSFETs, and high tunability is achieved by varying bias voltages, which enables accurate common-mode resonance. Designed in 65 nm process, the proposed VCO operates from $1.7 \mathrm{GHz}-3 \mathrm{GHz}$ with 55.3% tuning range (TR). While operating at 1.7 GHz, the VCO achieves a phase noise (PN) of $-131.7 \mathrm{dBc} / \mathrm{Hz}$ at 1 MHz offset under 1.2 V supply voltage and consumes 8.1 mW for a FOM of $\mathbf{1 8 7. 1 d B c / H z}$.

title: Decentralised Blogging Platform using Blockchain
authors: Sangita Lade, Muhammad Parkar, Shreyas Nagarkar, Om Shintre, Shivam Padalkar
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: This paper focuses on the design and development of a decentralized blogging platform aimed at overcoming the limitations of existing centralized content publishing systems through the use of blockchain technology. Most mainstream blogging platforms remain vulnerable to censorship, data breaches, content manipulation, and arbitrary content removal. To address these challenges, the proposed system leverages Ethereum smart contracts for transaction validation and content management, along with the Interplanetary File System (IPFS) for secure, reliable, and distributed storage. The integration of these technologies ensures immutability, author verification, and strong resistance to censorship. Additionally, the platform incorporates an incentive mechanism that rewards content creators through a token-based economy and wallet-driven identity management. The system was evaluated on the Ethereum testnet and demonstrated significant improvements in content persistence, ownership verification, and censorship resistance compared to traditional platforms. Performance analysis indicates stable transaction confirmation times and efficient storage utilization, with potential for further optimization of gas consumption. User interface testing further confirms that the platform effectively abstracts blockchain complexity, offering a user-friendly experience. Overall, this work presents a practical Web3-based content publishing solution that supports creator empowerment and content integrity in a trustless digital environment.

title: Full-Duplex Beamforming Optimization for Near-Field ISAC
authors: Ahsan Nazar, Zhambyl Shaikhanov, Sennur Ulukus
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: Integrated Sensing and Communications (ISAC) is a promising technology for future wireless networks, enabling simultaneous communication and sensing using shared resources. This paper investigates the performance of full-duplex (FD) communication in near-field ISAC systems, where spherical-wave propagation introduces unique beam-focusing capabilities. We propose a joint optimization framework for transmit and receive beamforming at the base station to minimize transmit power while satisfying rate constraints for multi-user downlink transmission, multi-user uplink reception, and multi-target sensing. Our approach employs alternating optimization combined with semi-definite relaxation and Rayleigh quotient techniques to address the non-convexity of the problem. Simulation results demonstrate that FD-enabled near-field ISAC achieves superior power efficiency compared to half-duplex and far-field benchmarks, effectively detecting targets at identical angles while meeting communication requirements.

title: CASA-CIM: A 28nm 131.54 TOPS/W SRAM-Based CIM Macro with Cap-Adder Weighting and Shift-After-Addition Data Streaming for Efficient MAC Operations
authors: Runru Yu, Chenyang Zhao, Honghu Yang, Zhiting Lin, Xiulong Wu, Keji Zhou, Jianguo Yang
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Integrated Circuits and Microsystems (ICICM)
abstract: Charge-domain Computing-In-Memory (CIM) for multiply-accumulate (MAC) operations has garnered significant attention due to its robust tolerance to process, voltage, and temperature (PVT) variations. However, two major challenges persist: performance trade-offs in multi-bit weighting methods within charge-domain CIM, and excessive cost from adder trees. To address these challenges, we present CASA-CIM, a novel CIM macro with three key innovations. Firstly, a hybrid digital-analog Cap-Adder weighting (CAW) scheme enhances linearity and reduces weighting-expansion cost. Secondly, a Shift-After-Addition data stream (SAS) scheme cuts adder cost by 10.4%. Thirdly, a dual 3bit flash analog-to-digital converter (3bit-FADC) structure lowers offset demands compared with traditional 4bit ADCs. The proposed CASA-CIM achieves an energy efficiency of 131.54 TOPS/W with INT4 input/weight precision @ 28 nm.

title: Resume Analytics and Role Suitability Assessment for Employees
authors: Udhaya T, Mithelesh S S, Mugesh Karthi G S
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: The rapid growth of digital recruitment platforms has increased the demand for sophisticated and automated solutions that can effectively match resumes with job requirements. Because they are unable to understand the contextual and semantic connections between candidate skills and job requirements, traditional keyword-based techniques usually yield inaccurate results. To get over this problem, this project proposes incorporating a deep learning-based resume matching engine into a Stream light web application. The system extracts semantic features from resumes and job descriptions using Techniques for the processing of natural language. Unlike conventional approaches, the model analyzes contextual meaning to identify synonyms, related concepts, and domain-specific terminology. This approach enhances the hiring process by providing recruiters with a more reliable method of evaluating applicants and by providing job seekers with insightful comments to enhance their applications. Overall, the study demonstrates how deep learning-driven natural language processing techniques may significantly improve talent acquisition by bridging the gap between applicant profiles and organizational requirements.

title: Sign-based Storytelling Platform for Hearing-Impaired Children with ASL Animation and Audio Narration Support
authors: Nayuni Sai Charan Teja, C. Priyadharsini
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: In this research, a sign-based narrative platform is being proposed, which will improve the accessibility of hearing-impaired children by automatically animating and narrating in American Sign Language (ASL) and audio. The system can transform text in as much as it can be translated into synchronized audio and visual forms in a combination of multilingual translation, ASL gloss mapping, and image-based sign retrieval. The usability testing of the system was performed on 20 participants, consisting of children and educators in inclusive classrooms to prove that the system is effective. Findings have shown a 35 per cent growth in the comprehension scores and 42 per cent increase in engagement as compared to the text alone story presentations. Real time performance on standard hardware is tested by technical assessment and it has an average frame rendering latency of 0.18s. The results show that cheap AI-driven storytelling tools can be of great use in mitigating communication obstacles during early stages of education. The future work will extend grammar-conscious ASL synthesis and dynamic gestures of avatars to enhance the expressiveness.

title: Application of Deep Learning in Concrete Strength Prediction: A Soft Computing Perspective using Mean Absolute Error
authors: S. Hariharasudhan, E. Thangaraj, Karthik Elangovan, A. Mohamed Anwar, K. Muthumayil, M. Vijayaraj
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: This work's primary objective is to test concretes compressive strength by means of the soft computing approach while using less time, materials and money. The use of deep learning in concrete mixture design is expanding rapidly; it can solve complicated issues on its own and has revolutionary potential. In this study, the compressive power of concrete at 28 days of age was predicted using a comparative analysis using the deep learning algorithm of Convolution Neural Network (CNN) to forecast the compressive power and water absorption ratio in cement mixture. The dataset was produced under a number of carefully monitored circumstances in a laboratory. The approaches of Mean Absolute Error (MAE) and coefficient’s determination (R2) were recycled to validate the proposed CNN model and the outcomes showed that the CNN prototype model accurately predicts the compressive power of the concrete ratio

title: A Compact Wideband E-band Low Noise Amplifier with 3.3-4.5 dB Noise Figure using 45-nm RFSOI
authors: Yinhan Lin, Haoshen Zhu, Taotao Xu, Zhuming Li, Guohai Quan, Pei Qin, Quan Xue
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Integrated Circuits and Microsystems (ICICM)
abstract: This paper proposes an E-band low noise amplifier (LNA) fabricated using a $\mathbf{4 5}-\mathrm{nm}$ RFSOI process. An out-of-phase feedback transformer is employed for wideband input matching. Building on this, the trade-off between impedance matching and transconductance in the input network is optimized, with carefully chosen coupling coefficients to further enhance performance. A current-reuse technique is incorporated to improve gain while minimizing power consumption. Additionally, a gate-drain feedback transformer is utilized in the output load to broaden the bandwidth. Post-simulation results show that the proposed LNA achieves a maximum gain of 16.2 dB with a 3-dB bandwidth of $62.8-85.7 \mathrm{GHz}(22.9 \mathrm{GHz})$. The noise figure (NF) ranges from 3.3 to 4.5 dB, with an $\mathrm{IP}_{1 \mathrm{~dB}}$ of -25.5 dBm at 79.9 GHz. The LNA operates with a DC power consumption of 15.6 mW and occupies a core area of $0.09 \mathrm{~mm}^{2}$.

title: PODM-mmHPE: Exploiting Physical Optics based mmWave Data Augmentation via Diffusion Model for Generalizable Human Pose Estimation
authors: Zhongmin Jiang, Yingxiao Wu, Zhiyuan Zhou, Wenxiang Wang, Jianping Han
publish: IEEE Internet of Things Journal
abstract: The scarcity of high-quality millimeter-wave (mmWave) radio frequency (RF) data for human sensing poses significant challenges to the generalization and robustness of deep learning models in this domain. The acquisition of RF data is constrained by the need for specialized equipment and specific application scenarios, resulting in a significant gap in both quantity and diversity compared to visual data. To address this critical bottleneck, we propose PODM-mmHPE, a novel framework that leverages Physical Optics (PO) and Diffusion Models (DM) to synthesize high-quality human RF data for mmWave Human Pose Estimation (mmHPE). Our framework introduces two key innovations: (1) a PO-based RF simulation pipeline that generates coarse RF data from 3D human mesh models by modeling electromagnetic wave interactions with body surface geometry and (2) a DM-based refinement module that transforms the coarse data into realistic RF heatmaps, capturing the complexity and noise of real-world RF signals. Furthermore, we develop map2pose, a Graph Convolutional Network (GCN)-based model that establishes an end-to-end mapping from RF heatmaps to 3D human poses, serving both as a downstream task benchmark and a validation mechanism for the quality of our synthetic data. Experiments demonstrate PODM-mmHPE’s effectiveness with 23.9% and 25.1% MPJPE reductions on HuPR and mmHPE datasets under synthetic augmentation. This validates our physics-guided synthesis enables generalizable mmWave pose estimation.

title: Next-Generation Security in the 6G Era: The Role of AI in Safeguarding Future Networks
authors: Ramesh Kumar, Joy Dutta, N Vamsi, Uma Sankararao Varri, Deepak Puthal
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: The integration of Artificial Intelligence (AI) into sixth-generation (6G) networks is a foundational requirement for achieving unprecedented performance, but it also introduces a sophisticated threat landscape that legacy security frameworks cannot address. This paper presents a comprehensive review of this dual role of AI, analyzing its potential to both compromise and safeguard future networks. Since AI has the ability to both protect and compromise security and privacy, its implementation with 6G technology may sometimes be a double-edged sword. The primary objective of this survey is to systematically analyze existing research that integrates AI techniques into 6G architectures, focusing on their implications for security and privacy. Among the concerns being investigated is the fundamental privacy and security risk associated with 6G technologies. Therefore, in order to incorporate and confirm this foundational research as a platform for future research, we have developed a review on the specifics of 6G security and privacy. The methodology involves reviewing recent academic and industrial studies related to AI-enabled 6G frameworks, threat models, and defense mechanisms, with an emphasis on how AI contributes to intrusion detection, authentication, and privacy preservation. This paper begins with a historical analysis of previous networking technologies and how they impacted contemporary 6G networking improvements. Therefore, this article discusses extensively the aspects that have rendered 6G technology relevant as well as the ongoing 6G-based projects. In addition, it identifies and critically evaluates key enabling technologies, including distributed ledger technology (DLT/blockchain), physical layer security (PLS), terahertz (THz) communication, quantum computing, visible light communication (VLC), and distributed AI/ML, that underpin secure 6G environments. The paper concludes by summarizing open challenges, future research opportunities, and potential pathways for building trustworthy AI-driven 6G systems.

title: AI-Powered Repetitive Transcranial Magnetic Stimulation Personalized Treatment Recommendation for Depression Based on Patient Profiles
authors: Lingling Xu, Haoran Xie, S. Joe Qin, Fu Lee Wang, Raj Gururajan, Soman Elangovan, Yanmei Shen
publish: IEEE Transactions on Computational Social Systems
abstract: Depression is a highly prevalent mental illness that poses significant challenges to global public health. Although various treatment options exist, their effectiveness is often limited by patient heterogeneity and the lack of individualized treatment strategies. Repetitive transcranial magnetic stimulation (rTMS) has emerged as a safe and noninvasive intervention for depression. However, current clinical practices typically rely on subjective or empirical decision-making and often lack personalized rTMS protocol selection, leading to suboptimal outcomes. To address this issue, we propose an artificial intelligence (AI)-powered model for personalized rTMS treatment recommendation. The model leverages multisource patient profiles, including demographic information, clinical depression data, and rTMS treatment parameters. Unlike conventional approaches, our method uses contrastive learning (CL) to enhance patient representation learning, enabling the model to better capture similarities between patient profiles. Treatment recommendations are generated by identifying the Top-<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$k$</tex-math></inline-formula> most similar patients in the learned embedding space. Additionally, a similarity-based grouping strategy is introduced to divide the dataset into two subgroups, one receiving personalized rTMS protocols and the other receiving standard protocols. Experimental results show that BERT-based models achieve over 77.3% accuracy in Acc@Top-5. Furthermore, patients who received AI-suggested personalized rTMS protocols exhibited greater improvements in psychometric scale scores and larger effect sizes, demonstrating the effectiveness of our approach. Finally, we conduct an ablation study to examine the role of CL and systematically analyze the impact of different neural encoders and Top-<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$k$</tex-math></inline-formula> values. These findings offer insights into model design and performance optimization.

title: Research Progress on the Surface/Interface Reaction Mechanism of Metal/Dielectric Heterogeneous Materials in Hybrid Bonding
authors: Xuze Li, Yu Zhang, Fei Ding, Renxi Jin, Yudong Yang, Qiushi Kang, Haibo Yang, Liqiang Cao, Qidong Wang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Components, Packaging and Manufacturing Technology
abstract: Advanced packaging has attached great attention with the rising demand for processor performance and the approaching physical limit of transistor size. Hybrid bonding technology stands out as one of the mainstream technologies for next-generation 3D packaging due to the small interconnect pitch and high bandwidth. The main process flow includes chemical mechanical polishing (CMP), surface activation, room-temperature pre-bonding, and annealing. However, due to the complex material system and long processing flow, the reaction mechanism at the bonding surface and interface remains unclear, which is closely related to the bonding process and interface quality. This paper systematically reviews the physicochemical reaction and the mechanism of metal/dielectric heterogeneous materials in the hybrid bonding process. Including (1) the influence of plasma and chemical treatment on the composition and structure of the metal/dielectric surface; (2) the evolution of the interfacial force, the influence of water molecules and bonding wave; (3) the bonding mechanism of metal/dielectric and the side reaction related to reliability. The comprehensive review of the surface and interface reaction helps to understand the bonding mechanism, which will guide the development of hybrid bonding technology.

title: Image-Free Infrared Detection Paradigm for Industrial Gas Leaks
authors: Yi-Xuan Jing, Qi Wang, Yi-Fan Liu, Yong Zhao
publish: IEEE Transactions on Industrial Informatics
abstract: Industrial gas leaks create hazardous situations that can lead to fires and explosions, making their detection and monitoring crucial. The optical gas imaging (OGI) has proven to be an attractive way to ensure safe working conditions. However, existing implementations for OGI schemes rely on pixelated sensors for image capture that produce abundant redundant information. Low computational overhead and real-time gas leak detection remain challenging. In this article, we propose an image-free gas leak detection approach that enables the direct extraction of leakage features from 1-D signals. Aimed at image-free measurement, the proposed method optically samples the partial Fourier spectrum by combining a single-scanline sensor with a Fourier optics architecture. Moreover, to effectively mine sequence features, the wavelet-fused convolution-transformer network architecture is proposed to deeply fuse a convolutional neural network, which has the ability of local sensing, with a transformer, which has the advantage of global modeling, in the feature space by using the wavelet transform. Extensive validation experiments of the proposed method are carried out on a self-constructed image-free gas leakage dataset and a very domain-representative industrial scene, IOD-Video. The results show that the proposed image-free detection paradigm exhibits significant advantages, achieving a detection accuracy of 96.4% in an inference time of 3.28 ms.

title: An improved sufficient condition for weighted $\ell _{r}-\ell _{1}$ minimization
authors: Jianwen Huang, Feng Zhang, Xinling Liu, Runbin Tang, Jinping Jia, Runke Wang
