title: A Decentralized Blue-Carbon MRV System and Tokenized Carbon Credit Marketplace with Gasless Transactions, IoT Telemetry, and ML-Driven SOC Estimation
authors: Ayush Vaibhav Hirlekar
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: Blue carbon ecosystems are vital for atmospheric CO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf> sequestration, yet measurement, reporting, and verification (MRV) methodologies remain fragmented and opaque, hindering scalable climate finance. This paper introduces a unified, standards-driven that integrates blockchain smart contracts, decentralized storage, IoT sensor arrays, and machine learning to digitize and automate the carbon credit lifecycle. The architecture anchors project design documents, geospatial layers, and laboratory datasets immutably on-chain via ERC-1155 and IPFS, enabling tamper-evident provenance, real-time evidence linkage, and transparent buffer pool enforcement. Gasless EIP-712 meta-transactions ensure inclusive stakeholder participation, while ML-enabled MRV modules yield accurate, conservative credit estimation from diverse soil and spectral features. Prototype deployment demonstrates automated verification, auditability, and cost-effective credit tokenization, significantly advancing market integrity, efficiency, and accessibility. Current constraints include limited deployment scale and sensor diversity, with ongoing work targeting mainnet expansion, advanced ML pipelines, and collaboration for robust real-world adoption and policy integration.

title: Enhancing Communication in Edge Applications with IoT-Based Overlay Peer-to-Peer Networks
authors: Marco Garofalo, Giuseppe Tricomi, Luca D'Agati, Zakaria Benomar, Giovanni Merlino, Antonio Puliafito, Francesco Longo
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conferences on Internet of Things (iThings) IEEE Green Computing &amp; Communications (GreenCom) IEEE Cyber, Physical &amp; Social Computing (CPSCom) and IEEE Smart Data (SmartData) and IEEE Congress on Cybermatics (Cybermatics)
abstract: The proliferation of the Internet of Things (IoT) has completely changed our digital environment, making effective and smooth communication among interconnected devices. Overlays, which enable network virtualization, are a feasible way to handle the different requirements of IoT applications. However, challenges like Network Address Translation (NAT) and the complexity of handling overlays make communication problematic. While our previous work on cloud-based solutions provided valuable insights and enabled foundational services, it also revealed latency issues that motivated a shift toward more decentralized architectures. Leveraging Web Real-Time Communication (WebRTC) technology, we propose the deployment of peer-to-peer overlay networks at the edge of the IoT infrastructure. This decentralized method improves scalability and flexibility while decreasing latency. Our approach reduces the risk of network congestion and single choke points while enhancing the responsiveness of IoT applications by eschewing centralized cloud servers.

title: A Low-Ripple Charge Pump with Adaptive Load Compensation for Flash-Based CIM
authors: Xuyuan Gu, Xiaofeng Gu, Zhiguo Yu
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Integrated Circuits and Microsystems (ICICM)
abstract: This paper presents an adaptive load compensation charge pump for the bit line (BL) driving circuit of flash-based compute-in-memory (CIM) chips. In CIM chips, severe load current fluctuations in BL circuits cause significant ripple and slow voltage recovery at the charge pump output. To address the problem, this work integrates a parallel structure combined with a delay-locked-loop (DLL) differential clock to reduce ripple and enhance driving capability. A dynamic compensation module adapts to load current changes, enabling real-time inverse compensation to maintain constant equivalent output current and ensure voltage stability. The charge pump is designed in 55-nm CMOS process. Simulation results show under load current fluctuations ranging from 50 to $200 \mu \mathrm{~A}$, the steady-state ripple remains approximately 2.1 mV, which is reduced by 86% compared to that of charge pump by dynamic clock frequency scaling. During the BL switching, the recovery time for a 2.04 V voltage drop caused by parasitic capacitance is approximately $2.01 \mu \mathrm{~s}$.

title: Islands of Exposure: Attacking HDMI Audio via Electromagnetic Side Channels
authors: Kui Wang, Meng Zhang, Yanyun Xu
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: We present a novel side-channel attack targeting HDMI audio transmissions via electromagnetic (EM) leakage. Our approach leverages both passive and active channels to extract information from HDMI signals without protocol-level access or physical tampering. Through the unintentional EM leakage channel, we accurately infer playback states (play vs. paused) and audio types (speech vs. music) with 100% classification accuracy. We further achieve 96.67% accuracy in fine-grained spoken digits recognition using feature fusion and bootstrapped learning. Complementing this, we demonstrate an actively modulated covert channel that encodes data into the EM emissions of HDMI audio streams. This covert channel supports reliable transmission across air-gapped, wall-separated environments with an effective throughput of 12bits per second. Our findings reveal that HDMI audio paths, traditionally considered benign, can in fact serve as powerful side-channel vectors for behavioral inference and stealthy data exfiltration, posing serious risks to both consumer and industrial systems.

title: Threshold Voltage Monitoring Method for SiC MOSFET Based on DM EMI Signals
authors: Mingxing Du, Xindi Liu, Jinliang Yin
publish: IEEE Power Electronics Magazine
abstract: Permanent threshold voltage (<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$V_{\mathrm {th}}$ </tex-math></inline-formula>) drift, induced by Bias Temperature Instability (BTI), constitutes one of the critical reliability challenges facing silicon carbide (SiC) metal-oxide-semiconductor field-effect transistors (MOSFET). However, existing in-situ monitoring methods face significant challenges related to intrusiveness and strong coupling with junction temperature (<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$T_{\mathrm {j}}$ </tex-math></inline-formula>). Based on this, this article proposes an innovative <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$V_{\mathrm {th}}$ </tex-math></inline-formula> measurement method based on differential-mode (DM) conducted electromagnetic interference (EMI). This pioneering approach enables online <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$V_{\mathrm {th}}$ </tex-math></inline-formula> monitoring decoupled from <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$T_{\mathrm {j}}$ </tex-math></inline-formula>, utilizing DM EMI signals for the first time. This non-invasive method enables the identification of impending faults, thereby facilitating early monitoring of BTI-driven degradation in SiC MOSFET.

title: Leaf Logic: Harnessing VGG16 for Precision Diagnosis of Tomato Plant Diseases
authors: Jayapal Lande, Arpanpreet Kaur, Suhail Vij, Kartikeya Raina
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: The study illustrates the process for identifying tomato leaf diseases using the VGG16 deep learning network. The research includes the categories of Healthy Tomato Leaf, Bacterial Spot, Early Blight, and Late Blight. The design of VGG16 is simple yet effective to application, demonstrated with true potential as a deep convolutional model with deep convolutional layers which shine when put to the test of visual recognition and identification. The model achieves excellent classification performance, and every category of disease has achieved impressive accuracy, recall, and F1-scores. The model achieves an F1-score of 95.54%, recall of 94.41%, and accuracy of 92.68% in the category of Healthy Tomato Leaf. The Early Blight category achieved precision of 94.68%, recall 94.78% and an F1-score of 95.90%. The Bacterial Spot class reached accuracy of 96.68%, memory of 95.41%, and an F1-score of 93.54%. For Late Blight, a F1-score of 93.54 and recall of 95.41% accuracy of 92.68% was achieved. The model perfectly differentiates damage from healthy leaves in every instance of classification with perfect accuracy (96% in all cases). This data has demonstrated the potential of VGG16 to handle the complexities associated with classifying plant disease, thereby demonstrating its potential advancement in future precision farming practices. The use of VGG16 would be a viable and effective automated crop disease identification method, improving disease management capabilities, assisting in decision making, and ultimately enhancing yield management techniques in agricultural practices.

title: Topology Evaluation-Based Layer Assignment Method for Free-assignment Routing in InFO Packages
authors: Zhan-Yang Zhu, Ning Xu, Hao-Ying Wu, Chenglin Lu
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Integrated Circuits and Microsystems (ICICM)
abstract: With the increasing complexity of system designs, advanced packaging technologies continue to emerge. Among them, the Integrated Fan-Out (InFO) Wafer-Level Chip-Scale Package (WLCSP) has gained significant attention as a cuttingedge solution that enables high-density and flexible system integration through multi-chip integration and multi-layer interconnection. As the physical size of InFO-WLCSP packages expands, the I/O pad density increases exponentially, making the topological crossover of free-assignment nets a critical bottleneck that severely constrains routing quality. Existing methods typically address topological crossover issues during the routing stage through iterative approaches, which often fail to provide satisfactory solutions. In this paper, we propose, for the first time, a predictive approach to anticipate topological crossovers of freeassignment nets prior to routing. This approach incorporates layer assignment considerations while aiming to minimize total wire length. We introduce a Voronoi Diagram-based iteration algorithm to effectively resolve the topology-compatible allocation problem in the fan-in region. Additionally, we propose a novel Voronoi region merging strategy to adaptively partition the fanout region across multiple chips. A novel model is developed to address the topology-compatible allocation problem, and a final layer assignment is derived using the Longest Common Subsequence (LCS) algorithm. Experimental results demonstrate the high quality and efficiency of our algorithm.

title: Electronic Properties of Violet Phosphorus Devices
authors: Chunyi Qiu, Ziyao Lu, Yiting Wei, Jiaxian Sun, Shilong Zhao
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Integrated Circuits and Microsystems (ICICM)
abstract: Violet phosphorus (VP), a layered allotrope of elemental phosphorus, possesses a unique monoclinic structure and intrinsic anisotropy, making it a promising candidate for future electronic and optoelectronic devices. In this study, we report the synthesis of high-quality VP via chemical vapor transport and the fabrication of few-layer VP-based field-effect transistors (FETs) using pre-defined electrodes. The devices demonstrate typical n-type behavior with strong gate modulation, stable transport characteristics, and a high on/off current ratio of $\sim 10^{4}-10^{5}$. The electrical performance is stable across multiple gate voltage sweeps, although a notable hysteresis is observed, attributable to interface traps and residual carriers. Our results establish VP as a viable wide-bandgap N-type semiconductors with potential application in high-performance memristors.

title: Design of a High-Bandwidth Low-Noise Amplifier
authors: Hongmei Chen, Ruiting Shen, Yuexin Tan, Zheyu Li
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Integrated Circuits and Microsystems (ICICM)
abstract: This paper presents the design of a high-bandwidth, low-noise rail-to-rail amplifier. The input stage achieves high gain while significantly enhancing bandwidth by cascading a high-gain operational amplifier path with a high-bandwidth operational amplifier path. The input transistor pair operates in the subthreshold region, enabling low equivalent input noise voltage and reduced power consumption. The intermediate stage employs a folded-cascode active load directly combined with a class-AB operational amplifier-controlled output stage, which not only reduces static power consumption but also expands the output signal swing range and significantly enhances load-driving capability. Additionally, a slew rate enhancement circuit is further designed to ensure the output stage delivers large output currents under low quiescent current conditions for rail-to-rail output swing. Finally, the output structure utilizes capacitive compensation through internal feedback loops to establish fast feedback channels, ensuring system stability while suppressing output ripple. Implemented by using HJ $0.18 \mu \mathrm{~m}$ BCD process technology, the layout occupies an area of $890 \mu \mathrm{~m} \times 495 \mu \mathrm{~m}$. Postlayout simulation results demonstrate that the amplifier achieves rail-to-rail input/output functionality with an open-loop gain of 150.9 dB, phase margin of 86.42°, and gain-bandwidth product of 20.43 MHz. The equivalent input noise at 1 kHz is $5.53 \mathrm{nV} / \sqrt{ } \mathrm{Hz}$, with a common-mode rejection ratio of 112.6 dB. The positive and negative power supply rejection ratios are 129.5 dB and 114 dB, respectively. The measured positive and negative slew rates reach $19.2 \mathrm{~V} / \mu \mathrm{s}$ and $14.2 \mathrm{~V} / \mu \mathrm{s}$.

title: A VHF memristor emulator for crossbar synaptic simulation
authors: Guangzhen Dai, Bingchen Liu, Sihao Yang, Wei Li, Daohua Wu, Yuefeng He
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Integrated Circuits and Microsystems (ICICM)
abstract: Here, it was recommended to develop a CMOS-based memristor emulator circuit that can operate well in both grounded and floating modes without the need for internal structural changes. The proposed emulator is constructed from a compact assembly of nine MOS transistors, three resistors, and a single capacitor. Interestingly, unlike previous research, the novel dual-function memristor emulator has an easy-to-use design and maintains the memristor’s hysteresis characteristic curves for input sine waves up to 500 MHz in frequency. The distinctive features of the pinched hysteresis curve and the nonvolatility of the memristor emulator across various frequency domains have been experimentally validated using 130 nm CMOS technology. The empirical validation of the circuit, realized on a breadboard utilizing commercial components, conclusively corroborates the findings of both theoretical analysis and simulation. Subsequently, a crossbar model of the memristor has been established using data derived from the proposed emulator. Utilizing three distinct datasets—comprising small digits, file types, and large digits—we have trained the model employing the backpropagation algorithm, subsequently assessing its training performance on diverse datasets. The outcomes indicate that the model achieves an accuracy rate as high as approximately 94%—even for the large digits set—after only 10 training epochs.

title: From Orbit to Insight: A Study on the Collection and Curation of Satellite Imagery Datasets
authors: Kinjal A. Patel, Kaushika Patel
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: The rationale behind this study is to assess and ensure the quality of datasets being used in published peer review journal articles, conference proceedings, and research papers during recent times, and to put some perspective into the contemporary applications of satellite imagery and remote sensing in disaster management, Land cover, land use, and agricultural productivity. The quality of the dataset is a multidimensional task that requires a lot of automated and manual steps. These studies play a very important role because they increase the credibility and relevance of single datasets in the remote sensing fraternity and the associated fields, strengthening the conclusions of published research findings on the reports of used and cited datasets and increasing the transparency and traceability of data and publications. Data papers are a scientifically valuable product, and they will provide the information needed to use the data in a big way. The data paper is complemented with a metadata file that outlines the dataset. We have outlined what are the prominent sources of satellite imagery, how the data captured by satellites are handled beginning from the process of retrieval, how they are interpreted, what are the core characteristics of the imagery in terms of channel types, sizes and many more factors, in what classes they are being bracketed to, how data science is the modern tool of choice pushing the boundaries of techniques and tooling employed at every stage, some emphasis is put on the systematic storage of these data.

title: Stochastic Computation Based Quantization Strategy for SRAM Computing-in-Memory Macro
authors: Xin Li, Yifan Wu, Lintao Chen, Chenghu Dai, Xiulong Wu, Zhiting Lin
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Integrated Circuits and Microsystems (ICICM)
abstract: This paper presents an innovative Stochastic Computing-in-Memory (CIM) macro structure aimed at improving the energy efficiency of edge devices performing multibit multiply-and-accumulate (MAC) operations. The proposed framework integrates a 8T SRAM-based CIM, input encoding mechanism, and a low cost 4-bit coarse fine analog-to-digital converter (ADC). By incorporating the quantization and encoding strategies of stochastic computing, the reuse of most digital devices and analog circuits is realized, and the hardware overhead and power consumption are utilized. The design includes a $\mathbf{4 K b}$ SRAM CIM macro implemented in 28 nm CMOS technology. Simulation results demonstrate that the proposed coarse-fine ADC achieves a 32% power reduction compared to conventional designs, while its coarse-fine quantization architecture significantly shortens the conversion cycle. The CIM macro can achieve a peak energy efficiency of $87.43 \mathrm{TOPS} / \mathrm{W}$, providing a significant boost to the performance of edge computing devices.

title: A 88 -dB SNDR 156-KHz-BW Noise-Shaping SAR ADC with 3rd-CIFF Structure and Dynamic Integrator
authors: Yulin Feng, Mei Jiang, Xinhui He, Zhengru Li
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Integrated Circuits and Microsystems (ICICM)
abstract: This paper presents a noise-shaping (NS) successive approximation register (SAR) analog-to-digital converter (ADC) with $3^{\text {rd }}$-order cascade of integrators with feedforward (CIFF) structrue. The amplifier modules in the integrators are implemented using two-stage floating inverter amplifier (FIA) structures, which provide high gain while achieving significantly lower power consumption compared to operational transconductance amplifiers (OTAs). The $3^{\text {th }}$-order integration is realized with two integrators, where the third stage is implemented by reusing the second integrator. This reuse strategy eliminates one FIA and thereby reduces hardware cost. The multi-input comparison functionality of the CIFF structure is achieved through capacitive series stacking combined with a conventional two-input comparator, leading to substantial power savings. The ADC operates at a sampling rate of $5 \mathrm{MS} / \mathrm{s}$ with a 1.2 V supply voltage and an oversampling ratio (OSR) of 16. Post-layout simulations, performed with a sinusoidal input signal at 50.96 kHz, yield a power consumption of $506 \mu \mathrm{~W}$. The measured signal-to-noise and distortion ratio (SNDR) is $\mathbf{8 8 ~ d B}$, corresponding to an effective number of bits (ENOB) of 14.32 bit. The Schreier figure-of-merit (FOMs) reaches $\mathbf{1 7 3 ~ d B}$.

title: Demo: Programmable Packet Scheduling on FPGA-Based Switches
authors: Mufaddal Enayath Hussain, Mario Patetta, Jonathan Rivalan
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on 6G Networking (6GNet)
abstract: We present an FPGA prototype of programmable traffic manager capable of dynamic adjusting its scheduling behaviour, enabling tailored enforcing of Quality-of-Service (QoS) guarantees. The proposed design is integrated within the Corundum NIC framework and deployed on an AMD Alveo U50 FPGA board that operates with <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{4 x} \mathbf{1 0}$</tex> Gbps ports. The demo shows the runtime configurability of both packet classification and scheduling policies-including weighted bandwidth sharing, strict priority and traffic shaping.

title: Flask-React based Machine Learning Platform for Heart Disease and Diabetes Risk Analysis
authors: Aditya Ladge, Aarushi Jain, Pratham Desai, Anindita Khade
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: The research paper describes a software-based medical risk analysis system which predicts heart disease and diabetes by analyzing patient health information collected without sensors or physical devices. The system functions by running machine learning algorithms which operate under a Python Flask backend that loads both pre-trained models and scaler files for data normalization. The user interface built with React and TypeScript and Tailwind CSS and Vite enables users to enter data efficiently. The system includes speech recognition functionality through Vosk API to improve accessibility for users who have disabilities. The system design protects user data privacy through temporary information processing during active sessions because it refrains from saving any data on the server. The modular design enables future system expansion through additional dataset integration and validation study implementation. The bibliography documents serve as reference materials to improve the literature review and methodology and validation discussion. Further validation with additional datasets and research from uploaded documents will be a key aspect of future development.

title: Transfer Learning Approach for Multi-Class Mushroom Identification using VGG16
authors: Bura Vijay Kumar, Ruchika Bhuria, Sonali Gupta, Vartika Aarwal
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: In food safety and toxicology, mushroom identification is an essential procedure due to the morphological resemblance of edible and toxic species which is very dangerous to health. This paper is a deep learning-based classification model of a fine-tuned VGG16 convolutional neural network to classify mushrooms into 4 different categories: Edible, Conditionally Edible, Deadly, and Poisonous. They used a very large dataset of about 104,000 images that are highly diverse in species, and one could be confident that the feature representation is robust when it comes to the cap structures, gill patterns, colour variations. Images were re-scaled and normalized and subjected to severe augmentation methods to improve generalization. VGG16 was pretrained with ImageNet weights and then used with a staged fine-tuning approach whereby the lower convolutional blocks were frozen, and then a task specific classifier head was trained and then the last convolutional layers were unfrozen selectively to adapt. The Adam optimizer was used to optimize with the use of the differential learning rates and weight decay, early stopping, and checkpointing. The model had a general accuracy of 95% in classification and an equal level of accuracy in terms of precision, recall, and F1-values. Grad-CAM visualizations also showed that the model gives attention to diagnostically useful mushroom patterns, which makes it more interpretable and reliable in practice.

title: AGROXAI: Explainable AI for Smart Farming
authors: Subhashree Rath, Allagadda Pranay Karthik Reddy, Bachhala Venkata Parthu, Balla Pavan Kumar, Bonala Praneeth Kumar Reddy
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: Data-driven decision support systems are definitely the most important systems in modern agriculture. Even though AI models can produce really accurate suggestions regarding crop planning and yield forecasting, their acceptance by farmers and agricultural specialists is always restricted due to the lack of transparency. A research paper presents AgroXAI, an up-to-date XAI-based smart agriculture platform, which meshes predictability with rainfall forecasting, crop recommendation, and yield prediction. To help the farmers comprehend and trust the forecasts, this system presents brief and local explanations with the use of SHAP and LIME. The suggested system is lightweight and, thus, either cloud-based or cloud-free and, therefore, can be easily used by a wide range of people. Also, it is a democratic system as it is easy to get access.

title: A cryogenic readout integrated circuit for blocked-impurity-band (BIB) far-infrared focal plane array detectors
authors: Yushi Chen, Xin Ge, Hongbo Ma, Zewen Wang, Zuoru Dong, Xiaodong Wang
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Integrated Circuits and Microsystems (ICICM)
abstract: Blocked-impurity-band (BIB) far-infrared focal plane array (FPA) detectors are widely used in infrared detection, the performance of which are directly affected by the dynamic range of the readout integrated circuits (ROICs). In this paper, two novel techniques are proposed to improve the dynamic range of ROICs. The proposed background signal suppression technique and integral capacitor sharing technique improve the dynamic range by reducing noise signals and increasing saturated charge capacity, respectively. At the same time, since BIB detectors need to work in cryogenic environment ($\mathrm{T}{\lt}10 \mathrm{~K}$), which means ROICs need to operate at the same temperature. In order to eliminate cryogenic non-ideal effect of transistors, this paper proposes a cryogenic transistor model to ensure the performance of ROICs. The proposed ROIC is designed and fabricated with $0.18 \mu \mathrm{~m}$ CMOS technology, the size of which is $700 \mu \mathrm{~m} \times 650 \mu \mathrm{~m}$. The power consumption is 3.02 mW, the readout rate is 1 MHz and the saturation charge capacity reaches 40 Me-/pixel. Overall, the dynamic range of the proposed ROIC is 70dB, which meets the aim of the design.

title: A Dual-Authentication Router-Assisted Attendance System
authors: D. Pavithra, Tarun Prasanth S, Nishore N, Kabinesh S
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: Using a dual-authentication strategy that combines Wi-Fi-based validation and One-Time Password (OTP) verification, the DA-Router Framework presents an intelligent attendance management system that improves accuracy and stops proxy marking. Time inefficiency, human error, and spoofing are some of the problems with traditional attendance techniques, such as manual and biometric systems. Only students who are physically connected to the classroom’s assigned network (by SSID/BSSID/MAC verification) are able to mark attendance thanks to the suggested framework’s use of router-based device authentication. Simultaneously, identity validation is strengthened by an OTP created by the instructor and validated via a mobile or web interface. Session logs, device information, and attendance analytics are all stored in a centralized database that is updated in real time. A fallback QR mechanism guarantees continuity in the event of Wi-Fi outages. The system offers an administrator dashboard for monitoring attendance statistics, student performance, and connectivity history. The DA-Router Framework advances the automation and integrity of attendance management by enabling a dependable, scalable, and impenetrable solution for contemporary educational institutions by fusing network-layer verification with OTP-based security.

title: RailSem19-H: A Physically Synthesized Multi-Density Fog Dataset for Rail Transit
authors: Chao Wang, Peng Wang, Hao Yin, Xuanying Li, Yijing Wang, Cheng Dai
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conferences on Internet of Things (iThings) IEEE Green Computing &amp; Communications (GreenCom) IEEE Cyber, Physical &amp; Social Computing (CPSCom) and IEEE Smart Data (SmartData) and IEEE Congress on Cybermatics (Cybermatics)
abstract: Image dehazing is crucial for robust visual perception in railway systems. However, current datasets primarily target general scenes, lacking the vital, specific structures and elements found in railway tracks. This data gap significantly hinders the development of railway visual perception algorithms, preventing models from achieving ideal performance. To bridge this, this research introduce RailSem19-H, the first large-scale foggy image dataset specifically designed for railway scenes, comprising 30,000 training images and 1,000 pairs of hazy test images. RailSem19-H construction strictly adheres to the physical model of atmospheric scattering. This research uses original clear images from RailSem19 as the scene radiance parameter <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$J(x)$</tex>, generating scene depth maps <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$d(x)$</tex> via the Midas depth estimation algorithm. Then, by systematically adjusting core parameters like atmospheric light <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$A$</tex> and scattering coefficient <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\beta$</tex>, this research create ten multi-gradient haze levels (moderate to dense fog) for each original image. DehazeFormer, trained on RailSem19-H, achieves exceptionally high results across various metrics and visual effects. RailSem19-H fills a critical void for dedicated datasets in railway dehazing and establishes a highperformance baseline model. This paves the way for algorithmic innovation and practical application breakthroughs in this field under complex meteorological conditions.

title: Analysis of an Electrically Doped Dielectric Modulated TFET Biosensor Design for Label Free Detection of Breast Cancer Cells
authors: Srinivasa Rao Karumuri, Rudra Lakshmi Prasanna, Girish Wadhwa, Jacopo Lannacci, Girija Sravani Kondavitee
publish: IEEE Sensors Journal
abstract: In this article, we have designed and analyzed a label free biosensor that uses Electrically Doped Dielectric Modulated TFET. The biosensor exhibits different drain current response for different breast cancer cell lines at an operating frequency of 230MHz. In the Proposed Electrically Doped DMTFET biosensors, drain and source regions are electrically doped by gate biasing voltage of +2.5V at PG-1 and −2.5 V at PG-2 across an intrinsic silicon body. The electrical behavior of the device is affected by the presence of neutral or charged biomolecules in the cavity region are analyzed by electric field distribution, energy band structure and drain current (I<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">d</sub>). Drain current, threshold voltage (V<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Th</sub>), I<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">on</sub>/I<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">off</sub> ratio and transconductance parameters are measures to identify the detection capabilities of biosensor. When the nanogap is fully filled with a neutral biomolecule with a dielectric constant of 27.5, the proposed device exhibits a maximum sensitivity of 2.6 × 10<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</sup>.

title: Rolling bearing fault diagnosis based on improved VSDP image and multi-head attention mechanism
authors: Xuejun Chen, Kang Yang, Feng Liu, Chenhua Zhang
publish: IEEE Sensors Journal
abstract: Rolling bearing fault diagnosis is critical for ensuring equipment operational safety. An intelligent fault diagnosis method is proposed, integrates an improved Symmetrized Dot Pattern (SDP) image with an AlexNet-based model augmented by a multi-head wavelet attention block. Vibration signals are first decomposed using Variational Mode Decomposition (VMD). The resulting modal data from multiple sensors are transformed into VMD SDP (VSDP) images and then integrated into a composite Multi-channel VSDP (MVSDP) image, which significantly enriches fault feature representation. This image is processed by a customized AlexNet model incorporating a multi-head wavelet attention mechanism, which collectively solves the challenges of feature clustering, multi-angle attention, and feature fusion to extract global fault information comprehensively. Validation on the CWRU bearing dataset confirms that our approach significantly outperforms existing methods in both recognition accuracy and operational stability.

title: Electromagnetic tracking of series inductive sensors for catheter shape sensing
authors: Eoin Higgins, Daragh Crowley, Pádraig Cantillon-Murphy
publish: IEEE Sensors Journal
abstract: Flexible medical devices require accurate real-time shape feedback during minimally invasive procedures. Conventional fluoroscopic imaging, while used, is limited to 2D views and exposes users to ionising radiation. Fibre-Bragg grating sensing provides a radiation-free alternative but demands complex and costly systems. A purely electromagnetic approach is introduced that uses three uniaxial inductive sensors connected in series, which reduces wiring complexity by requiring only two conductors, regardless of sensor count. This series-connected sensor configuration substantially reduces wiring complexity and acquisition hardware demands, however, it necessitates greater field generation requirements and incurs longer solver runtimes. A lumped parameter model for series-connected sensors is introduced and validated experimentally through impedance measurements, demonstrating minimal amplitude and phase distortion below 10 kHz. The open-source Anser electromagnetic tracking (EMT) platform is extended by using three planar field generators (totaling 24 coils) and implementing a novel objective function that simultaneously estimates the position and orientation of three series sensors. Static accuracy evaluations conducted over a volume of 200 mm × 200 mm × 100 mm yielded mean errors below 2.2 mm, while mean errors in dynamic assessments were below 1.2 mm. These results constitute an initial step toward compact and accurate shape sensing for flexible catheters in endovascular interventions.

title: A DeepONet Framework for Enhanced Surrogate Modeling of Reconfigurable Intelligent Surfaces with Limited Data
authors: Kaiyuan Jin, Zhun Wei, Jingwei Zhang, Yunlin Zou, Hao Xie, Wen-Yan Yin
publish: IEEE Transactions on Antennas and Propagation
abstract: Reconfigurable intelligent surfaces (RISs) have attracted significant attention due to their abilities to dynamically manipulate electromagnetic wave propagation. In this work, an efficient surrogate modeling framework based on an improved Deep Operator Network (DeepONet) is proposed to predict the far-field radiation patterns of RIS, significantly reducing the reliance on computationally expensive full wave simulations by the online inferences. Specifically, the proposed architecture integrates a convolutional branch network to extract spatial features from RIS configurations and a multilayer perceptron (MLP) based trunk network to encode angular information. Outputs of both networks are fused and passed through a decoder to generate accurate radiation pattern predictions. We verify the proposed framework on the RIS that employs a 20×20 array of 1 bit controllable units, with binary states representing the ON/OFF conditions. It is shown that, compared to several state-of-the-art learning frameworks, the proposed model suggests superior prediction accuracy and training efficiency under limited data scenarios, offering a promising solution for fast and reliable RIS radiation pattern evaluation.

title: Around-The-Corner Obstacle Detection and Localization Using a 228 GHZ FMCW Imaging Radar
authors: Abdullah Alburadi, Hussein N. Shaman, Kamal Sarabandi
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: This study investigates the use of a millimeter-wave (MMW) imaging radar system operating at 228 GHz for indoor mapping and the detection of non-line-of-sight (NLOS) objects behind a corner. Mapping experiments were conducted in an Lshaped corridor to evaluate the radar's capability to detect and localize both line-of-sight (LOS) and NLOS targets, as well as interior structural features. The radar system employs a scanning reflector that generates a fan beam with a narrow azimuth beamwidth (0.4°) and a wide elevation beam (4°). The results demonstrate that the radar achieves high precision in detecting and mapping LOS corridor walls and obstacles. Notably, NLOS objects were also detected due to multipath reflections between the corridor walls. However, the detected positions of these objects appeared as ghost targets located behind the reflecting walls. To address this, a mirroring transformation was applied to recover the true locations of the NLOS targets. Additionally, an algorithm was developed to generalize this transformation for indoor environments with arbitrary layouts. The final reconstructed corridor map shows that NLOS targets were accurately repositioned to their true locations, and previously occluded corridor areas were successfully reconstructed, demonstrating the system's effectiveness in complex indoor environments.

title: NeuroBA: Neuro-symbolic Bitrate Adaptation for IRS-aided Mobile Video Streaming
authors: Miaojiang Chen, Wenjing Xiao, Anfeng Liu, Ahmed Farouk, Min Chen, Dusit Niyato, Houbing Herbert Song, Victor C.M. Leung
publish: IEEE Transactions on Networking
abstract: Intelligent adaptive bitrate (ABR) schemes have been widely recognized for their excellent learning strategies. However, existing intelligent ABR methods have limitations, i.e., the lack of logical reasoning capability for video-aware symbolic representations leads to low sampling efficiency and fails to achieve the optimal performance of Bitrate Adaptation. We introduce NeuroBA, a learning-based approach to realize ABR using neuro-symbolic deep reinforcement learning. NeuroBA trains a neuro-symbolic deep network model without making any assumptions about the edge video scene and without relying on a predefined model. Instead, it enables bitrate decision-making under uncertainty and partial observability by knowledge-driven video quality perception in symbolic first-order logic. To enhance wireless signals, we have introduced Intelligent Reflecting Surface (IRS) technology to address this issue. By dynamically adjusting the phase shift of IRS, the throughput performance of wireless networks is significantly improved. Based on trace-driven and real-world experiments covering a variety of edge video scenarios, and network performance metrics, NeuroBA is compared with state-of-the-art ABR schemes, and NeuroBA exhibits superior performance, with an average QoE improvement of 16.58% (BOLA)-25.34% (Fugu). In particular, it outperforms existing baseline approaches even without pre-programmed models and network scenarios assumed for the edge network.

title: A Noise Reduction and Bubble Identification Algorithm for Conductivity Probe Signal Processing in Steam-Water Two-Phase Flow based on VMD-WTD, SNIP and SEVA
authors: Kang Li, Wenxiong Zhou, Liangming Pan, Hao Liu, Xubin Tan, Zaiyong Ma, Zhenmin Zhao
publish: IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
abstract: The conductivity probe serves as an effective instrument for measuring two-phase flow parameters; however, its application in high-temperature and high-pressure environments faces constraints due to structure and signal processing algorithm. Under such conditions, the probe signal is vulnerable to noise, baseline drift and waveform distortion. Conventional algorithms, predominantly designed for standard temperature and pressure conditions, demonstrate limited efficacy in addressing these complex challenges. Therefore, a comprehensive signal processing framework was proposed. First, variational mode decomposition (VMD) was integrated with wavelet threshold denoising (WTD) to effectively suppress noise. Subsequently, the sensitive nonlinear iterative peak (SNIP) algorithm was employed for accurate baseline estimation. Finally, the slope and extreme value analysis (SEVA) algorithm was utilized for precise identification of bubble signals. Experimental validation was conducted under pressures ranging from 0.8 MPa to 4.1 MPa. The results demonstrate that the proposed algorithm effectively processes conductivity probe signals under such conditions. The conductivity probe achieved an expanded uncertainty of 3.88% (coverage factor k = 2), corresponding to a 95% confidence level. Experimental void fraction results were compared with predictions from the classical drift-flux models, demonstrating relative deviations within 30%. Additionally, a comparison with image processing measurements revealed a smaller margin of relative deviation, limited to 12%.
