title: E-Tailers Facing Cyber-Attacks: Impacts of Risk Attitudes_supp1-3648054.docx
authors: Lipan Feng
publish: N/A
abstract: Cyber-security plays a critical role in e-commerce operations; however, the influence of e-tailer's risk preference on the strategic response to cyber-security challenges remains underexplored. This study aims to contribute to this underexplored area by examining a supply chain consisting of a supplier and a risk-sensitive e-tailer, whose risk preference may be risk-seeking, risk-neutral, or risk-averse. We examine the equilibrium outcomes under two scenarios: one with and one without the government penalty on the e-tailer for failing to defend against cyber-attacks. Interestingly, risk aversion of the e-tailer tends to hurt consumers, whereas a risk-seeking attitude could benefit consumers. More importantly, increased risk sensitivity of the e-tailer can lead to higher consumer surplus. However, compared to a risk-seeking e-tailer, a risk-averse e-tailer tends to generate greater social welfare. When the government penalty is implemented, it proves beneficial to consumers irrespective of the e-tailer's risk attitude. Counter intuitively, we also find that with or without the government penalty, the risk-seeking e-tailer invests more in cyber-security than the risk-averse e-tailer. To test the robustness of our main models, we extend the analysis to consider blockchain adoption and alliances among supply chain members. Our research provides valuable insights for policymakers and platforms in enhancing e-commerce platform security management by taking into account the e-tailer's risk attitude.

title: A Fine-Tuned AlexNet-Inspired CNN with Attention Mechanism for Brain Tumor Classification
authors: Gotte Ranjith Kumar, Ritu Rani, Sonal Malhotra, Kamlesh Kukreti
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: The research introduces an extended Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) architecture, based on AlexNet, to classify medical images into benign, malignant, and normal categories. The experimental dataset was downloaded from Kaggle and contains 1,194 images, out of which 1,050 images are used for training and 144 images are used for testing. Every image was preprocessed by resizing, normalizing, and applying augmentation techniques in order to maintain consistency and enhance generalization. The suggested architecture is started with various convolutional and pooling layers for the extraction of features, followed by the addition of Batch Normalization to stabilize the training process and Dropout layers in order to avoid overfitting. To avoid the complexity of the model and enhance robustness, a Global Average Pooling (GAP) layer is utilized rather than a conventional flattening operation. Moreover, a Squeeze-and-Excitation (SE) attention mechanism is used to enable the network to focus on salient areas of the image and suppresses irrelevant details. Lastly, the classification is conducted using dense fully connected layers followed by a softmax output layer. Experimental results prove that the proposed model attains about 99% accuracy on the test set, with high precision, recall, and F1-score for all classes. These results show that the suggested CNN model is excellent, efficient, and trustworthy for medical image classification, and is able to offer promising assistance in clinical decision-making.

title: Integrating IoT and Cloud for an Intelligent Home Security System with Efficient Intrusion Detection and Response
authors: K Vinod Kumar Reddy, Sundhar Singh Pitta, Sagarika Patel, David Raju Kuppala, Ganesula Satya Vara Prasad, V Suma Avani
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: The study outlines the design and implementation of a Home Security and Intrusion Detection System based on IoT with the goal of supplying homeowners with real-time monitoring, intelligent threat detection, and immediate alert systems. The suggested system will combine several Internet of Things (IoT) devices, including PIR and ultrasonic sensors, camera modules, and microcontrollers (Arduino/Raspberry Pi) and Wi-Fi modules to create a smart, autonomous, and connected surveillance network. The microcontroller processes data of the sensing layer and sends it via MQTT/HTTP protocols and displays on a mobile or web-based platform so that the user can immediately respond. To test the system in different scenarios of intrusion, a variety of intrusion conditions were applied to test the accuracy of detecting, the time of responding to alerts, and the power consumption of the system. The experimental results had shown a high success rate of detection of 98 % and low false alarms and low power consumption and the networks had constant connectivity. Evaluation on ease of set-up, accuracy, and reliability of the system was also done by the users who expressed more than 96 % satisfaction. Comprehensively, the study has served to advance smart home technologies due to the ability to offer an efficient, scalable, and affordable IoT-based security system that can protect in real-time and expand in the future through the inclusion of AI and cloud.

title: Arduino based Fire Fighting Robot with Real Time Tracking and Monitoring via Blynk IoT
authors: Venkateswara Rao Ch, R Bharath Kumar, Yadla Sai Prasanna, K Satyanarayana Raju, Phanimala Thiragati, Kothapalli Phani Varma
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: Fire accidents occur due to natural causes like forest fires, human mistakes, and poor fire safety in places such as malls, industries, and public transport. Because of these fire accidents, many people and animals are losing their lives, properties are being destroyed, and the environment is getting damaged due to air pollution. Because of recent technological advancements, the number of deaths from fire accidents is decreasing every year. However, these systems still face real-time challenges because they depend heavily on human involvement. To overcome the above-mentioned challenges, this work proposes a robot that can operate in difficult environments, detect fire, and control it by spraying water or foam. The proposed system consists of flame sensors (capable of identifying fire up to 100 cm and an angle of 600) to identify the fire and servo motor to rote the water pump when the fire is detected. The robot can move forward, backward, right and left sides in order to sprinkle the water in all directions of the fire. Simultaneously, alerts are transmitted to the user through the Blynk IoT platform, ensuring real-time monitoring via mobile notifications and email. Experimental results demonstrate that the robot reliably identifies fire, responds instantly, and provides continuous status updates through IoT connectivity. Finally, the proposed prototype offers an effective, portable, and economically viable solution for early fire response, particularly suitable for high-risk environments such as forests, malls, residential buildings, public parks, and industrial areas.

title: Intelligent Framework for Perfect Recognition of Intracranial Tumors
authors: M. Sasikumar, B. V. S. Bhargav, A. Sravan Kumar Reddy, S. P. Santhoshkumar, R. M. Dilip Charaan, J. Kavitha
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: In deep learning approach of classifying brain tumors by utilizing the VGG 19 convolutional neural network (CNNs) with transfer learning is proposed. To solve the class imbalance problem between tumor and healthy samples, the proposed methodology begins with preprocessing brain MRI images through data augmentation, i.e. rotation, shifting, shearing and flipping. In order to give better results to extract region of interest, post processing techniques like converting grayscale, gaussian, threshold, erosion, dilation and contour are applied. The main feature extractor is the VGG19 model, and it has already been trained on the ImageNet dataset. The frozen convolutional layers are used to train a classifier which is then selectively unfrozen and further trained to be tailored to the target dataset. Standard metrics such as accuracy and loss across training and validation and test sets are used to assess the recital of the system suggested. Results from experiments indicate that the use of transfer learning with VGG19 has made it possible to detect brain tumors efficiently and automatically, making it effective for improving clinical decision support and the diagnoses of medical images.

title: Interference-resistant reconfigurable antenna arrays via dynamic metasurface antennas
authors: Joseph Carlson, Nitish Vikas Deshpande, Robert W. Heath
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: Mitigating interference is an important application of antenna arrays in mobile ad hoc networks (MANETs). Unfortunately, antenna arrays add hardware constraints that may limit the effectiveness of interference mitigation for mobile devices. In this paper, we propose an energy-efficient, interference-resistant beamforming method through adaptive beam nulling with dynamic metasurface antennas (DMAs). We develop a genetic algorithm for configuring the DMA weights to adaptively steer both beams and nulls. We find that a DMA in electromagnetic simulations can consistently generate a peak-to-null ratio between 20 and 52 dB while maintaining good nullsteering accuracy.

title: A 2.4 GHz Wide-Tuning-Range Low-Phase-Noise Differential Digitally Controlled Ring Oscillator for CMOS Image Sensor Applications
authors: Zhigang Li, Hongjia Xu, Yao Nian, Jingyi Wang, Xin Li, Qiang Zhao, Xiulong Wu
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Integrated Circuits and Microsystems (ICICM)
abstract: In this paper, a novel 2.4 GHz wide-tuning-range low-phase-noise differential Digitally Controlled Ring Oscillator (DCRO) is proposed for CMOS Image Sensor (CIS) applications. The DCRO integrates cascaded differential operational amplifiers with an embedded 8-bit digital-to-analog converter (DAC) and a 4-bit switched varactor array, effectively enhancing frequency resolution while minimizing area occupation and phase noise. Moreover, the proposed two-stage frequency tuning mechanism significantly improves frequency accuracy and linearity. Post-layout simulation results demonstrate that the proposed DCRO achieves a $0.617-2.709 \mathrm{GHz}$ frequency range with a resolution of 1.56 MHz and a low phase noise of $-103.7 \mathrm{dBc} / \mathrm{Hz}$ at 1 MHz frequency offset. Implemented in a customized 90 nm CMOS technology, the DCRO occupies a compact core area of $0.008 \mathrm{~mm}^{2}$ and consumes only 3.564 mW from a 3.3 V supply voltage.

title: Deep Learning-based Reconstruction and Classification of Corneal Images using EfficientNet Variants
authors: R.Anusuya, Rajalingam Arumuganainar, J.R. Arunkumar, K.Saravanan
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: Fluorescein staining with cobalt blue light is a frequent way to find problems with the corneal surface since it shows epithelial abnormalities. Even though it is widely used in clinical practice, manually interpreting corneal images is not trustworthy or objective. To address these constraints, deep learning methodologies were employed to automate image classification and reconstruction. This research evaluates the efficacy of a Hybrid EfficientNetB13 model, EfficientNetB1, and EfficientNetB3 on fluorescein-stained corneal images. After training and testing each model, a variety of quantitative metrics were employed, including as Mean Squared Error (MSE), Peak Signal-to-Noise Ratio (PSNR), Structural Similarity Index (SSIM), Entropy, Accuracy, Precision, Recall, and F1 Score. The experimental findings showed that EfficientNetB1 had the best PSNR (10.48) and the worst MSE (5817.75), which means that the quality of the picture reconstruction was better than that of the other models. Even though the SSIM values were low, which showed how hard it is to keep minor structural information, all three models had the same classification performance, with an accuracy of 0.75 and an F1 score of 0.80. The results indicate that architectures based on EfficientNet may reliably automate the analysis of ophthalmic images, enabling physicians to diagnose corneal problems more swiftly and objectively.

title: Design of a Reusable UVM Verification Framework for Pixel Readout Chips
authors: Yu Zhao, Zexuan Zhao, Yuanhong Jiao, Xiaomin Wei, Heng Yang, Long Liu, Yongcai Hu
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Integrated Circuits and Microsystems (ICICM)
abstract: The escalating demands of High-Energy Physics (HEP) experiments impose significant challenges on pixel readout chips, including growing functional complexity, compressed design cycles, and high fabrication costs. Traditional verification approaches, relying heavily on static stimuli and manual inspection, suffer from insufficient coverage, low automation, and poor reusability, thus failing to guarantee the functional integrity of such complex designs. To address these challenges, this work proposes and implements a reusable verification framework based on the Universal Verification Methodology (UVM), specifically tailored for advanced pixel readout chips. The key contributions of this framework include: (1) a physics-aware stimulus generator for emulating realistic particle-hit events; (2) a generic serial bus configuration component leveraging the Register ion Layer (RAL) to enable high-level automated configuration; and (3) an intelligent scoreboard capable of out-oforder data matching to ensure robust data validation. The framework’s effectiveness was validated on a pixel readout chip, where its metric-driven verification (MDV) methodology successfully exercised complex functionalities and corner cases of the design. By adopting a modular architecture, the framework significantly enhances reusability and efficiency, offering a systematic and scalable solution for the verification of similar mixed-signal chips.

title: Development of an Interactive Simulation Platform for BB84 and E91 Quantum Cryptography Protocols with Integrated Security Analysis
authors: M. Sharmila Devi, M Madhu Latha, G. Chandana Swathi, A. Naresh, M. Vadivel, M. Vasudeva Reddy
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: The fast development of quantum computing is a serious threat on the traditional cryptographic algorithms like RSA and ECC, the security of which depends on their computational hardness. In order to overcome this new weakness quantum cryptography proposes a radically new security paradigm based on the laws of quantum mechanics. The given paper provides the design and implementation of a platform of an interactive simulation modeling two basic Quantum Key Distribution (QKD) protocols: BB84 and E91. The platform has been created as a series of modules in Streamlit to allow users to simulate the transmission of a key using qubits, visualize key-processing interactions after transmission, trace Quantum Bit Error Rate (QBER), and identify possible eavesdropping by assessing CHSH inequality after transmission. The system is also enhanced with other features like real time graphics dash boards, user authentication and a comparative module to analyse the classical and quantum cryptographic methodologies. An experimental simulation of the influence of channel noise and adversarial interference on QBER and the efficiency of key generation proves the resilience of quantum protocols in the face of eavesdropping attack. The platform is an educational and research resource, allowing users to learn about the concept of quantum physics, including superposition and entanglement, as well as visualize the process of secure key exchange, because of its intuitive interface and elaborate visualizations. The findings indicate that quantum cryptography has greater security potential, which supports the applicability of quantum cryptography in the post-quantum era in ensuring the security of communication.

title: A Blockchain-based Framework for Land Registration Ensuring Transparency, Tamper-Proof Records
authors: P Kalaiarasi, Penmetsa Sri Rishita Varma, Uppalapati Sanjay, Karumuru Lakshmi Sujan, Amilineni Tharun
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: In recent decades, blockchain technology has turned into a disruptive innovation that can tackle the inefficiencies posed by long-standing record-keeping systems across industries. One of the highly impactful applications relates to land registration and property management, which have been traditionally prone to issues like fraud, tampering, bureaucratic delays, and lack of transparency. So much so that traditional land registries are mostly based on centralized databases with an additional layer of paper-based records, making them all too easy to manipulate or corrupt. This research proposes a blockchain-based land- registration framework to ensure transparency, security, and tamper-proof ownership records. The system contains modules for buyers, sellers, and government agencies while implementing hashing algorithms, consensus protocols, and smart contracts to automate transactions and preserve data integrity. By eradicating intermediaries, the framework reduces costs and delays and enhances trust among the stakeholders. Unlike traditional systems, every transaction on the blockchain cannot be altered or tampered with and leaves an auditable trail of all ownership history. This model also includes administrative oversight to validate and monitor compliance, allowing technical robustness and legal acceptance. Furthermore, the system depicts worldwide accessibility and interoperability for securing verification of property details across jurisdictions. The framework offers e-governance in a scalable, efficient, and citizen-friendly manner, addressing fraud and double-selling. Overall, the system demonstrates that blockchain can transform land registration into a secure, transparent, and efficient establishment for managing lands.

title: An Adaptive dynamic R-tree indexing algorithm for HDI PCB layout
authors: Zhang Yang, Liang Xiaoyu, Ning Xu
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Integrated Circuits and Microsystems (ICICM)
abstract: The layout data intuitively conveys the fundamental spatial information of a PCB, and efficient querying of which is crucial for IC industrial manufacturing and EDA software algorithm development. In high-density interconnect (HDI) PCBs, traditional layout indexing algorithms suffer from low query efficiency due to massive data volumes, primarily caused by the large number of components and their compact spatial distribution. To address these challenges, this paper proposes an optimized approach to the classic R-tree algorithm. It adjusts the data storage capacity of nodes based on the scale of layout data adaptively and further optimizes the node splitting strategy using a heuristic splitting factor. This method reduces the overlap rate of spatial division, constructing an efficient indexing structure tailored for HDI PCBs. Experimental results show that compared with the traditional R -tree indexing algorithm, the proposed method achieves superior spatial index planning while ensuring query accuracy, with significantly improved indexing efficiency.

title: SSPNet: Semi-Supervised Prototypical Networks for Few-Shot Network Intrusion Detection
authors: Umid Suleymanov, Murat Kantarcioglu, Kevin S Chan, Michael De Lucia, Kevin Hamlen, Latifur Khan, Sharad Mehrotra, Ananthram Swami, Bhavani Thuraisingham
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: Network Intrusion Detection Systems (NIDS) play a crucial role in protecting digital infrastructures against evolving cyber threats. However, the increasing sophistication and frequency of novel attacks, combined with the limited access to labeled training data, pose significant challenges to traditional machine learning-based detection methods. To address these challenges, we propose a novel semi-supervised training schema to enhance Prototypical Networks for few-shot learning in NIDS. Our approach integrates a semi-supervised prototypical loss that leverages pseudo-labels from high-confidence samples, improving representation learning and model performance.We evaluate our method on benchmark network intrusion detection datasets, where we demonstrate its ability to generalize to novel attack classes with few labeled samples. Experimental results show that the proposed semi-supervised Prototypical Networks (SSPNet) outperforms standard Prototypical Networks and other competing models, particularly in scenarios where newly introduced target attack categories are highly dissimilar to source attacks: it performs 24% better on ACI-IoT-2023 Network Traffic Dataset and 15% better on CICIDS2017 than the standard Prototypical Networks. Our findings highlight the potential of semi-supervised few-shot learning in increasing the adaptability and reliability of NIDS in countering emerging cyber threats.

title: Hybrid Real-Time and MATLAB-Simulated Intelligent Auto-Surfacing System for Enhanced Diver Safety
authors: Sivabalan U, Sriram B, Priyanka B, Tamilselvan N
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: On this basis, there is a need for an autonomous and intelligent responding system to protect the divers in extreme underwater environments from physiological discomforts. And the existing manual diver communication and buoyancy systems are out of date if the person is unconscious from diving or there is not enough sensor data. This work presents a hybrid real-time + Matlab-simulated auto-surfacing system for biological data to mean constant observation and generation of optimum rescue rules quickly and effectively. A biological-sensor-coupled ESP32 controller of body temperature, heart rate, and SpO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf> constitutes the real prototype, and a virtual simulation model is established in MATLAB to simulate possible situations with impersonal acoustic underwater noise by altering signals of simulated underwater noise source fluctuation. The hybrid control logic incorporates both threshold and pattern-based algorithms to identify a diver in trouble, actuating an emergency ascent relay-driven inflator in 8–12 seconds. Ultimately, the comparison between simulation and hardware had a mean response time of 2.8 seconds, a false trigger rate less than 1.8%, and a detection accuracy of 97.2% within the framework with respect to the simulated replication scenario. Also, the real-time flexibility and signal strength of the integrated system design were verified through MATLAB visualization. Towards efficient and cheap future smart diving gadgets, this two-layer link is featuring a solid validation structure that connects the algorithmic simulation with hardware reality. The technology is highly suitable for defense and search operations at sea, maritime research missions, and offshore industrial safety automation.

title: Hybrid ResNet–BiLSTM Model for Dynamic Crack Detection and Structural Damage Prediction in Smart Structures
authors: S. Banupriya, Krithika S, Priyanga R, Erai Amudhan S, Naveenkumar E
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: Structural Damage Prediction has long placed a premium on crack detection due to the fact that cracks may drastically change material behaviour, weaken structures, and eventually cause catastrophic failures. Rapid escalation of even small cracks can cause catastrophic damage, loss of property, or even death. SDP overarching goal is to help with maintenance and decommissioning decisions by assessing a structure's status using sensor data. Each point in the material domain is categorised as damaged or undamaged in this work, which treats fracture detection and SDP as a semantic segmentation problem. In order to improve the clarity of the features, the preprocessing pipeline incorporates Thresholding, Greyscale Conversion, and Edge Detection. This Process present a new ResNet-BiLSTM model that utilises the robust spatial feature extraction of ResNet in conjunction with the bidirectional temporal modelling of BiLSTM to establish robust spatial-temporal correlations. The model grasps complicated data features efficiently using Crack Detection and Structural Damage Prediction. Evidence from experiments shows that the suggested model outperforms state-of-the-art approaches, reaching an impressive accuracy of 98.19 percent. These results demonstrate that the model is capable of reliably detecting fractures and foretelling structural damage. Proactive maintenance, enhanced safety, and prolonged service life of engineering structures are all made possible by the ResNet-BiLSTM framework's dependable and intelligent SDP solution.

title: Towards Sustainable Forecasting: Hybrid LSTM-CNN Model for Carbon Emission Prediction
authors: Shrikanth N G, Kutakole Gauri Mahadev, Pawade Alekha Pratap
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: Carbon emission forecasting is an essential domain of research in combating climate change and other ventures of promoting sustainable energy management. The traditional methods, which include ARIMA, SARIMA, and regression based have been extensively used but, in most cases, they are not able to capture the non- linear and temporal relationships of emission data. To overcome this gap, this paper will introduce a hybrid CNN-LSTM model that integrates the ability of feature extraction with Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs) and sequential learning capabilities of Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) networks. The CNN layers capture localized patterns in lifestyle and energy use whereas the LSTM layers are effective in capturing the long-term temporal patterns like seasonal changes and effects of the policy. The CNN-LSTM model has accuracy of 97.8% (R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> = 0.978) using a Kaggle based synthetic carbon footprint dataset outperforming Linear Regression, Random Forest, Gradient Boosting, SVR, and standalone MLP models in terms of MAE, RMSE, and R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>. Such results reveal CNN LSTM as a powerful and scalable carbon emission prediction framework, which provides useful information to make sustainable choices and policies.

title: Automated Cardiomegaly Detection using Deep Learning: A ResNet50-based Approach for Chest X-Ray Classification
authors: Jayapal Lande, Parul Nasra, Stuti Bhatt, Alankrita Joshi
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: Cardiomegaly is an abnormal enlargement of the heart, which is a prominent sign of most cardiovascular diseases. It is crucial that Cardiomegaly be identified early enough to allow early medical intervention, with its scope of avoiding the development of complications such as heart failure and arrhythmia. Traditional Cardiomegaly diagnosis from chest X-ray (CXR) images relies on manual assessment by radiologists, which is potential to be subjective and time-consuming. This paper introduces a deep learning method based on computer vision that utilizes the ResNet50 convolutional neural network (CNN) to distinguish Cardiomegaly and Normal with very high accuracy. The deep learning approach is trained to 20 iterations using the Adam optimizer and binary cross-entropy loss function and is found to achieve a 90.5% average classification accuracy. Performance measures such as precision, recall, F1-score, and confusion matrix exhibit high consistency in Cardiomegaly case recognition versus regular X-rays.

title: Transparent Loan Risk Assessment Through Machine and Deep Learning
authors: Poojari Suraksha, Poonam Nair, Khushi Shetty, Priya Bheemaraj Wadawadigi, Pushparani M K
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: The digitalization of the financial industry has resulted in a geometric increase in the need of smart and transparent credit risk evaluation systems. Conventional loan issuance systems tend to be based on inflexible statistical models, which are not easy to interpret and are not flexible to different applicant characteristics. We introduce a hybrid construct in this piece of work, which combines machine learning-based frameworks and deep learning algorithms to make loan risk assessment more transparent and more accurate. The suggested system takes advantage of supervised learning models in determining the risk categories based on features, and the deep-learning architectures exploit non-linear relationships among complex financial data. The framework is built using explainable artificial intelligence (XAI) modules in order to make the end-users interpret the result and thus overcome the black-box arguments that can be often linked to sophisticated predictive models. It has been experimentally proven that the system is more accurate, precise, and recalls than traditional methods and is also transparent and fair in terms of decision-making. The approach suggested provides a solution at scale to the banking ecosystems of the modern era that enables trust, efficiency, and responsible application of AI to financial services.

title: An FBAR Driven Fractional-N Ring PLL Using Harmonic-Mixer-Based Dual Feedback and Split-Feedback Frequency Division
authors: Qinglong Tian, Jiwei Huang, Hongqu Lin
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Integrated Circuits and Microsystems (ICICM)
abstract: This paper proposes a fractional-N dual-feedback phase-locked loop (DFPLL) architecture featuring a Class-Cdriven FBAR oscillator and harmonic mixer(HM)-based topology with nested phase-locked loops(nested PLL). The nested PLL serves as an anti-aliasing filter, enhancing the operating frequency of the delta-sigma modulator (DSM) and effectively suppressing quantization noise. The HM path, utilizing a low-noise, highfrequency FBAR reference, resolves stability issues inherent in the nested PLL structure and mitigates noise retro-injection to minimize reference noise gain. A ring-type VCO topology provides significant area reduction and enhanced robustness against electromagnetic interference. Designed in TSMC 65 nm CMOS technology with a 1.2 V supply voltage and occupying $0.394 \mathrm{~mm}^{2}$ layout area, when operating at 3.72 GHz output frequency, the circuit achieves 12.32 mW power dissipation with $-\mathbf{7 0. 4} d B c$ reference spurs and $\mathbf{3 5 5} f s$ integrated jitter.

title: Model-Agnostic Unsupervised Detection of Prompt Injection with Multiscale Perplexity Signatures
authors: Jielun Zhang, Fuhao Li
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: Prompt injection represents a critical and increasingly prevalent threat to the safety and reliability of large language models (LLMs). These attacks enable adversaries to override intended instructions using only natural language, often without access to model parameters or system internals. In this work, we propose a model-agnostic, unsupervised framework for prompt injection detection based on token-level uncertainty dynamics. Specifically, we introduce multi-scale perplexity signatures, i.e., structured representations of model perplexity computed across multiple sliding window sizes, to capture local and global fluctuations in predictive confidence. These signatures serve as input to lightweight statistical classifiers, such as OC-SVMs, which are trained exclusively on clean prompts to detect anomalous inputs. Extensive experiments are conducted on an open dataset, and the results demonstrate that the multiscale perplexity signatures captured by the proposed approach are effective in distinguishing injected prompts from clean ones across multiple detection models.

title: A 60-V 96.7%-Efficiency 175kHz Integrated Dimmable LED Driver with Mean-Peak Current Control and Frequency Jittering Scheme
authors: Jiamian Mao, Zhongguang Xu, Xiangyin Chen
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Integrated Circuits and Microsystems (ICICM)
abstract: This paper presents a mean-peak current control (MPCC) buck dimmable light-emitting diode (LED) driver for automotive headlamp lighting applications. The proposed MPCC scheme can provide precise inductor current regulation during dimming operations by employing an integrator to enhance the accuracy of the LED average current. To address electromagnetic interference (EMI) issues in LED driver operation, adoption of a frequency jitter oscillator reduces the EMI amplitude of critical signals. Under typical operating conditions, the system clock signal exhibits random frequency jittering within $\pm 5 \%$ of the 175 kHz center frequency. The adoption of a soft-start circuit prevents potential chip damage caused by inrush current during startup by gradually ramping up the integrator reference voltage to eliminate surge current. Implemented in a $0.35-\mu \mathrm{m}$ HV CMOS process, the proposed LED driver achieves 1% LED current error and 96.7% peak efficiency over an input voltage range of 6 to 60 V while driving 1 to 20 LEDs.

title: Detecting Presence Of Malicious Hub in MIMI Protocol for Cross-Platform Messaging Interoperability
authors: Harditya Sarvaiya, Eric W. Burger
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: The IETF More Instant Messaging Interoperability (MIMI) protocol enables interoperable group messaging across otherwise isolated services such as WhatsApp, Signal, and Telegram. It routes every Messaging Layer Security (MLS) ciphertext through a central hub that timestamps the message and broadcasts it to all group participants. If the hub is compromised, it can silently drop, delay, or reorder messages, undermining order integrity while leaving end-to-end encryption intact.We introduce a lightweight, Merkle-tree-based audit layer that allows clients to detect such misbehavior. Each client stores every received message together with its hub-assigned timestamp in an ordered list. Clients periodically generate a Merkle proof from this list and broadcast it by embedding the proof in an encrypted application message. Because the hub cannot predict which messages carry proofs, it cannot selectively discard them. Upon receiving a proof, other clients verify it and broadcast their own proofs. Any inconsistency is then propagated to the entire room, creating a non-repudiable record of hub misconduct.A Rust prototype built on OpenMLS was evaluated on a 100-node emulated network. With a client sampling rate of 5%, and a hub attack probability of 10%, the scheme detected 95% of message-drop or reordering attacks within the first 40 messages, consumed only 3kB of additional memory per client, and required less than 1ms of client-side processing per proof. The audit’s memory requirement grows linearly with room size and requires no changes to the hub protocol, providing a practical, low-overhead path to verifiable message-order integrity in large interoperable messaging systems.

title: Achieving Deterministic and Reliable Large-Scale Data Transfers in a Scientific Network
authors: Carolina Minami Oguchi, Vijeth Kumbarahally Lakshminarayana, Alex Sim, Kesheng Wu, Dipak Ghosal
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: Modern scientific workflows are data-intensive, geographically distributed, and time-sensitive, demanding reliable, low-latency data transfers across high-performance networks. While current solutions, such as ESnet’s OSCARS, offer static bandwidth reservation, they lack the fine-grained, deterministic guarantees essential for emerging real-time applications. To address this gap, we explore the applicability of Cyclic Queuing and Forwarding (CQF), a deterministic scheduling mechanism traditionally designed for Local Area Networks (LANs), to the unique challenges of Wide Area Networks (WANs). We propose a novel architecture that integrates CQF with multi-path routing to enhance reliability and evaluate it through a comparative simulation against OSCARS on a realistic ESnet topology, considering both time-triggered and event-triggered flows. Our results demonstrate that with proper parameter tuning, CQF can achieve a performance comparable to that of OSCARS in terms of latency, acceptance rate, and network utilization. As one of the first efforts to adapt CQF for WAN-scale scientific workflows, this study highlights its potential to enable deterministic communication for high-volume, long-distance scientific networks.

title: CrackNet: A CNN-based Framework for Automated Concrete Crack Detection
authors: Nagendar Yamsani, Arpanpreet Kaur, Manika Manwal, Gagan Bansal
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: Concrete is a key component in modern infrastructure used in dams, bridges, buildings, and roads since of its compressive strength and durability. Still, cracks in concrete constructions greatly affect safety and increase maintenance costs. Conventional visual inspections by engineers are labour-intensive, time-consuming, prone to human error, and demand exact, automated, effective method of cracking detection. This work uses TensorFlow Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs) to build an artificial intelligence-driven concrete structural cracking detection system. CNNs remove the need for handcrafted feature extraction required in traditional methods since they automatically extract spatial features from images. The work uses a 40,000 concrete surface photo collection under diverse environments in order to guarantee model durability. Among preprocessing techniques applied before training are normalising and resizing. Having been trained with the Adam optimiser and cross-entropy loss function, the CNN model consists of several fully linked layers, pooling layers, and convolutional layers. Evaluation of accuracy, precision, recall, and F1-score helps to confirm the model's capacity to distinguish between cracked and non-cracked surfaces. Accurate experimental findings show that the CNN-based model is reliable in case of automated fracture detection. Manual inspection is reduced, safety is supported, and maintenance expenses are decreased, which makes this AI-based solution enhance infrastructure monitoring. The further studies should dig into more advanced deep learning systems, expanding datasets, and real-time usage. Integrating artificial intelligence solutions will assist the building and civil engineering sectors to move towards proactive and innovative infrastructure maintenance solutions.

title: RadAround: A Field-Expedient Direction Finder for Contested IoT Sensing & EM Situational Awareness
authors: Owen Maute, Blake Roberts, Berker Peköz
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: This paper presents RadAround, a passive 2-D direction-finding system designed for adversarial IoT sensing in contested environments. Using mechanically steered narrowbeam antennas and field-deployable SCADA software, it generates high-resolution electromagnetic (EM) heatmaps using low-cost COTS or 3D-printed components. The microcontroller-deployable SCADA coordinates antenna positioning and SDR sampling in real time for resilient, on-site operation. Its modular design enables rapid adaptation for applications such as EMC testing in disaster-response deployments, battlefield spectrum monitoring, electronic intrusion detection, and tactical EM situational awareness (EMSA). Experiments show RadAround detecting computing machinery through walls, assessing utilization, and pinpointing EM interference (EMI) leakage sources from Faraday enclosures.

title: Double Deep Q-Learning Based UAV Base Station Positioning for Sum-Rate and Coverage Maximization
authors: Berke Kılınç, Alper Bereketli
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: Unmanned Aerial Vehicles (UAVs) have emerged as a promising solution to enhance wireless communication systems, especially in the context of dynamic and mobile mission-critical environments. In this paper, we propose a novel Double Deep Q-Learning (DDQN) based UAV Base Station Positioning (UBSP) approach to determine the three dimensional positions for multiple UAV base stations. The problem is framed as a reinforcement learning task, where the UAVs’ positions and flight trajectories are optimized through the exploitation of a dynamically changing hybrid reward function, which augments the impacts of UAV actions on sum-rate and coverage performance of ground units. Simulation results demonstrate that our proposed solution outperforms deep reinforcement learning based methods in terms of both sum-rate and user coverage. The results highlight the potential of DDQN-based UAV deployment strategies in next-generation wireless communication networks, offering a robust solution for dynamic and resource-constrained tactical communication environments.

title: Demonstration of mmWave Radar Passive Phantom Target Attack and Detection Using CNN
authors: Quy T. Le, James T. Jones, Drew Phelps, Emir Ekilic, Wesam Al Amiri, Terry N. Guo, Syed R. Hasan
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: Millimeter wave (mmWave) radar is widely used in both civilian and defense applications, especially in autonomous vehicles (AVs), due to its resilience in adverse weather and its capability to accurately estimate object range and velocity. However, the growing reliance on radar introduces security vulnerabilities, particularly spoofing attacks that can manipulate the perceived scene. This work investigates two passive spoofing scenarios: (1) using radar-absorbing material to conceal a target, and (2) using reflective material to create phantom/ghost objects, thereby altering the radar’s interpretation of its surroundings. Such manipulations can mislead AVs in perceiving their environment, potentially resulting in unsafe driving decisions or accidents. These attacks are both effective and easy to launch, becoming a potential threat to civilian and military applications. Range–Doppler data are collected from outdoor experiments under normal and spoofed conditions, including target-only, RF absorber, and reflector configurations. The collected data are used to train a convolutional neural network (CNN) based on the InceptionV3 architecture, pre-trained on ImageNet and fine-tuned using transfer learning to extract radar-specific features. The proposed model achieved a validation accuracy of 94.4% and an evaluation accuracy of 93%, demonstrating consistent performance across all classes. These results highlight the potential of vision-based deep learning to improve the robustness of mmWave radar sensing against passive spoofing attacks in AV applications.

title: Decentralized Blockchain-Integrated IoT Framework for Enhancing Cybersecurity and End-to-End Trust in Data Transmission
authors: Biru Rajak, Malik Bader Alazzam, B Karthikeyan, P N V Syamala Rao M, Jampani Satish Babu, R Saravanakumar
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: The scale of IoT and IIoT systems developing is growing rapidly since they deploy in critical infrastructure which also created major security issues such as data breaches, unauthorized access, and centralized model lack of trust issues. It is search of this study to formulate a block-chain-based IoT network that provides secure, trustful and corrupted-proof transmission of data. What is new in the approach is the combination of the use of machine learning-based real-time anomaly detection and the Ethereum-based smart contracts in the creation of a decentralized and intelligent security layer. In the offered framework, models XGBoost are trained using the Edge-IIoTset dataset with maximum accuracy of detection of 98%. Compared to traditional centralized and standalone ML-based solutions, the hybrid system is found to be much more efficient in both initial detection (precision), trust enforcement, and resilience. The findings ratify that the framework can be deployed in sensitive IoT/IIoT networks based not only on its ability to identify the source of cyber threats and curb them in real-time without necessitating any update, but also on its potential to increase the transparency and traceability of the network.

title: Hybrid Quantum-Classical Models and Optimization Techniques for Financial Fraud Detection
authors: K. Deepa, Raunak Singh, Kondapuram Tharun
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: Every day machine learning in financial systems is increasing with financial institutions taking every steps in their power to detect and block counterfeit transactions. Today, modern electronic payment instruments and financial facilities are becoming more and more susceptible to new methods of fraud which are unobtrusively reproducing the activities of legitimate interests to the detriment of the economy which is losing incalculable sums of money. In order to overcome this the combination technique of quantum and classical methods of calculating the data is a great way to enhance the reliability and accuracy of the fraud detection. It is applied by means of Quantum Support Vector Machine, Variational Quantum Classifier, the classical algorithms of Support Vector Machine and K-Nearest Neighbor with an ensemble based on Quadratic Unconstrained Binary Optimization. These algorithms are used together to scan a stream of transactions in real time and classify what is legitimate behaviour and what is unfavourable behaviour. The work provides evidence to prove that hybrid quantum-classical techniques can improve on the performance of classical systems using improved recall, less false negatives and the speed of detection of new types of frauds. It is shown that the integration of quantum intelligence based upon classical methods of analysis is a powerful and fruitful means to enhance levels of secure financial practice and help combat large scale financial frauds in modern digital environments.

title: A Wideband Input Buffer Based on AC-Coupled Flipped Source Follower Using Auxiliary Operational Amplifiers for 8-GS/s ADCs
authors: Yuhang Zhang, Jian Chen, Weiying Hu, Xianguo Kou, Changdong Guo, Haizhi Song
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Integrated Circuits and Microsystems (ICICM)
abstract: This work proposes an input buffer based on an AC-coupled flipped source follower (FSF) assisted by operational amplifiers. In the proposed structure, an operational amplifier is employed to track both the input signal and the output signal of the buffer. Additionally, gain-boosting technology is applied to the tail current source transistor to increase its output resistance, thereby improving linearity. The op-amp-assisted AC-coupled architecture enhances the linearity of the FSF, making it suitable for high-speed and high-resolution ADCs. The input buffer was simulated in a 28 nm mixed-signal CMOS process. Simulation results demonstrate that the buffer achieves a bandwidth exceeding 4 GHz. At a sampling rate of $8 \mathrm{GS} / \mathrm{s}$, with an input signal frequency of $\mathbf{3. 9 7 ~ G H z}$ at $\mathbf{- 1 ~ d B F S}$, the measured signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) and spurious-free dynamic range (SFDR) reach 69 dB and 73 dB, respectively. The power consumption of proposed input buffer is 224 mW.

title: Design and FPGA Implementation of a NTT Hardware Accelerator for PQC ML-DSA
authors: Shuhang Zhu, Liji Wu, Lei Li, Yifan Yang, Xiangmin Zhang
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Integrated Circuits and Microsystems (ICICM)
abstract: In this paper, we present a high - performance, resource - efficient hardware architecture for the 256-point Number Theoretic Transform (NTT) core tailored to the CRYSTALS-Dilithium post-quantum signature scheme. Our design introduces three key innovations: (1) a Barrett modular reduction unit that replaces conventional subtraction-based reduction with precomputed constants, achieving a 42% reduction in critical-path delay; (2) a dynamic, algorithmic address resolver that eliminates lookup tables and reduces LUT usage by $\mathbf{1 5. 2 \%}$; and (3) a quad-butterfly pipeline comprising four parallel configurable butterfly units that support both Cooley-Tukey and Gentleman-Sande modes, enabling a fourfold increase in per-cycle throughput. Implemented on FPGA with modulus $q=8,380,417$, the proposed NTT core consumes only $\mathbf{1, 0 3 3}$ slices ($\mathbf{3 9. 3 \%}$ fewer) and 3,189 LUTs (44.1% fewer) compared to state-of-the-art designs, at a modest cost of 28 DSPs and 8 BRAMs. Functional simulation over 512 test points confirms 100% correctness ($\mathbf{R}^{\mathbf{2}}=\mathbf{1. 0}$) across the full coefficient range. The architecture thus offers an attractive balance between throughput, resource utilization, and implementation simplicity, providing a practical foundation for lattice-based cryptosystems on resource constrained platforms.

title: A Wide-Range PFD and Low-Mismatch Source-Switched CP for MEMS Clock Systems
authors: Changfu Wei, Lu Tang, Ziyao Xiong
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Integrated Circuits and Microsystems (ICICM)
abstract: This paper presents a TSPC-based phase-frequency detector and source-switched charge pump for fractional-N CPPLLs in temperature-compensated MEMS clock systems. The proposed PFD eliminates dead zones while achieving $-1.95 \pi$ to $+1.95 \pi$ detection range through adjusting the device dimensions of the TSPC structure. The designed CP incorporates rail-to-rail clamping amplifiers and a fast turn-off path on the source-switched topology, achieving a current mismatch below 0.04% in the range of $0.4 \mathrm{~V} \sim 1.6 \mathrm{~V}$. Additionally, the PFD and CP demonstrate superior current noise performance, enabling the fractional-N PLL system to achieve -65.5 dBc reference spurs at a division ratio of 22.5 in simulations.

title: Keeping a Target "On the Radar", Using Model-Based Group Sensor Selection Algorithms
authors: Kaan Buyukkalayci, Xinlin Li, Merve Karakas, Tamoghna Sarkar, Christina Fragouli, Bhaskar Krishnamachari
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: We consider the problem of using low-cost sensor measurements to recommend a set of sensors, from which higher cost sensing would be most beneficial for target tracking. In particular, we consider a large-scale environment where sensing assets are deployed. Our objective is to determine, using low-cost, noisy measurements, which group of sensors is closest to a target. That is, our goal is to simply keep the target "on the radar": unlike traditional tracking algorithms that attempt to find the exact vehicle location, our aim is not to do so, but instead, identify a set of sensors, that would be most likely if prompted for higher quality (and cost) measurements to achieve an exact localization. To accomplish this task, we leverage a Bayesian inference algorithm that explicitly learns and integrates probabilistic observation models, both parametric and nonparametric, using offline training data. We evaluate our approach using experimental data collected from tracking ATV-type vehicles using acoustic sensors of Raspberry Pi nodes, and illustrate trade-offs between accuracy, number of measurements and size of the recommended sensor set.

title: A Timing Interleaving RX Scheme with direct Multiplexing Sampler based on dual reference for DDR interface
authors: Mia Xu, Chris Eom, Kenji Wen, Tinna Ding, Bosco Lai
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Integrated Circuits and Microsystems (ICICM)
abstract: A timing-interleaving RX scheme with a direct multiplexing sampler based on a dual reference is presented. To address the challenges associated with the current string problem, which leads to significant DFE coefficient variation due to voltage and temperature (VT) changes, a dual reference scheme has been implemented. However, this approach results in a circuit complexity that is more than twice that of the original design. To mitigate this issue, we propose the adoption of a Timing-Interleaving DFE (TID) summer and a direct multiplexing sampler. This method effectively reduces the circuit complexity to less than half of that required by the conventional loop-unrolled DFE design. Compared to the traditional current string scheme, the proposed design achieves a 90% reduction in DFE coefficient variation and improves the DFE feedback time by 0.12 UI at 7200Mbps

title: AI-Driven Autonomous Surveillance System for Real-Time Identification and Recovery of Missing Persons: A Systematic Review
authors: Kalai Selvi T, Santhakumar M, Samyuktha S, Pradeep K
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: The persistent global issue of missing persons poses significant challenges to law enforcement and communities, often exacerbated by delays in traditional search methods that rely on manual efforts and incomplete data integration. This expanded systematic review delves into AI-driven surveillance systems that harness real-time CCTV footage for the efficient detection and recovery of missing individuals. These systems typically feature dedicated databases storing images of missing persons, employing continuous facial analysis in video streams to facilitate immediate matches. Upon detection, automated alerts—via SMS, email, or integrated apps—are dispatched to authorities, complete with matched images, precise locations, and timestamps. Leveraging core technologies such as Python for scripting, OpenCV for computer vision tasks, advanced deep learning models like CNNs and YOLOv8 for recognition, web frameworks including Flask and Django for user interfaces, and APIs like Twilio or SMTP for communications, this review comprehensively examines system architectures, methodological approaches, performance evaluations, and sustainable deployment strategies optimized for hardware like Raspberry Pi or standard computing setups. By synthesizing insights from an extended set of studies spanning 2020–2025, we illuminate key advancements in achieving high-accuracy real-time identification and alert dissemination, while critically assessing gaps in areas such as model explainability, data robustness against environmental variations, ethical considerations including privacy and bias, and scalability for large-scale implementations. Furthermore, we propose an enhanced conceptual framework that integrates explainable AI (XAI), multi-modal analysis, and ethical safeguards to foster more intelligent, interpretable, and environmentally sustainable surveillance solutions, ultimately aiming to improve recovery outcomes and support humanitarian efforts.

title: Ma’at: FPGA-Assisted Dual-Core Architecture for Deterministic IoT Telemetry Integrity
authors: Mohamed El-Hadedy, Wen-Mei Hwu, Benny Cheng
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: Mission-critical IoT nodes must protect every telemetry record without blowing tight power and latency budgets, even under I/O and memory stress. We present Ma'at, a dual-core design on Zynq-7000 (PYNQ-Z1) that separates GPS ingest (Core-0) from hashing (Core-1) and adds two small FPGA blocks: an in-line NMEA 0183 checksum + timestamp guard and an Ascon-Hash accelerator reached via simple-mode AXI-DMA.On live GPS, Ma'at sustains about 1.0–1.1 hashes/s in software and 1.48 hashes/s with programmable-logic offload; the accelerator alone reaches 169.9 hashes/s in self-test. Offloading cuts Core-0 load from over 70% to under 60%, trims the long-tail GPS-to-tag delay by roughly one-fifth, and keeps any slowdown under background I/O within 20%. The guard enforces a fixed 2 s replay window in hardware. Energy per hash drops from more than 1 J in software to about 9 mJ in self-test.These results show that modest FPGA help—checksum, timestamp, DMA, and hash—hardens IoT telemetry today while preserving a direct path to authenticated encryption with Ascon.

title: Cross-Process Bayesian Multi-Objective Collaborative Optimization For Process Migration
authors: Zixi Guo, Ruiyu Lyu, Zhaori Bi, Changhao Yan, Ming Zhu, Xiulong Wu, Xuan Zeng
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Integrated Circuits and Microsystems (ICICM)
abstract: This paper introduces a cross-process Bayesian multi-objective collaborative optimization framework to address challenges in semiconductor technology migration. We leverage transfer learning within multi-objective Bayesian optimization through Gaussian copula, transforming simulation data into residual observations. By transferring prior knowledge from implemented technologies to advanced processes, we significantly reduce the number of required circuit simulations in newer technologies, effectively optimizing the parameter design space for next-generation processes. Furthermore, we establish Gaussian process regression models that correlate design variables with performance metrics across both advanced and implemented technologies. These models undergo continuous updates during iteration, enabling collaborative optimization throughout the technology migration engineering process.

title: Automated Cervical Cell Classification using InceptionV3: A Deep Learning Approach on Pap Smear Images
authors: Jayapal Lande, Parul Nasra, Stuti Bhatt, Alankrita Joshi
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: Cervical cancer is still a leading reason for death by cancer in women globally which is why catching it early is key to saving more lives. Conventional screening which still involves manual Pap Smear tests, takes a lot of effort, is hard to interpret and may cause errors because of variations in how each observer studies the sample. Researchers here use InceptionV3, a famous deep learning model, to build an automated system for classifying cervical cells. To use image data from Herlev Pap Smear, the model is fine-tuned by using pretrained weights learned on ImageNet and the images in the dataset are divided into the seven diagnostic categories: normal squamous, intermediate squamous, columnar epithelial, mild dysplasia, moderate dysplasia, severe dysplasia and carcinoma in situ. For better generalization and overfitting mitigation, techniques such as image size adjustment, scaling and a lot of extra data are employed. According to experiments, the system reaches an accuracy of 97% and precision, recall and F1-scores remain even throughout all the categories. Checking training and validation curves shows that the model trains accurately and the confusion matrix demonstrates that it can clearly tell apart different classes, even for cells that look alike. According to the suggested system, it will be easier to use automated methods for cervical cancer screening and early treatment, because the system offers a scalable, precise and effective way to diagnose.

title: An Enhanced Deep Learning Framework for Effective Arrhythmia Classification via the Electrocardiogram Signal
authors: Vinoth Murugan, Damodar Panigrahy, D Dinesh Kumar, Muthukumar T, A. Senthilkumar, Elamurugan P
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: Heart disease is a major cause of the increasing death rate around the globe. The electrocardiogram (ECG) is used to provide information about various heart diseases. This study presents the classification of heart disease, such as arrhythmias, using a novel framework that is based on robust empirical mode decomposition (REMD) with a deep convolutional neural network (CNN) + bidirectional long short-term memory (BiLSTM) + convolutional block attention module (CBAM). The low-frequency drift is contaminated with the raw ECG signal due to the patient’s movements and improper electrode selection. The REMD technique is used to eliminate low-frequency drift. Deep CNN is used to identify the spatial features, and BiLSTM captures the temporal information present in the preprocessed ECG signal. The CBAM layer focuses on the most important features through channel and spatial attention. The developed framework is assessed using the MIT-BIH arrhythmia database. The developed framework achieves an accuracy of 99.28% and an F1 score of 99.27% compared to existing techniques. The developed framework is suitable for automatic classification of arrhythmia in clinical practice.

title: Parameter Estimation of a Dissipative Quantum Channel
authors: Austin Bristow, Kwang-Cheng Chen
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: Error mitigation in a quantum channel is essential in quantum communication, remote sensing, and noisy intermediate-scale quantum computing systems. In addition to well-known quantum error correction codes, appropriate quantum signal processing suggests an effective alternative to accomplish the same purpose, while quantum channel estimation plays a critical role. After earlier explorations regarding the phase estimation of a quantum channel, in this paper, we investigate a more challenging estimation problem for a dissipative quantum channel, given the constraints in quantum measurements and the lack of quantum memory. By decomposing a quantum channel into a unitary operation and a dissipative mechanism, parameter estimation of a general quantum channel can be effectively completed in two-step sequential realization, which has been successfully verified by simulations.

title: Constant False Alarm Rate Detection in the Battlegrounds of the Future
authors: Anna Grabek, Harris Zebrowitz, Rick Howard
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: Constant False Alarm Rate (CFAR) algorithms are critical to the warfighter as they ensure detection radars maintain consistent false alarm rates amidst dynamic backgrounds with noise, clutter, and interference. However, there is growing evidence that emergent advanced wireless communications technologies, such as 4G and 5G, generate interference that violates the Gaussian assumption on which many CFAR algorithms rely. This paper presents a study of the effects of such non-Gaussian interference on CFAR algorithms, with a focus on the widely used Cell-Averaging CFAR (CA-CFAR). Through Monte Carlo simulations, we demonstrate that non-Gaussian interference can cause significant variability in false alarm rates, potentially undermining the ability of the modern warfighter to maintain operational superiority. To address these challenges, we evaluate Order Statistics CFAR (OS-CFAR) as a mitigation technique, finding that it can maintain CFAR in non-Gaussian environments at the expense of detection performance. We also discuss several considerations for optimizing the stability and detection performance of OS-CFAR detectors operating in complex and dynamic environments. By advancing our understanding of CFAR algorithms in non-Gaussian environments, this work provides actionable insights for the warfighter to maintain operational superiority in the dynamic battlegrounds of the future.

title: Efficacious Lung Cancer Detection Utilising Hybrid Deep Learning and Sophisticated Image Processing
authors: P Manikanta Simgamsetti, T Tirupal
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: Lung cancer remains a leading cause of cancer-related mortality worldwide, underscoring the critical need for accurate and early detection methods. This study presents an innovative technique for lung cancer diagnostics that integrates hybrid deep learning algorithms with advanced image processing methods. The proposed methodology includes a thorough pipeline that begins with data collection and preprocessing, proceeds with noise reduction via filtering, segmentation through advanced clustering algorithms, feature extraction and selection, and concludes with classification utilising a hybrid deep learning model. Some important contributions are the creation of a complete preprocessing and filtering framework that enhances picture quality, the use of hybrid K-means and Fuzzy C-means clustering for precise segmentation, and the extraction of radiomic characteristics to pinpoint important patterns. We present a new hybrid classification model that uses 10-fold cross-validation to improve detection accuracy. This model combines Crow Search, Locust Assist, Boolean Grey Wolf, and Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs). The findings indicate a significant improvement in detection precision and dependability relative to current techniques. The suggested hybrid method demonstrates enhanced performance, underscoring its applicability in lung cancer diagnostics. This discovery improves lung cancer detection and lays the groundwork for future investigations involving hybrid deep learning as well as image processing techniques.

title: A Neuron-and-Synapse Unit Circuit with Information Propagation Function for Spiking Neural Networks
authors: Yide Zhang, Zixuan Ling, Zicheng Yin, Xu Liu
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Integrated Circuits and Microsystems (ICICM)
abstract: This paper presents a CMOS Neuron-and-Synapse Unit (NSU) Circuit Design for Spiking Neural Network. Compared to the conventional NSU for SNN, this circuit have wide frequency response, which can be more adaptive to dynamic environments. The proposed NSU includes an LIF neuron circuit, an STDP synapse circuit for biologically inspired learning. For the STDP scheme designed in this work, the adaptive time window can be adjusted based on input spike frequency. Moreover, a multi-neuron synapse propagation model is designed in $\mathbf{1 8 0 - n m}$ CMOS process, and simulated in Cadence. The Simulation results of a two-layer six-neuron network validate the function of the NSU, with information propagation and learning capabilities. This demonstrates its potential for efficient signal processing for SNNs.

title: Hafnium-Based Ferroelectric Diode with Interlayer Enhancement for In-Memory Logic Application
authors: Shuo Han, Chuanzhi Liu, Qimiao Zeng, Yefan Zhang, Wei Wang, Rongrong Cao
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Integrated Circuits and Microsystems (ICICM)
abstract: Logic-in-Memory computing (LiM) has emerged as a key approach to overcome the von Neumann bottleneck, and hafnium-based ferroelectric diode (Fe diode) is a promising candidate for this application. For further performance optimization, we fabricated Fe diode devices with two strcutures: $\mathrm{TiN} / \mathrm{HZO} / \mathrm{TiN}$ and interlayer-enhanced $\mathrm{TiN} / \mathrm{HZO} / \mathrm{HfO}_{2} / \mathrm{TiN}$. The HfO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf> interlayer devices exhibit improved retention characteristics while maintaining bidirectional rectification behavior and a well-defined logic window, enabling stable logic operations. We demonstrated a circuit scheme of implementing both IMP and NIMP logic functions in a single operation with an ultra-low operating power consumption of 20.65 aJ. Additionally, by configuring different device combinations, all 16 Boolean logic functions can be realized based on Fe diodes. This work highlights the potential of interlayer-enhanced Fe diodes, offering a simple, easy-to-integrate, and low power consumption approach for developing high-performance LiM systems.

title: Practical Considerations for Failure Resilient ML Systems at the Edge
authors: Krishna Praneet Gudipaty, Walid A. Hanafy, Li Wu, Jeffrey Twigg, Benjamin M. Marlin, Jesse Milzman, Suhas Diggavi, Tarek Abdelzaher, Prashant Shenoy
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: Machine learning at the edge is increasingly embedded in our daily lives, supporting applications running on smartphones, wearables, and industrial IoT. Prior work has mainly focused on resource efficiency and latency optimization through innovations in compact model design and resource-management techniques to meet stringent performance targets. However, edge devices and networks are inherently subject to failures and performance fluctuations, requiring an emphasis on failure resilience, especially in resource-constrained edge environments. Although recent studies have proposed resource-aware mechanisms and failure-aware models to improve the resilience of machine learning systems at the edge, many overlook deployment overheads that impede the adoption of these approaches. In this paper, we highlight practical considerations that affect failure-detection and recovery times and analyze how these considerations shape system design. We outline future research directions to enable practical, failure-resilient machine-learning systems at the edge.

title: Multi-Interval Scheduling for Hybrid Time-Triggered and Event-Triggered Flows Transmission in Industrial Wireless Networks
authors: Jiangwei Xu, Shi-Ning Li, Qin Wen, Linjie Xiao, Wanbao Wang, Yuan Ji
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conferences on Internet of Things (iThings) IEEE Green Computing &amp; Communications (GreenCom) IEEE Cyber, Physical &amp; Social Computing (CPSCom) and IEEE Smart Data (SmartData) and IEEE Congress on Cybermatics (Cybermatics)
abstract: Industrial wireless networks (IWNs) have emerged as a key technology for interconnecting industrial equipment due to their deployment flexibility and cost-effectiveness. Ensuring real-time transmission of heterogeneous data flows in IWNs is both critical and challenging. This paper addresses the hybrid transmission problem of time-triggered (TT) and event-triggered (ET) flows. The conventional periodic-compact scheduling (PCS) allocates TT flow in a back-to-back manner, without fully accounting for the deadline requirement of ET flow. In this paper, we propose a multi-interval scheduling (MIS) scheme designed to distribute TT flow uniformly within hyper-period, thereby reducing excessive waiting time of ET flow. Furthermore, we theoretically derive and analyze the expected waiting time for ET flow under both scheduling schemes. Finally, through extensive experiments, we analyze the impact of factors including the number of TT flows and idle interval length on schedulability and waiting time.

title: Privacy-Preserving Authentication for Secure Military 5G Networks
authors: Isabella D. Lutz, Ava Hill, Matthew C. Valenti
publish: MILCOM 2025 - 2025 IEEE Military Communications Conference (MILCOM)
abstract: As 5G networks gain traction in defense applications, ensuring the privacy and integrity of the Authentication and Key Agreement (AKA) protocol is critical. While 5G AKA improves upon previous generations by concealing subscriber identities, it remains vulnerable to replay-based synchronization and linkability threats under realistic adversary models. This paper provides a unified analysis of the standardized 5G AKA flow, identifying several vulnerabilities and highlighting how each exploits protocol behavior to compromise user privacy. To address these risks, we present five lightweight mitigation strategies. We demonstrate through prototype implementation and testing that these enhancements strengthen resilience against linkability attacks with minimal computational and signaling overhead. Among the solutions studied, those introducing a UE-generated nonce emerge as the most promising, effectively neutralizing the identified tracking and correlation attacks with negligible additional overhead. Integrating this extension as an optional feature to the standard 5G AKA protocol offers a backward-compatible, low-overhead path toward a more privacy-preserving authentication framework for both commercial and military 5G deployments.

title: Easiway: A Gradient Boosting–Driven Predictive Framework for Intelligent and Sustainable Bus Transit Systems
authors: Busi Ramesh Babu, Chintha Yaswanth Sai Ram, Chinthala Manoj, Ganganapalli Venkatesh, Gamcheeri Tagore Chandra, Cheedepudi Mohitha
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on IoT Based Control Networks and Intelligent Systems (ICICNIS)
abstract: Accurate arrival time estimation and demand aware vehicle allocation are foundational for a dependable public transit experience. This paper presents Easiway, an end-to-end learning-based framework for stop level ETA prediction and near-term demand estimation aimed at for campus and urban bus fleets. The design is intentionally software first: models are trained on historical GPS traces and route metadata, while the architecture supports later integration with IoT telemetry (GNSS trackers, OBD-II, passenger counters). We evaluate Linear Regression, Support Vector Regression, Random Forest, and Gradient Boosting on a realistic synthesized dataset. Gradient Boosting (our proposed model) attains the best performance (MAPE 6.7%, RMSE 1.92 minutes, R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> = 0.95), demonstrates resilience against missing telemetry, and provides a practical path for field pilots. The manuscript follows the exact structure of the provided reference-style conference paper: problem identification, literature survey, proposed methodology, algorithmic details, results, and deployment considerations.

title: TEDR-YNet: A Dual-Encoder Retinal Multi-Lesion Segmentation Network
authors: Jie Qi, Pei Wang, Wei Chen
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: Multi-lesion segmentation in diabetic retinopathy faces numerous challenges, including complex fundus structures, small inter-class differences between lesions, blurred lesion boundaries, and class imbalance. To address these challenges, this paper proposes TEDR-YNet, an innovative Y-shaped dual-encoder network for the segmentation of diabetic retinopathy lesions. This network utilizes a dual-encoder architecture to capture features from different representations, significantly enhancing the model’s expressive capability. In the bottleneck layer, a meticulously designed lesion-aware enhancement module is introduced to improve multi-scale lesion perception and boundary segmentation accuracy.Askip connection mechanism with gated convolution is innovatively incorporated to strengthen the model’s focus on lesion regions. An edge enhancement module is further employed to optimize boundary segmentation performance, and a hybrid loss function is designed to effectively mitigate the class imbalance problem. Extensive experiments conducted on three public datasets IDRID, DDR, and TJDR demonstrate the superior performance of TEDR-YNet, achieving average Dice coefficients of 68.61%, 58.51%, and 58.14%, respectively. These results represent improvements of 11.47%, 7.15%, and 9.8% over the baseline UNet model. Additionally, the mIOU metrics on the three datasets reached 53.24%, 46.84%, and 44.43%, respectively. These findings robustly demonstrate the precision and robustness of TEDR-YNet in multi-lesion segmentation for diabetic retinopathy, offering strong technical support for clinical diagnostic assistance.

title: A DeepSHAP-based Adversarial Attack on Machine Learning-Based Network Intrusion Detection
authors: Byung Chang Chung, Gyu-Bum Han
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: We propose an adversarial attack for machine-learning-based network intrusion detection systems that selectively alters only the most influential features. Unlike conventional attacks such as the Fast Gradient Sign Method (FGSM) and multi-step Projected Gradient Descent (PGD), which can perturb all feature dimensions, our DeepSHAP-guided masked-PGD approach focuses its updates on a small set of highly influential features while still achieving competitive success rates on the X-IIoTID dataset. Experimental results indicate that it yields lower autoencoder-based reconstruction error and uses much sparser perturbations, making its adversarial examples harder to detect. By systematically varying the perturbation budget and the number of targeted features, we show the trade-off between stealth and effectiveness. These findings demonstrate the difficulty of detecting adversarial examples guided by feature importance.

title: Variational Depth Estimation for Endoscopic Images: A Lightweight Unsupervised Learning Approach
authors: Rehman Abdul, Abdul Majeed, Seong Oun Hwang
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: Monocular depth estimation plays a critical role in minimally invasive surgery (MIS) by enabling 3D scene understanding using a single endoscopic image, supporting compact design and lower system costs. However, existing unsupervised monocular depth estimation (UMDE) methods struggle with photometric inconsistencies and lack robustness in complex endoscopic environments due to the absence of ground truth depth data. In this work, we propose an efficient UMDE framework tailored for endoscopic imaging, featuring an optimized MobileNetV2-based encoder integrated with a First-order Variation Layer (V-layer) to enhance texture and edge representation. Additionally, we incorporate structural pruning to compress the model, reducing its parameters from 5M to 1.25M (4.35× compression), while preserving accuracy. Experimental results demonstrate that our method reduces Absolute Relative (Abs Rel) loss by 27.6% compared to the baseline, enabling accurate and lightweight depth estimation suitable for real-time 3D reconstruction in minimally invasive surgery, as demonstrated on the SCARED dataset.
